[MANSFIELD PARK]130-mansfield ( 1814 ) By [Jane Austen]99-jane austen Contents CHAPTER [I]0-i CHAPTER II CHAPTER III CHAPTER IV CHAPTER V CHAPTER VI CHAPTER VII CHAPTER VIII CHAPTER IX CHAPTER X CHAPTER XI CHAPTER XII CHAPTER XIII CHAPTER XIV CHAPTER XV CHAPTER XVI CHAPTER XVII CHAPTER XVIII CHAPTER [XIX CHAPTER XX CHAPTER XXI CHAPTER XXII CHAPTER XXIII CHAPTER XXIV CHAPTER XXV CHAPTER XXVI]307-xix chapter xx chapter xxi chapter xxii chapter xxiii chapter xxiv chapter xxv chapter xxvi CHAPTER XXVII CHAPTER XXVIII CHAPTER XXIX CHAPTER XXX CHAPTER XXXI CHAPTER XXXII CHAPTER XXXIII CHAPTER XXXIV CHAPTER XXXV CHAPTER XXXVI CHAPTER XXXVII CHAPTER XXXVIII CHAPTER XXXIX CHAPTER XL CHAPTER XLI CHAPTER XLII CHAPTER XLIII CHAPTER XLIV CHAPTER XLV CHAPTER XLVI CHAPTER XLVII CHAPTER XLVIII CHAPTER [I]0-i About thirty years ago [Miss Maria Ward]100-maria , of [Huntingdon]2-huntingdon , with only seven thousand pounds , had the good luck to captivate [Sir Thomas Bertram]101-sir thomas , of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , in [the county of Northampton]308-the county of northampton , and to be thereby raised to the rank of [[a baronet]309-a baronet ’s lady]310-a baronet ’s lady , with all the comforts and consequences of [an handsome house]311-an handsome house and large income . [All Huntingdon]2-huntingdon exclaimed on the greatness of the match , and [[her]100-maria uncle]312-her uncle , [the lawyer]313-the lawyer , [himself]313-the lawyer , allowed [her]100-maria to be at least three thousand pounds short of any equitable claim to it . [She]100-maria had [two sisters]314-two sisters to be benefited by [her]100-maria elevation ; and such of [their]314-two sisters acquaintance as thought [Miss Ward]100-maria and [Miss Frances]103-fanny quite as handsome as [Miss Maria]100-maria , did not scruple to predict [their]314-two sisters marrying with almost equal advantage . But there certainly are not so many men of large fortune in [the world]315-the world as there are [pretty women]316-pretty women to deserve [them]314-two sisters . [Miss Ward]100-maria , at the end of half a dozen years , found [herself]100-maria obliged to be attached to [the Rev. Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris , [a friend of [[her]100-maria brother - in - law]318-her brother - in - law]317-a friend of her brother - in - law , with scarcely any private fortune , and [Miss Frances]103-fanny fared yet worse . [Miss Ward]100-maria ’s match , indeed , when it came to the point , was not contemptible : [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas being happily able to give [[his]101-sir thomas friend]319-his friend an income in the living of [Mansfield]3-mansfield ; and [Mr.]320-mr. and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris began [their]314-two sisters career of [conjugal felicity]321-conjugal felicity with very little less than a thousand a year . But [Miss Frances]103-fanny married , in the common phrase , to disoblige [[her]103-fanny family]322-her family , and by fixing on [a lieutenant of marines]323-a lieutenant of marines , without education , fortune , or connexions , did it very thoroughly . [She]103-fanny could hardly have made a more untoward choice . [Sir Thomas Bertram]101-sir thomas had interest , which , from principle as well as pride — from a general wish of doing right , and a desire of seeing all that were connected with [him]101-sir thomas in situations of respectability , [he]101-sir thomas would have been glad to exert for the advantage of [[Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s sister]324-lady bertram ’s sister ; but [[her]106-lady bertram husband]325-her husband ’s profession was such as no interest could reach ; and before [he]101-sir thomas had time to devise any other method of assisting [them]326-them , an absolute breach between [the sisters]327-the sisters had taken place . It was the natural result of the conduct of [each party]328-each party , and such as a very imprudent marriage almost always produces . To save [herself]106-lady bertram from useless remonstrance , [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price never wrote to [[her]106-lady bertram family]322-her family on the subject till actually married . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , who was [a woman of very tranquil feelings , and a temper remarkably easy and indolent]330-a woman of very tranquil feelings , and a temper remarkably easy and indolent , would have contented [herself]106-lady bertram with merely giving up [[her]106-lady bertram sister]331-her sister , and thinking no more of the matter ; but [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had a spirit of activity , which could not be satisfied till [she]105-mrs. norris had written a long and angry letter to [Fanny]103-fanny , to point out the folly of [her]106-lady bertram conduct , and threaten [her]106-lady bertram with all its possible ill consequences . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price , in [her]107-mrs. price turn , was injured and angry ; and an answer , which comprehended [each sister]332-each sister in its bitterness , and bestowed such very disrespectful reflections on the pride of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could not possibly keep to [herself]105-mrs. norris , put an end to all intercourse between [them]333-their for a considerable period . [[Their]333-their homes]334-their homes were so distant , and the circles in which [they]333-their moved so distinct , as almost to preclude the means of ever hearing of each other ’s existence during the eleven following years , or , at least , to make it very wonderful to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas that [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris should ever have it in [her]105-mrs. norris power to tell [them]333-their , as [she]105-mrs. norris now and then did , in an angry voice , that [Fanny]103-fanny had got [another child]335-another child . By the end of eleven years , however , [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price could no longer afford to cherish pride or resentment , or to lose one connexion that might possibly assist [her]107-mrs. price . [A large and still increasing family]336-a large and still increasing family , [an husband disabled for active service , but not the less equal to company and good liquor]337-an husband disabled for active service , but not the less equal to company and good liquor , and a very small income to supply [their]333-their wants , made [her]107-mrs. price eager to regain [the friends [she]107-mrs. price had so carelessly sacrificed]338-the friends she had so carelessly sacrificed ; and [she]107-mrs. price addressed [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram in a letter which spoke so much contrition and despondence , such a superfluity of [children]339-children , and such a want of almost everything else , as could not but dispose [them]339-children all to a reconciliation . [She]107-mrs. price was preparing for [her]107-mrs. price ninth lying - in ; and after bewailing the circumstance , and imploring [their]333-their countenance as sponsors to [the expected child]340-the expected child , [she]107-mrs. price could not conceal how important [she]107-mrs. price felt [they]333-their might be to the future maintenance of the eight already in being . [[Her]107-mrs. price eldest]341-her eldest was [a boy of ten years old]342-a boy of ten years old , [a fine spirited fellow]343-a fine spirited fellow , who longed to be out in [the world]315-the world ; but what could [she]107-mrs. price do ? Was there any chance of [his]342-a boy of ten years old being hereafter useful to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas in the concerns of [[his]101-sir thomas West Indian property]345-his west indian property ? No situation would be beneath [him]342-a boy of ten years old ; or what did [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas think of [Woolwich]4-woolwich ? or how could [a boy]346-a boy be sent out to [the East]5-the east ? The letter was not unproductive . It re - established peace and kindness . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas sent friendly advice and professions , [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram dispatched money and baby - linen , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris wrote the letters . Such were its immediate effects , and within a twelvemonth a more important advantage to [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price resulted from it . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was often observing to [the others]347-the others that [she]105-mrs. norris could not get [[her]105-mrs. norris poor sister]348-her poor sister and [[her]105-mrs. norris family]322-her family out of [her]105-mrs. norris head , and that , much as [they]347-the others had all done for [her]105-mrs. norris , [she]105-mrs. norris seemed to be wanting to do more ; and at length [she]105-mrs. norris could not but own it to be [her]105-mrs. norris wish that poor [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price should be relieved from the charge and expense of [one child]350-one child entirely out of [her]107-mrs. price great number . “ What if [they]347-the others were among [them]347-the others to undertake the care of [[her]107-mrs. price eldest daughter]3652-her eldest daughter , [a girl now nine years old , of an age]3653-a girl now nine years old , of an age to require more attention than [[her]3652-her eldest daughter poor mother]3654-her poor mother could possibly give ? The trouble and expense of it to [them]347-the others would be nothing , compared with the benevolence of the action . ”[106-lady bertram] [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram agreed with [her]106-lady bertram instantly . “ [I]106-lady bertram think [we]3655-we can not do better , ”[106-lady bertram] said [she]106-lady bertram ; “ let [us]3655-we send for [the child]3656-the child . ”[106-lady bertram] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could not give so instantaneous and unqualified a consent . [He]101-sir thomas debated and hesitated;—it was a serious [charge;—a girl so brought up]351-charge;—a girl so brought up must be adequately provided for , or there would be cruelty instead of kindness in taking [her]351-charge;—a girl so brought up from [[her]351-charge;—a girl so brought up family]322-her family . [He]101-sir thomas thought of [[his]101-sir thomas own four children]353-his own four children , of [[his]101-sir thomas two sons]354-his two sons , of [cousins]355-cousins in love , etc.;—but no sooner had [he]101-sir thomas deliberately begun to state [his]101-sir thomas objections , than [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris interrupted [him]101-sir thomas with a reply to [them]356-them all , whether stated or not . “ [[My]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [I]105-mrs. norris perfectly comprehend [you]101-sir thomas , and do justice to the generosity and delicacy of [your]101-sir thomas notions , which indeed are quite of a piece with [your]101-sir thomas general conduct ; and [I]105-mrs. norris entirely agree with [you]101-sir thomas in the main as to the propriety of doing everything [one]3658-one could by way of providing for [a child one]3659-a child one had in a manner taken into one ’s own hands ; and [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [I]105-mrs. norris should be [the last person in [the world]315-the world to withhold [my]105-mrs. norris mite upon such an occasion . Having [no children of [my]105-mrs. norris own]3662-no children of my own , who should [I]105-mrs. norris look to in any little matter [I]105-mrs. norris may ever have to bestow]3660-the last person in the world to withhold my mite upon such an occasion . having no children of my own , who should i look to in any little matter i may ever have to bestow , but the children of [my]105-mrs. norris [sisters?—and]3663-sisters?—and [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris is too just — but [you]101-sir thomas know [I]105-mrs. norris am [a woman of few words and professions]3664-a woman of few words and professions . Do not let [us]3665-us be frightened from a good deed by a trifle . Give [a girl]3666-a girl an education , and introduce [her]3666-a girl properly into [the world]315-the world , and ten to one but [she]3666-a girl has the means of settling well , without farther expense to [anybody]3668-anybody . [A niece of ours]3669-a niece of ours , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [I]105-mrs. norris may say , or at least of _ yours _ , would not grow up in [this neighbourhood]3670-this neighbourhood without many advantages . [I]105-mrs. norris do n’t say [she]3666-a girl would be so handsome as [[her]3666-a girl cousins]3671-her cousins . [I]105-mrs. norris dare say [she]3666-a girl would not ; but [she]3666-a girl would be introduced into the society of [this country]3672-this country under such very favourable circumstances as , in all human probability , would get [her]3666-a girl a creditable establishment . [You]101-sir thomas are thinking of [[your]101-sir thomas sons]3673-your sons — but do not [you]101-sir thomas know that , of all things upon [earth]3674-earth , _ that _ is the least likely to happen , brought up as [they]3673-your sons would be , always together like [brothers]3675-brothers and [sisters]3676-sisters ? It is morally impossible . [I]105-mrs. norris never knew an instance of it . It is , in fact , the only sure way of providing against the connexion . Suppose [her]3666-a girl [a pretty girl , and seen by [Tom]101-sir thomas or [Edmund]108-edmund]3677-a pretty girl , and seen by tom or edmund for the first time seven years hence , and [I]105-mrs. norris dare say there would be mischief . The very idea of [her]3666-a girl having been suffered to grow up at a distance from [us]3678-ourselves all in poverty and neglect , would be enough to make either of [the dear , sweet - tempered boys in love with [her]3666-a girl]3679-the dear , sweet - tempered boys in love with her . But breed [her]3666-a girl up with [them]3679-the dear , sweet - tempered boys in love with her from this time , and suppose [her]3666-a girl even to have the beauty of [an angel]3680-an angel , and [she]3666-a girl will never be more to either than [a sister]3681-a sister . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ There is a great deal of truth in what [you]101-sir thomas say , ”[101-sir thomas] replied [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , “ and far be it from [me]101-sir thomas to throw any fanciful impediment in the way of a plan which would be so consistent with the relative situations of each . [I]101-sir thomas only meant to observe that it ought not to be lightly engaged in , and that to make it really serviceable to [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price , and creditable to [ourselves]3678-ourselves , [we]3678-ourselves must secure to [the child]3656-the child , or consider [ourselves]3678-ourselves engaged to secure to [her]3656-the child hereafter , as circumstances may arise , the provision of [a gentlewoman]3683-a gentlewoman , if no such establishment should offer as [you]101-sir thomas are so sanguine in expecting . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [I]105-mrs. norris thoroughly understand [you]101-sir thomas , ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , “ [you]101-sir thomas are everything that is generous and considerate , and [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [we]3678-ourselves shall never disagree on this point . Whatever [I]105-mrs. norris can do , as [you]101-sir thomas well know , [I]105-mrs. norris am always ready enough to do for the good of [those [I]105-mrs. norris love]3684-those i love ; and , though [I]105-mrs. norris could never feel for [this little girl]3685-this little girl the hundredth part of the regard [I]105-mrs. norris bear [[your]101-sir thomas own dear children]3686-your own dear children , nor consider [her]3685-this little girl , in any respect , so much [my]105-mrs. norris own , [I]105-mrs. norris should hate [myself]105-mrs. norris if [I]105-mrs. norris were capable of neglecting [her]3685-this little girl . Is not [she]3685-this little girl [[a sister]3681-a sister ’s child]3688-a sister ’s child ? and could [I]105-mrs. norris bear to see [her]3685-this little girl want while [I]105-mrs. norris had a bit of bread to give [her]3685-this little girl ? [[My]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear Sir [Thomas]101-sir thomas , with all [my]105-mrs. norris faults [I]105-mrs. norris have a warm heart ; and , poor as [I]105-mrs. norris am , would rather deny [myself]105-mrs. norris the necessaries of life than do an ungenerous thing . So , if [you]101-sir thomas are not against it , [I]105-mrs. norris will write to [[my]105-mrs. norris poor sister]3690-my poor sister tomorrow , and make the proposal ; and , as soon as matters are settled , _ [I]105-mrs. norris _ will engage to get [the child]3656-the child to [Mansfield]3-mansfield ; _ [you]101-sir thomas _ shall have no trouble about it . [My]105-mrs. norris own trouble , [you]101-sir thomas know , [I]105-mrs. norris never regard . [I]105-mrs. norris will send [Nanny]109-nanny to [London]6-london on purpose , and [she]109-nanny may have a bed at [[[her]109-nanny cousin]3692-her cousin [the saddler]3694-the saddler ’s]3693-her cousin the saddler ’s , and [the child]3656-the child be appointed to meet [her]109-nanny [there]3696-there . [They]3697-they may easily get [her]109-nanny from [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth to [town]3698-town by [the coach]3699-the coach , under the care of [any creditable person that may chance to be going]3700-any creditable person that may chance to be going . [I]105-mrs. norris dare say there is always [[some reputable tradesman]3701-some reputable tradesman ’s wife]3702-some reputable tradesman ’s wife or other going up . ”[105-mrs. norris] Except to the attack on [[Nanny]109-nanny ’s cousin]357-nanny ’s cousin , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas no longer made any objection , and a more respectable , though less economical rendezvous being accordingly substituted , everything was considered as settled , and the pleasures of so benevolent a scheme were already enjoyed . The division of gratifying sensations ought not , in strict justice , to have been equal ; for [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was fully resolved to be [the real and consistent patron of [the selected child]359-the selected child]358-the real and consistent patron of the selected child , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had not the least intention of being at any expense whatever in [her]105-mrs. norris maintenance . As far as walking , talking , and contriving reached , [she]105-mrs. norris was thoroughly benevolent , and [nobody]360-nobody knew better how to dictate liberality to [others]361-others ; but [her]105-mrs. norris love of money was equal to [her]105-mrs. norris love of directing , and [she]105-mrs. norris knew quite as well how to save [her]105-mrs. norris own as to spend that of [[her]105-mrs. norris friends]362-her friends . Having married on a narrower income than [she]105-mrs. norris had been used to look forward to , [she]105-mrs. norris had , from the first , fancied a very strict line of economy necessary ; and what was begun as a matter of prudence , soon grew into a matter of choice , as an object of that needful solicitude which there were [no children to supply]363-no children to supply . Had there been [a family]364-a family to provide for , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris might never have saved [her]105-mrs. norris money ; but having no care of that kind , there was nothing to impede [her]105-mrs. norris frugality , or lessen the comfort of making a yearly addition to an income which [they]365-they had never lived up to . Under this infatuating principle , counteracted by no real affection for [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister , it was impossible for [her]105-mrs. norris to aim at more than the credit of projecting and arranging so expensive a charity ; though perhaps [she]105-mrs. norris might so little know [herself]105-mrs. norris as to walk [home]367-home to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , after this conversation , in the happy belief of being [the most liberal - minded sister]369-the most liberal - minded sister and aunt in [the world]315-the world . When the subject was brought forward again , [her]105-mrs. norris views were more fully explained ; and , in reply to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s calm inquiry of “ Where shall [the child]3656-the child come to first , [sister]3704-sister , to [you]3704-sister or to [us]3705-us ? ”[106-lady bertram] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas heard with some surprise that it would be totally out of [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s power to take any share in the personal charge of [her]105-mrs. norris . [He]101-sir thomas had been considering [her]105-mrs. norris as a particularly welcome addition at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , as [a desirable companion to [an aunt who had no children of [her]373-an aunt who had no children of her own own]373-an aunt who had no children of her own]372-a desirable companion to an aunt who had no children of her own ; but [he]101-sir thomas found [himself]101-sir thomas wholly mistaken . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was sorry to say that [the little girl]374-the little girl ’s staying with [them]375-them , at least as things then were , was quite out of the question . [Poor Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris ’s indifferent state of health made it an impossibility : [he]104-mr. norris could no more bear the noise of [a child]376-a child than [he]104-mr. norris could fly ; if , indeed , [he]104-mr. norris should ever get well of [his]104-mr. norris gouty complaints , it would be a different matter : [she]105-mrs. norris should then be glad to take [her]105-mrs. norris turn , and think nothing of the inconvenience ; but just now , [poor Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris took up every moment of [her]105-mrs. norris time , and the very mention of such a thing [she]105-mrs. norris was sure would distract [him]104-mr. norris . “ Then [she]374-the little girl had better come to [us]375-them , ”[106-lady bertram] said [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , with the utmost composure . After a short pause [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas added with dignity , “ Yes , let [her]374-the little girl [home]367-home be in [this house]3707-this house . [We]375-them will endeavour to do [our]375-them duty by [her]374-the little girl , and [she]374-the little girl will , at least , have the advantage of [companions of [her]374-the little girl own age]3708-companions of her own age , and of [a regular instructress]3709-a regular instructress . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Very true , ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , “ which are both very important considerations ; and it will be just the same to [Miss Lee]110-miss lee whether [she]110-miss lee has [three girls]3710-three girls to teach , or only two — there can be no difference . [I]105-mrs. norris only wish [I]105-mrs. norris could be more useful ; but [you]3711-you see [I]105-mrs. norris do all in [my]105-mrs. norris power . [I]105-mrs. norris am not one of those that spare [their]3710-three girls own trouble ; and [Nanny]109-nanny shall fetch [her]374-the little girl , however it may put [me]105-mrs. norris to inconvenience to have [[my]105-mrs. norris chief counsellor]3712-my chief counsellor away for three days . [I]105-mrs. norris suppose , [sister]3704-sister , [you]3704-sister will put [the child]3656-the child in [the little white attic]3715-the little white attic , near [the old nurseries]3716-the old nurseries . It will be much the best place for [her]3656-the child , so near [Miss Lee]110-miss lee , and not far from [the girls]3717-the girls , and close by [the housemaids]3718-the housemaids , who could either of [them]3718-the housemaids help to dress [her]3656-the child , [you]3704-sister know , and take care of [her]3656-the child clothes , for [I]105-mrs. norris suppose [you]3704-sister would not think it fair to expect [Ellis]111-ellis to wait on [her]3656-the child as well as [the others]347-the others . Indeed , [I]105-mrs. norris do not see that [you]3704-sister could possibly place [her]3656-the child anywhere else . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram made no opposition . “ [I]105-mrs. norris hope [she]3656-the child will prove [a well - disposed girl]3720-a well - disposed girl , ”[105-mrs. norris] continued [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , “ and be sensible of [her]3656-the child uncommon good fortune in having [such friends]3721-such friends . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Should [her]3656-the child disposition be really bad , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , “ [we]3722-we must not , for [[our]3722-we own children]3723-our own children ’s sake , continue [her]3656-the child in [the family]3724-the family ; but there is no reason to expect so great an evil . [We]3722-we shall probably see much to wish altered in [her]3656-the child , and must prepare [ourselves]3722-we for gross ignorance , some meanness of opinions , and very distressing vulgarity of manner ; but these are not incurable faults ; nor , [I]101-sir thomas trust , can [they]3725-they be dangerous for [[her]3656-the child associates]3726-her associates . Had [[my]101-sir thomas daughters]3727-my daughters been _ younger _ than [herself]3656-the child , [I]101-sir thomas should have considered the introduction of [such a companion]3728-such a companion as a matter of very serious moment ; but , as it is , [I]101-sir thomas hope there can be nothing to fear for _ [them]3727-my daughters _ , and everything to hope for _ [her]3656-the child _ , from the association . ”[101-sir thomas] “ That is exactly what [I]105-mrs. norris think , ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , “ and what [I]105-mrs. norris was saying to [[my]105-mrs. norris husband]3729-my husband this morning . It will be an education for [the child]3656-the child , said [I]105-mrs. norris , only being with [[her]3656-the child cousins]3671-her cousins ; if [Miss Lee]110-miss lee taught [her]3656-the child nothing , [she]3656-the child would learn to be good and clever from _ [them]3671-her cousins _ . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]106-lady bertram hope [she]3656-the child will not tease [my]106-lady bertram poor pug , ”[106-lady bertram] said [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ; “ [I]106-lady bertram have but just got [Julia]112-julia to leave it alone . ”[106-lady bertram] “ There will be some difficulty in [our]3732-our way , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , ”[101-sir thomas] observed [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , “ as to the distinction proper to be made between [the girls]3717-the girls as [they]3717-the girls grow up : how to preserve in the minds of [[my]101-sir thomas _ daughters]3734-my _ daughters _ the consciousness of what [they]3717-the girls are , without making [them]3717-the girls think too lowly of [[their]3717-the girls cousin]3735-their cousin ; and how , without depressing [her]3656-the child spirits too far , to make [her]3656-the child remember that [she]3656-the child is not a _ [Miss Bertram _]112-julia . [I]101-sir thomas should wish to see [[them]3717-the girls very good friends]3736-them very good friends , and would , on no account , authorise in [[my]101-sir thomas girls]3737-my girls the smallest degree of arrogance towards [their]3717-the girls relation ; but still [they]3717-the girls can not be [equals]3738-equals . [Their]3717-the girls rank , fortune , rights , and expectations will always be different . It is a point of great delicacy , and [you]3739-you must assist [us]3740-us in [our]3740-us endeavours to choose exactly the right line of conduct . ”[101-sir thomas] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was quite at [his]377-him service ; and though [she]105-mrs. norris perfectly agreed with [him]377-him as to its being a most difficult thing , encouraged [him]377-him to hope that between [them]378-them it would be easily managed . It will be readily believed that [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris did not write to [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister in vain . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price seemed rather surprised that [a girl]3666-a girl should be fixed on , when [she]107-mrs. price had [so many fine boys]381-so many fine boys , but accepted the offer most thankfully , assuring [them]381-so many fine boys of [[her]107-mrs. price daughter]382-her daughter ’s being [a very well - disposed , good - humoured girl]383-a very well - disposed , good - humoured girl , and trusting [they]381-so many fine boys would never have cause to throw [her]107-mrs. price off . [She]107-mrs. price spoke of [her]107-mrs. price farther as somewhat delicate and puny , but was sanguine in the hope of [her]107-mrs. price being materially better for change of air . [Poor woman]384-poor woman ! [she]107-mrs. price probably thought change of air might agree with [many of [[her]107-mrs. price children]386-her children]385-many of her children . CHAPTER II [The little girl]374-the little girl performed [her]374-the little girl long journey in safety ; and at [Northampton]8-northampton was met by [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , who thus regaled in the credit of being foremost to welcome [her]374-the little girl , and in the importance of leading [her]374-the little girl in to [the others]347-the others , and recommending [her]374-the little girl to [their]347-the others kindness . [Fanny Price]113-fanny was at this time just ten years old , and though there might not be much in [her]107-mrs. price first appearance to captivate , there was , at least , nothing to disgust [[her]107-mrs. price relations]389-her relations . [She]107-mrs. price was small of [her]107-mrs. price age , with no glow of complexion , nor any other striking beauty ; exceedingly timid and shy , and shrinking from notice ; but [her]107-mrs. price air , though awkward , was not vulgar , [her]107-mrs. price voice was sweet , and when [she]107-mrs. price spoke [her]107-mrs. price countenance was pretty . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram received [her]107-mrs. price very kindly ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , seeing how much [she]107-mrs. price needed encouragement , tried to be all that was conciliating : but [he]101-sir thomas had to work against a most untoward gravity of deportment ; and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , without taking half so much trouble , or speaking one word where [he]101-sir thomas spoke ten , by the mere aid of a good - humoured smile , became immediately the less awful character of [the two]390-the two . [The young people]391-the young people were all at [home]367-home , and sustained [their]391-the young people share in the introduction very well , with much good humour , and no embarrassment , at least on the part of [[the sons]393-the sons , who , at seventeen and sixteen , and tall of [their]393-the sons age , had all the grandeur of [men]395-men in the eyes of [[their]393-the sons little cousin]396-their little cousin]394-the sons , who , at seventeen and sixteen , and tall of their age , had all the grandeur of men in the eyes of their little cousin . [The two girls]397-the two girls were more at a loss from being younger and in greater awe of [[their]397-the two girls father]398-their father , who addressed [them]397-the two girls on the occasion with rather an injudicious particularity . But [they]397-the two girls were too much used to company and praise to have anything like natural shyness ; and [their]397-the two girls confidence increasing from [[their]397-the two girls cousin]3735-their cousin ’s total want of it , [they]397-the two girls were soon able to take a full survey of [her]3735-their cousin face and [her]3735-their cousin frock in easy indifference . [They]397-the two girls were [a remarkably fine family]400-a remarkably fine family , [the sons]393-the sons very well - looking , [the daughters]402-the daughters decidedly handsome , and all of [them]397-the two girls well - grown and forward of [their]397-the two girls age , which produced as striking a difference between [the cousins in person]403-the cousins in person , as education had given to [their]397-the two girls address ; and [no one]404-no one would have supposed [the girls]3717-the girls so nearly of an age as [they]3717-the girls really were . There were in fact but two years between [the youngest]406-the youngest and [Fanny]113-fanny . [Julia Bertram]112-julia was only twelve , and [Maria]100-maria but a year older . [The little visitor]407-the little visitor meanwhile was as unhappy as possible . Afraid of [everybody]408-everybody , ashamed of [herself]407-the little visitor , and longing for [the home [she]407-the little visitor had left]409-the home she had left , [she]407-the little visitor knew not how to look up , and could scarcely speak to be heard , or without crying . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had been talking to [her]407-the little visitor the whole way from [Northampton]8-northampton of [her]407-the little visitor wonderful good fortune , and the extraordinary degree of gratitude and good behaviour which it ought to produce , and [her]407-the little visitor consciousness of misery was therefore increased by the idea of its being a wicked thing for [her]407-the little visitor not to be happy . The fatigue , too , of so long a journey , became soon no trifling evil . In vain were the well - meant condescensions of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and all the officious prognostications of [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris that [she]407-the little visitor would be [a good girl]410-a good girl ; in vain did [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram smile and make [her]407-the little visitor sit on the sofa with [herself]407-the little visitor and pug , and vain was even the sight of a gooseberry tart towards giving [her]407-the little visitor comfort ; [she]407-the little visitor could scarcely swallow two mouthfuls before tears interrupted [her]407-the little visitor , and sleep seeming to be [[her]407-the little visitor likeliest friend]411-her likeliest friend , [she]407-the little visitor was taken to finish [her]407-the little visitor sorrows in bed . “ This is not a very promising beginning , ”[105-mrs. norris] said [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , when [Fanny]113-fanny had left [the room]412-the room . “ After all that [I]105-mrs. norris said to [her]407-the little visitor as [we]3741-we came along , [I]105-mrs. norris thought [she]407-the little visitor would have behaved better ; [I]105-mrs. norris told [her]407-the little visitor how much might depend upon [her]407-the little visitor acquitting [herself]407-the little visitor well at first . [I]105-mrs. norris wish there may not be a little sulkiness of temper — [[her]407-the little visitor poor mother]3654-her poor mother had a good deal ; but [we]3741-we must make allowances for [such a child]3743-such a child — and [I]105-mrs. norris do not know that [her]407-the little visitor being sorry to leave [[her]407-the little visitor [home]367-home]3744-her home is really against [her]407-the little visitor , for , with all its faults , it _ was _ [[her]407-the little visitor home]3744-her home , and [she]407-the little visitor can not as yet understand how much [she]407-the little visitor has changed for the better ; but then there is moderation in all things . ”[105-mrs. norris] It required a longer time , however , than [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was inclined to allow , to reconcile [Fanny]113-fanny to the novelty of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and the separation from [everybody]408-everybody [she]414-her had been used to . [Her]414-her feelings were very acute , and too little understood to be properly attended to . [Nobody]360-nobody meant to be unkind , but [nobody]360-nobody put [themselves]360-nobody out of [their]360-nobody way to secure [her]414-her comfort . The holiday allowed to [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams the next day , on purpose to afford leisure for getting acquainted with , and entertaining [[their]360-nobody young cousin]417-their young cousin , produced little union . [They]360-nobody could not but hold [her]414-her cheap on finding that [she]414-her had but two sashes , and had never learned French ; and when [they]360-nobody perceived [her]414-her to be little struck with the duet [they]360-nobody were so good as to play , [they]360-nobody could do no more than make [her]414-her a generous present of some of [their]360-nobody least valued toys , and leave [her]414-her to [herself]414-her , while [they]360-nobody adjourned to whatever might be the favourite holiday sport of the moment , making artificial flowers or wasting gold paper . [Fanny]113-fanny , whether near or from [[her]414-her cousins]3671-her cousins , whether in [the schoolroom]419-the schoolroom , [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , or the shrubbery , was equally forlorn , finding something to fear in [every person]421-every person and place . [She]414-her was disheartened by [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s silence , awed by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s grave looks , and quite overcome by [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s admonitions . [[Her]414-her elder cousins]422-her elder cousins mortified [her]414-her by reflections on [her]414-her size , and abashed [her]414-her by noticing [her]414-her shyness : [Miss Lee]110-miss lee wondered at [her]414-her ignorance , and [the maid - servants]423-the maid - servants sneered at [her]414-her clothes ; and when to these sorrows was added the idea of [the brothers]424-the brothers and sisters among whom [she]414-her had always been important as playfellow , [instructress]425-instructress , and [nurse]426-nurse , the despondence that sunk [her]414-her little heart was severe . The grandeur of [the house]427-the house astonished , but could not console [her]414-her . [The rooms]428-the rooms were too large for [her]414-her to move in with ease : whatever [she]414-her touched [she]414-her expected to injure , and [she]414-her crept about in constant terror of something or other ; often retreating towards [[her]414-her own chamber]429-her own chamber to cry ; and [the little girl who was spoken of in [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room when [she]430-the little girl who was spoken of in the drawing - room when she left it at night as seeming so desirably sensible of her peculiar good fortune left [it]420-the drawing - room at night as seeming so desirably sensible of [her]430-the little girl who was spoken of in the drawing - room when she left it at night as seeming so desirably sensible of her peculiar good fortune peculiar good fortune]430-the little girl who was spoken of in the drawing - room when she left it at night as seeming so desirably sensible of her peculiar good fortune , ended every day ’s sorrows by sobbing [herself]430-the little girl who was spoken of in the drawing - room when she left it at night as seeming so desirably sensible of her peculiar good fortune to sleep . A week had passed in this way , and no suspicion of it conveyed by [her]414-her quiet passive manner , when [she]414-her was found one morning by [[her]414-her cousin]3692-her cousin [Edmund]108-edmund , [the youngest of [the sons]393-the sons]433-the youngest of the sons , sitting crying on [the attic stairs]435-the attic stairs . “ [[My]108-edmund dear little cousin]3747-my dear little cousin , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund , with all the gentleness of an excellent nature , “ what can be the matter ? ”[108-edmund] And sitting down by [her]414-her , [he]108-edmund was at great pains to overcome [her]414-her shame in being so surprised , and persuade [her]414-her to speak openly . Was [she]414-her ill ? or was [anybody]3668-anybody angry with [her]414-her ? or had [she]414-her quarrelled with [Maria]100-maria and [Julia]112-julia ? or was [she]414-her puzzled about anything in [her]414-her lesson that [he]108-edmund could explain ? Did [she]414-her , in short , want anything [he]108-edmund could possibly get [her]414-her , or do for [her]414-her ? For a long while no answer could be obtained beyond a “ no , no — not at all — no , thank [you]414-her ”[414-her] ; but [he]108-edmund still persevered ; and no sooner had [he]108-edmund begun to revert to [[her]414-her own home]437-her own home , than [her]414-her increased sobs explained to [him]108-edmund where the grievance lay . [He]108-edmund tried to console [her]414-her . “ [You]414-her are sorry to leave [Mama]115-mama , [[my]108-edmund dear]3657-my dear little [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund , “ which shows [you]414-her to be [a very good girl]3749-a very good girl ; but [you]414-her must remember that [you]414-her are with [relations]3750-relations and [friends]3751-friends , who all love [you]414-her , and wish to make [you]414-her happy . Let [us]3752-us walk out in [the park]3753-the park , and [you]414-her shall tell [me]108-edmund all about [[your]414-her brothers]3754-your brothers and [sisters]3676-sisters . ”[108-edmund] On pursuing the subject , [he]108-edmund found that , dear as [all these brothers]438-all these brothers and [sisters]3676-sisters generally were , there was one among [them]438-all these brothers who ran more in [her]440-her thoughts than [the rest]441-the rest . It was [William]228-william whom [she]440-her talked of most , and wanted most to see . [William]228-william , [the eldest]442-the eldest , a year older than [herself]440-her , [[her]440-her constant companion and [friend]444-friend]443-her constant companion and friend ; [[her]440-her advocate with [[her]440-her mother]446-her mother ( of whom [he]228-william was [the darling]447-the darling ) in every distress]445-her advocate with her mother ( of whom he was the darling ) in every distress . “ [William]228-william did not like [she]440-her should come away ; [he]228-william had told [her]440-her [he]228-william should miss [her]440-her very much indeed . ”[446-her mother] “ But [William]228-william will write to [you]440-her , [I]447-the darling dare say . ”[447-the darling] “ Yes , [he]228-william had promised [he]228-william would , but [he]228-william had told [_]117-_ [her]440-her _ to write first . ”[447-the darling] “ And when shall [you]447-the darling do it ? ”[446-her mother] [She]440-her hung [her]440-her head and answered hesitatingly , “ [she]440-her did not know ; [she]440-her had not any paper . ”[440-her] “ If that be all [your]440-her difficulty , [I]447-the darling will furnish [you]440-her with paper and every other material , and [you]440-her may write [your]440-her letter whenever [you]440-her choose . Would it make [you]440-her happy to write to [William]228-william ? ”[447-the darling] “ Yes , very . ”[447-the darling] “ Then let it be done now . Come with [me]447-the darling into [the breakfast - room]3756-the breakfast - room , [we]3757-we shall find everything there , and be sure of having [the room]412-the room to [ourselves]3757-we . ”[447-the darling] “ But , [cousin]3759-cousin , will it go to the post ? ”[447-the darling] “ Yes , depend upon [me]447-the darling it shall : it shall go with the other letters ; and , as [[your]440-her uncle]3760-your uncle will frank it , it will cost [William]228-william nothing . ”[447-the darling] “ [[My]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle ! ”[113-fanny] repeated [Fanny]113-fanny , with a frightened look . “ Yes , when [you]440-her have written the letter , [I]113-fanny will take it to [[my]113-fanny father]3762-my father to [frank]118-frank . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny thought it a bold measure , but offered no further resistance ; and [they]448-they went together into [the breakfast - room]3756-the breakfast - room , where [Edmund]108-edmund prepared [her]450-her paper , and ruled [her]450-her lines with all the goodwill that [[her]450-her brother]451-her brother could [himself]108-edmund have felt , and probably with somewhat more exactness . [He]108-edmund continued with [her]450-her the whole time of [her]450-her writing , to assist [her]450-her with [his]108-edmund penknife or [his]108-edmund orthography , as either were wanted ; and added to these attentions , which [she]450-her felt very much , a kindness to [[her]450-her brother]451-her brother which delighted [her]450-her beyond all the rest . [He]108-edmund wrote with [his]108-edmund own hand [his]108-edmund love to [[his]108-edmund cousin]453-his cousin [William]228-william , and sent [him]228-william half a guinea under the seal . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s feelings on the occasion were such as [she]450-her believed [herself]450-her incapable of expressing ; but [her]450-her countenance and a few artless words fully conveyed all [their]454-their gratitude and delight , and [[her]450-her cousin]3692-her cousin began to find [her]450-her an interesting object . [He]108-edmund talked to [her]450-her more , and , from all that [she]450-her said , was convinced of [her]450-her having an affectionate heart , and a strong desire of doing right ; and [he]108-edmund could perceive [her]450-her to be farther entitled to attention by great sensibility of [her]450-her situation , and great timidity . [He]108-edmund had never knowingly given [her]450-her pain , but [he]108-edmund now felt that [she]450-her required more positive kindness ; and with that view endeavoured , in the first place , to lessen [her]450-her fears of [them]454-their all , and gave [her]450-her especially a great deal of good advice as to playing with [Maria]100-maria and [Julia]112-julia , and being as merry as possible . From this day [Fanny]113-fanny grew more comfortable . [She]450-her felt that [she]450-her had [a friend]456-a friend , and the kindness of [[her]450-her cousin]3692-her cousin [Edmund]108-edmund gave [her]450-her better spirits with [everybody else]458-everybody else . [The place]459-the place became less strange , and [the people]460-the people less formidable ; and if there were [some amongst [them]460-the people whom [she]450-her could not cease to fear]461-some amongst them whom she could not cease to fear , [she]450-her began at least to know [their]460-the people ways , and to catch the best manner of conforming to [them]460-the people . The little rusticities and awkwardnesses which had at first made grievous inroads on the tranquillity of all , and not least of [herself]450-her , necessarily wore away , and [she]450-her was no longer materially afraid to appear before [[her]450-her uncle]312-her uncle , nor did [[her]450-her aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s voice make [her]450-her start very much . To [[her]450-her cousins]3671-her cousins [she]450-her became occasionally [an acceptable companion]465-an acceptable companion . Though unworthy , from inferiority of age and strength , to be [[their]3671-her cousins constant associate]466-their constant associate , [their]3671-her cousins pleasures and schemes were sometimes of a nature to make [a third]467-a third very useful , especially when that third was of an obliging , yielding temper ; and [they]3671-her cousins could not but own , when [[their]3671-her cousins aunt]468-their aunt inquired into [her]468-their aunt faults , or [[their]3671-her cousins brother]469-their brother [Edmund]108-edmund urged [her]468-their aunt claims to [their]3671-her cousins kindness , that “ [Fanny]113-fanny was good - natured enough . ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund was uniformly kind [himself]108-edmund ; and [she]450-her had nothing worse to endure on the part of [Tom]101-sir thomas than that sort of merriment which [a young man of seventeen]470-a young man of seventeen will always think fair with [a child of ten]471-a child of ten . [He]108-edmund was just entering into life , full of spirits , and with all the liberal dispositions of [an eldest son , who feels born only for expense and enjoyment]472-an eldest son , who feels born only for expense and enjoyment . [His]108-edmund kindness to [[his]108-edmund little cousin]473-his little cousin was consistent with [his]108-edmund situation and rights : [he]108-edmund made [her]450-her some very pretty presents , and laughed at [her]450-her . As [her]450-her appearance and spirits improved , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris thought with greater satisfaction of [their]3671-her cousins benevolent plan ; and it was pretty soon decided between [them]3671-her cousins that , though far from clever , [she]450-her showed a tractable disposition , and seemed likely to give [them]3671-her cousins little trouble . A mean opinion of [her]450-her abilities was not confined to _ [them]3671-her cousins _ . [Fanny]113-fanny could read , work , and write , but [she]450-her had been taught nothing more ; and as [[her]450-her cousins]3671-her cousins found [her]450-her ignorant of many things with which [they]3671-her cousins had been long familiar , [they]3671-her cousins thought [her]450-her prodigiously stupid , and for the first two or three weeks were continually bringing some fresh report of it into [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room . “ [Dear mama]3763-dear mama , only think , [[my]3671-her cousins cousin]3764-my cousin can not put the map of [Europe]9-europe together — or [[my]3671-her cousins cousin]3764-my cousin can not tell [the principal rivers in [Russia]10-russia]3766-the principal rivers in russia — or , [she]3764-my cousin never heard of [Asia Minor]11-asia minor — or [she]3764-my cousin does not know the difference between water - colours and crayons!—How strange!—Did [you]3763-dear mama ever hear anything so stupid ? ”[3671-her cousins] “ [[My]476-their considerate aunt dear]3657-my dear , ”[476-their considerate aunt] [[their]3671-her cousins considerate aunt]476-their considerate aunt would reply , “ it is very bad , but [you]3763-dear mama must not expect [everybody]408-everybody to be as forward and quick at learning as [yourself]3763-dear mama . ”[476-their considerate aunt] “ But , [aunt]3769-aunt , [she]3764-my cousin is really so very ignorant!—Do [you]3763-dear mama know , [we]3671-her cousins asked [her]3764-my cousin last night which way [she]3764-my cousin would go to get to [Ireland]12-ireland ; and [she]3764-my cousin said , [she]3764-my cousin should cross to [the Isle of Wight]13-the isle of wight . [She]3764-my cousin thinks of nothing but [the Isle of Wight]13-the isle of wight , and [she]3764-my cousin calls it _ [the _ _ Island _]3770-the _ _ island _ , as if there were [no other island in [the world]315-the world]3771-no other island in the world . [I]476-their considerate aunt am sure [I]476-their considerate aunt should have been ashamed of [myself]476-their considerate aunt , if [I]476-their considerate aunt had not known better long before [I]476-their considerate aunt was so old as [she]3764-my cousin is . [I]476-their considerate aunt can not remember the time when [I]476-their considerate aunt did not know a great deal that [she]3764-my cousin has not the least notion of yet . How long ago it is , [aunt]3769-aunt , since [we]3774-we used to repeat the chronological order of [the kings of [England]14-england]3775-the kings of england , with the dates of [their]3775-the kings of england accession , and most of the principal events of [their]3775-the kings of england reigns ! ”[476-their considerate aunt] “ Yes , ”[477-the other] added [the other]477-the other ; “ and of [the Roman emperors as low as [Severus]119-severus]3776-the roman emperors as low as severus ; besides a great deal of the heathen mythology , and all the metals , semi - metals , planets , and [distinguished philosophers]3777-distinguished philosophers . ”[477-the other] “ Very true indeed , [[my]476-their considerate aunt dears]3778-my dears , but [you]3778-my dears are blessed with wonderful memories , and [[your]3778-my dears poor cousin]3779-your poor cousin has probably none at all . There is a vast deal of difference in memories , as well as in everything else , and therefore [you]3778-my dears must make allowance for [[your]3778-my dears cousin]3780-your cousin , and pity [her]3780-your cousin deficiency . And remember that , if [you]3778-my dears are ever so forward and clever [yourselves]3778-my dears , [you]3778-my dears should always be modest ; for , much as [you]3778-my dears know already , there is a great deal more for [you]3778-my dears to learn . ”[476-their considerate aunt] “ Yes , [I]476-their considerate aunt know there is , till [I]476-their considerate aunt am seventeen . But [I]476-their considerate aunt must tell [you]3778-my dears another thing of [Fanny]113-fanny , so odd and so stupid . Do [you]3778-my dears know , [she]3780-your cousin says [she]3780-your cousin does not want to learn either music or drawing . ”[476-their considerate aunt] “ To be sure , [[my]476-their considerate aunt dear]3657-my dear , that is very stupid indeed , and shows a great want of genius and emulation . But , all things considered , [I]476-their considerate aunt do not know whether it is not as well that it should be so , for , though [you]3778-my dears know ( owing to [me]476-their considerate aunt ) [[your]3778-my dears papa]3782-your papa and [mama]3783-mama are so good as to bring [her]3780-your cousin up with [you]3778-my dears , it is not at all necessary that [she]3780-your cousin should be as accomplished as [you]3778-my dears are;—on the contrary , it is much more desirable that there should be a difference . ”[476-their considerate aunt] Such were the counsels by which [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris assisted to form [[her]105-mrs. norris nieces]478-her nieces ’ minds ; and it is not very wonderful that , with all [their]478-her nieces promising talents and early information , [they]478-her nieces should be entirely deficient in the less common acquirements of self - knowledge , generosity and humility . In everything but disposition [they]478-her nieces were admirably taught . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas did not know what was wanting , because , though [a truly anxious father]479-a truly anxious father , [he]101-sir thomas was not outwardly affectionate , and the reserve of [his]101-sir thomas manner repressed all the flow of [their]478-her nieces spirits before [him]101-sir thomas . To the education of [[her]105-mrs. norris daughters]480-her daughters [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram paid not the smallest attention . [She]105-mrs. norris had not time for such cares . [She]105-mrs. norris was [a woman who spent [her]105-mrs. norris days in sitting , nicely dressed , on a sofa , doing some long piece of needlework , of little use and no beauty , thinking more of [her]105-mrs. norris pug than [[her]105-mrs. norris children]386-her children , but very indulgent to the latter when it did not put [herself]105-mrs. norris to inconvenience , guided in everything important by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and in smaller concerns by [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister]481-a woman who spent her days in sitting , nicely dressed , on a sofa , doing some long piece of needlework , of little use and no beauty , thinking more of her pug than her children , but very indulgent to the latter when it did not put herself to inconvenience , guided in everything important by sir thomas , and in smaller concerns by her sister . Had [she]105-mrs. norris possessed greater leisure for the service of [[her]105-mrs. norris girls]484-her girls , [she]105-mrs. norris would probably have supposed it unnecessary , for [they]484-her girls were under the care of [a governess]485-a governess , with [proper masters]486-proper masters , and could want nothing more . As for [Fanny]113-fanny ’s being stupid at learning , “ [she]105-mrs. norris could only say it was very unlucky , but [some people]3784-some people _ were _ stupid , and [Fanny]113-fanny must take more pains : [she]105-mrs. norris did not know what else was to be done ; and , except [her]105-mrs. norris being so dull , [she]105-mrs. norris must add [she]105-mrs. norris saw no harm in [the poor little thing]3785-the poor little thing , and always found [her]105-mrs. norris very handy and quick in carrying messages , and fetching what [she]105-mrs. norris wanted . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny , with all [her]105-mrs. norris faults of ignorance and timidity , was fixed at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and learning to transfer in its favour much of [her]105-mrs. norris attachment to [[her]105-mrs. norris former home]487-her former home , grew up there not unhappily among [[her]105-mrs. norris cousins]3671-her cousins . There was no positive ill - nature in [Maria]100-maria or [Julia]112-julia ; and though [Fanny]113-fanny was often mortified by [their]489-their treatment of [her]105-mrs. norris , [she]105-mrs. norris thought too lowly of [her]105-mrs. norris own claims to feel injured by it . From about the time of [her]105-mrs. norris entering [the family]3724-the family , [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , in consequence of a little ill - health , and a great deal of indolence , gave up [the house in [town]3698-town]491-the house in town , which [she]105-mrs. norris had been used to occupy every spring , and remained wholly in [the country]493-the country , leaving [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas to attend [his]101-sir thomas duty in Parliament , with whatever increase or diminution of comfort might arise from [her]105-mrs. norris absence . In [the country]493-the country , therefore , [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams continued to exercise [their]489-their memories , practise [their]489-their duets , and grow tall and womanly : and [[their]489-their father]398-their father saw [them]489-their becoming in person , manner , and accomplishments , everything that could satisfy [his]398-their father anxiety . [[His]398-their father eldest son]496-his eldest son was careless and extravagant , and had already given [him]398-their father much uneasiness ; but [[his]398-their father other children]497-his other children promised [him]398-their father nothing but good . [[His]398-their father daughters]498-his daughters , [he]398-their father felt , while [they]498-his daughters retained the name of [Bertram]106-lady bertram , must be giving [it]499-it new grace , and in quitting it , [he]398-their father trusted , would extend [its]499-it respectable alliances ; and the character of [Edmund]108-edmund , [his]108-edmund strong good sense and uprightness of mind , bid most fairly for utility , honour , and happiness to [himself]108-edmund and all [his]108-edmund connexions . [He]108-edmund was to be [a clergyman]500-a clergyman . Amid the cares and the complacency which [[his]398-their father own children]501-his own children suggested , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas did not forget to do what [he]398-their father could for [the children of [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price]502-the children of mrs. price : [he]398-their father assisted [her]107-mrs. price liberally in the education and disposal of [[her]107-mrs. price sons]503-her sons as [they]503-her sons became old enough for a determinate pursuit ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , though almost totally separated from [[her]107-mrs. price family]322-her family , was sensible of the truest satisfaction in hearing of any kindness towards [them]322-her family , or of anything at all promising in [their]322-her family situation or conduct . Once , and once only , in the course of many years , had [she]107-mrs. price the happiness of being with [William]228-william . Of [the rest]441-the rest [she]107-mrs. price saw nothing : [nobody]360-nobody seemed to think of [her]107-mrs. price ever going amongst [them]322-her family again , even for a visit , [[nobody]360-nobody at [home]367-home]508-nobody at home seemed to want [her]107-mrs. price ; but [William]228-william determining , soon after [her]107-mrs. price removal , to be [a sailor]510-a sailor , was invited to spend a week with [[his]228-william sister]511-his sister in [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire before [he]228-william went to [sea]512-sea . [Their]322-her family eager affection in meeting , [their]322-her family exquisite delight in being together , [their]322-her family hours of happy mirth , and moments of serious conference , may be imagined ; as well as the sanguine views and spirits of [the boy]513-the boy even to the last , and the misery of [the girl]514-the girl when [he]228-william left [her]514-the girl . Luckily the visit happened in the Christmas holidays , when [she]514-the girl could directly look for comfort to [[her]514-the girl cousin]3692-her cousin [Edmund]108-edmund ; and [he]108-edmund told [her]514-the girl such charming things of what [William]228-william was to do , and be hereafter , in consequence of [his]108-edmund profession , as made [her]514-the girl gradually admit that the separation might have some use . [Edmund]108-edmund ’s friendship never failed [her]514-the girl : [his]108-edmund leaving [Eton]16-eton for [Oxford]39-oxford made no change in [his]108-edmund kind dispositions , and only afforded more frequent opportunities of proving [them]516-them . Without any display of doing more than the rest , or any fear of doing too much , [he]108-edmund was always true to [her]514-the girl interests , and considerate of [her]514-the girl feelings , trying to make [her]514-the girl good qualities understood , and to conquer the diffidence which prevented [their]517-their being more apparent ; giving [her]514-the girl advice , consolation , and encouragement . Kept back as [she]514-the girl was by [everybody else]458-everybody else , [his]108-edmund single support could not bring [her]514-the girl forward ; but [his]108-edmund attentions were otherwise of the highest importance in assisting the improvement of [her]514-the girl mind , and extending its pleasures . [He]108-edmund knew [her]514-the girl to be clever , to have a quick apprehension as well as good sense , and a fondness for reading , which , properly directed , must be an education in itself . [Miss Lee]110-miss lee taught [her]514-the girl French , and heard [her]514-the girl read the daily portion of history ; but [he]108-edmund recommended the books which charmed [her]514-the girl leisure hours , [he]108-edmund encouraged [her]514-the girl taste , and corrected [her]514-the girl judgment : [he]108-edmund made reading useful by talking to [her]514-the girl of what [she]514-the girl read , and heightened its attraction by judicious praise . In return for such services [she]514-the girl loved [him]108-edmund better than anybody in [the world]315-the world except [William]228-william : [her]514-the girl heart was divided between the two . CHAPTER III The first event of any importance in [the family]3724-the family was the death of [Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris , which happened when [Fanny]113-fanny was about fifteen , and necessarily introduced alterations and novelties . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , on quitting [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , removed first to [the Park]3753-the park , and afterwards to [a small house of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s in [the village]524-the village]523-a small house of sir thomas ’s in the village , and consoled [herself]105-mrs. norris for the loss of [[her]105-mrs. norris husband]325-her husband by considering that [she]105-mrs. norris could do very well without [him]108-edmund ; and for [her]105-mrs. norris reduction of income by the evident necessity of stricter economy . The living was hereafter for [Edmund]108-edmund ; and , had [[his]108-edmund uncle]526-his uncle died a few years sooner , it would have been duly given to [some friend]527-some friend to hold till [he]108-edmund were old enough for orders . But [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s extravagance had , previous to that event , been so great as to render a different disposal of the next presentation necessary , and [the younger brother]528-the younger brother must help to pay for the pleasures of [the elder]529-the elder . There was [another family living actually held for [Edmund]108-edmund]530-another family living actually held for edmund ; but though this circumstance had made the arrangement somewhat easier to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s conscience , [he]101-sir thomas could not but feel it to be an act of injustice , and [he]101-sir thomas earnestly tried to impress [[his]101-sir thomas eldest son]496-his eldest son with the same conviction , in the hope of its producing a better effect than anything [he]101-sir thomas had yet been able to say or do . “ [I]101-sir thomas blush for [you]101-sir thomas , [Tom]101-sir thomas , ”[101-sir thomas] said [he]101-sir thomas , in [his]101-sir thomas most dignified manner ; “ [I]101-sir thomas blush for the expedient which [I]101-sir thomas am driven on , and [I]101-sir thomas trust [I]101-sir thomas may pity [your]101-sir thomas feelings as [a brother on the occasion]3786-a brother on the occasion . [You]101-sir thomas have robbed [Edmund]108-edmund for ten , twenty , thirty years , perhaps for life , of more than half the income which ought to be [his]108-edmund . It may hereafter be in [my]101-sir thomas power , or in [yours]101-sir thomas ( [I]101-sir thomas hope it will ) , to procure [him]108-edmund better preferment ; but it must not be forgotten that no benefit of that sort would have been beyond [his]108-edmund natural claims on [us]3787-us , and that nothing can , in fact , be an equivalent for the certain advantage which [he]108-edmund is now obliged to forego through the urgency of [your]101-sir thomas debts . ”[101-sir thomas] [Tom]101-sir thomas listened with some shame and some sorrow ; but escaping as quickly as possible , could soon with cheerful selfishness reflect , firstly , that [he]101-sir thomas had not been half so much in debt as [some of [[his]101-sir thomas friends]533-his friends]532-some of his friends ; secondly , that [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father had made a most tiresome piece of work of it ; and , thirdly , that [the future incumbent]535-the future incumbent , whoever [he]101-sir thomas might be , would , in all probability , die very soon . On [Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris ’s death the presentation became the right of [a Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , who came consequently to reside at [Mansfield]3-mansfield ; and on proving to be [a hearty man of forty - five]536-a hearty man of forty - five , seemed likely to disappoint [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund ’s calculations . But “ no , [he]101-sir thomas was [a short - necked , apoplectic sort of fellow]3788-a short - necked , apoplectic sort of fellow , and , plied well with good things , would soon pop off . ”[101-sir thomas] [He]101-sir thomas had [a wife]537-a wife about fifteen years [his]101-sir thomas junior , but [no children]538-no children ; and [they]539-their entered [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood with the usual fair report of being [very respectable , agreeable people]541-very respectable , agreeable people . The time was now come when [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas expected [[his]101-sir thomas sister - in - law]542-his sister - in - law to claim [her]542-his sister - in - law share in [[their]539-their niece]543-their niece , the change in [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s situation , and the improvement in [Fanny]113-fanny ’s age , seeming not merely to do away any former objection to [their]539-their living together , but even to give it the most decided eligibility ; and as [his]101-sir thomas own circumstances were rendered less fair than heretofore , by some recent losses on [[his]101-sir thomas West India estate]544-his west india estate , in addition to [[his]101-sir thomas eldest son]496-his eldest son ’s extravagance , it became not undesirable to [himself]101-sir thomas to be relieved from the expense of [her]105-mrs. norris support , and the obligation of [her]105-mrs. norris future provision . In the fullness of [his]101-sir thomas belief that such a thing must be , [he]101-sir thomas mentioned its probability to [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife ; and the first time of the subject ’s occurring to [her]546-his wife again happening to be when [Fanny]113-fanny was present , [she]546-his wife calmly observed to [her]546-his wife , “ So , [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny are going to leave [us]3789-us , and live with [[my]546-his wife sister]3790-my sister . How shall [you]113-fanny like it ? ”[546-his wife] [Fanny]113-fanny was too much surprised to do more than repeat [[her]546-his wife aunt]463-her aunt ’s words , “ Going to leave [you]463-her aunt ? ”[546-his wife] “ Yes , [[my]546-his wife dear]3657-my dear ; why should [you]113-fanny be astonished ? [You]113-fanny have been five years with [us]3789-us , and [[my]546-his wife sister]3790-my sister always meant to take [you]113-fanny when [Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris died . But [you]113-fanny must come up and tack on [my]546-his wife patterns all the same . ”[546-his wife] The news was as disagreeable to [Fanny]113-fanny as it had been unexpected . [She]546-his wife had never received kindness from [[her]546-his wife aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris , and could not love [her]105-mrs. norris . “ [I]546-his wife shall be very sorry to go away , ”[546-his wife] said [she]546-his wife , with a faltering voice . “ Yes , [I]546-his wife dare say [you]113-fanny will ; _ that ’s _ natural enough . [I]546-his wife suppose [you]113-fanny have had as little to vex [you]113-fanny since [you]113-fanny came into [this house]3707-this house as any creature in [the world]315-the world . ”[546-his wife] “ [I]113-fanny hope [I]113-fanny am not ungrateful , [aunt]3769-aunt , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny modestly . “ No , [[my]113-fanny dear]3657-my dear ; [I]113-fanny hope not . [I]113-fanny have always found [you]113-fanny [a very good girl]3749-a very good girl . ”[113-fanny] “ And am [I]546-his wife never to live [here]3798-here again ? ”[546-his wife] “ Never , [[my]113-fanny dear]3657-my dear ; but [you]113-fanny are sure of [a comfortable home]3800-a comfortable home . It can make very little difference to [you]113-fanny , whether [you]113-fanny are in [one house]3801-one house or the other . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny left [the room]412-the room with a very sorrowful heart ; [she]550-i could not feel the difference to be so small , [she]550-i could not think of living with [[her]550-i aunt]463-her aunt with anything like satisfaction . As soon as [she]550-i met with [Edmund]108-edmund [she]550-i told [him]108-edmund [her]550-i distress . “ [Cousin]3759-cousin , ”[550-i] said [she]550-i , “ something is going to happen which [I]550-i do not like at all ; and though [you]3759-cousin have often persuaded [me]550-i into being reconciled to things that [I]550-i disliked at first , [you]3759-cousin will not be able to do it now . [I]550-i am going to live entirely with [[my]550-i aunt]3803-my aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris . ”[550-i] “ Indeed ! ”[550-i] “ Yes ; [[my]550-i aunt]3803-my aunt [Bertram]108-edmund has just told [me]550-i so . It is quite settled . [I]550-i am to leave [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and go to [the White House]3805-the white house , [I]550-i suppose , as soon as [she]105-mrs. norris is removed [there]3696-there . ”[550-i] “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , and if the plan were not unpleasant to [you]113-fanny , [I]550-i should call it an excellent one . ”[550-i] “ Oh , [cousin]3759-cousin ! ”[550-i] “ It has everything else in its favour . [[My]550-i aunt]3803-my aunt is acting like [a sensible woman]3809-a sensible woman in wishing for [you]113-fanny . [She]3803-my aunt is choosing [a friend]456-a friend and [companion]3811-companion exactly where [she]3803-my aunt ought , and [I]550-i am glad [her]3803-my aunt love of money does not interfere . [You]113-fanny will be what [you]113-fanny ought to be to [her]3803-my aunt . [I]550-i hope it does not distress [you]113-fanny very much , [Fanny]113-fanny ? ”[550-i] “ Indeed it does : [I]550-i can not like it . [I]550-i love [this house]3707-this house and everything in [it]3707-this house : [I]550-i shall love nothing there . [You]113-fanny know how uncomfortable [I]550-i feel with [her]3803-my aunt . ”[550-i] “ [I]550-i can say nothing for [her]3803-my aunt manner to [you]113-fanny as [a child]376-a child ; but it was the same with [us]3814-us all , or nearly so . [She]3803-my aunt never knew how to be pleasant to [children]339-children . But [you]113-fanny are now of an age to be treated better ; [I]550-i think [she]3803-my aunt is behaving better already ; and when [you]113-fanny are [[her]3803-my aunt only companion]3816-her only companion , [you]113-fanny _ must _ be important to [her]3803-my aunt . ”[550-i] “ [I]550-i can never be important to [any one]3817-any one . ”[550-i] “ What is to prevent [you]550-i ? ”[550-i] “ Everything . [My]550-i situation , [my]550-i foolishness and awkwardness . ”[550-i] “ As to [your]113-fanny foolishness and awkwardness , [[my]550-i dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , believe [me]550-i , [you]113-fanny never have a shadow of either , but in using the words so improperly . There is no reason in [the world]315-the world why [you]113-fanny should not be important where [you]113-fanny are known . [You]113-fanny have good sense , and a sweet temper , and [I]550-i am sure [you]113-fanny have a grateful heart , that could never receive kindness without wishing to return it . [I]550-i do not know any better qualifications for [a friend and companion]3820-a friend and companion . ”[550-i] “ [You]113-fanny are too kind , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , colouring at such praise ; “ how shall [I]113-fanny ever thank [you]113-fanny as [I]113-fanny ought , for thinking so well of [me]113-fanny . Oh ! [cousin]3759-cousin , if [I]113-fanny am to go away , [I]113-fanny shall remember [your]113-fanny goodness to the last moment of [my]113-fanny life . ”[113-fanny] “ Why , indeed , [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]550-i should hope to be remembered at such a distance as [the White House]3805-the white house . [You]113-fanny speak as if [you]113-fanny were going two hundred miles off instead of only across [the park]3753-the park ; but [you]113-fanny will belong to [us]3824-us almost as much as ever . [The two families]3825-the two families will be meeting every day in the year . The only difference will be that , living with [[your]113-fanny aunt]3826-your aunt , [you]113-fanny will necessarily be brought forward as [you]113-fanny ought to be . _ Here _ there are too many whom [you]113-fanny can hide behind ; but with _ [her]3826-your aunt _ [you]113-fanny will be forced to speak for [yourself]113-fanny . ”[550-i] “ Oh ! do not say so . ”[550-i] “ [I]113-fanny must say it , and say it with pleasure . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris is much better fitted than [[my]113-fanny mother]3827-my mother for having the charge of [you]113-fanny now . [She]105-mrs. norris is of a temper to do a great deal for anybody [she]105-mrs. norris really interests [herself]105-mrs. norris about , and [she]105-mrs. norris will force [you]113-fanny to do justice to [your]113-fanny natural powers . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny sighed , and said , “ [I]113-fanny can not see things as [you]113-fanny do ; but [I]113-fanny ought to believe [you]113-fanny to be right rather than [myself]113-fanny , and [I]113-fanny am very much obliged to [you]113-fanny for trying to reconcile [me]113-fanny to what must be . If [I]113-fanny could suppose [[my]113-fanny aunt]3803-my aunt really to care for [me]113-fanny , it would be delightful to feel [myself]113-fanny of consequence to [anybody]3668-anybody . _ Here _ , [I]113-fanny know , [I]113-fanny am of none , and yet [I]113-fanny love [the place]459-the place so well . ”[113-fanny] “ [The place]459-the place , [Fanny]113-fanny , is what [you]113-fanny will not quit , though [you]113-fanny quit [the house]427-the house . [You]113-fanny will have as free a command of [the park]3753-the park and [gardens]3834-gardens as ever . Even _ [your]113-fanny _ constant little heart need not take fright at such a nominal change . [You]113-fanny will have the same walks to frequent , [the same library]3835-the same library to choose from , [the same people]3836-the same people to look at , the same horse to ride . ”[550-i] “ Very true . Yes , [dear old grey pony]3837-dear old grey pony ! Ah ! [cousin]3759-cousin , when [I]550-i remember how much [I]550-i used to dread riding , what terrors it gave [me]550-i to hear it talked of as likely to do [me]550-i good ( oh ! how [I]550-i have trembled at [[my]550-i uncle]3761-my uncle ’s opening [his]3761-my uncle lips if horses were talked of ) , and then think of the kind pains [you]3759-cousin took to reason and persuade [me]550-i out of [my]550-i fears , and convince [me]550-i that [I]550-i should like it after a little while , and feel how right [you]3759-cousin proved to be , [I]550-i am inclined to hope [you]3759-cousin may always prophesy as well . ”[550-i] “ And [I]113-fanny am quite convinced that [your]3759-cousin being with [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris will be as good for [your]3759-cousin mind as riding has been for [your]3759-cousin health , and as much for [your]3759-cousin ultimate happiness too . ”[113-fanny] So ended [their]552-their discourse , which , for any very appropriate service it could render [Fanny]113-fanny , might as well have been spared , for [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had not the smallest intention of taking [her]553-her . It had never occurred to [her]553-her , on the present occasion , but as a thing to be carefully avoided . To prevent its being expected , [she]553-her had fixed on the smallest habitation which could rank as genteel among [the buildings of [Mansfield parish]3-mansfield]554-the buildings of mansfield parish , [the White House]3805-the white house being only just large enough to receive [herself]553-her and [[her]553-her servants]556-her servants , and allow [a spare room]557-a spare room for [a friend]456-a friend , of which [she]553-her made a very particular point . [The spare rooms at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage]559-the spare rooms at the parsonage had never been wanted , but the absolute necessity of [a spare room for [a friend]456-a friend]561-a spare room for a friend was now never forgotten . Not all [her]553-her precautions , however , could save [her]553-her from being suspected of something better ; or , perhaps , [her]553-her very display of the importance of [a spare room]557-a spare room might have misled [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas to suppose it really intended for [Fanny]113-fanny . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram soon brought the matter to a certainty by carelessly observing to [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris — “ [I]105-mrs. norris think , [sister]3704-sister , [we]3841-we need not keep [Miss Lee]110-miss lee any longer , when [Fanny]113-fanny goes to live with [you]3704-sister . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris almost started . “ Live with [me]105-mrs. norris , [dear Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ! what do [you]105-mrs. norris mean ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Is [she]110-miss lee not to live with [you]105-mrs. norris ? [I]105-mrs. norris thought [you]105-mrs. norris had settled it with [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [Me]105-mrs. norris ! never . [I]105-mrs. norris never spoke a syllable about it to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , nor [he]101-sir thomas to [me]105-mrs. norris . [Fanny]113-fanny live with [me]105-mrs. norris ! the last thing in [the world]315-the world for [me]105-mrs. norris to think of , or for [anybody]3668-anybody to wish that really knows [us]3844-us both . Good heaven ! what could [I]105-mrs. norris do with [Fanny]113-fanny ? [Me]105-mrs. norris ! [a poor , helpless , forlorn widow , unfit for anything]3845-a poor , helpless , forlorn widow , unfit for anything , [my]105-mrs. norris spirits quite broke down ; what could [I]105-mrs. norris do with [a girl]3666-a girl at [her]3666-a girl time of life ? [A girl of fifteen]3847-a girl of fifteen ! the very age of all others to need most attention and care , and put the cheerfullest spirits to the test ! [Sure Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could not seriously expect such a thing ! [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas is too much [[my]105-mrs. norris friend]3848-my friend . Nobody that wishes [me]105-mrs. norris well , [I]105-mrs. norris am sure , would propose it .
