How came [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas to speak to [you]105-mrs. norris about it ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Indeed , [I]105-mrs. norris do not know . [I]105-mrs. norris suppose [he]101-sir thomas thought it best . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ But what did [he]101-sir thomas say ? [He]101-sir thomas could not say [he]101-sir thomas _ wished _ [me]105-mrs. norris to take [Fanny]113-fanny . [I]105-mrs. norris am sure in [his]101-sir thomas heart [he]101-sir thomas could not wish [me]105-mrs. norris to do it . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ No ; [he]101-sir thomas only said [he]101-sir thomas thought it very likely ; and [I]105-mrs. norris thought so too . [We]3849-we both thought it would be a comfort to [you]105-mrs. norris . But if [you]105-mrs. norris do not like it , there is no more to be said . [She]3850-she is no encumbrance here . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [Dear sister]3851-dear sister , if [you]105-mrs. norris consider [my]105-mrs. norris unhappy state , how can [she]3850-she be any comfort to [me]105-mrs. norris ? Here am [I]105-mrs. norris , [a poor desolate widow , deprived of the best of husbands]3852-a poor desolate widow , deprived of the best of husbands , [my]105-mrs. norris health gone in attending and nursing [him]101-sir thomas , [my]105-mrs. norris spirits still worse , all [my]105-mrs. norris peace in [this world]3853-this world destroyed , with hardly enough to support [me]105-mrs. norris in the rank of [a gentlewoman]3683-a gentlewoman , and enable [me]105-mrs. norris to live so as not to disgrace the memory of [the dear departed]3855-the dear departed — what possible comfort could [I]105-mrs. norris have in taking such a charge upon [me]105-mrs. norris as [Fanny]113-fanny ? If [I]105-mrs. norris could wish it for [my]105-mrs. norris own sake , [I]105-mrs. norris would not do so unjust a thing by [the poor girl]3856-the poor girl . [She]3856-the poor girl is in good hands , and sure of doing well . [I]105-mrs. norris must struggle through [my]105-mrs. norris sorrows and difficulties as [I]105-mrs. norris can . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Then [you]105-mrs. norris will not mind living by [yourself]105-mrs. norris quite alone ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , [I]105-mrs. norris do not complain . [I]105-mrs. norris know [I]105-mrs. norris can not live as [I]105-mrs. norris have done , but [I]105-mrs. norris must retrench where [I]105-mrs. norris can , and learn to be [a better manager]3857-a better manager . [I]105-mrs. norris _ have _ _ been _ [a liberal housekeeper]3858-a liberal housekeeper enough , but [I]105-mrs. norris shall not be ashamed to practise economy now . [My]105-mrs. norris situation is as much altered as [my]105-mrs. norris income . A great many things were due from [poor Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris , as [clergyman of [the parish]3860-the parish]3859-clergyman of the parish , that can not be expected from [me]105-mrs. norris . It is unknown how much was consumed in [[our]3861-our kitchen]3862-our kitchen by [odd comers]3863-odd comers and [goers]3864-goers . At [the White House]3805-the white house , matters must be better looked after . [I]105-mrs. norris _ must _ live within [my]105-mrs. norris income , or [I]105-mrs. norris shall be miserable ; and [I]105-mrs. norris own it would give [me]105-mrs. norris great satisfaction to be able to do rather more , to lay by a little at the end of the year . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]105-mrs. norris dare say [you]105-mrs. norris will . [You]105-mrs. norris always do , do n’t [you]105-mrs. norris ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [My]105-mrs. norris object , [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , is to be of use to those that come after [me]105-mrs. norris . It is for [[your]106-lady bertram children]3866-your children ’s good that [I]105-mrs. norris wish to be richer . [I]105-mrs. norris have [nobody else to care for]3867-nobody else to care for , but [I]105-mrs. norris should be very glad to think [I]105-mrs. norris could leave a little trifle among [them]3866-your children worth [their]3866-your children having . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [You]105-mrs. norris are very good , but do not trouble [yourself]105-mrs. norris about [them]3866-your children . [They]3866-your children are sure of being well provided for . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas will take care of that . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Why , [you]105-mrs. norris know , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s means will be rather straitened if [the Antigua estate]3868-the antigua estate is to make such poor returns . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Oh ! _ that _ will soon be settled . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas has been writing about it , [I]105-mrs. norris know . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Well , [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , ”[105-mrs. norris] said [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , moving to go , “ [I]105-mrs. norris can only say that [my]105-mrs. norris sole desire is to be of use to [[your]106-lady bertram family]3869-your family : and so , if [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas should ever speak again about [my]105-mrs. norris taking [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]106-lady bertram will be able to say that [my]105-mrs. norris health and spirits put it quite out of the question ; besides that , [I]105-mrs. norris really should not have a bed to give [her]542-his sister - in - law , for [I]105-mrs. norris must keep [a spare room for [a friend]456-a friend]561-a spare room for a friend . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram repeated enough of this conversation to [[her]106-lady bertram husband]325-her husband to convince [him]325-her husband how much [he]325-her husband had mistaken [[his]325-her husband sister - in - law]542-his sister - in - law ’s views ; and [she]106-lady bertram was from that moment perfectly safe from all expectation , or the slightest allusion to it from [him]325-her husband . [He]325-her husband could not but wonder at [her]106-lady bertram refusing to do anything for [a niece whom [she]106-lady bertram had been so forward to adopt]566-a niece whom she had been so forward to adopt ; but , as [she]106-lady bertram took early care to make [him]325-her husband , as well as [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , understand that whatever [she]106-lady bertram possessed was designed for [[their]567-their family]568-their family , [he]325-her husband soon grew reconciled to a distinction which , at the same time that it was advantageous and complimentary to [them]567-their , would enable [him]325-her husband better to provide for [Fanny]113-fanny [himself]325-her husband . [Fanny]113-fanny soon learnt how unnecessary had been [her]106-lady bertram fears of a removal ; and [her]106-lady bertram spontaneous , untaught felicity on the discovery , conveyed some consolation to [Edmund]108-edmund for [his]108-edmund disappointment in what [he]108-edmund had expected to be so essentially serviceable to [her]106-lady bertram . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris took possession of [the White House]3805-the white house , [the Grants]122-the grants arrived at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , and these events over , everything at [Mansfield]3-mansfield went on for some time as usual . [The Grants]122-the grants showing a disposition to be friendly and sociable , gave great satisfaction in the main among [[their]122-the grants new acquaintance]571-their new acquaintance . [They]122-the grants had [their]122-the grants faults , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris soon found [them]122-the grants out . [The Doctor]572-the doctor was very fond of eating , and would have a good dinner every day ; and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , instead of contriving to gratify [him]108-edmund at little expense , gave [her]123-mrs. grant cook as high wages as [they]122-the grants did at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and was scarcely ever seen in [[her]123-mrs. grant offices]573-her offices . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could not speak with any temper of such grievances , nor of the quantity of butter and eggs that were regularly consumed in [the house]427-the house . “ [Nobody]360-nobody loved plenty and hospitality more than [herself]360-nobody ; [nobody]360-nobody more hated pitiful doings ; [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , [she]105-mrs. norris believed , had never been wanting in comforts of any sort , had never borne a bad character in _ [her]105-mrs. norris _ _ time _ , but this was a way of going on that [she]105-mrs. norris could not understand . [A fine lady in [a country parsonage]3876-a country parsonage]3875-a fine lady in a country parsonage was quite out of place . _ [[Her]105-mrs. norris _ store - room]3877-her _ store - room , [she]105-mrs. norris thought , might have been good enough for [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant to go into . Inquire where [she]105-mrs. norris would , [she]105-mrs. norris could not find out that [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant had ever had more than five thousand pounds . ”[106-lady bertram] [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram listened without much interest to this sort of invective . [She]106-lady bertram could not enter into the wrongs of [an economist]575-an economist , but [she]106-lady bertram felt all the injuries of beauty in [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s being so well settled in life without being handsome , and expressed [her]106-lady bertram astonishment on that point almost as often , though not so diffusely , as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris discussed the other . These opinions had been hardly canvassed a year before another event arose of such importance in [the family]3724-the family , as might fairly claim some place in the thoughts and conversation of [the ladies]577-the ladies . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas found it expedient to go to [Antigua]18-antigua [himself]101-sir thomas , for the better arrangement of [his]101-sir thomas affairs , and [he]101-sir thomas took [[his]101-sir thomas eldest son]496-his eldest son with [him]101-sir thomas , in the hope of detaching [him]496-his eldest son from some bad connexions at [home]367-home . [They]580-they left [England]14-england with the probability of being nearly a twelvemonth absent . The necessity of the measure in a pecuniary light , and the hope of its utility to [[his]101-sir thomas son]581-his son , reconciled [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas to the effort of quitting the rest of [[his]101-sir thomas family]582-his family , and of leaving [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters to the direction of [others]361-others at [their]498-his daughters present most interesting time of life . [He]101-sir thomas could not think [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram quite equal to supply [his]101-sir thomas place with [them]498-his daughters , or rather , to perform what should have been [her]106-lady bertram own ; but , in [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s watchful attention , and in [Edmund]108-edmund ’s judgment , [he]101-sir thomas had sufficient confidence to make [him]101-sir thomas go without fears for [their]580-they conduct . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram did not at all like to have [[her]106-lady bertram husband]325-her husband leave [her]106-lady bertram ; but [she]106-lady bertram was not disturbed by any alarm for [his]325-her husband safety , or solicitude for [his]325-her husband comfort , being [one of [those persons who think nothing can be dangerous]587-those persons who think nothing can be dangerous , or difficult , or fatiguing to anybody but [themselves]587-those persons who think nothing can be dangerous]586-one of those persons who think nothing can be dangerous , or difficult , or fatiguing to anybody but themselves . [The Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams were much to be pitied on the occasion : not for [their]498-his daughters sorrow , but for [their]498-his daughters want of it . [[Their]498-his daughters father]398-their father was no object of love to [them]498-his daughters ; [he]398-their father had never seemed the friend of [their]498-his daughters pleasures , and [his]398-their father absence was unhappily most welcome . [They]498-his daughters were relieved by it from all restraint ; and without aiming at one gratification that would probably have been forbidden by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [they]498-his daughters felt [themselves]498-his daughters immediately at [their]498-his daughters own disposal , and to have every indulgence within [their]498-his daughters reach . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s relief , and [her]589-her consciousness of it , were quite equal to [[her]589-her cousins]3671-her cousins ’ ; but a more tender nature suggested that [her]589-her feelings were ungrateful , and [she]589-her really grieved because [she]589-her could not grieve . “ [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , who had done so much for [her]589-her and [[her]589-her brothers]3878-her brothers , and who was gone perhaps never to return ! that [she]589-her should see [him]101-sir thomas go without a tear ! it was a shameful insensibility . ”[101-sir thomas] [He]101-sir thomas had said to [her]589-her , moreover , on the very last morning , that [he]101-sir thomas hoped [she]589-her might see [William]228-william again in the course of the ensuing winter , and had charged [her]589-her to write and invite [him]101-sir thomas to [Mansfield]3-mansfield as soon as [the squadron to which [he]101-sir thomas belonged]591-the squadron to which he belonged should be known to be in [England]14-england . “ This was so thoughtful and kind ! ”[101-sir thomas] and would [he]101-sir thomas only have smiled upon [her]589-her , and called [her]589-her “ [[my]101-sir thomas dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[101-sir thomas] while [he]101-sir thomas said it , every former frown or cold address might have been forgotten . But [he]101-sir thomas had ended [his]101-sir thomas speech in a way to sink [her]589-her in sad mortification , by adding , “ If [William]228-william does come to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [I]101-sir thomas hope [you]589-her may be able to convince [him]228-william that the many years which have passed since [you]589-her parted have not been spent on [your]589-her side entirely without improvement ; though , [I]101-sir thomas fear , [he]228-william must find [[his]228-william sister]511-his sister at sixteen in some respects too much like [[his]228-william sister]511-his sister at ten . ”[101-sir thomas] [She]589-her cried bitterly over this reflection when [[her]589-her uncle]312-her uncle was gone ; and [[her]589-her cousins]3671-her cousins , on seeing [her]589-her with red eyes , set [her]589-her down as [a hypocrite]594-a hypocrite . CHAPTER IV [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas had of late spent so little of [his]101-sir thomas time at [home]367-home that [he]101-sir thomas could be only nominally missed ; and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was soon astonished to find how very well [they]596-they did even without [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father , how well [Edmund]108-edmund could supply [his]108-edmund place in [carving]598-carving , talking to [the steward]599-the steward , writing to [the attorney]600-the attorney , settling with [the servants]601-the servants , and equally saving [her]106-lady bertram from all possible fatigue or exertion in every particular but that of directing [her]106-lady bertram letters . The earliest intelligence of [the travellers]602-the travellers ’ safe arrival at [Antigua]18-antigua , after a favourable voyage , was received ; though not before [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had been indulging in very dreadful fears , and trying to make [Edmund]108-edmund participate [them]603-them whenever [she]105-mrs. norris could get [him]108-edmund alone ; and as [she]105-mrs. norris depended on being [the first person made acquainted with any fatal catastrophe]604-the first person made acquainted with any fatal catastrophe , [she]105-mrs. norris had already arranged the manner of breaking it to [all the others]605-all the others , when [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s assurances of [their]606-their both being alive and well made it necessary to lay by [her]105-mrs. norris agitation and affectionate preparatory speeches for a while . The winter came and passed without [their]606-their being called for ; the accounts continued perfectly good ; and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , in promoting gaieties for [[her]105-mrs. norris nieces]478-her nieces , assisting [their]478-her nieces toilets , displaying [their]478-her nieces accomplishments , and looking about for [[their]478-her nieces future husbands]608-their future husbands , had so much to do as , in addition to all [her]105-mrs. norris own household cares , some interference in those of [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister , and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s wasteful doings to overlook , left [her]105-mrs. norris very little occasion to be occupied in fears for the absent . [The Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams were now fully established among [the belles of [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood]610-the belles of the neighbourhood ; and as [they]606-their joined to beauty and brilliant acquirements a manner naturally easy , and carefully formed to general civility and obligingness , [they]606-their possessed its favour as well as its admiration . [Their]606-their vanity was in such good order that [they]606-their seemed to be quite free from it , and gave [themselves]606-their no airs ; while the praises attending such behaviour , secured and brought round by [[their]606-their aunt]468-their aunt , served to strengthen [them]606-their in believing [they]606-their had no faults . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram did not go into public with [[her]106-lady bertram daughters]480-her daughters . [She]106-lady bertram was too indolent even to accept [a mother]614-a mother ’s gratification in witnessing [their]480-her daughters success and enjoyment at the expense of any personal trouble , and the charge was made over to [[her]106-lady bertram sister]331-her sister , who desired nothing better than a post of such honourable representation , and very thoroughly relished the means it afforded [her]106-lady bertram of mixing in society without having horses to hire . [Fanny]113-fanny had no share in the festivities of the season ; but [she]106-lady bertram enjoyed being avowedly useful as [[[her]106-lady bertram aunt]463-her aunt ’s companion when [they]480-her daughters called away [the rest of [the family]3724-the family]618-the rest of the family]617-her aunt ’s companion when they called away the rest of the family ; and , as [Miss Lee]110-miss lee had left [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [she]110-miss lee naturally became everything to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram during the night of a ball or a party . [She]110-miss lee talked to [her]110-miss lee , listened to [her]110-miss lee , read to [her]110-miss lee ; and the tranquillity of such evenings , [her]110-miss lee perfect security in such a _ tête - à - tête _ from any sound of unkindness , was unspeakably welcome to a mind which had seldom known a pause in its alarms or embarrassments . As to [[her]106-lady bertram cousins]3671-her cousins ’ gaieties , [she]106-lady bertram loved to hear an account of [them]3671-her cousins , especially of the balls , and whom [Edmund]108-edmund had danced with ; but thought too lowly of [her]106-lady bertram own situation to imagine [she]106-lady bertram should ever be admitted to the same , and listened , therefore , without an idea of any nearer concern in [them]3671-her cousins . Upon the whole , it was a comfortable winter to [her]106-lady bertram ; for though it brought [no William]621-no william to [England]14-england , the never - failing hope of [his]621-no william arrival was worth much . The ensuing spring deprived [her]106-lady bertram of [[her]106-lady bertram valued friend]622-her valued friend , [the old grey pony]623-the old grey pony ; and for some time [she]106-lady bertram was in danger of feeling the loss in [her]106-lady bertram health as well as in [her]106-lady bertram affections ; for in spite of the acknowledged importance of [her]106-lady bertram riding on horse - back , no measures were taken for mounting [her]106-lady bertram again , “ because , ”[624-her aunts] as it was observed by [[her]106-lady bertram aunts]624-her aunts , “ [she]106-lady bertram might ride one of [[her]106-lady bertram cousin]3692-her cousin ’s horses at any time when [they]624-her aunts did not want them , ”[624-her aunts] and as [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams regularly wanted [their]624-her aunts horses every fine day , and had no idea of carrying [their]624-her aunts obliging manners to the sacrifice of any real pleasure , that time , of course , never came . [They]624-her aunts took [their]624-her aunts cheerful rides in the fine mornings of April and May ; and [Fanny]113-fanny either sat at [home]367-home the whole day with [one aunt]626-one aunt , or walked beyond [her]106-lady bertram strength at the instigation of the other : [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram holding exercise to be as unnecessary for [everybody]408-everybody as it was unpleasant to [herself]106-lady bertram ; and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , who was walking all day , thinking [everybody]408-everybody ought to walk as much . [Edmund]108-edmund was absent at this time , or the evil would have been earlier remedied . When [he]108-edmund returned , to understand how [Fanny]113-fanny was situated , and perceived its ill effects , there seemed with [him]108-edmund but one thing to be done ; and that “ [Fanny]113-fanny must have a horse ”[108-edmund] was the resolute declaration with which [he]108-edmund opposed whatever could be urged by the supineness of [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother , or the economy of [[his]108-edmund aunt]630-his aunt , to make it appear unimportant . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could not help thinking that some steady old thing might be found among the numbers belonging to [the Park]3753-the park that would do vastly well ; or that one might be borrowed of [the steward]599-the steward ; or that perhaps [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant might now and then lend [them]633-them the pony [he]121-dr. grant sent to the post . [She]105-mrs. norris could not but consider it as absolutely unnecessary , and even improper , that [Fanny]113-fanny should have [a regular lady]634-a regular lady ’s horse of [her]105-mrs. norris own , in the style of [[her]105-mrs. norris cousins]3671-her cousins . [She]105-mrs. norris was sure [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had never intended it : and [she]105-mrs. norris must say that , to be making such a purchase in [his]101-sir thomas absence , and adding to the great expenses of [[his]101-sir thomas stable]636-his stable , at a time when a large part of [his]101-sir thomas income was unsettled , seemed to [her]105-mrs. norris very unjustifiable . “ [Fanny]113-fanny must have a horse , ”[106-lady bertram] was [Edmund]108-edmund ’s only reply . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could not see it in the same light . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram did : [she]106-lady bertram entirely agreed with [[her]106-lady bertram son]637-her son as to the necessity of it , and as to its being considered necessary by [[his]637-her son father]534-his father ; [she]106-lady bertram only pleaded against there being any hurry ; [she]106-lady bertram only wanted [him]637-her son to wait till [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s return , and then [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas might settle it all [himself]101-sir thomas . [He]637-her son would be at [home]367-home in September , and where would be the harm of only waiting till September ? Though [Edmund]108-edmund was much more displeased with [[his]108-edmund aunt]630-his aunt than with [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother , as evincing least regard for [[her]630-his aunt niece]642-her niece , [he]108-edmund could not help paying more attention to what [she]630-his aunt said ; and at length determined on a method of proceeding which would obviate the risk of [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father ’s thinking [he]108-edmund had done too much , and at the same time procure for [Fanny]113-fanny the immediate means of exercise , which [he]108-edmund could not bear [she]630-his aunt should be without . [He]108-edmund had three horses of [his]108-edmund own , but not one that would carry [a woman]644-a woman . Two of [them]645-them were [hunters]646-hunters ; the third , a useful road - horse : this third [he]108-edmund resolved to exchange for one that [[his]108-edmund cousin]453-his cousin might ride ; [he]108-edmund knew where such a one was to be met with ; and having once made up [his]108-edmund mind , the whole business was soon completed . The new mare proved a treasure ; with a very little trouble [she]630-his aunt became exactly calculated for the purpose , and [Fanny]113-fanny was then put in almost full possession of [her]630-his aunt . [She]630-his aunt had not supposed before that anything could ever suit [her]630-his aunt like the old grey pony ; but [her]630-his aunt delight in [Edmund]108-edmund ’s mare was far beyond any former pleasure of the sort ; and the addition it was ever receiving in the consideration of that kindness from which [her]630-his aunt pleasure sprung , was beyond all [her]630-his aunt words to express . [She]630-his aunt regarded [[her]630-his aunt cousin]3692-her cousin as an example of everything good and great , as possessing worth which [no one]404-no one but [herself]630-his aunt could ever appreciate , and as entitled to such gratitude from [her]630-his aunt as no feelings could be strong enough to pay . [Her]630-his aunt sentiments towards [him]3692-her cousin were compounded of all that was respectful , grateful , confiding , and tender . As the horse continued in name , as well as fact , [the property of [Edmund]108-edmund]650-the property of edmund , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could tolerate its being for [Fanny]113-fanny ’s use ; and had [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ever thought about [her]106-lady bertram own objection again , [he]3692-her cousin might have been excused in [her]106-lady bertram eyes for not waiting till [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s return in September , for when [September]124-september came [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was still abroad , and without any near prospect of finishing [his]101-sir thomas business . Unfavourable circumstances had suddenly arisen at a moment when [he]101-sir thomas was beginning to turn all [his]101-sir thomas thoughts towards [England]14-england ; and the very great uncertainty in which everything was then involved determined [him]101-sir thomas on sending [home]367-home [[his]101-sir thomas son]581-his son , and waiting the final arrangement by [himself]101-sir thomas . [Tom]101-sir thomas arrived safely , bringing an excellent account of [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father ’s health ; but to very little purpose , as far as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was concerned . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s sending away [[his]101-sir thomas son]581-his son seemed to [her]106-lady bertram so like [a parent]655-a parent ’s care , under the influence of a foreboding of evil to [himself]101-sir thomas , that [she]106-lady bertram could not help feeling dreadful presentiments ; and as the long evenings of autumn came on , was so terribly haunted by these ideas , in the sad solitariness of [[her]106-lady bertram cottage]656-her cottage , as to be obliged to take daily refuge in [the dining - room of [the Park]3753-the park]657-the dining - room of the park . The return of winter engagements , however , was not without its effect ; and in the course of [their]659-their progress , [her]106-lady bertram mind became so pleasantly occupied in superintending the fortunes of [[her]106-lady bertram eldest niece]660-her eldest niece , as tolerably to quiet [her]106-lady bertram nerves . “ If [poor Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas were fated never to return , it would be peculiarly consoling to see [[their]659-their dear]3883-their dear [Maria]100-maria well married , ”[106-lady bertram] [she]106-lady bertram very often thought ; always when [they]659-their were in the company of [men of fortune]661-men of fortune , and particularly on the introduction of [a young man who had recently succeeded to [one of the largest estates and finest places in [the country]493-the country]663-one of the largest estates and finest places in the country]662-a young man who had recently succeeded to one of the largest estates and finest places in the country . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was from the first struck with the beauty of [Miss Bertram]112-julia , and , being inclined to marry , soon fancied [himself]113-fanny in love . [He]113-fanny was [a heavy young man , with not more than common sense]665-a heavy young man , with not more than common sense ; but as there was nothing disagreeable in [his]113-fanny figure or address , [the young lady]666-the young lady was well pleased with [her]666-the young lady conquest . Being now in [her]112-julia twenty - first year , [Maria Bertram]126-maria was beginning to think matrimony a duty ; and as a marriage with [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny would give [her]112-julia the enjoyment of a larger income than [[her]112-julia father]667-her father ’s , as well as ensure [her]112-julia [the house in [town]3698-town]491-the house in town , which was now a prime object , it became , by the same rule of moral obligation , [her]112-julia evident duty to marry [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny if [she]112-julia could . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was most zealous in promoting the match , by every suggestion and contrivance likely to enhance its desirableness to [either party]670-either party ; and , among other means , by seeking an intimacy with [[the gentleman]671-the gentleman ’s mother]672-the gentleman ’s mother , who at present lived with [him]113-fanny , and to whom [she]672-the gentleman ’s mother even forced [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram to go through ten miles of [indifferent road]673-indifferent road to pay a morning visit . It was not long before a good understanding took place between [this lady]674-this lady and [herself]674-this lady . [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria acknowledged [herself]126-maria very desirous that [[her]126-maria son]637-her son should marry , and declared that of [all the young ladies [she]126-maria had ever seen]676-all the young ladies she had ever seen , [Miss Bertram]112-julia seemed , by [her]112-julia amiable qualities and accomplishments , the best adapted to make [him]113-fanny happy . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris accepted the compliment , and admired the nice discernment of character which could so well distinguish merit . [Maria]126-maria was indeed the pride and delight of [them]677-them all — perfectly faultless — [an angel]3680-an angel ; and , of course , so surrounded by [admirers]679-admirers , must be difficult in [her]126-maria choice : but yet , as far as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could allow [herself]105-mrs. norris to decide on so short an acquaintance , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny appeared precisely [the young man]680-the young man to deserve and attach [her]126-maria . After dancing with [each other]681-each other at a proper number of balls , [the young people]391-the young people justified these opinions , and an engagement , with a due reference to [the absent Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , was entered into , much to the satisfaction of [[their]391-the young people respective families]683-their respective families , and of [the general lookers - on of the neighbourhood]684-the general lookers - on of the neighbourhood , who had , for many weeks past , felt the expediency of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s marrying [Miss Bertram]112-julia . It was some months before [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s consent could be received ; but , in the meanwhile , as [no one]404-no one felt a doubt of [his]101-sir thomas most cordial pleasure in the connexion , the intercourse of [the two families]3825-the two families was carried on without restraint , and no other attempt made at secrecy than [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s talking of it everywhere as a matter not to be talked of at present . [Edmund]108-edmund was [the only one of [the family who could see a fault in the business]688-the family who could see a fault in the business]687-the only one of the family who could see a fault in the business ; but no representation of [[his]108-edmund aunt]630-his aunt ’s could induce [him]108-edmund to find [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny a desirable companion . [He]108-edmund could allow [[his]108-edmund sister]511-his sister to be the best judge of [her]511-his sister own happiness , but [he]108-edmund was not pleased that [her]511-his sister happiness should centre in a large income ; nor could [he]108-edmund refrain from often saying to [himself]108-edmund , in [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s company—“If [this man]3884-this man had not twelve thousand a year , [he]3884-this man would be [a very stupid fellow]3885-a very stupid fellow . ”[108-edmund] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , however , was truly happy in the prospect of an alliance so unquestionably advantageous , and of which [he]101-sir thomas heard nothing but the perfectly good and agreeable . It was a connexion exactly of the right sort — in [the same county]691-the same county , and the same interest — and [his]101-sir thomas most hearty concurrence was conveyed as soon as possible . [He]101-sir thomas only conditioned that the marriage should not take place before [his]101-sir thomas return , which [he]101-sir thomas was again looking eagerly forward to . [He]101-sir thomas wrote in April , and had strong hopes of settling everything to [his]101-sir thomas entire satisfaction , and leaving [Antigua]18-antigua before the end of the summer . Such was the state of affairs in the month of July ; and [Fanny]113-fanny had just reached [her]692-her eighteenth year , when [the society of [the village]524-the village]693-the society of the village received an addition in [the brother]695-the brother and sister of [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , [a Mr.]696-a mr. and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , [the children of [[her]692-her mother]446-her mother]697-the children of her mother by a second marriage . [They]699-their were [young people of fortune]700-young people of fortune . [The son]701-the son had [a good estate in [Norfolk]19-norfolk]702-a good estate in norfolk , [the daughter]703-the daughter twenty thousand pounds . As [children]339-children , [[their]699-their sister]705-their sister had been always very fond of [them]699-their ; but , as [her]705-their sister own marriage had been soon followed by the death of [[their]699-their common parent]706-their common parent , which left [them]699-their to the care of [a brother of [[their]699-their father]398-their father , of whom [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant]707-a brother of their father , of whom mrs. grant knew nothing , [she]123-mrs. grant had scarcely seen [them]699-their since . In [[[their]699-their uncle]709-their uncle ’s house]710-their uncle ’s house [they]699-their had found [a kind home]711-a kind home . [Admiral]128-admiral crawford and [Mrs. Crawford]129-mrs. crawford , though agreeing in nothing else , were united in affection for [these children]712-these children , or , at least , were no farther adverse in [their]699-their feelings than that each had [[their]699-their favourite]713-their favourite , to whom [they]699-their showed the greatest fondness of [the two]390-the two . [The Admiral]715-the admiral delighted in [the boy]513-the boy , [Mrs. Crawford]129-mrs. crawford doted on [the girl]514-the girl ; and it was [the lady]718-the lady ’s death which now obliged [[her]718-the lady _ protegee]719-her _ protegee _ , after some months ’ further trial at [[[her]718-the lady uncle]312-her uncle ’s house]721-her uncle ’s house , to find [another home]722-another home . [Admiral Crawford]128-admiral crawford was [a man of vicious conduct]723-a man of vicious conduct , who chose , instead of retaining [[his]128-admiral crawford niece]724-his niece , to bring [[his]128-admiral crawford mistress]725-his mistress under [his]128-admiral crawford own roof ; and to this [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant was indebted for [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister ’s proposal of coming to [her]123-mrs. grant , a measure quite as welcome on one side as it could be expedient on the other ; for [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , having by this time run through the usual resources of ladies residing in [the country]493-the country without [a family of children]728-a family of children — having more than filled [[her]123-mrs. grant favourite sitting - room]729-her favourite sitting - room with pretty furniture , and made a choice collection of plants and poultry — was very much in want of some variety at [home]367-home . The arrival , therefore , of [a sister whom [she]123-mrs. grant had always loved , and now hoped to retain with [her]123-mrs. grant as long as [she]123-mrs. grant remained single]731-a sister whom she had always loved , and now hoped to retain with her as long as she remained single , was highly agreeable ; and [her]123-mrs. grant chief anxiety was lest [Mansfield]130-mansfield should not satisfy the habits of [a young woman who had been mostly used to [London]6-london]732-a young woman who had been mostly used to london . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was not entirely free from similar apprehensions , though they arose principally from doubts of [[her]127-miss crawford sister]331-her sister ’s style of living and tone of society ; and it was not till after [she]127-miss crawford had tried in vain to persuade [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother to settle with [her]127-miss crawford at [[his]451-her brother own country house]735-his own country house , that [she]127-miss crawford could resolve to hazard [herself]127-miss crawford among [her]127-miss crawford other relations . To anything like a permanence of abode , or limitation of society , [Henry Crawford]131-henry had , unluckily , a great dislike : [he]131-henry could not accommodate [[his]131-henry sister]511-his sister in an article of such importance ; but [he]131-henry escorted [her]511-his sister , with the utmost kindness , into [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire , and as readily engaged to fetch [her]511-his sister away again , at half an hour ’s notice , whenever [she]511-his sister were weary of [the place]459-the place . The meeting was very satisfactory on each side . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford found [a sister without preciseness or rusticity]738-a sister without preciseness or rusticity , [[a sister]3681-a sister ’s husband who looked [the gentleman]671-the gentleman , and [a house]742-a house commodious and well fitted up]740-a sister ’s husband who looked the gentleman , and a house commodious and well fitted up ; and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant received in those whom [she]123-mrs. grant hoped to love better than ever [a young man]743-a young man and [woman of very prepossessing appearance]744-woman of very prepossessing appearance . [Mary Crawford]132-mary was remarkably pretty ; [Henry]131-henry , though not handsome , had air and countenance ; the manners of both were lively and pleasant , and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant immediately gave [them]745-them credit for everything else . [She]123-mrs. grant was delighted with each , but [Mary]132-mary was [her]123-mrs. grant dearest object ; and having never been able to glory in beauty of [her]123-mrs. grant own , [she]123-mrs. grant thoroughly enjoyed the power of being proud of [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister ’s . [She]123-mrs. grant had not waited [her]123-mrs. grant arrival to look out for a suitable match for [her]123-mrs. grant : [she]123-mrs. grant had fixed on [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas ; [the eldest son of a baronet]747-the eldest son of a baronet was not too good for [a girl of twenty thousand pounds]748-a girl of twenty thousand pounds , with all the elegance and accomplishments which [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant foresaw in [her]123-mrs. grant ; and being [a warm - hearted , unreserved woman]749-a warm - hearted , unreserved woman , [Mary]132-mary had not been three hours in [the house]427-the house before [she]132-mary told [her]132-mary what [she]132-mary had planned . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was glad to find [a family of such consequence]751-a family of such consequence so very near [them]752-them , and not at all displeased either at [[her]127-miss crawford sister]331-her sister ’s early care , or the choice it had fallen on . Matrimony was [her]127-miss crawford object , provided [she]127-miss crawford could marry well : and having seen [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund in [town]3698-town , [she]127-miss crawford knew that objection could no more be made to [[his]108-edmund person]755-his person than to [his]108-edmund situation in life . While [she]127-miss crawford treated it as a joke , therefore , [she]127-miss crawford did not forget to think of it seriously . The scheme was soon repeated to [Henry]131-henry . “ And now , ”[123-mrs. grant] added [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , “ [I]123-mrs. grant have thought of something to make it complete . [I]123-mrs. grant should dearly love to settle [you]131-henry both in [this country]3672-this country ; and therefore , [Henry]131-henry , [you]131-henry shall marry [the youngest [Miss Bertram]112-julia]3887-the youngest miss bertram , [a nice , handsome , good - humoured , accomplished girl , who will make [you]131-henry very happy]3888-a nice , handsome , good - humoured , accomplished girl , who will make you very happy . ”[123-mrs. grant] [Henry]131-henry bowed and thanked [her]127-miss crawford . “ [[My]132-mary dear sister]3889-my dear sister , ”[132-mary] said [Mary]132-mary , “ if [you]3889-my dear sister can persuade [him]131-henry into anything of the sort , it will be a fresh matter of delight to [me]132-mary to find [myself]132-mary allied to [anybody so clever]3890-anybody so clever , and [I]132-mary shall only regret that [you]3889-my dear sister have [not half a dozen daughters]3891-not half a dozen daughters to dispose of . If [you]3889-my dear sister can persuade [Henry]131-henry to marry , [you]3889-my dear sister must have the address of [a Frenchwoman]3892-a frenchwoman . All that English abilities can do has been tried already . [I]132-mary have [three very particular friends]3893-three very particular friends who have been all dying for [him]131-henry in [their]3893-three very particular friends turn ; and the pains which [they]3893-three very particular friends , [[their]3893-three very particular friends mothers]3894-their mothers ( [very clever women]3895-very clever women ) , as well as [[my]132-mary dear aunt]3896-my dear aunt and [myself]132-mary , have taken to reason , coax , or trick [him]131-henry into marrying , is inconceivable ! [He]131-henry is [the most horrible flirt that can be imagined]3897-the most horrible flirt that can be imagined . If [[your]3889-my dear sister [Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams]3898-your miss bertrams do not like to have [their]3898-your miss bertrams hearts broke , let [them]3898-your miss bertrams avoid [Henry]131-henry . ”[132-mary] “ [[My]123-mrs. grant dear brother]3899-my dear brother , [I]123-mrs. grant will not believe this of [you]3899-my dear brother . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ No , [I]132-mary am sure [you]3899-my dear brother are too good . [You]3899-my dear brother will be kinder than [Mary]132-mary . [You]3899-my dear brother will allow for the doubts of youth and inexperience . [I]132-mary am of a cautious temper , and unwilling to risk [my]132-mary happiness in a hurry . [Nobody]360-nobody can think more highly of the matrimonial state than [myself]132-mary . [I]132-mary consider the blessing of [a wife]537-a wife as most justly described in those discreet lines of the poet—‘Heaven ’s _ last _ best gift . ’ ”[132-mary] “ There , [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , [you]123-mrs. grant see how [he]131-henry dwells on one word , and only look at [his]131-henry smile . [I]123-mrs. grant assure [you]123-mrs. grant [he]131-henry is very detestable ; [the Admiral]715-the admiral ’s lessons have quite spoiled [him]131-henry . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ [I]123-mrs. grant pay very little regard , ”[123-mrs. grant] said [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , “ to what [any young person]3903-any young person says on the subject of marriage . If [they]3903-any young person profess a disinclination for it , [I]123-mrs. grant only set it down that [they]3903-any young person have not yet seen [the right person]3904-the right person . ”[123-mrs. grant] [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant laughingly congratulated [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford on feeling no disinclination to [the state]756-the state [herself]127-miss crawford . “ Oh yes ! [I]121-dr. grant am not at all ashamed of it . [I]121-dr. grant would have [everybody]408-everybody marry if [they]408-everybody can do it properly : [I]121-dr. grant do not like to have [people]3906-people throw [themselves]3906-people away ; but [everybody]408-everybody should marry as soon as [they]408-everybody can do it to advantage . ”[121-dr. grant] CHAPTER V [The young people]391-the young people were pleased with [each other]681-each other from the first . On each side there was much to attract , and [their]391-the young people acquaintance soon promised as early an intimacy as good manners would warrant . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s beauty did [her]127-miss crawford no disservice with [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams . [They]391-the young people were too handsome [themselves]391-the young people to dislike [any woman]759-any woman for being so too , and were almost as much charmed as [[their]391-the young people brothers]760-their brothers with [her]127-miss crawford lively dark eye , clear brown complexion , and general prettiness . Had [she]127-miss crawford been tall , full formed , and fair , it might have been more of a trial : but as it was , there could be no comparison ; and [she]127-miss crawford was most allowably [a sweet , pretty girl]761-a sweet , pretty girl , while [they]391-the young people were [the finest young women in [the country]493-the country]762-the finest young women in the country . [[Her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother was not handsome : no , when [they]391-the young people first saw [him]451-her brother [he]451-her brother was absolutely plain , black and plain ; but still [he]451-her brother was [the gentleman]671-the gentleman , with a pleasing address . The second meeting proved [him]451-her brother not so very plain : [he]451-her brother was plain , to be sure , but then [he]451-her brother had so much countenance , and [his]451-her brother teeth were so good , and [he]451-her brother was so well made , that [one]766-one soon forgot [he]451-her brother was plain ; and after a third interview , after dining in company with [him]451-her brother at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , [he]451-her brother was no longer allowed to be called so by [anybody]3668-anybody . [He]451-her brother was , in fact , [the most agreeable young man [the sisters]327-the sisters had ever known]769-the most agreeable young man the sisters had ever known , and [they]327-the sisters were equally delighted with [him]451-her brother . [Miss Bertram]112-julia ’s engagement made [him]451-her brother in equity [the property of [Julia]112-julia]771-the property of julia , of which [Julia]112-julia was fully aware ; and before [he]451-her brother had been at Mansfield a week , [she]112-julia was quite ready to be fallen in love with . [Maria]126-maria ’s notions on the subject were more confused and indistinct . [She]126-maria did not want to see or understand . “ There could be no harm in [her]112-julia liking [an agreeable man]3908-an agreeable man — [everybody]408-everybody knew [her]112-julia situation — [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford must take care of [himself]133-mr. crawford . ”[126-maria] [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford did not mean to be in any danger ! [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams were worth pleasing , and were ready to be pleased ; and [he]133-mr. crawford began with no object but of making [them]327-the sisters like [him]133-mr. crawford . [He]133-mr. crawford did not want [them]327-the sisters to die of love ; but with sense and temper which ought to have made [him]133-mr. crawford judge and feel better , [he]133-mr. crawford allowed [himself]133-mr. crawford great latitude on such points . “ [I]133-mr. crawford like [[your]114-the miss bertrams Miss]3910-your miss Bertrams exceedingly , [sister]3704-sister , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [he]133-mr. crawford , as [he]133-mr. crawford returned from attending [them]327-the sisters to [[their]327-the sisters carriage]772-their carriage after the said dinner visit ; “ [they]327-the sisters are [very elegant , agreeable girls]3912-very elegant , agreeable girls . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ So [they]327-the sisters are indeed , and [I]133-mr. crawford am delighted to hear [you]133-mr. crawford say it . But [you]133-mr. crawford like [Julia]112-julia best . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Oh yes ! [I]133-mr. crawford like [Julia]112-julia best . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ But do [you]133-mr. crawford really ? for [Miss Bertram]112-julia is in general thought the handsomest . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ So [I]133-mr. crawford should suppose . [Her]112-julia cares are over , and [she]112-julia feels that [she]112-julia may exert all [her]112-julia powers of pleasing without suspicion . All is safe with [a lady engaged]3915-a lady engaged : no harm can be done . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Why , as to that , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny is [a very good sort of young man]3916-a very good sort of young man , and it is a great match for [her]112-julia . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ But [Miss Bertram]112-julia does not care three straws for [him]113-fanny ; _ that _ is [your]133-mr. crawford opinion of [[your]133-mr. crawford intimate friend]3917-your intimate friend . _ [I]133-mr. crawford _ do not subscribe to it . [Everybody]408-everybody is taken in at some period or other . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Not always in marriage , [dear Mary]132-mary . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ In marriage especially . With all due respect to such of [the present company]3920-the present company as chance to be married , [[my]133-mr. crawford dear]3657-my dear [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , there is [not one in a hundred of either sex who is not taken in]3922-not one in a hundred of either sex who is not taken in when [they]3922-not one in a hundred of either sex who is not taken in marry . [You]133-mr. crawford have been in [a bad school for matrimony]3925-a bad school for matrimony , in [Hill Street]20-hill street . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [[My]133-mr. crawford poor aunt]3926-my poor aunt had certainly little cause to love [the state]756-the state ; but , however , speaking from [my]133-mr. crawford own observation , it is a manoeuvring business . [I]133-mr. crawford know [so many who have married in the full expectation and confidence of some one particular advantage in the connexion , or accomplishment , or good quality in [the person]3929-the person , who have found [themselves]3929-the person entirely deceived , and been obliged to put up with exactly the reverse]3928-so many who have married in the full expectation and confidence of some one particular advantage in the connexion , or accomplishment , or good quality in the person , who have found themselves entirely deceived , and been obliged to put up with exactly the reverse . What is this but a take in ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [[My]133-mr. crawford dear child]3930-my dear child , there must be a little imagination here . [I]133-mr. crawford beg [your]3930-my dear child pardon , but [I]133-mr. crawford can not quite believe [you]3930-my dear child . Depend upon it , [you]3930-my dear child see but half . [You]3930-my dear child see the evil , but [you]3930-my dear child do not see the consolation . There will be little rubs and disappointments everywhere , and [we]3931-we are all apt to expect too much ; but then , if one scheme of happiness fails , human nature turns to another ; if the first calculation is wrong , [we]3931-we make a second better : [we]3931-we find comfort somewhere — and [those evil - minded observers]3932-those evil - minded observers , dearest [Mary]132-mary , who make much of a little , are more taken in and deceived than [the parties themselves]3933-the parties themselves . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Well done , [sister]3704-sister ! [I]133-mr. crawford honour [[your]3930-my dear child _ esprit _ _ du _ _ corps]3935-your _ esprit _ _ du _ _ corps _ . [Mary]132-mary was satisfied with [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage as [a present home]774-a present home , and [Henry]131-henry equally ready to lengthen [his]131-henry visit . [He]131-henry had come , intending to spend only a few days with [them]135-the crawfords ; but [Mansfield]130-mansfield promised well , and there was nothing to call [him]131-henry [elsewhere]775-elsewhere . [The Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams ’ admiration of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was more rapturous than anything which [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s habits made [her]127-miss crawford likely to feel . [She]127-miss crawford acknowledged , however , that [the Mr. Bertrams]136-the mr. bertrams were [very fine young men]779-very fine young men , that [two such young men]780-two such young men were not often seen together even in [London]6-london , and that [their]780-two such young men manners , particularly those of [the eldest]442-the eldest , were very good . _ [He]133-mr. crawford _ had been much in [London]6-london , and had more liveliness and gallantry than [Edmund]108-edmund , and must , therefore , be preferred ; and , indeed , [his]133-mr. crawford being [the eldest]442-the eldest was another strong claim . [She]127-miss crawford had felt an early presentiment that [she]127-miss crawford _ should _ like [the eldest]442-the eldest best . [She]127-miss crawford knew it was [her]127-miss crawford way . [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas must have been thought pleasant , indeed , at any rate ; [he]101-sir thomas was [the sort of young man to be generally liked]784-the sort of young man to be generally liked , [his]101-sir thomas agreeableness was of the kind to be oftener found agreeable than some endowments of a higher stamp , for [he]101-sir thomas had easy manners , excellent spirits , a large acquaintance , and a great deal to say ; and the reversion of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and [a baronetcy]785-a baronetcy , did no harm to all this . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford soon felt that [he]101-sir thomas and [his]101-sir thomas situation might do . [She]127-miss crawford looked about [her]127-miss crawford with due consideration , and found almost everything in [his]101-sir thomas favour : [a park]786-a park , [a real park]787-a real park , five miles round , [a spacious modern - built house]788-a spacious modern - built house , so well placed and well screened as to deserve to be in any collection of engravings of [[gentlemen]789-gentlemen ’s seats in [the kingdom]791-the kingdom]790-gentlemen ’s seats in the kingdom , and wanting only to be completely new furnished — [pleasant sisters]792-pleasant sisters , [a quiet mother]793-a quiet mother , and [an agreeable man]3908-an agreeable man [himself]101-sir thomas — with the advantage of being tied up from much gaming at present by a promise to [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father , and of being [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas hereafter . It might do very well ; [she]127-miss crawford believed [she]127-miss crawford should accept [him]101-sir thomas ; and [she]127-miss crawford began accordingly to interest [herself]127-miss crawford a little about the horse which [he]101-sir thomas had to run at the B — — races . These races were to call [him]101-sir thomas away not long after [their]796-their acquaintance began ; and as it appeared that [the family]3724-the family did not , from [his]101-sir thomas usual goings on , expect [him]101-sir thomas back again for many weeks , it would bring [his]101-sir thomas passion to an early proof . Much was said on [his]101-sir thomas side to induce [her]127-miss crawford to attend the races , and schemes were made for a large party to [them]796-their , with all the eagerness of inclination , but it would only do to be talked of . And [Fanny]113-fanny , what was _ [she]127-miss crawford _ doing and thinking all this while ? and what was _ [her]127-miss crawford _ opinion of [the newcomers]798-the newcomers ? [Few young ladies of eighteen]799-few young ladies of eighteen could be less called on to speak [their]799-few young ladies of eighteen opinion than [Fanny]113-fanny . The notice , which [she]127-miss crawford excited [herself]127-miss crawford , was to this effect . “ [I]127-miss crawford begin now to understand [you]3940-you all , except [Miss Price]137-miss price , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , as [she]127-miss crawford was walking with [the Mr. Bertrams]136-the mr. bertrams . “ Pray , is [she]137-miss price out , or is [she]137-miss price not ? [[My]108-edmund cousin]3764-my cousin is grown up . [She]3764-my cousin has the age and sense of [a woman]644-a woman , but the outs and not outs are beyond [me]108-edmund . ”[108-edmund] “ And yet , in general , nothing can be more easily ascertained . The distinction is so broad . Manners as well as appearance are , generally speaking , so totally different . Till now , [I]127-miss crawford could not have supposed it possible to be mistaken as to [a girl]3666-a girl ’s being out or not . [A girl not out]3946-a girl not out has always the same sort of dress : a close bonnet , for instance ; looks very demure , and never says a word . [You]3940-you may smile , but it is so , [I]127-miss crawford assure [you]3940-you ; and except that it is sometimes carried a little too far , it is all very proper . [Girls]3947-girls should be quiet and modest . The most objectionable part is , that the alteration of manners on being introduced into [company]3948-company is frequently too sudden . [They]3947-girls sometimes pass in such very little time from reserve to quite the opposite — to confidence ! _ That _ is the faulty part of the present system . [One]766-one does not like to see [a girl of eighteen or nineteen]3950-a girl of eighteen or nineteen so immediately up to every thing — and perhaps when one has seen [her]3950-a girl of eighteen or nineteen hardly able to speak the year before .
