Certainly , [[my]108-edmund home at [[my]108-edmund uncle]3761-my uncle ’s]4127-my home at my uncle ’s brought [me]108-edmund acquainted with [a circle of [admirals]4122-admirals]4129-a circle of admirals . Of _ Rears _ and _ Vices _ [I]108-edmund saw enough . Now do not be suspecting [me]108-edmund of a pun , [I]108-edmund entreat . ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund again felt grave , and only replied , “ It is a noble profession . ”[108-edmund] “ Yes , the profession is well enough under two circumstances : if it make the fortune , and there be discretion in spending it ; but , in short , it is not a favourite profession of [mine]108-edmund . It has never worn an amiable form to _ [me]825-her _ . ”[825-her] [Edmund]108-edmund reverted to the harp , and was again very happy in the prospect of hearing [her]827-her play . The subject of improving grounds , meanwhile , was still under consideration among [the others]347-the others ; and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant could not help addressing [[her]123-mrs. grant brother]451-her brother , though it was calling [his]451-her brother attention from [Miss Julia Bertram]112-julia . “ [[My]112-julia dear]3657-my dear [Henry]131-henry , have _ [you]131-henry _ nothing to say ? [You]131-henry have been [an improver]810-an improver [yourself]131-henry , and from what [I]112-julia hear of [Everingham]31-everingham , it may vie with [any place in [England]14-england]4133-any place in england . [Its]31-everingham natural beauties , [I]112-julia am sure , are great . [Everingham]31-everingham , as [it]31-everingham _ used _ to be , was perfect in [my]112-julia estimation : such a happy fall of ground , and such timber ! What would [I]112-julia not give to see it again ! ”[112-julia] “ Nothing could be so gratifying to [me]830-me as to hear [your]131-henry opinion of it , ”[830-me] was [his]830-me answer ; “ but [I]830-me fear there would be some disappointment : [you]131-henry would not find it equal to [your]131-henry present ideas . In extent , it is a mere nothing ; [you]131-henry would be surprised at its insignificance ; and , as for improvement , there was very little for [me]830-me to do — too little : [I]830-me should like to have been busy much longer . ”[830-me] “ [You]830-me are fond of the sort of thing ? ”[112-julia] said [Julia]112-julia . “ Excessively ; but what with the natural advantages of the ground , which pointed out , even to [a very young eye]4134-a very young eye , what little remained to be done , and [my]112-julia own consequent resolutions , [I]112-julia had not been of age three months before [Everingham]31-everingham was all that it is now . [My]112-julia plan was laid at [Westminster]32-westminster , a little altered , perhaps , at [Cambridge]33-cambridge , and at one - and - twenty executed . [I]112-julia am inclined to envy [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny for having so much happiness yet before [him]113-fanny . [I]112-julia have been [a devourer of]4135-a devourer of [my]112-julia own . ”[112-julia] “ [Those who see quickly]4136-those who see quickly , will resolve quickly , and act quickly , ”[112-julia] said [Julia]112-julia . “ _ [You]4136-those who see quickly _ can never want employment . Instead of envying [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , [you]4136-those who see quickly should assist [him]113-fanny with [your]4136-those who see quickly opinion . ”[112-julia] [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , hearing the latter part of this speech , enforced it warmly , persuaded that no judgment could be equal to [[her]123-mrs. grant brother]451-her brother ’s ; and as [Miss Bertram]112-julia caught at the idea likewise , and gave it [her]112-julia full support , declaring that , in [her]112-julia opinion , it was infinitely better to consult with [friends]3751-friends and [disinterested advisers]833-disinterested advisers , than immediately to throw the business into the hands of [a professional man]834-a professional man , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was very ready to request the favour of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s assistance ; and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , after properly depreciating [his]133-mr. crawford own abilities , was quite at [his]133-mr. crawford service in any way that could be useful . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny then began to propose [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s doing [him]133-mr. crawford the honour of coming over to [Sotherton]27-sotherton , and taking a bed [there]3696-there ; when [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , as if reading in [[her]105-mrs. norris two nieces]836-her two nieces ’ minds [their]836-her two nieces little approbation of a plan which was to take [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford away , interposed with an amendment . “ There can be no doubt of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s willingness ; but why should not more of [us]4137-we go ? Why should not [we]4137-we make a little party ? Here are many that would be interested in [your]133-mr. crawford improvements , [[my]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , and that would like to hear [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s opinion on the spot , and that might be of some small use to [you]133-mr. crawford with _ [their]836-her two nieces _ opinions ; and , for [my]105-mrs. norris own part , [I]105-mrs. norris have been long wishing to wait upon [[your]133-mr. crawford good mother]4139-your good mother again ; nothing but having no horses of [my]105-mrs. norris own could have made [me]105-mrs. norris so remiss ; but now [I]105-mrs. norris could go and sit a few hours with [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , while the rest of [you]133-mr. crawford walked about and settled things , and then [we]4137-we could all return to a late dinner here , or dine at [Sotherton]27-sotherton , just as might be most agreeable to [[your]133-mr. crawford mother]4140-your mother , and have a pleasant drive [home]367-home by moonlight . [I]105-mrs. norris dare say [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford would take [[my]105-mrs. norris two nieces]4142-my two nieces and [me]105-mrs. norris in [[his]133-mr. crawford barouche]4102-his barouche , and [Edmund]108-edmund can go on horseback , [you]133-mr. crawford know , [sister]3704-sister , and [Fanny]113-fanny will stay at [home]367-home with [you]133-mr. crawford . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram made no objection ; and [every one concerned in the going]837-every one concerned in the going was forward in expressing [their]837-every one concerned in the going ready concurrence , excepting [Edmund]108-edmund , who heard it all and said nothing . [CHAPTER VII]152-chapter vii “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , and how do [you]113-fanny like [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford _ now _ ? ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund the next day , after thinking some time on the subject [himself]108-edmund . “ How did [you]113-fanny like [her]127-miss crawford yesterday ? ”[108-edmund] “ Very well — very much . [I]105-mrs. norris like to hear [her]127-miss crawford talk . [She]127-miss crawford entertains [me]105-mrs. norris ; and [she]127-miss crawford is so extremely pretty , that [I]105-mrs. norris have great pleasure in looking at [her]127-miss crawford . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ It is [her]127-miss crawford countenance that is so attractive . [She]127-miss crawford has a wonderful play of feature ! But was there nothing in [her]127-miss crawford conversation that struck [you]113-fanny , [Fanny]113-fanny , as not quite right ? ”[108-edmund] “ Oh yes ! [she]127-miss crawford ought not to have spoken of [[her]127-miss crawford uncle]312-her uncle as [she]127-miss crawford did . [I]108-edmund was quite astonished . [An uncle with whom [she]127-miss crawford has been living so many years , and who , whatever [his]312-her uncle faults may be , is so very fond of [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother , treating [him]312-her uncle , [they]4149-they say , quite like [a son]4150-a son]4147-an uncle with whom she has been living so many years , and who , whatever his faults may be , is so very fond of her brother , treating him , they say , quite like a son . [I]108-edmund could not have believed it ! ”[108-edmund] “ [I]105-mrs. norris thought [you]113-fanny would be struck . It was very wrong ; very indecorous . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ And very ungrateful , [I]108-edmund think . ”[108-edmund] “ Ungrateful is a strong word . [I]108-edmund do not know that [[her]127-miss crawford uncle]312-her uncle has any claim to [her]127-miss crawford _ gratitude _ ; [[his]312-her uncle wife]546-his wife certainly had ; and it is the warmth of [her]127-miss crawford respect for [[her]127-miss crawford aunt]463-her aunt ’s memory which misleads [her]127-miss crawford here . [She]127-miss crawford is awkwardly circumstanced . With such warm feelings and lively spirits it must be difficult to do justice to [her]127-miss crawford affection for [Mrs. Crawford]129-mrs. crawford , without throwing a shade on [the Admiral]715-the admiral . [I]108-edmund do not pretend to know which was most to blame in [their]4155-their disagreements , though [the Admiral]715-the admiral ’s present conduct might incline one to the side of [[his]715-the admiral wife]546-his wife ; but it is natural and amiable that [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford should acquit [[her]127-miss crawford aunt]463-her aunt entirely . [I]108-edmund do not censure [her]127-miss crawford _ opinions _ ; but there certainly _ is _ impropriety in making them public . ”[108-edmund] “ Do not [you]108-edmund think , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , after a little consideration , “ that this impropriety is a reflection itself upon [Mrs. Crawford]129-mrs. crawford , as [[her]129-mrs. crawford niece]642-her niece has been entirely brought up by [her]129-mrs. crawford ? [She]127-miss crawford can not have given [her]127-miss crawford right notions of what was due to [the Admiral]128-admiral crawford . ”[113-fanny] “ That is a fair remark . Yes , [we]4160-we must suppose the faults of [the niece]4161-the niece to have been those of [the aunt]4162-the aunt ; and it makes one more sensible of the disadvantages [she]127-miss crawford has been under . But [I]108-edmund think [[her]127-miss crawford present home]4163-her present home must do [her]127-miss crawford good . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s manners are just what they ought to be . [She]127-miss crawford speaks of [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother with a very pleasing affection . ”[108-edmund] “ Yes , except as to [his]451-her brother writing [her]127-miss crawford such short letters . [She]127-miss crawford made [me]108-edmund almost laugh ; but [I]108-edmund can not rate so very highly the love or good - nature of [a brother who will not give [himself]451-her brother the trouble of writing anything worth reading to [[his]451-her brother sisters]4166-his sisters , when [they]4166-his sisters are separated]4165-a brother who will not give himself the trouble of writing anything worth reading to his sisters , when they are separated . [I]108-edmund am sure [William]228-william would never have used _ [me]108-edmund _ so , under any circumstances . And what right had [she]127-miss crawford to suppose that _ [you]108-edmund _ would not write long letters when [you]108-edmund were absent ? ”[108-edmund] “ The right of a lively mind , [Fanny]113-fanny , seizing whatever may contribute to its own amusement or that of [others]361-others ; perfectly allowable , when untinctured by ill - humour or roughness ; and there is not a shadow of either in the countenance or manner of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford : nothing sharp , or loud , or coarse . [She]127-miss crawford is perfectly feminine , except in the instances [we]4168-we have been speaking of . There [she]127-miss crawford can not be justified . [I]113-fanny am glad [you]113-fanny saw it all as [I]113-fanny did . ”[113-fanny] Having formed [her]838-her mind and gained [her]838-her affections , [he]839-he had a good chance of [her]838-her thinking like [him]839-he ; though at this period , and on this subject , there began now to be some danger of dissimilarity , for [he]839-he was in a line of admiration of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , which might lead [him]839-he where [Fanny]113-fanny could not follow . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s attractions did not lessen . The harp arrived , and rather added to [her]838-her beauty , wit , and good - humour ; for [she]838-her played with the greatest obligingness , with an expression and taste which were peculiarly becoming , and there was something clever to be said at the close of every air . [Edmund]108-edmund was at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage every day , to be indulged with [his]108-edmund favourite instrument : one morning secured an invitation for the next ; for [the lady]718-the lady could not be unwilling to have [a listener]842-a listener , and every thing was soon in a fair train . [A young woman]843-a young woman , pretty , lively , with a harp as elegant as [herself]843-a young woman , and both placed near a window , cut down to the ground , and opening on [a little lawn]844-a little lawn , surrounded by shrubs in the rich foliage of summer , was enough to catch [any man]845-any man ’s heart . The season , the scene , the air , were all favourable to tenderness and sentiment . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [her]123-mrs. grant tambour frame were not without [their]846-their use : it was all in harmony ; and as everything will turn to account when love is once set going , even the sandwich tray , and [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant doing the honours of it , were worth looking at . Without studying the business , however , or knowing what [he]108-edmund was about , [Edmund]108-edmund was beginning , at the end of a week of such intercourse , to be a good deal in love ; and to the credit of [the lady]718-the lady it may be added that , without [his]108-edmund being [a man of [the world]315-the world]848-a man of the world or [an elder brother]850-an elder brother , without any of the arts of flattery or the gaieties of small talk , [he]108-edmund began to be agreeable to [her]718-the lady . [She]718-the lady felt it to be so , though [she]718-the lady had not foreseen , and could hardly understand it ; for [he]108-edmund was not pleasant by any common rule : [he]108-edmund talked no nonsense ; [he]108-edmund paid no compliments ; [his]108-edmund opinions were unbending , [his]108-edmund attentions tranquil and simple . There was a charm , perhaps , in [his]108-edmund sincerity , [his]108-edmund steadiness , [his]108-edmund integrity , which [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford might be equal to feel , though not equal to discuss with [herself]127-miss crawford . [She]718-the lady did not think very much about it , however : [he]108-edmund pleased [her]718-the lady for the present ; [she]718-the lady liked to have [him]108-edmund near [her]718-the lady ; it was enough . [Fanny]113-fanny could not wonder that [Edmund]108-edmund was at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage every morning ; [she]718-the lady would gladly have been [there]3696-there too , might [she]718-the lady have gone in uninvited and unnoticed , to hear the harp ; neither could [she]718-the lady wonder that , when the evening stroll was over , and [the two families]3825-the two families parted again , [he]108-edmund should think it right to attend [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister to [[their]3825-the two families home]855-their home , while [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was devoted to [the ladies of [the Park]3753-the park]856-the ladies of the park ; but [she]718-the lady thought it a very bad exchange ; and if [Edmund]108-edmund were not there to mix the wine and water for [her]718-the lady , would rather go without it than not . [She]718-the lady was a little surprised that [he]108-edmund could spend so many hours with [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , and not see more of the sort of fault which [he]108-edmund had already observed , and of which _ [she]718-the lady _ was almost always reminded by a something of the same nature whenever [she]718-the lady was in [her]718-the lady company ; but so it was . [Edmund]108-edmund was fond of speaking to [her]718-the lady of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , but [he]108-edmund seemed to think it enough that [the Admiral]715-the admiral had since been spared ; and [she]718-the lady scrupled to point out [her]718-the lady own remarks to [him]108-edmund , lest it should appear like ill - nature . The first actual pain which [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford occasioned [her]718-the lady was the consequence of an inclination to learn to ride , which [the former]859-the former caught , soon after [her]718-the lady being settled at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , from the example of [the young ladies at [the Park]3753-the park]860-the young ladies at the park , and which , when [Edmund]108-edmund ’s acquaintance with [her]718-the lady increased , led to [his]108-edmund encouraging the wish , and the offer of [his]108-edmund own quiet mare for the purpose of [her]718-the lady first attempts , as the best fitted for [a beginner that either stable]862-a beginner that either stable could furnish . No pain , no injury , however , was designed by [him]108-edmund to [[his]108-edmund cousin]453-his cousin in this offer : _ [she]718-the lady _ was not to lose a day ’s exercise by it . The mare was only to be taken down to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage half an hour before [her]718-the lady ride were to begin ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , on its being first proposed , so far from feeling slighted , was almost over - powered with gratitude that [he]108-edmund should be asking [her]718-the lady leave for it . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford made [her]127-miss crawford first essay with great credit to [herself]127-miss crawford , and no inconvenience to [Fanny]113-fanny . [Edmund]108-edmund , who had taken down [the mare and presided at the whole]865-the mare and presided at the whole , returned with it in excellent time , before either [Fanny]113-fanny or [the steady old coachman , who always attended [her]718-the lady when [she]718-the lady rode without [[her]718-the lady cousins]3671-her cousins]866-the steady old coachman , who always attended her when she rode without her cousins , were ready to set forward . The second day ’s trial was not so guiltless . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s enjoyment of riding was such that [she]127-miss crawford did not know how to leave off . Active and fearless , and though rather small , strongly made , [she]127-miss crawford seemed formed for [a horsewoman]868-a horsewoman ; and to the pure genuine pleasure of the exercise , something was probably added in [Edmund]108-edmund ’s attendance and instructions , and something more in the conviction of very much surpassing [her]127-miss crawford sex in general by [her]127-miss crawford early progress , to make [her]127-miss crawford unwilling to dismount . [Fanny]113-fanny was ready and waiting , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was beginning to scold [her]718-the lady for not being gone , and still no horse was announced , no [Edmund]108-edmund appeared . To avoid [[her]718-the lady aunt]463-her aunt , and look for [him]108-edmund , [she]718-the lady went out . [The houses]870-the houses , though scarcely half a mile apart , were not within sight of each other ; but , by walking fifty yards from [the hall]871-the hall door , [she]718-the lady could look down [the park]3753-the park , and command a view of [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage and [[all]874-all [its]368-the parsonage demesnes]875-all its demesnes , gently rising beyond [the village road]876-the village road ; and in [[Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant ’s meadow]877-dr. grant ’s meadow [she]718-the lady immediately saw [the group]878-the group — [Edmund]108-edmund and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford both on horse - back , riding side by side , [Dr.]121-dr. grant and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , with [two or three grooms]879-two or three grooms , standing about and looking on . A happy party it appeared to [her]718-the lady , all interested in one object : cheerful beyond a doubt , for the sound of merriment ascended even to [her]718-the lady . It was a sound which did not make _ [her]718-the lady _ cheerful ; [she]718-the lady wondered that [Edmund]108-edmund should forget [her]718-the lady , and felt a pang . [She]718-the lady could not turn [her]718-the lady eyes from [the meadow]880-the meadow ; [she]718-the lady could not help watching all that passed . At first [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford and [[her]127-miss crawford companion]881-her companion made the circuit of [the field]882-the field , which was not small , at a foot ’s pace ; then , at _ [her]718-the lady _ apparent suggestion , [they]883-they rose into a canter ; and to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s timid nature it was most astonishing to see how well [she]718-the lady sat . After a few minutes [they]883-they stopped entirely . [Edmund]108-edmund was close to [her]718-the lady ; [he]108-edmund was speaking to [her]718-the lady ; [he]108-edmund was evidently directing [her]718-the lady management of the bridle ; [he]108-edmund had hold of [her]718-the lady hand ; [she]718-the lady saw it , or the imagination supplied what the eye could not reach . [She]718-the lady must not wonder at all this ; what could be more natural than that [Edmund]108-edmund should be making [himself]108-edmund useful , and proving [his]108-edmund good - nature by [any one]3817-any one ? [She]718-the lady could not but think , indeed , that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford might as well have saved [him]108-edmund the trouble ; that it would have been particularly proper and becoming in [a brother]4109-a brother to have done it [himself]108-edmund ; but [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , with all [his]133-mr. crawford boasted good - nature , and all [his]133-mr. crawford coachmanship , probably knew nothing of the matter , and had no active kindness in comparison of [Edmund]108-edmund . [She]718-the lady began to think it rather hard upon the mare to have such double duty ; if [she]718-the lady were forgotten , the poor mare should be remembered . [Her]718-the lady feelings for [one and the other]886-one and the other were soon a little tranquillised by seeing the party in [the meadow]880-the meadow disperse , and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford still on horseback , but attended by [Edmund]108-edmund on foot , pass through a gate into [the lane]888-the lane , and so into [the park]3753-the park , and make towards [the spot where [she]127-miss crawford stood]890-the spot where she stood . [She]718-the lady began then to be afraid of appearing rude and impatient ; and walked to meet [them]891-them with a great anxiety to avoid the suspicion . “ [[My]127-miss crawford dear]3657-my dear [Miss Price]137-miss price , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , as soon as [she]127-miss crawford was at all within hearing , “ [I]127-miss crawford am come to make [my]127-miss crawford own apologies for keeping [you]137-miss price waiting ; but [I]127-miss crawford have nothing in [the world]315-the world to say for [myself]127-miss crawford — [I]127-miss crawford knew it was very late , and that [I]127-miss crawford was behaving extremely ill ; and therefore , if [you]137-miss price please , [you]137-miss price must forgive [me]127-miss crawford . Selfishness must always be forgiven , [you]137-miss price know , because there is no hope of a cure . ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny ’s answer was extremely civil , and [Edmund]108-edmund added [his]108-edmund conviction that [she]127-miss crawford could be in no hurry . “ For there is more than time enough for [[my]108-edmund cousin]3764-my cousin to ride twice as far as [she]3764-my cousin ever goes , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund , “ and [you]137-miss price have been promoting [her]3764-my cousin comfort by preventing [her]3764-my cousin from setting off half an hour sooner : clouds are now coming up , and [she]3764-my cousin will not suffer from the heat as [she]3764-my cousin would have done then . [I]108-edmund wish _ [you]137-miss price _ may not be fatigued by so much exercise . [I]108-edmund wish [you]137-miss price had saved [yourself]137-miss price this walk [home]367-home . ”[108-edmund] “ No part of it fatigues [me]127-miss crawford but getting off this horse , [I]127-miss crawford assure [you]108-edmund , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford , as [she]127-miss crawford sprang down with [his]108-edmund help ; “ [I]127-miss crawford am very strong . Nothing ever fatigues [me]127-miss crawford but doing what [I]127-miss crawford do not like . [Miss Price]137-miss price , [I]127-miss crawford give way to [you]137-miss price with a very bad grace ; but [I]127-miss crawford sincerely hope [you]137-miss price will have a pleasant ride , and that [I]127-miss crawford may have nothing but good to hear of [this dear , delightful , beautiful animal]4173-this dear , delightful , beautiful animal . ”[127-miss crawford] [The old coachman]892-the old coachman , who had been waiting about with [his]892-the old coachman own horse , now joining [them]893-them , [Fanny]113-fanny was lifted on [hers]113-fanny , and [they]893-them set off across [another part of [the park]3753-the park]894-another part of the park ; [her]127-miss crawford feelings of discomfort not lightened by seeing , as [she]127-miss crawford looked back , that [the others]347-the others were walking down [the hill]4046-the hill together to [the village]524-the village ; nor did [[her]127-miss crawford attendant]899-her attendant do [her]127-miss crawford much good by [his]892-the old coachman comments on [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s great cleverness as [a horse - woman]900-a horse - woman , which [he]892-the old coachman had been watching with an interest almost equal to [her]127-miss crawford own . “ It is a pleasure to see [a lady with such a good heart for riding]4174-a lady with such a good heart for riding ! ”[892-the old coachman] said [he]892-the old coachman . “ [I]892-the old coachman never see one sit a horse better . [She]127-miss crawford did not seem to have a thought of fear . Very different from [you]127-miss crawford , [miss]4175-miss , when [you]127-miss crawford first began , six years ago come next [Easter]153-easter . [Lord]4176-lord bless [you]127-miss crawford ! how [you]127-miss crawford did tremble when [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas first had [you]127-miss crawford put on ! ”[892-the old coachman] In [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was also celebrated . [Her]127-miss crawford merit in being gifted by Nature with strength and courage was fully appreciated by [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams ; [her]127-miss crawford delight in riding was like [their]902-their own ; [her]127-miss crawford early excellence in it was like [their]902-their own , and [they]902-their had great pleasure in praising it . “ [I]112-julia was sure [she]127-miss crawford would ride well , ”[112-julia] said [Julia]112-julia ; “ [she]127-miss crawford has the make for it . [Her]127-miss crawford figure is as neat as [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother ’s . ”[112-julia] “ Yes , ”[126-maria] added [Maria]126-maria , “ and [her]127-miss crawford spirits are as good , and [she]127-miss crawford has the same energy of character . [I]126-maria can not but think that good horsemanship has a great deal to do with the mind . ”[126-maria] When [they]902-their parted at night [Edmund]108-edmund asked [Fanny]113-fanny whether [she]127-miss crawford meant to ride the next day . “ No , [I]127-miss crawford do not know — not if [you]108-edmund want the mare , ”[127-miss crawford] was [her]127-miss crawford answer . “ [I]108-edmund do not want [her]127-miss crawford at all for [myself]108-edmund , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund ; “ but whenever [you]113-fanny are next inclined to stay at [home]367-home , [I]108-edmund think [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford would be glad to have [her]127-miss crawford a longer time — for a whole morning , in short . [She]127-miss crawford has a great desire to get as far as [Mansfield Common]34-mansfield common : [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant has been telling [her]127-miss crawford of [its]34-mansfield common fine views , and [I]108-edmund have no doubt of [her]127-miss crawford being perfectly equal to it . But any morning will do for this . [She]127-miss crawford would be extremely sorry to interfere with [you]113-fanny . It would be very wrong if [she]127-miss crawford did . _ [She]127-miss crawford _ rides only for pleasure ; _ [you]113-fanny _ for health . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]113-fanny shall not ride to - morrow , certainly , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny ; “ [I]113-fanny have been out very often lately , and would rather stay at [home]367-home . [You]113-fanny know [I]113-fanny am strong enough now to walk very well . ”[113-fanny] [Edmund]108-edmund looked pleased , which must be [Fanny]113-fanny ’s comfort , and the ride to [Mansfield Common]34-mansfield common took place the next morning : the party included [all the young people]903-all the young people but [herself]113-fanny , and was much enjoyed at the time , and doubly enjoyed again in the evening discussion . A successful scheme of this sort generally brings on another ; and the having been to [Mansfield Common]34-mansfield common disposed [them]903-all the young people all for going somewhere else the day after . There were many other views to be shewn ; and though the weather was hot , there were shady lanes wherever [they]903-all the young people wanted to go . [A young party]904-a young party is always provided with [a shady lane]905-a shady lane . Four fine mornings successively were spent in this manner , in shewing the [Crawfords]135-the crawfords [the country]493-the country , and doing the honours of [its]493-the country finest spots . Everything answered ; it was all gaiety and good - humour , the heat only supplying inconvenience enough to be talked of with pleasure — till the fourth day , when the happiness of one of [the party]907-the party was exceedingly clouded . [Miss Bertram]112-julia was the one . [Edmund]108-edmund and [Julia]112-julia were invited to dine at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , and _ [she]112-julia _ was excluded . It was meant and done by [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , with perfect good - humour , on [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s account , who was partly expected at [the Park]3753-the park that day ; but it was felt as a very grievous injury , and [her]112-julia good manners were severely taxed to conceal [her]112-julia vexation and anger till [she]112-julia reached [home]367-home . As [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny did _ not _ come , the injury was increased , and [she]112-julia had not even the relief of shewing [her]112-julia power over [him]113-fanny ; [she]112-julia could only be sullen to [[her]112-julia mother]446-her mother , [aunt]3769-aunt , and [cousin]3759-cousin , and throw as great a gloom as possible over [their]914-their dinner and dessert . Between ten and eleven [Edmund]108-edmund and [Julia]112-julia walked into [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , fresh with the evening air , glowing and cheerful , the very reverse of what [they]914-their found in [the three ladies sitting there]916-the three ladies sitting there , for [Maria]126-maria would scarcely raise [her]126-maria eyes from [her]126-maria book , and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was half - asleep ; and even [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , discomposed by [[her]105-mrs. norris niece]642-her niece ’s ill - humour , and having asked one or two questions about the dinner , which were not immediately attended to , seemed almost determined to say no more . For a few minutes [the brother]695-the brother and [sister]3704-sister were too eager in [their]914-their praise of the night and [their]914-their remarks on the stars , to think beyond [themselves]914-their ; but when the first pause came , [Edmund]108-edmund , looking around , said , “ But where is [Fanny]113-fanny ? Is [she]105-mrs. norris gone to bed ? ”[108-edmund] “ No , not that [I]105-mrs. norris know of , ”[105-mrs. norris] replied [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ; “ [she]105-mrs. norris was [here]3798-here a moment ago . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Her]105-mrs. norris own gentle voice speaking from the other end of [the room]412-the room , which was a very long one , told [them]914-their that [she]105-mrs. norris was on the sofa . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris began scolding . “ That is a very foolish trick , [Fanny]113-fanny , to be idling away all the evening upon a sofa . Why can not [you]113-fanny come and sit here , and employ [yourself]113-fanny as _ [we]4181-we _ do ? If [you]113-fanny have no work of [your]113-fanny own , [I]105-mrs. norris can supply [you]113-fanny from the poor basket . There is all the new calico , that was bought last week , not touched yet . [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [I]105-mrs. norris almost broke [my]105-mrs. norris back by cutting it out . [You]113-fanny should learn to think of [other people]4182-other people ; and , take [my]105-mrs. norris word for it , it is a shocking trick for [a young person]4183-a young person to be always lolling upon a sofa . ”[105-mrs. norris] Before half this was said , [Fanny]113-fanny was returned to [her]105-mrs. norris seat at the table , and had taken up [her]105-mrs. norris work again ; and [Julia]112-julia , who was in high good - humour , from the pleasures of the day , did [her]112-julia the justice of exclaiming , “ [I]112-julia must say , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , that [Fanny]113-fanny is as little upon the sofa as anybody in [the house]427-the house . ”[112-julia] “ [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , after looking at [her]105-mrs. norris attentively , “ [I]108-edmund am sure [you]105-mrs. norris have the headache . ”[108-edmund] [She]105-mrs. norris could not deny it , but said it was not very bad . “ [I]108-edmund can hardly believe [you]105-mrs. norris , ”[108-edmund] [he]108-edmund replied ; “ [I]108-edmund know [your]105-mrs. norris looks too well . How long have [you]105-mrs. norris had it ? ”[108-edmund] “ Since a little before dinner . It is nothing but the heat . ”[112-julia] “ Did [you]108-edmund go out in the heat ? ”[108-edmund] “ Go out ! to be sure [she]105-mrs. norris did , ”[105-mrs. norris] said [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris : “ would [you]108-edmund have [her]105-mrs. norris stay within such a fine day as this ? Were not [we]4186-we _ all _ out ? Even [[your]108-edmund mother]4140-your mother was out to - day for above an hour . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Yes , indeed , [Edmund]108-edmund , ”[921-her ladyship] added [[her]105-mrs. norris ladyship]921-her ladyship , who had been thoroughly awakened by [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s sharp reprimand to [Fanny]113-fanny ; “ [I]105-mrs. norris was out above an hour . [I]105-mrs. norris sat three - quarters of an hour in [the flower - garden]4188-the flower - garden , while [Fanny]113-fanny cut the roses ; and very pleasant it was , [I]105-mrs. norris assure [you]108-edmund , but very hot . It was shady enough in [the alcove]4189-the alcove , but [I]105-mrs. norris declare [I]105-mrs. norris quite dreaded the coming [home]367-home again . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [Fanny]113-fanny has been cutting roses , has [she]4140-your mother ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Yes , and [I]105-mrs. norris am afraid they will be the last this year . Poor thing ! _ [She]4140-your mother _ found it hot enough ; but they were so full - blown that [one]766-one could not wait . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ There was no help for it , certainly , ”[105-mrs. norris] rejoined [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , in a rather softened voice ; “ but [I]105-mrs. norris question whether [her]4140-your mother headache might not be caught _ then _ , [sister]3704-sister . There is nothing so likely to give it as standing and stooping in a hot sun ; but [I]105-mrs. norris dare say it will be well to - morrow . Suppose [you]108-edmund let [her]4140-your mother have [your]108-edmund aromatic vinegar ; [I]105-mrs. norris always forget to have [mine]105-mrs. norris filled . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [She]4140-your mother has got it , ”[106-lady bertram] said [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ; “ [she]4140-your mother has had it ever since [she]4140-your mother came back from [[your]108-edmund house]4193-your house the second time . ”[106-lady bertram] “ What ! ”[108-edmund] cried [Edmund]108-edmund ; “ has [she]4140-your mother been walking as well as cutting roses ; walking across [the hot park]4194-the hot park to [[your]108-edmund house]4193-your house , and doing it twice , [ma’am]4007-ma’am ? No wonder [her]4140-your mother head aches . ”[108-edmund] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was talking to [Julia]112-julia , and did not hear . “ [I]106-lady bertram was afraid it would be too much for [her]4140-your mother , ”[106-lady bertram] said [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ; “ but when the roses were gathered , [[your]108-edmund aunt]3826-your aunt wished to have them , and then [you]108-edmund know they must be taken [home]367-home . ”[106-lady bertram] “ But were there roses enough to oblige [her]4140-your mother to go twice ? ”[106-lady bertram] “ No ; but they were to be put into [the spare room]4199-the spare room to dry ; and , unluckily , [Fanny]113-fanny forgot to lock the door of [the room]412-the room and bring away the key , so [she]4140-your mother was obliged to go again . ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund got up and walked about [the room]412-the room , saying , “ And could [nobody]360-nobody be employed on such an errand but [Fanny]113-fanny ? Upon [my]108-edmund word , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , it has been a very ill - managed business . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [I]105-mrs. norris do not know how it was to have been done better , ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , unable to be longer deaf ; “ unless [I]105-mrs. norris had gone [myself]105-mrs. norris , indeed ; but [I]105-mrs. norris can not be in two places at once ; and [I]105-mrs. norris was talking to [Mr. Green]154-mr. green at that very time about [[your]4007-ma’am mother]4140-your mother ’s dairymaid , by _ [her]4140-your mother _ desire , and had promised [John Groom]155-john groom to write to [Mrs. Jefferies]156-mrs. jefferies about [[his]155-john groom son]581-his son , and [the poor fellow]4205-the poor fellow was waiting for [me]105-mrs. norris half an hour . [I]105-mrs. norris think [nobody]360-nobody can justly accuse [me]105-mrs. norris of sparing [myself]105-mrs. norris upon any occasion , but really [I]105-mrs. norris can not do everything at once . And as for [Fanny]113-fanny ’s just stepping down to [[my]105-mrs. norris house]4207-my house for [me]105-mrs. norris — it is not much above a quarter of a mile — [I]105-mrs. norris can not think [I]105-mrs. norris was unreasonable to ask it . How often do [I]105-mrs. norris pace it three times a day , early and late , ay , and in all weathers too , and say nothing about it ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]108-edmund wish [Fanny]113-fanny had half [your]108-edmund strength , [ma’am]4007-ma’am . ”[108-edmund] “ If [Fanny]113-fanny would be more regular in [her]4209-she exercise , [she]4209-she would not be knocked up so soon . [She]4209-she has not been out on horseback now this long while , and [I]105-mrs. norris am persuaded that , when [she]4209-she does not ride , [she]4209-she ought to walk . If [she]4209-she had been riding before , [I]105-mrs. norris should not have asked it of [her]4209-she . But [I]105-mrs. norris thought it would rather do [her]4209-she good after being stooping among the roses ; for there is nothing so refreshing as a walk after a fatigue of that kind ; and though the sun was strong , it was not so very hot . Between [ourselves]4210-ourselves , [Edmund]108-edmund , ”[105-mrs. norris] nodding significantly at [[his]923-his mother]629-his mother , “ it was cutting the roses , and dawdling about in the flower - garden , that did the mischief . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]106-lady bertram am afraid it was , indeed , ”[106-lady bertram] said the more candid [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , who had overheard [her]629-his mother ; “ [I]106-lady bertram am very much afraid [she]4209-she caught the headache there , for the heat was enough to kill [anybody]3668-anybody . It was as much as [I]106-lady bertram could bear [myself]106-lady bertram . Sitting and calling to [Pug]157-pug , and trying to keep [him]157-pug from the flower - beds , was almost too much for [me]106-lady bertram . ”[106-lady bertram] [Edmund]108-edmund said no more to [either lady]925-either lady ; but going quietly to another table , on which the supper - tray yet remained , brought a glass of Madeira to [Fanny]113-fanny , and obliged [her]629-his mother to drink the greater part . [She]629-his mother wished to be able to decline it ; but the tears , which a variety of feelings created , made it easier to swallow than to speak . Vexed as [Edmund]108-edmund was with [[his]923-his mother]629-his mother and [aunt]3769-aunt , [he]108-edmund was still more angry with [himself]108-edmund . [His]108-edmund own forgetfulness of [her]629-his mother was worse than anything which [they]928-they had done . Nothing of this would have happened had [she]629-his mother been properly considered ; but [she]629-his mother had been left four days together without any choice of companions or exercise , and without any excuse for avoiding whatever [[her]629-his mother unreasonable aunts]929-her unreasonable aunts might require . [He]108-edmund was ashamed to think that for four days together [she]629-his mother had not had the power of riding , and very seriously resolved , however unwilling [he]108-edmund must be to check a pleasure of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s , that it should never happen again . [Fanny]113-fanny went to bed with [her]629-his mother heart as full as on the first evening of [her]629-his mother arrival at [the Park]3753-the park . The state of [her]629-his mother spirits had probably had its share in [her]629-his mother indisposition ; for [she]629-his mother had been feeling neglected , and been struggling against discontent and envy for some days past . As [she]629-his mother leant on the sofa , to which [she]629-his mother had retreated that [she]629-his mother might not be seen , the pain of [her]629-his mother mind had been much beyond that in [her]629-his mother head ; and the sudden change which [Edmund]108-edmund ’s kindness had then occasioned , made [her]629-his mother hardly know how to support [herself]629-his mother . CHAPTER VIII [Fanny]113-fanny ’s rides recommenced the very next day ; and as it was a pleasant fresh - feeling morning , less hot than the weather had lately been , [Edmund]108-edmund trusted that [her]629-his mother losses , both of health and pleasure , would be soon made good . While [she]629-his mother was gone [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny arrived , escorting [[his]113-fanny mother]629-his mother , who came to be civil and to shew [her]629-his mother civility especially , in urging the execution of the plan for visiting [Sotherton]27-sotherton , which had been started a fortnight before , and which , in consequence of [her]629-his mother subsequent absence from [home]367-home , had since lain dormant . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris and [[her]105-mrs. norris nieces]478-her nieces were all well pleased with its revival , and an early day was named and agreed to , provided [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford should be disengaged : [the young ladies]934-the young ladies did not forget that stipulation , and though [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris would willingly have answered for [his]133-mr. crawford being so , [they]934-the young ladies would neither authorise the liberty nor run the risk ; and at last , on a hint from [Miss Bertram]112-julia , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny discovered that the properest thing to be done was for [him]113-fanny to walk down to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage directly , and call on [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and inquire whether Wednesday would suit [him]113-fanny or not . Before [his]113-fanny return [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford came in . Having been out some time , and taken a different route to [the house]427-the house , [they]934-the young ladies had not met [him]113-fanny . Comfortable hopes , however , were given that [he]113-fanny would find [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford at [home]367-home . The [Sotherton]27-sotherton scheme was mentioned of course . It was hardly possible , indeed , that anything else should be talked of , for [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was in high spirits about it ; and [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , [a well - meaning , civil , prosing , pompous woman , who thought nothing of consequence]938-a well - meaning , civil , prosing , pompous woman , who thought nothing of consequence , but as it related to [her]126-maria own and [[her]126-maria son]637-her son ’s concerns , had not yet given over pressing [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram to be of the party . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram constantly declined it ; but [her]106-lady bertram placid manner of refusal made [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria still think [she]106-lady bertram wished to come , till [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s more numerous words and louder tone convinced [her]126-maria of the truth . “ The fatigue would be too much for [[my]105-mrs. norris sister]3790-my sister , a great deal too much , [I]105-mrs. norris assure [you]126-maria , [[my]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria . Ten miles there , and ten back , [you]126-maria know . [You]126-maria must excuse [[my]105-mrs. norris sister]3790-my sister on this occasion , and accept of [[our]4215-our two dear girls]4216-our two dear girls and [myself]105-mrs. norris without [her]3790-my sister . [Sotherton]27-sotherton is the only place that could give [her]3790-my sister a _ wish _ to go so far , but it can not be , indeed . [She]3790-my sister will have [a companion in [Fanny Price]113-fanny]4217-a companion in fanny price , [you]126-maria know , so it will all do very well ; and as for [Edmund]108-edmund , as [he]108-edmund is not here to speak for [himself]108-edmund , [I]105-mrs. norris will answer for [his]108-edmund being most happy to join the party . [He]108-edmund can go on horseback , [you]126-maria know . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria being obliged to yield to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s staying at [home]367-home , could only be sorry . “ The loss of [[her]106-lady bertram ladyship]921-her ladyship ’s company would be a great drawback , and [she]106-lady bertram should have been extremely happy to have seen [the young lady]666-the young lady too , [Miss Price]137-miss price , who had never been at [Sotherton]27-sotherton yet , and it was a pity [she]106-lady bertram should not see [the place]459-the place . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [You]126-maria are very kind , [you]126-maria are all kindness , [[my]105-mrs. norris dear madam]4221-my dear madam , ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ; “ but as to [Fanny]113-fanny , [she]106-lady bertram will have opportunities in plenty of seeing [Sotherton]27-sotherton . [She]106-lady bertram has time enough before [her]106-lady bertram ; and [her]106-lady bertram going now is quite out of the question . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram could not possibly spare [her]106-lady bertram . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Oh no ! [I]126-maria can not do without [Fanny]113-fanny . ”[126-maria] [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria proceeded next , under the conviction that [everybody]408-everybody must be wanting to see [Sotherton]27-sotherton , to include [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford in the invitation ; and though [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , who had not been at the trouble of visiting [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , on [her]123-mrs. grant coming into [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood , civilly declined it on [her]123-mrs. grant own account , [she]123-mrs. grant was glad to secure any pleasure for [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister ; and [Mary]132-mary , properly pressed and persuaded , was not long in accepting [her]132-mary share of the civility . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny came back from [the Parsonage]36-the parsonage successful ; and [Edmund]108-edmund made [his]108-edmund appearance just in time to learn what had been settled for Wednesday , to attend [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria to [[her]126-maria carriage]944-her carriage , and walk half - way down [the park]3753-the park with [the two other ladies]946-the two other ladies . On [his]108-edmund return to [the breakfast - room]3756-the breakfast - room , [he]108-edmund found [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris trying to make up [her]105-mrs. norris mind as to whether [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s being of the party were desirable or not , or whether [[her]105-mrs. norris brother]451-her brother ’s barouche would not be full without [her]105-mrs. norris . [The Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams laughed at the idea , assuring [her]105-mrs. norris that [the barouche]949-the barouche would hold four perfectly well , independent of the box , on which _ one _ might go with [him]451-her brother . “ But why is it necessary , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ that [[Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s carriage]4222-crawford ’s carriage , or [his]133-mr. crawford _ only _ , should be employed ? Why is no use to be made of [[my]108-edmund mother]3827-my mother ’s chaise ? No , [[my]112-julia dear]3657-my dear [Edmund]108-edmund , that will not quite do . ”[112-julia] “ Besides , ”[126-maria] said [Maria]126-maria , “ [I]126-maria know that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford depends upon taking [us]4227-we . [I]126-maria will answer for it that [we]4227-we shall find no inconvenience from [narrow roads]4237-narrow roads on Wednesday . ”[126-maria] “ There is no hardship , [I]108-edmund suppose , nothing unpleasant , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ in going on the barouche box . ”[108-edmund] “ Unpleasant ! ”[126-maria] cried [Maria]126-maria : “ oh dear ! [Probably Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford will choose [the barouche - box]4240-the barouche - box [herself]133-mr. crawford . ”[126-maria] “ There can be no objection , then , to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s going with [you]108-edmund ; there can be no doubt of [your]108-edmund having room for [her]4241-her . ”[108-edmund] “ [Fanny]113-fanny ! ”[105-mrs. norris] repeated [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ; “ [[my]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Edmund]108-edmund , there is no idea of [her]4241-her going with [us]4243-us . [She]4241-her stays with [[her]4241-her aunt]463-her aunt . [I]105-mrs. norris told [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria so . [She]4241-her is not expected . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [You]629-his mother can have no reason , [I]950-i imagine , [madam]4024-madam , ”[950-i] said [he]950-i , addressing [[his]950-i mother]629-his mother , “ for wishing [Fanny]113-fanny _ not _ to be of [the party]907-the party , but as it relates to [yourself]629-his mother , to [your]629-his mother own comfort . If [you]629-his mother could do without [her]4241-her , [you]629-his mother would not wish to keep [her]4241-her at [home]367-home ? ”[950-i] “ To be sure not , but [I]105-mrs. norris _ can not _ do without [her]4241-her . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [You]629-his mother can , if [I]105-mrs. norris stay at [home]367-home with [you]629-his mother , as [I]105-mrs. norris mean to do . ”[105-mrs. norris] There was a general cry out at this . “ Yes , ”[950-i] [he]950-i continued , “ there is no necessity for [my]950-i going , and [I]950-i mean to stay at [home]367-home . [Fanny]113-fanny has a great desire to see [Sotherton]27-sotherton . [I]950-i know [she]4241-her wishes it very much . [She]4241-her has not often a gratification of the kind , and [I]950-i am sure , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , [you]629-his mother would be glad to give [her]4241-her the pleasure now ? ”[950-i] “ Oh yes ! very glad , if [[your]629-his mother aunt]3826-your aunt sees no objection . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was very ready with the only objection which could remain — [their]952-their having positively assured [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria that [Fanny]113-fanny could not go , and the very strange appearance there would consequently be in taking [her]126-maria , which seemed to [her]105-mrs. norris a difficulty quite impossible to be got over . It must have the strangest appearance ! It would be something so very unceremonious , so bordering on disrespect for [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , whose own manners were such a pattern of good - breeding and attention , that [she]105-mrs. norris really did not feel equal to it . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had no affection for [Fanny]113-fanny , and no wish of procuring [her]126-maria pleasure at any time ; but [her]105-mrs. norris opposition to [Edmund]108-edmund _ now _ , arose more from partiality for [her]105-mrs. norris own scheme , because it _ was _ [her]105-mrs. norris own , than from anything else . [She]105-mrs. norris felt that [she]105-mrs. norris had arranged everything extremely well , and that any alteration must be for the worse . When [Edmund]108-edmund , therefore , told [her]105-mrs. norris in reply , as [he]108-edmund did when [she]105-mrs. norris would give [him]108-edmund the hearing , that [she]105-mrs. norris need not distress [herself]105-mrs. norris on [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ’s account , because [he]108-edmund had taken the opportunity , as [he]108-edmund walked with [her]105-mrs. norris through [the hall]871-the hall , of mentioning [Miss Price]137-miss price as one who would probably be of [the party]907-the party , and had directly received a very sufficient invitation for [[his]108-edmund cousin]453-his cousin , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was too much vexed to submit with a very good grace , and would only say , “ Very well , very well , just as [you]105-mrs. norris chuse , settle it [your]105-mrs. norris own way , [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [I]105-mrs. norris do not care about it . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ It seems very odd , ”[126-maria] said [Maria]126-maria , “ that [you]105-mrs. norris should be staying at [home]367-home instead of [Fanny]113-fanny . ”[126-maria] “ [I]112-julia am sure [she]453-his cousin ought to be very much obliged to [you]105-mrs. norris , ”[112-julia] added [Julia]112-julia , hastily leaving [the room]412-the room as [she]112-julia spoke , from a consciousness that [she]112-julia ought to offer to stay at [home]367-home [herself]112-julia . “ [Fanny]113-fanny will feel quite as grateful as the occasion requires , ”[108-edmund] was [Edmund]108-edmund ’s only reply , and the subject dropt . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s gratitude , when [she]112-julia heard the plan , was , in fact , much greater than [her]112-julia pleasure . [She]112-julia felt [Edmund]108-edmund ’s kindness with all , and more than all , the sensibility which [he]108-edmund , unsuspicious of [her]112-julia fond attachment , could be aware of ; but that [he]108-edmund should forego any enjoyment on [her]112-julia account gave [her]112-julia pain , and [her]112-julia own satisfaction in seeing [Sotherton]27-sotherton would be nothing without [him]108-edmund . The next meeting of [the two Mansfield families]958-the two mansfield families produced another alteration in the plan , and one that was admitted with general approbation . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant offered [herself]123-mrs. grant as [companion]3811-companion for the day to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram in lieu of [[her]123-mrs. grant son]637-her son , and [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant was to join [them]961-them at dinner . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was very well pleased to have it so , and [the young ladies]934-the young ladies were in spirits again . Even [Edmund]108-edmund was very thankful for an arrangement which restored [him]108-edmund to [his]108-edmund share of the party ; and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris thought it an excellent plan , and had it at [her]105-mrs. norris tongue ’s end , and was on the point of proposing it , when [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant spoke . Wednesday was fine , and soon after breakfast the barouche arrived , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford driving [[his]133-mr. crawford sisters]4166-his sisters ; and as [everybody]408-everybody was ready , there was nothing to be done but for [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant to alight and [the others]347-the others to take [their]347-the others places . [The place of all places]966-the place of all places , the envied seat , the post of honour , was unappropriated . To whose happy lot was it to fall ? While [each of [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams]967-each of the miss bertrams were meditating how best , and with the most appearance of obliging [the others]347-the others , to secure it , the matter was settled by [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s saying , as [she]123-mrs. grant stepped from [the carriage]969-the carriage , “ As there are five of [you]4253-you , it will be better that [one]766-one should sit with [Henry]131-henry ; and as [you]4253-you were saying lately that [you]4253-you wished [you]4253-you could drive , [Julia]112-julia , [I]123-mrs. grant think this will be a good opportunity for [you]4253-you to take a lesson . ”[123-mrs. grant] [Happy Julia]159-happy julia ! [Unhappy Maria]160-unhappy maria ! [The former]859-the former was on [the barouche - box]4240-the barouche - box in a moment , [the latter]972-the latter took [her]972-the latter seat within , in gloom and mortification ; and [the carriage]969-the carriage drove off amid the good wishes of [the two remaining ladies]974-the two remaining ladies , and the barking of [Pug]157-pug in [[his]157-pug mistress]725-his mistress ’s arms . [[Their]976-their road]977-their road was through [a pleasant country]978-a pleasant country ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , whose rides had never been extensive , was soon beyond [her]979-her knowledge , and was very happy in observing all that was new , and admiring all that was pretty . [She]979-her was not often invited to join in the conversation of [the others]347-the others , nor did [she]979-her desire it . [Her]979-her own thoughts and reflections were habitually [[her]979-her best companions]981-her best companions ; and , in observing the appearance of [the country]493-the country , the bearings of [the roads]983-the roads , the difference of soil , the state of the harvest , [the cottages]984-the cottages , the cattle , [the children]985-the children , [she]979-her found entertainment that could only have been heightened by having [Edmund]108-edmund to speak to of what [she]979-her felt . That was the only point of resemblance between [her]979-her and [the lady who sat by [her]979-her]986-the lady who sat by her : in everything but a value for [Edmund]108-edmund , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was very unlike [her]979-her . [She]127-miss crawford had none of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s delicacy of taste , of mind , of feeling ; [she]127-miss crawford saw Nature , inanimate Nature , with little observation ; [her]127-miss crawford attention was all for [men]395-men and [women]988-women , [her]127-miss crawford talents for the light and lively . In looking back after [Edmund]108-edmund , however , when there was any stretch of [road]989-road behind [them]990-they , or when [he]108-edmund gained on [them]990-they in ascending [a considerable hill]991-a considerable hill , [they]990-they were united , and a “ there [he]108-edmund is ”[133-mr. crawford] broke at the same moment from [them]990-they both , more than once . For the first seven miles [Miss Bertram]112-julia had very little real comfort : [her]112-julia prospect always ended in [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister sitting side by side , full of conversation and merriment ; and to see only [his]108-edmund expressive profile as [he]108-edmund turned with a smile to [Julia]112-julia , or to catch the laugh of [the other]477-the other , was a perpetual source of irritation , which [her]112-julia own sense of propriety could but just smooth over . When [Julia]112-julia looked back , it was with a countenance of delight , and whenever [she]112-julia spoke to [them]990-they , it was in the highest spirits : “ [her]112-julia view of [the country]493-the country was charming , [she]112-julia wished [they]990-they could all see it , ”[112-julia] etc . ; but [her]112-julia only offer of exchange was addressed to [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , as [they]990-they gained [the summit of [a long hill]995-a long hill]994-the summit of a long hill , and was not more inviting than this : “ Here is [a fine burst of country]4256-a fine burst of country . [I]127-miss crawford wish [you]127-miss crawford had [my]127-miss crawford seat , but [I]127-miss crawford dare say [you]127-miss crawford will not take it , let [me]127-miss crawford press [you]127-miss crawford ever so much ; ”[127-miss crawford] and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford could hardly answer before [they]990-they were moving again at a good pace . When [they]990-they came within the influence of [Sotherton]27-sotherton associations , it was better for [Miss Bertram]112-julia , who might be said to have two strings to [her]112-julia bow . [She]112-julia had [Rushworth]126-maria feelings , and [Crawford]133-mr. crawford feelings , and in [the vicinity of [Sotherton]27-sotherton]996-the vicinity of sotherton the former had considerable effect . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s consequence was [hers]112-julia . [She]112-julia could not tell [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford that “ [those woods]4257-those woods belonged to [Sotherton]27-sotherton , ”[112-julia] [she]112-julia could not carelessly observe that “ [she]112-julia believed that it was now all [[Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s property on each side of [the road]4259-the road]4258-mr. rushworth ’s property on each side of the road , ”[112-julia] without elation of heart ; and it was a pleasure to increase with [their]990-they approach to [the capital freehold mansion]997-the capital freehold mansion , and [ancient manorial residence of [the family]3724-the family]998-ancient manorial residence of the family , with all [its]998-ancient manorial residence of the family rights of court - leet and court - baron . “ Now [we]990-they shall have [no more rough road]4260-no more rough road , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; [our]990-they difficulties are over . The rest of the way is such as it ought to be . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny has made it since [he]113-fanny succeeded to [the estate]4261-the estate . [Here]3798-here begins [the village]524-the village . [Those cottages]4264-those cottages are really a disgrace . The church spire is reckoned remarkably handsome . [I]127-miss crawford am glad [the church]4265-the church is not so close to [the great house]4266-the great house as often happens in old places . The annoyance of the bells must be terrible . There is [the parsonage]368-the parsonage : [a tidy - looking house]4268-a tidy - looking house , and [I]127-miss crawford understand [the clergyman]4269-the clergyman and [[his]4269-the clergyman wife]546-his wife are [very decent people]4271-very decent people . Those are [almshouses]4272-almshouses , built by [some of [the family]3724-the family]4273-some of the family . To the right is [[the steward]599-the steward ’s house]4276-the steward ’s house ; [he]599-the steward is [a very respectable man]4277-a very respectable man . Now [we]4278-we are coming to the lodge - gates ; but [we]4278-we have nearly a mile through [the park]3753-the park still . [It]4276-the steward ’s house is not ugly , [you]4280-you see , at this end ; there is some fine timber , but the situation of [the house]427-the house is dreadful . [We]4278-we go down hill to [it]427-the house for half a mile , and it is a pity , for [it]427-the house would not be [an ill - looking place]4282-an ill - looking place if [it]427-the house had a better approach . ”[127-miss crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was not slow to admire ; [she]127-miss crawford pretty well guessed [Miss Bertram]112-julia ’s feelings , and made it a point of honour to promote [her]112-julia enjoyment to the utmost . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was all delight and volubility ; and even [Fanny]113-fanny had something to say in admiration , and might be heard with complacency . [Her]112-julia eye was eagerly taking in everything within [her]112-julia reach ; and after being at some pains to get a view of [the house]427-the house , and observing that “ it was a sort of building which [she]112-julia could not look at but with respect , ”[112-julia] [she]112-julia added , “ Now , where is [the avenue]4044-the avenue ? [The house]427-the house fronts the east , [I]112-julia perceive . [The avenue]4044-the avenue , therefore , must be at the back of [it]427-the house . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny talked of the west front . ”[112-julia] “ Yes , [it]427-the house is exactly behind [the house]427-the house ; begins at a little distance , and ascends for half a mile to the extremity of [the grounds]4287-the grounds . [You]112-julia may see something of it here — something of the more distant trees . It is oak entirely . ”[112-julia] [Miss Bertram]112-julia could now speak with decided information of what [she]112-julia had known nothing about when [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had asked [her]112-julia opinion ; and [her]112-julia spirits were in as happy a flutter as vanity and pride could furnish , when [they]1001-they drove up to the spacious stone steps before the principal entrance . [CHAPTER IX Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was at the door to receive [[his]113-fanny fair lady]1002-his fair lady ; and [the whole party]1003-the whole party were welcomed by [him]113-fanny with due attention . In [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room [they]1003-the whole party were met with equal cordiality by [the mother]3960-the mother , and [Miss Bertram]112-julia had all the distinction with each that [she]112-julia could wish . After the business of arriving was over , it was first necessary to eat , and the doors were thrown open to admit [them]1003-the whole party through [one or two intermediate rooms]1006-one or two intermediate rooms into [the appointed dining - parlour]1007-the appointed dining - parlour , where a collation was prepared with abundance and elegance . Much was said , and much was ate , and all went well . The particular object of the day was then considered . How would [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford like , in what manner would [he]133-mr. crawford chuse , to take a survey of [the grounds]4287-the grounds ? [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny mentioned [his]113-fanny curricle . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford suggested the greater desirableness of [some carriage]1009-some carriage which might convey more than two . “ To be depriving [themselves]934-the young ladies of the advantage of other eyes and other judgments , might be an evil even beyond the loss of present pleasure . ”[126-maria] [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria proposed that the chaise should be taken also ; but this was scarcely received as an amendment : [the young ladies]934-the young ladies neither smiled nor spoke . [Her]126-maria next proposition , of shewing [the house]427-the house to such of [them]934-the young ladies as had not been [there]3696-there before , was more acceptable , for [Miss Bertram]112-julia was pleased to have [its]427-the house size displayed , and [all]874-all were glad to be doing something . [The whole party]1003-the whole party rose accordingly , and under [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ’s guidance were shewn through [a number of rooms]1015-a number of rooms , all lofty , and many large , and amply furnished in the taste of fifty years back , with shining floors , solid mahogany , rich damask , marble , gilding , and carving , each handsome in its way . Of pictures there were abundance , and some few good , but the larger part were family portraits , no longer anything to [anybody]3668-anybody but [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , who had been at great pains to learn all that [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper could teach , and was now almost equally well qualified to shew [the house]427-the house . On the present occasion [she]126-maria addressed [herself]126-maria chiefly to [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford and [Fanny]113-fanny , but there was no comparison in the willingness of [their]934-the young ladies attention ; for [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , who had seen scores of [great houses]1019-great houses , and cared for none of [them]1019-great houses , had only the appearance of civilly listening , while [Fanny]113-fanny , to whom everything was almost as interesting as it was new , attended with unaffected earnestness to all that [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria could relate of [the family]3724-the family in former times , its rise and grandeur , regal visits and loyal efforts , delighted to connect anything with history already known , or warm [her]126-maria imagination with scenes of the past . The situation of [the house]427-the house excluded the possibility of much prospect from [any of [the rooms]428-the rooms]1022-any of the rooms ; and while [Fanny]113-fanny and [some of [the others]347-the others]1024-some of the others were attending [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , [Henry Crawford]131-henry was looking grave and shaking [his]131-henry head at the windows . [Every room on the west front]1026-every room on the west front looked across a lawn to the beginning of [the avenue]4044-the avenue immediately beyond tall iron palisades and gates . Having visited [many more rooms]1028-many more rooms than could be supposed to be of any other use than to contribute to the window - tax , and find employment for [housemaids]1029-housemaids , “ Now , ”[126-maria] said [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , “ [we]1030-we are coming to [the chapel]4288-the chapel , which properly [we]1030-we ought to enter from above , and look down upon ; but as [we]1030-we are quite among [friends]3751-friends , [I]126-maria will take [you]113-fanny in this way , if [you]113-fanny will excuse [me]126-maria . ”[126-maria] [They]1030-we entered . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s imagination had prepared [her]1031-i for something grander than [a mere spacious , oblong room , fitted up for the purpose of devotion]1032-a mere spacious , oblong room , fitted up for the purpose of devotion : with nothing more striking or more solemn than the profusion of mahogany , and the crimson velvet cushions appearing over the ledge of [the family gallery above]1033-the family gallery above . “ [I]1031-i am disappointed , ”[1031-i] said [she]1031-i , in a low voice , to [Edmund]108-edmund . “ This is not [my]1031-i idea of [a chapel]4290-a chapel . There is nothing awful here , nothing melancholy , nothing grand . Here are [no aisles]4291-no aisles , no arches , no inscriptions , no banners . No banners , [cousin]3759-cousin , to be ‘ blown by the night wind of heaven . ’ No signs that [a ‘ Scottish monarch]4293-a ‘ scottish monarch sleeps below . ’ ”[1031-i] “ [You]113-fanny forget , [Fanny]113-fanny , how lately all this has been built , and for how confined a purpose , compared with [the old chapels of [castles]4295-castles and [monasteries]4296-monasteries]4294-the old chapels of castles and monasteries . It was only for the private use of [the family]3724-the family . [They]3724-the family have been buried , [I]1031-i suppose , in [the parish church]4298-the parish church . _ There _ [you]113-fanny must look for the banners and the achievements . ”[1031-i] “ It was foolish of [me]126-maria not to think of all that ; but [I]126-maria am disappointed . ”[126-maria] [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria began [her]126-maria relation . “ [This chapel]4299-this chapel was fitted up as [you]113-fanny see [it]4299-this chapel , in [James the Second]37-james the second ’s time . Before that period , as [I]126-maria understand , the pews were only wainscot ; and there is some reason to think that the linings and cushions of the pulpit and [family]4300-family seat were only purple cloth ; but this is not quite certain . [It]4299-this chapel is [a handsome chapel]4301-a handsome chapel , and was formerly in constant use both morning and evening . Prayers were always read in [it]4299-this chapel by [the domestic chaplain]4302-the domestic chaplain , within the memory of [many]4303-many ; but [the late Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny left it off . ”[126-maria] “ [Every generation]4304-every generation has its improvements , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , with a smile , to [Edmund]108-edmund . [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria was gone to repeat [her]126-maria lesson to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ; and [Edmund]108-edmund , [Fanny]113-fanny , and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford remained in a cluster together . “ It is a pity , ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny , “ that the custom should have been discontinued . It was a valuable part of former times . There is something in [a chapel]4290-a chapel and [chaplain]4306-chaplain so much in character with [a great house]4307-a great house , with one ’s ideas of what [such a household]4308-such a household should be ! [A whole family assembling regularly for the purpose of prayer]4309-a whole family assembling regularly for the purpose of prayer is fine ! ”[113-fanny] “ Very fine indeed , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , laughing . “ It must do [the heads of [the family]3724-the family]4310-the heads of the family a great deal of good to force [all [the poor housemaids]4313-the poor housemaids and [footmen]4314-footmen]4312-all the poor housemaids and footmen to leave business and pleasure , and say [their]4312-all the poor housemaids and footmen prayers here twice a day , while [they]4312-all the poor housemaids and footmen are inventing excuses [themselves]4312-all the poor housemaids and footmen for staying away . ”[127-miss crawford] “ _ That _ is hardly [Fanny]113-fanny ’s idea of a family assembling , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund . “ If [the master]4315-the master and [mistress]4316-mistress do _ not _ attend [themselves]4312-all the poor housemaids and footmen , there must be more harm than good in the custom . ”[108-edmund] “ At any rate , it is safer to leave [people]3906-people to [their]3906-people own devices on such subjects . [Everybody]408-everybody likes to go [their]3906-people own way — to chuse [their]3906-people own time and manner of devotion . The obligation of attendance , the formality , the restraint , the length of time — altogether it is a formidable thing , and what [nobody]360-nobody likes ; and if [the good people who used to kneel and gape in that gallery]4320-the good people who used to kneel and gape in that gallery could have foreseen that the time would ever come when [men]395-men and [women]988-women might lie another ten minutes in bed , when [they]4320-the good people who used to kneel and gape in that gallery woke with a headache , without danger of reprobation , because [chapel]4323-chapel was missed , [they]4320-the good people who used to kneel and gape in that gallery would have jumped with joy and envy . Can not [you]4324-you imagine with what unwilling feelings [the former belles of [the house of [Rushworth]126-maria]4326-the house of rushworth]4325-the former belles of the house of rushworth did many a time repair to [this chapel]4299-this chapel ? [The young Mrs. Eleanors]161-the young mrs. eleanors and [Mrs. Bridgets]162-mrs. bridgets — starched up into seeming piety , but with heads full of something very different — especially if [the poor chaplain]4328-the poor chaplain were not worth looking at — and , in those days , [I]1034-i fancy parsons were very inferior even to what [they]4328-the poor chaplain are now . ”[1034-i] For a few moments [she]1034-i was unanswered . [Fanny]113-fanny coloured and looked at [Edmund]108-edmund , but felt too angry for speech ; and [he]108-edmund needed a little recollection before [he]108-edmund could say , “ [Your]113-fanny lively mind can hardly be serious even on serious subjects . [You]113-fanny have given [us]4329-we an amusing sketch , and human nature can not say it was not so . [We]4329-we must all feel _ at _ _ times _ the difficulty of fixing [our]4329-we thoughts as [we]4329-we could wish ; but if [you]113-fanny are supposing it a frequent thing , that is to say , a weakness grown into a habit from neglect , what could be expected from the _ private _ devotions of [such persons]4330-such persons ? Do [you]113-fanny think the minds which are suffered , which are indulged in wanderings in [a chapel]4290-a chapel , would be more collected in [a closet]4332-a closet ? ”[108-edmund] “ Yes , very likely . [They]4330-such persons would have two chances at least in [their]4330-such persons favour . There would be less to distract the attention from without , and it would not be tried so long . ”[112-julia] “ The mind which does not struggle against itself under _ one _ circumstance , would find objects to distract it in the _ other _ , [I]108-edmund believe ; and the influence of the place and of example may often rouse better feelings than are begun with . The greater length of the service , however , [I]108-edmund admit to be sometimes too hard a stretch upon the mind . [One]766-one wishes it were not so ; but [I]108-edmund have not yet left [Oxford]39-oxford long enough to forget what [chapel]4323-chapel prayers are . ”[108-edmund] While this was passing , the rest of [the party]907-the party being scattered about [the chapel]4288-the chapel , [Julia]112-julia called [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s attention to [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister , by saying , “ Do look at [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny and [Maria]126-maria , standing side by side , exactly as if the ceremony were going to be performed . Have not [they]4335-they completely the air of it ? ”[112-julia] [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford smiled [his]133-mr. crawford acquiescence , and stepping forward to [Maria]126-maria , said , in a voice which [she]126-maria only could hear , “ [I]133-mr. crawford do not like to see [Miss Bertram]112-julia so near the altar . ”[133-mr. crawford] Starting , [the lady]718-the lady instinctively moved a step or two , but recovering [herself]718-the lady in a moment , affected to laugh , and asked [him]133-mr. crawford , in a tone not much louder , “ If [he]133-mr. crawford would give [her]126-maria away ? ”[718-the lady] “ [I]133-mr. crawford am afraid [I]133-mr. crawford should do it very awkwardly , ”[133-mr. crawford] was [his]133-mr. crawford reply , with a look of meaning .
