[Julia]112-julia , joining [them]1039-we at the moment , carried on the joke . “ Upon [my]112-julia word , it is really a pity that it should not take place directly , if [we]1039-we had but a proper licence , for here [we]1039-we are altogether , and nothing in [the world]315-the world could be more snug and pleasant . ”[112-julia] And [she]112-julia talked and laughed about it with so little caution as to catch the comprehension of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny and [[his]113-fanny mother]629-his mother , and expose [[her]718-the lady sister]331-her sister to the whispered gallantries of [[her]718-the lady lover]1042-her lover , while [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria spoke with proper smiles and dignity of its being a most happy event to [her]126-maria whenever it took place . “ If [Edmund]108-edmund were but in orders ! ”[112-julia] cried [Julia]112-julia , and running to where [he]133-mr. crawford stood with [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford and [Fanny]113-fanny : “ [[My]133-mr. crawford dear]3657-my dear [Edmund]108-edmund , if [you]108-edmund were but in orders now , [you]108-edmund might perform the ceremony directly . How unlucky that [you]108-edmund are not ordained ; [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny and [Maria]126-maria are quite ready . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s countenance , as [Julia]112-julia spoke , might have amused [a disinterested observer]1043-a disinterested observer . [She]112-julia looked almost aghast under the new idea [she]112-julia was receiving . [Fanny]113-fanny pitied [her]112-julia . “ How distressed [she]112-julia will be at what [she]112-julia said just now , ”[113-fanny] passed across [her]112-julia mind . “ Ordained ! ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; “ what , are [you]112-julia to be [a clergyman]500-a clergyman ? ”[127-miss crawford] “ Yes ; [I]127-miss crawford shall take orders soon after [[my]127-miss crawford father]3762-my father ’s return — probably at Christmas . ”[127-miss crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , rallying [her]127-miss crawford spirits , and recovering [her]127-miss crawford complexion , replied only , “ If [I]127-miss crawford had known this before , [I]127-miss crawford would have spoken of the cloth with more respect , ”[127-miss crawford] and turned the subject . [The chapel]4288-the chapel was soon afterwards left to the silence and stillness which reigned in it , with few interruptions , throughout the year . [Miss Bertram]112-julia , displeased with [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister , led the way , and [all]874-all seemed to feel that [they]874-all had been [there]3696-there long enough . [The lower part of [the house]427-the house]1048-the lower part of the house had been now entirely shewn , and [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , never weary in the cause , would have proceeded towards the principal staircase , and taken [them]874-all through all [the rooms above]1050-the rooms above , if [[her]126-maria son]637-her son had not interposed with a doubt of there being time enough . “ For if , ”[637-her son] said [he]637-her son , with the sort of self - evident proposition which [many a clearer head]1052-many a clearer head does not always avoid , “ [we]874-all are _ too _ long going over [the house]427-the house , [we]874-all shall not have time for what is to be done out of doors . It is past two , and [we]874-all are to dine at five . ”[126-maria] [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria submitted ; and the question of surveying [the grounds]4287-the grounds , with [the who]1054-the who and the how , was likely to be more fully agitated , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was beginning to arrange by what junction of [carriages]1055-carriages and horses most could be done , when [the young people]391-the young people , meeting with an outward door , temptingly open on a flight of steps which led immediately to turf and shrubs , and all the sweets of [pleasure - grounds]1057-pleasure - grounds , as by one impulse , one wish for air and liberty , all walked out . “ Suppose [we]874-all turn down here for the present , ”[126-maria] said [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , civilly taking the hint and following [them]391-the young people . “ Here are the greatest number of [our]874-all plants , and here are the curious pheasants . ”[126-maria] “ Query , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , looking round [him]637-her son , “ whether [we]874-all may not find something to employ [us]874-all [here]3798-here before [we]874-all go farther ? [I]133-mr. crawford see walls of great promise . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , shall [we]874-all summon a council on [this lawn]4342-this lawn ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [James]163-james , ”[126-maria] said [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria to [[her]126-maria son]637-her son , “ [I]126-maria believe [the wilderness]4343-the wilderness will be new to [all the party]4344-all the party . [The Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams have never seen [the wilderness]4343-the wilderness yet . ”[126-maria] No objection was made , but for some time there seemed no inclination to move in any plan , or to any distance . [All]874-all were attracted at first by the plants or the pheasants , and all dispersed about in happy independence . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was the first to move forward to examine the capabilities of [that end of [the house]427-the house]1060-that end of the house . [The lawn , bounded on each side by a high wall]1062-the lawn , bounded on each side by a high wall , contained beyond [the first planted area]1063-the first planted area [a bowling - green]1064-a bowling - green , and beyond [the bowling - green]1065-the bowling - green [a long terrace walk]1066-a long terrace walk , backed by iron palisades , and commanding a view over [them]1067-them into the tops of [the trees of [the wilderness immediately adjoining]1069-the wilderness immediately adjoining]1068-the trees of the wilderness immediately adjoining . It was [a good spot for fault - finding]1070-a good spot for fault - finding . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was soon followed by [Miss Bertram]112-julia and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ; and when , after a little time , [the others]347-the others began to form into [parties]1072-parties , [these three]1073-these three were found in busy consultation on [the terrace]1074-the terrace by [Edmund]108-edmund , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , and [Fanny]113-fanny , who seemed as naturally to unite , and who , after a short participation of [their]1073-these three regrets and difficulties , left [them]1073-these three and walked on . [The remaining three]1075-the remaining three , [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , and [Julia]112-julia , were still far behind ; for [Julia]112-julia , whose happy star no longer prevailed , was obliged to keep by the side of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , and restrain [her]112-julia impatient feet to [that lady]1076-that lady ’s slow pace , while [[her]112-julia aunt]463-her aunt , having fallen in with [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper , who was come out to feed the pheasants , was lingering behind in gossip with [her]112-julia . [Poor Julia]164-poor julia , [the only one out of the nine not tolerably satisfied with [their]1073-these three lot]1079-the only one out of the nine not tolerably satisfied with their lot , was now in a state of complete penance , and as different from the Julia of the barouche - box as could well be imagined . The politeness which [she]112-julia had been brought up to practise as a duty made it impossible for [her]112-julia to escape ; while the want of that higher species of self - command , that just consideration of [others]361-others , that knowledge of [her]112-julia own heart , that principle of right , which had not formed any essential part of [her]112-julia education , made [her]112-julia miserable under it . “ This is insufferably hot , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , when [they]1073-these three had taken one turn on [the terrace]1074-the terrace , and were drawing a second time to the door in the middle which opened to [the wilderness]4343-the wilderness . “ Shall [any of [us]1073-these three]4346-any of us object to being comfortable ? [Here]3798-here is a nice little wood , if one can but get into [it]3798-here . What happiness if the door should not be locked ! but of course it is ; for in [these great places]4348-these great places [the gardeners]4349-the gardeners are [the only people who can go where [they]4349-the gardeners like]4350-the only people who can go where they like . ”[127-miss crawford] The door , however , proved not to be locked , and [they]1073-these three were all agreed in turning joyfully through [it]1083-it , and leaving the unmitigated glare of day behind . A considerable flight of steps landed [them]1073-these three in [the wilderness]4343-the wilderness , which was a planted wood of about two acres , and though chiefly of larch and laurel , and beech cut down , and though laid out with too much regularity , was darkness and shade , and natural beauty , compared with the bowling - green and [the terrace]1074-the terrace . [They]1073-these three all felt the refreshment of it , and for some time could only walk and admire . At length , after a short pause , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford began with , “ So [you]127-miss crawford are to be [a clergyman]500-a clergyman , [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund . This is rather a surprise to [me]127-miss crawford . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Why should it surprise [you]127-miss crawford ? [You]127-miss crawford must suppose [me]113-fanny designed for some profession , and might perceive that [I]113-fanny am neither [a lawyer]4352-a lawyer , nor [a soldier]4353-a soldier , nor [a sailor]510-a sailor . ”[113-fanny] “ Very true ; but , in short , it had not occurred to [me]113-fanny . And [you]127-miss crawford know there is generally [an uncle]4355-an uncle or [a grandfather]4356-a grandfather to leave a fortune to [the second son]4357-the second son . ”[113-fanny] “ A very praiseworthy practice , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ but not quite universal . [I]108-edmund am one of the exceptions , and _ being _ one , must do something for [myself]108-edmund . ”[108-edmund] “ But why are [you]127-miss crawford to be [a clergyman]500-a clergyman ? [I]113-fanny thought _ that _ was always the lot of [the youngest]406-the youngest , where there were [many to chuse]4360-many to chuse before [him]406-the youngest . ”[113-fanny] “ Do [you]127-miss crawford think [the church itself]4361-the church itself never chosen , then ? ”[113-fanny] “ _ Never _ is a black word . But yes , in the _ never _ of conversation , which means _ not _ _ very _ _ often _ , [I]108-edmund do think it . For what is to be done in [the church]4265-the church ? [Men]395-men love to distinguish [themselves]395-men , and in either of the other lines distinction may be gained , but not in [the church]4265-the church . [A clergyman]500-a clergyman is nothing . ”[108-edmund] “ The _ nothing _ of conversation has its gradations , [I]113-fanny hope , as well as the _ never _ . [A clergyman]500-a clergyman can not be high in state or fashion . [He]500-a clergyman must not head mobs , or set [the ton]4367-the ton in dress . But [I]113-fanny can not call that situation nothing which has the charge of all that is of the first importance to [mankind]4368-mankind , individually or collectively considered , temporally and eternally , which has the guardianship of religion and morals , and consequently of the manners which result from [their]395-men influence . [No one here]4369-no one here can call the _ office _ nothing . If [the man who holds it]4370-the man who holds it is so , it is by the neglect of [his]4370-the man who holds it duty , by foregoing its just importance , and stepping out of [his]4370-the man who holds it place to appear what [he]4370-the man who holds it ought not to appear . ”[113-fanny] “ _ [You]127-miss crawford _ assign greater consequence to [the clergyman]4269-the clergyman than [one]766-one has been used to hear given , or than [I]113-fanny can quite comprehend . [One]766-one does not see much of this influence and importance in [society]4374-society , and how can it be acquired where [they]766-one are so seldom seen [themselves]766-one ? How can two sermons a week , even supposing them worth hearing , supposing [the preacher]4375-the preacher to have the sense to prefer [Blair]165-blair ’s to [his]4375-the preacher own , do all that [you]127-miss crawford speak of ? govern the conduct and fashion the manners of [a large congregation]4376-a large congregation for the rest of the week ? [One]766-one scarcely sees [a clergyman]500-a clergyman out of [[his]500-a clergyman pulpit]4379-his pulpit . ”[113-fanny] “ _ [You]127-miss crawford _ are speaking of [London]6-london , _ [I]108-edmund _ am speaking of [the nation at large]4380-the nation at large . ”[108-edmund] “ [The metropolis]4381-the metropolis , [I]113-fanny imagine , is a pretty fair sample of the rest . ”[113-fanny] “ Not , [I]113-fanny should hope , of the proportion of virtue to vice throughout [the kingdom]791-the kingdom . [We]4383-we do not look in [great cities]4384-great cities for [our]4383-we best morality . It is not there that [respectable people of any denomination]4385-respectable people of any denomination can do most good ; and it certainly is not there that the influence of [the clergy]4386-the clergy can be most felt . [A fine preacher]4387-a fine preacher is followed and admired ; but it is not in fine preaching only that [a good clergyman]4388-a good clergyman will be useful in [[his]4388-a good clergyman parish]4389-his parish and [[his]4388-a good clergyman neighbourhood]4390-his neighbourhood , where [the parish]3860-the parish and [neighbourhood]4392-neighbourhood are of a size capable of knowing [his]4388-a good clergyman private character , and observing [his]4388-a good clergyman general conduct , which in [London]6-london can rarely be the case . [The clergy]4386-the clergy are lost there in [the crowds of [[their]4386-the clergy parishioners]4395-their parishioners]4394-the crowds of their parishioners . [They]4386-the clergy are known to the largest part only as [preachers]4396-preachers . And with regard to [their]4386-the clergy influencing public manners , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford must not misunderstand [me]113-fanny , or suppose [I]113-fanny mean to call [them]4386-the clergy [the arbiters of good - breeding]4397-the arbiters of good - breeding , [the regulators of refinement and courtesy]4398-the regulators of refinement and courtesy , [the masters of the ceremonies of life]4399-the masters of the ceremonies of life . The _ manners _ [I]113-fanny speak of might rather be called _ conduct _ , perhaps , the result of good principles ; the effect , in short , of those doctrines which it is [their]4386-the clergy duty to teach and recommend ; and it will , [I]113-fanny believe , be everywhere found , that as [the clergy]4386-the clergy are , or are not what [they]4386-the clergy ought to be , so are the rest of [the nation]4401-the nation . ”[113-fanny] “ Certainly , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , with gentle earnestness . “ There , ”[127-miss crawford] cried [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ [you]113-fanny have quite convinced [Miss Price]137-miss price already . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]113-fanny wish [I]113-fanny could convince [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford too . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]127-miss crawford do not think [you]113-fanny ever will , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford , with an arch smile ; “ [I]127-miss crawford am just as much surprised now as [I]127-miss crawford was at first that [you]113-fanny should intend to take orders . [You]113-fanny really are fit for something better . Come , do change [your]113-fanny mind . It is not too late . Go into the law . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Go into the law ! With as much ease as [I]113-fanny was told to go into [this wilderness]4402-this wilderness . ”[113-fanny] “ Now [you]113-fanny are going to say something about law being [the worst wilderness of the two]4403-the worst wilderness of the two , but [I]113-fanny forestall [you]113-fanny ; remember , [I]113-fanny have forestalled [you]113-fanny . ”[113-fanny] “ [You]113-fanny need not hurry when the object is only to prevent [my]127-miss crawford saying a _ bon _ _ mot _ , for there is not the least wit in [my]127-miss crawford nature . [I]127-miss crawford am [a very matter - of - fact , plain - spoken being]4404-a very matter - of - fact , plain - spoken being , and may blunder on the borders of a repartee for half an hour together without striking it out . ”[127-miss crawford] A general silence succeeded . [Each]166-each was thoughtful . [Fanny]113-fanny made the first interruption by saying , “ [I]113-fanny wonder that [I]113-fanny should be tired with only walking in [this sweet wood]4405-this sweet wood ; but the next time [we]4406-we come to a seat , if it is not disagreeable to [you]108-edmund , [I]113-fanny should be glad to sit down for a little while . ”[113-fanny] “ [[My]108-edmund dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] cried [Edmund]108-edmund , immediately drawing [her]1086-you arm within [his]108-edmund , “ how thoughtless [I]108-edmund have been ! [I]108-edmund hope [you]108-edmund are not very tired . Perhaps , ”[108-edmund] turning to [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ [[my]108-edmund other companion]4408-my other companion may do [me]108-edmund the honour of taking an arm . ”[108-edmund] “ Thank [you]113-fanny , but [I]1086-you am not at all tired . ”[1086-you] [She]1086-you took it , however , as [she]1086-you spoke , and the gratification of having [her]1086-you do so , of feeling such a connexion for the first time , made [him]108-edmund a little forgetful of [Fanny]113-fanny . “ [You]1086-you scarcely touch [me]108-edmund , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund . “ [You]1086-you do not make [me]108-edmund of any use . What a difference in the weight of [a woman]644-a woman ’s arm from that of [a man]4410-a man ! At Oxford [I]108-edmund have been a good deal used to have [a man]4410-a man lean on [me]108-edmund for the length of [a street]4412-a street , and [you]1086-you are only [a fly in the comparison]4413-a fly in the comparison . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]1086-you am really not tired , which [I]1086-you almost wonder at ; for [we]4414-we must have walked at least a mile in [this wood]4415-this wood . Do not [you]1086-you think [we]4414-we have ? ”[1086-you] “ Not half a mile , ”[108-edmund] was [his]108-edmund sturdy answer ; for [he]108-edmund was not yet so much in love as to measure distance , or reckon time , with feminine lawlessness . “ Oh ! [you]1086-you do not consider how much [we]4414-we have wound about . [We]4414-we have taken such a very serpentine course , and the wood itself must be half a mile long in a straight line , for [we]4414-we have never seen the end of it yet since [we]4414-we left the first great path . ”[108-edmund] “ But if [you]1086-you remember , before [we]4414-we left [that first great path]4416-that first great path , [we]4414-we saw directly to the end of [it]4416-that first great path . [We]4414-we looked down [the whole vista]4417-the whole vista , and saw [it]4416-that first great path closed by iron gates , and it could not have been more than a furlong in length . ”[1086-you] “ Oh ! [I]1086-you know nothing of [your]1086-you furlongs , but [I]1086-you am sure it is a very long wood , and that [we]4414-we have been winding in and out ever since [we]4414-we came into [it]4416-that first great path ; and therefore , when [I]1086-you say that [we]4414-we have walked a mile in [it]4416-that first great path , [I]1086-you must speak within compass . ”[1086-you] “ [We]4414-we have been exactly a quarter of an hour here , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , taking out [his]108-edmund watch . “ Do [you]1086-you think [we]4414-we are walking four miles an hour ? ”[108-edmund] “ Oh ! do not attack [me]1086-you with [your]1086-you watch . A watch is always too fast or too slow . [I]1086-you can not be dictated to by a watch . ”[1086-you] A few steps farther brought [them]1087-they out at the bottom of the very walk [they]1087-they had been talking of ; and standing back , well shaded and sheltered , and looking over [a ha - ha]1088-a ha - ha into [the park]3753-the park , was a comfortable - sized bench , on which [they]1087-they all sat down . “ [I]108-edmund am afraid [you]1090-you are very tired , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , observing [her]1090-you ; “ why would not [you]1090-you speak sooner ? This will be a bad day ’s amusement for [you]1090-you if [you]1090-you are to be knocked up . Every sort of exercise fatigues [her]1090-you so soon , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , except riding . ”[108-edmund] “ How abominable in [you]1086-you , then , to let [me]127-miss crawford engross [her]1090-you horse as [I]127-miss crawford did all last week ! [I]127-miss crawford am ashamed of [you]1086-you and of [myself]127-miss crawford , but it shall never happen again . ”[127-miss crawford] “ _ [Your]1086-you _ attentiveness and consideration makes [me]108-edmund more sensible of [my]108-edmund own neglect . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s interest seems in safer hands with [you]1086-you than with [me]108-edmund . ”[108-edmund] “ That [she]1090-you should be tired now , however , gives [me]108-edmund no surprise ; for there is nothing in the course of one ’s duties so fatiguing as what [we]4418-we have been doing this morning : seeing [a great house]4307-a great house , dawdling from [one room]4420-one room to another , straining [one]766-one ’s eyes and [one]766-one ’s attention , hearing what [one]766-one does not understand , admiring what [one]766-one does not care for . It is generally allowed to be the greatest bore in [the world]315-the world , and [Miss Price]137-miss price has found it so , though [she]137-miss price did not know it . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]113-fanny shall soon be rested , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny ; “ to sit in the shade on a fine day , and look upon verdure , is the most perfect refreshment . ”[113-fanny] After sitting a little while [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was up again . “ [I]127-miss crawford must move , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford ; “ resting fatigues [me]127-miss crawford . [I]127-miss crawford have looked across [the ha - ha]4426-the ha - ha till [I]127-miss crawford am weary . [I]127-miss crawford must go and look through that iron gate at the same view , without being able to see it so well . ”[127-miss crawford] [Edmund]108-edmund left the seat likewise . “ Now , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , if [you]127-miss crawford will look up [the walk]4427-the walk , [you]127-miss crawford will convince [yourself]127-miss crawford that it can not be half a mile long , or half half a mile . ”[108-edmund] “ [It]4428-it is an immense distance , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford ; “ [I]127-miss crawford see _ that _ with a glance . ”[127-miss crawford] [He]108-edmund still reasoned with [her]127-miss crawford , but in vain . [She]127-miss crawford would not calculate , [she]127-miss crawford would not compare . [She]127-miss crawford would only smile and assert . The greatest degree of rational consistency could not have been more engaging , and [they]1091-they talked with mutual satisfaction . At last it was agreed that [they]1091-they should endeavour to determine the dimensions of [the wood]1092-the wood by walking a little more about it . [They]1091-they would go to one end of [it]1092-the wood , in the line [they]1091-they were then in — for there was a straight green walk along the bottom by the side of [the ha - ha]4426-the ha - ha — and perhaps turn a little way in some other direction , if it seemed likely to assist [them]1091-they , and be back in a few minutes . [Fanny]113-fanny said [she]127-miss crawford was rested , and would have moved too , but this was not suffered . [Edmund]108-edmund urged [her]127-miss crawford remaining where [she]127-miss crawford was with an earnestness which [she]127-miss crawford could not resist , and [she]127-miss crawford was left on the bench to think with pleasure of [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin ’s care , but with great regret that [she]127-miss crawford was not stronger . [She]127-miss crawford watched [them]1091-they till [they]1091-they had turned the corner , and listened till all sound of [them]1091-they had ceased . CHAPTER X A quarter of an hour , twenty minutes , passed away , and [Fanny]113-fanny was still thinking of [Edmund]108-edmund , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , and [herself]113-fanny , without interruption from [any one]3817-any one . [She]127-miss crawford began to be surprised at being left so long , and to listen with an anxious desire of hearing [their]1091-they steps and [their]1091-they voices again . [She]127-miss crawford listened , and at length [she]127-miss crawford heard ; [she]127-miss crawford heard voices and feet approaching ; but [she]127-miss crawford had just satisfied [herself]127-miss crawford that it was not those [she]127-miss crawford wanted , when [Miss Bertram]112-julia , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford issued from the same path which [she]127-miss crawford had trod [herself]127-miss crawford , and were before [her]127-miss crawford . “ [Miss Price]137-miss price all alone ”[133-mr. crawford] and “ [[My]133-mr. crawford dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , how comes this ? ”[133-mr. crawford] were the first salutations . [She]127-miss crawford told [her]127-miss crawford story . “ Poor dear [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[127-miss crawford] cried [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin , “ how ill [you]113-fanny have been used by [them]1098-them ! [You]113-fanny had better have staid with [us]1098-them . ”[127-miss crawford] Then seating [herself]127-miss crawford with [a gentleman on each side]1097-a gentleman on each side , [she]127-miss crawford resumed the conversation which had engaged [them]1098-them before , and discussed the possibility of improvements with much animation . Nothing was fixed on ; but [Henry Crawford]131-henry was full of ideas and projects , and , generally speaking , whatever [he]131-henry proposed was immediately approved , first by [her]127-miss crawford , and then by [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , whose principal business seemed to be to hear [the others]347-the others , and who scarcely risked an original thought of [his]113-fanny own beyond a wish that [they]1098-them had seen [[his]113-fanny friend]319-his friend [[Smith]144-smith ’s place]4035-smith ’s place . After some minutes spent in this way , [Miss Bertram]112-julia , observing the iron gate , expressed a wish of passing through [it]1102-it into [the park]3753-the park , that [their]1098-them views and [their]1098-them plans might be more comprehensive . It was the very thing of all others to be wished , it was the best , it was the only way of proceeding with any advantage , in [Henry Crawford]131-henry ’s opinion ; and [he]131-henry directly saw [a knoll not half a mile off , which would give [them]1098-them exactly the requisite command of [the house]427-the house]1104-a knoll not half a mile off , which would give them exactly the requisite command of the house . Go therefore [they]1098-them must to [that knoll]1106-that knoll , and through that gate ; but the gate was locked . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny wished [he]113-fanny had brought the key ; [he]113-fanny had been very near thinking whether [he]113-fanny should not bring the key ; [he]113-fanny was determined [he]113-fanny would never come without the key again ; but still this did not remove the present evil . [They]1098-them could not get through ; and as [Miss Bertram]112-julia ’s inclination for so doing did by no means lessen , it ended in [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s declaring outright that [he]113-fanny would go and fetch the key . [He]113-fanny set off accordingly . “ It is undoubtedly the best thing [we]1098-them can do now , as [we]1098-them are so far from [the house]427-the house already , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , when [he]113-fanny was gone . “ Yes , there is nothing else to be done . But now , sincerely , do not [you]113-fanny find [the place]459-the place altogether worse than [you]113-fanny expected ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ No , indeed , far otherwise . [I]112-julia find [it]459-the place better , grander , more complete in [its]459-the place style , though that style may not be the best . And to tell [you]113-fanny the truth , ”[112-julia] speaking rather lower , “ [I]112-julia do not think that _ [I]112-julia _ shall ever see [Sotherton]27-sotherton again with so much pleasure as [I]112-julia do now . Another summer will hardly improve it to [me]112-julia . ”[112-julia] After a moment ’s embarrassment [the lady]718-the lady replied , “ [You]113-fanny are too much [a man of [the world]315-the world]848-a man of the world not to see with the eyes of [the world]315-the world . If [other people]4182-other people think [Sotherton]27-sotherton improved , [I]718-the lady have no doubt that [you]113-fanny will . ”[718-the lady] “ [I]133-mr. crawford am afraid [I]133-mr. crawford am not quite so much [the man of [the world]315-the world]4436-the man of the world as might be good for [me]133-mr. crawford in some points . [My]133-mr. crawford feelings are not quite so evanescent , nor [my]133-mr. crawford memory of the past under such easy dominion as one finds to be the case with [men of]4438-men of [the world]315-the world . ”[133-mr. crawford] This was followed by a short silence . [Miss Bertram]112-julia began again . “ [You]113-fanny seemed to enjoy [your]113-fanny drive [here]3798-here very much this morning . [I]112-julia was glad to see [you]113-fanny so well entertained . [You]113-fanny and [Julia]112-julia were laughing the whole way . ”[112-julia] “ Were [we]4441-we ? Yes , [I]718-the lady believe [we]4441-we were ; but [I]718-the lady have not the least recollection at what . Oh ! [I]718-the lady believe [I]718-the lady was relating to [her]112-julia some ridiculous stories of [an old Irish groom of [[my]718-the lady uncle]3761-my uncle ’s]4442-an old irish groom of my uncle ’s . [[Your]113-fanny sister]4444-your sister loves to laugh . ”[718-the lady] “ [You]1108-you think [her]112-julia more light - hearted than [I]718-the lady am ? ”[718-the lady] “ More easily amused , ”[1108-you] [he]1108-you replied ; “ consequently , [you]113-fanny know , ”[1108-you] smiling , “ better company . [I]1108-you could not have hoped to entertain [you]113-fanny with Irish anecdotes during a ten miles ’ drive . ”[1108-you] “ Naturally , [I]718-the lady believe , [I]718-the lady am as lively as [Julia]112-julia , but [I]718-the lady have more to think of now . ”[718-the lady] “ [You]113-fanny have , undoubtedly ; and there are situations in which very high spirits would denote insensibility . [Your]113-fanny prospects , however , are too fair to justify want of spirits . [You]113-fanny have a very smiling scene before [you]113-fanny . ”[718-the lady] “ Do [you]1108-you mean literally or figuratively ? Literally , [I]1109-i conclude . Yes , certainly , the sun shines , and [the park]3753-the park looks very cheerful . But unluckily that iron gate , that ha - ha , give [me]1109-i a feeling of restraint and hardship . ‘ [I]1109-i can not get out , ’ as [the starling]4446-the starling said . ”[1109-i] As [she]1109-i spoke , and it was with expression , [she]1109-i walked to the gate : [he]1108-you followed [her]1109-i . “ [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny is so long fetching this key ! ”[1109-i] “ And for [the world]315-the world [you]113-fanny would not get out without the key and without [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s authority and protection , or [I]718-the lady think [you]113-fanny might with little difficulty pass round the edge of the gate , here , with [my]718-the lady assistance ; [I]718-the lady think it might be done , if [you]113-fanny really wished to be more at large , and could allow [yourself]113-fanny to think it not prohibited . ”[718-the lady] “ Prohibited ! nonsense ! [I]1109-i certainly can get out that way , and [I]1109-i will . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny will be [here]3798-here in a moment , [you]113-fanny know ; [we]4449-we shall not be out of sight . ”[1109-i] “ Or if [we]4449-we are , [Miss Price]137-miss price will be so good as to tell [him]113-fanny that [he]113-fanny will find [us]4449-we near [that knoll]1106-that knoll : [the grove of oak on [the knoll]4452-the knoll]4451-the grove of oak on the knoll . ”[1109-i] [Fanny]113-fanny , feeling all this to be wrong , could not help making an effort to prevent it . “ [You]113-fanny will hurt [yourself]113-fanny , [Miss Bertram]112-julia , ”[1110-she] [she]1110-she cried ; “ [you]113-fanny will certainly hurt [yourself]113-fanny against those spikes ; [you]113-fanny will tear [your]113-fanny gown ; [you]113-fanny will be in danger of slipping into the ha - ha . [You]113-fanny had better not go . ”[1110-she] [[Her]1110-she cousin]3692-her cousin was safe on the other side while these words were spoken , and , smiling with all the good - humour of success , [she]1110-she said , “ Thank [you]112-julia , [[my]1110-she dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , but [I]1110-she and [my]1110-she gown are alive and well , and so good - bye . ”[1110-she] [Fanny]113-fanny was again left to [her]1110-she solitude , and with no increase of pleasant feelings , for [she]1110-she was sorry for almost all that [she]1110-she had seen and heard , astonished at [Miss Bertram]112-julia , and angry with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . By taking a circuitous , and , as it appeared to [her]1110-she , very unreasonable direction to [the knoll]4452-the knoll , they were soon beyond [her]1110-she eye ; and for some minutes longer [she]1110-she remained without sight or sound of [any companion]1113-any companion . [She]1110-she seemed to have the little wood all to [herself]1110-she . [She]1110-she could almost have thought that [Edmund]108-edmund and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had left [it]1114-it , but that it was impossible for [Edmund]108-edmund to forget [her]1110-she so entirely . [She]1110-she was again roused from disagreeable musings by sudden footsteps : [somebody]1115-somebody was coming at a quick pace down [the principal walk]1116-the principal walk . [She]1110-she expected [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , but it was [Julia]112-julia , who , hot and out of breath , and with a look of disappointment , cried out on seeing [her]1110-she , “ Heyday ! Where are [the others]347-the others ? [I]113-fanny thought [Maria]126-maria and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford were with [you]112-julia . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny explained . “ A pretty trick , upon [my]113-fanny word ! [I]113-fanny can not see [them]347-the others anywhere , ”[113-fanny] looking eagerly into [the park]3753-the park . “ But [they]347-the others can not be very far off , and [I]113-fanny think [I]113-fanny am equal to as much as [Maria]126-maria , even without help . ”[113-fanny] “ But , [Julia]112-julia , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny will be here in a moment with the key . Do wait for [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . ”[113-fanny] “ Not [I]113-fanny , indeed . [I]113-fanny have had enough of [the family]3724-the family for one morning . Why , [child]4456-child , [I]113-fanny have but this moment escaped from [[his]113-fanny horrible mother]4457-his horrible mother . Such a penance as [I]113-fanny have been enduring , while [you]112-julia were sitting here so composed and so happy ! It might have been as well , perhaps , if [you]112-julia had been in [[my]113-fanny place]4458-my place , but [you]112-julia always contrive to keep out of these scrapes . ”[113-fanny] This was a most unjust reflection , but [Fanny]113-fanny could allow for it , and let it pass : [Julia]112-julia was vexed , and [her]112-julia temper was hasty ; but [she]112-julia felt that it would not last , and therefore , taking no notice , only asked [her]112-julia if [she]112-julia had not seen [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . “ Yes , yes , [we]4459-we saw [him]113-fanny . [He]113-fanny was posting away as if upon life and death , and could but just spare time to tell [us]4459-we [his]113-fanny errand , and where [you]112-julia all were . ”[112-julia] “ It is a pity [he]113-fanny should have so much trouble for nothing . ”[112-julia] “ _ That _ is [Miss Maria]100-maria ’s concern . [I]112-julia am not obliged to punish [myself]112-julia for _ [her]100-maria _ sins . [The mother]3960-the mother [I]112-julia could not avoid , as long as [[my]112-julia tiresome aunt]4461-my tiresome aunt was dancing about with [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper , but [the son [I]112-julia _ can _ get away from]4463-the son i _ can _ get away from . ”[112-julia] And [she]112-julia immediately scrambled across the fence , and walked away , not attending to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s last question of whether [she]112-julia had seen anything of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford and [Edmund]108-edmund . The sort of dread in which [Fanny]113-fanny now sat of seeing [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny prevented [her]112-julia thinking so much of [their]1118-they continued absence , however , as [she]112-julia might have done . [She]112-julia felt that [he]113-fanny had been very ill - used , and was quite unhappy in having to communicate what had passed . [He]113-fanny joined [her]112-julia within five minutes after [Julia]112-julia ’s exit ; and though [she]112-julia made the best of the story , [he]113-fanny was evidently mortified and displeased in no common degree . At first [he]113-fanny scarcely said anything ; [his]113-fanny looks only expressed [his]113-fanny extreme surprise and vexation , and [he]113-fanny walked to the gate and stood there , without seeming to know what to do . “ [They]1118-they desired [me]113-fanny to stay — [[my]113-fanny cousin]3764-my cousin [Maria]100-maria charged [me]113-fanny to say that [you]112-julia would find [them]1118-they at [that knoll]1106-that knoll , or thereabouts . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny do not believe [I]113-fanny shall go any farther , ”[113-fanny] said [he]113-fanny sullenly ; “ [I]113-fanny see nothing of [them]1118-they . By the time [I]113-fanny get to [the knoll]4452-the knoll [they]1118-they may be gone somewhere else . [I]113-fanny have had walking enough . ”[113-fanny] And [he]113-fanny sat down with a most gloomy countenance by [Fanny]113-fanny . “ [I]1119-she am very sorry , ”[1119-she] said [she]1119-she ; “ it is very unlucky . ”[1119-she] And [she]1119-she longed to be able to say something more to the purpose . After an interval of silence , “ [I]113-fanny think [they]1118-they might as well have staid for [me]113-fanny , ”[113-fanny] said [he]113-fanny . “ [Miss Bertram]112-julia thought [you]113-fanny would follow [her]112-julia . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny should not have had to follow [her]112-julia if [she]112-julia had staid . ”[113-fanny] This could not be denied , and [Fanny]113-fanny was silenced . After another pause , [he]113-fanny went on—“Pray , [Miss Price]137-miss price , are [you]137-miss price such a great admirer of [this Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford as [some people]3784-some people are ? For [my]113-fanny part , [I]113-fanny can see nothing in [him]133-mr. crawford . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny do not think [him]133-mr. crawford at all handsome . ”[113-fanny] “ [Handsome]167-handsome ! [Nobody]360-nobody can call such [an undersized man handsome]4469-an undersized man handsome . [He]133-mr. crawford is not five foot nine . [I]113-fanny should not wonder if [he]133-mr. crawford is not more than five foot eight . [I]113-fanny think [he]133-mr. crawford is [an ill - looking fellow]4470-an ill - looking fellow . In [my]113-fanny opinion , [these Crawfords]4471-these crawfords are [no addition]4472-no addition at all . [We]4473-we did very well without [them]4471-these crawfords . ”[113-fanny] A small sigh escaped [Fanny]113-fanny here , and [she]1120-she did not know how to contradict [him]1121-you . “ If [I]1120-she had made any difficulty about fetching the key , there might have been some excuse , but [I]1120-she went the very moment [she]1120-she said [she]1120-she wanted it . ”[1120-she] “ Nothing could be more obliging than [your]1121-you manner , [I]1121-you am sure , and [I]1121-you dare say [you]1121-you walked as fast as [you]1121-you could ; but still it is some distance , [you]1121-you know , from this spot to [the house]427-the house , quite into [the house]427-the house ; and when [people]3906-people are waiting , [they]3906-people are bad judges of time , and every half minute seems like five . ”[1121-you] [He]1121-you got up and walked to the gate again , and “ wished [he]1121-you had had the key about [him]1121-you at the time . ”[1121-you] [Fanny]113-fanny thought [she]1120-she discerned in [his]1121-you standing there an indication of relenting , which encouraged [her]1120-she to another attempt , and [she]1120-she said , therefore , “ It is a pity [you]1121-you should not join [them]3906-people . [They]3906-people expected to have a better view of [the house]427-the house from [that part of [the park]3753-the park]4478-that part of the park , and will be thinking how it may be improved ; and nothing of that sort , [you]1121-you know , can be settled without [you]1121-you . ”[1120-she] [She]1120-she found [herself]1120-she more successful in sending away than in retaining [a companion]1122-a companion . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was worked on . “ Well , ”[113-fanny] said [he]113-fanny , “ if [you]113-fanny really think [I]113-fanny had better go : it would be foolish to bring the key for nothing . ”[113-fanny] And letting [himself]113-fanny out , [he]113-fanny walked off without farther ceremony . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s thoughts were now all engrossed by the two who had left [her]1120-she so long ago , and getting quite impatient , [she]1120-she resolved to go in search of [them]1123-their . [She]1120-she followed [their]1123-their steps along the bottom walk , and had just turned up into another , when the voice and the laugh of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford once more caught [her]1120-she ear ; the sound approached , and a few more windings brought [them]1123-their before [her]1120-she . [They]1123-their were just returned into [the wilderness]4343-the wilderness from [the park]3753-the park , to which a sidegate , not fastened , had tempted [them]1123-their very soon after [their]1123-their leaving [her]1120-she , and [they]1123-their had been across [a portion of [the park]3753-the park]1126-a portion of the park into [the very avenue]1128-the very avenue which [Fanny]113-fanny had been hoping the whole morning to reach at last , and had been sitting down under one of the trees . This was [their]1123-their history . It was evident that [they]1123-their had been spending [their]1123-their time pleasantly , and were not aware of the length of [their]1123-their absence . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s best consolation was in being assured that [Edmund]108-edmund had wished for [her]1120-she very much , and that [he]108-edmund should certainly have come back for [her]1120-she , had [she]1120-she not been tired already ; but this was not quite sufficient to do away with the pain of having been left a whole hour , when [he]108-edmund had talked of only a few minutes , nor to banish the sort of curiosity [she]1120-she felt to know what [they]1123-their had been conversing about all that time ; and the result of the whole was to [her]1120-she disappointment and depression , as [they]1123-their prepared by general agreement to return to [the house]427-the house . On reaching the bottom of the steps to [the terrace]1074-the terrace , [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris presented [themselves]1123-their at the top , just ready for [the wilderness]4343-the wilderness , at the end of an hour and a half from [their]1123-their leaving [the house]427-the house . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had been too well employed to move faster . Whatever cross - accidents had occurred to intercept the pleasures of [[her]1120-she nieces]478-her nieces , [she]1120-she had found a morning of complete enjoyment ; for [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper , after a great many courtesies on the subject of pheasants , had taken [her]1120-she to [the dairy]1135-the dairy , told [her]1120-she all about [their]1123-their cows , and given [her]1120-she the receipt for a famous cream cheese ; and since [Julia]112-julia ’s leaving [them]1123-their [they]1123-their had been met by [the gardener , with whom [she]1120-she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for [she]1120-she had set [him]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness right as to [[his]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness grandson]1137-his grandson ’s illness]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness , convinced [him]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness that it was an ague , and promised [him]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness a charm for it ; and [he]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness , in return , had shewn [her]1120-she all [his]1136-the gardener , with whom she had made a most satisfactory acquaintance , for she had set him right as to his grandson ’s illness choicest nursery of plants , and actually presented [her]1120-she with a very curious specimen of heath . On this _ rencontre _ [they]1123-their all returned to [the house]427-the house together , there to lounge away the time as [they]1123-their could with sofas , and chit - chat , and [Quarterly Reviews]168-quarterly reviews , till the return of [the others]347-the others , and the arrival of dinner . It was late before [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams and [the two gentlemen]1140-the two gentlemen came in , and [their]1123-their ramble did not appear to have been more than partially agreeable , or at all productive of anything useful with regard to the object of the day . By [their]1123-their own accounts [they]1123-their had been all walking after [each other]681-each other , and the junction which had taken place at last seemed , to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s observation , to have been as much too late for re - establishing harmony , as it confessedly had been for determining on any alteration . [She]1120-she felt , as [she]1120-she looked at [Julia]112-julia and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , that [hers]1120-she was not [the only dissatisfied bosom amongst [them]1123-their]1142-the only dissatisfied bosom amongst them : there was gloom on the face of each . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [Miss Bertram]112-julia were much more gay , and [she]1120-she thought that [he]113-fanny was taking particular pains , during dinner , to do away any little resentment of [the other two]1143-the other two , and restore general good - humour . Dinner was soon followed by tea and coffee , a ten miles ’ drive [home]367-home allowed no waste of hours ; and from the time of [their]1123-their sitting down to table , it was a quick succession of busy nothings till [the carriage]969-the carriage came to the door , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , having fidgeted about , and obtained a few pheasants ’ eggs and a cream cheese from [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper , and made abundance of civil speeches to [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , was ready to lead the way . At the same moment [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , approaching [Julia]112-julia , said , “ [I]133-mr. crawford hope [I]133-mr. crawford am not to lose [[my]133-mr. crawford companion]4480-my companion , unless [she]4480-my companion is afraid of the evening air in so exposed a seat . ”[133-mr. crawford] The request had not been foreseen , but was very graciously received , and [Julia]112-julia ’s day was likely to end almost as well as it began . [Miss Bertram]112-julia had made up [her]112-julia mind to something different , and was a little disappointed ; but [her]112-julia conviction of being really [the one preferred]1147-the one preferred comforted [her]112-julia under it , and enabled [her]112-julia to receive [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s parting attentions as [she]112-julia ought . [He]113-fanny was certainly better pleased to hand [her]112-julia into the barouche than to assist [her]112-julia in ascending the box , and [his]113-fanny complacency seemed confirmed by the arrangement . “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , this has been a fine day for [you]113-fanny , upon [my]105-mrs. norris word , ”[105-mrs. norris] said [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , as [they]1148-they drove through [the park]3753-the park . “ Nothing but pleasure from beginning to end ! [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [you]113-fanny ought to be very much obliged to [[your]113-fanny aunt]3826-your aunt [Bertram]112-julia and [me]105-mrs. norris for contriving to let [you]113-fanny go . A pretty good day ’s amusement [you]113-fanny have had ! ”[105-mrs. norris] [Maria]126-maria was just discontented enough to say directly , “ [I]126-maria think _ [you]113-fanny _ have done pretty well [yourself]113-fanny , [ma’am]4007-ma’am . [Your]113-fanny lap seems full of good things , and here is a basket of something between [us]1148-they which has been knocking [my]126-maria elbow unmercifully . ”[126-maria] “ [[My]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear , it is only a beautiful little heath , which [that nice old gardener]4484-that nice old gardener would make [me]105-mrs. norris take ; but if it is in [your]113-fanny way , [I]105-mrs. norris will have it in [my]105-mrs. norris lap directly . There , [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny shall carry that parcel for [me]105-mrs. norris ; take great care of it : do not let it fall ; it is a cream cheese , just like the excellent one [we]1148-they had at dinner . Nothing would satisfy that good old [Mrs. Whitaker]169-mrs. whitaker , but [my]105-mrs. norris taking one of the cheeses . [I]105-mrs. norris stood out as long as [I]105-mrs. norris could , till the tears almost came into [her]169-mrs. whitaker eyes , and [I]105-mrs. norris knew it was just the sort that [[my]105-mrs. norris sister]3790-my sister would be delighted with . That [Mrs. Whitaker]169-mrs. whitaker is a treasure ! [She]169-mrs. whitaker was quite shocked when [I]105-mrs. norris asked [her]169-mrs. whitaker whether wine was allowed at the second table , and [she]169-mrs. whitaker has turned away [two housemaids]4486-two housemaids for wearing white gowns . Take care of the cheese , [Fanny]113-fanny . Now [I]105-mrs. norris can manage the other parcel and the basket very well . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ What else have [you]27-sotherton been spunging ? ”[126-maria] said [Maria]126-maria , half - pleased that [Sotherton]27-sotherton should be so complimented . “ Spunging , [[my]126-maria dear]3657-my dear ! It is nothing but four of those beautiful pheasants ’ eggs , which [Mrs. Whitaker]169-mrs. whitaker would quite force upon [me]126-maria : [she]169-mrs. whitaker would not take a denial . [She]169-mrs. whitaker said it must be such an amusement to [me]126-maria , as [she]169-mrs. whitaker understood [I]126-maria lived quite alone , to have [a few living creatures of that sort]4488-a few living creatures of that sort ; and so to be sure it will . [I]126-maria shall get [the dairymaid]4489-the dairymaid to set [them]4488-a few living creatures of that sort under the first spare hen , and if [they]4488-a few living creatures of that sort come to good [I]126-maria can have [them]4488-a few living creatures of that sort moved to [[my]126-maria own house]4490-my own house and borrow a coop ; and it will be a great delight to [me]126-maria in [my]126-maria lonely hours to attend to them . And if [I]126-maria have good luck , [[your]4491-your mother]4140-your mother shall have some . ”[126-maria] It was a beautiful evening , mild and still , and the drive was as pleasant as the serenity of Nature could make it ; but when [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ceased speaking , it was altogether a silent drive to [those within]1150-those within . [Their]1150-those within spirits were in general exhausted ; and to determine whether the day had afforded most pleasure or pain , might occupy the meditations of almost all . CHAPTER XI The day at [Sotherton]27-sotherton , with all its imperfections , afforded [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams much more agreeable feelings than were derived from the letters from [Antigua]18-antigua , which soon afterwards reached [Mansfield]3-mansfield . It was much pleasanter to think of [Henry Crawford]131-henry than of [[their]1150-those within father]398-their father ; and to think of [[their]1150-those within father]398-their father in [England]14-england again within a certain period , which these letters obliged [them]1150-those within to do , was a most unwelcome exercise . November was the black month fixed for [his]398-their father return . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas wrote of it with as much decision as experience and anxiety could authorise . [His]101-sir thomas business was so nearly concluded as to justify [him]101-sir thomas in proposing to take [his]101-sir thomas passage in the September packet , and [he]101-sir thomas consequently looked forward with the hope of being with [[his]101-sir thomas beloved family]1153-his beloved family again early in November . [Maria]126-maria was more to be pitied than [Julia]112-julia ; for to [her]126-maria [the father]1154-the father brought [a husband]1155-a husband , and the return of [the friend]1156-the friend most solicitous for [her]126-maria happiness would unite [her]126-maria to the lover , on whom [she]126-maria had chosen that happiness should depend . It was a gloomy prospect , and all [she]126-maria could do was to throw a mist over it , and hope when the mist cleared away [she]126-maria should see something else . It would hardly be _ early _ in November , there were generally delays , a bad passage or _ something _ ; that favouring _ something _ which [everybody who shuts [their]1157-everybody who shuts their eyes while they look , or their understandings while they reason eyes while [they]1157-everybody who shuts their eyes while they look , or their understandings while they reason look , or [their]1157-everybody who shuts their eyes while they look , or their understandings while they reason understandings while [they]1157-everybody who shuts their eyes while they look , or their understandings while they reason reason]1157-everybody who shuts their eyes while they look , or their understandings while they reason , feels the comfort of . It would probably be the middle of November at least ; the middle of November was three months off . Three months comprised thirteen weeks . Much might happen in thirteen weeks . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas would have been deeply mortified by a suspicion of half that [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters felt on the subject of [his]101-sir thomas return , and would hardly have found consolation in a knowledge of the interest it excited in the breast of [another young lady]1159-another young lady . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , on walking up with [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother to spend the evening at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , heard the good news ; and though seeming to have no concern in the affair beyond politeness , and to have vented all [her]127-miss crawford feelings in a quiet congratulation , heard it with an attention not so easily satisfied . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris gave the particulars of the letters , and the subject was dropt ; but after tea , as [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was standing at an open window with [Edmund]108-edmund and [Fanny]113-fanny looking out on a twilight scene , while [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams , [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , and [Henry Crawford]131-henry were all busy with candles at the pianoforte , [she]127-miss crawford suddenly revived it by turning round towards [the group]878-the group , and saying , “ How happy [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny looks ! [He]113-fanny is thinking of [November]171-november . ”[127-miss crawford] [Edmund]108-edmund looked round at [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny too , but had nothing to say . “ [[Your]127-miss crawford father]4493-your father ’s return will be a very interesting event . ”[113-fanny] “ It will , indeed , after such an absence ; an absence not only long , but including so many dangers . ”[127-miss crawford] “ It will be the forerunner also of other interesting events : [[your]127-miss crawford sister]4444-your sister ’s marriage , and [your]127-miss crawford taking orders . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Yes . ”[113-fanny] “ Do n’t be affronted , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford , laughing , “ but it does put [me]127-miss crawford in mind of some of [the old heathen heroes , who , after performing great exploits in [a foreign land]4496-a foreign land , offered sacrifices to [the gods]4497-the gods on [their]4497-the gods safe return]4495-the old heathen heroes , who , after performing great exploits in a foreign land , offered sacrifices to the gods on their safe return . ”[127-miss crawford] “ There is no sacrifice in the case , ”[108-edmund] replied [Edmund]108-edmund , with a serious smile , and glancing at the pianoforte again ; “ it is entirely [her]127-miss crawford own doing . ”[108-edmund] “ Oh yes [I]127-miss crawford know it is . [I]127-miss crawford was merely joking . [She]127-miss crawford has done no more than what [every young woman]4498-every young woman would do ; and [I]127-miss crawford have no doubt of [her]127-miss crawford being extremely happy . [My]127-miss crawford other sacrifice , of course , [you]127-miss crawford do not understand . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [My]127-miss crawford taking orders , [I]127-miss crawford assure [you]127-miss crawford , is quite as voluntary as [Maria]126-maria ’s marrying . ”[127-miss crawford] “ It is fortunate that [your]127-miss crawford inclination and [[your]127-miss crawford father]4493-your father ’s convenience should accord so well . There is a very good living kept for [you]127-miss crawford , [I]108-edmund understand , hereabouts . ”[108-edmund] “ Which [you]108-edmund suppose has biassed [me]127-miss crawford ? ”[127-miss crawford] “ But _ that _ [I]113-fanny am sure it has not , ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny . “ Thank [you]127-miss crawford for [your]127-miss crawford good word , [Fanny]113-fanny , but it is more than [I]113-fanny would affirm [myself]113-fanny . On the contrary , the knowing that there was such a provision for [me]113-fanny probably did bias [me]113-fanny . Nor can [I]113-fanny think it wrong that it should . There was no natural disinclination to be overcome , and [I]113-fanny see no reason why [a man]4410-a man should make [a worse clergyman]4501-a worse clergyman for knowing that [he]4410-a man will have a competence early in life . [I]113-fanny was in safe hands . [I]113-fanny hope [I]113-fanny should not have been influenced [myself]113-fanny in a wrong way , and [I]113-fanny am sure [[my]113-fanny father]3762-my father was too conscientious to have allowed it . [I]113-fanny have no doubt that [I]113-fanny was biased , but [I]113-fanny think it was blamelessly . ”[113-fanny] “ It is the same sort of thing , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , after a short pause , “ as for [the son of [an admiral]4504-an admiral to go into [the navy]4121-the navy]4503-the son of an admiral to go into the navy , or [the son of [a general]4507-a general to be in [the army]4508-the army]4506-the son of a general to be in the army , and [nobody]360-nobody sees anything wrong in that . [Nobody]360-nobody wonders that [they]360-nobody should prefer the line where [[their]360-nobody friends]4511-their friends can serve [them]360-nobody best , or suspects [them]360-nobody to be less in earnest in it than [they]360-nobody appear . ”[113-fanny] “ No , [[my]127-miss crawford dear]3657-my dear Miss Price , and for reasons good . The profession , either [navy or army]4513-navy or army , is [its]4513-navy or army own justification . [It]4513-navy or army has everything in [its]4513-navy or army favour : heroism , danger , bustle , fashion . [Soldiers]4514-soldiers and [sailors]4515-sailors are always acceptable in [society]4374-society . [Nobody]360-nobody can wonder that [men]395-men are [soldiers]4514-soldiers and [sailors]4515-sailors . ”[127-miss crawford] “ But the motives of [a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment may be fairly suspected , [you]127-miss crawford think ? ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund . “ To be justified in [your]127-miss crawford eyes , [he]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment must do it in the most complete uncertainty of any provision . ”[108-edmund] “ What ! take orders without a living ! No ; that is madness indeed ; absolute madness . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Shall [I]127-miss crawford ask [you]127-miss crawford how [the church]4265-the church is to be filled , if [a man]4410-a man is neither to take orders with a living nor without ? No ; for [you]127-miss crawford certainly would not know what to say . But [I]127-miss crawford must beg some advantage to [the clergyman]4269-the clergyman from [your]127-miss crawford own argument . As [he]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment can not be influenced by those feelings which [you]127-miss crawford rank highly as temptation and reward to [the soldier]4525-the soldier and [sailor]4526-sailor in [their]4269-the clergyman choice of a profession , as heroism , and noise , and fashion , are all against [him]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment , [he]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment ought to be less liable to the suspicion of wanting sincerity or good intentions in the choice of [his]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Oh ! no doubt [he]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment is very sincere in preferring an income ready made , to the trouble of working for one ; and has the best intentions of doing nothing all the rest of [his]4521-a man who takes orders with the certainty of preferment days but eat , drink , and grow fat . It is indolence , [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , indeed . Indolence and love of ease ; a want of all laudable ambition , of taste for good company , or of inclination to take the trouble of being agreeable , which make [men clergymen]4527-men clergymen . [A clergyman]500-a clergyman has nothing to do but be slovenly and selfish — read the newspaper , watch the weather , and quarrel with [[his]500-a clergyman wife]546-his wife . [[His]500-a clergyman curate]4530-his curate does all the work , and the business of [his]500-a clergyman own life is to dine . ”[108-edmund] “ There are [such clergymen]4531-such clergymen , no doubt , but [I]127-miss crawford think [they]4531-such clergymen are not so common as to justify [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford in esteeming it [their]4531-such clergymen general character . [I]127-miss crawford suspect that in this comprehensive and ( may [I]127-miss crawford say ) commonplace censure , [you]4532-you are not judging from [yourself]4532-you , but from [prejudiced persons]4533-prejudiced persons , whose opinions [you]4532-you [have been in the habit of hearing]4534-have been in the habit of hearing . It is impossible that [your]4532-you own observation can have given [you]4532-you much knowledge of [the clergy]4386-the clergy . [You]4532-you can have been personally acquainted with very few of a set of men [you]4532-you condemn so conclusively . [You]4532-you are speaking what [you]4532-you have been told at [[your]4532-you uncle]3760-your uncle ’s table . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]127-miss crawford speak what appears to [me]127-miss crawford the general opinion ; and where an opinion is general , it is usually correct . Though [_]117-_ [I]127-miss crawford _ have not seen much of the domestic lives of [clergymen]4537-clergymen , it is seen by too many to leave any deficiency of information . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Where [any one body of educated men , of whatever denomination]4538-any one body of educated men , of whatever denomination , are condemned indiscriminately , there must be a deficiency of information , or ( smiling ) of something else . [[Your]4532-you uncle]3760-your uncle , and [[his]3760-your uncle brother]805-his brother admirals , perhaps knew little of [clergymen]4537-clergymen beyond [the chaplains whom , good or bad , [they]4542-the chaplains whom , good or bad , they were always wishing away were always wishing away]4542-the chaplains whom , good or bad , they were always wishing away . ”[108-edmund] “ [Poor William]228-william ! [He]3760-your uncle has met with great kindness from [the chaplain of [the Antwerp]4544-the antwerp]4543-the chaplain of the antwerp , ”[127-miss crawford] was a tender apostrophe of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s , very much to the purpose of [her]1162-her own feelings if not of the conversation . “ [I]127-miss crawford have been so little addicted to take [my]127-miss crawford opinions from [[my]127-miss crawford uncle]3761-my uncle , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ that [I]127-miss crawford can hardly suppose — and since [you]4532-you push [me]127-miss crawford so hard , [I]127-miss crawford must observe , that [I]127-miss crawford am not entirely without the means of seeing what [clergymen]4537-clergymen are , being at this present time [the guest of [[my]127-miss crawford own brother]4548-my own brother]4547-the guest of my own brother , [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant . And though [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant is most kind and obliging to [me]127-miss crawford , and though [he]121-dr. grant is really [a gentleman]4549-a gentleman , and , [I]127-miss crawford dare say , [a good scholar and clever]4550-a good scholar and clever , and often preaches good sermons , and is very respectable , _ [I]127-miss crawford _ see [him]121-dr. grant to be an indolent , selfish _ bon _ _ vivant _ , who must have [his]121-dr. grant palate consulted in everything ; who will not stir a finger for the convenience of [any one]3817-any one ; and who , moreover , if [the cook]4552-the cook makes a blunder , is out of humour with [[his]4552-the cook excellent wife]4553-his excellent wife . To own the truth , [Henry]131-henry and [I]127-miss crawford were partly driven out this very evening by a disappointment about a green goose , which [he]121-dr. grant could not get the better of . [[My]127-miss crawford poor sister]3690-my poor sister was forced to stay and bear it . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]127-miss crawford do not wonder at [your]113-fanny disapprobation , upon [my]127-miss crawford word . It is a great defect of temper , made worse by a very faulty habit of self - indulgence ; and to see [[your]113-fanny sister]4444-your sister suffering from it must be exceedingly painful to such feelings as [yours]113-fanny . [Fanny]113-fanny , it goes against [us]4556-we . [We]4556-we can not attempt to defend [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant . ”[127-miss crawford] “ No , ”[113-fanny] replied [Fanny]113-fanny , “ but [we]4556-we need not give up [his]121-dr. grant profession for all that ; because , whatever profession [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant had chosen , [he]121-dr. grant would have taken a — not a good temper into it ; and as [he]121-dr. grant must , either in [the navy or army]4557-the navy or army , have had [a great many more people under [his]121-dr. grant command]4558-a great many more people under his command than [he]121-dr. grant has now , [I]113-fanny think more would have been made unhappy by [him]121-dr. grant as [a sailor]510-a sailor or [soldier]4560-soldier than as [a clergyman]500-a clergyman . Besides , [I]113-fanny can not but suppose that whatever there may be to wish otherwise in [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant would have been in a greater danger of becoming worse in a more active and worldly profession , where [he]121-dr. grant would have had less time and obligation — where [he]121-dr. grant might have escaped that knowledge of [himself]121-dr. grant , the _ frequency _ , at least , of that knowledge which it is impossible [he]121-dr. grant should escape as [he]121-dr. grant is now . [A man]4410-a man — [a sensible man]4563-a sensible man like [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , can not be in the habit of teaching [others]361-others [their]361-others duty every week , can not go to [church]4565-church twice every Sunday , and preach such very good sermons in so good a manner as [he]121-dr. grant does , without being the better for it [himself]121-dr. grant . It must make [him]121-dr. grant think ; and [I]113-fanny have no doubt that [he]121-dr. grant oftener endeavours to restrain [himself]121-dr. grant than [he]121-dr. grant would if [he]121-dr. grant had been anything but [a clergyman]500-a clergyman . ”[113-fanny] “ [We]4567-we can not prove to the contrary , to be sure ; but [I]127-miss crawford wish [you]4568-you a better fate , [Miss Price]137-miss price , than to be [the wife of [a man whose amiableness depends upon [his]121-dr. grant own sermons]4570-a man whose amiableness depends upon his own sermons]4569-the wife of a man whose amiableness depends upon his own sermons ; for though [he]121-dr. grant may preach [himself]121-dr. grant into a good - humour every Sunday , it will be bad enough to have [him]121-dr. grant quarrelling about green geese from Monday morning till Saturday night . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]108-edmund think [the man who could often quarrel with [Fanny]113-fanny]4571-the man who could often quarrel with fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund affectionately , “ must be beyond the reach of any sermons . ”[108-edmund] [Fanny]113-fanny turned farther into the window ; and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had only time to say , in a pleasant manner , “ [I]127-miss crawford fancy [Miss Price]137-miss price has been more used to deserve praise than to hear it ”[127-miss crawford] ; when , being earnestly invited by [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams to join in a glee , [she]127-miss crawford tripped off to the instrument , leaving [Edmund]108-edmund looking after [her]127-miss crawford in an ecstasy of admiration of all [her]127-miss crawford many virtues , from [her]127-miss crawford obliging manners down to [her]127-miss crawford light and graceful tread . “ There goes good - humour , [I]108-edmund am sure , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund presently . “ There goes a temper which would never give pain ! How well [she]127-miss crawford walks ! and how readily [she]127-miss crawford falls in with the inclination of [others]361-others ! joining [them]361-others the moment [she]127-miss crawford is asked . What a pity , ”[108-edmund] [he]108-edmund added , after an instant ’s reflection , “ that [she]127-miss crawford should have been in such hands ! ”[108-edmund] [Fanny]113-fanny agreed to it , and had the pleasure of seeing [him]108-edmund continue at the window with [her]127-miss crawford , in spite of the expected glee ; and of having [his]108-edmund eyes soon turned , like [hers]113-fanny , towards the scene without , where all that was solemn , and soothing , and lovely , appeared in the brilliancy of an unclouded night , and the contrast of the deep shade of [the woods]4061-the woods . [Fanny]113-fanny spoke [her]127-miss crawford feelings . “ Here ’s harmony ! ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford ; “ here ’s repose ! Here ’s what may leave all painting and all music behind , and what poetry only can attempt to describe ! Here ’s what may tranquillise every care , and lift the heart to rapture ! When [I]127-miss crawford look out on such a night as this , [I]127-miss crawford feel as if there could be neither wickedness nor sorrow in [the world]315-the world ; and there certainly would be less of both if the sublimity of Nature were more attended to , and [people]3906-people were carried more out of [themselves]3906-people by contemplating such a scene . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]113-fanny like to hear [your]113-fanny enthusiasm , [Fanny]113-fanny . It is a lovely night , and [they]3906-people are much to be pitied who have not been taught to feel , in some degree , as [you]113-fanny do ; who have not , at least , been given a taste for Nature in early life . [They]3906-people lose a great deal . ”[113-fanny] “ _ [You]113-fanny _ taught [me]1166-the singers to think and feel on the subject , [cousin]3759-cousin . ”[1166-the singers] “ [I]127-miss crawford had [a very apt scholar]4576-a very apt scholar . There ’s [Arcturus]172-arcturus looking very bright . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Yes , and the Bear . [I]113-fanny wish [I]113-fanny could see [Cassiopeia]173-cassiopeia . ”[113-fanny] “ [We]4577-we must go out on [the lawn]4578-the lawn for that . Should [you]1164-he be afraid ? ”[113-fanny] “ Not in the least . It is a great while since [we]4577-we have had any star - gazing . ”[1166-the singers] “ Yes ; [I]113-fanny do not know how it has happened . ”[113-fanny] The glee began . “ [We]4577-we will stay till this is finished , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[1164-he] said [he]1164-he , turning [his]1164-he back on the window ; and as it advanced , [she]1165-she had the mortification of seeing [him]1164-he advance too , moving forward by gentle degrees towards the instrument , and when it ceased , [he]1164-he was close by [the singers]1166-the singers , among the most urgent in requesting to hear the glee again . [Fanny]113-fanny sighed alone at the window till scolded away by [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s threats of catching cold . CHAPTER XII [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was to return in November , and [[his]101-sir thomas eldest son]496-his eldest son had duties to call [him]101-sir thomas earlier [home]367-home . The approach of [September]124-september brought tidings of [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , first in a letter to [the gamekeeper]1169-the gamekeeper and then in a letter to [Edmund]108-edmund ; and by the end of August [he]1164-he arrived [himself]1164-he , to be gay , agreeable , and gallant again as occasion served , or [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford demanded ; to tell of races and [Weymouth]40-weymouth , and parties and [friends]3751-friends , to which [she]1165-she might have listened six weeks before with some interest , and altogether to give [her]1165-she the fullest conviction , by the power of actual comparison , of [her]1165-she preferring [[his]1164-he younger brother]1171-his younger brother . It was very vexatious , and [she]1165-she was heartily sorry for it ; but so it was ; and so far from now meaning to marry [the elder]529-the elder , [she]1165-she did not even want to attract [him]529-the elder beyond what the simplest claims of conscious beauty required : [his]529-the elder lengthened absence from [Mansfield]3-mansfield , without anything but pleasure in view , and [his]529-the elder own will to consult , made it perfectly clear that [he]529-the elder did not care about [her]1165-she ; and [his]529-the elder indifference was so much more than equalled by [her]1165-she own , that were [he]529-the elder now to step forth [the owner of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield]1173-the owner of mansfield park , [the Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas complete , which [he]529-the elder was to be in time , [she]1165-she did not believe [she]1165-she could accept [him]529-the elder . The season and duties which brought [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund back to [Mansfield]3-mansfield took [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford into [Norfolk]19-norfolk . [Everingham]31-everingham could not do without [him]133-mr. crawford in the beginning of September . [He]133-mr. crawford went for a fortnight — a fortnight of such dullness to [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams as ought to have put [them]1174-them both on [their]1174-them guard , and made even [Julia]112-julia admit , in [her]112-julia jealousy of [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister , the absolute necessity of distrusting [his]133-mr. crawford attentions , and wishing [him]133-mr. crawford not to return ; and a fortnight of sufficient leisure , in the intervals of shooting and sleeping , to have convinced [the gentleman]671-the gentleman that [he]133-mr. crawford ought to keep longer away , had [he]133-mr. crawford been more in the habit of examining [his]133-mr. crawford own motives , and of reflecting to what the indulgence of [his]133-mr. crawford idle vanity was tending ; but , thoughtless and selfish from prosperity and bad example , [he]133-mr. crawford would not look beyond the present moment . [The sisters]327-the sisters , handsome , clever , and encouraging , were an amusement to [his]133-mr. crawford sated mind ; and finding nothing in [Norfolk]19-norfolk to equal the social pleasures of [Mansfield]130-mansfield , [he]133-mr. crawford gladly returned to [it]130-mansfield at the time appointed , and was welcomed thither quite as gladly by those whom [he]133-mr. crawford came to trifle with further . [Maria]126-maria , with only [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny to attend to [her]126-maria , and doomed to the repeated details of [his]133-mr. crawford day ’s sport , good or bad , [his]133-mr. crawford boast of [his]133-mr. crawford dogs , [his]133-mr. crawford jealousy of [[his]133-mr. crawford neighbours]1178-his neighbours , [his]133-mr. crawford doubts of [their]1178-his neighbours qualifications , and [his]133-mr. crawford zeal after poachers , subjects which will not find [their]1179-their way to [female feelings without some talent on one side or some attachment on the other]1180-female feelings without some talent on one side or some attachment on the other , had missed [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford grievously ; and [Julia]112-julia , unengaged and unemployed , felt all the right of missing [him]133-mr. crawford much more . [Each sister]332-each sister believed [herself]332-each sister the favourite . [Julia]112-julia might be justified in so doing by the hints of [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , inclined to credit what [she]123-mrs. grant wished , and [Maria]126-maria by the hints of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford [himself]133-mr. crawford . Everything returned into the same channel as before [his]133-mr. crawford absence ; [his]133-mr. crawford manners being to each so animated and agreeable as to lose no ground with either , and just stopping short of the consistence , the steadiness , the solicitude , and the warmth which might excite general notice .
