What gentleman among [you]4825-my good friends am [I]127-miss crawford to have the pleasure of making love to ? ”[127-miss crawford] For a moment [no one]404-no one spoke ; and then [many]4303-many spoke together to tell the same melancholy truth , that [they]4303-many had not yet got any [Anhalt]178-anhalt . “ [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was to be [Count Cassel]178-anhalt , but [no one]404-no one had yet undertaken [Anhalt]178-anhalt . ”[4303-many] “ [I]113-fanny had [my]113-fanny choice of the parts , ”[113-fanny] said [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ; “ but [I]113-fanny thought [I]113-fanny should like [the Count]1324-the count best , though [I]113-fanny do not much relish the finery [I]113-fanny am to have . ”[113-fanny] “ [You]113-fanny chose very wisely , [I]127-miss crawford am sure , ”[127-miss crawford] replied [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , with a brightened look ; “ [Anhalt]178-anhalt is a heavy part . ”[127-miss crawford] “ _ [The _ _ Count]4830-the _ _ count _ has two - and - forty speeches , ”[113-fanny] returned [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , “ which is no trifle . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]127-miss crawford am not at all surprised , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , after a short pause , “ at this want of an [Anhalt]178-anhalt . [Amelia]197-amelia deserves no better . [Such a forward young lady]4831-such a forward young lady may well frighten [the men]4832-the men . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]101-sir thomas should be but too happy in taking the part , if it were possible , ”[101-sir thomas] cried [Tom]101-sir thomas ; “ but , unluckily , [the Butler]203-the butler and [Anhalt]178-anhalt are in together . [I]101-sir thomas will not entirely give it up , however ; [I]101-sir thomas will try what can be done — [I]101-sir thomas will look it over again . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [[Your]127-miss crawford _ brother]4833-your _ brother _ should take the part , ”[174-mr. yates] said [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , in a low voice . “ Do not [you]127-miss crawford think [he]4833-your _ brother would ? ”[174-mr. yates] “ _ [I]101-sir thomas _ shall not ask [him]4833-your _ brother , ”[101-sir thomas] replied [Tom]101-sir thomas , in a cold , determined manner . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford talked of something else , and soon afterwards rejoined [the party]907-the party at the fire . “ [They]4832-the men do not want [me]127-miss crawford at all , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford , seating [herself]127-miss crawford . “ [I]127-miss crawford only puzzle [them]4832-the men , and oblige [them]4832-the men to make civil speeches . [Mr. Edmund Bertram]108-edmund , as [you]108-edmund do not act [yourself]108-edmund , [you]108-edmund will be [a disinterested adviser]4834-a disinterested adviser ; and , therefore , [I]127-miss crawford apply to _ [you]108-edmund _ . What shall [we]4835-we do for an [Anhalt]178-anhalt ? Is it practicable for any of [the others]347-the others to double it ? What is [your]108-edmund advice ? ”[127-miss crawford] “ [My]1352-he advice , ”[1352-he] said [he]1352-he calmly , “ is that [you]127-miss crawford change the play . ”[1352-he] “ _ [I]127-miss crawford _ should have no objection , ”[127-miss crawford] [she]127-miss crawford replied ; “ for though [I]127-miss crawford should not particularly dislike the part of [Amelia]197-amelia if well supported , that is , if everything went well , [I]127-miss crawford shall be sorry to be an inconvenience ; but as [they]4837-they do not chuse to hear [your]108-edmund advice at _ that _ _ table _ ”[127-miss crawford] ( looking round ) , “ it certainly will not be taken . ”[127-miss crawford] [Edmund]108-edmund said no more . “ If _ any _ part could tempt _ [you]108-edmund _ to act , [I]1353-the lady archly suppose it would be [Anhalt]178-anhalt , ”[1353-the lady archly] observed [the lady archly]1353-the lady archly , after a short pause ; “ for [he]1352-he is [a clergyman]500-a clergyman , [you]108-edmund know . ”[1353-the lady archly] “ _ That _ circumstance would by no means tempt [me]1352-he , ”[1352-he] [he]1352-he replied , “ for [I]1352-he should be sorry to make the character ridiculous by bad acting . It must be very difficult to keep [Anhalt]178-anhalt from appearing [a formal , solemn lecturer]4839-a formal , solemn lecturer ; and [the man who chuses the profession itself]4840-the man who chuses the profession itself is , perhaps , one of [the last who would wish to represent it on the stage]4841-the last who would wish to represent it on the stage . ”[1352-he] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was silenced , and with some feelings of resentment and mortification , moved [her]127-miss crawford chair considerably nearer the tea - table , and gave all [her]127-miss crawford attention to [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , who was presiding [there]3696-there . “ [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[101-sir thomas] cried [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas , from the other table , where the conference was eagerly carrying on , and the conversation incessant , “ [we]4842-we want [your]113-fanny services . ”[101-sir thomas] [Fanny]113-fanny was up in a moment , expecting some errand ; for the habit of employing [her]127-miss crawford in that way was not yet overcome , in spite of all that [Edmund]108-edmund could do . “ Oh ! [we]4842-we do not want to disturb [you]113-fanny from [your]113-fanny seat . [We]4842-we do not want [your]113-fanny _ present _ services . [We]4842-we shall only want [you]113-fanny in [our]4842-we play . [You]113-fanny must be [[Cottager]198-cottager ’s wife]4744-cottager ’s wife . ”[108-edmund] “ [Me]113-fanny ! ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny , sitting down again with a most frightened look . “ Indeed [you]108-edmund must excuse [me]113-fanny . [I]113-fanny could not act anything if [you]108-edmund were to give [me]113-fanny [the world]315-the world . No , indeed , [I]113-fanny can not act . ”[113-fanny] “ Indeed , but [you]113-fanny must , for [we]4842-we can not excuse [you]113-fanny . It need not frighten [you]113-fanny : it is a nothing of a part , a mere nothing , not above half a dozen speeches altogether , and it will not much signify if [nobody]360-nobody hears a word [you]113-fanny say ; so [you]113-fanny may be as creep - mouse as [you]113-fanny like , but [we]4842-we must have [you]113-fanny to look at . ”[108-edmund] “ If [you]113-fanny are afraid of half a dozen speeches , ”[113-fanny] cried [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , “ what would [you]113-fanny do with such a part as [mine]113-fanny ? [I]113-fanny have forty - two to learn . ”[113-fanny] “ It is not that [I]113-fanny am afraid of learning by heart , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , shocked to find [herself]113-fanny at that moment [the only speaker in [the room]412-the room]1355-the only speaker in the room , and to feel that almost every eye was upon [her]1355-the only speaker in the room ; “ but [I]113-fanny really can not act . ”[113-fanny] “ Yes , yes , [you]113-fanny can act well enough for _ [us]4842-we _ . Learn [your]113-fanny part , and [we]4842-we will teach [you]113-fanny all the rest . [You]113-fanny have only two scenes , and as [I]108-edmund shall be [Cottager]198-cottager , [I]108-edmund ’ll put [you]113-fanny in and push [you]113-fanny about , and [you]113-fanny will do it very well , [I]108-edmund ’ll answer for it . ”[108-edmund] “ No , indeed , [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , [you]108-edmund must excuse [me]113-fanny . [You]108-edmund can not have an idea . It would be absolutely impossible for [me]113-fanny . If [I]113-fanny were to undertake it , [I]113-fanny should only disappoint [you]108-edmund . ”[113-fanny] “ [Phoo]204-phoo ! [Phoo]204-phoo ! Do not be so shamefaced . [You]113-fanny ’ll do it very well . Every allowance will be made for [you]113-fanny . [We]4846-we do not expect perfection . [You]113-fanny must get a brown gown , and a white apron , and a mob cap , and [we]4846-we must make [you]113-fanny a few wrinkles , and a little of the crowsfoot at the corner of [your]113-fanny eyes , and [you]113-fanny will be [a very proper , little old woman]4847-a very proper , little old woman . ”[108-edmund] “ [You]108-edmund must excuse [me]113-fanny , indeed [you]108-edmund must excuse [me]113-fanny , ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny , growing more and more red from excessive agitation , and looking distressfully at [Edmund]108-edmund , who was kindly observing [her]1357-her ; but unwilling to exasperate [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother by interference , gave [her]1357-her only an encouraging smile . [Her]1357-her entreaty had no effect on [Tom]101-sir thomas : [he]101-sir thomas only said again what [he]101-sir thomas had said before ; and it was not merely [Tom]101-sir thomas , for the requisition was now backed by [Maria]126-maria , and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , with an urgency which differed from [his]101-sir thomas but in being more gentle or more ceremonious , and which altogether was quite overpowering to [Fanny]113-fanny ; and before [she]1357-her could breathe after it , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris completed the whole by thus addressing [her]1357-her in a whisper at once angry and audible—“What a piece of work here is about nothing : [I]105-mrs. norris am quite ashamed of [you]113-fanny , [Fanny]113-fanny , to make such a difficulty of obliging [[your]113-fanny cousins]4848-your cousins in a trifle of this sort — so kind as [they]4848-your cousins are to [you]113-fanny ! Take the part with a good grace , and let [us]4849-us hear no more of the matter , [I]105-mrs. norris entreat . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Do not urge [her]1357-her , [madam]4024-madam , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund . “ It is not fair to urge [her]1357-her in this manner . [You]4024-madam see [she]1357-her does not like to act . Let [her]1357-her chuse for [herself]1357-her , as well as [the rest of [us]4849-us]4851-the rest of us . [Her]1357-her judgment may be quite as safely trusted . Do not urge [her]1357-her any more . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]105-mrs. norris am not going to urge [her]1357-her , ”[105-mrs. norris] replied [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris sharply ; “ but [I]105-mrs. norris shall think [her]1357-her [a very obstinate , ungrateful girl]4852-a very obstinate , ungrateful girl , if [she]1357-her does not do what [[her]1357-her aunt]463-her aunt and [cousins]355-cousins wish [her]1357-her — very ungrateful , indeed , considering who and what [she]1357-her is . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Edmund]108-edmund was too angry to speak ; but [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , looking for a moment with astonished eyes at [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , and then at [Fanny]113-fanny , whose tears were beginning to shew themselves , immediately said , with some keenness , “ [I]113-fanny do not like [my]113-fanny situation : [this _ place]4855-this _ place _ is too hot for [me]113-fanny , ”[113-fanny] and moved away [her]127-miss crawford chair to the opposite side of the table , close to [Fanny]113-fanny , saying to [her]127-miss crawford , in a kind , low whisper , as [she]127-miss crawford placed [herself]127-miss crawford , “ Never mind , [[my]127-miss crawford dear]3657-my dear [Miss Price]137-miss price , this is a cross evening : [everybody]408-everybody is cross and teasing , but do not let [us]4858-us mind [them]408-everybody ”[127-miss crawford] ; and with pointed attention continued to talk to [her]127-miss crawford and endeavour to raise [her]127-miss crawford spirits , in spite of being out of spirits [herself]127-miss crawford . By a look at [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother [she]127-miss crawford prevented any farther entreaty from the theatrical board , and the really good feelings by which [she]127-miss crawford was almost purely governed were rapidly restoring [her]127-miss crawford to all the little [she]127-miss crawford had lost in [Edmund]108-edmund ’s favour . [Fanny]113-fanny did not love [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; but [she]127-miss crawford felt very much obliged to [her]127-miss crawford for [her]127-miss crawford present kindness ; and when , from taking notice of [her]127-miss crawford work , and wishing _ [she]127-miss crawford _ could work as well , and begging for the pattern , and supposing [Fanny]113-fanny was now preparing for [her]127-miss crawford _ appearance _ , as of course [she]127-miss crawford would come out when [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin was married , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford proceeded to inquire if [she]127-miss crawford had heard lately from [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother at [sea]512-sea , and said that [she]127-miss crawford had quite a curiosity to see [him]451-her brother , and imagined [him]451-her brother [a very fine young man]1363-a very fine young man , and advised [Fanny]113-fanny to get [his]451-her brother picture drawn before [he]451-her brother went to [sea]512-sea again — [she]127-miss crawford could not help admitting it to be very agreeable flattery , or help listening , and answering with more animation than [she]127-miss crawford had intended . The consultation upon the play still went on , and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s attention was first called from [Fanny]113-fanny by [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas ’s telling [her]127-miss crawford , with infinite regret , that [he]101-sir thomas found it absolutely impossible for [him]101-sir thomas to undertake the part of [Anhalt]178-anhalt in addition to [the Butler]203-the butler : [he]101-sir thomas had been most anxiously trying to make it out to be feasible , but it would not do ; [he]101-sir thomas must give it up . “ But there will not be the smallest difficulty in filling it , ”[101-sir thomas] [he]101-sir thomas added . “ [We]4859-we have but to speak the word ; [we]4859-we may pick and chuse . [I]101-sir thomas could name , at this moment , at least [six young men within six miles of [us]4859-we , who are wild to be admitted into [our]4859-we company]4860-six young men within six miles of us , who are wild to be admitted into our company , and there are one or two that would not disgrace [us]4859-we : [I]101-sir thomas should not be afraid to trust either of [the Olivers]205-the olivers or [Charles Maddox]206-charles maddox . [Tom Oliver]207-tom is [a very clever fellow]4861-a very clever fellow , and [Charles Maddox]206-charles maddox is as [gentlemanlike a man]4862-gentlemanlike a man as [you]108-edmund will see anywhere , so [I]101-sir thomas will take [my]101-sir thomas horse early to - morrow morning and ride over to [Stoke]46-stoke , and settle with [one of [them]1366-them]4863-one of them . ”[101-sir thomas] While [he]1365-he spoke , [Maria]126-maria was looking apprehensively round at [Edmund]108-edmund in full expectation that [he]108-edmund must oppose such an enlargement of the plan as this : so contrary to all [their]1366-them first protestations ; but [Edmund]108-edmund said nothing . After a moment ’s thought , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford calmly replied , “ As far as [I]127-miss crawford am concerned , [I]127-miss crawford can have no objection to anything that [you]108-edmund all think eligible . Have [I]127-miss crawford ever seen [either of [the gentlemen]4865-the gentlemen]4864-either of the gentlemen ? Yes , [Mr. Charles Maddox]206-charles maddox dined at [[my]127-miss crawford sister]3790-my sister ’s one day , did not [he]206-charles maddox , [Henry]131-henry ? [A quiet - looking young man]4867-a quiet - looking young man . [I]127-miss crawford remember [him]206-charles maddox . Let _ [him]206-charles maddox _ be applied to , if [you]131-henry please , for it will be less unpleasant to [me]127-miss crawford than to have [a perfect stranger]4868-a perfect stranger . ”[127-miss crawford] [Charles Maddox]206-charles maddox was to be [the man]4818-the man . [Tom]207-tom repeated [his]207-tom resolution of going to [him]206-charles maddox early on the morrow ; and though [Julia]112-julia , who had scarcely opened [her]112-julia lips before , observed , in a sarcastic manner , and with a glance first at [Maria]126-maria and then at [Edmund]108-edmund , that “ [the Mansfield]130-mansfield theatricals would enliven [the whole neighbourhood]4869-the whole neighbourhood exceedingly , ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund still held [his]108-edmund peace , and shewed [his]108-edmund feelings only by a determined gravity . “ [I]127-miss crawford am not very sanguine as to [our]4870-our play , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , in an undervoice to [Fanny]113-fanny , after some consideration ; “ and [I]127-miss crawford can tell [Mr. Maddox]206-charles maddox that [I]127-miss crawford shall shorten some of _ [his]206-charles maddox _ speeches , and a great many of _ [my]127-miss crawford _ _ own _ , before [we]4870-our rehearse together . It will be very disagreeable , and by no means what [I]127-miss crawford expected . ”[127-miss crawford] [CHAPTER XVI]208-chapter xvi It was not in [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s power to talk [Fanny]113-fanny into any real forgetfulness of what had passed . When the evening was over , [she]127-miss crawford went to bed full of it , [her]127-miss crawford nerves still agitated by the shock of such an attack from [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin [Tom]207-tom , so public and so persevered in , and [her]127-miss crawford spirits sinking under [[her]127-miss crawford aunt]463-her aunt ’s unkind reflection and reproach . To be called into notice in such a manner , to hear that it was but the prelude to something so infinitely worse , to be told that [she]127-miss crawford must do what was so impossible as to act ; and then to have the charge of obstinacy and ingratitude follow it , enforced with such a hint at the dependence of [her]127-miss crawford situation , had been too distressing at the time to make the remembrance when [she]127-miss crawford was alone much less so , especially with the superadded dread of what the morrow might produce in continuation of the subject . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had protected [her]127-miss crawford only for the time ; and if [she]127-miss crawford were applied to again among [themselves]1370-themselves with all the authoritative urgency that [Tom]207-tom and [Maria]126-maria were capable of , and [Edmund]108-edmund perhaps away , what should [she]127-miss crawford do ? [She]127-miss crawford fell asleep before [she]127-miss crawford could answer the question , and found it quite as puzzling when [she]127-miss crawford awoke the next morning . [The little white attic , which had continued [her]127-miss crawford sleeping - room ever since [her]127-miss crawford first entering [the family]3724-the family]1371-the little white attic , which had continued her sleeping - room ever since her first entering the family , proving incompetent to suggest any reply , [she]127-miss crawford had recourse , as soon as [she]127-miss crawford was dressed , to [another apartment more spacious and more meet for walking about in and thinking , and of which [she]127-miss crawford had now for some time been almost equally [mistress]4316-mistress]1373-another apartment more spacious and more meet for walking about in and thinking , and of which she had now for some time been almost equally mistress . It had been [[their]1370-themselves school - room]1375-their school - room ; so called till [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams would not allow [it]1375-their school - room to be called so any longer , and inhabited as such to a later period . There [Miss Lee]110-miss lee had lived , and there [they]1370-themselves had read and written , and talked and laughed , till within the last three years , when [she]110-miss lee had quitted [them]1370-themselves . [The room]412-the room had then become useless , and for some time was quite deserted , except by [Fanny]113-fanny , when [she]127-miss crawford visited [[her]127-miss crawford plants]1377-her plants , or wanted one of the books , which [she]127-miss crawford was still glad to keep there , from the deficiency of space and accommodation in [[her]127-miss crawford little chamber above]1378-her little chamber above : but gradually , as [her]127-miss crawford value for the comforts of it increased , [she]127-miss crawford had added to [her]127-miss crawford possessions , and spent more of [her]127-miss crawford time [there]3696-there ; and having nothing to oppose [her]127-miss crawford , had so naturally and so artlessly worked [herself]127-miss crawford into it , that it was now generally admitted to be [hers]127-miss crawford . [The East room]1380-the east room , as [it]1380-the east room had been called ever since [Maria Bertram]126-maria was sixteen , was now considered [Fanny]113-fanny ’s , almost as decidedly as [the white attic]1381-the white attic : the smallness of [the one making the use of the other]1382-the one making the use of the other so evidently reasonable that [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams , with every superiority in [[their]1383-their own apartments]1384-their own apartments which [their]1383-their own sense of superiority could demand , were entirely approving it ; and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , having stipulated for there never being a fire in [it]3696-there on [Fanny]113-fanny ’s account , was tolerably resigned to [her]105-mrs. norris having the use of what [nobody else]4733-nobody else wanted , though the terms in which [she]105-mrs. norris sometimes spoke of the indulgence seemed to imply that it was [the best room in [the house]427-the house]1386-the best room in the house . The aspect was so favourable that even without a fire it was habitable in many an early spring and late autumn morning to such a willing mind as [Fanny]113-fanny ’s ; and while there was a gleam of sunshine [she]105-mrs. norris hoped not to be driven from it entirely , even when winter came . The comfort of it in [her]105-mrs. norris hours of leisure was extreme . [She]105-mrs. norris could go [there]3696-there after anything unpleasant below , and find immediate consolation in some pursuit , or some train of thought at hand . [Her]105-mrs. norris plants , [her]105-mrs. norris books — of which [she]105-mrs. norris had been a collector from the first hour of [her]105-mrs. norris commanding a shilling — [her]105-mrs. norris writing - desk , and [her]105-mrs. norris works of charity and ingenuity , were all within [her]105-mrs. norris reach ; or if indisposed for employment , if nothing but musing would do , [she]105-mrs. norris could scarcely see an object in [that room]1389-that room which had not an interesting remembrance connected with it . Everything was [a friend]456-a friend , or bore [her]105-mrs. norris thoughts to [a friend]456-a friend ; and though there had been sometimes much of suffering to [her]105-mrs. norris ; though [her]105-mrs. norris motives had often been misunderstood , [her]105-mrs. norris feelings disregarded , and [her]105-mrs. norris comprehension undervalued ; though [she]105-mrs. norris had known the pains of tyranny , of ridicule , and neglect , yet almost every recurrence of either had led to something consolatory : [[her]105-mrs. norris aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]126-maria had spoken for [her]105-mrs. norris , or [Miss Lee]110-miss lee had been encouraging , or , what was yet more frequent or more dear , [Edmund]108-edmund had been [[her]105-mrs. norris champion]1393-her champion and [[her]105-mrs. norris friend]1394-her friend : [he]108-edmund had supported [her]105-mrs. norris cause or explained [her]105-mrs. norris meaning , [he]108-edmund had told [her]105-mrs. norris not to cry , or had given [her]105-mrs. norris some proof of affection which made [her]105-mrs. norris tears delightful ; and the whole was now so blended together , so harmonised by distance , that every former affliction had its charm . [The room]412-the room was most dear to [her]105-mrs. norris , and [she]105-mrs. norris would not have changed [its]412-the room furniture for the handsomest in [the house]427-the house , though what had been originally plain had suffered all the ill - usage of [children]339-children ; and [its]412-the room greatest elegancies and ornaments were a faded footstool of [Julia]112-julia ’s work , too ill done for [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , three transparencies , made in a rage for transparencies , for the three lower panes of one window , where [Tintern Abbey]47-tintern abbey held [its]47-tintern abbey station between [a cave in [Italy]48-italy]1399-a cave in italy and [a moonlight lake in [Cumberland]49-cumberland]1400-a moonlight lake in cumberland , a collection of family profiles , thought unworthy of being anywhere else , over the mantelpiece , and by [their]1401-their side , and pinned against the wall , a small sketch of [a ship]1402-a ship sent four years ago from [the Mediterranean]1403-the mediterranean by [William]228-william , with H.M.S. Antwerp at the bottom , in letters as tall as the mainmast . To this nest of comforts [Fanny]113-fanny now walked down to try its influence on an agitated , doubting spirit , to see if by looking at [Edmund]108-edmund ’s profile [she]105-mrs. norris could catch any of [his]108-edmund counsel , or by giving air to [her]105-mrs. norris geraniums [she]105-mrs. norris might inhale a breeze of mental strength [herself]105-mrs. norris . But [she]105-mrs. norris had more than fears of [her]105-mrs. norris own perseverance to remove : [she]105-mrs. norris had begun to feel undecided as to what [she]105-mrs. norris _ ought _ _ to _ _ do _ ; and as [she]105-mrs. norris walked round [the room]412-the room [her]105-mrs. norris doubts were increasing . Was [she]105-mrs. norris _ right _ in refusing what was so warmly asked , so strongly wished for — what might be so essential to a scheme on which [some of those to whom [she]105-mrs. norris owed the greatest complaisance had set [their]1405-some of those to whom she owed the greatest complaisance had set their hearts hearts]1405-some of those to whom she owed the greatest complaisance had set their hearts ? Was it not ill - nature , selfishness , and a fear of exposing [herself]105-mrs. norris ? And would [Edmund]108-edmund ’s judgment , would [his]108-edmund persuasion of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s disapprobation of the whole , be enough to justify [her]105-mrs. norris in a determined denial in spite of all the rest ? It would be so horrible to [her]105-mrs. norris to act that [she]105-mrs. norris was inclined to suspect the truth and purity of [her]105-mrs. norris own scruples ; and as [she]105-mrs. norris looked around [her]105-mrs. norris , the claims of [[her]105-mrs. norris cousins]3671-her cousins to being obliged were strengthened by the sight of present upon present that [she]105-mrs. norris had received from [them]3671-her cousins . The table between the windows was covered with work - boxes and netting - boxes which had been given [her]105-mrs. norris at different times , principally by [Tom]101-sir thomas ; and [she]105-mrs. norris grew bewildered as to the amount of the debt which all these kind remembrances produced . A tap at the door roused [her]105-mrs. norris in the midst of this attempt to find [her]105-mrs. norris way to [her]105-mrs. norris duty , and [her]105-mrs. norris gentle “ Come in ”[105-mrs. norris] was answered by the appearance of one , before whom all [her]105-mrs. norris doubts were wo nt to be laid . [Her]105-mrs. norris eyes brightened at the sight of [Edmund]108-edmund . “ Can [I]108-edmund speak with [you]105-mrs. norris , [Fanny]113-fanny , for a few minutes ? ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund . “ Yes , certainly . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]105-mrs. norris want to consult . [I]105-mrs. norris want [your]108-edmund opinion . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [My]105-mrs. norris opinion ! ”[105-mrs. norris] [she]105-mrs. norris cried , shrinking from such a compliment , highly as it gratified [her]105-mrs. norris . “ Yes , [your]108-edmund advice and opinion . [I]105-mrs. norris do not know what to do . This acting scheme gets worse and worse , [you]108-edmund see . [They]4871-they have chosen almost as bad a play as [they]4871-they could , and now , to complete the business , are going to ask the help of [a young man very slightly known to any of [us]4873-us]4872-a young man very slightly known to any of us . This is the end of all the privacy and propriety which was talked about at first . [I]105-mrs. norris know no harm of [Charles Maddox]206-charles maddox ; but the excessive intimacy which must spring from [his]206-charles maddox being admitted among [us]4873-us in this manner is highly objectionable , the _ more _ than intimacy — the familiarity . [I]105-mrs. norris can not think of it with any patience ; and it does appear to [me]105-mrs. norris an evil of such magnitude as must , _ if _ _ possible _ , be prevented . Do not [you]108-edmund see it in the same light ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Yes ; but what can be done ? [[Your]113-fanny brother]3938-your brother is so determined . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ There is but _ one _ thing to be done , [Fanny]113-fanny . [I]1407-i must take [Anhalt]178-anhalt [myself]1407-i . [I]1407-i am well aware that nothing else will quiet [Tom]101-sir thomas . ”[1407-i] [Fanny]113-fanny could not answer [him]1407-i . “ It is not at all what [I]1407-i like , ”[1407-i] [he]1407-i continued . “ [No man]4875-no man can like being driven into the _ appearance _ of such inconsistency . After being known to oppose the scheme from the beginning , there is absurdity in the face of [my]1407-i joining [them]4876-them _ now _ , when [they]4876-them are exceeding [their]4876-them first plan in every respect ; but [I]1407-i can think of no other alternative . Can [you]113-fanny , [Fanny]113-fanny ? ”[1407-i] “ No , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny slowly , “ not immediately , but — ”[113-fanny] “ But what ? [I]105-mrs. norris see [your]1407-i judgment is not with [me]105-mrs. norris . Think it a little over . Perhaps [you]1407-i are not so much aware as [I]105-mrs. norris am of the mischief that _ may _ , of the unpleasantness that _ must _ arise from [a young man]743-a young man ’s being received in this manner : domesticated among [us]4878-us ; authorised to come at all hours , and placed suddenly on a footing which must do away all restraints . To think only of the licence which every rehearsal must tend to create . It is all very bad ! Put [yourself]1407-i in [[Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s place]4879-miss crawford ’s place , [Fanny]113-fanny . Consider what it would be to act [Amelia]197-amelia with [a stranger]4880-a stranger . [She]197-amelia has a right to be felt for , because [she]197-amelia evidently feels for [herself]197-amelia . [I]105-mrs. norris heard enough of what [she]197-amelia said to [you]1407-i last night to understand [her]197-amelia unwillingness to be acting with [a stranger]4880-a stranger ; and as [she]197-amelia probably engaged in the part with different expectations — perhaps without considering the subject enough to know what was likely to be — it would be ungenerous , it would be really wrong to expose [her]197-amelia to it . [Her]197-amelia feelings ought to be respected . Does it not strike [you]1407-i so , [Fanny]113-fanny ? [You]1407-i hesitate . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]1407-i am sorry for [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; but [I]1407-i am more sorry to see [you]127-miss crawford drawn in to do what [you]127-miss crawford had resolved against , and what [you]127-miss crawford are known to think will be disagreeable to [[my]1407-i uncle]3761-my uncle . It will be such a triumph to [the others]347-the others ! ”[1407-i] “ [They]347-the others will not have much cause of triumph when [they]347-the others see how infamously [I]113-fanny act . But , however , triumph there certainly will be , and [I]113-fanny must brave it . But if [I]113-fanny can be the means of restraining the publicity of the business , of limiting the exhibition , of concentrating [our]4884-our folly , [I]113-fanny shall be well repaid . As [I]113-fanny am now , [I]113-fanny have no influence , [I]113-fanny can do nothing : [I]113-fanny have offended [them]347-the others , and [they]347-the others will not hear [me]113-fanny ; but when [I]113-fanny have put [them]347-the others in good - humour by this concession , [I]113-fanny am not without hopes of persuading [them]347-the others to confine the representation within a much smaller circle than [they]347-the others are now in the high road for . This will be a material gain . [My]113-fanny object is to confine it to [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria and [the Grants]122-the grants . Will not this be worth gaining ? ”[113-fanny] “ Yes , it will be a great point . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ But still it has not [your]113-fanny approbation . Can [you]113-fanny mention any other measure by which [I]1407-i have a chance of doing equal good ? ”[1407-i] “ No , [I]113-fanny can not think of anything else . ”[113-fanny] “ Give [me]105-mrs. norris [your]113-fanny approbation , then , [Fanny]113-fanny . [I]105-mrs. norris am not comfortable without it . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Oh , [cousin]3759-cousin ! ”[105-mrs. norris] “ If [you]113-fanny are against [me]113-fanny , [I]113-fanny ought to distrust [myself]113-fanny , and yet — But it is absolutely impossible to let [Tom]101-sir thomas go on in this way , riding about [the country]493-the country in quest of [anybody who can be persuaded to act — no matter whom : the look of a gentleman]4887-anybody who can be persuaded to act — no matter whom : the look of a gentleman is to be enough . [I]113-fanny thought _ [you]113-fanny _ would have entered more into [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s feelings . ”[113-fanny] “ No doubt [she]127-miss crawford will be very glad . It must be a great relief to [her]127-miss crawford , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , trying for greater warmth of manner . “ [She]127-miss crawford never appeared more amiable than in [her]127-miss crawford behaviour to [you]113-fanny last night . It gave [her]127-miss crawford a very strong claim on [my]113-fanny goodwill . ”[113-fanny] “ [She]127-miss crawford _ was _ very kind , indeed , and [I]1408-her am glad to have [her]127-miss crawford spared ”[1408-her] ... [She]1408-her could not finish the generous effusion . [Her]1408-her conscience stopt [her]1408-her in the middle , but [Edmund]108-edmund was satisfied . “ [I]108-edmund shall walk down immediately after breakfast , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund , “ and am sure of giving pleasure there . And now , [dear Fanny]113-fanny , [I]108-edmund will not interrupt [you]113-fanny any longer . [You]113-fanny want to be reading . But [I]108-edmund could not be easy till [I]108-edmund had spoken to [you]113-fanny , and come to a decision . Sleeping or waking , [my]108-edmund head has been full of this matter all night . It is an evil , but [I]108-edmund am certainly making it less than it might be . If [Tom]101-sir thomas is up , [I]108-edmund shall go to [him]101-sir thomas directly and get it over , and when [we]4888-we meet at breakfast [we]4888-we shall be all in high good - humour at the prospect of acting [the fool]4889-the fool together with such unanimity . _ [You]113-fanny _ , in the meanwhile , will be taking a trip into [China]50-china , [I]108-edmund suppose . How does [Lord Macartney]209-lord macartney go on?”—opening[108-edmund] a volume on the table and then taking up some others . “ And here are [Crabbe]210-crabbe ’s Tales , and [the Idler]4890-the idler , at hand to relieve [you]113-fanny , if [you]113-fanny tire of [your]113-fanny great book . [I]1409-he admire [[your]113-fanny little establishment]4891-your little establishment exceedingly ; and as soon as [I]1409-he am gone , [you]113-fanny will empty [your]113-fanny head of all this nonsense of acting , and sit comfortably down to [your]113-fanny table . But do not stay here to be cold . ”[1409-he] [He]1409-he went ; but there was no reading , no China , no composure for [Fanny]113-fanny . [He]1409-he had told [her]1410-her the most extraordinary , the most inconceivable , the most unwelcome news ; and [she]1410-her could think of nothing else . To be acting ! After all [his]1409-he objections — objections so just and so public ! After all that [she]1410-her had heard [him]1409-he say , and seen [him]1409-he look , and known [him]1409-he to be feeling . Could it be possible ? [Edmund]108-edmund so inconsistent ! Was [he]1409-he not deceiving [himself]1409-he ? Was [he]1409-he not wrong ? Alas ! it was all [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s doing . [She]1410-her had seen [her]1410-her influence in every speech , and was miserable . The doubts and alarms as to [her]1410-her own conduct , which had previously distressed [her]1410-her , and which had all slept while [she]1410-her listened to [him]1409-he , were become of little consequence now . This deeper anxiety swallowed [them]1411-them up . Things should take their course ; [she]1410-her cared not how it ended . [[Her]1410-her cousins]3671-her cousins might attack , but could hardly tease [her]1410-her . [She]1410-her was beyond [their]3671-her cousins reach ; and if at last obliged to yield — no matter — it was all misery now . CHAPTER XVII It was , indeed , a triumphant day to [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund and [Maria]126-maria . Such a victory over [Edmund]108-edmund ’s discretion had been beyond [their]3671-her cousins hopes , and was most delightful . There was no longer anything to disturb [them]3671-her cousins in [their]3671-her cousins darling project , and [they]3671-her cousins congratulated [each other]681-each other in private on the jealous weakness to which [they]3671-her cousins attributed the change , with all the glee of feelings gratified in every way . [Edmund]108-edmund might still look grave , and say [he]108-edmund did not like the scheme in general , and must disapprove the play in particular ; [their]3671-her cousins point was gained : [he]108-edmund was to act , and [he]108-edmund was driven to it by the force of selfish inclinations only . [Edmund]108-edmund had descended from that moral elevation which [he]108-edmund had maintained before , and [they]3671-her cousins were both as much the better as the happier for the descent . [They]3671-her cousins behaved very well , however , to _ [him]108-edmund _ on the occasion , betraying no exultation beyond the lines about the corners of the mouth , and seemed to think it as great an escape to be quit of the intrusion of [Charles Maddox]206-charles maddox , as if [they]3671-her cousins had been forced into admitting [him]108-edmund against [their]3671-her cousins inclination . “ To have it quite in [[their]3671-her cousins own family circle]4892-their own family circle was what [they]3671-her cousins had particularly wished . [A stranger among [them]3671-her cousins]4893-a stranger among them would have been the destruction of all [their]3671-her cousins comfort ”[105-mrs. norris] ; and when [Edmund]108-edmund , pursuing that idea , gave a hint of [his]108-edmund hope as to the limitation of [the audience]1414-the audience , [they]3671-her cousins were ready , in the complaisance of the moment , to promise anything . It was all good - humour and encouragement . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris offered to contrive [his]108-edmund dress , [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates assured [him]108-edmund that [Anhalt]178-anhalt ’s last scene with [the Baron]4626-the baron admitted a good deal of action and emphasis , and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny undertook to count [his]108-edmund speeches . “ Perhaps , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Tom]101-sir thomas , “ [Fanny]113-fanny may be more disposed to oblige [us]3671-her cousins now . Perhaps [you]113-fanny may persuade _ [her]127-miss crawford _ . ”[101-sir thomas] “ No , [she]127-miss crawford is quite determined . [She]127-miss crawford certainly will not act . ”[108-edmund] “ Oh ! very well . ”[101-sir thomas] And not another word was said ; but [Fanny]113-fanny felt [herself]113-fanny again in danger , and [her]1416-she indifference to the danger was beginning to fail [her]1416-she already . There were not fewer smiles at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage than at [the Park]3753-the park on this change in [Edmund]108-edmund ; [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford looked very lovely in [hers]127-miss crawford , and entered with such an instantaneous renewal of cheerfulness into the whole affair as could have but one effect on [him]108-edmund . “ [He]108-edmund was certainly right in respecting such feelings ; [he]108-edmund was glad [he]108-edmund had determined on it . ”[127-miss crawford] And the morning wore away in satisfactions very sweet , if not very sound . One advantage resulted from it to [Fanny]113-fanny : at the earnest request of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant had , with [her]123-mrs. grant usual good - humour , agreed to undertake the part for which [Fanny]113-fanny had been wanted ; and this was all that occurred to gladden _ [her]1416-she _ heart during the day ; and even this , when imparted by [Edmund]108-edmund , brought a pang with it , for it was [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford to whom [she]1416-she was obliged — it was [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford whose kind exertions were to excite [her]1416-she gratitude , and whose merit in making [them]1419-them was spoken of with a glow of admiration . [She]1416-she was safe ; but peace and safety were unconnected here . [Her]1416-she mind had been never farther from peace . [She]1416-she could not feel that [she]1416-she had done wrong [herself]1416-she , but [she]1416-she was disquieted in every other way . [Her]1416-she heart and [her]1416-she judgment were equally against [Edmund]108-edmund ’s decision : [she]1416-she could not acquit [his]108-edmund unsteadiness , and [his]108-edmund happiness under it made [her]1416-she wretched . [She]1416-she was full of jealousy and agitation . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford came with looks of gaiety which seemed an insult , with friendly expressions towards [herself]127-miss crawford which [she]127-miss crawford could hardly answer calmly . Everybody around [her]127-miss crawford was gay and busy , prosperous and important ; [each]1248-each had [their]1248-each object of interest , [their]1248-each part , [their]1248-each dress , [their]1248-each favourite scene , [[their]1248-each friends]4511-their friends and [confederates]1422-confederates : [all]874-all were finding employment in consultations and comparisons , or diversion in the playful conceits [they]874-all suggested . [She]1416-she alone was sad and insignificant : [she]1416-she had no share in anything ; [she]1416-she might go or stay ; [she]1416-she might be in the midst of [their]874-all noise , or retreat from it to the solitude of [the East room]1380-the east room , without being seen or missed . [She]1416-she could almost think anything would have been preferable to this . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant was of consequence : _ [her]123-mrs. grant _ good - nature had honourable mention ; [her]123-mrs. grant taste and [her]123-mrs. grant time were considered ; [her]123-mrs. grant presence was wanted ; [she]123-mrs. grant was sought for , and attended , and praised ; and [Fanny]113-fanny was at first in some danger of envying [her]123-mrs. grant the character [she]1416-she had accepted . But reflection brought better feelings , and [shewed]1425-shewed [her]1416-she that [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant was entitled to respect , which could never have belonged to _ [her]123-mrs. grant _ ; and that , had [she]123-mrs. grant received even the greatest , [she]123-mrs. grant could never have been easy in joining a scheme which , considering only [[her]123-mrs. grant uncle]312-her uncle , [she]123-mrs. grant must condemn altogether . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s heart was not absolutely the only saddened one amongst [them]1427-them , as [she]123-mrs. grant soon began to acknowledge to [herself]123-mrs. grant . [Julia]112-julia was [a sufferer]1428-a sufferer too , though not quite so blamelessly . [Henry Crawford]131-henry had trifled with [her]123-mrs. grant feelings ; but [she]123-mrs. grant had very long allowed and even sought [his]131-henry attentions , with a jealousy of [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister so reasonable as ought to have been [their]1430-their cure ; and now that the conviction of [his]131-henry preference for [Maria]126-maria had been forced on [her]123-mrs. grant , [she]123-mrs. grant submitted to it without any alarm for [Maria]126-maria ’s situation , or any endeavour at rational tranquillity for [herself]123-mrs. grant . [She]123-mrs. grant either sat in gloomy silence , wrapt in such gravity as nothing could subdue , no curiosity touch , no wit amuse ; or allowing the attentions of [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , was talking with forced gaiety to [him]174-mr. yates alone , and ridiculing the acting of [the others]347-the others . For a day or two after the affront was given , [Henry Crawford]131-henry had endeavoured to do it away by the usual attack of gallantry and compliment , but [he]131-henry had not cared enough about it to persevere against a few repulses ; and becoming soon too busy with [his]131-henry play to have time for more than one flirtation , [he]131-henry grew indifferent to the quarrel , or rather thought it a lucky occurrence , as quietly putting an end to what might ere long have raised expectations in more than [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant . [She]123-mrs. grant was not pleased to see [Julia]112-julia excluded from the play , and sitting by disregarded ; but as it was not a matter which really involved [her]123-mrs. grant happiness , as [Henry]131-henry must be [the best judge of [his]131-henry own]1432-the best judge of his own , and as [he]131-henry did assure [her]123-mrs. grant , with a most persuasive smile , that neither [he]131-henry nor [Julia]112-julia had ever had a serious thought of [each other]681-each other , [she]123-mrs. grant could only renew [her]123-mrs. grant former caution as to [the elder sister]1434-the elder sister , entreat [him]131-henry not to risk [his]131-henry tranquillity by too much admiration there , and then gladly take [her]123-mrs. grant share in anything that brought cheerfulness to [the young people in general]1435-the young people in general , and that did so particularly promote the pleasure of [the two so dear to [her]123-mrs. grant]1436-the two so dear to her . “ [I]123-mrs. grant rather wonder [Julia]112-julia is not in love with [Henry]131-henry , ”[123-mrs. grant] was [her]123-mrs. grant observation to [Mary]132-mary . “ [I]132-mary dare say [she]112-julia is , ”[132-mary] replied [Mary]132-mary coldly . “ [I]132-mary imagine [both sisters]4894-both sisters are . ”[132-mary] “ Both ! no , no , that must not be . Do not give [him]131-henry a hint of it . Think of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ! ”[123-mrs. grant] “ [You]132-mary had better tell [Miss Bertram]112-julia to think of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . It may do _ [her]112-julia _ some good . [I]123-mrs. grant often think of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s property and independence , and wish them in other hands ; but [I]123-mrs. grant never think of [him]113-fanny . [A man]4410-a man might represent [the county]4896-the county with such an estate ; [a man]4410-a man might escape a profession and represent [the county]4896-the county . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ [I]132-mary dare say [he]113-fanny _ will _ be in parliament soon . When [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas comes , [I]132-mary dare say [he]113-fanny will be in for [some borough]4899-some borough , but there has been [nobody]360-nobody to put [him]113-fanny in the way of doing anything yet . ”[132-mary] “ [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas is to achieve many mighty things when [he]113-fanny comes [home]367-home , ”[132-mary] said [Mary]132-mary , after a pause . “ Do [you]4902-you remember [Hawkins Browne]211-hawkins browne ’s ‘ Address to Tobacco , ’ in imitation of [Pope]212-pope ? — Blest leaf ! whose aromatic gales dispense To Templars modesty , to [Parsons]51-parsons sense . [I]132-mary will parody [them]4903-them — [Blest Knight]213-blest knight ! whose dictatorial looks dispense To [Children]214-children affluence , to [Rushworth]126-maria sense . Will not that do , [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ? Everything seems to depend upon [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s return . ”[132-mary] “ [You]4902-you will find [his]101-sir thomas consequence very just and reasonable when [you]4902-you see [him]101-sir thomas in [[his]101-sir thomas family]582-his family , [I]132-mary assure [you]4902-you . [I]132-mary do not think [we]4905-we do so well without [him]101-sir thomas . [He]101-sir thomas has a fine dignified manner , which suits [the head of [such a house]4907-such a house]4906-the head of such a house , and keeps [everybody]408-everybody in [their]408-everybody place . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram seems more of a cipher now than when [he]101-sir thomas is at [home]367-home ; and [nobody else]4733-nobody else can keep [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris in order . But , [Mary]132-mary , do not fancy that [Maria Bertram]126-maria cares for [Henry]131-henry . [I]132-mary am sure _ [Julia]112-julia _ does not , or [she]126-maria would not have flirted as [she]126-maria did last night with [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ; and though [he]101-sir thomas and [Maria]126-maria are [very good friends]4911-very good friends , [I]132-mary think [she]126-maria likes [Sotherton]27-sotherton too well to be inconstant . ”[132-mary] “ [I]132-mary would not give much for [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s chance if [Henry]131-henry stept in before the articles were signed . ”[132-mary] “ If [you]132-mary have such a suspicion , something must be done ; and as soon as the play is all over , [we]4912-we will talk to [him]131-henry seriously and make [him]131-henry know [his]131-henry own mind ; and if [he]131-henry means nothing , [we]4912-we will send [him]131-henry off , though [he]131-henry is [Henry]131-henry , for a time . ”[132-mary] [Julia]112-julia _ did _ suffer , however , though [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant discerned it not , and though it escaped the notice of [many of [[her]123-mrs. grant own family]1438-her own family]1437-many of her own family likewise . [She]123-mrs. grant had loved , [she]123-mrs. grant did love still , and [she]123-mrs. grant had all the suffering which a warm temper and a high spirit were likely to endure under the disappointment of a dear , though irrational hope , with a strong sense of ill - usage . [Her]123-mrs. grant heart was sore and angry , and [she]123-mrs. grant was capable only of angry consolations . [The sister with whom [she]123-mrs. grant was used to be on easy terms]1439-the sister with whom she was used to be on easy terms was now become [[her]123-mrs. grant greatest enemy]1440-her greatest enemy : [they]1441-their were alienated from [each other]681-each other ; and [Julia]112-julia was not superior to the hope of some distressing end to the attentions which were still carrying on there , some punishment to [Maria]126-maria for conduct so shameful towards [herself]126-maria as well as towards [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . With no material fault of temper , or difference of opinion , to prevent [their]1441-their being very [good friends]817-good friends while [their]1441-their interests were the same , [the sisters]327-the sisters , under such a trial as this , had not affection or principle enough to make [them]1441-their merciful or just , to give [them]1441-their honour or compassion . [Maria]126-maria felt [her]126-maria triumph , and pursued [her]126-maria purpose , careless of [Julia]112-julia ; and [Julia]112-julia could never see [Maria]126-maria distinguished by [Henry Crawford]131-henry without trusting that it would create jealousy , and bring a public disturbance at last . [Fanny]113-fanny saw and pitied much of this in [Julia]112-julia ; but there was no outward fellowship between [them]1441-their . [Julia]112-julia made no communication , and [Fanny]113-fanny took no liberties . [They]1441-their were [two solitary sufferers]1445-two solitary sufferers , or connected only by [Fanny]113-fanny ’s consciousness . The inattention of [the two brothers]1446-the two brothers and [the aunt]4162-the aunt to [Julia]112-julia ’s discomposure , and [their]1441-their blindness to its true cause , must be imputed to the fullness of [their]1441-their own minds . [They]1441-their were totally preoccupied . [Tom]101-sir thomas was engrossed by the concerns of [[his]101-sir thomas theatre]1448-his theatre , and saw nothing that did not immediately relate to it . [Edmund]108-edmund , between [his]108-edmund theatrical and [his]108-edmund real part , between [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s claims and [his]108-edmund own conduct , between love and consistency , was equally unobservant ; and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was too busy in contriving and directing the general little matters of [the company]4721-the company , superintending [their]4721-the company various dresses with economical expedient , for which [nobody]360-nobody thanked [her]105-mrs. norris , and saving , with delighted integrity , half a crown here and there to the absent [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , to have leisure for watching the behaviour , or guarding the happiness of [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters . CHAPTER XVIII Everything was now in a regular train : theatre , [actors]1452-actors , [actresses]1453-actresses , and dresses , were all getting forward ; but though no other great impediments arose , [Fanny]113-fanny found , before many days were past , that it was not all uninterrupted enjoyment to the party [themselves]4721-the company , and that [she]1454-she had not to witness the continuance of such unanimity and delight as had been almost too much for [her]1454-she at first . [Everybody]408-everybody began to have [their]408-everybody vexation . [Edmund]108-edmund had many . Entirely against _ [his]108-edmund _ judgment , [a scene - painter]1456-a scene - painter arrived from [town]3698-town , and was at work , much to the increase of the expenses , and , what was worse , of the eclat of [their]4721-the company proceedings ; and [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother , instead of being really guided by [him]108-edmund as to the privacy of the representation , was giving an invitation to [every family who came in [his]108-edmund way]1459-every family who came in his way . [Tom]101-sir thomas [himself]101-sir thomas began to fret over [the scene - painter]1460-the scene - painter ’s slow progress , and to feel the miseries of waiting . [He]108-edmund had learned [his]108-edmund part — all [his]108-edmund parts , for [he]108-edmund took every trifling one that could be united with [the Butler]1461-the butler , and began to be impatient to be acting ; and every day thus unemployed was tending to increase [his]108-edmund sense of the insignificance of all [his]108-edmund parts together , and make [him]108-edmund more ready to regret that some other play had not been chosen . [Fanny]113-fanny , being always [a very courteous listener]1462-a very courteous listener , and often [the only listener at hand]1463-the only listener at hand , came in for the complaints and the distresses of most of [them]4721-the company . _ [She]1464-she _ knew that [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates was in general thought to rant dreadfully ; that [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates was disappointed in [Henry Crawford]131-henry ; that [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas spoke so quick [he]101-sir thomas would be unintelligible ; that [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant spoiled everything by laughing ; that [Edmund]108-edmund was behindhand with [his]108-edmund part , and that it was misery to have anything to do with [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , who was wanting [a prompter through every speech]1465-a prompter through every speech . [She]1464-she knew , also , that poor [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny could seldom get [anybody]3668-anybody to rehearse with [him]113-fanny : _ [his]113-fanny _ complaint came before [her]1464-she as well as the rest ; and so decided to [her]1464-she eye was [[her]1464-she cousin]3692-her cousin [Maria]126-maria ’s avoidance of [him]113-fanny , and so needlessly often the rehearsal of the first scene between [her]126-maria and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , that [she]1464-she had soon all the terror of other complaints from _ [him]113-fanny _ . So far from being all satisfied and all enjoying , [she]1464-she found [everybody]408-everybody requiring something [they]408-everybody had not , and giving occasion of discontent to [the others]347-the others . [Everybody]408-everybody had a part either too long or too short ; [nobody]360-nobody would attend as [they]408-everybody ought ; [nobody]360-nobody would remember on which side [they]408-everybody were to come in ; [[nobody]360-nobody but [the complainer]1475-the complainer]1474-nobody but the complainer would observe any directions . [Fanny]113-fanny believed [herself]113-fanny to derive as much innocent enjoyment from the play as any of [them]1476-them ; [Henry Crawford]131-henry acted well , and it was a pleasure to _ [her]1464-she _ to creep into [the theatre]1230-the theatre , and attend the rehearsal of the first act , in spite of the feelings it excited in some speeches for [Maria]126-maria . [Maria]126-maria , [she]1464-she also thought , acted well , too well ; and after the first rehearsal or two , [Fanny]113-fanny began to be [[their]1476-them only audience]1478-their only audience ; and sometimes as [prompter]1479-prompter , sometimes as [spectator]1480-spectator , was often very useful . As far as [she]1464-she could judge , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was considerably [the best actor of all]1481-the best actor of all : [he]133-mr. crawford had more confidence than [Edmund]108-edmund , more judgment than [Tom]101-sir thomas , more talent and taste than [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates . [She]1464-she did not like [him]133-mr. crawford as [a man]4410-a man , but [she]1464-she must admit [him]133-mr. crawford to be [the best actor]1483-the best actor , and on this point there were not many who differed from [her]1464-she . [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , indeed , exclaimed against [his]133-mr. crawford tameness and insipidity ; and the day came at last , when [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny turned to [her]1464-she with a black look , and said , “ Do [you]1464-she think there is anything so very fine in all this ? For the life and soul of [me]113-fanny , [I]113-fanny can not admire [him]133-mr. crawford ; and , between [ourselves]4913-ourselves , to see [such an undersized , little , mean - looking man]4914-such an undersized , little , mean - looking man , set up for [a fine actor]4915-a fine actor , is very ridiculous in [my]113-fanny opinion . ”[113-fanny] From this moment there was a return of [his]133-mr. crawford former jealousy , which [Maria]126-maria , from increasing hopes of [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , was at little pains to remove ; and the chances of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s ever attaining to the knowledge of [his]133-mr. crawford two - and - forty speeches became much less . As to [his]133-mr. crawford ever making anything _ tolerable _ of [them]1484-them , [nobody]360-nobody had the smallest idea of that except [[his]133-mr. crawford mother]629-his mother ; _ [she]629-his mother _ , indeed , regretted that [his]133-mr. crawford part was not more considerable , and deferred coming over to [Mansfield]130-mansfield till [they]1487-they were forward enough in [their]1487-they rehearsal to comprehend all [his]133-mr. crawford scenes ; but [the others]347-the others aspired at nothing beyond [his]133-mr. crawford remembering the catchword , and the first line of [his]133-mr. crawford speech , and being able to follow [the prompter]1489-the prompter through the rest . [Fanny]113-fanny , in [her]629-his mother pity and kindheartedness , was at great pains to teach [him]133-mr. crawford how to learn , giving [him]133-mr. crawford all the helps and directions in [her]629-his mother power , trying to make an artificial memory for [him]133-mr. crawford , and learning every word of [his]133-mr. crawford part [herself]629-his mother , but without [his]133-mr. crawford being much [the forwarder]1490-the forwarder . Many uncomfortable , anxious , apprehensive feelings [she]629-his mother certainly had ; but with all these , and other claims on [her]629-his mother time and attention , [she]629-his mother was as far from finding [herself]629-his mother without employment or utility amongst them , as without [a companion]1122-a companion in uneasiness ; quite as far from having no demand on [her]629-his mother leisure as on [her]629-his mother compassion . The gloom of [her]629-his mother first anticipations was proved to have been unfounded . [She]629-his mother was occasionally useful to [all]874-all ; [she]629-his mother was perhaps as much at peace as any . There was a great deal of needlework to be done , moreover , in which [her]629-his mother help was wanted ; and that [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris thought [her]629-his mother quite as well off as [the rest]441-the rest , was evident by the manner in which [she]105-mrs. norris claimed it—“Come , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[105-mrs. norris] [she]105-mrs. norris cried , “ these are fine times for [you]113-fanny , but [you]113-fanny must not be always walking from [one room]4420-one room to the other , and doing the lookings - on at [your]113-fanny ease , in this way ; [I]105-mrs. norris want [you]113-fanny [here]3798-here . [I]105-mrs. norris have been slaving [myself]105-mrs. norris till [I]105-mrs. norris can hardly stand , to contrive [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s cloak without sending for any more satin ; and now [I]105-mrs. norris think [you]113-fanny may give [me]105-mrs. norris [your]113-fanny help in putting it together . There are but three seams ; [you]113-fanny may do them in a trice . It would be lucky for [me]105-mrs. norris if [I]105-mrs. norris had nothing but the executive part to do . _ [You]113-fanny _ are best off , [I]105-mrs. norris can tell [you]113-fanny : but if [nobody]360-nobody did more than _ [you]113-fanny _ , [we]4919-we should not get on very fast . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Fanny]113-fanny took the work very quietly , without attempting any defence ; but [her]1494-her kinder aunt [Bertram]126-maria observed on [her]1494-her behalf — “ [One]766-one can not wonder , [sister]3704-sister , that [Fanny]113-fanny _ should _ be delighted : it is all new to [her]1494-her , [you]3704-sister know ; [you]3704-sister and [I]126-maria used to be very fond of a play [ourselves]4919-we , and so am [I]126-maria still ; and as soon as [I]126-maria am a little more at leisure , _ [I]126-maria _ mean to look in at [their]4922-their rehearsals too . What is the play about , [Fanny]113-fanny ? [you]3704-sister have never told [me]126-maria . ”[126-maria] “ Oh ! [sister]3704-sister , pray do not ask [her]1494-her now ; for [Fanny]113-fanny is not one of [those who can talk and work at the same time]4924-those who can talk and work at the same time . It is about [Lovers]4611-lovers ’ Vows . ”[126-maria] “ [I]113-fanny believe , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny to [[her]1495-her aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]126-maria , “ there will be three acts rehearsed to - morrow evening , and that will give [you]3704-sister an opportunity of seeing [all the actors]4926-all the actors at once . ”[113-fanny] “ [You]3704-sister had better stay till the curtain is hung , ”[105-mrs. norris] interposed [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ; “ the curtain will be hung in a day or two — there is very little sense in a play without a curtain — and [I]105-mrs. norris am much mistaken if [you]3704-sister do not find it draw up into very handsome festoons . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram seemed quite resigned to waiting . [Fanny]113-fanny did not share [[her]1495-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s composure : [she]1495-her thought of the morrow a great deal , for if the three acts were rehearsed , [Edmund]108-edmund and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford would then be acting together for the first time ; the third act would bring a scene between [them]1498-they which interested [her]1495-her most particularly , and which [she]1495-her was longing and dreading to see how [they]1498-they would perform . The whole subject of it was love — a marriage of love was to be described by [the gentleman]671-the gentleman , and very little short of a declaration of love be made by [the lady]718-the lady . [She]1495-her had read and read the scene again with many painful , many wondering emotions , and looked forward to [their]1498-they representation of it as a circumstance almost too interesting . [She]1495-her did not _ believe _ [they]1498-they had yet rehearsed it , even in private . The morrow came , the plan for the evening continued , and [Fanny]113-fanny ’s consideration of it did not become less agitated . [She]1495-her worked very diligently under [[her]1495-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s directions , but [her]1495-her diligence and [her]1495-her silence concealed a very absent , anxious mind ; and about noon [she]1495-her made [her]1495-her escape with [her]1495-her work to [the East room]1380-the east room , that [she]1495-her might have no concern in another , and , as [she]1495-her deemed it , most unnecessary rehearsal of the first act , which [Henry Crawford]131-henry was just proposing , desirous at once of having [her]1495-her time to [herself]1495-her , and of avoiding the sight of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . A glimpse , as [she]1495-her passed through [the hall]871-the hall , of [the two ladies]1504-the two ladies walking up from [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage made no change in [her]1495-her wish of retreat , and [she]1495-her worked and meditated in [the East room]1380-the east room , undisturbed , for a quarter of an hour , when a gentle tap at the door was followed by the entrance of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . “ Am [I]127-miss crawford right ? Yes ; this is [the East room]1380-the east room . [[My]127-miss crawford dear]3657-my dear [Miss Price]137-miss price , [I]127-miss crawford beg [your]137-miss price pardon , but [I]127-miss crawford have made [my]127-miss crawford way to [you]137-miss price on purpose to entreat [your]137-miss price help . ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny , quite surprised , endeavoured to shew [herself]1495-her mistress of [the room]412-the room by [her]1495-her civilities , and looked at the bright bars of [her]1495-her empty grate with concern . “ Thank [you]137-miss price ; [I]113-fanny am quite warm , very warm . Allow [me]113-fanny to stay [here]3798-here a little while , and do have the goodness to hear [me]113-fanny [my]113-fanny third act . [I]113-fanny have brought [my]113-fanny book , and if [you]137-miss price would but rehearse it with [me]113-fanny , [I]113-fanny should be _ so _ obliged ! [I]113-fanny came here to - day intending to rehearse it with [Edmund]108-edmund — by [ourselves]4930-ourselves — against the evening , but [he]108-edmund is not in the way ; and if [he]108-edmund _ were _ , [I]113-fanny do not think [I]113-fanny could go through it with _ [him]108-edmund _ , till [I]113-fanny have hardened [myself]113-fanny a little ; for really there is a speech or two . [You]137-miss price will be so good , wo n’t [you]137-miss price ? ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny was most civil in [her]1508-i assurances , though [she]1508-i could not give them in a very steady voice . “ Have [you]137-miss price ever happened to look at the part [I]127-miss crawford mean ? ”[127-miss crawford] continued [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , opening [her]127-miss crawford book . “ Here it is . [I]127-miss crawford did not think much of it at first — but , upon [my]127-miss crawford word . There , look at _ that _ speech , and _ that _ , and _ that _ . How am [I]127-miss crawford ever to look [him]108-edmund in the face and say such things ? Could [you]137-miss price do it ? But then [he]108-edmund is [[your]137-miss price cousin]3780-your cousin , which makes all the difference . [You]137-miss price must rehearse it with [me]127-miss crawford , that [I]127-miss crawford may fancy _ [you]137-miss price _ [him]108-edmund , and get on by degrees . [You]137-miss price _ have _ a look of _ [his]108-edmund _ sometimes . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Have [I]1508-i ? [I]1508-i will do [my]1508-i best with the greatest readiness ; but [I]1508-i must _ read _ the part , for [I]1508-i can say very little of it . ”[1508-i] “ _ None _ of it , [I]1509-she suppose . [You]137-miss price are to have the book , of course . Now for it . [We]4932-we must have two chairs at hand for [you]137-miss price to bring forward to the front of the stage . There — very good school - room chairs , not made for [a theatre]4649-a theatre , [I]1509-she dare say ; much more fitted for [little girls]4934-little girls to sit and kick [their]4934-little girls feet against when [they]4934-little girls are learning a lesson . What would [[your]137-miss price governess]4935-your governess and [[your]137-miss price uncle]3760-your uncle say to see [them]4934-little girls used for such a purpose ? Could [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas look in upon [us]4932-we just now , [he]101-sir thomas would bless [himself]101-sir thomas , for [we]4932-we are rehearsing all over [the house]427-the house . [Yates]174-mr. yates is storming away in [the dining - room]4938-the dining - room . [I]1509-she heard [him]174-mr. yates as [I]1509-she came [upstairs]4939-upstairs , and [the theatre]1230-the theatre is engaged of course by [those indefatigable rehearsers]4941-those indefatigable rehearsers , [Agatha]181-agatha and [Frederick]180-frederick . If _ [they]4941-those indefatigable rehearsers _ are not perfect , [I]1509-she _ shall _ be surprised . By the bye , [I]1509-she looked in upon [them]4941-those indefatigable rehearsers five minutes ago , and it happened to be exactly at one of the times when [they]4941-those indefatigable rehearsers were trying _ not _ to embrace , and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was with [me]1509-she . [I]1509-she thought [he]113-fanny began to look a little queer , so [I]1509-she turned it off as well as [I]1509-she could , by whispering to [him]113-fanny , ‘ [We]4942-we shall have an excellent [Agatha]181-agatha ; there is something so _ maternal _ in [her]181-agatha manner , so completely _ maternal _ in [her]181-agatha voice and countenance . ’ Was not that well done of [me]1509-she ? [He]113-fanny brightened up directly . Now for [my]1509-she soliloquy . ”[1509-she] [She]1509-she began , and [Fanny]113-fanny joined in with all the modest feeling which the idea of representing [Edmund]108-edmund was so strongly calculated to inspire ; but with looks and voice so truly feminine as to be no very good picture of [a man]4410-a man . With such an Anhalt , however , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had courage enough ; and [they]1511-they had got through half the scene , when a tap at the door brought a pause , and the entrance of [Edmund]108-edmund , the next moment , suspended it all . Surprise , consciousness , and pleasure appeared in each of the three on this unexpected meeting ; and as [Edmund]108-edmund was come on the very same business that had brought [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , consciousness and pleasure were likely to be more than momentary in _ them _ . [He]108-edmund too had [his]108-edmund book , and was seeking [Fanny]113-fanny , to ask [her]1509-she to rehearse with [him]108-edmund , and help [him]108-edmund to prepare for the evening , without knowing [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford to be in [the house]427-the house ; and great was the joy and animation of being thus thrown together , of comparing schemes , and sympathising in praise of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s kind offices . _ [She]1509-she _ could not equal [them]1511-they in [their]1511-they warmth . _ [Her]1509-she _ spirits sank under the glow of theirs , and [she]1509-she felt [herself]1509-she becoming too nearly nothing to both to have any comfort in having been sought by either . [They]1511-they must now rehearse together . [Edmund]108-edmund proposed , urged , entreated it , till [the lady]718-the lady , not very unwilling at first , could refuse no longer , and [Fanny]113-fanny was wanted only to prompt and observe [them]1511-they . [She]1509-she was invested , indeed , with the office of [judge]1514-judge and [critic]1515-critic , and earnestly desired to exercise it and tell [them]1511-they all [their]1511-they faults ; but from doing so every feeling within [her]1509-she shrank — [she]1509-she could not , would not , dared not attempt it : had [she]1509-she been otherwise qualified for criticism , [her]1509-she conscience must have restrained [her]1509-she from venturing at disapprobation . [She]1509-she believed [herself]1509-she to feel too much of it in the aggregate for honesty or safety in particulars . To prompt [them]1511-they must be enough for [her]1509-she ; and it was sometimes _ more _ than enough ; for [she]1509-she could not always pay attention to the book . In watching [them]1511-they [she]1509-she forgot [herself]1509-she ; and , agitated by the increasing spirit of [Edmund]108-edmund ’s manner , had once closed the page and turned away exactly as [he]108-edmund wanted help . It was imputed to very reasonable weariness , and [she]1509-she was thanked and pitied ; but [she]1509-she deserved [their]1511-they pity more than [she]1509-she hoped [they]1511-they would ever surmise . At last the scene was over , and [Fanny]113-fanny forced [herself]113-fanny to add [her]1509-she praise to the compliments [each]1248-each was giving [the other]477-the other ; and when again alone and able to recall the whole , [she]1509-she was inclined to believe [their]1511-they performance would , indeed , have such nature and feeling in it as must ensure [their]1511-they credit , and make it a very suffering exhibition to [herself]1509-she . Whatever might be its effect , however , [she]1509-she must stand the brunt of it again that very day . The first regular rehearsal of the three first acts was certainly to take place in the evening : [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [the Crawfords]1518-the crawfords were engaged to return for that purpose as soon as [they]1511-they could after dinner ; and [every one concerned]1519-every one concerned was looking forward with eagerness . There seemed a general diffusion of cheerfulness on the occasion . [Tom]101-sir thomas was enjoying such an advance towards the end ; [Edmund]108-edmund was in spirits from the morning ’s rehearsal , and little vexations seemed everywhere smoothed away . [All]874-all were alert and impatient ; [the ladies]577-the ladies moved soon , [the gentlemen]4865-the gentlemen soon followed [them]577-the ladies , and with the exception of [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , and [Julia]112-julia , [everybody]408-everybody was in [the theatre]1230-the theatre at an early hour ; and having lighted [it]1230-the theatre up as well as [its]1230-the theatre unfinished state admitted , were waiting only the arrival of [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords to begin . [They]1511-they did not wait long for [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords , but there was no [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant . [She]123-mrs. grant could not come . [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , professing an indisposition , for which [he]121-dr. grant had little credit with [[his]121-dr. grant fair sister - in - law]1525-his fair sister - in - law , could not spare [[his]121-dr. grant wife]546-his wife . “ [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant is ill , ”[123-mrs. grant] said [she]123-mrs. grant , with mock solemnity . “ [He]121-dr. grant has been ill ever since [he]121-dr. grant did not eat any of the pheasant today . [He]121-dr. grant fancied it tough , sent away [his]121-dr. grant plate , and has been suffering ever since ”[123-mrs. grant] . Here was disappointment ! [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s non - attendance was sad indeed . [Her]123-mrs. grant pleasant manners and cheerful conformity made [her]123-mrs. grant always valuable amongst [them]1511-they ; but _ now _ [she]123-mrs. grant was absolutely necessary . [They]1511-they could not act , [they]1511-they could not rehearse with any satisfaction without [her]123-mrs. grant . The comfort of the whole evening was destroyed . What was to be done ? [Tom]101-sir thomas , as [Cottager]198-cottager , was in despair . After a pause of perplexity , some eyes began to be turned towards [Fanny]113-fanny , and a voice or two to say , “ If [Miss Price]137-miss price would be so good as to _ read _ the part . ”[123-mrs. grant] [She]123-mrs. grant was immediately surrounded by supplications ; [everybody]408-everybody asked it ; even [Edmund]108-edmund said , “ Do , [Fanny]113-fanny , if it is not _ very _ disagreeable to [you]113-fanny . ”[108-edmund] But [Fanny]113-fanny still hung back . [She]123-mrs. grant could not endure the idea of it . Why was not [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford to be applied to as well ? Or why had not [she]123-mrs. grant rather gone to [[her]123-mrs. grant own room]1528-her own room , as [she]123-mrs. grant had felt to be safest , instead of attending the rehearsal at all ? [She]123-mrs. grant had known it would irritate and distress [her]123-mrs. grant ; [she]123-mrs. grant had known it [her]123-mrs. grant duty to keep away . [She]123-mrs. grant was properly punished . “ [You]113-fanny have only to _ read _ the part , ”[131-henry] said [Henry Crawford]131-henry , with renewed entreaty . “ And [I]126-maria do believe [she]123-mrs. grant can say every word of it , ”[126-maria] added [Maria]126-maria , “ for [she]123-mrs. grant could put [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant right the other day in twenty places . [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]126-maria am sure [you]113-fanny know the part . ”[126-maria] [Fanny]113-fanny could not say [she]123-mrs. grant did _ not _ ; and as [they]1529-they all persevered , as [Edmund]108-edmund repeated [his]108-edmund wish , and with a look of even fond dependence on [her]123-mrs. grant good - nature , [she]123-mrs. grant must yield . [She]123-mrs. grant would do [her]123-mrs. grant best . [Everybody]408-everybody was satisfied ; and [she]123-mrs. grant was left to the tremors of a most palpitating heart , while [the others]347-the others prepared to begin . [They]1529-they _ did _ begin ; and being too much engaged in [their]1529-they own noise to be struck by an unusual noise in the other part of [the house]427-the house , had proceeded some way when the door of [the room]412-the room was thrown open , and [Julia]112-julia , appearing at [it]1534-it , with a face all aghast , exclaimed , “ [[My]112-julia father]3762-my father is come ! [He]3762-my father is in [the hall]871-the hall at this moment . ”[112-julia] CHAPTER XIX How is the consternation of [the party]907-the party to be described ? To the greater number it was a moment of absolute horror . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas in [the house]427-the house ! All felt the instantaneous conviction . Not a hope of imposition or mistake was harboured anywhere . [Julia]112-julia ’s looks were an evidence of the fact that made it indisputable ; and after the first starts and exclamations , not a word was spoken for half a minute : [each with an altered countenance]1537-each with an altered countenance was looking at [some other]1538-some other , and almost [each]1248-each was feeling it a stroke the most unwelcome , most ill - timed , most appalling !
