[Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates might consider it only as a vexatious interruption for the evening , and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny might imagine it a blessing ; but every other heart was sinking under some degree of self - condemnation or undefined alarm , every other heart was suggesting , “ What will become of [us]4945-us ? what is to be done now ? ”[113-fanny] It was a terrible pause ; and terrible to every ear were the corroborating sounds of opening doors and passing footsteps . [Julia]112-julia was the first to move and speak again . Jealousy and bitterness had been suspended : selfishness was lost in the common cause ; but at the moment of [her]112-julia appearance , [Frederick]180-frederick was listening with looks of devotion to [Agatha]181-agatha ’s narrative , and pressing [her]112-julia hand to [his]180-frederick heart ; and as soon as [she]112-julia could notice this , and see that , in spite of the shock of [her]112-julia words , [he]180-frederick still kept [his]180-frederick station and retained [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister ’s hand , [her]112-julia wounded heart swelled again with injury , and looking as red as [she]112-julia had been white before , [she]112-julia turned out of [the room]412-the room , saying , “ _ [I]112-julia _ need not be afraid of appearing before [him]180-frederick . ”[112-julia] [Her]112-julia going roused [the rest]441-the rest ; and at the same moment [the two brothers]1446-the two brothers stepped forward , feeling the necessity of doing something . A very few words between [them]1446-the two brothers were sufficient . The case admitted no difference of opinion : [they]1446-the two brothers must go to [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room directly . [Maria]126-maria joined [them]1446-the two brothers with the same intent , just then the stoutest of [the three]1545-the three ; for the very circumstance which had driven [Julia]112-julia away was to [her]112-julia the sweetest support . [Henry Crawford]131-henry ’s retaining [her]112-julia hand at such a moment , a moment of such peculiar proof and importance , was worth ages of doubt and anxiety . [She]126-maria hailed it as an earnest of the most serious determination , and was equal even to encounter [[her]126-maria father]667-her father . [They]1446-the two brothers walked off , utterly heedless of [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s repeated question of , “ Shall [I]113-fanny go too ? Had not [I]113-fanny better go too ? Will not it be right for [me]113-fanny to go too ? ”[113-fanny] but [they]1446-the two brothers were no sooner through the door than [Henry Crawford]131-henry undertook to answer the anxious inquiry , and , encouraging [him]667-her father by all means to pay [his]667-her father respects to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas without delay , sent [him]667-her father after [the others]347-the others with delighted haste . [Fanny]113-fanny was left with only [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords and [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates . [She]126-maria had been quite overlooked by [[her]126-maria cousins]3671-her cousins ; and as [her]126-maria own opinion of [her]126-maria claims on [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s affection was much too humble to give [her]126-maria any idea of classing [herself]126-maria with [[his]101-sir thomas children]1549-his children , [she]126-maria was glad to remain behind and gain a little breathing - time . [Her]126-maria agitation and alarm exceeded all that was endured by [the rest]441-the rest , by the right of a disposition which not even innocence could keep from suffering . [She]126-maria was nearly fainting : all [her]126-maria former habitual dread of [[her]126-maria uncle]312-her uncle was returning , and with it compassion for [him]312-her uncle and for almost [every one of the party on the development before [him]312-her uncle]1552-every one of the party on the development before him , with solicitude on [Edmund]108-edmund ’s account indescribable . [She]126-maria had found a seat , where in excessive trembling [she]126-maria was enduring all these fearful thoughts , while [the other three , no longer under any restraint]1553-the other three , no longer under any restraint , were giving vent to [their]1553-the other three , no longer under any restraint feelings of vexation , lamenting over such an unlooked - for premature arrival as a most untoward event , and without mercy wishing poor [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had been twice as long on [his]101-sir thomas passage , or were still in [Antigua]18-antigua . [The Crawfords]135-the crawfords were more warm on the subject than [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , from better understanding [the family]3724-the family , and judging more clearly of the mischief that must ensue . The ruin of the play was to [them]135-the crawfords a certainty : [they]135-the crawfords felt the total destruction of the scheme to be inevitably at hand ; while [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates considered it only as a temporary interruption , a disaster for the evening , and could even suggest the possibility of the rehearsal being renewed after tea , when the bustle of receiving [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas were over , and [he]312-her uncle might be at leisure to be amused by it . [The Crawfords]135-the crawfords laughed at the idea ; and having soon agreed on the propriety of [their]135-the crawfords walking quietly [home]367-home and leaving [the family]3724-the family to [themselves]135-the crawfords , proposed [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ’s accompanying [them]135-the crawfords and spending the evening at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage . But [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , having never been with [those who thought much of parental claims , or family]1558-those who thought much of parental claims , or family confidence , could not perceive that anything of the kind was necessary ; and therefore , thanking [them]135-the crawfords , said , “ [he]312-her uncle preferred remaining where [he]312-her uncle was , that [he]312-her uncle might pay [his]312-her uncle respects to [the old gentleman]4946-the old gentleman handsomely since [he]312-her uncle _ was _ come ; and besides , [he]312-her uncle did not think it would be fair by [the others]347-the others to have [everybody]408-everybody run away . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny was just beginning to collect [herself]113-fanny , and to feel that if [she]1559-her staid longer behind it might seem disrespectful , when this point was settled , and being commissioned with [the brother and sister]1560-the brother and sister ’s apology , saw [them]135-the crawfords preparing to go as [she]1559-her quitted [the room]412-the room [herself]1559-her to perform the dreadful duty of appearing before [[her]1559-her uncle]312-her uncle . Too soon did [she]1559-her find [herself]1559-her at [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room door ; and after pausing a moment for what [she]1559-her knew would not come , for a courage which the outside of no door had ever supplied to [her]1559-her , [she]1559-her turned the lock in desperation , and the lights of [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , and [all the collected family]1565-all the collected family , were before [her]1559-her . As [she]1559-her entered , [her]1559-her own name caught [her]1559-her ear . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was at that moment looking round [him]101-sir thomas , and saying , “ But where is [Fanny]113-fanny ? Why do not [I]101-sir thomas see [my]101-sir thomas little Fanny?”—and[101-sir thomas] on perceiving [her]1559-her , came forward with a kindness which astonished and penetrated [her]1559-her , calling [her]1559-her [his]101-sir thomas dear [Fanny]113-fanny , kissing [her]1559-her affectionately , and observing with decided pleasure how much [she]1559-her was grown ! [Fanny]113-fanny knew not how to feel , nor where to look . [She]1559-her was quite oppressed . [He]101-sir thomas had never been so kind , so _ very _ kind to [her]1559-her in [his]101-sir thomas life . [His]101-sir thomas manner seemed changed , [his]101-sir thomas voice was quick from the agitation of joy ; and all that had been awful in [his]101-sir thomas dignity seemed lost in tenderness . [He]101-sir thomas led [her]1559-her nearer the light and looked at [her]1559-her again — inquired particularly after [her]1559-her health , and then , correcting [himself]101-sir thomas , observed that [he]101-sir thomas need not inquire , for [her]1559-her appearance spoke sufficiently on that point . A fine blush having succeeded the previous paleness of [her]1559-her face , [he]101-sir thomas was justified in [his]101-sir thomas belief of [her]1559-her equal improvement in health and beauty . [He]101-sir thomas inquired next after [[her]1559-her family]322-her family , especially [William]228-william : and [his]101-sir thomas kindness altogether was such as made [her]1559-her reproach [herself]1559-her for loving [him]101-sir thomas so little , and thinking [his]101-sir thomas return a misfortune ; and when , on having courage to lift [her]1559-her eyes to [his]101-sir thomas face , [she]1559-her saw that [he]101-sir thomas was grown thinner , and had the burnt , fagged , worn look of fatigue and a hot climate , every tender feeling was increased , and [she]1559-her was miserable in considering how much unsuspected vexation was probably ready to burst on [him]101-sir thomas . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was indeed the life of [the party]907-the party , who at [his]101-sir thomas suggestion now seated [themselves]907-the party round the fire . [He]101-sir thomas had the best right to be [the talker]1568-the talker ; and the delight of [his]101-sir thomas sensations in being again in [[his]101-sir thomas own house]1569-his own house , in [the centre of [[his]101-sir thomas family]582-his family]1570-the centre of his family , after such a separation , made [him]101-sir thomas communicative and chatty in a very unusual degree ; and [he]101-sir thomas was ready to give every information as to [his]101-sir thomas voyage , and answer every question of [[his]101-sir thomas two sons]354-his two sons almost before it was put . [His]101-sir thomas business in [Antigua]18-antigua had latterly been prosperously rapid , and [he]101-sir thomas came directly from [Liverpool]52-liverpool , having had an opportunity of making [his]101-sir thomas passage thither in [a private vessel]1573-a private vessel , instead of waiting for [the packet]1574-the packet ; and all the little particulars of [his]101-sir thomas proceedings and events , [his]101-sir thomas arrivals and departures , were most promptly delivered , as [he]101-sir thomas sat by [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram and looked with heartfelt satisfaction on the faces around [him]101-sir thomas — interrupting [himself]101-sir thomas more than once , however , to remark on [his]101-sir thomas good fortune in finding [them]1575-them all at [home]367-home — coming unexpectedly as [he]101-sir thomas did — all collected together exactly as [he]101-sir thomas could have wished , but dared not depend on . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was not forgotten : a most friendly reception and warmth of hand - shaking had already met [him]113-fanny , and with pointed attention [he]113-fanny was now included in the objects most intimately connected with [Mansfield]130-mansfield . There was nothing disagreeable in [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s appearance , and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was liking [him]113-fanny already . By [not one of the circle]1577-not one of the circle was [he]101-sir thomas listened to with such unbroken , unalloyed enjoyment as by [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife , who was really extremely happy to see [him]101-sir thomas , and whose feelings were so warmed by [his]101-sir thomas sudden arrival as to place [her]546-his wife nearer agitation than [she]546-his wife had been for the last twenty years . [She]546-his wife had been _ almost _ fluttered for a few minutes , and still remained so sensibly animated as to put away [her]546-his wife work , move Pug from [her]546-his wife side , and give all [her]546-his wife attention and all the rest of [her]546-his wife sofa to [[her]546-his wife husband]325-her husband . [She]546-his wife had no anxieties for [anybody]3668-anybody to cloud _ [her]546-his wife _ pleasure : [her]546-his wife own time had been irreproachably spent during [his]101-sir thomas absence : [she]546-his wife had done a great deal of carpet - work , and made many yards of fringe ; and [she]546-his wife would have answered as freely for the good conduct and useful pursuits of [all the young people]903-all the young people as for [her]546-his wife own . It was so agreeable to [her]546-his wife to see [him]101-sir thomas again , and hear [him]101-sir thomas talk , to have [her]546-his wife ear amused and [her]546-his wife whole comprehension filled by [his]101-sir thomas narratives , that [she]546-his wife began particularly to feel how dreadfully [she]546-his wife must have missed [him]101-sir thomas , and how impossible it would have been for [her]546-his wife to bear a lengthened absence . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was by no means to be compared in happiness to [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister . Not that _ [she]105-mrs. norris _ was incommoded by many fears of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s disapprobation when the present state of [[his]101-sir thomas house]4696-his house should be known , for [her]546-his wife judgment had been so blinded that , except by the instinctive caution with which [she]546-his wife had whisked away [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s pink satin cloak as [[her]546-his wife brother - in - law]318-her brother - in - law entered , [she]546-his wife could hardly be said to shew any sign of alarm ; but [she]546-his wife was vexed by the _ manner _ of [his]101-sir thomas return . It had left [her]546-his wife nothing to do . Instead of being sent for out of [the room]412-the room , and seeing [him]101-sir thomas first , and having to spread the happy news through [the house]427-the house , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , with a very reasonable dependence , perhaps , on the nerves of [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife and [children]339-children , had sought [no confidant]1589-no confidant but [the butler]1461-the butler , and had been following [him]101-sir thomas almost instantaneously into [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris felt [herself]105-mrs. norris defrauded of [an office on which [she]105-mrs. norris had always depended , whether [his]101-sir thomas arrival or [his]101-sir thomas death were to be the thing unfolded]1592-an office on which she had always depended , whether his arrival or his death were to be the thing unfolded ; and was now trying to be in a bustle without having anything to bustle about , and labouring to be important where nothing was wanted but tranquillity and silence . Would [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas have consented to eat , [she]105-mrs. norris might have gone to [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper with troublesome directions , and insulted [the footmen]1594-the footmen with injunctions of despatch ; but [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas resolutely declined all dinner : [he]101-sir thomas would take nothing , nothing till tea came — [he]101-sir thomas would rather wait for tea . Still [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was at intervals urging something different ; and in the most interesting moment of [his]101-sir thomas passage to [England]14-england , when the alarm of [a French privateer]1595-a french privateer was at the height , [she]105-mrs. norris burst through [his]101-sir thomas recital with the proposal of soup . “ Sure , [[my]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , a basin of soup would be a much better thing for [you]101-sir thomas than tea . Do have a basin of soup . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could not be provoked . “ Still the same anxiety for [everybody]408-everybody ’s comfort , [[my]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , ”[105-mrs. norris] was [his]101-sir thomas answer . “ But indeed [I]105-mrs. norris would rather have nothing but tea . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Well , then , [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , suppose [you]106-lady bertram speak for tea directly ; suppose [you]106-lady bertram hurry [Baddeley]215-baddeley a little ; [he]101-sir thomas seems behindhand to - night . ”[105-mrs. norris] [She]105-mrs. norris carried this point , and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s narrative proceeded . At length there was a pause . [His]101-sir thomas immediate communications were exhausted , and it seemed enough to be looking joyfully around [him]101-sir thomas , now at one , now at another of the beloved circle ; but the pause was not long : in the elation of [her]105-mrs. norris spirits [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram became talkative , and what were the sensations of [[her]105-mrs. norris children]386-her children upon hearing [her]105-mrs. norris say , “ How do [you]101-sir thomas think [the young people]391-the young people have been amusing [themselves]391-the young people lately , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ? [They]391-the young people have been acting . [We]4953-we have been all alive with acting . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Indeed ! and what have [you]101-sir thomas been acting ? ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Oh ! [they]391-the young people ’ll tell [you]101-sir thomas all about it . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ The _ all _ will soon be told , ”[101-sir thomas] cried [Tom]101-sir thomas hastily , and with affected unconcern ; “ but it is not worth while to bore [[my]101-sir thomas father]3762-my father with it now . [You]101-sir thomas will hear enough of it to - morrow , [sir]4023-sir . [We]4953-we have just been trying , by way of doing something , and amusing [[my]101-sir thomas mother]3827-my mother , just within the last week , to get up a few scenes , a mere trifle . [We]4953-we have had such incessant rains almost since October began , that [we]4953-we have been nearly confined to [the house]427-the house for days together . [I]101-sir thomas have hardly taken out a gun since the 3rd . Tolerable sport the first three days , but there has been no attempting anything since . The first day [I]101-sir thomas went over [Mansfield Wood]53-mansfield wood , and [Edmund]108-edmund took [the copses beyond [Easton]54-easton]4958-the copses beyond easton , and [we]4953-we brought [home]367-home six brace between [us]4953-we , and might each have killed six times as many , but [we]4953-we respect [your]4023-sir pheasants , [sir]4023-sir , [I]101-sir thomas assure [you]4023-sir , as much as [you]4023-sir could desire . [I]101-sir thomas do not think [you]4023-sir will find [[your]4023-sir woods]4961-your woods by any means worse stocked than they were . _ [I]101-sir thomas _ never saw [Mansfield Wood]53-mansfield wood so full of pheasants in [my]101-sir thomas life as this year . [I]101-sir thomas hope [you]4023-sir will take a day ’s sport [there]3696-there [yourself]4023-sir , [sir]4023-sir , soon . ”[101-sir thomas] For the present the danger was over , and [Fanny]113-fanny ’s sick feelings subsided ; but when tea was soon afterwards brought in , and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , getting up , said that [he]101-sir thomas found that [he]101-sir thomas could not be any longer in [the house]427-the house without just looking into [[his]101-sir thomas own dear room]1598-his own dear room , every agitation was returning . [He]101-sir thomas was gone before anything had been said to prepare [him]101-sir thomas for the change [he]101-sir thomas must find [there]3696-there ; and a pause of alarm followed [his]101-sir thomas disappearance . [Edmund]108-edmund was the first to speak — “ Something must be done , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund . “ It is time to think of [[our]1600-their visitors]4964-our visitors , ”[126-maria] said [Maria]126-maria , still feeling [her]126-maria hand pressed to [Henry Crawford]131-henry ’s heart , and caring little for anything else . “ Where did [you]108-edmund leave [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , [Fanny]113-fanny ? ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny told of [their]1600-their departure , and delivered [their]1600-their message . “ Then poor [Yates]174-mr. yates is all alone , ”[101-sir thomas] cried [Tom]101-sir thomas . “ [I]101-sir thomas will go and fetch [him]174-mr. yates . [He]174-mr. yates will be [no bad assistant]4965-no bad assistant when it all comes out . ”[101-sir thomas] To [the theatre]1230-the theatre [he]101-sir thomas went , and reached [it]1230-the theatre just in time to witness the first meeting of [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father and [[his]101-sir thomas friend]319-his friend . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had been a good deal surprised to find candles burning in [[his]101-sir thomas room]1604-his room ; and on casting [his]101-sir thomas eye round [it]1604-his room , to see other symptoms of recent habitation and a general air of confusion in the furniture . The removal of the bookcase from before the billiard - room door struck [him]101-sir thomas especially , but [he]101-sir thomas had scarcely more than time to feel astonished at all this , before there were sounds from [the billiard - room]1244-the billiard - room to astonish [him]101-sir thomas still farther . [Some one]1606-some one was talking there in a very loud accent ; [he]101-sir thomas did not know the voice — more than talking — almost hallooing . [He]101-sir thomas stepped to the door , rejoicing at that moment in having the means of immediate communication , and , opening it , found [himself]101-sir thomas on the stage of [a theatre]4649-a theatre , and opposed to [a ranting young man]1608-a ranting young man , who appeared likely to knock [him]101-sir thomas down backwards . At the very moment of [Yates]174-mr. yates perceiving [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and giving perhaps the very best start [he]174-mr. yates had ever given in the whole course of [his]174-mr. yates rehearsals , [Tom Bertram]101-sir thomas entered at the other end of [the room]412-the room ; and never had [he]101-sir thomas found greater difficulty in keeping [his]101-sir thomas countenance . [[His]174-mr. yates father]534-his father ’s looks of solemnity and amazement on this [his]174-mr. yates first appearance on any stage , and the gradual metamorphosis of [the impassioned Baron Wildenheim]196-baron wildenheim into the well - bred and easy [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , making [his]174-mr. yates bow and apology to [Sir Thomas Bertram]101-sir thomas , was such an exhibition , such a piece of true acting , as [he]101-sir thomas would not have lost upon any account . It would be the last — in all probability — the last scene on that stage ; but [he]101-sir thomas was sure there could not be a finer . [The house]427-the house would close with the greatest eclat . There was little time , however , for the indulgence of any images of merriment . It was necessary for [him]101-sir thomas to step forward , too , and assist the introduction , and with many awkward sensations [he]101-sir thomas did [his]101-sir thomas best . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas received [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates with all the appearance of cordiality which was due to [his]101-sir thomas own character , but was really as far from pleased with the necessity of the acquaintance as with the manner of its commencement . [[Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ’s family]1612-mr. yates ’s family and connexions were sufficiently known to [him]174-mr. yates to render [his]174-mr. yates introduction as [the “ particular friend]4966-the “ particular friend , ”[4966-the “ particular friend] [another of the hundred particular friends of [[his]174-mr. yates son]581-his son]1613-another of the hundred particular friends of his son , exceedingly unwelcome ; and it needed all the felicity of being again at [home]367-home , and all the forbearance it could supply , to save [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas from anger on finding [himself]101-sir thomas thus bewildered in [[his]101-sir thomas own house]1569-his own house , making part of a ridiculous exhibition in the midst of theatrical nonsense , and forced in so untoward a moment to admit the acquaintance of [a young man whom [he]101-sir thomas felt sure of disapproving , and [whose easy indifference and volubility in the course of the first five minutes]1618-whose easy indifference and volubility in the course of the first five minutes seemed to mark [him]101-sir thomas the most at home of [the two]390-the two]1617-a young man whom he felt sure of disapproving , and whose easy indifference and volubility in the course of the first five minutes seemed to mark him the most at home of the two . [Tom]101-sir thomas understood [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father ’s thoughts , and heartily wishing [he]101-sir thomas might be always as well disposed to give [them]1621-them but partial expression , began to see , more clearly than [he]101-sir thomas had ever done before , that there might be some ground of offence , that there might be some reason for the glance [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father gave towards the ceiling and stucco of [the room]412-the room ; and that when [he]101-sir thomas inquired with mild gravity after the fate of the billiard - table , [he]101-sir thomas was not proceeding beyond a very allowable curiosity . A few minutes were enough for such unsatisfactory sensations on each side ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas having exerted [himself]101-sir thomas so far as to speak a few words of calm approbation in reply to an eager appeal of [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , as to the happiness of the arrangement , [the three gentlemen]1624-the three gentlemen returned to [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room together , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas with an increase of gravity which was not lost on all . “ [I]101-sir thomas come from [[your]174-mr. yates theatre]4967-your theatre , ”[101-sir thomas] said [he]101-sir thomas composedly , as [he]101-sir thomas sat down ; “ [I]101-sir thomas found [myself]101-sir thomas in [it]4967-your theatre rather unexpectedly . Its vicinity to [[my]101-sir thomas own room]4968-my own room — but in every respect , indeed , it took [me]101-sir thomas by surprise , as [I]101-sir thomas had not the smallest suspicion of [your]174-mr. yates acting having assumed so serious a character . It appears a neat job , however , as far as [I]101-sir thomas could judge by candlelight , and does [[my]101-sir thomas friend]3848-my friend [Christopher Jackson]187-christopher jackson credit . ”[101-sir thomas] And then [he]101-sir thomas would have changed the subject , and sipped [his]101-sir thomas coffee in peace over domestic matters of a calmer hue ; but [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , without discernment to catch [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s meaning , or diffidence , or delicacy , or discretion enough to allow [him]101-sir thomas to lead the discourse while [he]101-sir thomas mingled among [the others]347-the others with the least obtrusiveness [himself]101-sir thomas , would keep [him]101-sir thomas on the topic of the theatre , would torment [him]101-sir thomas with questions and remarks relative to it , and finally would make [him]101-sir thomas hear the whole history of [his]101-sir thomas disappointment at [Ecclesford]42-ecclesford . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas listened most politely , but found much to offend [his]101-sir thomas ideas of decorum , and confirm [his]101-sir thomas ill - opinion of [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ’s habits of thinking , from the beginning to the end of the story ; and when it was over , could give [him]101-sir thomas no other assurance of sympathy than what a slight bow conveyed . “ This was , in fact , the origin of _ [our]4970-our _ acting , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Tom]101-sir thomas , after a moment ’s thought . “ [[My]101-sir thomas friend]3848-my friend [Yates]174-mr. yates brought the infection from [Ecclesford]42-ecclesford , and it spread — as those things always spread , [you]101-sir thomas know , [sir]4023-sir — the faster , probably , from _ [your]101-sir thomas _ having so often encouraged the sort of thing in [us]4970-our formerly . It was like treading old ground again . ”[101-sir thomas] [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates took the subject from [[his]174-mr. yates friend]319-his friend as soon as possible , and immediately gave [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas an account of what [they]1628-they had done and were doing : told [him]101-sir thomas of the gradual increase of [their]1628-they views , the happy conclusion of [their]1628-they first difficulties , and present promising state of affairs ; relating everything with so blind an interest as made [him]101-sir thomas not only totally unconscious of the uneasy movements of many of [[his]174-mr. yates friends]533-his friends as [they]1628-they sat , the change of countenance , the fidget , the hem ! of unquietness , but prevented [him]101-sir thomas even from seeing the expression of the face on which [his]101-sir thomas own eyes were fixed — from seeing [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s dark brow contract as [he]101-sir thomas looked with inquiring earnestness at [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters and [Edmund]108-edmund , dwelling particularly on [the latter]972-the latter , and speaking a language , a remonstrance , a reproof , which _ [he]101-sir thomas _ felt at [his]101-sir thomas heart . Not less acutely was it felt by [Fanny]113-fanny , who had edged back [her]1632-her chair behind [[her]1632-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s end of the sofa , and , screened from notice [herself]1632-her , saw all that was passing before [her]1632-her . Such a look of reproach at [Edmund]108-edmund from [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father [she]1632-her could never have expected to witness ; and to feel that it was in any degree deserved was an aggravation indeed . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s look implied , “ On [your]108-edmund judgment , [Edmund]108-edmund , [I]1632-her depended ; what have [you]108-edmund been about ? ”[1632-her] [She]1632-her knelt in spirit to [[her]1632-her uncle]312-her uncle , and [her]1632-her bosom swelled to utter , “ Oh , not to _ [him]312-her uncle _ ! Look so to [all the others]605-all the others , but not to _ [him]312-her uncle _ ! ”[1632-her] [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates was still talking . “ To own the truth , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [we]4974-we were in the middle of a rehearsal when [you]101-sir thomas arrived this evening . [We]4974-we were going through the three first acts , and not unsuccessfully upon the whole . [[Our]4974-we company]4975-our company is now so dispersed , from [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords being gone [home]367-home , that nothing more can be done to - night ; but if [you]101-sir thomas will give [us]4974-we the honour of [your]101-sir thomas company to - morrow evening , [I]174-mr. yates should not be afraid of the result . [We]4974-we bespeak [your]101-sir thomas indulgence , [you]101-sir thomas understand , as [young performers]4977-young performers ; [we]4974-we bespeak [your]101-sir thomas indulgence . ”[174-mr. yates] “ [My]101-sir thomas indulgence shall be given , [sir]4023-sir , ”[101-sir thomas] replied [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas gravely , “ but without any other rehearsal . ”[101-sir thomas] And with a relenting smile , [he]101-sir thomas added , “ [I]101-sir thomas come [home]367-home to be happy and indulgent . ”[101-sir thomas] Then turning away towards any or all of [the rest]441-the rest , [he]101-sir thomas tranquilly said , “ [Mr.]4980-mr. and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford were mentioned in [my]101-sir thomas last letters from [Mansfield]130-mansfield . Do [you]101-sir thomas find [them]4981-them agreeable acquaintance ? ”[101-sir thomas] [Tom]101-sir thomas was [the only one]1637-the only one at all ready with an answer , but [he]101-sir thomas being entirely without particular regard for either , without jealousy either in love or acting , could speak very handsomely of both . “ [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was [a most pleasant , gentleman - like man]4982-a most pleasant , gentleman - like man ; [[his]133-mr. crawford sister]511-his sister [a sweet , pretty , elegant , lively girl]4984-a sweet , pretty , elegant , lively girl . ”[101-sir thomas] [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny could be silent no longer . “ [I]113-fanny do not say [he]133-mr. crawford is not gentleman - like , considering ; but [you]101-sir thomas should tell [[your]101-sir thomas father]4493-your father [he]4493-your father is not above five feet eight , or [he]4493-your father will be expecting [a well - looking man]4986-a well - looking man . ”[113-fanny] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas did not quite understand this , and looked with some surprise at [the speaker]1638-the speaker . “ If [I]113-fanny must say what [I]113-fanny think , ”[113-fanny] continued [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , “ in [my]113-fanny opinion it is very disagreeable to be always rehearsing . It is having too much of a good thing . [I]113-fanny am not so fond of acting as [I]113-fanny was at first . [I]113-fanny think [we]4987-we are a great deal better employed , sitting comfortably here among [ourselves]4987-we , and doing nothing . ”[113-fanny] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas looked again , and then replied with an approving smile , “ [I]101-sir thomas am happy to find [our]4987-we sentiments on this subject so much the same . It gives [me]101-sir thomas sincere satisfaction . That [I]101-sir thomas should be cautious and quick - sighted , and feel many scruples which [[my]101-sir thomas children]4988-my children do _ not _ feel , is perfectly natural ; and equally so that [my]101-sir thomas value for domestic tranquillity , for a home which shuts out noisy pleasures , should much exceed [theirs]4988-my children . But at [your]4989-your time of life to feel all this , is a most favourable circumstance for [yourself]4989-your , and for [everybody connected with [you]4989-your]4990-everybody connected with you ; and [I]101-sir thomas am sensible of the importance of having [an ally of such weight]4991-an ally of such weight . ”[101-sir thomas] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas meant to be giving [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s opinion in better words than [he]101-sir thomas could find [himself]101-sir thomas . [He]101-sir thomas was aware that [he]101-sir thomas must not expect a genius in [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ; but as [a well - judging , steady young man]1639-a well - judging , steady young man , with better notions than [his]113-fanny elocution would do justice to , [he]101-sir thomas intended to value [him]113-fanny very highly . It was impossible for [many of [the others]347-the others]1640-many of the others not to smile . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny hardly knew what to do with so much meaning ; but by looking , as [he]113-fanny really felt , most exceedingly pleased with [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s good opinion , and saying scarcely anything , [he]113-fanny did [his]113-fanny best towards preserving that good opinion a little longer . [CHAPTER XX Edmund]216-edmund ’s first object the next morning was to see [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father alone , and give [him]534-his father a fair statement of the whole acting scheme , defending [his]101-sir thomas own share in it as far only as [he]101-sir thomas could then , in a soberer moment , feel [his]101-sir thomas motives to deserve , and acknowledging , with perfect ingenuousness , that [his]101-sir thomas concession had been attended with such partial good as to make [his]101-sir thomas judgment in it very doubtful . [He]101-sir thomas was anxious , while vindicating [himself]101-sir thomas , to say nothing unkind of [the others]347-the others : but there was [only one amongst [them]347-the others whose conduct [he]101-sir thomas could mention without some necessity of defence or palliation]1644-only one amongst them whose conduct he could mention without some necessity of defence or palliation . “ [We]4992-we have all been more or less to blame , ”[101-sir thomas] said [he]101-sir thomas , “ [every one of [us]4992-we]4993-every one of us , excepting [Fanny]113-fanny . [Fanny]113-fanny is [the only one who has judged rightly throughout ; who has been consistent]4994-the only one who has judged rightly throughout ; who has been consistent . _ [Her]4994-the only one who has judged rightly throughout ; who has been consistent _ feelings have been steadily against it from first to last . [She]4994-the only one who has judged rightly throughout ; who has been consistent never ceased to think of what was due to [you]216-edmund . [You]216-edmund will find [Fanny]113-fanny everything [you]216-edmund could wish . ”[101-sir thomas] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas saw all the impropriety of such a scheme among [such a party]1645-such a party , and at such a time , as strongly as [[his]101-sir thomas son]581-his son had ever supposed [he]101-sir thomas must ; [he]101-sir thomas felt it too much , indeed , for many words ; and having shaken hands with [Edmund]216-edmund , meant to try to lose the disagreeable impression , and forget how much [he]101-sir thomas had been forgotten [himself]101-sir thomas as soon as [he]101-sir thomas could , after [the house]427-the house had been cleared of every object enforcing the remembrance , and restored to its proper state . [He]101-sir thomas did not enter into any remonstrance with [[his]101-sir thomas other children]497-his other children : [he]101-sir thomas was more willing to believe [they]497-his other children felt [their]497-his other children error than to run the risk of investigation . The reproof of an immediate conclusion of everything , the sweep of every preparation , would be sufficient . There was [one person , however , in [the house]427-the house , whom [he]101-sir thomas could not leave to learn [his]101-sir thomas sentiments merely through [his]101-sir thomas conduct]1649-one person , however , in the house , whom he could not leave to learn his sentiments merely through his conduct . [He]101-sir thomas could not help giving [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris a hint of [his]101-sir thomas having hoped that [her]105-mrs. norris advice might have been interposed to prevent what [her]105-mrs. norris judgment must certainly have disapproved . [The young people]391-the young people had been very inconsiderate in forming the plan ; [they]391-the young people ought to have been capable of a better decision [themselves]391-the young people ; but [they]391-the young people were young ; and , excepting [Edmund]216-edmund , [he]101-sir thomas believed , of unsteady characters ; and with greater surprise , therefore , [he]101-sir thomas must regard [her]105-mrs. norris acquiescence in [their]391-the young people wrong measures , [her]105-mrs. norris countenance of [their]391-the young people unsafe amusements , than that such measures and such amusements should have been suggested . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was a little confounded and as nearly being silenced as ever [she]105-mrs. norris had been in [her]105-mrs. norris life ; for [she]105-mrs. norris was ashamed to confess having never seen any of the impropriety which was so glaring to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and would not have admitted that [her]105-mrs. norris influence was insufficient — that [she]105-mrs. norris might have talked in vain . [Her]105-mrs. norris only resource was to get out of the subject as fast as possible , and turn the current of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s ideas into a happier channel . [She]105-mrs. norris had a great deal to insinuate in [her]105-mrs. norris own praise as to _ general _ attention to the interest and comfort of [[his]101-sir thomas family]582-his family , much exertion and many sacrifices to glance at in the form of hurried walks and sudden removals from [her]105-mrs. norris own fireside , and many excellent hints of distrust and economy to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram and [Edmund]216-edmund to detail , whereby a most considerable saving had always arisen , and [more than one bad servant]1653-more than one bad servant been detected . But [her]105-mrs. norris chief strength lay in [Sotherton]27-sotherton . [Her]105-mrs. norris greatest support and glory was in having formed the connexion with [the Rushworths]217-the rushworths . _ There _ [she]105-mrs. norris was impregnable . [She]105-mrs. norris took to [herself]105-mrs. norris all the credit of bringing [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s admiration of [Maria]126-maria to any effect . “ If [I]105-mrs. norris had not been active , ”[105-mrs. norris] said [she]105-mrs. norris , “ and made a point of being introduced to [[his]101-sir thomas mother]629-his mother , and then prevailed on [[my]105-mrs. norris sister]3790-my sister to pay the first visit , [I]105-mrs. norris am as certain as [I]105-mrs. norris sit here that nothing would have come of it ; for [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny is [the sort of amiable modest young man who wants a great deal of encouragement]4997-the sort of amiable modest young man who wants a great deal of encouragement , and there were [girls enough on the catch]4998-girls enough on the catch for [him]101-sir thomas if [we]4999-we had been idle . But [I]105-mrs. norris left no stone unturned . [I]105-mrs. norris was ready to move [heaven and earth]5000-heaven and earth to persuade [[my]105-mrs. norris sister]3790-my sister , and at last [I]105-mrs. norris did persuade [her]3790-my sister . [You]5002-you know the distance to [Sotherton]27-sotherton ; it was in the middle of winter , and [the roads]983-the roads almost impassable , but [I]105-mrs. norris did persuade [her]3790-my sister . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]105-mrs. norris know how great , how justly great , [your]5002-you influence is with [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram and [[her]106-lady bertram children]386-her children , and am the more concerned that it should not have been — ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [[My]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear Sir [Thomas]101-sir thomas , if [you]5002-you had seen the state of [the roads]983-the roads _ that _ day ! [I]105-mrs. norris thought [we]5007-we should never have got through them , though [we]5007-we had the four horses of course ; and [poor old coachman]5008-poor old coachman would attend [us]5007-we , out of [his]5008-poor old coachman great love and kindness , though [he]5008-poor old coachman was hardly able to sit the box on account of the rheumatism which [I]105-mrs. norris had been doctoring [him]5008-poor old coachman for ever since [Michaelmas]218-michaelmas . [I]105-mrs. norris cured [him]5008-poor old coachman at last ; but [he]5008-poor old coachman was very bad all the winter — and this was such a day , [I]105-mrs. norris could not help going to [him]5008-poor old coachman up in [[his]5008-poor old coachman room]1604-his room before [we]5007-we set off to advise [him]5008-poor old coachman not to venture : [he]5008-poor old coachman was putting on [his]5008-poor old coachman wig ; so [I]105-mrs. norris said , ‘ [Coachman]219-coachman , [you]219-coachman had much better not go ; [[your]219-coachman Lady]5010-your lady and [I]105-mrs. norris shall be very safe ; [you]219-coachman know how steady [Stephen]220-stephen is , and [Charles]206-charles maddox has been upon [the leaders]5011-the leaders so often now , that [I]105-mrs. norris am sure there is no fear . ’ But , however , [I]105-mrs. norris soon found it would not do ; [he]5008-poor old coachman was bent upon going , and as [I]105-mrs. norris hate to be worrying and officious , [I]105-mrs. norris said no more ; but [my]105-mrs. norris heart quite ached for [him]5008-poor old coachman at every jolt , and when [we]5012-we got into [the rough lanes about [Stoke]46-stoke]5013-the rough lanes about stoke , where , what with frost and snow upon beds of stones , it was worse than anything [you]5014-you can imagine , [I]105-mrs. norris was quite in an agony about [him]5008-poor old coachman . And then the poor horses too ! To see [them]5015-them straining away ! [You]5014-you know how [I]105-mrs. norris always feel for the horses . And when [we]5012-we got to [the bottom of [Sandcroft Hill]55-sandcroft hill]5016-the bottom of sandcroft hill , what do [you]5014-you think [I]105-mrs. norris did ? [You]5014-you will laugh at [me]105-mrs. norris ; but [I]105-mrs. norris got out and walked up . [I]105-mrs. norris did indeed . It might not be saving [them]5015-them much , but it was something , and [I]105-mrs. norris could not bear to sit at [my]105-mrs. norris ease and be dragged up at the expense of those noble animals . [I]105-mrs. norris caught a dreadful cold , but _ that _ [I]105-mrs. norris did not regard . [My]105-mrs. norris object was accomplished in the visit . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]105-mrs. norris hope [we]5012-we shall always think [the acquaintance]5017-the acquaintance worth any trouble that might be taken to establish it . There is nothing very striking in [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s manners , but [I]105-mrs. norris was pleased last night with what appeared to be [his]113-fanny opinion on one subject : [his]113-fanny decided preference of [a quiet family party]5018-a quiet family party to the bustle and confusion of acting . [He]113-fanny seemed to feel exactly as [one]766-one could wish . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Yes , indeed , and the more [you]5014-you know of [him]113-fanny the better [you]5014-you will like [him]113-fanny . [He]113-fanny is not a shining character , but [he]113-fanny has a thousand good qualities ; and is so disposed to look up to [you]5014-you , that [I]105-mrs. norris am quite laughed at about it , for [everybody]408-everybody considers it as [my]105-mrs. norris doing . ‘ Upon [my]105-mrs. norris word , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , ’ said [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant the other day , ‘ if [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny were [a son of [your]105-mrs. norris own]5021-a son of your own , [he]113-fanny could not hold [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas in greater respect . ’ ”[105-mrs. norris] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas gave up the point , foiled by [her]1654-her evasions , disarmed by [her]1654-her flattery ; and was obliged to rest satisfied with the conviction that where the present pleasure of those [she]1654-her loved was at stake , [her]1654-her kindness did sometimes overpower [her]1654-her judgment . It was a busy morning with [him]101-sir thomas . Conversation with any of [them]1655-them occupied but a small part of it . [He]101-sir thomas had to reinstate [himself]101-sir thomas in all the wonted concerns of [his]101-sir thomas Mansfield life : to see [[his]101-sir thomas steward]1656-his steward and [[his]101-sir thomas bailiff]1657-his bailiff ; to examine and compute , and , in the intervals of business , to walk into [[his]101-sir thomas stables]1658-his stables and [[his]101-sir thomas gardens]1659-his gardens , and [nearest plantations]1660-nearest plantations ; but active and methodical , [he]101-sir thomas had not only done all this before [he]101-sir thomas resumed [his]101-sir thomas seat as [master of [the house]427-the house]1236-master of the house at dinner , [he]101-sir thomas had also set [the carpenter]4705-the carpenter to work in pulling down what had been so lately put up in [the billiard - room]1244-the billiard - room , and given [the scene - painter]1460-the scene - painter [his]101-sir thomas dismissal long enough to justify the pleasing belief of [his]101-sir thomas being then at least as far off as [Northampton]8-northampton . [The scene - painter]1460-the scene - painter was gone , having spoilt only the floor of [one room]4420-one room , ruined all [the coachman]1668-the coachman ’s sponges , and made [five of [the under - servants]1670-the under - servants]1669-five of the under - servants idle and dissatisfied ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was in hopes that another day or two would suffice to wipe away every outward memento of what had been , even to the destruction of every unbound copy of [Lovers]177-lovers ’ Vows in [the house]427-the house , for [he]101-sir thomas was burning all that met [his]101-sir thomas eye . [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates was beginning now to understand [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s intentions , though as far as ever from understanding [their]1672-their source . [He]174-mr. yates and [[his]174-mr. yates friend]319-his friend had been out with [their]1674-their guns [the chief of the morning]1675-the chief of the morning , and [Tom]101-sir thomas had taken the opportunity of explaining , with proper apologies for [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father ’s particularity , what was to be expected . [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates felt it as acutely as might be supposed . To be a second time disappointed in the same way was an instance of very severe ill - luck ; and [his]174-mr. yates indignation was such , that had it not been for delicacy towards [[his]174-mr. yates friend]319-his friend , and [[his]174-mr. yates friend ’s youngest sister]1678-his friend ’s youngest sister , [he]174-mr. yates believed [he]174-mr. yates should certainly attack [the baronet]1679-the baronet on the absurdity of [his]1679-the baronet proceedings , and argue [him]1679-the baronet into a little more rationality . [He]174-mr. yates believed this very stoutly while [he]174-mr. yates was in [Mansfield Wood]53-mansfield wood , and all the way [home]367-home ; but there was a something in [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , when [they]1681-they sat round the same table , which made [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates think it wiser to let [him]174-mr. yates pursue [his]174-mr. yates own way , and feel the folly of it without opposition . [He]174-mr. yates had known [many disagreeable fathers]1682-many disagreeable fathers before , and often been struck with the inconveniences [they]1682-many disagreeable fathers occasioned , but never , in the whole course of [his]174-mr. yates life , had [he]174-mr. yates seen [one of that class so unintelligibly moral]1683-one of that class so unintelligibly moral , so infamously tyrannical as [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . [He]174-mr. yates was not [a man]4410-a man to be endured but for [[his]174-mr. yates children]1549-his children ’s sake , and [he]174-mr. yates might be thankful to [[his]174-mr. yates fair daughter]1686-his fair daughter [Julia]112-julia that [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates did yet mean to stay a few days longer under [his]174-mr. yates roof . The evening passed with external smoothness , though almost every mind was ruffled ; and the music which [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas called for from [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters helped to conceal the want of real harmony . [Maria]126-maria was in a good deal of agitation . It was of the utmost consequence to [her]126-maria that [Crawford]133-mr. crawford should now lose no time in declaring [himself]133-mr. crawford , and [she]126-maria was disturbed that even a day should be gone by without seeming to advance that point . [She]126-maria had been expecting to see [him]133-mr. crawford the whole morning , and all the evening , too , was still expecting [him]133-mr. crawford . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had set off early with the great news for [Sotherton]27-sotherton ; and [she]126-maria had fondly hoped for such an immediate _ eclaircissement _ as might save [him]133-mr. crawford the trouble of ever coming back again . But [they]1688-they had seen [no one from the Parsonage]1689-no one from the parsonage , not [a creature]1690-a creature , and had heard no tidings beyond a friendly note of congratulation and inquiry from [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram . It was the first day for many , many weeks , in which [the families]802-the families had been wholly divided . Four - and - twenty hours had never passed before , since August began , without bringing [them]802-the families together in some way or other . It was a sad , anxious day ; and the morrow , though differing in the sort of evil , did by no means bring less . A few moments of feverish enjoyment were followed by hours of acute suffering . [Henry Crawford]131-henry was again in [the house]427-the house : [he]131-henry walked up with [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , who was anxious to pay [his]121-dr. grant respects to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and at rather an early hour [they]1688-they were ushered into [the breakfast - room]3756-the breakfast - room , where were [most of [the family]3724-the family]1694-most of the family . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas soon appeared , and [Maria]126-maria saw with delight and agitation the introduction of [the man [she]126-maria loved to [[her]126-maria father]667-her father]1696-the man she loved to her father . [Her]126-maria sensations were indefinable , and so were [they]802-the families a few minutes afterwards upon hearing [Henry Crawford]131-henry , who had a chair between [herself]131-henry and [Tom]101-sir thomas , ask [the latter]972-the latter in an undervoice whether there were any plans for resuming the play after the present happy interruption ( with a courteous glance at [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ) , because , in that case , [he]101-sir thomas should make a point of returning to [Mansfield]3-mansfield at any time required by [the party]907-the party : [he]101-sir thomas was going away immediately , being to meet [[his]101-sir thomas uncle]526-his uncle at [Bath]56-bath without delay ; but if there were any prospect of a renewal of [Lovers]177-lovers ’ Vows , [he]101-sir thomas should hold [himself]101-sir thomas positively engaged , [he]101-sir thomas should break through every other claim , [he]101-sir thomas should absolutely condition with [[his]101-sir thomas uncle]526-his uncle for attending [them]1702-them whenever [he]101-sir thomas might be wanted . The play should not be lost by _ [his]101-sir thomas _ absence . “ From [Bath]56-bath , [Norfolk]19-norfolk , [London]6-london , [York]57-york , wherever [I]101-sir thomas may be , ”[101-sir thomas] said [he]101-sir thomas ; “ [I]101-sir thomas will attend [you]511-his sister from [any place in [England]14-england]4133-any place in england , at an hour ’s notice . ”[101-sir thomas] It was well at that moment that [Tom]101-sir thomas had to speak , and not [[his]101-sir thomas sister]511-his sister . [He]101-sir thomas could immediately say with easy fluency , “ [I]101-sir thomas am sorry [you]511-his sister are going ; but as to [our]5023-our play , _ that _ is all over — entirely at an end ”[101-sir thomas] ( looking significantly at [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father ) . “ [The painter]5024-the painter was sent off yesterday , and very little will remain of [the theatre]1230-the theatre to - morrow . [I]101-sir thomas knew how _ that _ would be from the first . It is early for [Bath]56-bath . [You]511-his sister will find [nobody there]5026-nobody there . ”[101-sir thomas] “ It is about [[my]101-sir thomas uncle]3761-my uncle ’s usual time . ”[101-sir thomas] “ When do [you]534-his father think of going ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ [I]101-sir thomas may , perhaps , get as far as [Banbury]58-banbury to - day . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Whose stables do [you]534-his father use at [Bath]56-bath ? ”[101-sir thomas] was the next question ; and while this branch of the subject was under discussion , [Maria]126-maria , who wanted neither pride nor resolution , was preparing to encounter [her]126-maria share of it with tolerable calmness . To [her]126-maria [he]534-his father soon turned , repeating much of what [he]534-his father had already said , with only a softened air and stronger expressions of regret . But what availed [his]534-his father expressions or [his]534-his father air ? [He]534-his father was going , and , if not voluntarily going , voluntarily intending to stay away ; for , excepting what might be due to [[his]534-his father uncle]526-his uncle , [his]534-his father engagements were all self - imposed . [He]534-his father might talk of necessity , but [she]126-maria knew [his]534-his father independence . The hand which had so pressed [hers]126-maria to [his]534-his father heart ! the hand and the heart were alike motionless and passive now ! [Her]126-maria spirit supported [her]126-maria , but the agony of [her]126-maria mind was severe . [She]126-maria had not long to endure what arose from listening to language which [his]534-his father actions contradicted , or to bury the tumult of [her]126-maria feelings under the restraint of society ; for [general civilities]1706-general civilities soon called [his]534-his father notice from [her]126-maria , and the farewell visit , as it then became openly acknowledged , was a very short one . [He]534-his father was gone — [he]534-his father had touched [her]126-maria hand for the last time , [he]534-his father had made [his]534-his father parting bow , and [she]126-maria might seek directly all that solitude could do for [her]126-maria . [Henry Crawford]131-henry was gone , gone from [the house]427-the house , and within two hours afterwards from [the parish]3860-the parish ; and so ended all the hopes [his]131-henry selfish vanity had raised in [Maria]126-maria and [Julia Bertram]112-julia . [Julia]112-julia could rejoice that [he]131-henry was gone . [His]131-henry presence was beginning to be odious to [her]112-julia ; and if [Maria]126-maria gained [him]131-henry not , [she]112-julia was now cool enough to dispense with any other revenge . [She]112-julia did not want exposure to be added to desertion . [Henry Crawford]131-henry gone , [she]112-julia could even pity [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister . With a purer spirit did [Fanny]113-fanny rejoice in the intelligence . [She]1710-she heard it at dinner , and felt it a blessing . By [all the others]605-all the others it was mentioned with regret ; and [his]131-henry merits honoured with due gradation of feeling — from the sincerity of [Edmund]216-edmund ’s too partial regard , to the unconcern of [[his]131-henry mother]629-his mother speaking entirely by rote . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris began to look about [her]105-mrs. norris , and wonder that [his]131-henry falling in love with [Julia]112-julia had come to nothing ; and could almost fear that [she]105-mrs. norris had been remiss [herself]105-mrs. norris in forwarding it ; but with so [many to care for]1713-many to care for , how was it possible for even _ [her]105-mrs. norris _ activity to keep pace with [her]105-mrs. norris wishes ? Another day or two , and [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates was gone likewise . In _ [his]131-henry _ departure [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas felt the chief interest : wanting to be alone with [[his]101-sir thomas family]582-his family , the presence of [a stranger superior to [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates]1715-a stranger superior to mr. yates must have been irksome ; but of [him]101-sir thomas , trifling and confident , idle and expensive , it was every way vexatious . In [himself]101-sir thomas [he]101-sir thomas was wearisome , but as [the friend of [Tom]101-sir thomas]1716-the friend of tom and [the admirer of [Julia]112-julia]1717-the admirer of julia [he]101-sir thomas became offensive . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had been quite indifferent to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s going or staying : but [his]101-sir thomas good wishes for [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ’s having a pleasant journey , as [he]101-sir thomas walked with [him]101-sir thomas to the hall - door , were given with genuine satisfaction . [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates had staid to see the destruction of every theatrical preparation at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , the removal of everything appertaining to the play : [he]174-mr. yates left [the house]427-the house in all the soberness of [its]427-the house general character ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas hoped , in seeing [him]174-mr. yates out of [it]427-the house , to be rid of the worst object connected with the scheme , and the last that must be inevitably reminding [him]174-mr. yates of its existence . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris contrived to remove one article from [his]174-mr. yates sight that might have distressed [him]174-mr. yates . The curtain , over which [she]105-mrs. norris had presided with such talent and such success , went off with [her]105-mrs. norris to [[her]105-mrs. norris cottage]656-her cottage , where [she]105-mrs. norris happened to be particularly in want of green baize . CHAPTER XXI [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s return made a striking change in the ways of [the family]3724-the family , independent of [Lovers]177-lovers ’ Vows . Under [his]101-sir thomas government , [Mansfield]3-mansfield was [an altered place]1721-an altered place . [Some members of [their]1723-their society]1722-some members of their society sent away , and the spirits of [many others]1724-many others saddened — it was all sameness and gloom compared with the past — a sombre family party rarely enlivened . There was little intercourse with [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , drawing back from intimacies in general , was particularly disinclined , at this time , for any engagements but in one quarter . [The Rushworths]217-the rushworths were the only addition to [his]101-sir thomas own domestic circle which [he]101-sir thomas could solicit . [Edmund]216-edmund did not wonder that such should be [[his]216-edmund father]534-his father ’s feelings , nor could [he]216-edmund regret anything but the exclusion of the Grants . “ But [they]5028-they , ”[216-edmund] [he]216-edmund observed to [Fanny]113-fanny , “ have a claim . [They]5028-they seem to belong to [us]5029-us ; [they]5028-they seem to be part of [ourselves]5029-us . [I]216-edmund could wish [[my]216-edmund father]3762-my father were more sensible of [their]5028-they very great attention to [[my]216-edmund mother]3827-my mother and [sisters]3676-sisters while [he]3762-my father was away . [I]216-edmund am afraid [they]5028-they may feel [themselves]5028-they neglected . But the truth is , that [[my]216-edmund father]3762-my father hardly knows [them]5028-they . [They]5028-they had not been [here]3798-here [a twelvemonth]5035-a twelvemonth when [he]3762-my father left [England]14-england . If [he]3762-my father knew [them]5028-they better , [he]3762-my father would value [their]5028-they society as it deserves ; for [they]5028-they are in fact exactly [the sort of people [he]3762-my father would like]5036-the sort of people he would like . [We]5037-we are sometimes a little in want of animation among [ourselves]5037-we : [[my]216-edmund sisters]4714-my sisters seem out of spirits , and [Tom]101-sir thomas is certainly not at [his]101-sir thomas ease . [Dr.]121-dr. grant and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant would enliven [us]5037-we , and make [our]5037-we evenings pass away with more enjoyment even to [[my]216-edmund father]3762-my father . ”[216-edmund] “ Do [you]3762-my father think so ? ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny : “ in [my]113-fanny opinion , [[my]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle would not like _ any _ addition . [I]113-fanny think [he]3761-my uncle values the very quietness [you]3762-my father speak of , and that the repose of [his]3761-my uncle own family circle is all [he]3761-my uncle wants . And it does not appear to [me]113-fanny that [we]5037-we are more serious than [we]5037-we used to be — [I]113-fanny mean before [[my]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle went abroad . As well as [I]113-fanny can recollect , it was always much the same . There was never much laughing in [his]3761-my uncle presence ; or , if there is any difference , it is not more , [I]113-fanny think , than such an absence has a tendency to produce at first . There must be a sort of shyness ; but [I]113-fanny can not recollect that [our]5037-we evenings formerly were ever merry , except when [[my]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle was in [town]3698-town . [No young people]5044-no young people ’s are , [I]113-fanny suppose , when those [they]5044-no young people look up to are at [home]367-home ”[113-fanny] . “ [I]1727-i believe [you]113-fanny are right , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[1727-i] was [his]1727-i reply , after a short consideration . “ [I]1727-i believe [our]5037-we evenings are rather returned to what they were , than assuming a new character . The novelty was in [their]5044-no young people being lively . Yet , how strong the impression that only a few weeks will give ! [I]1727-i have been feeling as if [we]5037-we had never lived so before . ”[1727-i] “ [I]113-fanny suppose [I]113-fanny am graver than [other people]4182-other people , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny . “ The evenings do not appear long to [me]113-fanny . [I]113-fanny love to hear [[my]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle talk of [the West Indies]23-the west indies . [I]113-fanny could listen to [him]3761-my uncle for an hour together . It entertains _ [me]113-fanny _ more than many other things have done ; but then [I]113-fanny am unlike [other people]4182-other people , [I]113-fanny dare say . ”[113-fanny] “ Why should [you]113-fanny dare say _ that _ ? ”[1727-i] ( smiling ) . “ Do [you]113-fanny want to be told that [you]113-fanny are only unlike [other people]4182-other people in being more wise and discreet ? But when did [you]113-fanny , or [anybody]3668-anybody , ever get a compliment from [me]1727-i , [Fanny]113-fanny ? Go to [[my]1727-i father]3762-my father if [you]113-fanny want to be complimented . [He]3762-my father will satisfy [you]113-fanny . Ask [[your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle what [he]3760-your uncle thinks , and [you]113-fanny will hear compliments enough : and though they may be chiefly on [your]113-fanny person , [you]113-fanny must put up with it , and trust to [his]3760-your uncle seeing as much beauty of mind in time . ”[1727-i] Such language was so new to [Fanny]113-fanny that it quite embarrassed [her]1728-her . “ [[Your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle thinks [you]113-fanny very pretty , dear [Fanny]113-fanny — and that is the long and the short of the matter . [[Anybody]3668-anybody but [myself]113-fanny]5055-anybody but myself would have made something more of it , and [anybody]3668-anybody but [you]113-fanny would resent that [you]113-fanny had not been thought very pretty before ; but the truth is , that [[your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle never did admire [you]113-fanny till now — and now [he]3760-your uncle does . [Your]113-fanny complexion is so improved!—and [you]113-fanny have gained so much countenance!—and [your]113-fanny figure — nay , [Fanny]113-fanny , do not turn away about it — it is but [an uncle]4355-an uncle . If [you]113-fanny can not bear [an uncle]4355-an uncle ’s admiration , what is to become of [you]113-fanny ? [You]113-fanny must really begin to harden [yourself]113-fanny to the idea of being worth looking at . [You]113-fanny must try not to mind growing up into [a pretty woman]5060-a pretty woman . ”[113-fanny] “ Oh ! do n’t talk so , do n’t talk so , ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny , distressed by more feelings than [he]1729-he was aware of ; but seeing that [she]1729-he was distressed , [he]1729-he had done with the subject , and only added more seriously — “ [[Your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle is disposed to be pleased with [you]113-fanny in every respect ; and [I]1729-he only wish [you]113-fanny would talk to [him]3760-your uncle more . [You]113-fanny are one of [those who are too silent in the evening circle]5062-those who are too silent in the evening circle . ”[1729-he] “ But [I]113-fanny do talk to [him]3760-your uncle more than [I]113-fanny used . [I]113-fanny am sure [I]113-fanny do . Did not [you]113-fanny hear [me]113-fanny ask [him]3760-your uncle about the slave - trade last night ? ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny did — and was in hopes the question would be followed up by [others]361-others . It would have pleased [[your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle to be inquired of farther . ”[113-fanny] “ And [I]113-fanny longed to do it — but there was such a dead silence ! And while [[my]113-fanny cousins]4582-my cousins were sitting by without speaking a word , or seeming at all interested in the subject , [I]113-fanny did not like — [I]113-fanny thought it would appear as if [I]113-fanny wanted to set [myself]113-fanny off at [their]4582-my cousins expense , by [shewing]5066-shewing a curiosity and pleasure in [his]3760-your uncle information which [he]3760-your uncle must wish [[his]3760-your uncle own daughters]5067-his own daughters to feel . ”[113-fanny] “ [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was very right in what [she]127-miss crawford said of [you]113-fanny the other day : that [you]113-fanny seemed almost as fearful of notice and praise as [other women]5068-other women were of neglect . [We]5069-we were talking of [you]113-fanny at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , and those were [her]127-miss crawford words . [She]127-miss crawford has great discernment . [I]113-fanny know [nobody who distinguishes characters]5071-nobody who distinguishes characters better . For [so young a woman]5072-so young a woman it is remarkable ! [She]127-miss crawford certainly understands _ [you]113-fanny _ better than [you]113-fanny are understood by the greater part of [those who have known [you]113-fanny so long]5073-those who have known you so long ; and with regard to some others , [I]113-fanny can perceive , from occasional lively hints , the unguarded expressions of the moment , that [she]127-miss crawford could define _ many _ as accurately , did not delicacy forbid it . [I]113-fanny wonder what [she]127-miss crawford thinks of [[my]113-fanny father]3762-my father ! [She]127-miss crawford must admire [him]3762-my father as [a fine - looking man]5075-a fine - looking man , with most gentlemanlike , dignified , consistent manners ; but perhaps , having seen [him]3762-my father so seldom , [his]3762-my father reserve may be a little repulsive . Could [they]5076-they be much together , [I]113-fanny feel sure of [their]5076-they liking each other . [He]3762-my father would enjoy [her]127-miss crawford liveliness and [she]127-miss crawford has talents to value [his]3762-my father powers . [I]113-fanny wish [they]5076-they met more frequently ! [I]113-fanny hope [she]127-miss crawford does not suppose there is any dislike on [his]3762-my father side . ”[113-fanny] “ [She]127-miss crawford must know [herself]127-miss crawford too secure of the regard of [all the rest of [you]5078-you]5077-all the rest of you , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , with half a sigh , “ to have any such apprehension . And [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s wishing just at first to be only with [[his]101-sir thomas family]582-his family , is so very natural , that [she]127-miss crawford can argue nothing from that . After a little while , [I]113-fanny dare say , [we]5076-they shall be meeting again in the same sort of way , allowing for the difference of the time of year . ”[113-fanny] “ This is the first October that [she]127-miss crawford has passed in [the country]493-the country since [her]127-miss crawford infancy . [I]113-fanny do not call [Tunbridge]59-tunbridge or [Cheltenham]60-cheltenham [the country]493-the country ; and November is a still more serious month , and [I]113-fanny can see that [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant is very anxious for [her]127-miss crawford not finding [Mansfield]3-mansfield dull as winter comes on . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny could have said a great deal , but it was safer to say nothing , and leave untouched all [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s resources — [her]127-miss crawford accomplishments , [her]127-miss crawford spirits , [her]127-miss crawford importance , [[her]127-miss crawford friends]362-her friends , lest it should betray [her]127-miss crawford into any observations seemingly unhandsome . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s kind opinion of [herself]127-miss crawford deserved at least a grateful forbearance , and [she]127-miss crawford began to talk of something else . “ To - morrow , [I]127-miss crawford think , [[my]127-miss crawford uncle]3761-my uncle dines at [Sotherton]27-sotherton , and [you]113-fanny and [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund too . [We]5083-we shall be quite a small party at [home]367-home . [I]127-miss crawford hope [[my]127-miss crawford uncle]3761-my uncle may continue to like [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . ”[127-miss crawford] “ That is impossible , [Fanny]113-fanny . [He]3761-my uncle must like [him]113-fanny less after to - morrow ’s visit , for [we]5083-we shall be five hours in [his]113-fanny company . [I]127-miss crawford should dread the stupidity of the day , if there were not a much greater evil to follow — the impression it must leave on [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . [He]101-sir thomas can not much longer deceive [himself]101-sir thomas . [I]127-miss crawford am sorry for [them]5086-them all , and would give something that [Rushworth]113-fanny and [Maria]126-maria had never met . ”[127-miss crawford] In this quarter , indeed , disappointment was impending over [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . Not all [his]101-sir thomas good - will for [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , not [all Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s deference for [him]113-fanny , could prevent [him]101-sir thomas from soon discerning some part of the truth — that [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was [an inferior young man , as ignorant in business as in books , with opinions in general unfixed]1731-an inferior young man , as ignorant in business as in books , with opinions in general unfixed , and without seeming much aware of it [himself]113-fanny . [He]101-sir thomas had expected [a very different son - in - law]1732-a very different son - in - law ; and beginning to feel grave on [Maria]126-maria ’s account , tried to understand _ [her]126-maria _ feelings . Little observation there was necessary to tell [him]101-sir thomas that indifference was the most favourable state [they]1733-they could be in . [Her]126-maria behaviour to [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was careless and cold . [She]126-maria could not , did not like [him]113-fanny . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas resolved to speak seriously to [her]126-maria . Advantageous as would be the alliance , and long standing and public as was the engagement , [her]126-maria happiness must not be sacrificed to it . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had , perhaps , been accepted on too short an acquaintance , and , on knowing [him]113-fanny better , [she]126-maria was repenting . With solemn kindness [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas addressed [her]126-maria : told [her]126-maria [his]101-sir thomas fears , inquired into [her]126-maria wishes , entreated [her]126-maria to be open and sincere , and assured [her]126-maria that every inconvenience should be braved , and the connexion entirely given up , if [she]126-maria felt [herself]126-maria unhappy in the prospect of it . [He]101-sir thomas would act for [her]126-maria and release [her]126-maria . [Maria]126-maria had a moment ’s struggle as [she]126-maria listened , and only a moment ’s : when [[her]126-maria father]667-her father ceased , [she]126-maria was able to give [her]126-maria answer immediately , decidedly , and with no apparent agitation . [She]126-maria thanked [him]101-sir thomas for [his]101-sir thomas great attention , [his]101-sir thomas paternal kindness , but [he]101-sir thomas was quite mistaken in supposing [she]126-maria had the smallest desire of breaking through [her]126-maria engagement , or was sensible of any change of opinion or inclination since [her]126-maria forming it . [She]126-maria had the highest esteem for [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s character and disposition , and could not have a doubt of [her]126-maria happiness with [him]113-fanny . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was satisfied ; too glad to be satisfied , perhaps , to urge the matter quite so far as [his]101-sir thomas judgment might have dictated to [others]361-others . It was an alliance which [he]101-sir thomas could not have relinquished without pain ; and thus [he]101-sir thomas reasoned . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was young enough to improve . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny must and would improve in good society ; and if [Maria]126-maria could now speak so securely of [her]126-maria happiness with [him]101-sir thomas , speaking certainly without the prejudice , the blindness of love , [she]126-maria ought to be believed . [Her]126-maria feelings , probably , were not acute ; [he]101-sir thomas had never supposed them to be so ; but [her]126-maria comforts might not be less on that account ; and if [she]126-maria could dispense with seeing [[her]126-maria husband]325-her husband a leading , shining character , there would certainly be everything else in [her]126-maria favour . [A well - disposed young woman , who did not marry for love]1737-a well - disposed young woman , who did not marry for love , was in general but the more attached to [[her]1737-a well - disposed young woman , who did not marry for love own family]1438-her own family ; and the nearness of [Sotherton]27-sotherton to [Mansfield]130-mansfield must naturally hold out the greatest temptation , and would , in all probability , be a continual supply of the most amiable and innocent enjoyments . Such and such - like were the reasonings of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , happy to escape the embarrassing evils of a rupture , the wonder , the reflections , the reproach that must attend it ; happy to secure a marriage which would bring [him]101-sir thomas such an addition of respectability and influence , and very happy to think anything of [[his]101-sir thomas daughter]1739-his daughter ’s disposition that was most favourable for the purpose . To [her]126-maria the conference closed as satisfactorily as to [him]101-sir thomas . [She]126-maria was in a state of mind to be glad that [she]126-maria had secured [her]126-maria fate beyond recall : that [she]126-maria had pledged [herself]126-maria anew to [Sotherton]27-sotherton ; that [she]126-maria was safe from the possibility of giving [Crawford]127-miss crawford the triumph of governing [her]126-maria actions , and destroying [her]126-maria prospects ; and retired in proud resolve , determined only to behave more cautiously to [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny in future , that [[her]126-maria father]667-her father might not be again suspecting [her]126-maria . Had [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas applied to [[his]101-sir thomas daughter]1739-his daughter within the first three or four days after [Henry Crawford]131-henry ’s leaving [Mansfield]3-mansfield , before [her]126-maria feelings were at all tranquillised , before [she]126-maria had given up every hope of [him]131-henry , or absolutely resolved on enduring [[his]131-henry rival]1742-his rival , [her]126-maria answer might have been different ; but after another three or four days , when there was no return , no letter , no message , no symptom of a softened heart , no hope of advantage from separation , [her]126-maria mind became cool enough to seek all the comfort that pride and self revenge could give . [Henry Crawford]131-henry had destroyed [her]126-maria happiness , but [he]131-henry should not know that [he]131-henry had done it ; [he]131-henry should not destroy [her]126-maria credit , [her]126-maria appearance , [her]126-maria prosperity , too . [He]131-henry should not have to think of [her]126-maria as pining in the retirement of [Mansfield]130-mansfield for _ [him]131-henry _ , rejecting [Sotherton]27-sotherton and [London]6-london , independence and splendour , for _ [his]131-henry _ sake . Independence was more needful than ever ; the want of it at [Mansfield]3-mansfield more sensibly felt . [She]126-maria was less and less able to endure the restraint which [[her]126-maria father]667-her father imposed . The liberty which [his]131-henry absence had given was now become absolutely necessary .
