[She]126-maria must escape from [him]131-henry and [Mansfield]3-mansfield as soon as possible , and find consolation in fortune and consequence , bustle and [the world]315-the world , for a wounded spirit . [Her]126-maria mind was quite determined , and varied not . To such feelings delay , even the delay of much preparation , would have been an evil , and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny could hardly be more impatient for the marriage than [herself]126-maria . In all the important preparations of the mind [she]126-maria was complete : being prepared for matrimony by an hatred of [home]367-home , restraint , and tranquillity ; by the misery of disappointed affection , and contempt of [the man [she]126-maria was to marry]1746-the man she was to marry . The rest might wait . The preparations of [new carriages]1747-new carriages and furniture might wait for [London]6-london and spring , when [her]126-maria own taste could have fairer play . The principals being all agreed in this respect , it soon appeared that a very few weeks would be sufficient for such arrangements as must precede the wedding . [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria was quite ready to retire , and make way for [the fortunate young woman whom [[her]126-maria dear son]1749-her dear son had selected]1748-the fortunate young woman whom her dear son had selected ; and very early in November removed [herself]126-maria , [[her]126-maria maid]1750-her maid , [[her]126-maria footman]1751-her footman , and [[her]126-maria chariot]1752-her chariot , with true dowager propriety , to Bath , there to parade over the wonders of [Sotherton]27-sotherton in [her]126-maria evening parties ; enjoying them as thoroughly , perhaps , in the animation of a card - table , as [she]126-maria had ever done on the spot ; and before the middle of the same month the ceremony had taken place which gave [Sotherton]27-sotherton [another mistress]1753-another mistress . It was a very proper wedding . [The bride]1754-the bride was elegantly dressed ; [the two bridesmaids]1755-the two bridesmaids were duly inferior ; [[her]1754-the bride father]667-her father gave [her]1754-the bride away ; [[her]1754-the bride mother]446-her mother stood with salts in [her]446-her mother hand , expecting to be agitated ; [[her]1754-the bride aunt]463-her aunt tried to cry ; and the service was impressively read by [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant . Nothing could be objected to when it came under the discussion of [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood , except that the carriage which conveyed [the bride]1754-the bride and [bridegroom]1761-bridegroom and [Julia]112-julia from [the church]4265-the church - door to [Sotherton]27-sotherton was the same chaise which [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had used for a twelvemonth before . In everything else the etiquette of the day might stand the strictest investigation . It was done , and [they]1763-they were gone . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas felt as [an anxious father]1764-an anxious father must feel , and was indeed experiencing much of the agitation which [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife had been apprehensive of for [herself]546-his wife , but had fortunately escaped . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , most happy to assist in the duties of the day , by spending it at [the Park]3753-the park to support [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister ’s spirits , and drinking the health of [Mr.]1768-mr. and [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria in a supernumerary glass or two , was all joyous delight ; for [she]546-his wife had made the match ; [she]546-his wife had done everything ; and [no one]404-no one would have supposed , from [her]546-his wife confident triumph , that [she]546-his wife had ever heard of conjugal infelicity in [her]546-his wife life , or could have the smallest insight into the disposition of [the niece who had been brought up under]1770-the niece who had been brought up under [her]546-his wife eye . The plan of [the young couple]1771-the young couple was to proceed , after a few days , to [Brighton]61-brighton , and take [a house there]1772-a house there for some weeks . [Every public place]1773-every public place was new to [Maria]126-maria , and [Brighton]61-brighton is almost as gay in winter as in summer . When the novelty of amusement there was over , it would be time for [the wider range of [London]6-london]1774-the wider range of london . [Julia]112-julia was to go with [them]1771-the young couple to [Brighton]61-brighton . Since rivalry between [the sisters]327-the sisters had ceased , [they]327-the sisters had been gradually recovering much of [their]327-the sisters former good understanding ; and were at least sufficiently [friends]3751-friends to make each of [them]327-the sisters exceedingly glad to be with the other at such a time . [Some other companion than [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny]1777-some other companion than mr. rushworth was of the first consequence to [[his]113-fanny lady]1778-his lady ; and [Julia]112-julia was quite as eager for novelty and pleasure as [Maria]126-maria , though [she]112-julia might not have struggled through so much to obtain [them]327-the sisters , and could better bear a subordinate situation . [Their]1771-the young couple departure made another material change at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , a chasm which required some time to fill up . [The family circle]1779-the family circle became greatly contracted ; and though [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams had latterly added little to [its]1779-the family circle gaiety , [they]1771-the young couple could not but be missed . Even [[their]1771-the young couple mother]1249-their mother missed [them]1771-the young couple ; and how much more [[[their]1771-the young couple tenderhearted cousin]1781-their tenderhearted cousin , who wandered about [the house]427-the house , and thought of [them]1771-the young couple , and felt for [them]1771-the young couple , with a degree of affectionate regret which [they]1771-the young couple had never done much to deserve]1782-their tenderhearted cousin , who wandered about the house , and thought of them , and felt for them , with a degree of affectionate regret which they had never done much to deserve ! CHAPTER XXII [Fanny]113-fanny ’s consequence increased on the departure of [[her]1784-her cousins]3671-her cousins . Becoming , as [she]1784-her then did , [the only young woman in [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room]1786-the only young woman in the drawing - room , [the only occupier of that interesting division of [a family in which [she]1784-her had hitherto held so humble a third]1789-a family in which she had hitherto held so humble a third , it was impossible for [her]1784-her not to be more looked at , more thought of and attended to , than [she]1784-her had ever been before]1788-the only occupier of that interesting division of a family in which she had hitherto held so humble a third , it was impossible for her not to be more looked at , more thought of and attended to , than she had ever been before ; and “ Where is [Fanny]113-fanny ? ”[1784-her] became no uncommon question , even without [her]1784-her being wanted for [any one]3817-any one ’s convenience . Not only at [home]367-home did [her]1784-her value increase , but at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage too . In [that house]1793-that house , which [she]1784-her had hardly entered twice a year since [Mr. Norris]104-mr. norris ’s death , [she]1784-her became a welcome , [an invited guest , and in the gloom and dirt of a November day]1794-an invited guest , and in the gloom and dirt of a november day , most acceptable to [Mary Crawford]132-mary . [Her]1784-her visits [there]3696-there , beginning by chance , were continued by solicitation . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , really eager to get any change for [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister , could , by the easiest self - deceit , persuade [herself]123-mrs. grant that [she]123-mrs. grant was doing the kindest thing by [Fanny]113-fanny , and giving [her]123-mrs. grant the most important opportunities of improvement in pressing [her]1784-her frequent calls . [Fanny]113-fanny , having been sent into [the village]524-the village on some errand by [[her]1784-her aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris , was overtaken by a heavy shower close to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage ; and being descried from one of the windows endeavouring to find shelter under the branches and lingering leaves of an oak just beyond [[their]1800-their premises]1801-their premises , was forced , though not without some modest reluctance on [her]1784-her part , to come in . [A civil servant]1802-a civil servant [she]1784-her had withstood ; but when [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant [himself]121-dr. grant went out with an umbrella , there was nothing to be done but to be very much ashamed , and to get into [the house]427-the house as fast as possible ; and to poor [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , who had just been contemplating the dismal rain in a very desponding state of mind , sighing over the ruin of all [her]127-miss crawford plan of exercise for that morning , and of every chance of seeing a single creature beyond [themselves]1800-their for the next twenty - four hours , the sound of a little bustle at the front door , and the sight of [Miss Price]137-miss price dripping with wet in [the vestibule]1804-the vestibule , was delightful . The value of an event on a wet day in [the country]493-the country was most forcibly brought before [her]127-miss crawford . [She]1784-her was all alive again directly , and among the most active in being useful to [Fanny]113-fanny , in detecting [her]1784-her to be wetter than [she]1784-her would at first allow , and providing [her]1784-her with dry clothes ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , after being obliged to submit to all this attention , and to being assisted and waited on by [mistresses]1806-mistresses and [maids]1807-maids , being also obliged , on returning [downstairs]1808-downstairs , to be fixed in [[their]1800-their drawing - room]1809-their drawing - room for an hour while the rain continued , the blessing of something fresh to see and think of was thus extended to [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , and might carry on [her]127-miss crawford spirits to the period of dressing and dinner . [The two sisters]1810-the two sisters were so kind to [her]127-miss crawford , and so pleasant , that [Fanny]113-fanny might have enjoyed [her]127-miss crawford visit could [she]127-miss crawford have believed [herself]127-miss crawford not in the way , and could [she]127-miss crawford have foreseen that the weather would certainly clear at the end of the hour , and save [her]127-miss crawford from the shame of having [[Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant ’s carriage]1811-dr. grant ’s carriage and horses out to take [her]127-miss crawford [home]367-home , with which [she]127-miss crawford was threatened . As to anxiety for any alarm that [her]127-miss crawford absence in such weather might occasion at [home]367-home , [she]127-miss crawford had nothing to suffer on that score ; for as [her]127-miss crawford being out was known only to [[her]127-miss crawford two aunts]1814-her two aunts , [she]127-miss crawford was perfectly aware that none would be felt , and that in [whatever cottage [aunt Norris]105-mrs. norris might chuse to establish [her]127-miss crawford]1815-whatever cottage aunt norris might chuse to establish her during the rain , [her]127-miss crawford being in [such cottage]1816-such cottage would be indubitable to [aunt Bertram]112-julia . It was beginning to look brighter , when [Fanny]113-fanny , observing a harp in [the room]412-the room , asked some questions about it , which soon led to an acknowledgment of [her]127-miss crawford wishing very much to hear it , and a confession , which could hardly be believed , of [her]127-miss crawford having never yet heard it since its being in [Mansfield]3-mansfield . To [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny it appeared a very simple and natural circumstance . [She]127-miss crawford had scarcely ever been at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage since [the instrument]1819-the instrument ’s arrival , there had been no reason that [she]127-miss crawford should ; but [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , calling to mind an early expressed wish on the subject , was concerned at [her]127-miss crawford own neglect ; and “ Shall [I]127-miss crawford play to [you]113-fanny now ? ”[127-miss crawford] and “ What will [you]113-fanny have ? ”[127-miss crawford] were questions immediately following with the readiest good - humour . [She]127-miss crawford played accordingly ; happy to have [a new listener]1820-a new listener , and [a listener who seemed so much obliged , so full of wonder at the performance]1821-a listener who seemed so much obliged , so full of wonder at the performance , and who shewed [herself]127-miss crawford not wanting in taste . [She]127-miss crawford played till [Fanny]113-fanny ’s eyes , straying to the window on the weather ’s being evidently fair , spoke what [she]127-miss crawford felt must be done . “ Another quarter of an hour , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ and [we]5087-we shall see how it will be . Do not run away the first moment of its holding up . Those clouds look alarming . ”[127-miss crawford] “ But they are passed over , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny . “ [I]113-fanny have been watching them . This weather is all from [the south]5088-the south . ”[113-fanny] “ South or north , [I]127-miss crawford know a black cloud when [I]127-miss crawford see it ; and [you]113-fanny must not set forward while it is so threatening . And besides , [I]127-miss crawford want to play something more to [you]113-fanny — a very pretty piece — and [[your]113-fanny cousin]3780-your cousin [Edmund]108-edmund ’s prime favourite . [You]113-fanny must stay and hear [[your]113-fanny cousin]3780-your cousin ’s favourite . ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny felt that [she]127-miss crawford must ; and though [she]127-miss crawford had not waited for that sentence to be thinking of [Edmund]108-edmund , such a memento made [her]127-miss crawford particularly awake to [his]108-edmund idea , and [she]127-miss crawford fancied [him]108-edmund sitting in [that room]1389-that room again and again , perhaps in the very spot where [she]127-miss crawford sat now , listening with constant delight to the favourite air , played , as it appeared to [her]127-miss crawford , with superior tone and expression ; and though pleased with it [herself]127-miss crawford , and glad to like whatever was liked by [him]108-edmund , [she]127-miss crawford was more sincerely impatient to go away at the conclusion of it than [she]127-miss crawford had been before ; and on this being evident , [she]127-miss crawford was so kindly asked to call again , to take [them]1823-them in [her]127-miss crawford walk whenever [she]127-miss crawford could , to come and hear more of the harp , that [she]127-miss crawford felt it necessary to be done , if no objection arose at [home]367-home . Such was the origin of the sort of intimacy which took place between [them]1825-they within the first fortnight after [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams ’ going away — an intimacy resulting principally from [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s desire of something new , and which had little reality in [Fanny]113-fanny ’s feelings . [Fanny]113-fanny went to [her]127-miss crawford every two or three days : it seemed a kind of fascination : [she]127-miss crawford could not be easy without going , and yet it was without loving [her]127-miss crawford , without ever thinking like [her]127-miss crawford , without any sense of obligation for being sought after now when [nobody else]4733-nobody else was to be had ; and deriving no higher pleasure from [her]127-miss crawford conversation than occasional amusement , and _ that _ often at the expense of [her]127-miss crawford judgment , when it was raised by pleasantry on [people]3906-people or subjects which [she]127-miss crawford wished to be respected . [She]127-miss crawford went , however , and [they]1825-they sauntered about together many an half - hour in [[Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s shrubbery]1828-mrs. grant ’s shrubbery , the weather being unusually mild for the time of year , and venturing sometimes even to sit down on one of the benches now comparatively unsheltered , remaining there perhaps till , in the midst of some tender ejaculation of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s on the sweets of so protracted an autumn , [they]1825-they were forced , by the sudden swell of a cold gust shaking down the last few yellow leaves about [them]1825-they , to jump up and walk for warmth . “ This is pretty , very pretty , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , looking around [her]127-miss crawford as [they]1825-they were thus sitting together one day ; “ every time [I]127-miss crawford come into [this shrubbery]5091-this shrubbery [I]127-miss crawford am more struck with its growth and beauty . Three years ago , this was nothing but a rough hedgerow along [the upper side of [the field]882-the field]5092-the upper side of the field , never thought of as anything , or capable of becoming anything ; and now it is converted into a walk , and it would be difficult to say whether most valuable as a convenience or an ornament ; and perhaps , in another three years , [we]1825-they may be forgetting — almost forgetting what it was before . How wonderful , how very wonderful the operations of time , and the changes of the human mind ! ”[127-miss crawford] And following the latter train of thought , [she]127-miss crawford soon afterwards added : “ If any one faculty of [our]1825-they nature may be called _ more _ wonderful than the rest , [I]127-miss crawford do think it is memory . There seems something more speakingly incomprehensible in the powers , the failures , the inequalities of memory , than in any other of [our]1825-they intelligences . The memory is sometimes so retentive , so serviceable , so obedient ; at [others]361-others , so bewildered and so weak ; and at [others]361-others again , so tyrannic , so beyond control ! [We]1825-they are , to be sure , a miracle every way ; but [our]1825-they powers of recollecting and of forgetting do seem peculiarly past finding out . ”[127-miss crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , untouched and inattentive , had nothing to say ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , perceiving it , brought back [her]127-miss crawford own mind to what [she]127-miss crawford thought must interest . “ It may seem impertinent in _ [me]113-fanny _ to praise , but [I]113-fanny must admire the taste [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant has shewn in all this . There is such a quiet simplicity in the plan of the walk ! Not too much attempted ! ”[113-fanny] “ Yes , ”[127-miss crawford] replied [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford carelessly , “ it does very well for [a place of this sort]5096-a place of this sort . [One]766-one does not think of extent _ here _ ; and between [ourselves]1825-they , till [I]127-miss crawford came to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [I]127-miss crawford had not imagined [a country parson]5098-a country parson ever aspired to a shrubbery , or anything of the kind . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]113-fanny am so glad to see the evergreens thrive ! ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , in reply . “ [[My]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle ’s gardener always says the soil here is better than [his]3761-my uncle own , and so it appears from the growth of the laurels and evergreens in general . The evergreen ! How beautiful , how welcome , how wonderful the evergreen ! When one thinks of it , how astonishing a variety of nature ! In [some countries]5100-some countries [we]1825-they know the tree that sheds its leaf is the variety , but that does not make it less amazing that the same soil and the same sun should nurture plants differing in the first rule and law of [their]5100-some countries existence . [You]5101-you will think [me]113-fanny rhapsodising ; but when [I]113-fanny am out of doors , especially when [I]113-fanny am sitting out of doors , [I]113-fanny am very apt to get into this sort of wondering strain . One can not fix [one]766-one ’s eyes on the commonest natural production without finding food for a rambling fancy . ”[113-fanny] “ To say the truth , ”[127-miss crawford] replied [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ [I]127-miss crawford am something like the famous Doge at [the court of [Lewis XIV]62-lewis xiv]5103-the court of lewis xiv . ; and may declare that [I]127-miss crawford see no wonder in this shrubbery equal to seeing [myself]127-miss crawford in it . If [anybody]3668-anybody had told [me]127-miss crawford a year ago that [this place]5105-this place would be [[my]127-miss crawford home]5106-my home , that [I]127-miss crawford should be spending month after month here , as [I]127-miss crawford have done , [I]127-miss crawford certainly should not have believed [them]3668-anybody . [I]127-miss crawford have now been [here]3798-here nearly five months ; and , moreover , the quietest five months [I]127-miss crawford ever passed . ”[127-miss crawford] “ _ Too _ quiet for [you]127-miss crawford , [I]113-fanny believe . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]1829-i should have thought so _ theoretically _ [myself]1829-i , but , ”[1829-i] and [her]1829-i eyes brightened as [she]1829-i spoke , “ take it all and all , [I]1829-i never spent so happy a summer . But then , ”[1829-i] with a more thoughtful air and lowered voice , “ there is no saying what it may lead to . ”[1829-i] [Fanny]113-fanny ’s heart beat quick , and [she]1829-i felt quite unequal to surmising or soliciting anything more . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , however , with renewed animation , soon went on — “ [I]127-miss crawford am conscious of being far better reconciled to [a country residence]5108-a country residence than [I]127-miss crawford had ever expected to be . [I]127-miss crawford can even suppose it pleasant to spend _ half _ the year in [the country]493-the country , under certain circumstances , very pleasant . [An elegant , moderate - sized house in the centre of family connexions]5110-an elegant , moderate - sized house in the centre of family connexions ; continual engagements among [them]3668-anybody ; commanding [the first society in [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood]5111-the first society in the neighbourhood ; looked up to , perhaps , as leading [it]5113-it even more than those of larger fortune , and turning from the cheerful round of such amusements to nothing worse than a _ tête - à - tête _ with [the person one]5114-the person one feels most agreeable in [the world]315-the world . There is nothing frightful in such a picture , is there , [Miss Price]137-miss price ? [One]766-one need not envy the new [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria with such [a home]5117-a home as _ that _ . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Envy [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ! ”[127-miss crawford] was all that [Fanny]113-fanny attempted to say . “ Come , come , it would be very un - handsome in [us]5118-us to be severe on [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , for [I]113-fanny look forward to [our]5118-us owing [her]126-maria a great many gay , brilliant , happy hours . [I]113-fanny expect [we]5118-us shall be all very much at [Sotherton]27-sotherton another year . [I]123-mrs. grant am so glad [[your]123-mrs. grant eldest cousin]5123-your eldest cousin is gone , that [he]5123-your eldest cousin may be [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund again . There is something in the sound of [Mr. _ Edmund _ Bertram]108-edmund so formal , so pitiful , so younger - brother - like , that [I]123-mrs. grant detest it . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ How differently [we]1830-them feel ! ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny . “ To [me]113-fanny , the sound of [_ Mr. _ Bertram]108-edmund is so cold and nothing - meaning , so entirely without warmth or character ! It just stands for [a gentleman]4549-a gentleman , and that ’s all . But there is nobleness in the name of [Edmund]108-edmund . It is a name of heroism and renown ; of [kings]5125-kings , [princes]5126-princes , and [knights]5127-knights ; and seems to breathe the spirit of chivalry and warm affections . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]108-edmund grant [you]123-mrs. grant the name is good in itself , and _ [Lord _ Edmund]222-lord _ edmund or [_ Sir _ Edmund]101-sir thomas sound delightfully ; but sink it under the chill , the annihilation of [a Mr.]696-a mr. , and [Mr. Edmund]108-edmund is no more than [Mr. John]223-mr. john or [Mr. Thomas]224-mr. thomas . Well , shall [we]5129-we join and disappoint [them]1831-you of half [their]1831-you lecture upon sitting down out of doors at this time of year , by being up before [they]1831-you can begin ? ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund met [them]1831-you with particular pleasure . It was the first time of [his]108-edmund seeing [them]1831-you together since the beginning of that better acquaintance which [he]108-edmund had been hearing of with great satisfaction . A friendship between two so very dear to [him]108-edmund was exactly what [he]108-edmund could have wished : and to the credit of [the lover]1832-the lover ’s understanding , be it stated , that [he]108-edmund did not by any means consider [Fanny]113-fanny as the only , or even as [the greater gainer by such a friendship]1833-the greater gainer by such a friendship . “ Well , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ and do [you]108-edmund not scold [us]5129-we for [our]5129-we imprudence ? What do [you]108-edmund think [we]5129-we have been sitting down for but to be talked to about it , and entreated and supplicated never to do so again ? ”[127-miss crawford] “ Perhaps [I]108-edmund might have scolded , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ if either of [you]1831-you had been sitting down alone ; but while [you]1831-you do wrong together , [I]108-edmund can overlook a great deal . ”[108-edmund] “ [They]1831-you can not have been sitting long , ”[123-mrs. grant] cried [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , “ for when [I]123-mrs. grant went up for [my]123-mrs. grant shawl [I]123-mrs. grant saw [them]1831-you from the staircase window , and then [they]1831-you were walking . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ And really , ”[108-edmund] added [Edmund]108-edmund , “ the day is so mild , that [your]1831-you sitting down for a few minutes can be hardly thought imprudent . [Our]5129-we weather must not always be judged by the calendar . [We]5129-we may sometimes take greater liberties in November than in May . ”[108-edmund] “ Upon [my]127-miss crawford word , ”[127-miss crawford] cried [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , “ [you]108-edmund are [two of the most disappointing and unfeeling kind friends [I]127-miss crawford ever met with]5130-two of the most disappointing and unfeeling kind friends i ever met with ! There is no giving [you]108-edmund a moment ’s uneasiness . [You]108-edmund do not know how much [we]5129-we have been suffering , nor what chills [we]5129-we have felt ! But [I]127-miss crawford have long thought [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund one of the worst subjects to work on , in any little manoeuvre against common sense , that [a woman]644-a woman could be plagued with . [I]127-miss crawford had very little hope of _ [him]108-edmund _ from the first ; but [you]1831-you , [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , [[my]127-miss crawford sister]3790-my sister , [[my]127-miss crawford own sister]5133-my own sister , [I]127-miss crawford think [I]127-miss crawford had a right to alarm [you]1831-you a little . ”[127-miss crawford] “ Do not flatter [yourself]1831-you , [[my]108-edmund dearest]5134-my dearest [Mary]132-mary . [You]1831-you have not the smallest chance of moving [me]108-edmund . [I]108-edmund have [my]108-edmund alarms , but they are quite in a different quarter ; and if [I]108-edmund could have altered the weather , [you]1831-you would have had a good sharp east wind blowing on [you]1831-you the whole time — for here are some of [my]108-edmund plants which [Robert]108-edmund _ will _ leave out because the nights are so mild , and [I]108-edmund know the end of it will be , that [we]5135-we shall have a sudden change of weather , a hard frost setting in all at once , taking [everybody]408-everybody ( at least [Robert]108-edmund ) by surprise , and [I]108-edmund shall lose every one ; and what is worse , [cook]5137-cook has just been telling [me]108-edmund that the turkey , which [I]108-edmund particularly wished not to be dressed till Sunday , because [I]108-edmund know how much more [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant would enjoy it on Sunday after the fatigues of the day , will not keep beyond to - morrow . These are something like grievances , and make [me]108-edmund think the weather most unseasonably close . ”[108-edmund] “ The sweets of housekeeping in [a country village]5138-a country village ! ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford archly . “ Commend [me]127-miss crawford to [the nurseryman]5139-the nurseryman and [the poulterer]5140-the poulterer . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [[My]108-edmund dear child]3930-my dear child , commend [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant to [the deanery of [Westminster]32-westminster or [St. Paul ’s]63-st. paul ’s]5142-the deanery of westminster or st. paul ’s , and [I]108-edmund should be as glad of [[your]3930-my dear child nurseryman]5143-your nurseryman and poulterer as [you]3930-my dear child could be . But [we]5144-we have [no such people]5145-no such people in [Mansfield]3-mansfield . What would [you]3930-my dear child have [me]108-edmund do ? ”[108-edmund] “ Oh ! [you]3930-my dear child can do nothing but what [you]3930-my dear child do already : be plagued very often , and never lose [your]3930-my dear child temper . ”[108-edmund] “ Thank [you]3930-my dear child ; but there is no escaping these little vexations , [Mary]132-mary , live where [we]5144-we may ; and when [you]3930-my dear child are settled in [town]3698-town and [I]127-miss crawford come to see [you]3930-my dear child , [I]127-miss crawford dare say [I]127-miss crawford shall find [you]3930-my dear child with [yours]3930-my dear child , in spite of [the nurseryman]5139-the nurseryman and the poulterer , perhaps on [their]5148-their very account . [Their]5148-their remoteness and unpunctuality , or [their]5148-their exorbitant charges and frauds , will be drawing forth bitter lamentations . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [I]108-edmund mean to be too rich to lament or to feel anything of the sort . A large income is the best recipe for happiness [I]108-edmund ever heard of . It certainly may secure all the myrtle and turkey part of it . ”[108-edmund] “ [You]108-edmund intend to be very rich ? ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , with a look which , to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s eye , had a great deal of serious meaning . “ To be sure . Do not [you]108-edmund ? Do not [we]5144-we all ? ”[108-edmund] “ [I]108-edmund can not intend anything which it must be so completely beyond [my]108-edmund power to command . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford may chuse [her]127-miss crawford degree of wealth . [She]127-miss crawford has only to fix on [her]127-miss crawford number of thousands a year , and there can be no doubt of [their]5148-their coming . [My]108-edmund intentions are only not to be poor . ”[108-edmund] “ By moderation and economy , and bringing down [your]3930-my dear child wants to [your]3930-my dear child income , and all that . [I]108-edmund understand [you]3930-my dear child — and a very proper plan it is for [a person]5149-a person at [your]3930-my dear child time of life , with such limited means and indifferent connexions . What can _ [you]3930-my dear child _ want but a decent maintenance ? [You]3930-my dear child have not much time before [you]3930-my dear child ; and [[your]3930-my dear child relations]5150-your relations are in no situation to do anything for [you]3930-my dear child , or to mortify [you]3930-my dear child by the contrast of [their]5150-your relations own wealth and consequence . Be honest and poor , by all means — but [I]108-edmund shall not envy [you]3930-my dear child ; [I]108-edmund do not much think [I]108-edmund shall even respect [you]3930-my dear child . [I]108-edmund have a much greater respect for those that are honest and rich . ”[108-edmund] “ [Your]3930-my dear child degree of respect for honesty , rich or poor , is precisely what [I]108-edmund have no manner of concern with . [I]108-edmund do not mean to be poor . Poverty is exactly what [I]108-edmund have determined against . Honesty , in the something between , in the middle state of worldly circumstances , is all that [I]108-edmund am anxious for [your]3930-my dear child not looking down on . ”[108-edmund] “ But [I]108-edmund do look down upon it , if it might have been higher . [I]108-edmund must look down upon anything contented with obscurity when it might rise to distinction . ”[108-edmund] “ But how may it rise ? How may [my]108-edmund honesty at least rise to any distinction ? ”[108-edmund] This was not so very easy a question to answer , and occasioned an “ Oh ! ”[108-edmund] of some length from [the fair lady]1834-the fair lady before [she]1834-the fair lady could add , “ [You]3930-my dear child ought to be in [parliament]5151-parliament , or [you]3930-my dear child should have gone into [the army]4508-the army ten years ago . ”[1834-the fair lady] “ _ That _ is not much to the purpose now ; and as to [my]1835-i being in [parliament]5151-parliament , [I]1835-i believe [I]1835-i must wait till there is an especial assembly for the representation of [younger sons who have little to live on]5154-younger sons who have little to live on . No , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , ”[1835-i] [he]1835-i added , in a more serious tone , “ there _ are _ distinctions which [I]1835-i should be miserable if [I]1835-i thought [myself]1835-i without any chance — absolutely without chance or possibility of obtaining — but they are of a different character . ”[1835-i] A look of consciousness as [he]1835-i spoke , and what seemed a consciousness of manner on [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s side as [she]127-miss crawford made some laughing answer , was sorrowfull food for [Fanny]113-fanny ’s observation ; and finding [herself]113-fanny quite unable to attend as [she]127-miss crawford ought to [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , by whose side [she]127-miss crawford was now following [the others]347-the others , [she]127-miss crawford had nearly resolved on going [home]367-home immediately , and only waited for courage to say so , when the sound of the great clock at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , striking three , made [her]127-miss crawford feel that [she]127-miss crawford had really been much longer absent than usual , and brought the previous self - inquiry of whether [she]127-miss crawford should take leave or not just then , and how , to a very speedy issue . With undoubting decision [she]127-miss crawford directly began [her]127-miss crawford adieus ; and [Edmund]108-edmund began at the same time to recollect that [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother had been inquiring for [her]629-his mother , and that [he]108-edmund had walked down to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage on purpose to bring [her]629-his mother back . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s hurry increased ; and without in the least expecting [Edmund]108-edmund ’s attendance , [she]127-miss crawford would have hastened away alone ; but the general pace was quickened , and [they]1840-they all accompanied [her]127-miss crawford into [the house]427-the house , through which it was necessary to pass . [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant was in [the vestibule]1804-the vestibule , and as [they]1840-they stopt to speak to [him]108-edmund [she]127-miss crawford found , from [Edmund]108-edmund ’s manner , that [he]108-edmund _ did _ mean to go with [her]127-miss crawford . [He]108-edmund too was taking leave . [She]127-miss crawford could not but be thankful . In the moment of parting , [Edmund]108-edmund was invited by [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant to eat [his]108-edmund mutton with [him]108-edmund the next day ; and [Fanny]113-fanny had barely time for an unpleasant feeling on the occasion , when [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , with sudden recollection , turned to [her]127-miss crawford and asked for the pleasure of [her]127-miss crawford company too . This was so new an attention , so perfectly new a circumstance in the events of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s life , that [she]127-miss crawford was all surprise and embarrassment ; and while stammering out [her]127-miss crawford great obligation , and [her]127-miss crawford “ but [she]127-miss crawford did not suppose it would be in [her]127-miss crawford power , ”[127-miss crawford] was looking at [Edmund]108-edmund for [his]108-edmund opinion and help . But [Edmund]108-edmund , delighted with [her]127-miss crawford having such an happiness offered , and ascertaining with half a look , and half a sentence , that [she]127-miss crawford had no objection but on [[her]127-miss crawford aunt]463-her aunt ’s account , could not imagine that [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother would make any difficulty of sparing [her]127-miss crawford , and therefore gave [his]108-edmund decided open advice that the invitation should be accepted ; and though [Fanny]113-fanny would not venture , even on [his]108-edmund encouragement , to such a flight of audacious independence , it was soon settled , that if nothing were heard to the contrary , [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant might expect [her]127-miss crawford . “ And [you]108-edmund know what [your]108-edmund dinner will be , ”[123-mrs. grant] said [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , smiling—“the turkey , and [I]123-mrs. grant assure [you]108-edmund a very fine one ; for , [[my]123-mrs. grant dear]3657-my dear , ”[123-mrs. grant] turning to [[her]123-mrs. grant husband]325-her husband , “ [cook]5137-cook insists upon the turkey ’s being dressed to - morrow . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ Very well , very well , ”[121-dr. grant] cried [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , “ all the better ; [I]121-dr. grant am glad to hear [you]108-edmund have anything so good in [the house]427-the house . But [Miss Price]137-miss price and [Mr. Edmund Bertram]108-edmund , [I]121-dr. grant dare say , would take [their]1846-the two cousins chance . [We]1846-the two cousins none of [us]1846-the two cousins want to hear the bill of fare . A friendly meeting , and not a fine dinner , is all [we]1846-the two cousins have in view . A turkey , or a goose , or a leg of mutton , or whatever [you]108-edmund and [[your]108-edmund cook]5158-your cook chuse to give [us]1846-the two cousins . ”[121-dr. grant] [The two cousins]1846-the two cousins walked [home]367-home together ; and , except in the immediate discussion of this engagement , which [Edmund]108-edmund spoke of with the warmest satisfaction , as so particularly desirable for [her]1848-her in the intimacy which [he]108-edmund saw with so much pleasure established , it was a silent walk ; for having finished that subject , [he]108-edmund grew thoughtful and indisposed for any other . CHAPTER XXIII “ But why should [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ask [Fanny]113-fanny ? ”[106-lady bertram] said [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram . “ How came [she]123-mrs. grant to think of asking [Fanny]113-fanny ? [Fanny]113-fanny never dines [there]3696-there , [you]108-edmund know , in this sort of way . [I]106-lady bertram can not spare [her]1848-her , and [I]106-lady bertram am sure [she]1848-her does not want to go . [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny do not want to go , do [you]113-fanny ? ”[106-lady bertram] “ If [you]453-his cousin put such a question to [her]1848-her , ”[108-edmund] cried [Edmund]108-edmund , preventing [[his]108-edmund cousin]453-his cousin ’s speaking , “ [Fanny]113-fanny will immediately say No ; but [I]108-edmund am sure , [[my]108-edmund dear mother]4677-my dear mother , [she]1848-her would like to go ; and [I]108-edmund can see no reason why [she]1848-her should not . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]106-lady bertram can not imagine why [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant should think of asking [her]1848-her ? [She]123-mrs. grant never did before . [She]123-mrs. grant used to ask [[your]113-fanny sisters]4713-your sisters now and then , but [she]123-mrs. grant never asked [Fanny]113-fanny . ”[106-lady bertram] “ If [you]108-edmund can not do without [me]113-fanny , [ma’am]4007-ma’am — ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , in a self - denying tone . “ But [[my]113-fanny mother]3827-my mother will have [[my]113-fanny father]3762-my father with [her]3827-my mother all the evening . ”[113-fanny] “ To be sure , so [I]108-edmund shall . ”[108-edmund] “ Suppose [you]108-edmund take [[my]108-edmund father]3762-my father ’s opinion , [ma’am]4007-ma’am . ”[108-edmund] “ That ’s well thought of . So [I]108-edmund will , [Edmund]108-edmund . [I]108-edmund will ask [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , as soon as [he]101-sir thomas comes in , whether [I]108-edmund can do without [her]3827-my mother . ”[108-edmund] “ As [you]108-edmund please , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , on that head ; but [I]108-edmund meant [[my]108-edmund father]3762-my father ’s opinion as to the _ propriety _ of the invitation ’s being accepted or not ; and [I]108-edmund think [he]101-sir thomas will consider it a right thing by [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , as well as by [Fanny]113-fanny , that being the _ first _ invitation it should be accepted . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]108-edmund do not know . [We]5169-we will ask [him]101-sir thomas . But [he]101-sir thomas will be very much surprised that [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant should ask [Fanny]113-fanny at all . ”[108-edmund] There was nothing more to be said , or that could be said to any purpose , till [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas were present ; but the subject involving , as it did , [her]1850-her own evening ’s comfort for the morrow , was so much uppermost in [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s mind , that half an hour afterwards , on [his]101-sir thomas looking in for a minute in [his]101-sir thomas way from [[his]101-sir thomas plantation]1851-his plantation to [[his]101-sir thomas dressing - room]1852-his dressing - room , [she]1850-her called [him]101-sir thomas back again , when [he]101-sir thomas had almost closed the door , with “ [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , stop a moment — [I]1850-her have something to say to [you]101-sir thomas . ”[1850-her] [Her]1850-her tone of calm languor , for [she]1850-her never took the trouble of raising [her]1850-her voice , was always heard and attended to ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas came back . [Her]1850-her story began ; and [Fanny]113-fanny immediately slipped out of [the room]412-the room ; for to hear [herself]113-fanny the subject of any discussion with [[her]1850-her uncle]312-her uncle was more than [her]1850-her nerves could bear . [She]1850-her was anxious , [she]1850-her knew — more anxious perhaps than [she]1850-her ought to be — for what was it after all whether [she]1850-her went or staid ? but if [[her]1850-her uncle]312-her uncle were to be a great while considering and deciding , and with very grave looks , and those grave looks directed to [her]1850-her , and at last decide against [her]1850-her , [she]1850-her might not be able to appear properly submissive and indifferent . [Her]1850-her cause , meanwhile , went on well . It began , on [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s part , with—“I have something to tell [you]5170-you that will surprise [you]5170-you . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant has asked [Fanny]113-fanny to dinner . ”[106-lady bertram] “ Well , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , as if waiting more to accomplish the surprise . “ [Edmund]108-edmund wants [her]1850-her to go . But how can [I]101-sir thomas spare [her]1850-her ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ [She]1850-her will be late , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , taking out [his]101-sir thomas watch ; “ but what is [your]108-edmund difficulty ? ”[101-sir thomas] [Edmund]108-edmund found [himself]108-edmund obliged to speak and fill up the blanks in [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother ’s story . [He]108-edmund told the whole ; and [she]629-his mother had only to add , “ So strange ! for [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant never used to ask [her]1850-her . ”[629-his mother] “ But is it not very natural , ”[108-edmund] observed [Edmund]108-edmund , “ that [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant should wish to procure so agreeable a visitor for [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister ? ”[108-edmund] “ Nothing can be more natural , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , after a short deliberation ; “ nor , were there [no sister in the case]5172-no sister in the case , could anything , in [my]101-sir thomas opinion , be more natural . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s shewing civility to [Miss Price]137-miss price , to [[Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s niece]5173-lady bertram ’s niece , could never want explanation . The only surprise [I]101-sir thomas can feel is , that this should be the _ first _ time of its being paid . [Fanny]113-fanny was perfectly right in giving only a conditional answer . [She]629-his mother appears to feel as [she]629-his mother ought . But as [I]101-sir thomas conclude that [she]629-his mother must wish to go , since [all young people]5174-all young people like to be together , [I]101-sir thomas can see no reason why [she]629-his mother should be denied the indulgence . ”[101-sir thomas] “ But can [I]108-edmund do without [her]629-his mother , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ? ”[108-edmund] “ Indeed [I]101-sir thomas think [you]108-edmund may . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [She]629-his mother always makes tea , [you]108-edmund know , when [[my]101-sir thomas sister]3790-my sister is not [here]3798-here . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [[Your]108-edmund sister]4444-your sister , perhaps , may be prevailed on to spend the day with [us]5178-us , and [I]108-edmund shall certainly be at [home]367-home . ”[108-edmund] “ Very well , then , [Fanny]113-fanny may go , [Edmund]108-edmund . ”[101-sir thomas] The good news soon followed [her]1857-she . [Edmund]108-edmund knocked at [her]1857-she door in [his]108-edmund way to [his]108-edmund own . “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , it is all happily settled , and without the smallest hesitation on [[your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle ’s side . [He]3760-your uncle had but one opinion . [You]113-fanny are to go . ”[108-edmund] “ Thank [you]108-edmund , [I]108-edmund am _ so _ glad , ”[108-edmund] was [Fanny]113-fanny ’s instinctive reply ; though when [she]1857-she had turned from [him]108-edmund and shut the door , [she]1857-she could not help feeling , “ And yet why should [I]1857-she be glad ? for am [I]1857-she not certain of seeing or hearing something there to pain [me]1857-she ? ”[1857-she] In spite of this conviction , however , [she]1857-she was glad . Simple as such an engagement might appear in other eyes , it had novelty and importance in [hers]1857-she , for excepting the day at [Sotherton]27-sotherton , [she]1857-she had scarcely ever dined out before ; and though now going only half a mile , and only to [three people]1858-three people , still it was dining out , and all the little interests of preparation were enjoyments in [themselves]1858-three people . [She]1857-she had neither sympathy nor assistance from [those who ought to have entered into]1859-those who ought to have entered into [her]1857-she feelings and directed [her]1857-she taste ; for [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram never thought of being useful to [anybody]3668-anybody , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , when [she]105-mrs. norris came on the morrow , in consequence of an early call and invitation from [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , was in a very ill humour , and seemed intent only on lessening [[her]105-mrs. norris niece]642-her niece ’s pleasure , both present and future , as much as possible . “ Upon [my]105-mrs. norris word , [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny are in high luck to meet with such attention and indulgence ! [You]113-fanny ought to be very much obliged to [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant for thinking of [you]113-fanny , and to [[your]113-fanny aunt]3826-your aunt for letting [you]113-fanny go , and [you]113-fanny ought to look upon it as something extraordinary ; for [I]105-mrs. norris hope [you]113-fanny are aware that there is no real occasion for [your]113-fanny going into company in this sort of way , or ever dining out at all ; and it is what [you]113-fanny must not depend upon ever being repeated . Nor must [you]113-fanny be fancying that the invitation is meant as any particular compliment to _ [you]113-fanny _ ; the compliment is intended to [[your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle and [aunt]3769-aunt and [me]105-mrs. norris . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant thinks it a civility due to _ [us]5184-us _ to take a little notice of [you]113-fanny , or else it would never have come into [her]123-mrs. grant head , and [you]113-fanny may be very certain that , if [[your]113-fanny cousin]3780-your cousin [Julia]112-julia had been at [home]367-home , [you]113-fanny would not have been asked at all . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had now so ingeniously done away all [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s part of the favour , that [Fanny]113-fanny , who found [herself]113-fanny expected to speak , could only say that [she]1862-her was very much obliged to [[her]1862-her aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]106-lady bertram for sparing [her]1862-her , and that [she]1862-her was endeavouring to put [[her]1862-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s evening work in such a state as to prevent [her]1862-her being missed . “ Oh ! depend upon it , [[your]113-fanny aunt]3826-your aunt can do very well without [you]113-fanny , or [you]113-fanny would not be allowed to go . _ [I]105-mrs. norris _ shall be [here]3798-here , so [you]113-fanny may be quite easy about [[your]113-fanny aunt]3826-your aunt . And [I]105-mrs. norris hope [you]113-fanny will have a very _ agreeable _ day , and find it all mighty _ delightful _ . But [I]105-mrs. norris must observe that five is the very awkwardest of all possible numbers to sit down to table ; and [I]105-mrs. norris can not but be surprised that [such an _ elegant _ lady as [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant]5190-such an _ elegant _ lady as mrs. grant should not contrive better ! And round [their]5190-such an _ elegant _ lady as mrs. grant enormous great wide table , too , which fills up [the room]412-the room so dreadfully ! Had [the doctor]572-the doctor been contented to take [my]105-mrs. norris dining - table when [I]105-mrs. norris came away , as anybody in [their]5190-such an _ elegant _ lady as mrs. grant senses would have done , instead of having that absurd new one of [his]572-the doctor own , which is wider , literally wider than the dinner - table here , how infinitely better it would have been ! and how much more [he]572-the doctor would have been respected ! for [people]3906-people are never respected when [they]3906-people step out of [their]3906-people proper sphere . Remember that , [Fanny]113-fanny . Five — only five to be sitting round that table . However , [you]113-fanny will have dinner enough on it for ten , [I]105-mrs. norris dare say . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris fetched breath , and went on again . “ The nonsense and folly of [people]3906-people ’s stepping out of [their]3906-people rank and trying to appear above [themselves]3906-people , makes [me]105-mrs. norris think it right to give _ [you]113-fanny _ a hint , [Fanny]113-fanny , now that [you]113-fanny are going into company without any of [us]5195-us ; and [I]105-mrs. norris do beseech and entreat [you]113-fanny not to be putting [yourself]113-fanny forward , and talking and giving [your]113-fanny opinion as if [you]113-fanny were [one of [[your]113-fanny cousins]4848-your cousins]5196-one of your cousins — as if [you]113-fanny were dear [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria or [Julia]112-julia . _ That _ will never do , believe [me]105-mrs. norris . Remember , wherever [you]113-fanny are , [you]113-fanny must be the lowest and last ; and though [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford is in a manner at [home]367-home at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , [you]113-fanny are not to be taking place of [her]127-miss crawford . And as to coming away at night , [you]113-fanny are to stay just as long as [Edmund chuses]108-edmund . Leave [him]108-edmund to settle _ that _ . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Yes , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , [I]105-mrs. norris should not think of anything else . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ And if it should rain , which [I]1865-i think exceedingly likely , for [I]1865-i never saw it more threatening for a wet evening in [my]1865-i life , [you]113-fanny must manage as well as [you]113-fanny can , and not be expecting [the carriage]969-the carriage to be sent for [you]113-fanny . [I]1865-i certainly do not go [home]367-home to - night , and , therefore , [the carriage]969-the carriage will not be out on [my]1865-i account ; so [you]113-fanny must make up [your]113-fanny mind to what may happen , and take [your]113-fanny things accordingly . ”[1865-i] [[Her]1865-i niece]642-her niece thought it perfectly reasonable . [She]642-her niece rated [her]642-her niece own claims to comfort as low even as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could ; and when [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas soon afterwards , just opening the door , said , “ [Fanny]113-fanny , at what time would [you]113-fanny have [the carriage]969-the carriage come round ? ”[101-sir thomas] [she]642-her niece felt a degree of astonishment which made it impossible for [her]642-her niece to speak . “ [[My]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ! ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , red with anger , “ [Fanny]113-fanny can walk . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ Walk ! ”[101-sir thomas] repeated [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , in a tone of most unanswerable dignity , and coming farther into [the room]412-the room . “ [[My]101-sir thomas niece]5206-my niece walk to a dinner engagement at this time of the year ! Will twenty minutes after four suit [you]113-fanny ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ Yes , [sir]4023-sir , ”[113-fanny] was [Fanny]113-fanny ’s humble answer , given with the feelings almost of [a criminal]1868-a criminal towards [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ; and not bearing to remain with [her]642-her niece in what might seem a state of triumph , [she]642-her niece followed [[her]642-her niece uncle]312-her uncle out of [the room]412-the room , having staid behind [him]312-her uncle only long enough to hear these words spoken in angry agitation — “ Quite unnecessary ! a great deal too kind ! But [Edmund]108-edmund goes ; true , it is upon [Edmund]108-edmund ’s account . [I]312-her uncle observed [he]108-edmund was hoarse on Thursday night . ”[312-her uncle] But this could not impose on [Fanny]113-fanny . [She]642-her niece felt that [the carriage]969-the carriage was for [herself]642-her niece , and [herself]642-her niece alone : and [[her]642-her niece uncle]312-her uncle ’s consideration of [her]642-her niece , coming immediately after such representations from [[her]642-her niece aunt]463-her aunt , cost [her]642-her niece some tears of gratitude when [she]642-her niece was alone . [The coachman]1668-the coachman drove round to a minute ; another minute brought down [the gentleman]671-the gentleman ; and as [the lady]718-the lady had , with a most scrupulous fear of being late , been many minutes seated in [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas saw [them]1878-them off in as good time as [his]101-sir thomas own correctly punctual habits required . “ Now [I]108-edmund must look at [you]642-her niece , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , with the kind smile of [an affectionate brother]1879-an affectionate brother , “ and tell [you]642-her niece how [I]108-edmund like [you]642-her niece ; and as well as [I]108-edmund can judge by this light , [you]642-her niece look very nicely indeed . What have [you]642-her niece got on ? ”[108-edmund] “ The new dress that [[my]1879-an affectionate brother uncle]3761-my uncle was so good as to give [me]1879-an affectionate brother on [[my]1879-an affectionate brother cousin]3764-my cousin ’s marriage . [I]1879-an affectionate brother hope it is not too fine ; but [I]1879-an affectionate brother thought [I]1879-an affectionate brother ought to wear it as soon as [I]1879-an affectionate brother could , and that [I]1879-an affectionate brother might not have such another opportunity all the winter . [I]1879-an affectionate brother hope [you]642-her niece do not think [me]1879-an affectionate brother too fine . ”[1879-an affectionate brother] “ [A woman]644-a woman can never be too fine while [she]644-a woman is all in white . No , [I]108-edmund see no finery about [you]642-her niece ; nothing but what is perfectly proper . [Your]642-her niece gown seems very pretty . [I]108-edmund like these glossy spots . Has not [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford a gown something the same ? ”[108-edmund] In approaching [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage [they]1881-they passed close by [the stable - yard]1882-the stable - yard and [coach - house]1883-coach - house . “ Heyday ! ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ here ’s company , here ’s [a carriage]5211-a carriage ! who have [they]1881-they got to meet [us]1881-they ? ”[108-edmund] And letting down the side - glass to distinguish , “ ’ Tis [Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s , [[Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s barouche]127-miss crawford , [I]108-edmund protest ! There are [[his]108-edmund own two men]5212-his own two men pushing [it]127-miss crawford back into [its old quarters]5213-its old quarters . [He]108-edmund is here , of course . This is quite a surprise , [Fanny]113-fanny . [I]108-edmund shall be very glad to see [him]108-edmund . ”[108-edmund] There was no occasion , there was no time for [Fanny]113-fanny to say how very differently [she]1884-her felt ; but the idea of having such another to observe [her]1884-her was a great increase of the trepidation with which [she]1884-her performed the very awful ceremony of walking into [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room . In [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford certainly was , having been just long enough arrived to be ready for dinner ; and the smiles and pleased looks of [the three others standing round [him]133-mr. crawford]1887-the three others standing round him , [shewed]1888-shewed how welcome was [his]133-mr. crawford sudden resolution of coming to [them]1887-the three others standing round him for a few days on leaving [Bath]56-bath . A very cordial meeting passed between [him]133-mr. crawford and [Edmund]108-edmund ; and with the exception of [Fanny]113-fanny , the pleasure was general ; and even to _ [her]1884-her _ there might be some advantage in [his]133-mr. crawford presence , since [every addition to [the party]907-the party]1889-every addition to the party must rather forward [her]1884-her favourite indulgence of being suffered to sit silent and unattended to . [She]1884-her was soon aware of this [herself]1884-her ; for though [she]1884-her must submit , as [her]1884-her own propriety of mind directed , in spite of [her]1884-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s opinion , to being [the principal lady in company]1891-the principal lady in company , and to all the little distinctions consequent thereon , [she]1884-her found , while [they]1887-the three others standing round him were at table , such a happy flow of conversation prevailing , in which [she]1884-her was not required to take any part — there was so much to be said between [the brother]695-the brother and sister about [Bath]1893-bath , so much between [the two young men about hunting]1894-the two young men about hunting , so much of politics between [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , and of everything and all together between [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , as to leave [her]1884-her the fairest prospect of having only to listen in quiet , and of passing a very agreeable day . [She]1884-her could not compliment [the newly arrived gentleman]1895-the newly arrived gentleman , however , with any appearance of interest , in a scheme for extending [his]1895-the newly arrived gentleman stay at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , and sending for [[his]1895-the newly arrived gentleman hunters]1896-his hunters from [Norfolk]19-norfolk , which , suggested by [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , advised by [Edmund]108-edmund , and warmly urged by [the two sisters]1810-the two sisters , was soon in possession of [his]1895-the newly arrived gentleman mind , and which [he]1895-the newly arrived gentleman seemed to want to be encouraged even by [her]1884-her to resolve on . [Her]1884-her opinion was sought as to the probable continuance of the open weather , but [her]1884-her answers were as short and indifferent as civility allowed . [She]1884-her could not wish [him]1895-the newly arrived gentleman to stay , and would much rather not have [him]1895-the newly arrived gentleman speak to [her]1884-her . [[Her]1884-her two absent cousins]1898-her two absent cousins , especially [Maria]126-maria , were much in [her]1884-her thoughts on seeing [him]1895-the newly arrived gentleman ; but no embarrassing remembrance affected [_]117-_ [his]1895-the newly arrived gentleman _ spirits . Here [he]1895-the newly arrived gentleman was again on the same ground where all had passed before , and apparently as willing to stay and be happy without [the Miss Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams , as if [he]1895-the newly arrived gentleman had never known [Mansfield]130-mansfield in any other state . [She]1884-her heard [them]1899-them spoken of by [him]1895-the newly arrived gentleman only in a general way , till [they]1899-them were all re - assembled in [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , when [Edmund]108-edmund , being engaged apart in some matter of business with [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , which seemed entirely to engross [them]1899-them , and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant occupied at the tea - table , [he]1895-the newly arrived gentleman began talking of [them]1899-them with more particularity to [[his]1895-the newly arrived gentleman other sister]1901-his other sister . With a significant smile , which made [Fanny]113-fanny quite hate [him]1895-the newly arrived gentleman , [he]1895-the newly arrived gentleman said , “ So !
