[Your]113-fanny kindness and patience can never be forgotten , [your]113-fanny indefatigable patience in trying to make it possible for [him]174-mr. yates to learn [his]174-mr. yates part — in trying to give [him]174-mr. yates a brain which nature had denied — to mix up an understanding for [him]174-mr. yates out of the superfluity of [your]113-fanny own ! _ [He]174-mr. yates _ might not have sense enough [himself]174-mr. yates to estimate [your]113-fanny kindness , but [I]1902-he may venture to say that it had honour from [all the rest of [the party]907-the party]5225-all the rest of the party . ”[1902-he] [Fanny]113-fanny coloured , and said nothing . “ It is as a dream , a pleasant dream ! ”[1902-he] [he]1902-he exclaimed , breaking forth again , after a few minutes ’ musing . “ [I]1902-he shall always look back on [our]5227-we theatricals with exquisite pleasure . There was such an interest , such an animation , such a spirit diffused . [Everybody]408-everybody felt it . [We]5227-we were all alive . There was employment , hope , solicitude , bustle , for every hour of the day . Always some little objection , some little doubt , some little anxiety to be got over . [I]1902-he never was happier . ”[1902-he] With silent indignation [Fanny]113-fanny repeated to [herself]113-fanny , “ Never happier!—never happier than when doing what [you]108-edmund must know was not justifiable!—never happier than when behaving so dishonourably and unfeelingly ! Oh ! what a corrupted mind ! ”[113-fanny] “ [We]5227-we were unlucky , [Miss Price]137-miss price , ”[1902-he] [he]1902-he continued , in a lower tone , to avoid the possibility of being heard by [Edmund]108-edmund , and not at all aware of [her]1903-her feelings , “ [we]5227-we certainly were very unlucky . Another week , only one other week , would have been enough for [us]5227-we . [I]1902-he think if [we]5227-we had had the disposal of events — if [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield had had the government of the winds just for a week or two , about the equinox , there would have been a difference . Not that [we]5227-we would have endangered [his]1902-he safety by any tremendous weather — but only by a steady contrary wind , or a calm . [I]1902-he think , [Miss Price]137-miss price , [we]5227-we would have indulged [ourselves]5227-we with a week ’s calm in [the Atlantic]66-the atlantic at that season . ”[1902-he] [He]1902-he seemed determined to be answered ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , averting [her]1903-her face , said , with a firmer tone than usual , “ As far as _ [I]1903-her _ am concerned , [sir]4023-sir , [I]1903-her would not have delayed [his]1902-he return for a day . [[My]1903-her uncle]3761-my uncle disapproved it all so entirely when [he]1902-he did arrive , that in [my]1903-her opinion everything had gone quite far enough . ”[1903-her] [She]1903-her had never spoken so much at once to [him]1902-he in [her]1903-her life before , and never so angrily to [any one]3817-any one ; and when [her]1903-her speech was over , [she]1903-her trembled and blushed at [her]1903-her own daring . [He]1902-he was surprised ; but after a few moments ’ silent consideration of [her]1903-her , replied in a calmer , graver tone , and as if the candid result of conviction , “ [I]1902-he believe [you]1903-her are right . It was more pleasant than prudent . [We]5231-we were getting too noisy . ”[1902-he] And then turning the conversation , [he]1902-he would have engaged [her]1903-her on some other subject , but [her]1903-her answers were so shy and reluctant that [he]1902-he could not advance in any . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , who had been repeatedly eyeing [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant and [Edmund]108-edmund , now observed , “ [Those gentlemen]5232-those gentlemen must have some very interesting point to discuss . ”[127-miss crawford] “ The most interesting in [the world]315-the world , ”[1903-her] replied [her]1903-her brother—“how to make money ; how to turn a good income into a better . [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant is giving [Bertram]108-edmund instructions about the living [he]108-edmund is to step into so soon . [I]1905-i find [he]108-edmund takes orders in a few weeks . [They]5232-those gentlemen were at it in [the dining - parlour]813-the dining - parlour . [I]1905-i am glad to hear [Bertram]108-edmund will be so well off . [He]108-edmund will have a very pretty income to make ducks and drakes with , and earned without much trouble . [I]1905-i apprehend [he]108-edmund will not have less than seven hundred a year . Seven hundred a year is a fine thing for [a younger brother]5235-a younger brother ; and as of course [he]108-edmund will still live at [home]367-home , it will be all for [his]108-edmund _ menus _ _ plaisirs _ ; and a sermon at Christmas and Easter , [I]1905-i suppose , will be the sum total of sacrifice . ”[1905-i] [[His]1905-i sister]511-his sister tried to laugh off [her]511-his sister feelings by saying , “ Nothing amuses [me]1905-i more than the easy manner with which [everybody]408-everybody settles the abundance of those who have a great deal less than [themselves]5232-those gentlemen . [You]1905-i would look rather blank , [Henry]131-henry , if [your]1905-i _ menus _ _ plaisirs _ were to be limited to seven hundred a year . ”[1905-i] “ Perhaps [I]127-miss crawford might ; but all _ that _ [you]1905-i know is entirely comparative . Birthright and habit must settle the business . [Bertram]108-edmund is certainly well off for [a cadet of [even a baronet]5239-even a baronet ’s family]5238-a cadet of even a baronet ’s family . By the time [he]108-edmund is four or five and twenty [he]108-edmund will have seven hundred a year , and nothing to do for it . ”[127-miss crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford _ could _ have said that there would be a something to do and to suffer for it , which [she]127-miss crawford could not think lightly of ; but [she]127-miss crawford checked [herself]127-miss crawford and let it pass ; and tried to look calm and unconcerned when [the two gentlemen]1140-the two gentlemen shortly afterwards joined [them]1140-the two gentlemen . “ [Bertram]108-edmund , ”[131-henry] said [Henry Crawford]131-henry , “ [I]131-henry shall make a point of coming to [Mansfield]3-mansfield to hear [you]108-edmund preach [your]108-edmund first sermon . [I]131-henry shall come on purpose to encourage [a young beginner]5240-a young beginner . When is it to be ? [Miss Price]137-miss price , will not [you]108-edmund join [me]131-henry in encouraging [[your]108-edmund cousin]3780-your cousin ? Will not [you]108-edmund engage to attend with [your]108-edmund eyes steadily fixed on [him]3780-your cousin the whole time — as [I]131-henry shall do — not to lose a word ; or only looking off just to note down any sentence preeminently beautiful ? [We]5242-we will provide [ourselves]5242-we with tablets and a pencil . When will it be ? [You]108-edmund must preach at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [you]108-edmund know , that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram may hear [you]108-edmund . ”[131-henry] “ [I]108-edmund shall keep clear of [you]108-edmund , [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , as long as [I]108-edmund can , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund ; “ for [you]108-edmund would be more likely to disconcert [me]108-edmund , and [I]108-edmund should be more sorry to see [you]108-edmund trying at it than almost [any other man]5243-any other man . ”[108-edmund] “ Will [he]121-dr. grant not feel this ? ”[113-fanny] thought [Fanny]113-fanny . “ No , [he]121-dr. grant can feel nothing as [he]121-dr. grant ought . ”[113-fanny] [The party being now all united]1908-the party being now all united , and [the chief talkers]1909-the chief talkers attracting [each other]681-each other , [she]1911-she remained in tranquillity ; and as a whist - table was formed after tea — formed really for the amusement of [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , by [[his]121-dr. grant attentive wife]1912-his attentive wife , though it was not to be supposed so — and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford took [her]127-miss crawford harp , [she]127-miss crawford had nothing to do but to listen ; and [her]127-miss crawford tranquillity remained undisturbed the rest of the evening , except when [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford now and then addressed to [her]127-miss crawford a question or observation , which [she]127-miss crawford could not avoid answering . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was too much vexed by what had passed to be in a humour for anything but music . With that [she]127-miss crawford soothed [herself]127-miss crawford and amused [[her]127-miss crawford friend]1394-her friend . The assurance of [Edmund]108-edmund ’s being so soon to take orders , coming upon [her]127-miss crawford like a blow that had been suspended , and still hoped uncertain and at a distance , was felt with resentment and mortification . [She]127-miss crawford was very angry with [him]133-mr. crawford . [She]127-miss crawford had thought [her]127-miss crawford influence more . [She]127-miss crawford _ had _ begun to think of [him]133-mr. crawford ; [she]127-miss crawford felt that [she]127-miss crawford had , with great regard , with almost decided intentions ; but [she]127-miss crawford would now meet [him]133-mr. crawford with [his]133-mr. crawford own cool feelings . It was plain that [he]133-mr. crawford could have no serious views , no true attachment , by fixing [himself]133-mr. crawford in a situation which [he]133-mr. crawford must know [she]127-miss crawford would never stoop to . [She]127-miss crawford would learn to match [him]133-mr. crawford in [his]133-mr. crawford indifference . [She]127-miss crawford would henceforth admit [his]133-mr. crawford attentions without any idea beyond immediate amusement . If _ [he]133-mr. crawford _ could so command [his]133-mr. crawford affections , _ [hers]127-miss crawford _ should do [her]127-miss crawford no harm . CHAPTER XXIV [Henry Crawford]131-henry had quite made up [his]131-henry mind by the next morning to give another fortnight to [Mansfield]130-mansfield , and having sent for [[his]131-henry hunters]1896-his hunters , and written a few lines of explanation to [the Admiral]715-the admiral , [he]131-henry looked round at [[his]131-henry sister]511-his sister as [he]131-henry sealed and threw the letter from [him]131-henry , and seeing the coast clear of [the rest of [the family]3724-the family]618-the rest of the family , said , with a smile , “ And how do [you]511-his sister think [I]131-henry mean to amuse [myself]131-henry , [Mary]132-mary , on the days that [I]131-henry do not hunt ? [I]131-henry am grown too old to go out more than three times a week ; but [I]131-henry have a plan for the intermediate days , and what do [you]511-his sister think it is ? ”[131-henry] “ To walk and ride with [me]131-henry , to be sure . ”[131-henry] “ Not exactly , though [I]131-henry shall be happy to do both , but _ that _ would be exercise only to [my]131-henry body , and [I]131-henry must take care of [my]131-henry mind . Besides , _ that _ would be all recreation and indulgence , without the wholesome alloy of labour , and [I]131-henry do not like to eat the bread of idleness . No , [my]131-henry plan is to make [Fanny Price]113-fanny in love with [me]131-henry . ”[131-henry] “ [Fanny Price]113-fanny ! Nonsense ! No , no . [You]511-his sister ought to be satisfied with [[her]132-mary two cousins]800-her two cousins . ”[131-henry] “ But [I]131-henry can not be satisfied without [Fanny Price]113-fanny , without making a small hole in [Fanny Price]113-fanny ’s heart . [You]511-his sister do not seem properly aware of [her]132-mary claims to notice . When [we]5245-we talked of [her]132-mary last night , [you]511-his sister none of [you]511-his sister seemed sensible of the wonderful improvement that has taken place in [her]132-mary looks within the last six weeks . [You]511-his sister see [her]132-mary every day , and therefore do not notice it ; but [I]131-henry assure [you]511-his sister [she]132-mary is quite a different creature from what [she]132-mary was in the autumn . [She]132-mary was then merely [a quiet , modest , not plain - looking girl]5246-a quiet , modest , not plain - looking girl , but [she]132-mary is now absolutely pretty . [I]131-henry used to think [she]132-mary had neither complexion nor countenance ; but in that soft skin of [hers]132-mary , so frequently tinged with a blush as it was yesterday , there is decided beauty ; and from what [I]131-henry observed of [her]132-mary eyes and mouth , [I]131-henry do not despair of [their]5247-their being capable of expression enough when [she]132-mary has anything to express . And then , [her]132-mary air , [her]132-mary manner , [her]132-mary _ tout _ _ ensemble _ , is so indescribably improved ! [She]132-mary must be grown two inches , at least , since October . ”[131-henry] “ Phoo ! phoo ! This is only because there were [no tall women]5248-no tall women to compare [her]132-mary with , and because [she]132-mary has got a new gown , and [you]5249-you never saw [her]132-mary so well dressed before . [She]132-mary is just what [she]132-mary was in October , believe [me]1919-i . The truth is , that [she]132-mary was the only girl in company for [you]5249-you to notice , and [you]5249-you must have [a somebody]5250-a somebody . [I]1919-i have always thought [her]132-mary pretty — not strikingly pretty — but ‘ pretty enough , ’ as [people]3906-people say ; a sort of beauty that grows on one . [Her]132-mary eyes should be darker , but [she]132-mary has a sweet smile ; but as for this wonderful degree of improvement , [I]1919-i am sure it may all be resolved into a better style of dress , and [your]5249-you having [nobody else]4733-nobody else to look at ; and therefore , if [you]5249-you do set about a flirtation with [her]132-mary , [you]5249-you never will persuade [me]1919-i that it is in compliment to [her]132-mary beauty , or that it proceeds from anything but [your]5249-you own idleness and folly . ”[1919-i] [[Her]1919-i brother]451-her brother gave only a smile to this accusation , and soon afterwards said , “ [I]1919-i do not quite know what to make of [Miss Fanny]103-fanny . [I]1919-i do not understand [her]132-mary . [I]1919-i could not tell what [she]132-mary would be at yesterday . What is [her]132-mary character ? Is [she]132-mary solemn ? Is [she]132-mary queer ? Is [she]132-mary prudish ? Why did [she]132-mary draw back and look so grave at [me]1919-i ? [I]1919-i could hardly get [her]132-mary to speak . [I]1919-i never was so long in company with [a girl in [my]1919-i life]5253-a girl in my life , trying to entertain [her]132-mary , and succeed so ill ! Never met with [a girl who looked so grave on [me]1919-i]5254-a girl who looked so grave on me ! [I]1919-i must try to get the better of this . [Her]132-mary looks say , ‘ [I]1919-i will not like [you]1919-i , [I]1919-i am determined not to like [you]1919-i ’ ; and [I]1919-i say [she]132-mary shall . ”[1919-i] “ [Foolish fellow]5255-foolish fellow ! And so this is [her]132-mary attraction after all ! This it is , [her]132-mary not caring about [you]1919-i , which gives [her]132-mary such a soft skin , and makes [her]132-mary so much taller , and produces all these charms and graces ! [I]132-mary do desire that [you]1919-i will not be making [her]132-mary really unhappy ; a _ little _ love , perhaps , may animate and do [her]132-mary good , but [I]132-mary will not have [you]1919-i plunge [her]132-mary deep , for [she]132-mary is as good [a little creature as ever lived]5256-a little creature as ever lived , and has a great deal of feeling . ”[132-mary] “ It can be but for a fortnight , ”[131-henry] said [Henry]131-henry ; “ and if a fortnight can kill [her]132-mary , [she]132-mary must have a constitution which nothing could save . No , [I]131-henry will not do [her]132-mary any harm , [dear little soul]5257-dear little soul ! [I]131-henry only want [her]132-mary to look kindly on [me]131-henry , to give [me]131-henry smiles as well as blushes , to keep a chair for [me]131-henry by [herself]132-mary wherever [we]5258-we are , and be all animation when [I]131-henry take it and talk to [her]132-mary ; to think as [I]131-henry think , be interested in all [my]131-henry possessions and pleasures , try to keep [me]131-henry longer at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , and feel when [I]131-henry go away that [she]132-mary shall be never happy again . [I]131-henry want nothing more . ”[131-henry] “ Moderation itself ! ”[132-mary] said [Mary]132-mary . “ [I]132-mary can have no scruples now . Well , [you]103-fanny will have opportunities enough of endeavouring to recommend [yourself]103-fanny , for [we]5259-we are a great deal together . ”[132-mary] And without attempting any farther remonstrance , [she]132-mary left [Fanny]103-fanny to [her]103-fanny fate , a fate which , had not [Fanny]103-fanny ’s heart been guarded in a way unsuspected by [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , might have been a little harder than [she]103-fanny deserved ; for although there doubtless are such [unconquerable young ladies of eighteen]1921-unconquerable young ladies of eighteen ( or one should not read about [them]1921-unconquerable young ladies of eighteen ) as are never to be persuaded into love against [their]1921-unconquerable young ladies of eighteen judgment by all that talent , manner , attention , and flattery can do , [I]0-i have no inclination to believe [Fanny]103-fanny one of [them]1921-unconquerable young ladies of eighteen , or to think that with so much tenderness of disposition , and so much taste as belonged to [her]103-fanny , [she]103-fanny could have escaped heart - whole from the courtship ( though the courtship only of a fortnight ) of [such a man as [Crawford]131-henry]1922-such a man as crawford , in spite of there being some previous ill opinion of [him]131-henry to be overcome , had not [her]103-fanny affection been engaged elsewhere . With all the security which love of another and disesteem of [him]131-henry could give to the peace of mind [he]131-henry was attacking , [his]131-henry continued attentions — continued , but not obtrusive , and adapting themselves more and more to the gentleness and delicacy of [her]103-fanny character — obliged [her]103-fanny very soon to dislike [him]131-henry less than formerly . [She]103-fanny had by no means forgotten the past , and [she]103-fanny thought as ill of [him]131-henry as ever ; but [she]103-fanny felt [his]131-henry powers : [he]131-henry was entertaining ; and [his]131-henry manners were so improved , so polite , so seriously and blamelessly polite , that it was impossible not to be civil to [him]131-henry in return . A very few days were enough to effect this ; and at the end of those few days , circumstances arose which had a tendency rather to forward [his]131-henry views of pleasing [her]103-fanny , inasmuch as they gave [her]103-fanny a degree of happiness which must dispose [her]103-fanny to be pleased with [everybody]408-everybody . [William]228-william , [[her]103-fanny brother]451-her brother , [the so long absent and dearly loved brother]1925-the so long absent and dearly loved brother , was in [England]14-england again . [She]103-fanny had a letter from [him]228-william [herself]103-fanny , a few hurried happy lines , written as [the ship]1926-the ship came up [Channel]1927-channel , and sent into [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth with [the first boat]1928-the first boat that left [the Antwerp]67-the antwerp at anchor in [Spithead]68-spithead ; and when [Crawford]131-henry walked up with the newspaper in [his]131-henry hand , which [he]131-henry had hoped would bring the first tidings , [he]131-henry found [her]103-fanny trembling with joy over this letter , and listening with a glowing , grateful countenance to the kind invitation which [[her]103-fanny uncle]312-her uncle was most collectedly dictating in reply . It was but the day before that [Crawford]131-henry had made [himself]131-henry thoroughly master of the subject , or had in fact become at all aware of [her]103-fanny having such [a brother]4109-a brother , or [his]228-william being in such [a ship]1402-a ship , but the interest then excited had been very properly lively , determining [him]131-henry on [his]131-henry return to [town]3698-town to apply for information as to the probable period of [the Antwerp]67-the antwerp ’s return from [the Mediterranean]1403-the mediterranean , etc . ; and the good luck which attended [his]131-henry early examination of ship news the next morning seemed the reward of [his]131-henry ingenuity in finding out such a method of pleasing [her]103-fanny , as well as of [his]131-henry dutiful attention to [the Admiral]715-the admiral , in having for many years taken in the paper esteemed to have the earliest naval intelligence . [He]131-henry proved , however , to be too late . All those fine first feelings , of which [he]131-henry had hoped to be [the exciter]1935-the exciter , were already given . But [his]131-henry intention , the kindness of [his]131-henry intention , was thankfully acknowledged : quite thankfully and warmly , for [she]103-fanny was elevated beyond the common timidity of [her]103-fanny mind by the flow of [her]103-fanny love for [William]228-william . [This dear William]1936-this dear william would soon be amongst [them]1937-them . There could be no doubt of [his]131-henry obtaining leave of absence immediately , for [he]131-henry was still only [a midshipman]1938-a midshipman ; and as [[his]131-henry parents]1939-his parents , from living on the spot , must already have seen [him]131-henry , and be seeing [him]131-henry perhaps daily , [his]131-henry direct holidays might with justice be instantly given to [the sister]1940-the sister , who had been [[his]131-henry best correspondent]1941-his best correspondent through a period of seven years , and [the uncle who had done most for [his]131-henry support and advancement]1942-the uncle who had done most for his support and advancement ; and accordingly the reply to [her]103-fanny reply , fixing a very early day for [his]228-william arrival , came as soon as possible ; and scarcely ten days had passed since [Fanny]103-fanny had been in the agitation of [her]103-fanny first dinner - visit , when [she]103-fanny found [herself]103-fanny in an agitation of a higher nature , watching in [the hall]871-the hall , in [the lobby]1944-the lobby , on the stairs , for the first sound of [the carriage]969-the carriage which was to bring [her]103-fanny [a brother]4109-a brother . It came happily while [she]103-fanny was thus waiting ; and there being neither ceremony nor fearfulness to delay the moment of meeting , [she]103-fanny was with [him]228-william as [he]228-william entered [the house]427-the house , and the first minutes of exquisite feeling had no interruption and [no witnesses]1948-no witnesses , unless [the servants chiefly intent upon opening the proper doors]1949-the servants chiefly intent upon opening the proper doors could be called such . This was exactly what [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas and [Edmund]108-edmund had been separately conniving at , as [each]1248-each proved to [the other]477-the other by the sympathetic alacrity with which [they]1952-they both advised [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s continuing where [she]105-mrs. norris was , instead of rushing out into [the hall]871-the hall as soon as the noises of the arrival reached [them]1952-they . [William]228-william and [Fanny]103-fanny soon [shewed]1954-shewed [themselves]1952-they ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had the pleasure of receiving , in [his]101-sir thomas protégé , certainly [a very different person from the one [he]101-sir thomas had equipped seven years ago]1955-a very different person from the one he had equipped seven years ago , but [a young man of an open , pleasant countenance , and frank , unstudied , but feeling and respectful manners]1956-a young man of an open , pleasant countenance , and frank , unstudied , but feeling and respectful manners , and such as confirmed [him]101-sir thomas [[his]101-sir thomas friend]319-his friend . It was long before [Fanny]103-fanny could recover from the agitating happiness of such an hour as was formed by the last thirty minutes of expectation , and the first of fruition ; it was some time even before [her]103-fanny happiness could be said to make [her]103-fanny happy , before the disappointment inseparable from the alteration of [person]1958-person had vanished , and [she]103-fanny could see in [him]228-william the same [William]228-william as before , and talk to [him]228-william , as [her]103-fanny heart had been yearning to do through many a past year . That time , however , did gradually come , forwarded by an affection on [his]228-william side as warm as [her]103-fanny own , and much less encumbered by refinement or self - distrust . [She]103-fanny was the first object of [his]228-william love , but it was a love which [his]228-william stronger spirits , and bolder temper , made it as natural for [him]228-william to express as to feel . On the morrow [they]1959-they were walking about together with true enjoyment , and every succeeding morrow renewed a _ tête - à - tête _ which [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could not but observe with complacency , even before [Edmund]108-edmund had pointed it out to [him]101-sir thomas . Excepting the moments of peculiar delight , which any marked or unlooked - for instance of [Edmund]108-edmund ’s consideration of [her]103-fanny in the last few months had excited , [Fanny]103-fanny had never known so much felicity in [her]103-fanny life , as in this unchecked , equal , fearless intercourse with [the brother]695-the brother and friend who was opening all [his]228-william heart to [her]103-fanny , telling [her]103-fanny all [his]228-william hopes and fears , plans , and solicitudes respecting that long thought of , dearly earned , and justly valued blessing of promotion ; who could give [her]103-fanny direct and minute information of [the father]1154-the father and [mother]3977-mother , [brothers]3675-brothers and [sisters]3676-sisters , of whom [she]103-fanny very seldom heard ; who was interested in all the comforts and all the little hardships of [[her]103-fanny home at [Mansfield]3-mansfield]1965-her home at mansfield ; ready to think of [every member of [that home]1967-that home]1966-every member of that home as [she]103-fanny directed , or differing only by a less scrupulous opinion , and more noisy abuse of [[their]1968-their aunt]468-their aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris , and with whom ( perhaps the dearest indulgence of the whole ) all the evil and good of [their]1968-their earliest years could be gone over again , and [every former united pain and pleasure retraced with the fondest recollection]1970-every former united pain and pleasure retraced with the fondest recollection . An advantage this , a strengthener of love , in which even the conjugal tie is beneath the fraternal . [Children of the same family]1971-children of the same family , the same blood , with the same first associations and habits , have some means of enjoyment in [their]1971-children of the same family power , which no subsequent connexions can supply ; and it must be by a long and unnatural estrangement , by a divorce which [no subsequent connexion]1972-no subsequent connexion can justify , if such precious remains of the earliest attachments are ever entirely outlived . Too often , alas ! it is so . Fraternal love , sometimes almost everything , is at others worse than nothing . But with [William]228-william and [Fanny Price]113-fanny it was still a sentiment in all its prime and freshness , wounded by no opposition of interest , cooled by no separate attachment , and feeling the influence of time and absence only in its increase . An affection so amiable was advancing each in the opinion of [all who had hearts to value anything good]1973-all who had hearts to value anything good . [Henry Crawford]131-henry was as much struck with it as any . [He]131-henry honoured the warm - hearted , blunt fondness of [the young sailor]1974-the young sailor , which led [him]131-henry to say , with [his]131-henry hands stretched towards [Fanny]113-fanny ’s head , “ Do [you]113-fanny know , [I]131-henry begin to like that queer fashion already , though when [I]131-henry first heard of such things being done in [England]14-england , [I]131-henry could not believe it ; and when [Mrs. Brown]227-mrs. brown , and [[the other women at the Commissioner]5260-the other women at the commissioner ’s at [Gibraltar]69-gibraltar]5261-the other women at the commissioner ’s at gibraltar , appeared in the same trim , [I]131-henry thought [they]5261-the other women at the commissioner ’s at gibraltar were mad ; but [Fanny]113-fanny can reconcile [me]131-henry to anything ”[131-henry] ; and saw , with lively admiration , the glow of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s cheek , the brightness of [her]1975-her eye , the deep interest , the absorbed attention , while [[her]1975-her brother]451-her brother was describing any of the imminent hazards , or terrific scenes , which such a period at [sea]512-sea must supply . It was a picture which [Henry Crawford]131-henry had moral taste enough to value . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s attractions increased — increased twofold ; for the sensibility which beautified [her]1975-her complexion and illumined [her]1975-her countenance was an attraction in itself . [He]131-henry was no longer in doubt of the capabilities of [her]1975-her heart . [She]1975-her had feeling , genuine feeling . It would be something to be loved by [such a girl]1978-such a girl , to excite the first ardours of [her]1975-her young unsophisticated mind ! [She]1975-her interested [him]131-henry more than [he]131-henry had foreseen . A fortnight was not enough . [His]131-henry stay became indefinite . [William]228-william was often called on by [[his]228-william uncle]526-his uncle to be [the talker]1568-the talker . [His]228-william recitals were amusing in themselves to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , but the chief object in seeking them was to understand [the reciter]1981-the reciter , to know [the young man]680-the young man by [his]680-the young man histories ; and [he]228-william listened to [his]228-william clear , simple , spirited details with full satisfaction , seeing in them the proof of good principles , professional knowledge , energy , courage , and cheerfulness , everything that could deserve or promise well . Young as [he]228-william was , [William]228-william had already seen a great deal . [He]131-henry had been in [the Mediterranean]70-the mediterranean ; in [the West Indies]23-the west indies ; in [the Mediterranean]70-the mediterranean again ; had been often taken on [shore]1983-shore by the favour of [[his]131-henry captain]1984-his captain , and in the course of seven years had known every variety of danger which sea and war together could offer . With such means in [his]131-henry power [he]131-henry had a right to be listened to ; and though [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris could fidget about [the room]412-the room , and disturb [everybody]408-everybody in quest of two needlefuls of thread or a second - hand shirt button , in the midst of [[her]105-mrs. norris nephew]1987-her nephew ’s account of a shipwreck or an engagement , [everybody else]458-everybody else was attentive ; and even [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram could not hear of such horrors unmoved , or without sometimes lifting [her]106-lady bertram eyes from [her]106-lady bertram work to say , “ Dear [me]106-lady bertram ! how disagreeable ! [I]106-lady bertram wonder [anybody]3668-anybody can ever go to [sea]512-sea . ”[106-lady bertram] To [Henry Crawford]131-henry [they]1989-they gave a different feeling . [He]131-henry longed to have been at [sea]512-sea , and seen and done and suffered as much . [His]131-henry heart was warmed , [his]131-henry fancy fired , and [he]131-henry felt the highest respect for [a lad who , before [he]1991-a lad who , before he was twenty , had gone through such bodily hardships and given such proofs of mind was twenty , had gone through such bodily hardships and given such proofs of mind]1991-a lad who , before he was twenty , had gone through such bodily hardships and given such proofs of mind . The glory of heroism , of usefulness , of exertion , of endurance , made [his]131-henry own habits of selfish indulgence appear in shameful contrast ; and [he]131-henry wished [he]131-henry had been [a William Price]228-william , distinguishing [himself]131-henry and working [his]131-henry way to fortune and consequence with so much self - respect and happy ardour , instead of what [he]131-henry was ! The wish was rather eager than lasting . [He]131-henry was roused from the reverie of retrospection and regret produced by it , by some inquiry from [Edmund]108-edmund as to [his]131-henry plans for the next day ’s hunting ; and [he]131-henry found it was as well to be [a man of fortune]1992-a man of fortune at once with horses and [grooms]1993-grooms at [his]131-henry command . In one respect it was better , as it gave [him]131-henry the means of conferring a kindness where [he]131-henry wished to oblige . With spirits , courage , and curiosity up to anything , [William]228-william expressed an inclination to hunt ; and [Crawford]131-henry could mount [him]131-henry without the slightest inconvenience to [himself]131-henry , and with only some scruples to obviate in [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , who knew better than [[his]101-sir thomas nephew]1994-his nephew the value of such a loan , and some alarms to reason away in [Fanny]113-fanny . [She]1995-she feared for [William]228-william ; by no means convinced by all that [he]228-william could relate of [his]228-william own horsemanship in [various countries]1996-various countries , of the scrambling parties in which [he]228-william had been engaged , the rough horses and mules [he]228-william had ridden , or [his]228-william many narrow escapes from dreadful falls , that [he]228-william was at all equal to the management of [a high - fed hunter in an English fox - chase]1997-a high - fed hunter in an english fox - chase ; nor till [he]228-william returned safe and well , without accident or discredit , could [she]1995-she be reconciled to the risk , or feel any of that obligation to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford for lending the horse which [he]133-mr. crawford had fully intended it should produce . When it was proved , however , to have done [William]228-william no harm , [she]1995-she could allow it to be a kindness , and even reward [the owner]1998-the owner with a smile when the animal was one minute tendered to [his]133-mr. crawford use again ; and the next , with the greatest cordiality , and in a manner not to be resisted , made over to [his]133-mr. crawford use entirely so long as [he]133-mr. crawford remained in [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire . CHAPTER XXV The intercourse of [the two families]3825-the two families was at this period more nearly restored to what it had been in the autumn , than [any member of the old intimacy]2000-any member of the old intimacy had thought ever likely to be again . The return of [Henry Crawford]131-henry , and the arrival of [William Price]228-william , had much to do with it , but much was still owing to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s more than toleration of the neighbourly attempts at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage . [His]228-william mind , now disengaged from the cares which had pressed on [him]228-william at first , was at leisure to find [the Grants]122-the grants and [[their]122-the grants young inmates]2002-their young inmates really worth visiting ; and though infinitely above scheming or contriving for any the most advantageous matrimonial establishment that could be among the apparent possibilities of any one most dear to [him]228-william , and disdaining even as a littleness the being quick - sighted on such points , [he]228-william could not avoid perceiving , in a grand and careless way , that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was somewhat distinguishing [[his]133-mr. crawford niece]724-his niece — nor perhaps refrain ( though unconsciously ) from giving a more willing assent to invitations on that account . [His]228-william readiness , however , in agreeing to dine at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , when the general invitation was at last hazarded , after many debates and many doubts as to whether it were worth while , “ because [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas seemed so ill inclined , and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was so indolent ! ”[228-william] proceeded from good - breeding and goodwill alone , and had nothing to do with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , but as being [one in an agreeable group]2005-one in an agreeable group : for it was in the course of that very visit that [he]228-william first began to think that [any one in the habit of such idle observations _]2006-any one in the habit of such idle observations _ would _ _ have _ _ thought _ that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was [the admirer of [Fanny Price]113-fanny]2007-the admirer of fanny price . The meeting was generally felt to be a pleasant one , being composed in a good proportion of those who would talk and [those who would listen]2008-those who would listen ; and the dinner itself was elegant and plentiful , according to the usual style of [the Grants]2009-the grants , and too much according to the usual habits of all to raise any emotion except in [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , who could never behold either the wide table or the number of dishes on it with patience , and who did always contrive to experience some evil from the passing of [the servants]601-the servants behind [her]105-mrs. norris chair , and to bring away some fresh conviction of its being impossible among so many dishes but that some must be cold . In the evening it was found , according to the predetermination of [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister , that after making up the whist - table there would remain sufficient for a round game , and [everybody]408-everybody being as perfectly complying and without a choice as on such occasions [they]408-everybody always are , speculation was decided on almost as soon as whist ; and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram soon found [herself]106-lady bertram in the critical situation of being applied to for [her]106-lady bertram own choice between the games , and being required either to draw a card for whist or not . [She]106-lady bertram hesitated . [Luckily Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was at hand . “ What shall [I]101-sir thomas do , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ? Whist and speculation ; which will amuse [me]101-sir thomas most ? ”[101-sir thomas] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , after a moment ’s thought , recommended speculation . [He]101-sir thomas was [a whist player]2013-a whist player [himself]101-sir thomas , and perhaps might feel that it would not much amuse [him]101-sir thomas to have [her]106-lady bertram for [a partner]1191-a partner . “ Very well , ”[921-her ladyship] was [[her]106-lady bertram ladyship]921-her ladyship ’s contented answer ; “ then speculation , if [you]106-lady bertram please , [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant . [I]921-her ladyship know nothing about it , but [Fanny]113-fanny must teach [me]921-her ladyship . ”[921-her ladyship] Here [Fanny]113-fanny interposed , however , with anxious protestations of [her]106-lady bertram own equal ignorance ; [she]106-lady bertram had never played the game nor seen it played in [her]106-lady bertram life ; and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram felt a moment ’s indecision again ; but upon [everybody]408-everybody ’s assuring [her]106-lady bertram that nothing could be so easy , that it was the easiest game on the cards , and [Henry Crawford]131-henry ’s stepping forward with a most earnest request to be allowed to sit between [[her]106-lady bertram ladyship]921-her ladyship and [Miss Price]137-miss price , and teach [them]2018-them both , it was so settled ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , and [Dr.]121-dr. grant and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant being seated at the table of prime intellectual state and dignity , the remaining six , under [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s direction , were arranged round the other . It was a fine arrangement for [Henry Crawford]131-henry , who was close to [Fanny]113-fanny , and with [his]131-henry hands full of business , having [two persons]2019-two persons ’ cards to manage as well as [his]131-henry own ; for though it was impossible for [Fanny]113-fanny not to feel [herself]113-fanny mistress of the rules of the game in three minutes , [he]131-henry had yet to inspirit [her]106-lady bertram play , sharpen [her]106-lady bertram avarice , and harden [her]106-lady bertram heart , which , especially in any competition with [William]228-william , was a work of some difficulty ; and as for [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , [he]131-henry must continue in charge of all [her]106-lady bertram fame and fortune through the whole evening ; and if quick enough to keep [her]106-lady bertram from looking at [her]106-lady bertram cards when the deal began , must direct [her]106-lady bertram in whatever was to be done with them to the end of it . [He]131-henry was in high spirits , doing everything with happy ease , and preeminent in all the lively turns , quick resources , and playful impudence that could do honour to the game ; and the round table was altogether a very comfortable contrast to the steady sobriety and orderly silence of the other . [Twice]229-twice had [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas inquired into the enjoyment and success of [[his]101-sir thomas lady]1778-his lady , but in vain ; no pause was long enough for the time [his]101-sir thomas measured manner needed ; and very little of [her]1778-his lady state could be known till [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant was able , at the end of the first rubber , to go to [her]1778-his lady and pay [her]1778-his lady compliments . “ [I]123-mrs. grant hope [[your]123-mrs. grant ladyship]4820-your ladyship is pleased with the game . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ Oh dear , yes ! very entertaining indeed . A very odd game . [I]123-mrs. grant do not know what it is all about . [I]123-mrs. grant am never to see [my]123-mrs. grant cards ; and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford does all the rest . ”[123-mrs. grant] “ [Bertram]106-lady bertram , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , some time afterwards , taking the opportunity of a little languor in the game , “ [I]133-mr. crawford have never told [you]106-lady bertram what happened to [me]133-mr. crawford yesterday in [my]133-mr. crawford ride [home]367-home . ”[133-mr. crawford] [They]2021-they had been hunting together , and were in the midst of a good run , and at some distance from [Mansfield]3-mansfield , when [his]133-mr. crawford horse being found to have flung a shoe , [Henry Crawford]131-henry had been obliged to give up , and make the best of [his]133-mr. crawford way back . “ [I]231-thornton lacey told [you]106-lady bertram [I]231-thornton lacey lost [my]231-thornton lacey way after passing [that old farmhouse]5266-that old farmhouse with the yew - trees , because [I]231-thornton lacey can never bear to ask ; but [I]231-thornton lacey have not told [you]106-lady bertram that , with [my]231-thornton lacey usual luck — for [I]231-thornton lacey never do wrong without gaining by it — [I]231-thornton lacey found [myself]231-thornton lacey in due time in [the very place which [I]231-thornton lacey had a curiosity to see]5267-the very place which i had a curiosity to see . [I]231-thornton lacey was suddenly , upon turning the corner of [a steepish downy field]5268-a steepish downy field , in [the midst of [a retired little village]5270-a retired little village between [gently rising hills]5271-gently rising hills]5269-the midst of a retired little village between gently rising hills ; [a small stream before [me]231-thornton lacey to be forded]5272-a small stream before me to be forded , [a church standing on [a sort of knoll]5274-a sort of knoll to [my]231-thornton lacey right]5273-a church standing on a sort of knoll to my right — which [church]4565-church was strikingly large and handsome for [the place]459-the place , and not [a gentleman]4549-a gentleman or [half [a gentleman]4549-a gentleman ’s house]5278-half a gentleman ’s house to be seen excepting one — to be presumed [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage — within a stone ’s throw of [the said knoll and church]5281-the said knoll and church . [I]231-thornton lacey found [myself]231-thornton lacey , in short , in [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey . ”[231-thornton lacey] “ It sounds like it , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund ; “ but which way did [you]231-thornton lacey turn after passing [[Sewell]230-sewell ’s farm]5282-sewell ’s farm ? ”[231-thornton lacey] “ [I]231-thornton lacey answer no such irrelevant and insidious questions ; though were [I]231-thornton lacey to answer all that [you]231-thornton lacey could put in the course of an hour , [you]231-thornton lacey would never be able to prove that it was _ not [_ Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey — for such it certainly was . ”[231-thornton lacey] “ [You]231-thornton lacey inquired , then ? ”[231-thornton lacey] “ No , [I]231-thornton lacey never inquire . But [I]231-thornton lacey _ told _ [a man]4410-a man mending a hedge that it was [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey , and [he]4410-a man agreed to it . ”[231-thornton lacey] “ [You]231-thornton lacey have a good memory . [I]231-thornton lacey had forgotten having ever told [you]231-thornton lacey half so much of [the place]459-the place . ”[231-thornton lacey] [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey was the name of [his]231-thornton lacey impending living , as [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford well knew ; and [her]127-miss crawford interest in a negotiation for [[William Price]228-william ’s knave]2022-william price ’s knave increased . “ Well , ”[108-edmund] continued [Edmund]108-edmund , “ and how did [you]231-thornton lacey like what [you]231-thornton lacey saw ? ”[108-edmund] “ Very much indeed . [You]231-thornton lacey are [a lucky fellow]5285-a lucky fellow . There will be work for five summers at least before [the place]459-the place is liveable . ”[231-thornton lacey] “ No , no , not so bad as that . [The farmyard]5287-the farmyard must be moved , [I]108-edmund grant [you]231-thornton lacey ; but [I]108-edmund am not aware of anything else . [The house]427-the house is by no means bad , and when [the yard]5289-the yard is removed , there may be a very tolerable approach to [it]427-the house . ”[108-edmund] “ [The farmyard]5287-the farmyard must be cleared away entirely , and planted up to shut out [[the blacksmith]5291-the blacksmith ’s shop]5292-the blacksmith ’s shop . [The house]427-the house must be turned to front the east instead of the north — the entrance and principal rooms , [I]108-edmund mean , must be on that side , where the view is really very pretty ; [I]108-edmund am sure it may be done . And _ there _ must be [your]231-thornton lacey approach , through what is at present [the garden]5294-the garden . [You]231-thornton lacey must make [a new garden at what is now the back of [the house]427-the house]5295-a new garden at what is now the back of the house ; which will be giving [it]427-the house the best aspect in [the world]315-the world , sloping to the south - east . The ground seems precisely formed for it . [I]108-edmund rode fifty yards up [the lane]888-the lane , between [the church]4265-the church and [the house]427-the house , in order to look about [me]108-edmund ; and saw how it might all be . Nothing can be easier . The meadows beyond what _ will _ _ be _ [the garden]5294-the garden , as well as what now _ is _ , sweeping round from [the lane]888-the lane [I]108-edmund stood in to the north - east , that is , to [the principal road through [the village]524-the village]5303-the principal road through the village , must be all laid together , of course ; very pretty meadows [they]5294-the garden are , finely sprinkled with timber . They belong to [the living]5305-the living , [I]108-edmund suppose ; if not , [you]231-thornton lacey must purchase them . Then [the stream]5306-the stream — something must be done with [the stream]5306-the stream ; but [I]108-edmund could not quite determine what . [I]108-edmund had two or three ideas . ”[108-edmund] “ And [I]108-edmund have two or three ideas also , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ and one of them is , that very little of [your]108-edmund plan for [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey will ever be put in practice . [I]108-edmund must be satisfied with rather less ornament and beauty . [I]108-edmund think [the house]427-the house and [premises]5309-premises may be made comfortable , and given the air of [[a gentleman]4549-a gentleman ’s residence]5311-a gentleman ’s residence , without any very heavy expense , and that must suffice [me]108-edmund ; and , [I]108-edmund hope , may suffice all who care about [me]108-edmund . ”[108-edmund] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , a little suspicious and resentful of a certain tone of voice , and a certain half - look attending the last expression of [his]2023-his hope , made a hasty finish of [her]127-miss crawford dealings with [William Price]228-william ; and securing [his]2023-his knave at an exorbitant rate , exclaimed , “ There , [I]127-miss crawford will stake [my]127-miss crawford last like [a woman of spirit]5312-a woman of spirit . No cold prudence for [me]127-miss crawford . [I]127-miss crawford am not born to sit still and do nothing . If [I]127-miss crawford lose the game , it shall not be from not striving for it . ”[127-miss crawford] The game was [hers]127-miss crawford , and only did not pay [her]127-miss crawford for what [she]127-miss crawford had given to secure it . Another deal proceeded , and [Crawford]133-mr. crawford began again about [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey . “ [My]133-mr. crawford plan may not be the best possible : [I]133-mr. crawford had not many minutes to form it in ; but [you]133-mr. crawford must do a good deal . [The place]459-the place deserves [it]459-the place , and [you]133-mr. crawford will find [yourself]133-mr. crawford not satisfied with much less than [it]459-the place is capable of . ( Excuse [me]133-mr. crawford , [[your]133-mr. crawford ladyship]4820-your ladyship must not see [your]133-mr. crawford cards . There , let them lie just before [you]133-mr. crawford . ) [The place]459-the place deserves it , [Bertram]106-lady bertram . [You]133-mr. crawford talk of giving it the air of [[a gentleman]4549-a gentleman ’s residence]5311-a gentleman ’s residence . _ That _ will be done by the removal of [the farmyard]5287-the farmyard ; for , independent of that terrible nuisance , [I]133-mr. crawford never saw [a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air of [a gentleman]4549-a gentleman ’s residence]5319-a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air of a gentleman ’s residence , so much the look of a something above [a mere parsonage - house]5321-a mere parsonage - house — above the expenditure of a few hundreds a year . It is not [a scrambling collection of [low single rooms]5323-low single rooms , with as many roofs as windows]5322-a scrambling collection of low single rooms , with as many roofs as windows ; [it]5319-a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air of a gentleman ’s residence is not cramped into the vulgar compactness of [a square farmhouse]5324-a square farmhouse : [it]5319-a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air of a gentleman ’s residence is [a solid , roomy , mansion - like looking house]5325-a solid , roomy , mansion - like looking house , such as one might suppose [a respectable old country family]5326-a respectable old country family had lived in from generation to generation , through two centuries at least , and were now spending from two to three thousand a year in . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford listened , and [Edmund]108-edmund agreed to this . “ The air of [[a gentleman]4549-a gentleman ’s residence]5311-a gentleman ’s residence , therefore , [you]133-mr. crawford can not but give it , if [you]133-mr. crawford do anything . But it is capable of much more . ( Let [me]108-edmund see , [Mary]132-mary ; [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram bids a dozen for [that queen]5329-that queen ; no , no , a dozen is more than it is worth . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram does not bid a dozen . [She]106-lady bertram will have nothing to say to it . Go on , go on . ) By some such improvements as [I]108-edmund have suggested ( [I]108-edmund do not really require [you]133-mr. crawford to proceed upon [my]108-edmund plan , though , by the bye , [I]108-edmund doubt [anybody]3668-anybody ’s striking out a better ) [you]133-mr. crawford may give [it]5311-a gentleman ’s residence a higher character . [You]133-mr. crawford may raise [it]5311-a gentleman ’s residence into [a _ place]5331-a _ place _ . All this may be stamped on [it]5311-a gentleman ’s residence ; and [that house]1793-that house receive such an air as to make [[its]1793-that house owner]5337-its owner be set down as [the great landholder of [the parish]3860-the parish]5338-the great landholder of the parish by [every creature travelling [the road]4259-the road]5340-every creature travelling the road ; especially as there is [[no real squire]5342-no real squire ’s house]5343-no real squire ’s house to dispute the point — a circumstance , between [ourselves]5344-ourselves , to enhance the value of such a situation in point of privilege and independence beyond all calculation . _ [You]113-fanny _ think with [me]108-edmund , [I]108-edmund hope ”[108-edmund] ( turning with a softened voice to [Fanny]113-fanny ) . “ Have [you]113-fanny ever seen [the place]459-the place ? ”[108-edmund] [Fanny]113-fanny gave a quick negative , and tried to hide [her]2024-her interest in the subject by an eager attention to [[her]2024-her brother]451-her brother , who was driving as hard a bargain , and imposing on [her]2024-her as much as [he]451-her brother could ; but [Crawford]133-mr. crawford pursued with “ No , no , [you]113-fanny must not part with [the queen]5346-the queen . [You]113-fanny have bought [her]5346-the queen too dearly , and [[your]113-fanny brother]3938-your brother does not offer half [her]5346-the queen value . The game will be [yours]113-fanny , ”[133-mr. crawford] turning to [her]2024-her again ; “ it will certainly be [yours]113-fanny . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ And [Fanny]113-fanny had much rather it were [William]228-william ’s , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , smiling at [her]2024-her . “ [Poor Fanny]113-fanny ! not allowed to cheat [herself]113-fanny as [she]2024-her wishes ! ”[108-edmund] “ [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , a few minutes afterwards , “ [you]108-edmund know [Henry]131-henry to be such [a capital improver]5351-a capital improver , that [you]108-edmund can not possibly engage in anything of the sort at [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey without accepting [his]131-henry help . Only think how useful [he]131-henry was at [Sotherton]27-sotherton ! Only think what grand things were produced there by [our]5352-we all going with [him]131-henry one hot day in August to drive about [the grounds]4287-the grounds , and see [his]131-henry genius take fire . There [we]5352-we went , and there [we]5352-we came [home]367-home again ; and what was done there is not to be told ! ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny ’s eyes were turned on [Crawford]133-mr. crawford for a moment with an expression more than grave — even reproachful ; but on catching [his]133-mr. crawford , were instantly withdrawn . With something of consciousness [he]133-mr. crawford shook [his]133-mr. crawford head at [[his]133-mr. crawford sister]511-his sister , and laughingly replied , “ [I]133-mr. crawford can not say there was much done at [Sotherton]27-sotherton ; but it was a hot day , and [we]5352-we were all walking after [each other]681-each other , and bewildered . ”[133-mr. crawford] As soon as a general buzz gave [him]133-mr. crawford shelter , [he]133-mr. crawford added , in a low voice , directed solely at [Fanny]113-fanny , “ [I]133-mr. crawford should be sorry to have [my]133-mr. crawford powers of _ planning _ judged of by the day at [Sotherton]27-sotherton . [I]133-mr. crawford see things very differently now . Do not think of [me]133-mr. crawford as [I]133-mr. crawford appeared then . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Sotherton]27-sotherton was a word to catch [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , and being just then in the happy leisure which followed securing the odd trick by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s capital play and [her]105-mrs. norris own against [Dr.]121-dr. grant and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s great hands , [she]105-mrs. norris called out , in high good - humour , “ [Sotherton]27-sotherton ! Yes , that is [a place]5356-a place , indeed , and [we]5352-we had a charming day there . [William]228-william , [you]228-william are quite out of luck ; but the next time [you]228-william come , [I]105-mrs. norris hope [dear Mr.]5357-dear mr. and [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria will be at [home]367-home , and [I]105-mrs. norris am sure [I]105-mrs. norris can answer for [your]228-william being kindly received by [both]5359-both . [[Your]228-william cousins]4848-your cousins are not of a sort to forget [their]4848-your cousins relations , and [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny is [a most amiable man]5361-a most amiable man . [They]4848-your cousins are at [Brighton]61-brighton now , [you]228-william know ; in [one of [the best houses there]5363-the best houses there]5362-one of the best houses there , as [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s fine fortune gives [them]4848-your cousins a right to be . [I]105-mrs. norris do not exactly know the distance , but when [you]228-william get back to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , if it is not very far off , [you]228-william ought to go over and pay [your]228-william respects to [them]4848-your cousins ; and [I]105-mrs. norris could send a little parcel by [you]228-william that [I]105-mrs. norris want to get conveyed to [[your]228-william cousins]4848-your cousins . ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [I]105-mrs. norris should be very happy , [aunt]3769-aunt ; but [Brighton]61-brighton is almost by [Beachey Head]73-beachey head ; and if [I]105-mrs. norris could get so far , [I]105-mrs. norris could not expect to be welcome in such a smart place as that — [poor scrubby midshipman as [I]105-mrs. norris am]5366-poor scrubby midshipman as i am . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was beginning an eager assurance of the affability [he]2027-you might depend on , when [she]105-mrs. norris was stopped by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s saying with authority , “ [I]101-sir thomas do not advise [your]2027-you going to [Brighton]61-brighton , [William]228-william , as [I]101-sir thomas trust [you]2027-you may soon have more convenient opportunities of meeting ; but [[my]101-sir thomas daughters]3727-my daughters would be happy to see [[their]3727-my daughters cousins]5368-their cousins anywhere ; and [you]2027-you will find [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny most sincerely disposed to regard all the connexions of [[our]5369-our family]5370-our family as [his]113-fanny own . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [I]228-william would rather find [him]113-fanny [private secretary to [the First Lord]232-the first lord]5371-private secretary to the first lord than anything else , ”[228-william] was [William]228-william ’s only answer , in an undervoice , not meant to reach far , and the subject dropped . As yet [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had seen nothing to remark in [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s behaviour ; but when the whist - table broke up at the end of the second rubber , and leaving [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris to dispute over [their]2028-their last play , [he]101-sir thomas became [a looker - on]2029-a looker - on at the other , [he]101-sir thomas found [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece the object of attentions , or rather of professions , of a somewhat pointed character . [Henry Crawford]131-henry was in the first glow of another scheme about [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey ; and not being able to catch [Edmund]108-edmund ’s ear , was detailing it to [[his]131-henry fair neighbour]2031-his fair neighbour with a look of considerable earnestness . [His]131-henry scheme was to rent [the house]427-the house [himself]131-henry the following winter , that [he]131-henry might have [a home of [his]131-henry own]2033-a home of his own in [that neighbourhood]2034-that neighbourhood ; and it was not merely for the use of [it]2033-a home of his own in the hunting - season ( as [he]131-henry was then telling [her]2031-his fair neighbour ) , though _ that _ consideration had certainly some weight , feeling as [he]131-henry did that , in spite of all [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant ’s very great kindness , it was impossible for [him]131-henry and [[his]131-henry horses]2035-his horses to be accommodated where they now were without material inconvenience ; but [his]131-henry attachment to [that neighbourhood]2034-that neighbourhood did not depend upon one amusement or one season of the year : [he]131-henry had set [his]131-henry heart upon having a something there that [he]131-henry could come to at any time , [a little homestall at [his]131-henry command]2037-a little homestall at his command , where all the holidays of [his]131-henry year might be spent , and [he]131-henry might find [himself]131-henry continuing , improving , and _ perfecting _ that friendship and intimacy with [the Mansfield Park family]2038-the mansfield park family which was increasing in value to [him]131-henry every day . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas heard and was not offended . There was no want of respect in [the young man]680-the young man ’s address ; and [Fanny]113-fanny ’s reception of it was so proper and modest , so calm and uninviting , that [he]131-henry had nothing to censure in [her]2040-her . [She]2040-her said little , assented only here and there , and betrayed no inclination either of appropriating any part of the compliment to [herself]2040-her , or of strengthening [his]131-henry views in favour of [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire . Finding by whom [he]131-henry was observed , [Henry Crawford]131-henry addressed [himself]131-henry on the same subject to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , in a more everyday tone , but still with feeling . “ [I]131-henry want to be [[your]101-sir thomas neighbour]5372-your neighbour , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , as [you]101-sir thomas have , perhaps , heard [me]131-henry telling [Miss Price]137-miss price . May [I]131-henry hope for [your]101-sir thomas acquiescence , and for [your]101-sir thomas not influencing [[your]101-sir thomas son]5373-your son against [such a tenant]5374-such a tenant ? ”[131-henry] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , politely bowing , replied , “ It is the only way , [sir]4023-sir , in which [I]101-sir thomas could _ not _ wish [you]108-edmund established as [a permanent neighbour]5376-a permanent neighbour ; but [I]101-sir thomas hope , and believe , that [Edmund]108-edmund will occupy [[his]108-edmund own house at [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey]5377-his own house at thornton lacey . [Edmund]108-edmund , am [I]101-sir thomas saying too much ? ”[101-sir thomas] [Edmund]108-edmund , on this appeal , had first to hear what was going on ; but , on understanding the question , was at no loss for an answer . “ Certainly , [sir]4023-sir , [I]101-sir thomas have no idea but of residence . But , [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , though [I]101-sir thomas refuse [you]108-edmund as [a tenant]5379-a tenant , come to [me]101-sir thomas as [a friend]456-a friend . Consider [the house]427-the house as half [your]108-edmund own every winter , and [we]5382-we will add to [the stables]5383-the stables on [your]108-edmund own improved plan , and with all the improvements of [your]108-edmund improved plan that may occur to [you]108-edmund this spring . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [We]5382-we shall be [the losers]5384-the losers , ”[101-sir thomas] continued [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . “ [His]108-edmund going , though only eight miles , will be an unwelcome contraction of [[our]5382-we family circle]5385-our family circle ; but [I]101-sir thomas should have been deeply mortified if [any son of mine]5386-any son of mine could reconcile [himself]5386-any son of mine to doing less . It is perfectly natural that [you]108-edmund should not have thought much on the subject , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . But [a parish]5387-a parish has wants and claims which can be known only by [a clergyman constantly resident]5388-a clergyman constantly resident , and which [no proxy]5389-no proxy can be capable of satisfying to the same extent . [Edmund]108-edmund might , in the common phrase , do the duty of [Thornton]231-thornton lacey , that is , [he]108-edmund might read prayers and preach , without giving up [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield : [he]108-edmund might ride over every Sunday , to [a house nominally inhabited]5390-a house nominally inhabited , and go through divine service ; [he]108-edmund might be [the clergyman of [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey]5391-the clergyman of thornton lacey every seventh day , for three or four hours , if that would content [him]108-edmund . But it will not . [He]108-edmund knows that human nature needs more lessons than a weekly sermon can convey ; and that if [he]108-edmund does not live among [[his]108-edmund parishioners]5392-his parishioners , and prove [himself]108-edmund , by constant attention , [[their]5392-his parishioners well - wisher and [friend]444-friend]5393-their well - wisher and friend , [he]108-edmund does very little either for [their]5392-his parishioners good or [his]108-edmund own . ”[101-sir thomas] [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford bowed [his]133-mr. crawford acquiescence . “ [I]101-sir thomas repeat again , ”[101-sir thomas] added [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , “ that [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey is [the only house in [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood in which [I]101-sir thomas should _ not _ be happy to wait on [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford as [occupier]5397-occupier]5395-the only house in the neighbourhood in which i should _ not _ be happy to wait on mr. crawford as occupier . ”[101-sir thomas] [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford bowed [his]133-mr. crawford thanks . “ [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ undoubtedly understands the duty of [a parish priest]5398-a parish priest . [We]5399-we must hope [[his]133-mr. crawford son]581-his son may prove that _ [he]581-his son _ knows it too . ”[108-edmund] Whatever effect [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s little harangue might really produce on [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , it raised some awkward sensations in two of the others , [two of [his]133-mr. crawford most attentive listeners]2041-two of his most attentive listeners — [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford and [Fanny]113-fanny . [One of whom , having never before understood that [Thornton]231-thornton lacey was so soon and so completely to be [[his]133-mr. crawford home]2043-his home]2042-one of whom , having never before understood that thornton was so soon and so completely to be his home , was pondering with downcast eyes on what it would be _ not _ to see [Edmund]108-edmund every day ; and [the other]477-the other , startled from the agreeable fancies [she]477-the other had been previously indulging on the strength of [[her]477-the other brother]451-her brother ’s description , no longer able , in the picture [she]477-the other had been forming of a future [Thornton]231-thornton lacey , to shut out [the church]4265-the church , sink [the clergyman]4269-the clergyman , and see only [the respectable , elegant , modernised , and occasional residence of [a man of independent fortune]2049-a man of independent fortune]2048-the respectable , elegant , modernised , and occasional residence of a man of independent fortune , was considering [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , with decided ill - will , as [the destroyer of all this]2050-the destroyer of all this , and suffering the more from that involuntary forbearance which [his]101-sir thomas character and manner commanded , and from not daring to relieve [herself]477-the other by a single attempt at throwing ridicule on [his]101-sir thomas cause . All the agreeable of _ [her]477-the other _ speculation was over for that hour . It was time to have done with cards , if sermons prevailed ; and [she]477-the other was glad to find it necessary to come to a conclusion , and be able to refresh [her]477-the other spirits by a change of place and neighbour . [The chief of the party]2051-the chief of the party were now collected irregularly round the fire , and waiting the final break - up . [William]228-william and [Fanny]113-fanny were the most detached . [They]2052-them remained together at the otherwise deserted card - table , talking very comfortably , and not thinking of the rest , till some of [the rest]441-the rest began to think of [them]2052-them . [Henry Crawford]131-henry ’s chair was the first to be given a direction towards [them]2052-them , and [he]131-henry sat silently observing [them]2052-them for a few minutes ; [himself]131-henry , in the meanwhile , observed by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , who was standing in chat with [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant . “ This is the assembly night , ”[228-william] said [William]228-william . “ If [I]228-william were at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth [I]228-william should be at it , perhaps . ”[228-william] “ But [you]228-william do not wish [yourself]228-william at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , [William]228-william ? ”[131-henry] “ No , [Fanny]113-fanny , that [I]228-william do not . [I]228-william shall have enough of [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth and of dancing too , when [I]228-william can not have [you]113-fanny . And [I]228-william do not know that there would be any good in going to the assembly , for [I]228-william might not get [a partner]1191-a partner . [The Portsmouth girls]5402-the portsmouth girls turn up [their]5402-the portsmouth girls noses at [anybody who has not a commission]5403-anybody who has not a commission . [One]766-one might as well be nothing as [a midshipman]1938-a midshipman . [One _]5406-one _ is _ nothing , indeed . [You]113-fanny remember [the Gregorys]234-the gregorys ; [they]234-the gregorys are grown up amazing [fine girls]5407-fine girls , but [they]234-the gregorys will hardly speak to _ [me]228-william _ , because [Lucy]235-lucy is courted by [a lieutenant]5408-a lieutenant . ”[228-william] “ Oh ! shame , shame ! But never mind it , [William]228-william ”[2054-i] ( [her]2054-i own cheeks in a glow of indignation as [she]2054-i spoke ) . “ It is not worth minding . It is no reflection on _ [you]113-fanny _ ; it is no more than what [the greatest admirals]5409-the greatest admirals have all experienced , more or less , in [their]5409-the greatest admirals time . [You]113-fanny must think of that , [you]113-fanny must try to make up [your]113-fanny mind to it as one of the hardships which fall to [every sailor]5410-every sailor ’s share , like bad weather and hard living , only with this advantage , that there will be an end to it , that there will come a time when [you]113-fanny will have nothing of that sort to endure . When [you]113-fanny are [a lieutenant]5408-a lieutenant ! only think , [William]228-william , when [you]113-fanny are [a lieutenant]5408-a lieutenant , how little [you]113-fanny will care for any nonsense of this kind . ”[2054-i] “ [I]2054-i begin to think [I]2054-i shall never be [a lieutenant]5408-a lieutenant , [Fanny]113-fanny . [Everybody]408-everybody gets made but [me]2054-i . ”[2054-i] “ Oh ! [[my]2055-my dear]3657-my dear [William]228-william , do not talk so ; do not be so desponding . [[My]2055-my uncle]3761-my uncle says nothing , but [I]2055-my am sure [he]3761-my uncle will do everything in [his]3761-my uncle power to get [you]228-william made . [He]3761-my uncle knows , as well as [you]228-william do , of what consequence it is . ”[2055-my] [She]2055-my was checked by the sight of [[her]2055-my uncle]312-her uncle much nearer to [them]2057-them than [she]2055-my had any suspicion of , and [each]1248-each found it necessary to talk of something else . “ Are [you]228-william fond of dancing , [Fanny]113-fanny ? ”[1248-each] “ Yes , very ; only [I]2054-i am soon tired . ”[2054-i] “ [I]1248-each should like to go to a ball with [you]228-william and see [you]228-william dance . Have [you]228-william never any balls at [Northampton]8-northampton ? [I]1248-each should like to see [you]228-william dance , and [I]1248-each ’d dance with [you]228-william if [you]228-william _ would _ , for [nobody]360-nobody would know who [I]1248-each was [here]3798-here , and [I]1248-each should like to be [[your]228-william partner]5419-your partner once more . [We]2061-we used to jump about together many a time , did not [we]2061-we ? when the hand - organ was in [the street]5420-the street ? [I]1248-each am [a pretty good dancer in [my]1248-each way]5421-a pretty good dancer in my way , but [I]1248-each dare say [you]228-william are a better . ”[1248-each] And turning to [[his]2059-her uncle]526-his uncle , who was now close to [them]2061-we , “ Is not [Fanny]113-fanny [a very good dancer]5422-a very good dancer , [sir]4023-sir ? ”[526-his uncle] [Fanny]113-fanny , in dismay at such an unprecedented question , did not know which way to look , or how to be prepared for the answer . Some very grave reproof , or at least the coldest expression of indifference , must be coming to distress [[her]2059-her brother]451-her brother , and sink [her]2059-her to the ground . But , on the contrary , it was no worse than , “ [I]131-henry am sorry to say that [I]131-henry am unable to answer [your]4023-sir question . [I]131-henry have never seen [Fanny]113-fanny dance since [she]2059-her was [a little girl]5424-a little girl ; but [I]131-henry trust [we]2061-we shall both think [she]2059-her acquits [herself]2059-her like [a gentlewoman]3683-a gentlewoman when [we]2061-we do see [her]2059-her , which , perhaps , [we]2061-we may have an opportunity of doing ere long . ”[131-henry] “ [I]131-henry have had the pleasure of seeing [[your]4023-sir sister]4444-your sister dance , [Mr. Price]228-william , ”[131-henry] said [Henry Crawford]131-henry , leaning forward , “ and will engage to answer every inquiry which [you]4023-sir can make on the subject , to [your]4023-sir entire satisfaction . But [I]131-henry believe ”[131-henry] ( seeing [Fanny]113-fanny looked distressed ) “ it must be at some other time . There is [_ one _ person in company who does not like to have [Miss Price]137-miss price]5427-_ one _ person in company who does not like to have miss price spoken of . ”[131-henry] True enough , [he]131-henry had once seen [Fanny]113-fanny dance ; and it was equally true that [he]131-henry would now have answered for [her]2063-her gliding about with quiet , light elegance , and in admirable time ; but , in fact , [he]131-henry could not for the life of [him]131-henry recall what [her]2063-her dancing had been , and rather took it for granted that [she]2063-her had been present than remembered anything about [her]2063-her . [He]131-henry passed , however , for an admirer of [her]2063-her dancing ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , by no means displeased , prolonged the conversation on dancing in general , and was so well engaged in describing the balls of [Antigua]18-antigua , and listening to what [[his]101-sir thomas nephew]1994-his nephew could relate of the different modes of dancing which had fallen within [his]101-sir thomas observation , that [he]131-henry had not heard [[his]131-henry carriage]4233-his carriage announced , and was first called to the knowledge of it by the bustle of [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris . “ Come , [Fanny]113-fanny , [Fanny]113-fanny , what are [you]113-fanny about ? [We]5428-we are going . Do not [you]113-fanny see [[your]113-fanny aunt]3826-your aunt is going ? Quick , quick ! [I]105-mrs. norris can not bear to keep [good old Wilcox]158-wilcox waiting . [You]113-fanny should always remember [the coachman]1668-the coachman and horses . [[My]105-mrs. norris dear]3657-my dear [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [we]5428-we have settled it that [the carriage]969-the carriage should come back for [you]113-fanny , and [Edmund]108-edmund and [William]228-william . ”[105-mrs. norris] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could not dissent , as it had been [his]101-sir thomas own arrangement , previously communicated to [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife and [sister]3704-sister ; but _ that _ seemed forgotten by [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , who must fancy that [she]105-mrs. norris settled it all [herself]105-mrs. norris . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s last feeling in the visit was disappointment : for the shawl which [Edmund]108-edmund was quietly taking from [the servant]2068-the servant to bring and put round [her]105-mrs. norris shoulders was seized by [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s quicker hand , and [she]105-mrs. norris was obliged to be indebted to [his]133-mr. crawford more prominent attention . CHAPTER XXVI [William]228-william ’s desire of seeing [Fanny]113-fanny dance made more than a momentary impression on [[his]228-william uncle]526-his uncle . The hope of an opportunity , which [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had then given , was not given to be thought of no more . [He]133-mr. crawford remained steadily inclined to gratify so amiable a feeling ; to gratify [anybody else who might wish to see [Fanny]113-fanny dance , and to give pleasure to [the young people in general]1435-the young people in general]2070-anybody else who might wish to see fanny dance , and to give pleasure to the young people in general ; and having thought the matter over , and taken [his]133-mr. crawford resolution in quiet independence , the result of it appeared the next morning at breakfast , when , after recalling and commending what [[his]133-mr. crawford nephew]1994-his nephew had said , [he]133-mr. crawford added , “ [I]133-mr. crawford do not like , [William]228-william , that [you]228-william should leave [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire without this indulgence . It would give [me]133-mr. crawford pleasure to see [you]228-william both dance . [You]228-william spoke of the balls at [Northampton]8-northampton . [[Your]228-william cousins]4848-your cousins have occasionally attended them ; but [they]4848-your cousins would not altogether suit [us]5434-us now . The fatigue would be too much for [[your]228-william aunt]3826-your aunt . [I]133-mr. crawford believe [we]5434-us must not think of a [Northampton]8-northampton ball . A dance at [home]367-home would be more eligible ; and if — ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Ah , [my]105-mrs. norris dear [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ! ”[105-mrs. norris] interrupted [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , “ [I]105-mrs. norris knew what was coming . [I]105-mrs. norris knew what [you]101-sir thomas were going to say . If dear [Julia]112-julia were at [home]367-home , or [dearest Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria at [Sotherton]27-sotherton , to afford a reason , an occasion for such a thing , [you]101-sir thomas would be tempted to give [the young people]391-the young people a dance at [Mansfield]3-mansfield .
