[I]105-mrs. norris know [you]101-sir thomas would . If _ [they]391-the young people _ were at [home]367-home to grace the ball , a ball [you]101-sir thomas would have this very Christmas . Thank [[your]101-sir thomas uncle]3760-your uncle , [William]228-william , thank [[your]101-sir thomas uncle]3760-your uncle ! ”[105-mrs. norris] “ [[My]101-sir thomas daughters]3727-my daughters , ”[101-sir thomas] replied [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , gravely interposing , “ have [their]3727-my daughters pleasures at [Brighton]61-brighton , and [I]101-sir thomas hope are very happy ; but the dance which [I]101-sir thomas think of giving at [Mansfield]3-mansfield will be for [[their]3727-my daughters cousins]5368-their cousins . Could [we]5444-we be all assembled , [our]5444-we satisfaction would undoubtedly be more complete , but the absence of [some]5445-some is not to debar [the others]347-the others of amusement . ”[101-sir thomas] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had not another word to say . [She]105-mrs. norris saw decision in [his]101-sir thomas looks , and [her]105-mrs. norris surprise and vexation required some minutes ’ silence to be settled into composure . A ball at such a time ! [[His]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters absent and [herself]105-mrs. norris not consulted ! There was comfort , however , soon at hand . _ [She]105-mrs. norris _ must be [the doer of everything]2074-the doer of everything : [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram would of course be spared all thought and exertion , and it would all fall upon _ [her]105-mrs. norris _ . [She]105-mrs. norris should have to do the honours of the evening ; and this reflection quickly restored so much of [her]105-mrs. norris good - humour as enabled [her]105-mrs. norris to join in with [the others]347-the others , before [their]347-the others happiness and thanks were all expressed . [Edmund]108-edmund , [William]228-william , and [Fanny]113-fanny did , in [their]347-the others different ways , look and speak as much grateful pleasure in the promised ball as [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could desire . [Edmund]108-edmund ’s feelings were for [the other two]1143-the other two . [[His]108-edmund father]534-his father had never conferred a favour or shewn a kindness more to [his]534-his father satisfaction . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was perfectly quiescent and contented , and had no objections to make . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas engaged for its giving [her]106-lady bertram very little trouble ; and [she]106-lady bertram assured [him]101-sir thomas “ that [she]106-lady bertram was not at all afraid of the trouble ; indeed , [she]106-lady bertram could not imagine there would be any . ”[106-lady bertram] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was ready with [her]105-mrs. norris suggestions as to [the rooms [he]101-sir thomas would think fittest to be used]2078-the rooms he would think fittest to be used , but found it all prearranged ; and when [she]105-mrs. norris would have conjectured and hinted about the day , it appeared that the day was settled too . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had been amusing [himself]101-sir thomas with shaping a very complete outline of the business ; and as soon as [she]105-mrs. norris would listen quietly , could read [his]101-sir thomas list of [the families to be invited]2079-the families to be invited , from whom [he]101-sir thomas calculated , with all necessary allowance for the shortness of the notice , to collect [young people enough to form twelve or fourteen couple]2080-young people enough to form twelve or fourteen couple : and could detail the considerations which had induced [him]101-sir thomas to fix on the 22nd as the most eligible day . [William]228-william was required to be at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth on the 24th ; the 22nd would therefore be the last day of [his]228-william visit ; but where the days were so few it would be unwise to fix on any earlier . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was obliged to be satisfied with thinking just the same , and with having been on the point of proposing the 22nd [herself]105-mrs. norris , as by far the best day for the purpose . The ball was now a settled thing , and before the evening a proclaimed thing to all whom it concerned . Invitations were sent with despatch , and many [a young lady]1192-a young lady went to bed that night with [her]1192-a young lady head full of happy cares as well as [Fanny]113-fanny . To [her]105-mrs. norris the cares were sometimes almost beyond the happiness ; for young and inexperienced , with small means of choice and no confidence in [her]105-mrs. norris own taste , the “ how [she]105-mrs. norris should be dressed ”[105-mrs. norris] was a point of painful solicitude ; and the almost solitary ornament in [her]105-mrs. norris possession , a very pretty amber cross which [William]228-william had brought [her]105-mrs. norris from [Sicily]74-sicily , was the greatest distress of all , for [she]105-mrs. norris had nothing but a bit of ribbon to fasten it to ; and though [she]105-mrs. norris had worn it in that manner once , would it be allowable at such a time in the midst of all the rich ornaments which [she]105-mrs. norris supposed [all the other young ladies]2082-all the other young ladies would appear in ? And yet not to wear it ! [William]228-william had wanted to buy [her]105-mrs. norris a gold chain too , but the purchase had been beyond [his]228-william means , and therefore not to wear the cross might be mortifying [him]228-william . These were anxious considerations ; enough to sober [her]105-mrs. norris spirits even under the prospect of a ball given principally for [her]105-mrs. norris gratification . The preparations meanwhile went on , and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram continued to sit on [her]106-lady bertram sofa without any inconvenience from [them]2083-them . [She]106-lady bertram had some extra visits from [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper , and [[her]106-lady bertram maid]1750-her maid was rather hurried in making up a new dress for [her]106-lady bertram : [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas gave orders , and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ran about ; but all this gave [_]117-_ [her]106-lady bertram _ no trouble , and as [she]106-lady bertram had foreseen , “ there was , in fact , no trouble in the business . ”[106-lady bertram] [Edmund]108-edmund was at this time particularly full of cares : [his]108-edmund mind being deeply occupied in the consideration of two important events now at hand , which were to fix [his]108-edmund fate in life — ordination and matrimony — events of such a serious character as to make the ball , which would be very quickly followed by one of them , appear of less moment in [his]108-edmund eyes than in those of [any other person in [the house]427-the house]2086-any other person in the house . On the 23rd [he]108-edmund was going to [a friend near [Peterborough]75-peterborough]2088-a friend near peterborough , in the same situation as [himself]108-edmund , and [they]2089-they were to receive ordination in the course of the Christmas week . Half [his]108-edmund destiny would then be determined , but the other half might not be so very smoothly wooed . [His]108-edmund duties would be established , but [the wife who was to share , and animate , and reward those duties]2090-the wife who was to share , and animate , and reward those duties , might yet be unattainable . [He]108-edmund knew [his]108-edmund own mind , but [he]108-edmund was not always perfectly assured of knowing [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s . There were points on which [they]2089-they did not quite agree ; there were moments in which [she]127-miss crawford did not seem propitious ; and though trusting altogether to [her]127-miss crawford affection , so far as to be resolved — almost resolved — on bringing it to a decision within a very short time , as soon as the variety of business before [him]108-edmund were arranged , and [he]108-edmund knew what [he]108-edmund had to offer [her]127-miss crawford , [he]108-edmund had many anxious feelings , many doubting hours as to the result . [His]108-edmund conviction of [her]127-miss crawford regard for [him]108-edmund was sometimes very strong ; [he]108-edmund could look back on a long course of encouragement , and [she]127-miss crawford was as perfect in disinterested attachment as in everything else . But at other times doubt and alarm intermingled with [his]108-edmund hopes ; and when [he]108-edmund thought of [her]127-miss crawford acknowledged disinclination for privacy and retirement , [her]127-miss crawford decided preference of a [London]6-london life , what could [he]108-edmund expect but a determined rejection ? unless it were an acceptance even more to be deprecated , demanding such sacrifices of situation and employment on [his]108-edmund side as conscience must forbid . The issue of all depended on one question . Did [she]127-miss crawford love [him]108-edmund well enough to forego what had used to be essential points ? Did [she]127-miss crawford love [him]108-edmund well enough to make them no longer essential ? And this question , which [he]108-edmund was continually repeating to [himself]108-edmund , though oftenest answered with a “ Yes , ”[127-miss crawford] had sometimes its “ No . ”[127-miss crawford] [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was soon to leave [Mansfield]3-mansfield , and on this circumstance the “ no ”[127-miss crawford] and the “ yes ”[127-miss crawford] had been very recently in alternation . [He]108-edmund had seen [her]127-miss crawford eyes sparkle as [she]127-miss crawford spoke of the [dear friend]2091-dear friend ’s letter , which claimed a long visit from [her]127-miss crawford in [London]6-london , and of the kindness of [Henry]131-henry , in engaging to remain where [he]131-henry was till January , that [he]131-henry might convey [her]127-miss crawford thither ; [he]108-edmund had heard [her]127-miss crawford speak of the pleasure of such a journey with an animation which had “ no ”[127-miss crawford] in every tone . But this had occurred on the first day of its being settled , within the first hour of the burst of such enjoyment , when nothing but [the friends [she]127-miss crawford was to visit]2092-the friends she was to visit was before [her]127-miss crawford . [He]108-edmund had since heard [her]127-miss crawford express [herself]127-miss crawford differently , with other feelings , more chequered feelings : [he]108-edmund had heard [her]127-miss crawford tell [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant that [she]127-miss crawford should leave [her]127-miss crawford with regret ; that [she]127-miss crawford began to believe neither [the friends]2093-the friends nor the pleasures [she]127-miss crawford was going to were worth those [she]127-miss crawford left behind ; and that though [she]127-miss crawford felt [she]127-miss crawford must go , and knew [she]127-miss crawford should enjoy [herself]127-miss crawford when once away , [she]127-miss crawford was already looking forward to being at [Mansfield]3-mansfield again . Was there not a “ yes ”[108-edmund] in all this ? With such matters to ponder over , and arrange , and re - arrange , [Edmund]108-edmund could not , on [his]108-edmund own account , think very much of the evening which [the rest of [the family]3724-the family]618-the rest of the family were looking forward to with a more equal degree of strong interest . Independent of [[his]108-edmund two cousins]2096-his two cousins ’ enjoyment in it , the evening was to [him]108-edmund of no higher value than any other appointed meeting of [the two families]3825-the two families might be . In every meeting there was a hope of receiving farther confirmation of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s attachment ; but the whirl of a ballroom , perhaps , was not particularly favourable to the excitement or expression of serious feelings . To engage [her]127-miss crawford early for the two first dances was all the command of individual happiness which [he]108-edmund felt in [his]108-edmund power , and the only preparation for the ball which [he]108-edmund could enter into , in spite of all that was passing around [him]108-edmund on the subject , from morning till night . Thursday was the day of the ball ; and on Wednesday morning [Fanny]113-fanny , still unable to satisfy [herself]113-fanny as to what [she]127-miss crawford ought to wear , determined to seek the counsel of [the more enlightened]2098-the more enlightened , and apply to [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant and [[her]123-mrs. grant sister]331-her sister , whose acknowledged taste would certainly bear [her]127-miss crawford blameless ; and as [Edmund]108-edmund and [William]228-william were gone to [Northampton]8-northampton , and [she]127-miss crawford had reason to think [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford likewise out , [she]127-miss crawford walked down to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage without much fear of wanting an opportunity for private discussion ; and the privacy of such a discussion was a most important part of it to [Fanny]113-fanny , being more than half - ashamed of [her]127-miss crawford own solicitude . [She]127-miss crawford met [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford within a few yards of [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , just setting out to call on [her]127-miss crawford , and as it seemed to [her]127-miss crawford that [[her]127-miss crawford friend]1394-her friend , though obliged to insist on turning back , was unwilling to lose [her]1394-her friend walk , [she]127-miss crawford explained [her]127-miss crawford business at once , and observed , that if [she]127-miss crawford would be so kind as to give [her]127-miss crawford opinion , it might be all talked over as well without doors as within . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford appeared gratified by the application , and after a moment ’s thought , urged [Fanny]113-fanny ’s returning with [her]127-miss crawford in a much more cordial manner than before , and proposed [their]2103-they going up into [[her]127-miss crawford room]2104-her room , where [they]2103-they might have a comfortable coze , without disturbing [Dr.]121-dr. grant and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , who were together in [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room . It was just the plan to suit [Fanny]113-fanny ; and with a great deal of gratitude on [her]127-miss crawford side for such ready and kind attention , [they]2103-they proceeded [indoors]2106-indoors , and [upstairs]4939-upstairs , and were soon deep in the interesting subject . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , pleased with the appeal , gave [her]127-miss crawford all [her]127-miss crawford best judgment and taste , made everything easy by [her]127-miss crawford suggestions , and tried to make everything agreeable by [her]127-miss crawford encouragement . The dress being settled in all its grander parts—“But what shall [you]113-fanny have by way of necklace ? ”[127-miss crawford] said [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . “ Shall not [you]113-fanny wear [[your]113-fanny brother]3938-your brother ’s cross ? ”[127-miss crawford] And as [she]127-miss crawford spoke [she]127-miss crawford was undoing a small parcel , which [Fanny]113-fanny had observed in [her]127-miss crawford hand when [they]2103-they met . [Fanny]113-fanny acknowledged [her]127-miss crawford wishes and doubts on this point : [she]127-miss crawford did not know how either to wear the cross , or to refrain from wearing it . [She]127-miss crawford was answered by having a small trinket - box placed before [her]127-miss crawford , and being requested to chuse from among several gold chains and necklaces . Such had been the parcel with which [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was provided , and such the object of [her]127-miss crawford intended visit : and in the kindest manner [she]127-miss crawford now urged [Fanny]113-fanny ’s taking one for the cross and to keep for [her]127-miss crawford sake , saying everything [she]127-miss crawford could think of to obviate the scruples which were making [Fanny]113-fanny start back at first with a look of horror at the proposal . “ [You]113-fanny see what a collection [I]127-miss crawford have , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford ; “ more by half than [I]127-miss crawford ever use or think of . [I]127-miss crawford do not offer them as new . [I]127-miss crawford offer nothing but an old necklace . [You]113-fanny must forgive the liberty , and oblige [me]127-miss crawford . ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny still resisted , and from [her]127-miss crawford heart . The gift was too valuable . But [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford persevered , and argued the case with so much affectionate earnestness through all the heads of [William]228-william and the cross , and the ball , and [herself]113-fanny , as to be finally successful . [Fanny]113-fanny found [herself]113-fanny obliged to yield , that [she]127-miss crawford might not be accused of pride or indifference , or some other littleness ; and having with modest reluctance given [her]127-miss crawford consent , proceeded to make the selection . [She]127-miss crawford looked and looked , longing to know which might be least valuable ; and was determined in [her]127-miss crawford choice at last , by fancying there was one necklace more frequently placed before [her]127-miss crawford eyes than the rest . It was of gold , prettily worked ; and though [Fanny]113-fanny would have preferred a longer and a plainer chain as more adapted for [her]127-miss crawford purpose , [she]127-miss crawford hoped , in fixing on this , to be chusing what [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford least wished to keep . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford smiled [her]127-miss crawford perfect approbation ; and hastened to complete the gift by putting the necklace round [her]127-miss crawford , and making [her]127-miss crawford see how well it looked . [Fanny]113-fanny had not a word to say against its becomingness , and , excepting what remained of [her]127-miss crawford scruples , was exceedingly pleased with an acquisition so very apropos . [She]127-miss crawford would rather , perhaps , have been obliged to [some other person]2108-some other person . But this was an unworthy feeling . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had anticipated [her]127-miss crawford wants with a kindness which proved [her]127-miss crawford [a real friend]2109-a real friend . “ When [I]127-miss crawford wear this necklace [I]127-miss crawford shall always think of [you]127-miss crawford , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford , “ and feel how very kind [you]127-miss crawford were . ”[127-miss crawford] “ [You]113-fanny must think of [somebody else]5448-somebody else too , when [you]113-fanny wear that necklace , ”[127-miss crawford] replied [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . “ [You]113-fanny must think of [Henry]131-henry , for it was [his]131-henry choice in the first place . [He]131-henry gave it to [me]113-fanny , and with the necklace [I]113-fanny make over to [you]127-miss crawford all the duty of remembering [the original giver]5449-the original giver . It is to be [a family remembrancer]5450-a family remembrancer . [The sister]1940-the sister is not to be in [your]113-fanny mind without bringing [the brother]695-the brother too . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny , in great astonishment and confusion , would have returned the present instantly . To take what had been the gift of [another person]1214-another person , of [a brother]4109-a brother too , impossible ! it must not be ! and with an eagerness and embarrassment quite diverting to [[her]127-miss crawford companion]881-her companion , [she]127-miss crawford laid down the necklace again on its cotton , and seemed resolved either to take another or none at all . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford thought [she]127-miss crawford had never seen [a prettier consciousness]2113-a prettier consciousness . “ [[My]127-miss crawford dear child]3930-my dear child , ”[127-miss crawford] said [she]127-miss crawford , laughing , “ what are [you]3930-my dear child afraid of ? Do [you]3930-my dear child think [Henry]131-henry will claim the necklace as [mine]127-miss crawford , and fancy [you]3930-my dear child did not come honestly by it ? or are [you]3930-my dear child imagining [he]131-henry would be too much flattered by seeing round [your]3930-my dear child lovely throat an ornament which [his]131-henry money purchased three years ago , before [he]131-henry knew there was such a throat in [the world]315-the world ? or perhaps”—looking[127-miss crawford] archly—“you suspect a confederacy between [us]5455-us , and that what [I]127-miss crawford am now doing is with [his]131-henry knowledge and at [his]131-henry desire ? ”[127-miss crawford] With the deepest blushes [Fanny]113-fanny protested against such a thought . “ Well , then , ”[127-miss crawford] replied [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford more seriously , but without at all believing [her]127-miss crawford , “ to convince [me]127-miss crawford that [you]3930-my dear child suspect no trick , and are as unsuspicious of compliment as [I]127-miss crawford have always found [you]3930-my dear child , take the necklace and say no more about it . Its being a gift of [[my]127-miss crawford brother]5456-my brother ’s need not make the smallest difference in [your]3930-my dear child accepting it , as [I]127-miss crawford assure [you]3930-my dear child it makes none in [my]127-miss crawford willingness to part with it . [He]131-henry is always giving [me]127-miss crawford something or other . [I]127-miss crawford have such innumerable presents from [him]131-henry that it is quite impossible for [me]127-miss crawford to value or for [him]131-henry to remember half . And as for this necklace , [I]127-miss crawford do not suppose [I]127-miss crawford have worn it six times : it is very pretty , but [I]127-miss crawford never think of it ; and though [you]3930-my dear child would be most heartily welcome to any other in [my]127-miss crawford trinket - box , [you]3930-my dear child have happened to fix on the very one which , if [I]127-miss crawford have a choice , [I]127-miss crawford would rather part with and see in [your]3930-my dear child possession than any other . Say no more against it , [I]127-miss crawford entreat [you]3930-my dear child . Such a trifle is not worth half so many words . ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny dared not make any farther opposition ; and with renewed but less happy thanks accepted the necklace again , for there was an expression in [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s eyes which [she]127-miss crawford could not be satisfied with . It was impossible for [her]127-miss crawford to be insensible of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s change of manners . [She]127-miss crawford had long seen it . [He]133-mr. crawford evidently tried to please [her]127-miss crawford : [he]133-mr. crawford was gallant , [he]133-mr. crawford was attentive , [he]133-mr. crawford was something like what [he]133-mr. crawford had been to [[her]127-miss crawford cousins]3671-her cousins : [he]133-mr. crawford wanted , [she]127-miss crawford supposed , to cheat [her]127-miss crawford of [her]127-miss crawford tranquillity as [he]133-mr. crawford had cheated [them]3671-her cousins ; and whether [he]133-mr. crawford might not have some concern in this necklace — [she]127-miss crawford could not be convinced that [he]133-mr. crawford had not , for [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , complaisant as [a sister]3681-a sister , was careless as [a woman]644-a woman and [a friend]456-a friend . Reflecting and doubting , and feeling that the possession of what [she]127-miss crawford had so much wished for did not bring much satisfaction , [she]127-miss crawford now walked [home]367-home again , with a change rather than a diminution of cares since [her]127-miss crawford treading that path before . CHAPTER XXVII On reaching [home]367-home [Fanny]113-fanny went immediately [upstairs]4939-upstairs to deposit this unexpected acquisition , this doubtful good of a necklace , in [some favourite box in [the East room]1380-the east room , which held all [her]127-miss crawford smaller treasures]2121-some favourite box in the east room , which held all her smaller treasures ; but on opening the door , what was [her]127-miss crawford surprise to find [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin [Edmund]108-edmund there writing at the table ! Such a sight having never occurred before , was almost as wonderful as it was welcome . “ [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [he]133-mr. crawford directly , leaving [his]133-mr. crawford seat and [his]133-mr. crawford pen , and meeting [her]127-miss crawford with something in [his]133-mr. crawford hand , “ [I]133-mr. crawford beg [your]127-miss crawford pardon for being [here]3798-here . [I]133-mr. crawford came to look for [you]127-miss crawford , and after waiting a little while in hope of [your]127-miss crawford coming in , was making use of [your]127-miss crawford inkstand to explain [my]133-mr. crawford errand . [You]127-miss crawford will find the beginning of a note to [yourself]127-miss crawford ; but [I]133-mr. crawford can now speak [my]133-mr. crawford business , which is merely to beg [your]127-miss crawford acceptance of this little trifle — a chain for [William]228-william ’s cross . [You]127-miss crawford ought to have had it a week ago , but there has been a delay from [[my]133-mr. crawford brother]5456-my brother ’s not being in [town]3698-town by several days so soon as [I]133-mr. crawford expected ; and [I]133-mr. crawford have only just now received it at [Northampton]8-northampton . [I]133-mr. crawford hope [you]127-miss crawford will like the chain itself , [Fanny]113-fanny . [I]133-mr. crawford endeavoured to consult the simplicity of [your]127-miss crawford taste ; but , at any rate , [I]133-mr. crawford know [you]127-miss crawford will be kind to [my]133-mr. crawford intentions , and consider it , as it really is , a token of the love of [one of [[your]127-miss crawford oldest friends]5461-your oldest friends]5460-one of your oldest friends . ”[133-mr. crawford] And so saying , [he]2124-you was hurrying away , before [Fanny]113-fanny , overpowered by a thousand feelings of pain and pleasure , could attempt to speak ; but quickened by one sovereign wish , [she]2125-she then called out , “ Oh ! [cousin]3759-cousin , stop a moment , pray stop ! ”[2125-she] [He]2124-you turned back . “ [I]2125-she can not attempt to thank [you]2124-you , ”[2125-she] [she]2125-she continued , in a very agitated manner ; “ thanks are out of the question . [I]2125-she feel much more than [I]2125-she can possibly express . [Your]2124-you goodness in thinking of [me]2125-she in such a way is beyond — ”[2125-she] “ If that is all [you]2124-you have to say , [Fanny]113-fanny ”[2125-she] smiling and turning away again . “ No , no , it is not . [I]2125-she want to consult [you]2124-you . ”[2125-she] Almost unconsciously [she]2125-she had now undone the parcel [he]2124-you had just put into [her]2125-she hand , and seeing before [her]2125-she , in all the niceness of [jewellers]2126-jewellers ’ packing , a plain gold chain , perfectly simple and neat , [she]2125-she could not help bursting forth again , “ Oh , this is beautiful indeed ! This is the very thing , precisely what [I]2125-she wished for ! This is the only ornament [I]2125-she have ever had a desire to possess . It will exactly suit [my]2125-she cross . They must and shall be worn together . It comes , too , in such an acceptable moment . Oh , [cousin]3759-cousin , [you]2124-you do not know how acceptable it is . ”[2125-she] “ [My]2125-she dear [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny feel these things a great deal too much . [I]2125-she am most happy that [you]113-fanny like the chain , and that it should be here in time for to - morrow ; but [your]113-fanny thanks are far beyond the occasion . Believe [me]2125-she , [I]2125-she have no pleasure in [the world]315-the world superior to that of contributing to [yours]113-fanny . No , [I]2125-she can safely say , [I]2125-she have no pleasure so complete , so unalloyed . It is without a drawback . ”[2125-she] Upon such expressions of affection [Fanny]113-fanny could have lived an hour without saying another word ; but [Edmund]108-edmund , after waiting a moment , obliged [her]2125-she to bring down [her]2125-she mind from its heavenly flight by saying , “ But what is it that [you]113-fanny want to consult [me]108-edmund about ? ”[108-edmund] It was about the necklace , which [she]2125-she was now most earnestly longing to return , and hoped to obtain [his]108-edmund approbation of [her]2125-she doing . [She]2125-she gave the history of [her]2125-she recent visit , and now [her]2125-she raptures might well be over ; for [Edmund]108-edmund was so struck with the circumstance , so delighted with what [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had done , so gratified by such a coincidence of conduct between [them]2127-them , that [Fanny]113-fanny could not but admit the superior power of one pleasure over [his]108-edmund own mind , though it might have its drawback . It was some time before [she]2125-she could get [his]108-edmund attention to [her]2125-she plan , or any answer to [her]2125-she demand of [his]108-edmund opinion : [he]108-edmund was in a reverie of fond reflection , uttering only now and then a few half - sentences of praise ; but when [he]108-edmund did awake and understand , [he]108-edmund was very decided in opposing what [she]2125-she wished . “ Return the necklace ! No , [[my]108-edmund dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , upon no account . It would be mortifying [her]2125-she severely . There can hardly be a more unpleasant sensation than the having anything returned on [our]5466-our hands which [we]5466-our have given with a reasonable hope of its contributing to the comfort of [a friend]456-a friend . Why should [she]2125-she lose a pleasure which [she]2125-she has shewn [herself]2125-she so deserving of ? ”[108-edmund] “ If it had been given to [me]113-fanny in the first instance , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , “ [I]113-fanny should not have thought of returning it ; but being [[her]2125-she brother]451-her brother ’s present , is not it fair to suppose that [she]2125-she would rather not part with it , when it is not wanted ? ”[113-fanny] “ [She]2125-she must not suppose it not wanted , not acceptable , at least : and its having been originally [[her]2125-she brother]451-her brother ’s gift makes no difference ; for as [she]2125-she was not prevented from offering , nor [you]113-fanny from taking it on that account , it ought not to prevent [you]113-fanny from keeping it . No doubt it is handsomer than [mine]113-fanny , and fitter for [a ballroom]5470-a ballroom . ”[108-edmund] “ No , it is not handsomer , not at all handsomer in its way , and , for [my]108-edmund purpose , not half so fit . The chain will agree with [William]228-william ’s cross beyond all comparison better than the necklace . ”[108-edmund] “ For one night , [Fanny]113-fanny , for only one night , if it _ be _ a sacrifice ; [I]2128-i am sure [you]113-fanny will , upon consideration , make that sacrifice rather than give pain to [one who has been so studious of [your]113-fanny comfort]5471-one who has been so studious of your comfort . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s attentions to [you]113-fanny have been — not more than [you]113-fanny were justly entitled to — [I]2128-i am [the last person to think that _ could _ _ be _]5472-the last person to think that _ could _ _ be _ , but they have been invariable ; and to be returning [them]5473-them with what must have something the _ air _ of ingratitude , though [I]2128-i know it could never have the _ meaning _ , is not in [your]113-fanny nature , [I]2128-i am sure . Wear the necklace , as [you]113-fanny are engaged to do , to - morrow evening , and let the chain , which was not ordered with any reference to the ball , be kept for commoner occasions . This is [my]2128-i advice . [I]2128-i would not have the shadow of a coolness between the two whose intimacy [I]2128-i have been observing with the greatest pleasure , and in whose characters there is so much general resemblance in true generosity and natural delicacy as to make the few slight differences , resulting principally from situation , no reasonable hindrance to a perfect friendship . [I]2128-i would not have the shadow of a coolness arise , ”[2128-i] [he]2128-i repeated , [his]2128-i voice sinking a little , “ between the two dearest objects [I]2128-i have on [earth]3674-earth . ”[2128-i] [He]2128-i was gone as [he]2128-i spoke ; and [Fanny]113-fanny remained to tranquillise [herself]113-fanny as [she]2129-her could . [She]2129-her was [one of [[his]2128-i two dearest]2131-his two dearest]2130-one of his two dearest — that must support [her]2129-her . But the other : the first ! [She]2129-her had never heard [him]2128-i speak so openly before , and though it told [her]2129-her no more than what [she]2129-her had long perceived , it was a stab , for it told of [his]2128-i own convictions and views . [They]2132-they were decided . [He]2128-i would marry [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . It was a stab , in spite of every long - standing expectation ; and [she]2129-her was obliged to repeat again and again , that [she]2129-her was one of [[his]2128-i two dearest]2131-his two dearest , before the words gave [her]2129-her any sensation . Could [she]2129-her believe [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford to deserve [him]2128-i , it would be — oh , how different would it be — how far more tolerable ! But [he]2128-i was deceived in [her]2129-her : [he]2128-i gave [her]2129-her merits which [she]2129-her had not ; [her]2129-her faults were what they had ever been , but [he]2128-i saw them no longer . Till [she]2129-her had shed many tears over this deception , [Fanny]113-fanny could not subdue [her]2129-her agitation ; and the dejection which followed could only be relieved by the influence of fervent prayers for [his]2128-i happiness . It was [her]2129-her intention , as [she]2129-her felt it to be [her]2129-her duty , to try to overcome all that was excessive , all that bordered on selfishness , in [her]2129-her affection for [Edmund]108-edmund . To call or to fancy it a loss , a disappointment , would be a presumption for which [she]2129-her had not words strong enough to satisfy [her]2129-her own humility . To think of [him]2128-i as [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford might be justified in thinking , would in [her]2129-her be insanity . To [her]2129-her [he]2128-i could be nothing under any circumstances ; nothing dearer than [a friend]456-a friend . Why did such an idea occur to [her]2129-her even enough to be reprobated and forbidden ? It ought not to have touched on the confines of [her]2129-her imagination . [She]2129-her would endeavour to be rational , and to deserve the right of judging of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s character , and the privilege of true solicitude for [him]2128-i by a sound intellect and an honest heart . [She]2129-her had all the heroism of principle , and was determined to do [her]2129-her duty ; but having also many of the feelings of youth and nature , let [her]2129-her not be much wondered at , if , after making all these good resolutions on the side of self - government , [she]2129-her seized the scrap of paper on which [Edmund]108-edmund had begun writing to [her]2129-her , as a treasure beyond all [her]2129-her hopes , and reading with the tenderest emotion these words , “ [My]2129-her very dear [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny must do [me]2129-her the favour to accept ”[2129-her] locked it up with the chain , as the dearest part of the gift . It was the only thing approaching to a letter which [she]2129-her had ever received from [him]108-edmund ; [she]2129-her might never receive another ; it was impossible that [she]2129-her ever should receive another so perfectly gratifying in the occasion and the style . Two lines more prized had never fallen from the pen of [the most distinguished author]2135-the most distinguished author — never more completely blessed the researches of [the fondest biographer]2136-the fondest biographer . The enthusiasm of [a woman]644-a woman ’s love is even beyond [the biographer]2138-the biographer ’s . To [her]2129-her , the handwriting itself , independent of anything it may convey , is a blessedness . Never were such characters cut by [any other human being]2139-any other human being as [Edmund]108-edmund ’s commonest handwriting gave ! This specimen , written in haste as it was , had not a fault ; and there was a felicity in the flow of the first four words , in the arrangement of “ [[My]108-edmund very dear [Fanny]113-fanny]5475-my very dear fanny , ”[108-edmund] which [she]2129-her could have looked at for ever . Having regulated [her]2129-her thoughts and comforted [her]2129-her feelings by this happy mixture of reason and weakness , [she]2129-her was able in due time to go down and resume [her]2129-her usual employments near [[her]2129-her aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]108-edmund , and pay [her]2129-her the usual observances without any apparent want of spirits . Thursday , predestined to hope and enjoyment , came ; and opened with more kindness to [Fanny]113-fanny than such self - willed , unmanageable days often volunteer , for soon after breakfast a very friendly note was brought from [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford to [William]228-william , stating that as [he]228-william found [himself]228-william obliged to go to [London]6-london on the morrow for a few days , [he]228-william could not help trying to procure [a companion]1122-a companion ; and therefore hoped that if [William]228-william could make up [his]228-william mind to leave [Mansfield]3-mansfield half a day earlier than had been proposed , [he]228-william would accept a place in [[his]228-william carriage]4233-his carriage . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford meant to be in [town]3698-town by [[his]133-mr. crawford uncle]526-his uncle ’s accustomary late dinner - hour , and [William]228-william was invited to dine with [him]133-mr. crawford at [the Admiral ’s]2145-the admiral ’s . The proposal was a very pleasant one to [William]228-william [himself]228-william , who enjoyed the idea of travelling post with four horses , and such [a good - humoured , agreeable friend]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend ; and , in likening it to going up with despatches , was saying at once everything in favour of its happiness and dignity which [his]228-william imagination could suggest ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , from a different motive , was exceedingly pleased ; for the original plan was that [William]228-william should go up by the mail from [Northampton]8-northampton the following night , which would not have allowed [him]228-william an hour ’s rest before [he]228-william must have got into [a Portsmouth coach]2147-a portsmouth coach ; and though this offer of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s would rob [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend of many hours of [his]228-william company , [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend was too happy in having [William]228-william spared from the fatigue of such a journey , to think of anything else . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas approved of it for another reason . [[His]101-sir thomas nephew]1994-his nephew ’s introduction to [Admiral Crawford]128-admiral crawford might be of service . [The Admiral]715-the admiral , [he]101-sir thomas believed , had interest . Upon the whole , it was a very joyous note . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s spirits lived on it half the morning , deriving some accession of pleasure from [its writer]2150-its writer being [himself]101-sir thomas to go away . As for the ball , so near at hand , [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend had too many agitations and fears to have half the enjoyment in anticipation which [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend ought to have had , or must have been supposed to have by [the many young ladies looking forward to the same event in situations more at ease]2151-the many young ladies looking forward to the same event in situations more at ease , but under circumstances of less novelty , less interest , less peculiar gratification , than would be attributed to [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend . [Miss Price]137-miss price , known only by name to half [the people invited]2152-the people invited , was now to make [her]137-miss price first appearance , and must be regarded as [the queen of the evening]2153-the queen of the evening . Who could be happier than [Miss Price]137-miss price ? But [Miss Price]137-miss price had not been brought up to the trade of _ coming _ _ out _ ; and had [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend known in what light this ball was , in general , considered respecting [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend , it would very much have lessened [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend comfort by increasing the fears [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend already had of doing wrong and being looked at . To dance without much observation or any extraordinary fatigue , to have strength and [partners]1200-partners for about half the evening , to dance a little with [Edmund]108-edmund , and not a great deal with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , to see [William]228-william enjoy [himself]228-william , and be able to keep away from [[her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris , was the height of [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend ambition , and seemed to comprehend [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend greatest possibility of happiness . As these were the best of [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend hopes , they could not always prevail ; and in the course of a long morning , spent principally with [[her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend two aunts]1814-her two aunts , [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend was often under the influence of much less sanguine views . [William]228-william , determined to make this last day a day of thorough enjoyment , was out snipe - shooting ; [Edmund]108-edmund , [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend had too much reason to suppose , was at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage ; and left alone to bear the worrying of [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , who was cross because [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper would have [her]1017-the housekeeper own way with the supper , and whom _ [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend _ could not avoid though [the housekeeper]1017-the housekeeper might , [Fanny]113-fanny was worn down at last to think everything an evil belonging to the ball , and when sent off with a parting worry to dress , moved as languidly towards [[her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend own room]1528-her own room , and felt as incapable of happiness as if [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend had been allowed no share in it . As [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend walked slowly [upstairs]4939-upstairs [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend thought of yesterday ; it had been about the same hour that [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend had returned from [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , and found [Edmund]108-edmund in [the East room]1380-the east room . “ Suppose [I]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend were to find [him]108-edmund [there]3696-there again to - day ! ”[2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend] said [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend to [herself]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend , in a fond indulgence of fancy . “ [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said a voice at that moment near [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend . Starting and looking up , [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend saw , across [the lobby [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend had just reached]2164-the lobby she had just reached , [Edmund]108-edmund [himself]108-edmund , standing at the head of a different staircase . [He]108-edmund came towards [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend . “ [You]113-fanny look tired and fagged , [Fanny]113-fanny . [You]113-fanny have been walking too far . ”[108-edmund] “ No , [I]108-edmund have not been out at all . ”[108-edmund] “ Then [you]113-fanny have had fatigues within doors , which are worse . [You]113-fanny had better have gone out . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny , not liking to complain , found it easiest to make no answer ; and though [he]108-edmund looked at [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend with [his]108-edmund usual kindness , [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend believed [he]108-edmund had soon ceased to think of [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend countenance . [He]108-edmund did not appear in spirits : something unconnected with [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend was probably amiss . [They]2165-they proceeded [upstairs]4939-upstairs together , [[their]2165-they rooms]2167-their rooms being on the same floor above . “ [I]108-edmund come from [[Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant ’s]5477-dr. grant ’s , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund presently . “ [You]113-fanny may guess [my]108-edmund errand there , [Fanny]113-fanny . ”[108-edmund] And [he]108-edmund looked so conscious , that [Fanny]113-fanny could think but of one errand , which turned [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend too sick for speech . “ [I]108-edmund wished to engage [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford for the two first dances , ”[108-edmund] was the explanation that followed , and brought [Fanny]113-fanny to life again , enabling [her]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend , as [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend found [she]2146-a good - humoured , agreeable friend was expected to speak , to utter something like an inquiry as to the result . “ Yes , ”[108-edmund] [he]108-edmund answered , “ [she]127-miss crawford is engaged to [me]108-edmund ; but ”[108-edmund] ( with a smile that did not sit easy ) “ [she]127-miss crawford says it is to be the last time that [she]127-miss crawford ever will dance with [me]113-fanny . [She]127-miss crawford is not serious . [I]113-fanny think , [I]113-fanny hope , [I]113-fanny am sure [she]127-miss crawford is not serious ; but [I]113-fanny would rather not hear it . [She]127-miss crawford never has danced with [a clergyman]500-a clergyman , [she]127-miss crawford says , and [she]127-miss crawford never _ will _ . For [my]113-fanny own sake , [I]113-fanny could wish there had been no ball just at — [I]113-fanny mean not this very week , this very day ; to - morrow [I]113-fanny leave [home]367-home . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny struggled for speech , and said , “ [I]113-fanny am very sorry that anything has occurred to distress [you]113-fanny . This ought to be a day of pleasure . [[My]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle meant it so . ”[113-fanny] “ Oh yes , yes ! and it will be a day of pleasure . It will all end right . [I]113-fanny am only vexed for a moment . In fact , it is not that [I]113-fanny consider the ball as ill - timed ; what does it signify ? But , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[113-fanny] stopping [her]2168-her , by taking [her]2168-her hand , and speaking low and seriously , “ [you]113-fanny know what all this means . [You]113-fanny see how it is ; and could tell [me]113-fanny , perhaps better than [I]113-fanny could tell [you]113-fanny , how and why [I]113-fanny am vexed . Let [me]113-fanny talk to [you]113-fanny a little . [You]113-fanny are [a kind , kind listener]5481-a kind , kind listener . [I]113-fanny have been pained by [her]2168-her manner this morning , and can not get the better of it . [I]113-fanny know [her]2168-her disposition to be as sweet and faultless as [your]113-fanny own , but the influence of [[her]2168-her former companions]5482-her former companions makes [her]2168-her seem — gives to [her]2168-her conversation , to [her]2168-her professed opinions , sometimes a tinge of wrong . [She]2168-her does not _ think _ evil , but [she]2168-her speaks it , speaks it in playfulness ; and though [I]113-fanny know it to be playfulness , it grieves [me]113-fanny to the soul . ”[113-fanny] “ The effect of education , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny gently . [Edmund]108-edmund could not but agree to it . “ Yes , [that uncle]5483-that uncle and [aunt]3769-aunt ! [They]5485-they have injured the finest mind ; for sometimes , [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]108-edmund own to [you]113-fanny , it does appear more than manner : it appears as if the mind itself was tainted . ”[108-edmund] [Fanny]113-fanny imagined this to be an appeal to [her]2169-her judgment , and therefore , after a moment ’s consideration , said , “ If [you]108-edmund only want [me]113-fanny as [a listener]842-a listener , [cousin]3759-cousin , [I]113-fanny will be as useful as [I]113-fanny can ; but [I]113-fanny am not qualified for [an adviser]5488-an adviser . Do not ask advice of _ [me]113-fanny _ . [I]113-fanny am not competent . ”[113-fanny] “ [You]108-edmund are right , [Fanny]113-fanny , to protest against such an office , but [you]113-fanny need not be afraid . It is a subject on which [I]108-edmund should never ask advice ; it is the sort of subject on which it had better never be asked ; and [few]5489-few , [I]108-edmund imagine , do ask it , but when [they]5489-few want to be influenced against [their]5489-few conscience . [I]108-edmund only want to talk to [you]113-fanny . ”[108-edmund] “ One thing more . Excuse the liberty ; but take care _ how _ [you]113-fanny talk to [me]2170-me . Do not tell [me]2170-me anything now , which hereafter [you]113-fanny may be sorry for . The time may come — ”[2170-me] The colour rushed into [her]2170-me cheeks as [she]2170-me spoke . “ [Dearest Fanny]236-dearest fanny ! ”[108-edmund] cried [Edmund]108-edmund , pressing [her]2170-me hand to [his]108-edmund lips with almost as much warmth as if it had been [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s , “ [you]113-fanny are all considerate thought ! But it is unnecessary here . The time will never come . No such time as [you]113-fanny allude to will ever come . [I]2171-i begin to think it most improbable : the chances grow less and less ; and even if it should , there will be nothing to be remembered by either [you]113-fanny or [me]2171-i that [we]5490-we need be afraid of , for [I]2171-i can never be ashamed of [my]2171-i own scruples ; and if they are removed , it must be by changes that will only raise [her]127-miss crawford character the more by the recollection of the faults [she]127-miss crawford once had . [You]113-fanny are the only being upon [earth]3674-earth to whom [I]2171-i should say what [I]2171-i have said ; but [you]113-fanny have always known [my]2171-i opinion of [her]127-miss crawford ; [you]113-fanny can bear [me]2171-i witness , [Fanny]113-fanny , that [I]2171-i have never been blinded . How many a time have [we]5490-we talked over [her]127-miss crawford little errors ! [You]113-fanny need not fear [me]2171-i ; [I]2171-i have almost given up every serious idea of [her]127-miss crawford ; but [I]2171-i must be [a blockhead]5492-a blockhead indeed , if , whatever befell [me]2171-i , [I]2171-i could think of [your]113-fanny kindness and sympathy without the sincerest gratitude . ”[2171-i] [He]2171-i had said enough to shake the experience of eighteen . [He]2171-i had said enough to give [Fanny]113-fanny some happier feelings than [she]2172-her had lately known , and with a brighter look , [she]2172-her answered , “ Yes , [cousin]3759-cousin , [I]2172-her am convinced that _ [you]3759-cousin _ would be incapable of anything else , though perhaps some might not . [I]2172-her can not be afraid of hearing anything [you]3759-cousin wish to say . Do not check [yourself]3759-cousin . Tell [me]2172-her whatever [you]3759-cousin like . ”[2172-her] [They]2173-they were now on [the second floor]2174-the second floor , and the appearance of [a housemaid]2175-a housemaid prevented any farther conversation . For [Fanny]113-fanny ’s present comfort it was concluded , perhaps , at the happiest moment : had [he]2171-i been able to talk another five minutes , there is no saying that [he]2171-i might not have talked away all [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s faults and [his]2171-i own despondence . But as it was , [they]2173-they parted with looks on [his]2171-i side of grateful affection , and with some very precious sensations on [hers]2172-her . [She]2172-her had felt nothing like it for hours . Since the first joy from [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s note to [William]228-william had worn away , [she]2172-her had been in a state absolutely the reverse ; there had been no comfort around , no hope within [her]2172-her . Now everything was smiling . [William]228-william ’s good fortune returned again upon [her]2172-her mind , and seemed of greater value than at first . The ball , too — such an evening of pleasure before [her]2172-her ! It was now a real animation ; and [she]2172-her began to dress for it with much of the happy flutter which belongs to a ball . All went well : [she]2172-her did not dislike [her]2172-her own looks ; and when [she]2172-her came to the necklaces again , [her]2172-her good fortune seemed complete , for upon trial the one given [her]2172-her by [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford would by no means go through the ring of the cross . [She]2172-her had , to oblige [Edmund]108-edmund , resolved to wear it ; but it was too large for the purpose . [His]108-edmund , therefore , must be worn ; and having , with delightful feelings , joined the chain and the cross — those memorials of the two most beloved of [her]2172-her heart , those dearest tokens so formed for each other by everything real and imaginary — and put them round [her]2172-her neck , and seen and felt how full of [William]228-william and [Edmund]108-edmund [they]2176-they were , [she]2172-her was able , without an effort , to resolve on wearing [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s necklace too . [She]2172-her acknowledged it to be right . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had a claim ; and when it was no longer to encroach on , to interfere with the stronger claims , the truer kindness of another , [she]127-miss crawford could do [her]127-miss crawford justice even with pleasure to [herself]127-miss crawford . The necklace really looked very well ; and [Fanny]113-fanny left [[her]2172-her room]2104-her room at last , comfortably satisfied with [herself]2172-her and all about [her]2172-her . [[Her]2172-her aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]108-edmund had recollected [her]2172-her on this occasion with an unusual degree of wakefulness . It had really occurred to [her]2172-her , unprompted , that [Fanny]113-fanny , preparing for a ball , might be glad of better help than [the upper housemaid]2179-the upper housemaid ’s , and when dressed [herself]2172-her , [she]2172-her actually sent [[her]2172-her own maid]2180-her own maid to assist [her]2172-her ; too late , of course , to be of any use . [Mrs. Chapman]237-chapman had just reached the attic floor , when [Miss Price]137-miss price came out of [[her]137-miss price room]2104-her room completely dressed , and only civilities were necessary ; but [Fanny]113-fanny felt [[her]2172-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s attention almost as much as [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram or [Mrs. Chapman]237-chapman could do [themselves]2183-themselves . CHAPTER XXVIII [[Her]2172-her uncle]312-her uncle and both [[her]2172-her aunts]624-her aunts were in [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room when [Fanny]113-fanny went down . To the former [she]2172-her was an interesting object , and [he]312-her uncle saw with pleasure the general elegance of [her]2172-her appearance , and [her]2172-her being in remarkably good looks . The neatness and propriety of [her]2172-her dress was all that [he]312-her uncle would allow [himself]312-her uncle to commend in [her]2172-her presence , but upon [her]2172-her leaving [the room]412-the room again soon afterwards , [he]312-her uncle spoke of [her]2172-her beauty with very decided praise . “ Yes , ”[106-lady bertram] said [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , “ [she]2172-her looks very well . [I]106-lady bertram sent [Chapman]237-chapman to [her]2172-her . ”[106-lady bertram] “ Look well ! Oh , yes ! ”[105-mrs. norris] cried [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , “ [she]2172-her has good reason to look well with all [her]2172-her advantages : brought up in [this family]5494-this family as [she]2172-her has been , with all the benefit of [[her]2172-her cousins]3671-her cousins ’ manners before [her]2172-her . Only think , [my]105-mrs. norris dear [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , what extraordinary advantages [you]101-sir thomas and [I]105-mrs. norris have been the means of giving [her]2172-her . The very gown [you]101-sir thomas have been taking notice of is [your]101-sir thomas own generous present to [her]2172-her when dear [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria married . What would [she]2172-her have been if [we]2188-we had not taken [her]2172-her by the hand ? ”[105-mrs. norris] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas said no more ; but when [they]2188-we sat down to table the eyes of [the two young men]2189-the two young men assured [him]101-sir thomas that the subject might be gently touched again , when [the ladies]577-the ladies withdrew , with more success . [Fanny]113-fanny saw that [she]2191-her was approved ; and the consciousness of looking well made [her]2191-her look still better . From a variety of causes [she]2191-her was happy , and [she]2191-her was soon made still happier ; for in following [[her]2191-her aunts]624-her aunts out of [the room]412-the room , [Edmund]108-edmund , who was holding open the door , said , as [she]2191-her passed [him]108-edmund , “ [You]2191-her must dance with [me]108-edmund , [Fanny]113-fanny ; [you]2191-her must keep two dances for [me]108-edmund ; any two that [you]2191-her like , except the first . ”[108-edmund] [She]2191-her had nothing more to wish for . [She]2191-her had hardly ever been in a state so nearly approaching high spirits in [her]2191-her life . [[Her]2191-her cousins]3671-her cousins ’ former gaiety on the day of a ball was no longer surprising to [her]2191-her ; [she]2191-her felt it to be indeed very charming , and was actually practising [her]2191-her steps about [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room as long as [she]2191-her could be safe from the notice of [[her]2191-her aunt]463-her aunt Norris , who was entirely taken up at first in fresh arranging and injuring the noble fire which [the butler]1461-the butler had prepared . Half an hour followed that would have been at least languid under any other circumstances , but [Fanny]113-fanny ’s happiness still prevailed . It was but to think of [her]2191-her conversation with [Edmund]108-edmund , and what was the restlessness of [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ? What were the yawns of [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ? [The gentlemen]4865-the gentlemen joined [them]4865-the gentlemen ; and soon after began the sweet expectation of [a carriage]5211-a carriage , when a general spirit of ease and enjoyment seemed diffused , and [they]4865-the gentlemen all stood about and talked and laughed , and every moment had its pleasure and its hope . [Fanny]113-fanny felt that there must be a struggle in [Edmund]108-edmund ’s cheerfulness , but it was delightful to see the effort so successfully made . When [the carriages]2200-the carriages were really heard , when [the guests]2201-the guests began really to assemble , [her]2191-her own gaiety of heart was much subdued : the sight of [so many strangers]2202-so many strangers threw [her]2191-her back into [herself]2191-her ; and besides the gravity and formality of the first great circle , which the manners of neither [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas nor [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram were of a kind to do away , [she]2191-her found [herself]2191-her occasionally called on to endure something worse . [She]2191-her was introduced here and there by [[her]2191-her uncle]312-her uncle , and forced to be spoken to , and to curtsey , and speak again . This was a hard duty , and [she]2191-her was never summoned to it without looking at [William]228-william , as [he]228-william walked about at [his]228-william ease in the background of the scene , and longing to be with [him]228-william . The entrance of [the Grants]122-the grants and [Crawfords]135-the crawfords was a favourable epoch . The stiffness of the meeting soon gave way before [their]2204-their popular manners and more diffused intimacies : [little groups]2205-little groups were formed , and [everybody]408-everybody grew comfortable . [Fanny]113-fanny felt the advantage ; and , drawing back from the toils of civility , would have been again most happy , could [she]2191-her have kept [her]2191-her eyes from wandering between [Edmund]108-edmund and [Mary Crawford]132-mary . _ [She]2191-her _ looked all loveliness — and what might not be the end of it ? [Her]2191-her own musings were brought to an end on perceiving [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford before [her]2191-her , and [her]2191-her thoughts were put into another channel by [his]133-mr. crawford engaging [her]2191-her almost instantly for the first two dances . [Her]2191-her happiness on this occasion was very much _ à la mortal _ , finely chequered . To be secure of [a partner]1191-a partner at first was a most essential good — for the moment of beginning was now growing seriously near ; and [she]2191-her so little understood [her]2191-her own claims as to think that if [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford had not asked [her]2191-her , [she]2191-her must have been the last to be sought after , and should have received [a partner]1191-a partner only through a series of inquiry , and bustle , and interference , which would have been terrible ; but at the same time there was a pointedness in [his]133-mr. crawford manner of asking [her]2191-her which [she]2191-her did not like , and [she]2191-her saw [his]133-mr. crawford eye glancing for a moment at [her]2191-her necklace , with a smile — [she]2191-her thought there was a smile — which made [her]2191-her blush and feel wretched . And though there was no second glance to disturb [her]2191-her , though [his]133-mr. crawford object seemed then to be only quietly agreeable , [she]2191-her could not get the better of [her]2191-her embarrassment , heightened as it was by the idea of [his]133-mr. crawford perceiving it , and had no composure till [he]133-mr. crawford turned away to [some one else]2209-some one else . Then [she]2191-her could gradually rise up to the genuine satisfaction of having [a partner]1191-a partner , [a voluntary partner]2211-a voluntary partner , secured against the dancing began . When [the company]4721-the company were moving into [the ballroom]2213-the ballroom , [she]2191-her found [herself]2191-her for the first time near [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , whose eyes and smiles were immediately and more unequivocally directed as [[her]2191-her brother]451-her brother ’s had been , and who was beginning to speak on the subject , when [Fanny]113-fanny , anxious to get the story over , hastened to give the explanation of the second necklace : the real chain . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford listened ; and all [her]127-miss crawford intended compliments and insinuations to [Fanny]113-fanny were forgotten : [she]127-miss crawford felt only one thing ; and [her]127-miss crawford eyes , bright as they had been before , [shewing]2215-shewing they could yet be brighter , [she]127-miss crawford exclaimed with eager pleasure , “ Did [he]2216-he ? Did [Edmund]108-edmund ? That was like [himself]2216-he . [No other man]5496-no other man would have thought of it . [I]127-miss crawford honour [him]2216-he beyond expression . ”[127-miss crawford] And [she]127-miss crawford looked around as if longing to tell [him]2216-he so . [He]2216-he was not near , [he]2216-he was attending a party of ladies out of [the room]412-the room ; and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant coming up to [the two girls]397-the two girls , and taking an arm of [each]1248-each , [they]397-the two girls followed with [the rest]441-the rest . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s heart sunk , but there was no leisure for thinking long even of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s feelings . [They]397-the two girls were in [the ballroom]2213-the ballroom , the violins were playing , and [her]127-miss crawford mind was in a flutter that forbade its fixing on anything serious . [She]127-miss crawford must watch the general arrangements , and see how everything was done . In a few minutes [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas came to [her]127-miss crawford , and asked if [she]127-miss crawford were engaged ; and the “ Yes , [sir]4023-sir ; to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , ”[101-sir thomas] was exactly what [he]101-sir thomas had intended to hear . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was not far off ; [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas brought [him]133-mr. crawford to [her]127-miss crawford , saying something which discovered to [Fanny]113-fanny , that _ [she]127-miss crawford _ was to lead the way and open the ball ; an idea that had never occurred to [her]127-miss crawford before . Whenever [she]127-miss crawford had thought of the minutiae of the evening , it had been as a matter of course that [Edmund]108-edmund would begin with [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; and the impression was so strong , that though _ [[her]127-miss crawford _ _ uncle]2222-her _ _ uncle _ spoke the contrary , [she]127-miss crawford could not help an exclamation of surprise , a hint of [her]127-miss crawford unfitness , an entreaty even to be excused . To be urging [her]127-miss crawford opinion against [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s was a proof of the extremity of the case ; but such was [her]127-miss crawford horror at the first suggestion , that [she]127-miss crawford could actually look [him]101-sir thomas in the face and say that [she]127-miss crawford hoped it might be settled otherwise ; in vain , however : [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas smiled , tried to encourage [her]127-miss crawford , and then looked too serious , and said too decidedly , “ It must be so , [[my]101-sir thomas dear]3657-my dear , ”[101-sir thomas] for [her]127-miss crawford to hazard another word ; and [she]127-miss crawford found [herself]127-miss crawford the next moment conducted by [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford to the top of [the room]412-the room , and standing there to be joined by [the rest of [the dancers]1198-the dancers]2224-the rest of the dancers , couple after [couple]2226-couple , as [they]2224-the rest of the dancers were formed . [She]127-miss crawford could hardly believe it . To be placed above [so many elegant young women]2227-so many elegant young women ! The distinction was too great . It was treating [her]127-miss crawford like [[her]127-miss crawford cousins]3671-her cousins ! And [her]127-miss crawford thoughts flew to [those absent cousins]2229-those absent cousins with most unfeigned and truly tender regret , that [they]2229-those absent cousins were not at [home]367-home to take [their]2229-those absent cousins own place in [the room]412-the room , and have [their]2229-those absent cousins share of a pleasure which would have been so very delightful to [them]2229-those absent cousins . So often as [she]127-miss crawford had heard [them]2229-those absent cousins wish for a ball at [home]367-home as the greatest of all felicities ! And to have [them]2229-those absent cousins away when it was given — and for _ [her]127-miss crawford _ to be opening the ball — and with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford too ! [She]127-miss crawford hoped [they]2229-those absent cousins would not envy [her]127-miss crawford that distinction _ now _ ; but when [she]127-miss crawford looked back to the state of things in the autumn , to what [they]2229-those absent cousins had all been to [each other]681-each other when once dancing in [that house]1793-that house before , the present arrangement was almost more than [she]127-miss crawford could understand [herself]127-miss crawford . The ball began . It was rather honour than happiness to [Fanny]113-fanny , for the first dance at least : [[her]127-miss crawford partner]1202-her partner was in excellent spirits , and tried to impart them to [her]127-miss crawford ; but [she]127-miss crawford was a great deal too much frightened to have any enjoyment till [she]127-miss crawford could suppose [herself]127-miss crawford no longer looked at . Young , pretty , and gentle , however , [she]127-miss crawford had no awkwardnesses that were not as good as graces , and there were [few persons present that were not disposed to praise [her]127-miss crawford]2236-few persons present that were not disposed to praise her . [She]127-miss crawford was attractive , [she]127-miss crawford was modest , [she]127-miss crawford was [[Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s niece]2237-sir thomas ’s niece , and [she]127-miss crawford was soon said to be admired by [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . It was enough to give [her]127-miss crawford general favour . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas [himself]101-sir thomas was watching [her]127-miss crawford progress down the dance with much complacency ; [he]101-sir thomas was proud of [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece ; and without attributing all [her]127-miss crawford personal beauty , as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris seemed to do , to [her]127-miss crawford transplantation to [Mansfield]130-mansfield , [he]101-sir thomas was pleased with [himself]101-sir thomas for having supplied everything else : education and manners [she]127-miss crawford owed to [him]101-sir thomas . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford saw much of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s thoughts as [he]101-sir thomas stood , and having , in spite of all [his]101-sir thomas wrongs towards [her]127-miss crawford , a general prevailing desire of recommending [herself]127-miss crawford to [him]101-sir thomas , took an opportunity of stepping aside to say something agreeable of [Fanny]113-fanny . [Her]127-miss crawford praise was warm , and [he]101-sir thomas received it as [she]127-miss crawford could wish , joining in it as far as discretion , and politeness , and slowness of speech would allow , and certainly appearing to greater advantage on the subject than [[his]101-sir thomas lady]1778-his lady did soon afterwards , when [Mary]132-mary , perceiving [her]127-miss crawford on a sofa very near , turned round before [she]127-miss crawford began to dance , to compliment [her]127-miss crawford on [Miss Price]137-miss price ’s looks . “ Yes , [she]127-miss crawford does look very well , ”[106-lady bertram] was [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s placid reply . “ [Chapman]237-chapman helped [her]127-miss crawford to dress . [I]127-miss crawford sent [Chapman]237-chapman to [her]127-miss crawford . ”[127-miss crawford] Not but that [she]127-miss crawford was really pleased to have [Fanny]113-fanny admired ; but [she]127-miss crawford was so much more struck with [her]127-miss crawford own kindness in sending [Chapman]237-chapman to [her]127-miss crawford , that [she]127-miss crawford could not get it out of [her]127-miss crawford head . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford knew [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris too well to think of gratifying _ [her]105-mrs. norris _ by commendation of [Fanny]113-fanny ; to [her]105-mrs. norris , it was as the occasion offered—“Ah ! ma’am , how much [we]5499-we want dear [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria and [Julia]112-julia to - night ! ”[105-mrs. norris] and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris paid [her]105-mrs. norris with as many smiles and courteous words as [she]105-mrs. norris had time for , amid so much occupation as [she]105-mrs. norris found for [herself]105-mrs. norris in making up card - tables , giving hints to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and trying to move [all the chaperons]2240-all the chaperons to a better part of [the room]412-the room . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford blundered most towards [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny in [her]105-mrs. norris intentions to please . [She]127-miss crawford meant to be giving [her]105-mrs. norris little heart a happy flutter , and filling [her]105-mrs. norris with sensations of delightful self - consequence ; and , misinterpreting [Fanny]113-fanny ’s blushes , still thought [she]127-miss crawford must be doing so when [she]127-miss crawford went to [her]105-mrs. norris after the two first dances , and said , with a significant look , “ Perhaps _ [you]105-mrs. norris _ can tell [me]127-miss crawford why [[my]127-miss crawford brother]5456-my brother goes to [town]3698-town to - morrow ? [He]5456-my brother says [he]5456-my brother has business [there]3696-there , but will not tell [me]127-miss crawford what . The first time [he]5456-my brother ever denied [me]127-miss crawford [his]5456-my brother confidence ! But this is what [we]5503-we all come to . [All]874-all are supplanted sooner or later . Now , [I]127-miss crawford must apply to [you]105-mrs. norris for information . Pray , what is [Henry]131-henry going for ? ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny protested [her]105-mrs. norris ignorance as steadily as [her]105-mrs. norris embarrassment allowed . “ Well , then , ”[127-miss crawford] replied [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , laughing , “ [I]127-miss crawford must suppose it to be purely for the pleasure of conveying [[your]105-mrs. norris brother]3938-your brother , and of talking of [you]105-mrs. norris by the way . ”[127-miss crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny was confused , but it was the confusion of discontent ; while [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford wondered [she]127-miss crawford did not smile , and thought [her]105-mrs. norris over - anxious , or thought [her]105-mrs. norris odd , or thought [her]105-mrs. norris anything rather than insensible of pleasure in [Henry]131-henry ’s attentions . [Fanny]113-fanny had a good deal of enjoyment in the course of the evening ; but [Henry]131-henry ’s attentions had very little to do with it . [She]105-mrs. norris would much rather _ not _ have been asked by [him]131-henry again so very soon , and [she]105-mrs. norris wished [she]105-mrs. norris had not been obliged to suspect that [his]131-henry previous inquiries of [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , about the supper hour , were all for the sake of securing [her]105-mrs. norris at that part of the evening . But it was not to be avoided : [he]131-henry made [her]105-mrs. norris feel that [she]105-mrs. norris was the object of all ; though [she]105-mrs. norris could not say that it was unpleasantly done , that there was indelicacy or ostentation in [his]131-henry manner ; and sometimes , when [he]131-henry talked of [William]228-william , [he]131-henry was really not unagreeable , and [shewed]2242-shewed even a warmth of heart which did [him]131-henry credit . But still [his]131-henry attentions made no part of [her]105-mrs. norris satisfaction . [She]105-mrs. norris was happy whenever [she]105-mrs. norris looked at [William]228-william , and saw how perfectly [he]228-william was enjoying [himself]228-william , in every five minutes that [she]105-mrs. norris could walk about with [him]228-william and hear [his]228-william account of [[his]228-william partners]2243-his partners ; [she]105-mrs. norris was happy in knowing [herself]105-mrs. norris admired ; and [she]105-mrs. norris was happy in having the two dances with [Edmund]108-edmund still to look forward to , during the greatest part of the evening , [her]105-mrs. norris hand being so eagerly sought after that [her]105-mrs. norris indefinite engagement with _ [him]131-henry _ was in continual perspective . [She]105-mrs. norris was happy even when they did take place ; but not from any flow of spirits on [his]131-henry side , or any such expressions of tender gallantry as had blessed the morning . [His]131-henry mind was fagged , and [her]105-mrs. norris happiness sprung from being [the friend with whom it could find repose]2244-the friend with whom it could find repose . “ [I]131-henry am worn out with civility , ”[131-henry] said [he]131-henry . “ [I]131-henry have been talking incessantly all night , and with nothing to say . But with _ [you]105-mrs. norris _ , [Fanny]113-fanny , there may be peace . [You]105-mrs. norris will not want to be talked to . Let [us]2245-they have the luxury of silence . ”[131-henry] [Fanny]113-fanny would hardly even speak [her]105-mrs. norris agreement . A weariness , arising probably , in great measure , from the same feelings which [he]131-henry had acknowledged in the morning , was peculiarly to be respected , and [they]2245-they went down [their]2245-they two dances together with such sober tranquillity as might satisfy [any looker - on]2246-any looker - on that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had been bringing up [no wife for [[his]101-sir thomas younger son]2248-his younger son]2247-no wife for his younger son . The evening had afforded [Edmund]108-edmund little pleasure . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had been in gay spirits when [they]2245-they first danced together , but it was not [her]127-miss crawford gaiety that could do [him]131-henry good : it rather sank than raised [his]131-henry comfort ; and afterwards , for [he]131-henry found [himself]131-henry still impelled to seek [her]127-miss crawford again , [she]127-miss crawford had absolutely pained [him]131-henry by [her]127-miss crawford manner of speaking of the profession to which [he]131-henry was now on the point of belonging . [They]2245-they had talked , and [they]2245-they had been silent ; [he]131-henry had reasoned , [she]127-miss crawford had ridiculed ; and [they]2245-they had parted at last with mutual vexation . [Fanny]113-fanny , not able to refrain entirely from observing [them]2245-they , had seen enough to be tolerably satisfied . It was barbarous to be happy when [Edmund]108-edmund was suffering . Yet some happiness must and would arise from the very conviction that [he]108-edmund did suffer . When [her]127-miss crawford two dances with [him]131-henry were over , [her]127-miss crawford inclination and strength for more were pretty well at an end ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , having seen [her]127-miss crawford walk rather than dance down the shortening set , breathless , and with [her]127-miss crawford hand at [her]127-miss crawford side , gave [his]101-sir thomas orders for [her]127-miss crawford sitting down entirely . From that time [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford sat down likewise . “ [Poor Fanny]113-fanny ! ”[228-william] cried [William]228-william , coming for a moment to visit [her]127-miss crawford , and working away [[his]228-william partner]2249-his partner ’s fan as if for life , “ how soon [she]127-miss crawford is knocked up ! Why , the sport is but just begun . [I]228-william hope [we]5506-we shall keep it up these two hours . How can [you]127-miss crawford be tired so soon ? ”[228-william] “ So soon ! [[my]101-sir thomas good friend]4754-my good friend , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , producing [his]101-sir thomas watch with all necessary caution ; “ it is three o’clock , and [[your]127-miss crawford sister]4444-your sister is not used to these sort of hours . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Well , then , [Fanny]113-fanny , [you]113-fanny shall not get up to - morrow before [I]228-william go . Sleep as long as [you]113-fanny can , and never mind [me]228-william . ”[228-william] “ Oh ! [William]228-william . ”[228-william] “ What !
