Having so satisfactorily settled the conviction [her]2421-she note would convey , [she]2421-she could not but be astonished to see [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , as [she]2421-she accidentally did , coming up to [the house]427-the house again , and at an hour as early as the day before . [His]133-mr. crawford coming might have nothing to do with [her]2421-she , but [she]2421-she must avoid seeing [him]133-mr. crawford if possible ; and being then on [her]2421-she way [upstairs]4939-upstairs , [she]2421-she resolved there to remain , during the whole of [his]133-mr. crawford visit , unless actually sent for ; and as [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris was still in [the house]427-the house , there seemed little danger of [her]2421-she being wanted . [She]2421-she sat some time in a good deal of agitation , listening , trembling , and fearing to be sent for every moment ; but as no footsteps approached [the East room]1380-the east room , [she]2421-she grew gradually composed , could sit down , and be able to employ [herself]2421-she , and able to hope that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford had come and would go without [her]2421-she being obliged to know anything of the matter . Nearly half an hour had passed , and [she]2421-she was growing very comfortable , when suddenly the sound of a step in regular approach was heard ; a heavy step , an unusual step in that part of [the house]427-the house : it was [[her]2421-she uncle]312-her uncle ’s ; [she]2421-she knew it as well as [his]133-mr. crawford voice ; [she]2421-she had trembled at it as often , and began to tremble again , at the idea of [his]133-mr. crawford coming up to speak to [her]2421-she , whatever might be the subject . It was indeed [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas who opened the door and asked if [she]2421-she were [there]3696-there , and if [he]133-mr. crawford might come in . The terror of [his]133-mr. crawford former occasional visits to [that room]1389-that room seemed all renewed , and [she]2421-she felt as if [he]133-mr. crawford were going to examine [her]2421-she again in French and English . [She]2421-she was all attention , however , in placing a chair for [him]133-mr. crawford , and trying to appear honoured ; and , in [her]2421-she agitation , had quite overlooked the deficiencies of [[her]2421-she apartment]2435-her apartment , till [he]133-mr. crawford , stopping short as [he]133-mr. crawford entered , said , with much surprise , “ Why have [you]2421-she no fire to - day ? ”[133-mr. crawford] There was snow on the ground , and [she]2421-she was sitting in a shawl . [She]2421-she hesitated . “ [I]2421-she am not cold , [sir]4023-sir : [I]2421-she never sit [here]3798-here long at this time of year . ”[2421-she] “ But [you]4023-sir have a fire in general ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ No , [sir]4023-sir . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ How comes this about ? Here must be some mistake . [I]2421-she understood that [you]4023-sir had the use of [this room]4656-this room by way of making [you]4023-sir perfectly comfortable . In [[your]4023-sir bedchamber]5677-your bedchamber [I]2421-she know [you]4023-sir _ can not _ have a fire . Here is some great misapprehension which must be rectified . It is highly unfit for [you]4023-sir to sit , be it only half an hour a day , without a fire . [You]4023-sir are not strong . [You]4023-sir are chilly . [[Your]4023-sir aunt]3826-your aunt can not be aware of this . ”[2421-she] [Fanny]113-fanny would rather have been silent ; but being obliged to speak , [she]2436-she could not forbear , in justice to [the aunt]4162-the aunt [she]2436-she loved best , from saying something in which the words “ [[my]133-mr. crawford aunt]3803-my aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris ”[133-mr. crawford] were distinguishable . “ [I]312-her uncle understand , ”[312-her uncle] cried [[her]2436-she uncle]312-her uncle , recollecting [himself]312-her uncle , and not wanting to hear more : “ [I]312-her uncle understand . [[Your]4023-sir aunt]3826-your aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris has always been [an advocate]5681-an advocate , and very judiciously , for [young people]4599-young people ’s being brought up without unnecessary indulgences ; but there should be moderation in everything . [She]105-mrs. norris is also very hardy [herself]105-mrs. norris , which of course will influence [her]105-mrs. norris in [her]105-mrs. norris opinion of the wants of [others]361-others . And on another account , too , [I]312-her uncle can perfectly comprehend . [I]312-her uncle know what [her]105-mrs. norris sentiments have always been . The principle was good in itself , but it may have been , and [I]312-her uncle believe _ has _ _ been _ , carried too far in [your]4023-sir case . [I]312-her uncle am aware that there has been sometimes , in some points , a misplaced distinction ; but [I]312-her uncle think too well of [you]4023-sir , [Fanny]113-fanny , to suppose [you]4023-sir will ever harbour resentment on that account . [You]4023-sir have an understanding which will prevent [you]4023-sir from receiving things only in part , and judging partially by the event . [You]4023-sir will take in the whole of the past , [you]4023-sir will consider times , [persons]5684-persons , and probabilities , and [you]4023-sir will feel that _ [they]5685-they _ were not least [[your]4023-sir friends who were educating and preparing [you]4023-sir for that mediocrity of condition which _ seemed _ to be [your]4023-sir lot]5686-your friends who were educating and preparing you for that mediocrity of condition which _ seemed _ to be your lot . Though [their]5685-they caution may prove eventually unnecessary , it was kindly meant ; and of this [you]4023-sir may be assured , that every advantage of affluence will be doubled by the little privations and restrictions that may have been imposed . [I]312-her uncle am sure [you]4023-sir will not disappoint [my]312-her uncle opinion of [you]4023-sir , by failing at any time to treat [[your]4023-sir aunt]3826-your aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris with the respect and attention that are due to [her]105-mrs. norris . But enough of this . Sit down , [[my]312-her uncle dear]3657-my dear . [I]312-her uncle must speak to [you]4023-sir for a few minutes , but [I]312-her uncle will not detain [you]4023-sir long . ”[312-her uncle] [Fanny]113-fanny obeyed , with eyes cast down and colour rising . After a moment ’s pause , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , trying to suppress a smile , went on . “ [You]4023-sir are not aware , perhaps , that [I]101-sir thomas have had [a visitor]5689-a visitor this morning . [I]101-sir thomas had not been long in [[my]101-sir thomas own room]4968-my own room , after breakfast , when [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was shewn in . [His]133-mr. crawford errand [you]4023-sir may probably conjecture . ”[101-sir thomas] [Fanny]113-fanny ’s colour grew deeper and deeper ; and [[her]2439-her uncle]312-her uncle , perceiving that [she]2439-her was embarrassed to a degree that made either speaking or looking up quite impossible , turned away [his]312-her uncle own eyes , and without any farther pause proceeded in [his]312-her uncle account of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s visit . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s business had been to declare [himself]133-mr. crawford [the lover of [Fanny]113-fanny]2441-the lover of fanny , make decided proposals for [her]2439-her , and entreat the sanction of [the uncle]2442-the uncle , who seemed to stand in the place of [[her]2439-her parents]2443-her parents ; and [he]133-mr. crawford had done it all so well , so openly , so liberally , so properly , that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , feeling , moreover , [his]101-sir thomas own replies , and [his]101-sir thomas own remarks to have been very much to the purpose , was exceedingly happy to give the particulars of [their]2444-their conversation ; and little aware of what was passing in [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece ’s mind , conceived that by such details [he]101-sir thomas must be gratifying [her]2439-her far more than [himself]101-sir thomas . [He]101-sir thomas talked , therefore , for several minutes without [Fanny]113-fanny ’s daring to interrupt [him]101-sir thomas . [She]2439-her had hardly even attained the wish to do it . [Her]2439-her mind was in too much confusion . [She]2439-her had changed [her]2439-her position ; and , with [her]2439-her eyes fixed intently on one of the windows , was listening to [[her]2439-her uncle]312-her uncle in the utmost perturbation and dismay . For a moment [he]101-sir thomas ceased , but [she]2439-her had barely become conscious of it , when , rising from [his]101-sir thomas chair , [he]101-sir thomas said , “ And now , [Fanny]113-fanny , having performed one part of [my]101-sir thomas commission , and shewn [you]113-fanny everything placed on a basis the most assured and satisfactory , [I]101-sir thomas may execute the remainder by prevailing on [you]113-fanny to accompany [me]101-sir thomas [downstairs]1808-downstairs , where , though [I]101-sir thomas can not but presume on having been no unacceptable companion [myself]101-sir thomas , [I]101-sir thomas must submit to [your]113-fanny finding one still better worth listening to . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , as [you]113-fanny have perhaps foreseen , is yet in [the house]427-the house . [He]133-mr. crawford is in [[my]101-sir thomas room]5693-my room , and hoping to see [you]113-fanny [there]3696-there . ”[101-sir thomas] There was a look , a start , an exclamation on hearing this , which astonished [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ; but what was [his]101-sir thomas increase of astonishment on hearing [her]2447-her exclaim—“Oh ! no , [sir]4023-sir , [I]101-sir thomas can not , indeed [I]101-sir thomas can not go down to [him]133-mr. crawford . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ought to know — [he]133-mr. crawford must know that : [I]101-sir thomas told [him]133-mr. crawford enough yesterday to convince [him]133-mr. crawford ; [he]133-mr. crawford spoke to [me]101-sir thomas on this subject yesterday , and [I]101-sir thomas told [him]133-mr. crawford without disguise that it was very disagreeable to [me]101-sir thomas , and quite out of [my]101-sir thomas power to return [his]133-mr. crawford good opinion . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [I]101-sir thomas do not catch [your]101-sir thomas meaning , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , sitting down again . “ Out of [your]101-sir thomas power to return [his]133-mr. crawford good opinion ? What is all this ? [I]101-sir thomas know [he]133-mr. crawford spoke to [you]101-sir thomas yesterday , and ( as far as [I]101-sir thomas understand ) received as much encouragement to proceed as [a well - judging young woman]5696-a well - judging young woman could permit [herself]5696-a well - judging young woman to give . [I]101-sir thomas was very much pleased with what [I]101-sir thomas collected to have been [your]101-sir thomas behaviour on the occasion ; it [shewed]5697-shewed a discretion highly to be commended . But now , when [he]133-mr. crawford has made [his]133-mr. crawford overtures so properly , and honourably — what are [your]101-sir thomas scruples _ now _ ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ [You]312-her uncle are mistaken , [sir]4023-sir , ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny , forced by the anxiety of the moment even to tell [[her]2448-her uncle]312-her uncle that [he]312-her uncle was wrong ; “ [you]312-her uncle are quite mistaken . How could [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford say such a thing ? [I]2450-i gave [him]133-mr. crawford no encouragement yesterday . On the contrary , [I]2450-i told [him]133-mr. crawford , [I]2450-i can not recollect [my]2450-i exact words , but [I]2450-i am sure [I]2450-i told [him]133-mr. crawford that [I]2450-i would not listen to [him]133-mr. crawford , that it was very unpleasant to [me]2450-i in every respect , and that [I]2450-i begged [him]133-mr. crawford never to talk to [me]2450-i in that manner again . [I]2450-i am sure [I]2450-i said as much as that and more ; and [I]2450-i should have said still more , if [I]2450-i had been quite certain of [his]133-mr. crawford meaning anything seriously ; but [I]2450-i did not like to be , [I]2450-i could not bear to be , imputing more than might be intended . [I]2450-i thought it might all pass for nothing with _ [him]133-mr. crawford _ . ”[2450-i] [She]2450-i could say no more ; [her]2450-i breath was almost gone . “ Am [I]101-sir thomas to understand , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , after a few moments ’ silence , “ that [you]2450-i mean to _ refuse [_]5699-_ [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ Yes , [sir]4023-sir . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Refuse [him]133-mr. crawford ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ Yes , [sir]4023-sir . ”[101-sir thomas] “ [Refuse Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ! Upon what plea ? For what reason ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ [I]101-sir thomas — [I]101-sir thomas can not like [him]133-mr. crawford , [sir]4023-sir , well enough to marry [him]133-mr. crawford . ”[101-sir thomas] “ This is very strange ! ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , in a voice of calm displeasure . “ There is something in this which [my]101-sir thomas comprehension does not reach . Here is [a young man]743-a young man wishing to pay [his]743-a young man addresses to [you]2450-i , with everything to recommend [him]743-a young man : not merely situation in life , fortune , and character , but with more than common agreeableness , with address and conversation pleasing to [everybody]408-everybody . And [he]743-a young man is not [an acquaintance of to - day]5705-an acquaintance of to - day ; [you]2450-i have now known [him]743-a young man some time . [[His]743-a young man sister]511-his sister , moreover , is [[your]2450-i intimate friend]3917-your intimate friend , and [he]743-a young man has been doing _ that _ for [[your]2450-i brother]3938-your brother , which [I]101-sir thomas should suppose would have been almost sufficient recommendation to [you]2450-i , had there been no other . It is very uncertain when [my]101-sir thomas interest might have got [William]228-william on . [He]743-a young man has done it already . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Yes , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , in a faint voice , and looking down with fresh shame ; and [she]2451-she did feel almost ashamed of [herself]2451-she , after such a picture as [[her]2451-she uncle]312-her uncle had drawn , for not liking [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . “ [You]113-fanny must have been aware , ”[101-sir thomas] continued [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas presently , “ [you]113-fanny must have been some time aware of a particularity in [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s manners to [you]113-fanny . This can not have taken [you]113-fanny by surprise . [You]113-fanny must have observed [his]133-mr. crawford attentions ; and though [you]113-fanny always received them very properly ( [I]101-sir thomas have no accusation to make on that head ) , [I]101-sir thomas never perceived them to be unpleasant to [you]113-fanny . [I]101-sir thomas am half inclined to think , [Fanny]113-fanny , that [you]113-fanny do not quite know [your]113-fanny own feelings . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Oh yes , [sir]4023-sir ! indeed [I]101-sir thomas do . [His]133-mr. crawford attentions were always — what [I]101-sir thomas did not like . ”[101-sir thomas] [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas looked at [her]2453-her with deeper surprise . “ This is beyond [me]101-sir thomas , ”[101-sir thomas] said [he]101-sir thomas . “ This requires explanation . Young as [you]113-fanny are , and having seen [scarcely any one]5710-scarcely any one , it is hardly possible that [your]113-fanny affections — ”[101-sir thomas] [He]101-sir thomas paused and eyed [her]2453-her fixedly . [He]101-sir thomas saw [her]2453-her lips formed into a _ no _ , though the sound was inarticulate , but [her]2453-her face was like scarlet . That , however , in so modest [a girl]3666-a girl , might be very compatible with innocence ; and chusing at least to appear satisfied , [he]101-sir thomas quickly added , “ No , no , [I]101-sir thomas know _ that _ is quite out of the question ; quite impossible . Well , there is nothing more to be said . ”[101-sir thomas] And for a few minutes [he]101-sir thomas did say nothing . [He]101-sir thomas was deep in thought . [[His]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece was deep in thought likewise , trying to harden and prepare [herself]724-his niece against farther questioning . [She]724-his niece would rather die than own the truth ; and [she]724-his niece hoped , by a little reflection , to fortify [herself]724-his niece beyond betraying it . “ Independently of the interest which [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s _ choice _ seemed to justify ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , beginning again , and very composedly , “ [his]133-mr. crawford wishing to marry at all so early is recommendatory to [me]101-sir thomas . [I]101-sir thomas am an advocate for early marriages , where there are means in proportion , and would have [every young man]5711-every young man , with a sufficient income , settle as soon after four - and - twenty as [he]5711-every young man can . This is so much [my]101-sir thomas opinion , that [I]101-sir thomas am sorry to think how little likely [[my]101-sir thomas own eldest son]5712-my own eldest son , [[your]5713-your cousin]3780-your cousin , [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , is to marry early ; but at present , as far as [I]101-sir thomas can judge , matrimony makes no part of [his]133-mr. crawford plans or thoughts . [I]101-sir thomas wish [he]133-mr. crawford were more likely to fix . ”[101-sir thomas] Here was a glance at [Fanny]113-fanny . “ [Edmund]108-edmund , [I]101-sir thomas consider , from [his]108-edmund dispositions and habits , as much more likely to marry early than [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother . _ [He]108-edmund _ , indeed , [I]101-sir thomas have lately thought , has seen [the woman [he]108-edmund could love]5716-the woman he could love , which , [I]101-sir thomas am convinced , [[my]101-sir thomas eldest son]5717-my eldest son has not . Am [I]101-sir thomas right ? Do [you]113-fanny agree with [me]101-sir thomas , [[my]101-sir thomas dear]3657-my dear ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ Yes , [sir]4023-sir . ”[101-sir thomas] It was gently , but it was calmly said , and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was easy on the score of [the cousins]2456-the cousins . But the removal of [his]101-sir thomas alarm did [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece no service : as [her]724-his niece unaccountableness was confirmed [his]101-sir thomas displeasure increased ; and getting up and walking about [the room]412-the room with a frown , which [Fanny]113-fanny could picture to [herself]113-fanny , though [she]724-his niece dared not lift up [her]724-his niece eyes , [he]101-sir thomas shortly afterwards , and in a voice of authority , said , “ Have [you]113-fanny any reason , [child]4456-child , to think ill of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s temper ? ”[101-sir thomas] “ No , [sir]4023-sir . ”[724-his niece] [She]724-his niece longed to add , “ But of [his]101-sir thomas principles [I]724-his niece have ”[724-his niece] ; but [her]724-his niece heart sunk under the appalling prospect of discussion , explanation , and probably non - conviction . [Her]724-his niece ill opinion of [him]101-sir thomas was founded chiefly on observations , which , for [[her]724-his niece cousins]3671-her cousins ’ sake , [she]724-his niece could scarcely dare mention to [[their]3671-her cousins father]398-their father . [Maria]126-maria and [Julia]112-julia , and especially [Maria]126-maria , were so closely implicated in [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s misconduct , that [she]724-his niece could not give [his]101-sir thomas character , such as [she]724-his niece believed it , without betraying [them]3671-her cousins . [She]724-his niece had hoped that , to [a man like [[her]724-his niece uncle]312-her uncle , so discerning , so honourable , so good , the simple acknowledgment of settled _ dislike _ on [her]724-his niece side]2461-a man like her uncle , so discerning , so honourable , so good , the simple acknowledgment of settled _ dislike _ on her side would have been sufficient . To [her]724-his niece infinite grief [she]724-his niece found it was not . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas came towards the table where [she]724-his niece sat in trembling wretchedness , and with a good deal of cold sternness , said , “ It is of no use , [I]101-sir thomas perceive , to talk to [you]724-his niece . [We]5722-we had better put an end to this most mortifying conference . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford must not be kept longer waiting . [I]101-sir thomas will , therefore , only add , as thinking it [my]101-sir thomas duty to mark [my]101-sir thomas opinion of [your]724-his niece conduct , that [you]724-his niece have disappointed every expectation [I]101-sir thomas had formed , and proved [yourself]724-his niece of a character the very reverse of what [I]101-sir thomas had supposed . For [I]101-sir thomas _ had _ , [Fanny]113-fanny , as [I]101-sir thomas think [my]101-sir thomas behaviour must have shewn , formed a very favourable opinion of [you]724-his niece from the period of [my]101-sir thomas return to [England]14-england . [I]101-sir thomas had thought [you]724-his niece peculiarly free from wilfulness of temper , self - conceit , and every tendency to that independence of spirit which prevails so much in modern days , even in [young women]5723-young women , and which in [young women]5723-young women is offensive and disgusting beyond all common offence . But [you]724-his niece have now shewn [me]101-sir thomas that [you]724-his niece can be wilful and perverse ; that [you]724-his niece can and will decide for [yourself]724-his niece , without any consideration or deference for those who have surely some right to guide [you]724-his niece , without even asking [their]5723-young women advice . [You]724-his niece have shewn [yourself]724-his niece very , very different from anything that [I]101-sir thomas had imagined . The advantage or disadvantage of [[your]724-his niece family]3869-your family , of [[your]724-his niece parents]5726-your parents , [[your]724-his niece brothers and [sisters]3676-sisters]5727-your brothers and sisters , never seems to have had a moment ’s share in [your]724-his niece thoughts on this occasion . How _ [they]5723-young women _ might be benefited , how _ [they]5723-young women _ must rejoice in such an establishment for [you]724-his niece , is nothing to _ [you]724-his niece _ . [You]724-his niece think only of [yourself]724-his niece , and because [you]724-his niece do not feel for [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford exactly what [a young heated fancy]5729-a young heated fancy imagines to be necessary for happiness , [you]724-his niece resolve to refuse [him]133-mr. crawford at once , without wishing even for a little time to consider of it , a little more time for cool consideration , and for really examining [your]724-his niece own inclinations ; and are , in a wild fit of folly , throwing away from [you]724-his niece such an opportunity of being settled in life , eligibly , honourably , nobly settled , as will , probably , never occur to [you]724-his niece again . Here is [a young man of sense , of character , of temper , of manners , and of fortune]5730-a young man of sense , of character , of temper , of manners , and of fortune , exceedingly attached to [you]724-his niece , and seeking [your]724-his niece hand in the most handsome and disinterested way ; and let [me]101-sir thomas tell [you]724-his niece , [Fanny]113-fanny , that [you]724-his niece may live eighteen years longer in [the world]315-the world without being addressed by [a man of half [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s estate]5732-a man of half mr. crawford ’s estate , or a tenth part of [his]133-mr. crawford merits . Gladly would [I]101-sir thomas have bestowed either of [[my]101-sir thomas own daughters]5733-my own daughters on [him]133-mr. crawford . [Maria]126-maria is nobly married ; but had [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford sought [Julia]112-julia ’s hand , [I]101-sir thomas should have given it to [him]133-mr. crawford with superior and more heartfelt satisfaction than [I]101-sir thomas gave [Maria]126-maria ’s to [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny . ”[101-sir thomas] After half a moment ’s pause : “ And [I]2463-he should have been very much surprised had [either of [[my]2463-he daughters]3727-my daughters]5734-either of my daughters , on receiving a proposal of marriage at any time which might carry with it only _ half _ the eligibility of _ this _ , immediately and peremptorily , and without paying [my]2463-he opinion or [my]2463-he regard the compliment of any consultation , put a decided negative on it . [I]2463-he should have been much surprised and much hurt by such a proceeding . [I]2463-he should have thought it a gross violation of duty and respect . _ [You]113-fanny _ are not to be judged by the same rule . [You]113-fanny do not owe [me]2463-he the duty of [a child]376-a child . But , [Fanny]113-fanny , if [your]113-fanny heart can acquit [you]113-fanny of _ ingratitude _ — ”[2463-he] [He]2463-he ceased . [Fanny]113-fanny was by this time crying so bitterly that , angry as [he]2463-he was , [he]2463-he would not press that article farther . [Her]2464-her heart was almost broke by such a picture of what [she]2464-her appeared to [him]2463-he ; by such accusations , so heavy , so multiplied , so rising in dreadful gradation ! Self - willed , obstinate , selfish , and ungrateful . [He]2463-he thought [her]2464-her all this . [She]2464-her had deceived [his]2463-he expectations ; [she]2464-her had lost [his]2463-he good opinion . What was to become of [her]2464-her ? “ [I]2464-her am very sorry , ”[2464-her] said [she]2464-her inarticulately , through [her]2464-her tears , “ [I]2464-her am very sorry indeed . ”[2464-her] “ Sorry ! yes , [I]2464-her hope [you]680-the young man are sorry ; and [you]680-the young man will probably have reason to be long sorry for this day ’s transactions . ”[2464-her] “ If it were possible for [me]2464-her to do otherwise ”[2464-her] said [she]2464-her , with another strong effort ; “ but [I]2464-her am so perfectly convinced that [I]2464-her could never make [him]680-the young man happy , and that [I]2464-her should be miserable [myself]2464-her . ”[2464-her] Another burst of tears ; but in spite of that burst , and in spite of that great black word _ miserable _ , which served to introduce it , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas began to think a little relenting , a little change of inclination , might have something to do with it ; and to augur favourably from the personal entreaty of [the young man]680-the young man [himself]101-sir thomas . [He]101-sir thomas knew [her]2464-her to be very timid , and exceedingly nervous ; and thought it not improbable that [her]2464-her mind might be in such a state as a little time , a little pressing , a little patience , and a little impatience , a judicious mixture of all on [the lover]1832-the lover ’s side , might work [their]2467-their usual effect on . If [the gentleman]671-the gentleman would but persevere , if [he]671-the gentleman had but love enough to persevere , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas began to have hopes ; and these reflections having passed across [his]101-sir thomas mind and cheered it , “ Well , ”[101-sir thomas] said [he]101-sir thomas , in a tone of becoming gravity , but of less anger , “ well , [child]4456-child , dry up [your]4456-child tears . There is no use in these tears ; they can do no good . [You]4456-child must now come [downstairs]1808-downstairs with [me]101-sir thomas . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford has been kept waiting too long already . [You]4456-child must give [him]133-mr. crawford [your]4456-child own answer : [we]5739-we can not expect [him]133-mr. crawford to be satisfied with less ; and [you]4456-child only can explain to [him]133-mr. crawford the grounds of that misconception of [your]4456-child sentiments , which , unfortunately for [himself]133-mr. crawford , [he]133-mr. crawford certainly has imbibed . [I]101-sir thomas am totally unequal to it . ”[101-sir thomas] But [Fanny]113-fanny shewed such reluctance , such misery , at the idea of going down to [him]101-sir thomas , that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , after a little consideration , judged it better to indulge [her]2469-her . [His]101-sir thomas hopes from both [gentleman]2470-gentleman and [lady]2471-lady suffered a small depression in consequence ; but when [he]101-sir thomas looked at [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece , and saw the state of feature and complexion which [her]724-his niece crying had brought [her]724-his niece into , [he]101-sir thomas thought there might be as much lost as gained by an immediate interview . With a few words , therefore , of no particular meaning , [he]101-sir thomas walked off by [himself]101-sir thomas , leaving [[his]101-sir thomas poor niece]2473-his poor niece to sit and cry over what had passed , with very wretched feelings . [Her]724-his niece mind was all disorder . The past , present , future , everything was terrible . But [[her]724-his niece uncle]312-her uncle ’s anger gave [her]724-his niece the severest pain of all . Selfish and ungrateful ! to have appeared so to [him]312-her uncle ! [She]724-his niece was miserable for ever . [She]724-his niece had [no one]404-no one to take [her]724-his niece part , to counsel , or speak for [her]724-his niece . [[Her]724-his niece only friend]2476-her only friend was absent . [He]2476-her only friend might have softened [[his]2476-her only friend father]534-his father ; but all , perhaps all , would think [her]724-his niece selfish and ungrateful . [She]724-his niece might have to endure the reproach again and again ; [she]724-his niece might hear it , or see it , or know it to exist for ever in every connexion about [her]724-his niece . [She]724-his niece could not but feel some resentment against [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ; yet , if [he]133-mr. crawford really loved [her]724-his niece , and were unhappy too ! It was all wretchedness together . In about a quarter of an hour [[her]724-his niece uncle]312-her uncle returned ; [she]724-his niece was almost ready to faint at the sight of [him]312-her uncle . [He]312-her uncle spoke calmly , however , without austerity , without reproach , and [she]724-his niece revived a little . There was comfort , too , in [his]312-her uncle words , as well as [his]312-her uncle manner , for [he]312-her uncle began with , “ [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford is gone : [he]133-mr. crawford has just left [me]312-her uncle . [I]312-her uncle need not repeat what has passed . [I]312-her uncle do not want to add to anything [you]724-his niece may now be feeling , by an account of what [he]133-mr. crawford has felt . Suffice it , that [he]133-mr. crawford has behaved in the most gentlemanlike and generous manner , and has confirmed [me]312-her uncle in a most favourable opinion of [his]133-mr. crawford understanding , heart , and temper . Upon [my]312-her uncle representation of what [you]724-his niece were suffering , [he]133-mr. crawford immediately , and with the greatest delicacy , ceased to urge to see [you]724-his niece for the present . ”[312-her uncle] Here [Fanny]113-fanny , who had looked up , looked down again . “ Of course , ”[312-her uncle] continued [[her]724-his niece uncle]312-her uncle , “ it can not be supposed but that [he]133-mr. crawford should request to speak with [you]724-his niece alone , be it only for five minutes ; a request too natural , a claim too just to be denied . But there is no time fixed ; perhaps to - morrow , or whenever [your]724-his niece spirits are composed enough . For the present [you]724-his niece have only to tranquillise [yourself]724-his niece . Check these tears ; they do but exhaust [you]724-his niece . If , as [I]312-her uncle am willing to suppose , [you]724-his niece wish to shew [me]312-her uncle any observance , [you]724-his niece will not give way to these emotions , but endeavour to reason [yourself]724-his niece into a stronger frame of mind . [I]312-her uncle advise [you]724-his niece to go out : the air will do [you]724-his niece good ; go out for an hour on the gravel ; [you]724-his niece will have the shrubbery to [yourself]724-his niece , and will be the better for air and exercise . And , [Fanny]113-fanny ”[312-her uncle] ( turning back again for a moment ) , “ [I]312-her uncle shall make no mention below of what has passed ; [I]312-her uncle shall not even tell [[your]724-his niece aunt]3826-your aunt [Bertram]101-sir thomas . There is no occasion for spreading the disappointment ; say nothing about it [yourself]724-his niece . ”[312-her uncle] This was an order to be most joyfully obeyed ; this was an act of kindness which [Fanny]113-fanny felt at [her]2480-her heart . To be spared from [[her]2480-her aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s interminable reproaches ! [he]2482-his left [her]2480-her in a glow of gratitude . Anything might be bearable rather than such reproaches . Even to see [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford would be less overpowering . [She]2480-her walked out directly , as [[her]2480-her uncle]312-her uncle recommended , and followed [his]2482-his advice throughout , as far as [she]2480-her could ; did check [her]2480-her tears ; did earnestly try to compose [her]2480-her spirits and strengthen [her]2480-her mind . [She]2480-her wished to prove to [him]2482-his that [she]2480-her did desire [his]2482-his comfort , and sought to regain [his]2482-his favour ; and [he]2482-his had given [her]2480-her another strong motive for exertion , in keeping the whole affair from the knowledge of [[her]2480-her aunts]624-her aunts . Not to excite suspicion by [her]2480-her look or manner was now an object worth attaining ; and [she]2480-her felt equal to almost anything that might save [her]2480-her from [[her]2480-her aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris . [She]2480-her was struck , quite struck , when , on returning from [her]2480-her walk and going into [the East room]1380-the east room again , the first thing which caught [her]2480-her eye was a fire lighted and burning . A fire ! it seemed too much ; just at that time to be giving [her]2480-her such an indulgence was exciting even painful gratitude . [She]2480-her wondered that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could have leisure to think of such a trifle again ; but [she]2480-her soon found , from the voluntary information of [the housemaid , who came in to attend it , that so it was to be every day]2487-the housemaid , who came in to attend it , that so it was to be every day . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had given orders for it . “ [I]2480-her must be [a brute]5741-a brute , indeed , if [I]2480-her can be really ungrateful ! ”[2480-her] said [she]2480-her , in soliloquy . “ Heaven defend [me]2480-her from being ungrateful ! ”[2480-her] [She]2480-her saw nothing more of [[her]2480-her uncle]312-her uncle , nor of [[her]2480-her aunt]463-her aunt [Norris]105-mrs. norris , till [they]2490-they met at dinner . [[Her]2480-her uncle]312-her uncle ’s behaviour to [her]2480-her was then as nearly as possible what it had been before ; [she]2480-her was sure [he]312-her uncle did not mean there should be any change , and that it was only [her]2480-her own conscience that could fancy any ; but [[her]2480-her aunt]463-her aunt was soon quarrelling with [her]2480-her ; and when [she]2480-her found how much and how unpleasantly [her]2480-her having only walked out without [[her]2480-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s knowledge could be dwelt on , [she]2480-her felt all the reason [she]2480-her had to bless the kindness which saved [her]2480-her from the same spirit of reproach , exerted on a more momentous subject . “ If [I]2480-her had known [you]312-her uncle were going out , [I]2480-her should have got [you]312-her uncle just to go as far as [[my]2480-her house]4207-my house with some orders for [Nanny]5743-nanny , ”[2480-her] said [she]2480-her , “ which [I]2480-her have since , to [my]2480-her very great inconvenience , been obliged to go and carry [myself]2480-her . [I]2480-her could very ill spare the time , and [you]312-her uncle might have saved [me]2480-her the trouble , if [you]312-her uncle would only have been so good as to let [us]5744-us know [you]312-her uncle were going out . It would have made no difference to [you]312-her uncle , [I]2480-her suppose , whether [you]312-her uncle had walked in the shrubbery or gone to [[my]2480-her house]4207-my house . ”[2480-her] “ [I]101-sir thomas recommended the shrubbery to [Fanny]113-fanny as [the driest place]5746-the driest place , ”[101-sir thomas] said [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . “ Oh ! ”[105-mrs. norris] said [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , with a moment ’s check , “ that was very kind of [you]312-her uncle , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ; but [you]312-her uncle do not know how dry the path is to [[my]105-mrs. norris house]4207-my house . [Fanny]113-fanny would have had quite as good a walk [there]3696-there , [I]105-mrs. norris assure [you]312-her uncle , with the advantage of being of some use , and obliging [[her]5749-she aunt]463-her aunt : it is all [her]5749-she fault . If [she]5749-she would but have let [us]5751-us know [she]5749-she was going out but there is a something about [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]105-mrs. norris have often observed it before — [she]5749-she likes to go [her]5749-she own way to work ; [she]5749-she does not like to be dictated to ; [she]5749-she takes [her]5749-she own independent walk whenever [she]5749-she can ; [she]5749-she certainly has a little spirit of secrecy , and independence , and nonsense , about [her]5749-she , which [I]105-mrs. norris would advise [her]5749-she to get the better of . ”[105-mrs. norris] As a general reflection on [Fanny]113-fanny , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas thought nothing could be more unjust , though [he]101-sir thomas had been so lately expressing the same sentiments [himself]101-sir thomas , and [he]101-sir thomas tried to turn the conversation : tried repeatedly before [he]101-sir thomas could succeed ; for [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris had not discernment enough to perceive , either now , or at any other time , to what degree [he]101-sir thomas thought well of [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece , or how very far [he]101-sir thomas was from wishing to have [[his]101-sir thomas own children]501-his own children ’s merits set off by the depreciation of [hers]113-fanny . [She]105-mrs. norris was talking _ at [_ Fanny]113-fanny , and resenting this private walk half through the dinner . It was over , however , at last ; and the evening set in with more composure to [Fanny]113-fanny , and more cheerfulness of spirits than [she]105-mrs. norris could have hoped for after so stormy a morning ; but [she]105-mrs. norris trusted , in the first place , that [she]105-mrs. norris had done right : that [her]105-mrs. norris judgment had not misled [her]105-mrs. norris . For the purity of [her]105-mrs. norris intentions [she]105-mrs. norris could answer ; and [she]105-mrs. norris was willing to hope , secondly , that [[her]105-mrs. norris uncle]312-her uncle ’s displeasure was abating , and would abate farther as [he]312-her uncle considered the matter with more impartiality , and felt , as [a good man]2497-a good man must feel , how wretched , and how unpardonable , how hopeless , and how wicked it was to marry without affection . When the meeting with which [she]105-mrs. norris was threatened for the morrow was past , [she]105-mrs. norris could not but flatter [herself]105-mrs. norris that the subject would be finally concluded , and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford once gone from [Mansfield]3-mansfield , that everything would soon be as if no such subject had existed . [She]105-mrs. norris would not , could not believe , that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s affection for [her]105-mrs. norris could distress [him]133-mr. crawford long ; [his]133-mr. crawford mind was not of that sort . [London]6-london would soon bring its cure . In [London]6-london [he]133-mr. crawford would soon learn to wonder at [his]133-mr. crawford infatuation , and be thankful for the right reason in [her]105-mrs. norris which had saved [him]133-mr. crawford from its evil consequences . While [Fanny]113-fanny ’s mind was engaged in these sort of hopes , [[her]105-mrs. norris uncle]312-her uncle was , soon after tea , called out of [the room]412-the room ; an occurrence too common to strike [her]105-mrs. norris , and [she]105-mrs. norris thought nothing of it till [the butler]1461-the butler reappeared ten minutes afterwards , and advancing decidedly towards [herself]105-mrs. norris , said , “ [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas wishes to speak with [you]105-mrs. norris , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , in [[his]101-sir thomas own room]1291-his own room . ”[1461-the butler] Then it occurred to [her]105-mrs. norris what might be going on ; a suspicion rushed over [her]105-mrs. norris mind which drove the colour from [her]105-mrs. norris cheeks ; but instantly rising , [she]105-mrs. norris was preparing to obey , when [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris called out , “ Stay , stay , [Fanny]113-fanny ! what are [you]113-fanny about ? where are [you]113-fanny going ? do n’t be in such a hurry . Depend upon it , it is not [you]113-fanny who are wanted ; depend upon it , it is [me]105-mrs. norris ”[105-mrs. norris] ( looking at [the butler]1461-the butler ) ; “ but [you]113-fanny are so very eager to put [yourself]113-fanny forward . What should [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas want [you]113-fanny for ? It is [me]105-mrs. norris , [Baddeley]215-baddeley , [you]113-fanny mean ; [I]105-mrs. norris am coming this moment . [You]113-fanny mean [me]105-mrs. norris , [Baddeley]215-baddeley , [I]105-mrs. norris am sure ; [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas wants [me]105-mrs. norris , not [Miss Price]137-miss price . ”[105-mrs. norris] But [Baddeley]215-baddeley was stout . “ No , [ma’am]4007-ma’am , it is [Miss Price]137-miss price ; [I]215-baddeley am certain of its being [Miss Price]137-miss price . ”[215-baddeley] And there was a half - smile with the words , which meant , “ [I]215-baddeley do not think [you]4007-ma’am would answer the purpose at all . ”[215-baddeley] [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , much discontented , was obliged to compose [herself]105-mrs. norris to work again ; and [Fanny]113-fanny , walking off in agitating consciousness , found [herself]113-fanny , as [she]2502-she anticipated , in another minute alone with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . CHAPTER XXXIII The conference was neither so short nor so conclusive as [the lady]718-the lady had designed . [The gentleman]671-the gentleman was not so easily satisfied . [He]671-the gentleman had all the disposition to persevere that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could wish [him]671-the gentleman . [He]671-the gentleman had vanity , which strongly inclined [him]671-the gentleman in the first place to think [she]718-the lady did love [him]671-the gentleman , though [she]718-the lady might not know it [herself]718-the lady ; and which , secondly , when constrained at last to admit that [she]718-the lady did know [her]718-the lady own present feelings , convinced [him]671-the gentleman that [he]671-the gentleman should be able in time to make those feelings what [he]671-the gentleman wished . [He]671-the gentleman was in love , very much in love ; and it was a love which , operating on an active , sanguine spirit , of more warmth than delicacy , made [her]718-the lady affection appear of greater consequence because it was withheld , and determined [him]671-the gentleman to have the glory , as well as the felicity , of forcing [her]718-the lady to love [him]671-the gentleman . [He]671-the gentleman would not despair : [he]671-the gentleman would not desist . [He]671-the gentleman had every well - grounded reason for solid attachment ; [he]671-the gentleman knew [her]718-the lady to have all the worth that could justify the warmest hopes of lasting happiness with [her]718-the lady ; [her]718-the lady conduct at this very time , by speaking the disinterestedness and delicacy of [her]718-the lady character ( qualities which [he]671-the gentleman believed most rare indeed ) , was of a sort to heighten all [his]671-the gentleman wishes , and confirm all [his]671-the gentleman resolutions . [He]671-the gentleman knew not that [he]671-the gentleman had a pre - engaged heart to attack . Of _ that _ [he]671-the gentleman had no suspicion . [He]671-the gentleman considered [her]718-the lady rather as [one who had never thought on the subject enough to be in danger]2505-one who had never thought on the subject enough to be in danger ; [who had been guarded by youth]2506-who had been guarded by youth , [a youth of mind as lovely as of person]2507-a youth of mind as lovely as of person ; whose modesty had prevented [her]718-the lady from understanding [his]671-the gentleman attentions , and who was still overpowered by the suddenness of addresses so wholly unexpected , and the novelty of a situation which [her]718-the lady fancy had never taken into account . Must it not follow of course , that , when [he]671-the gentleman was understood , [he]671-the gentleman should succeed ? [He]671-the gentleman believed it fully . Love such as [his]671-the gentleman , in [a man like [himself]671-the gentleman]2508-a man like himself , must with perseverance secure a return , and at no great distance ; and [he]671-the gentleman had so much delight in the idea of obliging [her]718-the lady to love [him]671-the gentleman in a very short time , that [her]718-the lady not loving [him]671-the gentleman now was scarcely regretted . A little difficulty to be overcome was no evil to [Henry Crawford]131-henry . [He]671-the gentleman rather derived spirits from it . [He]671-the gentleman had been apt to gain hearts too easily . [His]671-the gentleman situation was new and animating . To [Fanny]113-fanny , however , who had known too much opposition all [her]718-the lady life to find any charm in it , all this was unintelligible . [She]718-the lady found that [he]671-the gentleman did mean to persevere ; but how [he]671-the gentleman could , after such language from [her]718-the lady as [she]718-the lady felt [herself]718-the lady obliged to use , was not to be understood . [She]718-the lady told [him]671-the gentleman that [she]718-the lady did not love [him]671-the gentleman , could not love [him]671-the gentleman , was sure [she]718-the lady never should love [him]671-the gentleman ; that such a change was quite impossible ; that the subject was most painful to [her]718-the lady ; that [she]718-the lady must entreat [him]671-the gentleman never to mention it again , to allow [her]718-the lady to leave [him]671-the gentleman at once , and let it be considered as concluded for ever . And when farther pressed , had added , that in [her]718-the lady opinion [their]2509-their dispositions were so totally dissimilar as to make mutual affection incompatible ; and that [they]2509-their were unfitted for each other by nature , education , and habit . All this [she]718-the lady had said , and with the earnestness of sincerity ; yet this was not enough , for [he]671-the gentleman immediately denied there being anything uncongenial in [their]2509-their characters , or anything unfriendly in [their]2509-their situations ; and positively declared , that [he]671-the gentleman would still love , and still hope ! [Fanny]113-fanny knew [her]718-the lady own meaning , but was no judge of [her]718-the lady own manner . [Her]718-the lady manner was incurably gentle ; and [she]718-the lady was not aware how much it concealed the sternness of [her]718-the lady purpose . [Her]718-the lady diffidence , gratitude , and softness made every expression of indifference seem almost an effort of self - denial ; seem , at least , to be giving nearly as much pain to [herself]718-the lady as to [him]671-the gentleman . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was no longer [the Mr. Crawford who , as [the clandestine , insidious , treacherous admirer of [Maria Bertram]126-maria]2511-the clandestine , insidious , treacherous admirer of maria bertram]2510-the mr. crawford who , as the clandestine , insidious , treacherous admirer of maria bertram , had been [her]718-the lady abhorrence , [whom [she]718-the lady had hated to see or to speak to , in whom [she]718-the lady could believe no good quality to exist , and whose power , even of being agreeable , [she]718-the lady had barely acknowledged]2512-whom she had hated to see or to speak to , in whom she could believe no good quality to exist , and whose power , even of being agreeable , she had barely acknowledged . [He]133-mr. crawford was now [the Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford who was addressing [herself]718-the lady with ardent , disinterested love ; [whose feelings were apparently become all that was honourable and upright , whose views of happiness were all fixed on a marriage of attachment]2513-whose feelings were apparently become all that was honourable and upright , whose views of happiness were all fixed on a marriage of attachment ; who was pouring out [his]133-mr. crawford sense of [her]718-the lady merits , describing and describing again [his]133-mr. crawford affection , proving as far as words could prove it , and in the language , tone , and spirit of [a man of talent too]2514-a man of talent too , that [he]133-mr. crawford sought [her]718-the lady for [her]718-the lady gentleness and [her]718-the lady goodness ; and to complete the whole , [he]133-mr. crawford was now [the Mr. Crawford who had procured [William]228-william ’s promotion]2515-the mr. crawford who had procured william ’s promotion ! Here was a change , and here were claims which could not but operate ! [She]718-the lady might have disdained [him]133-mr. crawford in all the dignity of angry virtue , in [the grounds of [Sotherton]27-sotherton]2516-the grounds of sotherton , or [the theatre at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield]2517-the theatre at mansfield park ; but [he]133-mr. crawford approached [her]718-the lady now with rights that demanded different treatment . [She]718-the lady must be courteous , and [she]718-the lady must be compassionate . [She]718-the lady must have a sensation of being honoured , and whether thinking of [herself]718-the lady or [[her]718-the lady brother]451-her brother , [she]718-the lady must have a strong feeling of gratitude . The effect of the whole was a manner so pitying and agitated , and words intermingled with [her]718-the lady refusal so expressive of obligation and concern , that to a temper of vanity and hope like [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s , the truth , or at least the strength of [her]718-the lady indifference , might well be questionable ; and [he]133-mr. crawford was not so irrational as [Fanny]113-fanny considered [him]133-mr. crawford , in the professions of persevering , assiduous , and not desponding attachment which closed the interview . It was with reluctance that [he]133-mr. crawford suffered [her]718-the lady to go ; but there was no look of despair in parting to belie [his]133-mr. crawford words , or give [her]718-the lady hopes of [his]133-mr. crawford being less unreasonable than [he]133-mr. crawford professed [himself]133-mr. crawford . Now [she]718-the lady was angry . Some resentment did arise at a perseverance so selfish and ungenerous . Here was again a want of delicacy and regard for others which had formerly so struck and disgusted [her]718-the lady . Here was again a something of the same [Mr. Crawford whom [she]718-the lady had so reprobated before]133-mr. crawford . How evidently was there a gross want of feeling and humanity where [his]133-mr. crawford own pleasure was concerned — And , alas ! how always known no principle to supply as a duty what the heart was deficient in . Had [her]718-the lady own affections been as free — as perhaps they ought to have been — [he]133-mr. crawford never could have engaged [them]2519-them . So thought [Fanny]113-fanny , in good truth and sober sadness , as [she]718-the lady sat musing over that too great indulgence and luxury of a fire [upstairs]4939-upstairs : wondering at the past and present ; wondering at what was yet to come , and in a nervous agitation which made nothing clear to [her]718-the lady but the persuasion of [her]718-the lady being never under any circumstances able to love [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and the felicity of having a fire to sit over and think of it . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was obliged , or obliged [himself]101-sir thomas , to wait till the morrow for a knowledge of what had passed between [the young people]391-the young people . [He]101-sir thomas then saw [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and received [his]101-sir thomas account . The first feeling was disappointment : [he]101-sir thomas had hoped better things ; [he]101-sir thomas had thought that an hour ’s entreaty from [a young man]743-a young man like [Crawford]133-mr. crawford could not have worked so little change on [a gentle - tempered girl like [Fanny]113-fanny]2523-a gentle - tempered girl like fanny ; but there was speedy comfort in the determined views and sanguine perseverance of [the lover]1832-the lover ; and when seeing such confidence of success in the principal , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was soon able to depend on it [himself]101-sir thomas . Nothing was omitted , on [his]101-sir thomas side , of civility , compliment , or kindness , that might assist the plan . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s steadiness was honoured , and [Fanny]113-fanny was praised , and the connexion was still the most desirable in [the world]315-the world . At [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford would always be welcome ; [he]133-mr. crawford had only to consult [his]133-mr. crawford own judgment and feelings as to the frequency of [his]133-mr. crawford visits , at present or in future . In [all [[his]133-mr. crawford niece]724-his niece ’s family and [friends]3751-friends]2526-all his niece ’s family and friends , there could be but one opinion , one wish on the subject ; the influence of all who loved [her]724-his niece must incline one way . Everything was said that could encourage , every encouragement received with grateful joy , and [the gentlemen]4865-the gentlemen parted the best of [friends]3751-friends . Satisfied that the cause was now on a footing the most proper and hopeful , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas resolved to abstain from all farther importunity with [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece , and to shew no open interference . Upon [her]724-his niece disposition [he]101-sir thomas believed kindness might be the best way of working . Entreaty should be from one quarter only . The forbearance of [[her]724-his niece family]322-her family on a point , respecting which [she]724-his niece could be in no doubt of [their]322-her family wishes , might be [their]322-her family surest means of forwarding it . Accordingly , on this principle , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas took the first opportunity of saying to [her]724-his niece , with a mild gravity , intended to be overcoming , “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]101-sir thomas have seen [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford again , and learn from [him]133-mr. crawford exactly how matters stand between [you]113-fanny . [He]133-mr. crawford is [a most extraordinary young man]5755-a most extraordinary young man , and whatever be the event , [you]113-fanny must feel that [you]113-fanny have created an attachment of no common character ; though , young as [you]113-fanny are , and little acquainted with the transient , varying , unsteady nature of love , as it generally exists , [you]113-fanny can not be struck as [I]101-sir thomas am with all that is wonderful in a perseverance of this sort against discouragement . With [him]133-mr. crawford it is entirely a matter of feeling : [he]133-mr. crawford claims no merit in it ; perhaps is entitled to none . Yet , having chosen so well , [his]133-mr. crawford constancy has a respectable stamp . Had [his]133-mr. crawford choice been less unexceptionable , [I]101-sir thomas should have condemned [his]133-mr. crawford persevering . ”[101-sir thomas] “ Indeed , [sir]4023-sir , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , “ [I]113-fanny am very sorry that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford should continue to — [I]113-fanny know that it is paying [me]113-fanny a very great compliment , and [I]113-fanny feel most undeservedly honoured ; but [I]113-fanny am so perfectly convinced , and [I]113-fanny have told [him]133-mr. crawford so , that it never will be in [my]113-fanny power — ”[113-fanny] “ [[My]101-sir thomas dear]3657-my dear , ”[101-sir thomas] interrupted [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , “ there is no occasion for this . [Your]3657-my dear feelings are as well known to [me]101-sir thomas as [my]101-sir thomas wishes and regrets must be to [you]3657-my dear . There is nothing more to be said or done . From this hour the subject is never to be revived between [us]5758-us . [You]3657-my dear will have nothing to fear , or to be agitated about . [You]3657-my dear can not suppose [me]101-sir thomas capable of trying to persuade [you]3657-my dear to marry against [your]3657-my dear inclinations . [Your]3657-my dear happiness and advantage are all that [I]101-sir thomas have in view , and nothing is required of [you]3657-my dear but to bear with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s endeavours to convince [you]3657-my dear that they may not be incompatible with [his]133-mr. crawford . [He]133-mr. crawford proceeds at [his]133-mr. crawford own risk . [You]3657-my dear are on [safe ground]5759-safe ground . [I]101-sir thomas have engaged for [your]3657-my dear seeing [him]133-mr. crawford whenever [he]133-mr. crawford calls , as [you]3657-my dear might have done had nothing of this sort occurred . [You]3657-my dear will see [him]133-mr. crawford with [the rest of [us]5761-us]4851-the rest of us , in the same manner , and , as much as [you]3657-my dear can , dismissing the recollection of everything unpleasant . [He]133-mr. crawford leaves [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire so soon , that even this slight sacrifice can not be often demanded . The future must be very uncertain . And now , [[my]101-sir thomas dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , this subject is closed between [us]5761-us . ”[101-sir thomas] The promised departure was all that [Fanny]113-fanny could think of with much satisfaction . [[Her]2533-she uncle]312-her uncle ’s kind expressions , however , and forbearing manner , were sensibly felt ; and when [she]2533-she considered how much of the truth was unknown to [him]312-her uncle , [she]2533-she believed [she]2533-she had no right to wonder at the line of conduct [he]312-her uncle pursued . [He]312-her uncle , who had married [a daughter]2535-a daughter to [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny : romantic delicacy was certainly not to be expected from [him]312-her uncle . [She]2533-she must do [her]2533-she duty , and trust that time might make [her]2533-she duty easier than it now was . [She]2533-she could not , though only eighteen , suppose [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s attachment would hold out for ever ; [she]2533-she could not but imagine that steady , unceasing discouragement from [herself]2533-she would put an end to it in time . How much time [she]2533-she might , in [her]2533-she own fancy , allot for its dominion , is another concern . It would not be fair to inquire into [a young lady]1192-a young lady ’s exact estimate of [her]1192-a young lady own perfections . In spite of [his]312-her uncle intended silence , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas found [himself]312-her uncle once more obliged to mention the subject to [[his]312-her uncle niece]724-his niece , to prepare [her]724-his niece briefly for its being imparted to [[her]724-his niece aunts]624-her aunts ; a measure which [he]312-her uncle would still have avoided , if possible , but which became necessary from the totally opposite feelings of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford as to any secrecy of proceeding . [He]312-her uncle had no idea of concealment . It was all known at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , where [he]312-her uncle loved to talk over the future with both [[his]312-her uncle sisters]4166-his sisters , and it would be rather gratifying to [him]312-her uncle to have enlightened witnesses of the progress of [his]312-her uncle success . When [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas understood this , [he]312-her uncle felt the necessity of making [[his]312-her uncle own wife and sister - in - law]2541-his own wife and sister - in - law acquainted with the business without delay ; though , on [Fanny]113-fanny ’s account , [he]312-her uncle almost dreaded the effect of the communication to [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris as much as [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny . [He]312-her uncle deprecated [her]105-mrs. norris mistaken but well - meaning zeal . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , indeed , was , by this time , not very far from classing [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris as one of [those well - meaning people who are always doing mistaken and very disagreeable things]2542-those well - meaning people who are always doing mistaken and very disagreeable things . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , however , relieved [him]312-her uncle . [He]312-her uncle pressed for the strictest forbearance and silence towards [[their]2543-their niece]543-their niece ; [she]105-mrs. norris not only promised , but did observe it . [She]105-mrs. norris only looked [her]105-mrs. norris increased ill - will . Angry [she]105-mrs. norris was : bitterly angry ; but [she]105-mrs. norris was more angry with [Fanny]113-fanny for having received such an offer than for refusing it . It was an injury and affront to [Julia]112-julia , who ought to have been [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s choice ; and , independently of that , [she]105-mrs. norris disliked [Fanny]113-fanny , because [she]105-mrs. norris had neglected [her]105-mrs. norris ; and [she]105-mrs. norris would have grudged such an elevation to one whom [she]105-mrs. norris had been always trying to depress . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas gave [her]105-mrs. norris more credit for discretion on the occasion than [she]105-mrs. norris deserved ; and [Fanny]113-fanny could have blessed [her]105-mrs. norris for allowing [her]105-mrs. norris only to see [her]105-mrs. norris displeasure , and not to hear it . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram took it differently . [She]105-mrs. norris had been [a beauty]2545-a beauty , and [a prosperous beauty]2546-a prosperous beauty , all [her]105-mrs. norris life ; and beauty and wealth were all that excited [her]105-mrs. norris respect . To know [Fanny]113-fanny to be sought in marriage by [a man of fortune]1992-a man of fortune , raised [her]105-mrs. norris , therefore , very much in [her]105-mrs. norris opinion . By convincing [her]106-lady bertram that [Fanny]113-fanny _ was _ very pretty , which [she]106-lady bertram had been doubting about before , and that [she]105-mrs. norris would be advantageously married , it made [her]106-lady bertram feel a sort of credit in calling [[her]106-lady bertram niece]642-her niece . “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[106-lady bertram] said [she]106-lady bertram , as soon as [they]2549-they were alone together afterwards , and [she]106-lady bertram really had known something like impatience to be alone with [her]106-lady bertram , and [her]106-lady bertram countenance , as [she]106-lady bertram spoke , had extraordinary animation ; “ Well , [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]106-lady bertram have had a very agreeable surprise this morning . [I]106-lady bertram must just speak of it _ once _ , [I]106-lady bertram told [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas [I]106-lady bertram must _ once _ , and then [I]106-lady bertram shall have done . [I]106-lady bertram give [you]113-fanny joy , [[my]106-lady bertram dear niece]5763-my dear niece . ”[106-lady bertram] And looking at [her]106-lady bertram complacently , [she]106-lady bertram added , “ Humph , [we]5764-we certainly are [a handsome family]5765-a handsome family ! ”[106-lady bertram] [Fanny]113-fanny coloured , and doubted at first what to say ; when , hoping to assail [her]106-lady bertram on [her]106-lady bertram vulnerable side , [she]106-lady bertram presently answered — “ [[My]106-lady bertram dear aunt]3896-my dear aunt , _ [you]3896-my dear aunt _ can not wish [me]106-lady bertram to do differently from what [I]106-lady bertram have done , [I]106-lady bertram am sure . _ [You]3896-my dear aunt _ can not wish [me]106-lady bertram to marry ; for [you]3896-my dear aunt would miss [me]106-lady bertram , should not [you]3896-my dear aunt ? Yes , [I]106-lady bertram am sure [you]3896-my dear aunt would miss [me]106-lady bertram too much for that . ”[106-lady bertram] “ No , [[my]106-lady bertram dear]3657-my dear , [I]106-lady bertram should not think of missing [you]3657-my dear , when such an offer as this comes in [your]3657-my dear way . [I]106-lady bertram could do very well without [you]3657-my dear , if [you]3657-my dear were married to [a man of such good estate]5768-a man of such good estate as [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . And [you]3657-my dear must be aware , [Fanny]113-fanny , that it is [every young woman]4498-every young woman ’s duty to accept such a very unexceptionable offer as this . ”[106-lady bertram] This was almost the only rule of conduct , the only piece of advice , which [Fanny]113-fanny had ever received from [[her]2550-her aunt]463-her aunt in the course of eight years and a half . It silenced [her]2550-her . [She]2550-her felt how unprofitable contention would be . If [[her]2550-her aunt]463-her aunt ’s feelings were against [her]2550-her , nothing could be hoped from attacking [her]2550-her understanding . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was quite talkative . “ [I]106-lady bertram will tell [you]113-fanny what , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[106-lady bertram] said [she]106-lady bertram , “ [I]106-lady bertram am sure [he]133-mr. crawford fell in love with [you]113-fanny at the ball ; [I]106-lady bertram am sure the mischief was done that evening . [You]113-fanny did look remarkably well . [Everybody]408-everybody said so . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas said so . And [you]113-fanny know [you]113-fanny had [Chapman]237-chapman to help [you]113-fanny to dress . [I]106-lady bertram am very glad [I]106-lady bertram sent [Chapman]237-chapman to [you]113-fanny . [I]106-lady bertram shall tell [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas that [I]106-lady bertram am sure it was done that evening . ”[106-lady bertram] And still pursuing the same cheerful thoughts , [she]106-lady bertram soon afterwards added , “ And [I]106-lady bertram will tell [you]113-fanny what , [Fanny]113-fanny , which is more than [I]106-lady bertram did for [Maria]126-maria : the next time [Pug]157-pug has [a litter]5771-a litter [you]113-fanny shall have a puppy . ”[106-lady bertram] CHAPTER XXXIV [Edmund]108-edmund had great things to hear on [his]108-edmund return . Many surprises were awaiting [him]108-edmund . The first that occurred was not least in interest : the appearance of [Henry Crawford]131-henry and [[his]131-henry sister]511-his sister walking together through [the village]524-the village as [he]108-edmund rode into [it]524-the village . [He]108-edmund had concluded — [he]108-edmund had meant [them]2555-them to be far distant . [His]108-edmund absence had been extended beyond a fortnight purposely to avoid [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . [He]108-edmund was returning to [Mansfield]3-mansfield with [spirits ready to feed on melancholy remembrances , and tender associations]2556-spirits ready to feed on melancholy remembrances , and tender associations , when [her]127-miss crawford own fair self was before [him]108-edmund , leaning on [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother ’s arm , and [he]108-edmund found [himself]108-edmund receiving a welcome , unquestionably friendly , from [the woman whom , two moments before , [he]108-edmund had been thinking of as seventy miles off , and as farther , much farther , from [him]108-edmund in inclination than any distance could express]2558-the woman whom , two moments before , he had been thinking of as seventy miles off , and as farther , much farther , from him in inclination than any distance could express . [Her]127-miss crawford reception of [him]108-edmund was of a sort which [he]108-edmund could not have hoped for , had [he]108-edmund expected to see [her]127-miss crawford . Coming as [he]108-edmund did from such a purport fulfilled as had taken [him]108-edmund away , [he]108-edmund would have expected anything rather than a look of satisfaction , and words of simple , pleasant meaning . It was enough to set [his]108-edmund heart in a glow , and to bring [him]108-edmund [home]367-home in the properest state for feeling the full value of the other joyful surprises at hand . [William]228-william ’s promotion , with all its particulars , [he]228-william was soon master of ; and with such a secret provision of comfort within [his]228-william own breast to help the joy , [he]228-william found in it a source of most gratifying sensation and unvarying cheerfulness all dinner - time . After dinner , when [he]108-edmund and [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father were alone , [he]108-edmund had [Fanny]113-fanny ’s history ; and then all the great events of the last fortnight , and the present situation of matters at [Mansfield]3-mansfield were known to [him]108-edmund . [Fanny]113-fanny suspected what was going on . [They]2561-they sat so much longer than usual in [the dining - parlour]813-the dining - parlour , that [she]2563-her was sure [they]2561-they must be talking of [her]2563-her ; and when tea at last brought [them]2561-they away , and [she]2563-her was to be seen by [Edmund]108-edmund again , [she]2563-her felt dreadfully guilty . [He]108-edmund came to [her]2563-her , sat down by [her]2563-her , took [her]2563-her hand , and pressed it kindly ; and at that moment [she]2563-her thought that , but for the occupation and the scene which the tea - things afforded , [she]2563-her must have betrayed [her]2563-her emotion in some unpardonable excess . [He]108-edmund was not intending , however , by such action , to be conveying to [her]2563-her that unqualified approbation and encouragement which [her]2563-her hopes drew from it . It was designed only to express [his]108-edmund participation in all that interested [her]2563-her , and to tell [her]2563-her that [he]108-edmund had been hearing what quickened every feeling of affection . [He]108-edmund was , in fact , entirely on [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father ’s side of the question . [His]108-edmund surprise was not so great as [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father ’s at [her]2563-her refusing [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , because , so far from supposing [her]2563-her to consider [him]108-edmund with anything like a preference , [he]108-edmund had always believed it to be rather the reverse , and could imagine [her]2563-her to be taken perfectly unprepared , but [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could not regard the connexion as more desirable than [he]101-sir thomas did . [It]2566-it had every recommendation to [him]101-sir thomas ; and while honouring [her]2563-her for what [she]2563-her had done under the influence of [her]2563-her present indifference , honouring [her]2563-her in rather stronger terms than [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could quite echo , [he]108-edmund was most earnest in hoping , and sanguine in believing , that it would be a match at last , and that , united by mutual affection , it would appear that [their]2567-their dispositions were as exactly fitted to make [them]2567-their blessed in each other , as [he]108-edmund was now beginning seriously to consider them . [Crawford]133-mr. crawford had been too precipitate . [He]108-edmund had not given [her]2563-her time to attach [herself]2563-her . [He]108-edmund had begun at the wrong end . With such powers as [his]108-edmund , however , and such a disposition as [hers]2563-her , [Edmund]108-edmund trusted that everything would work out a happy conclusion . Meanwhile , [he]108-edmund saw enough of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s embarrassment to make [him]108-edmund scrupulously guard against exciting it a second time , by any word , or look , or movement . [Crawford]133-mr. crawford called the next day , and on the score of [Edmund]108-edmund ’s return , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas felt [himself]101-sir thomas more than licensed to ask [him]108-edmund to stay dinner ; it was really a necessary compliment . [He]108-edmund staid of course , and [Edmund]108-edmund had then ample opportunity for observing how [he]108-edmund sped with [Fanny]113-fanny , and what degree of immediate encouragement for [him]108-edmund might be extracted from [her]2563-her manners ; and it was so little , so very , very little — every chance , every possibility of it , resting upon [her]2563-her embarrassment only ; if there was not hope in [her]2563-her confusion , there was hope in nothing else — that [he]108-edmund was almost ready to wonder at [[his]108-edmund friend]319-his friend ’s perseverance . [Fanny]113-fanny was worth it all ; [he]108-edmund held [her]2563-her to be worth every effort of patience , every exertion of mind , but [he]108-edmund did not think [he]108-edmund could have gone on [himself]108-edmund with [any woman]759-any woman breathing , without something more to warm [his]108-edmund courage than [his]108-edmund eyes could discern in [hers]113-fanny . [He]108-edmund was very willing to hope that [Crawford]133-mr. crawford saw clearer , and this was the most comfortable conclusion for [[his]108-edmund friend]319-his friend that [he]108-edmund could come to from all that [he]108-edmund observed to pass before , and at , and after dinner . In the evening a few circumstances occurred which [he]108-edmund thought more promising . When [he]108-edmund and [Crawford]133-mr. crawford walked into [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room , [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother and [Fanny]113-fanny were sitting as intently and silently at work as if there were nothing else to care for . [Edmund]108-edmund could not help noticing [their]2573-we apparently deep tranquillity . “ [We]2573-we have not been so silent all the time , ”[629-his mother] replied [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother . “ [Fanny]113-fanny has been reading to [me]629-his mother , and only put the book down upon hearing [you]108-edmund coming . ”[629-his mother] And sure enough there was a book on the table which had the air of being very recently closed : a volume of Shakespeare . “ [She]319-his friend often reads to [me]133-mr. crawford out of those books ; and [she]319-his friend was in the middle of a very fine speech of [that man’s]5772-that man’s — what ’s [his]5772-that man’s name , [Fanny?—when]246-fanny?—when [we]2573-we heard [your]108-edmund footsteps . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Crawford]133-mr. crawford took the volume . “ Let [me]133-mr. crawford have the pleasure of finishing that speech to [[your]108-edmund ladyship]4820-your ladyship , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [he]133-mr. crawford . “ [I]133-mr. crawford shall find it immediately . ”[133-mr. crawford] And by carefully giving way to the inclination of the leaves , [he]133-mr. crawford did find it , or within a page or two , quite near enough to satisfy [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , who assured [him]133-mr. crawford , as soon as [he]133-mr. crawford mentioned the name of [Cardinal Wolsey]247-cardinal wolsey , that [he]133-mr. crawford had got the very speech . Not a look or an offer of help had [Fanny]113-fanny given ; not a syllable for or against . All [her]106-lady bertram attention was for [her]106-lady bertram work . [She]106-lady bertram seemed determined to be interested by nothing else . But taste was too strong in [her]106-lady bertram . [She]106-lady bertram could not abstract [her]106-lady bertram mind five minutes : [she]106-lady bertram was forced to listen ; [his]133-mr. crawford reading was capital , and [her]106-lady bertram pleasure in good reading extreme . To _ good _ reading , however , [she]106-lady bertram had been long used : [[her]106-lady bertram uncle]312-her uncle read well , [[her]106-lady bertram cousins]3671-her cousins all , [Edmund]108-edmund very well , but in [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s reading there was a variety of excellence beyond what [she]106-lady bertram had ever met with . [The King]4118-the king , [the Queen]5346-the queen , [Buckingham]248-buckingham , [Wolsey]247-cardinal wolsey , [Cromwell]249-cromwell , all were given in turn ; for with the happiest knack , the happiest power of jumping and guessing , [he]133-mr. crawford could always alight at will on the best scene , or the best speeches of each ; and whether it were dignity , or pride , or tenderness , or remorse , or whatever were to be expressed , [he]133-mr. crawford could do it with equal beauty . It was truly dramatic . [His]133-mr. crawford acting had first taught [Fanny]113-fanny what pleasure a play might give , and [his]133-mr. crawford reading brought all [his]133-mr. crawford acting before [her]106-lady bertram again ; nay , perhaps with greater enjoyment , for it came unexpectedly , and with no such drawback as [she]106-lady bertram had been used to suffer in seeing [him]133-mr. crawford on the stage with [Miss Bertram]112-julia . [Edmund]108-edmund watched the progress of [her]106-lady bertram attention , and was amused and gratified by seeing how [she]106-lady bertram gradually slackened in the needlework , which at the beginning seemed to occupy [her]106-lady bertram totally : how it fell from [her]106-lady bertram hand while [she]106-lady bertram sat motionless over it , and at last , how the eyes which had appeared so studiously to avoid [him]133-mr. crawford throughout the day were turned and fixed on [Crawford]133-mr. crawford — fixed on [him]133-mr. crawford for minutes , fixed on [him]133-mr. crawford , in short , till the attraction drew [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s upon [her]106-lady bertram , and the book was closed , and the charm was broken . Then [she]106-lady bertram was shrinking again into [herself]106-lady bertram , and blushing and working as hard as ever ; but it had been enough to give [Edmund]108-edmund encouragement for [[his]108-edmund friend]319-his friend , and as [he]108-edmund cordially thanked [him]108-edmund , [he]108-edmund hoped to be expressing [Fanny]113-fanny ’s secret feelings too . “ That play must be a favourite with [you]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund ; “ [you]113-fanny read as if [you]113-fanny knew it well . ”[108-edmund] “ It will be a favourite , [I]133-mr. crawford believe , from this hour , ”[133-mr. crawford] replied [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ; “ but [I]133-mr. crawford do not think [I]133-mr. crawford have had a volume of Shakespeare in [my]133-mr. crawford hand before since [I]133-mr. crawford was fifteen . [I]133-mr. crawford once saw [Henry the Eighth]250-henry the eighth acted , or [I]133-mr. crawford have heard of it from somebody who did , [I]133-mr. crawford am not certain which . But [Shakespeare]251-shakespeare [one]766-one gets acquainted with without knowing how . It is a part of [an Englishman]5775-an englishman ’s constitution . [His]251-shakespeare thoughts and beauties are so spread abroad that [one]766-one touches them everywhere ; [one]766-one is intimate with [him]251-shakespeare by instinct .
