[No man of any brain]5778-no man of any brain can open at a good part of one of [his]251-shakespeare plays without falling into the flow of [his]251-shakespeare meaning immediately . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ No doubt [one]766-one is familiar with [Shakespeare]251-shakespeare in a degree , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , “ from one ’s earliest years . [His]251-shakespeare celebrated passages are quoted by [everybody]408-everybody ; they are in half the books [we]5781-we open , and [we]5781-we all talk [Shakespeare]251-shakespeare , use [his]251-shakespeare similes , and describe with [his]251-shakespeare descriptions ; but this is totally distinct from giving [his]251-shakespeare sense as [you]108-edmund gave it . To know [him]251-shakespeare in bits and scraps is common enough ; to know [him]251-shakespeare pretty thoroughly is , perhaps , not uncommon ; but to read [him]251-shakespeare well aloud is no everyday talent . ”[108-edmund] “ [Sir]4023-sir , [you]4023-sir do [me]133-mr. crawford honour , ”[133-mr. crawford] was [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s answer , with a bow of mock gravity . [Both gentlemen]2580-both gentlemen had a glance at [Fanny]113-fanny , to see if a word of accordant praise could be extorted from [her]2581-her ; yet both feeling that it could not be . [Her]2581-her praise had been given in [her]2581-her attention ; _ that _ must content [them]2580-both gentlemen . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s admiration was expressed , and strongly too . “ It was really like being at a play , ”[2581-her] said [she]2581-her . “ [I]133-mr. crawford wish [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had been [here]3798-here . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Crawford]133-mr. crawford was excessively pleased . If [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , with all [her]106-lady bertram incompetency and languor , could feel this , the inference of what [[her]106-lady bertram niece]642-her niece , alive and enlightened as [she]2581-her was , must feel , was elevating . “ [You]133-mr. crawford have a great turn for acting , [I]921-her ladyship am sure , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , ”[921-her ladyship] said [[her]2581-her ladyship]921-her ladyship soon afterwards ; “ and [I]921-her ladyship will tell [you]133-mr. crawford what , [I]921-her ladyship think [you]133-mr. crawford will have [a theatre]4649-a theatre , some time or other , at [[your]133-mr. crawford house in [Norfolk]19-norfolk]5785-your house in norfolk . [I]921-her ladyship mean when [you]133-mr. crawford are settled [there]3696-there . [I]921-her ladyship do indeed . [I]921-her ladyship think [you]133-mr. crawford will fit up [a theatre at [[your]133-mr. crawford house in [Norfolk]19-norfolk]5785-your house in norfolk]5787-a theatre at your house in norfolk . ”[921-her ladyship] “ Do [you]113-fanny , [ma’am]4007-ma’am ? ”[2584-he] cried [he]2584-he , with quickness . “ No , no , that will never be . [[Your]133-mr. crawford ladyship]4820-your ladyship is quite mistaken . [No theatre at [Everingham]31-everingham]5791-no theatre at everingham ! Oh no ! ”[2584-he] And [he]2584-he looked at [Fanny]113-fanny with an expressive smile , which evidently meant , “ [That lady]1076-that lady will never allow [a theatre at [Everingham]31-everingham]5793-a theatre at everingham . ”[2584-he] [Edmund]108-edmund saw it all , and saw [Fanny]113-fanny so determined _ not _ to see it , as to make it clear that the voice was enough to convey the full meaning of the protestation ; and such a quick consciousness of compliment , such a ready comprehension of a hint , [he]108-edmund thought , was rather favourable than not . The subject of reading aloud was farther discussed . [The two young men]2189-the two young men were [the only talkers]2586-the only talkers , but [they]2189-the two young men , standing by the fire , talked over the too common neglect of the qualification , the total inattention to it , in the ordinary school - system for [boys]4685-boys , the consequently natural , yet in some instances almost unnatural , degree of ignorance and uncouthness of [men]395-men , of [sensible and well - informed men]2589-sensible and well - informed men , when suddenly called to the necessity of reading aloud , which had fallen within [their]2189-the two young men notice , giving instances of blunders , and failures with [their]2189-the two young men secondary causes , the want of management of the voice , of proper modulation and emphasis , of foresight and judgment , all proceeding from the first cause : want of early attention and habit ; and [Fanny]113-fanny was listening again with great entertainment . “ Even in [my]108-edmund profession , ”[108-edmund] said [Edmund]108-edmund , with a smile , “ how little the art of reading has been studied ! how little a clear manner , and good delivery , have been attended to ! [I]108-edmund speak rather of the past , however , than the present . There is now a spirit of improvement abroad ; but among [those who were ordained twenty , thirty , forty years ago]5794-those who were ordained twenty , thirty , forty years ago , the larger number , to judge by [their]5794-those who were ordained twenty , thirty , forty years ago performance , must have thought reading was reading , and preaching was preaching . It is different now . The subject is more justly considered . It is felt that distinctness and energy may have weight in recommending the most solid truths ; and besides , there is more general observation and taste , a more critical knowledge diffused than formerly ; in [every congregation]5795-every congregation there is [a larger proportion who know a little of the matter , and who can judge and criticise]5796-a larger proportion who know a little of the matter , and who can judge and criticise . ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund had already gone through the service once since [his]108-edmund ordination ; and upon this being understood , [he]108-edmund had a variety of questions from [Crawford]133-mr. crawford as to [his]108-edmund feelings and success ; questions , which being made , though with the vivacity of friendly interest and quick taste , without any touch of that spirit of banter or air of levity which [Edmund]108-edmund knew to be most offensive to [Fanny]113-fanny , [he]108-edmund had true pleasure in satisfying ; and when [Crawford]133-mr. crawford proceeded to ask [his]133-mr. crawford opinion and give [his]133-mr. crawford own as to the properest manner in which particular passages in the service should be delivered , [shewing]2590-shewing it to be a subject on which [he]133-mr. crawford had thought before , and thought with judgment , [Edmund]108-edmund was still more and more pleased . This would be the way to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s heart . [She]2591-she was not to be won by all that gallantry and wit and good - nature together could do ; or , at least , [she]2591-she would not be won by [them]2592-them nearly so soon , without the assistance of sentiment and feeling , and seriousness on serious subjects . “ [Our]5797-our liturgy , ”[133-mr. crawford] observed [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , “ has beauties , which not even a careless , slovenly style of reading can destroy ; but it has also redundancies and repetitions which require good reading not to be felt . For [myself]133-mr. crawford , at least , [I]133-mr. crawford must confess being not always so attentive as [I]133-mr. crawford ought to be ”[133-mr. crawford] ( here was a glance at [Fanny]113-fanny ) ; “ that nineteen times out of twenty [I]133-mr. crawford am thinking how such a prayer ought to be read , and longing to have it to read [myself]133-mr. crawford . Did [you]113-fanny speak ? ”[133-mr. crawford] stepping eagerly to [Fanny]113-fanny , and addressing [her]2591-she in a softened voice ; and upon [her]2591-she saying “ No , ”[108-edmund] [he]108-edmund added , “ Are [you]113-fanny sure [you]113-fanny did not speak ? [I]108-edmund saw [your]113-fanny lips move . [I]108-edmund fancied [you]113-fanny might be going to tell [me]108-edmund [I]108-edmund ought to be more attentive , and not _ allow _ [my]108-edmund thoughts to wander . Are not [you]113-fanny going to tell [me]108-edmund so ? ”[108-edmund] “ No , indeed , [you]113-fanny know [your]113-fanny duty too well for [me]2591-she to — even supposing — ”[2591-she] [She]2591-she stopt , felt [herself]2591-she getting into a puzzle , and could not be prevailed on to add another word , not by dint of several minutes of supplication and waiting . [He]108-edmund then returned to [[his]108-edmund former station]2593-his former station , and went on as if there had been no such tender interruption . “ A sermon , well delivered , is more uncommon even than prayers well read . A sermon , good in itself , is no rare thing . It is more difficult to speak well than to compose well ; that is , the rules and trick of composition are oftener an object of study . A thoroughly good sermon , thoroughly well delivered , is a capital gratification . [I]108-edmund can never hear [such a one]5798-such a one without the greatest admiration and respect , and more than half a mind to take orders and preach [myself]108-edmund . There is something in the eloquence of the pulpit , when it is really eloquence , which is entitled to the highest praise and honour . [The preacher who can touch and affect such an heterogeneous mass of [hearers , on subjects limited , and long worn threadbare in all common hands]5800-hearers , on subjects limited , and long worn threadbare in all common hands ; who can say anything new or striking , anything that rouses the attention without offending the taste , or wearing out the feelings of [[his]5799-the preacher who can touch and affect such an heterogeneous mass of hearers , on subjects limited , and long worn threadbare in all common hands ; who can say anything new or striking , anything that rouses the attention without offending the taste , or wearing out the feelings of his hearers hearers]1232-his hearers]5799-the preacher who can touch and affect such an heterogeneous mass of hearers , on subjects limited , and long worn threadbare in all common hands ; who can say anything new or striking , anything that rouses the attention without offending the taste , or wearing out the feelings of his hearers , is [a man whom [one]766-one could not , in [his]5799-the preacher who can touch and affect such an heterogeneous mass of hearers , on subjects limited , and long worn threadbare in all common hands ; who can say anything new or striking , anything that rouses the attention without offending the taste , or wearing out the feelings of his hearers public capacity]5802-a man whom one could not , in his public capacity , honour enough . [I]108-edmund should like to be such [a man]4410-a man . ”[108-edmund] [Edmund]108-edmund laughed . “ [I]108-edmund should indeed . [I]108-edmund never listened to [a distinguished preacher]5805-a distinguished preacher in [my]108-edmund life without a sort of envy . But then , [I]108-edmund must have a [London]6-london audience . [I]108-edmund could not preach but to [the educated]5806-the educated ; to [those who were capable of estimating [my]108-edmund composition]5807-those who were capable of estimating my composition . And [I]108-edmund do not know that [I]108-edmund should be fond of preaching often ; now and then , perhaps once or twice in the spring , after being anxiously expected for half a dozen Sundays together ; but not for a constancy ; it would not do for a constancy . ”[108-edmund] Here [Fanny]113-fanny , who could not but listen , involuntarily shook [her]2594-her head , and [Crawford]133-mr. crawford was instantly by [her]2594-her side again , entreating to know [her]2594-her meaning ; and as [Edmund]108-edmund perceived , by [his]108-edmund drawing in a chair , and sitting down close by [her]2594-her , that it was to be a very thorough attack , that looks and undertones were to be well tried , [he]108-edmund sank as quietly as possible into a corner , turned [his]108-edmund back , and took up a newspaper , very sincerely wishing that [dear little Fanny]113-fanny might be persuaded into explaining away that shake of the head to the satisfaction of [[her]2594-her ardent lover]2595-her ardent lover ; and as earnestly trying to bury every sound of the business from [himself]108-edmund in murmurs of [his]108-edmund own , over the various advertisements of “ [A most desirable Estate in [South Wales]79-south wales]5808-a most desirable estate in south wales ”[113-fanny] ; “ To [Parents]5809-parents and [Guardians ”]5810-guardians ”[108-edmund] ; and a “ Capital season’d [Hunter]252-hunter . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny , meanwhile , vexed with [herself]113-fanny for not having been as motionless as [she]2594-her was speechless , and grieved to the heart to see [Edmund]108-edmund ’s arrangements , was trying by everything in the power of [her]2594-her modest , gentle nature , to repulse [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and avoid both [his]133-mr. crawford looks and inquiries ; and [he]133-mr. crawford , unrepulsable , was persisting in both . “ What did that shake of the head mean ? ”[133-mr. crawford] said [he]133-mr. crawford . “ What was it meant to express ? Disapprobation , [I]133-mr. crawford fear . But of what ? What had [I]133-mr. crawford been saying to displease [you]113-fanny ? Did [you]113-fanny think [me]133-mr. crawford speaking improperly , lightly , irreverently on the subject ? Only tell [me]133-mr. crawford if [I]133-mr. crawford was . Only tell [me]133-mr. crawford if [I]133-mr. crawford was wrong . [I]133-mr. crawford want to be set right . Nay , nay , [I]133-mr. crawford entreat [you]113-fanny ; for one moment put down [your]113-fanny work . What did that shake of the head mean ? ”[133-mr. crawford] In vain was [her]2594-her “ Pray , [sir]4023-sir , do n’t ; pray , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , ”[2594-her] repeated twice over ; and in vain did [she]2594-her try to move away . In the same low , eager voice , and [the same close neighbourhood]2596-the same close neighbourhood , [he]133-mr. crawford went on , reurging the same questions as before . [She]2594-her grew more agitated and displeased . “ How can [you]133-mr. crawford , [sir]4023-sir ? [You]113-fanny quite astonish [me]2594-her ; [I]2594-her wonder how [you]113-fanny can — ”[2594-her] “ Do [I]133-mr. crawford astonish [you]2594-her ? ”[133-mr. crawford] said [he]133-mr. crawford . “ Do [you]113-fanny wonder ? Is there anything in [my]133-mr. crawford present entreaty that [you]113-fanny do not understand ? [I]133-mr. crawford will explain to [you]113-fanny instantly all that makes [me]133-mr. crawford urge [you]113-fanny in this manner , all that gives [me]133-mr. crawford an interest in what [you]113-fanny look and do , and excites [my]133-mr. crawford present curiosity . [I]133-mr. crawford will not leave [you]113-fanny to wonder long . ”[133-mr. crawford] In spite of [herself]2597-you , [she]2597-you could not help half a smile , but [she]2597-you said nothing . “ [You]113-fanny shook [your]113-fanny head at [my]133-mr. crawford acknowledging that [I]133-mr. crawford should not like to engage in the duties of [a clergyman]500-a clergyman always for a constancy . Yes , that was the word . Constancy : [I]133-mr. crawford am not afraid of the word . [I]133-mr. crawford would spell it , read it , write it with [anybody]3668-anybody . [I]133-mr. crawford see nothing alarming in the word . Did [you]113-fanny think [I]133-mr. crawford ought ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Perhaps , [sir]4023-sir , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , wearied at last into speaking—“perhaps , [sir]4023-sir , [I]133-mr. crawford thought it was a pity [you]4023-sir did not always know [yourself]4023-sir as well as [you]4023-sir seemed to do at that moment . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , delighted to get [her]2597-you to speak at any rate , was determined to keep it up ; and [poor [Fanny]113-fanny , who had hoped to silence [him]133-mr. crawford by such an extremity of reproof]113-fanny , found [herself]113-fanny sadly mistaken , and that it was only a change from one object of curiosity and one set of words to another . [He]133-mr. crawford had always something to entreat the explanation of . The opportunity was too fair . None such had occurred since [his]133-mr. crawford seeing [her]2597-you in [[[her]2597-you uncle]312-her uncle ’s room]2599-her uncle ’s room , none such might occur again before [his]133-mr. crawford leaving [Mansfield]3-mansfield . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s being just on the other side of the table was a trifle , for [she]106-lady bertram might always be considered as only half - awake , and [Edmund]108-edmund ’s advertisements were still of the first utility . “ Well , ”[133-mr. crawford] said [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , after a course of rapid questions and reluctant answers ; “ [I]133-mr. crawford am happier than [I]133-mr. crawford was , because [I]133-mr. crawford now understand more clearly [your]2597-you opinion of [me]133-mr. crawford . [You]2597-you think [me]133-mr. crawford unsteady : easily swayed by the whim of the moment , easily tempted , easily put aside . With such an opinion , no wonder that — But [we]5817-we shall see.—It is not by protestations that [I]133-mr. crawford shall endeavour to convince [you]2597-you [I]133-mr. crawford am wronged ; it is not by telling [you]2597-you that [my]133-mr. crawford affections are steady . [My]133-mr. crawford conduct shall speak for [me]133-mr. crawford ; absence , distance , time shall speak for [me]133-mr. crawford . _ [They]5818-they _ shall prove that , as far as [you]2597-you can be deserved by [anybody]3668-anybody , [I]133-mr. crawford do deserve [you]2597-you . [You]2597-you are infinitely [my]133-mr. crawford superior in merit ; all _ that _ [I]133-mr. crawford know . [You]2597-you have qualities which [I]133-mr. crawford had not before supposed to exist in such a degree in [any human creature]5820-any human creature . [You]2597-you have some touches of the angel in [you]2597-you beyond what — not merely beyond what [one]766-one sees , because [one]766-one never sees anything like it — but beyond what one fancies might be . But still [I]133-mr. crawford am not frightened . It is not by equality of merit that [you]2597-you can be won . That is out of the question . It is [he]5823-he who sees and worships [your]2597-you merit the strongest , who loves [you]2597-you most devotedly , that has the best right to a return . There [I]133-mr. crawford build [my]133-mr. crawford confidence . By that right [I]133-mr. crawford do and will deserve [you]2597-you ; and when once convinced that [my]133-mr. crawford attachment is what [I]133-mr. crawford declare it , [I]133-mr. crawford know [you]2597-you too well not to entertain the warmest hopes . Yes , dearest , sweetest [Fanny]113-fanny . Nay ”[133-mr. crawford] ( seeing [her]2600-she draw back displeased ) , “ forgive [me]133-mr. crawford . Perhaps [I]133-mr. crawford have as yet no right ; but by what other name can [I]133-mr. crawford call [you]2597-you ? Do [you]2597-you suppose [you]2597-you are ever present to [my]133-mr. crawford imagination under any other ? No , it is ‘ [Fanny]113-fanny ’ that [I]133-mr. crawford think of all day , and dream of all night . [You]2597-you have given the name such reality of sweetness , that nothing else can now be descriptive of [you]2597-you . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny could hardly have kept [her]2600-she seat any longer , or have refrained from at least trying to get away in spite of all the too public opposition [she]2600-she foresaw to it , had it not been for the sound of approaching relief , the very sound which [she]2600-she had been long watching for , and long thinking strangely delayed . The solemn procession , headed by [Baddeley]215-baddeley , of tea - board , [urn , and cake - bearers]2601-urn , and cake - bearers , made its appearance , and delivered [her]2600-she from a grievous imprisonment of body and mind . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was obliged to move . [She]2600-she was at liberty , [she]2600-she was busy , [she]2600-she was protected . [Edmund]108-edmund was not sorry to be admitted again among the number of [those who might speak and hear]2602-those who might speak and hear . But though the conference had seemed full long to [him]108-edmund , and though on looking at [Fanny]113-fanny [he]108-edmund saw rather a flush of vexation , [he]108-edmund inclined to hope that so much could not have been said and listened to without some profit to [the speaker]1638-the speaker . CHAPTER XXXV [Edmund]108-edmund had determined that it belonged entirely to [Fanny]113-fanny to chuse whether [her]2600-she situation with regard to [Crawford]133-mr. crawford should be mentioned between [them]2604-them or not ; and that if [she]2600-she did not lead the way , it should never be touched on by [him]108-edmund ; but after a day or two of mutual reserve , [he]108-edmund was induced by [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father to change [his]108-edmund mind , and try what [his]108-edmund influence might do for [[his]108-edmund friend]319-his friend . A day , and a very early day , was actually fixed for [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords ’ departure ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas thought it might be as well to make one more effort for [the young man]680-the young man before [he]680-the young man left [Mansfield]3-mansfield , that all [his]680-the young man professions and vows of unshaken attachment might have as much hope to sustain [them]2604-them as possible . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was most cordially anxious for the perfection of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s character in that point . [He]101-sir thomas wished [him]680-the young man to be [a model of constancy]2608-a model of constancy ; and fancied the best means of effecting it would be by not trying [him]680-the young man too long . [Edmund]108-edmund was not unwilling to be persuaded to engage in the business ; [he]108-edmund wanted to know [Fanny]113-fanny ’s feelings . [She]319-his friend had been used to consult [him]108-edmund in every difficulty , and [he]108-edmund loved [her]319-his friend too well to bear to be denied [her]319-his friend confidence now ; [he]108-edmund hoped to be of service to [her]319-his friend , [he]108-edmund thought [he]108-edmund must be of service to [her]319-his friend ; whom else had [she]319-his friend to open [her]319-his friend heart to ? If [she]319-his friend did not need counsel , [she]319-his friend must need the comfort of communication . [Fanny]113-fanny estranged from [him]108-edmund , silent and reserved , was an unnatural state of things ; a state which [he]108-edmund must break through , and which [he]108-edmund could easily learn to think [she]319-his friend was wanting [him]108-edmund to break through . “ [I]108-edmund will speak to [her]319-his friend , [sir]4023-sir : [I]108-edmund will take the first opportunity of speaking to [her]319-his friend alone , ”[108-edmund] was the result of such thoughts as these ; and upon [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s information of [her]319-his friend being at that very time walking alone in the shrubbery , [he]108-edmund instantly joined [her]319-his friend . “ [I]108-edmund am come to walk with [you]319-his friend , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund . “ Shall [I]108-edmund ? ”[108-edmund] Drawing [her]319-his friend arm within [his]108-edmund . “ It is a long while since [we]5825-we have had a comfortable walk together . ”[319-his friend] [She]319-his friend assented to it all rather by look than word . [Her]319-his friend spirits were low . “ But , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] [he]108-edmund presently added , “ in order to have a comfortable walk , something more is necessary than merely pacing this gravel together . [You]113-fanny must talk to [me]108-edmund . [I]108-edmund know [you]113-fanny have something on [your]113-fanny mind . [I]108-edmund know what [you]113-fanny are thinking of . [You]113-fanny can not suppose [me]108-edmund uninformed . Am [I]108-edmund to hear of it from [everybody]408-everybody but [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny ? ”[108-edmund] [Fanny]113-fanny , at once agitated and dejected , replied , “ If [you]108-edmund hear of it from [everybody]408-everybody , [cousin]3759-cousin , there can be nothing for [me]113-fanny to tell . ”[113-fanny] “ Not of facts , perhaps ; but of feelings , [Fanny]113-fanny . No one but [you]113-fanny can tell [me]108-edmund [them]5829-them . [I]108-edmund do not mean to press [you]113-fanny , however . If it is not what [you]113-fanny wish [yourself]113-fanny , [I]108-edmund have done . [I]108-edmund had thought it might be a relief . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]113-fanny am afraid [we]5830-we think too differently for [me]113-fanny to find any relief in talking of what [I]113-fanny feel . ”[113-fanny] “ Do [you]113-fanny suppose that [we]5830-we think differently ? [I]113-fanny have no idea of it . [I]113-fanny dare say that , on a comparison of [our]5830-we opinions , [they]5829-them would be found as much alike as they have been used to be : to the point — [I]113-fanny consider [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s proposals as most advantageous and desirable , if [you]113-fanny could return [his]133-mr. crawford affection . [I]113-fanny consider it as most natural that [all [your]113-fanny family]5831-all your family should wish [you]113-fanny could return it ; but that , as [you]113-fanny can not , [you]113-fanny have done exactly as [you]113-fanny ought in refusing [him]133-mr. crawford . Can there be any disagreement between [us]5830-we here ? ”[113-fanny] “ Oh no ! But [I]108-edmund thought [you]113-fanny blamed [me]108-edmund . [I]108-edmund thought [you]113-fanny were against [me]108-edmund . This is such a comfort ! ”[108-edmund] “ This comfort [you]113-fanny might have had sooner , [Fanny]113-fanny , had [you]113-fanny sought it . But how could [you]113-fanny possibly suppose [me]113-fanny against [you]113-fanny ? How could [you]113-fanny imagine [me]113-fanny an advocate for marriage without love ? Were [I]113-fanny even careless in general on such matters , how could [you]113-fanny imagine [me]113-fanny so where [your]113-fanny happiness was at stake ? ”[113-fanny] “ [[My]113-fanny uncle]3761-my uncle thought [me]113-fanny wrong , and [I]113-fanny knew [he]3761-my uncle had been talking to [you]113-fanny . ”[113-fanny] “ As far as [you]113-fanny have gone , [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]108-edmund think [you]113-fanny perfectly right . [I]108-edmund may be sorry , [I]108-edmund may be surprised — though hardly _ that _ , for [you]113-fanny had not had time to attach [yourself]113-fanny — but [I]108-edmund think [you]113-fanny perfectly right . Can it admit of a question ? It is disgraceful to [us]5833-us if it does . [You]113-fanny did not love [him]3761-my uncle ; nothing could have justified [your]113-fanny accepting [him]3761-my uncle . ”[108-edmund] [Fanny]113-fanny had not felt so comfortable for days and days . “ So far [your]113-fanny conduct has been faultless , and [they]5834-they were quite mistaken who wished [you]113-fanny to do otherwise . But the matter does not end here . [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s is no common attachment ; [he]133-mr. crawford perseveres , with the hope of creating that regard which had not been created before . This , [we]5833-us know , must be a work of time . But ”[113-fanny] ( with an affectionate smile ) “ let [him]3761-my uncle succeed at last , [Fanny]113-fanny , let [him]3761-my uncle succeed at last . [You]113-fanny have proved [yourself]113-fanny upright and disinterested , prove [yourself]113-fanny grateful and tender - hearted ; and then [you]113-fanny will be [the perfect model of [a woman which [I]2609-i have always believed [you]113-fanny born for]5836-a woman which i have always believed you born for]5835-the perfect model of a woman which i have always believed you born for . ”[2609-i] “ Oh ! never , never , never ! [he]3761-my uncle never will succeed with [me]2609-i . ”[2609-i] And [she]2609-i spoke with a warmth which quite astonished [Edmund]108-edmund , and which [she]2609-i blushed at the recollection of [herself]2609-i , when [she]2609-i saw [his]108-edmund look , and heard [him]108-edmund reply , “ Never ! [Fanny!—so]253-fanny!—so very determined and positive ! This is not like [yourself]113-fanny , [your]113-fanny rational self . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]2609-i mean , ”[2609-i] [she]2609-i cried , sorrowfully correcting [herself]2609-i , “ that [I]2609-i _ think _ [I]2609-i never shall , as far as the future can be answered for ; [I]2609-i think [I]2609-i never shall return [his]3761-my uncle regard . ”[2609-i] “ [I]108-edmund must hope better things . [I]108-edmund am aware , more aware than [Crawford]133-mr. crawford can be , that [the man who means to make [you]113-fanny love [him]3761-my uncle ( [you]113-fanny having due notice of [his]3761-my uncle intentions]5837-the man who means to make you love him ( you having due notice of his intentions ) must have very uphill work , for there are all [your]113-fanny early attachments and habits in battle array ; and before [he]3761-my uncle can get [your]113-fanny heart for [his]3761-my uncle own use [he]3761-my uncle has to unfasten it from all the holds upon things animate and inanimate , which so many years ’ growth have confirmed , and which are considerably tightened for the moment by the very idea of separation . [I]108-edmund know that the apprehension of being forced to quit [Mansfield]3-mansfield will for a time be arming [you]113-fanny against [him]3761-my uncle . [I]108-edmund wish [he]3761-my uncle had not been obliged to tell [you]113-fanny what [he]3761-my uncle was trying for . [I]108-edmund wish [he]3761-my uncle had known [you]113-fanny as well as [I]108-edmund do , [Fanny]113-fanny . Between [us]5838-we , [I]108-edmund think [we]5838-we should have won [you]113-fanny . [My]108-edmund theoretical and [his]3761-my uncle practical knowledge together could not have failed . [He]3761-my uncle should have worked upon [my]108-edmund plans . [I]108-edmund must hope , however , that time , proving [him]3761-my uncle ( as [I]108-edmund firmly believe it will ) to deserve [you]113-fanny by [his]3761-my uncle steady affection , will give [him]3761-my uncle [his]3761-my uncle reward . [I]108-edmund can not suppose that [you]113-fanny have not the _ wish _ to love [him]3761-my uncle — the natural wish of gratitude . [You]113-fanny must have some feeling of that sort . [You]113-fanny must be sorry for [your]113-fanny own indifference . ”[108-edmund] “ [We]5838-we are so totally unlike , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , avoiding a direct answer , “ [we]5838-we are so very , very different in all [our]5838-we inclinations and ways , that [I]113-fanny consider it as quite impossible [we]5838-we should ever be tolerably happy together , even if [I]113-fanny _ could _ like [him]3761-my uncle . There never were [two people]5839-two people more dissimilar . [We]5838-we have not one taste in common . [We]5838-we should be miserable . ”[113-fanny] “ [You]113-fanny are mistaken , [Fanny]113-fanny . The dissimilarity is not so strong . [You]113-fanny are quite enough alike . [You]113-fanny _ have _ tastes in common . [You]113-fanny have moral and literary tastes in common . [You]113-fanny have both warm hearts and benevolent feelings ; and , [Fanny]113-fanny , who that heard [him]3761-my uncle read , and saw [you]113-fanny listen to [Shakespeare]251-shakespeare the other night , will think [you]113-fanny unfitted as [companions]5840-companions ? [You]113-fanny forget [yourself]113-fanny : there is a decided difference in [your]113-fanny tempers , [I]113-fanny allow . [He]3761-my uncle is lively , [you]113-fanny are serious ; but so much the better : [his]3761-my uncle spirits will support [yours]113-fanny . It is [your]113-fanny disposition to be easily dejected and to fancy difficulties greater than they are . [His]3761-my uncle cheerfulness will counteract this . [He]3761-my uncle sees difficulties nowhere : and [his]3761-my uncle pleasantness and gaiety will be a constant support to [you]113-fanny . [Your]113-fanny being so far unlike , [Fanny]113-fanny , does not in the smallest degree make against the probability of [your]113-fanny happiness together : do not imagine it . [I]113-fanny am [myself]113-fanny convinced that it is rather a favourable circumstance . [I]113-fanny am perfectly persuaded that the tempers had better be unlike : [I]113-fanny mean unlike in the flow of the spirits , in the manners , in the inclination for much or little company , in the propensity to talk or to be silent , to be grave or to be gay . Some opposition here is , [I]113-fanny am thoroughly convinced , friendly to matrimonial happiness . [I]113-fanny exclude extremes , of course ; and a very close resemblance in all those points would be the likeliest way to produce an extreme . A counteraction , gentle and continual , is the best safeguard of manners and conduct . ”[113-fanny] Full well could [Fanny]113-fanny guess where [his]2610-his thoughts were now : [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s power was all returning . [He]2610-his had been speaking of [her]127-miss crawford cheerfully from the hour of [his]2610-his coming [home]367-home . [His]2610-his avoiding [her]127-miss crawford was quite at an end . [He]2610-his had dined at [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage only the preceding day . After leaving [him]2610-his to [his]2610-his happier thoughts for some minutes , [Fanny]113-fanny , feeling it due to [herself]113-fanny , returned to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and said , “ It is not merely in _ temper _ that [I]133-mr. crawford consider [him]2610-his as totally unsuited to [myself]133-mr. crawford ; though , in _ that _ respect , [I]133-mr. crawford think the difference between [us]5841-us too great , infinitely too great : [his]2610-his spirits often oppress [me]133-mr. crawford ; but there is something in [him]2610-his which [I]133-mr. crawford object to still more . [I]133-mr. crawford must say , [cousin]3759-cousin , that [I]133-mr. crawford can not approve [his]2610-his character . [I]133-mr. crawford have not thought well of [him]2610-his from the time of the play . [I]133-mr. crawford then saw [him]2610-his behaving , as it appeared to [me]133-mr. crawford , so very improperly and unfeelingly — [I]133-mr. crawford may speak of it now because it is all over — so improperly by poor [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny , not seeming to care how [he]2610-his exposed or hurt [him]2610-his , and paying attentions to [[my]133-mr. crawford cousin]3764-my cousin [Maria]126-maria , which — in short , at the time of the play , [I]133-mr. crawford received an impression which will never be got over . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [My]108-edmund dear [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] replied [Edmund]108-edmund , scarcely hearing [her]2613-her to the end , “ let [us]5844-we not , any of [us]5844-we , be judged by what [we]5844-we appeared at that period of general folly . The time of the play is a time which [I]108-edmund hate to recollect . [Maria]126-maria was wrong , [Crawford]133-mr. crawford was wrong , [we]5844-we were all wrong together ; but none so wrong as [myself]108-edmund . Compared with [me]108-edmund , [all the rest]5845-all the rest were blameless . [I]108-edmund was playing [the fool]4889-the fool with [my]108-edmund eyes open . ”[108-edmund] “ As [a bystander]1347-a bystander , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , “ perhaps [I]113-fanny saw more than [you]108-edmund did ; and [I]113-fanny do think that [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny was sometimes very jealous . ”[113-fanny] “ Very possibly . No wonder . Nothing could be more improper than the whole business . [I]108-edmund am shocked whenever [I]108-edmund think that [Maria]126-maria could be capable of it ; but , if [she]126-maria could undertake the part , [we]5844-we must not be surprised at the rest . ”[108-edmund] “ Before the play , [I]108-edmund am much mistaken if _ [Julia]112-julia _ did not think [he]113-fanny was paying [her]112-julia attentions . ”[108-edmund] “ [Julia]112-julia ! [I]113-fanny have heard before from some one of [his]113-fanny being in love with [Julia]112-julia ; but [I]113-fanny could never see anything of it . And , [Fanny]113-fanny , though [I]113-fanny hope [I]113-fanny do justice to [[my]113-fanny sisters]4714-my sisters ’ good qualities , [I]113-fanny think it very possible that [they]4714-my sisters might , one or both , be more desirous of being admired by [Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and might shew that desire rather more unguardedly than was perfectly prudent . [I]113-fanny can remember that [they]4714-my sisters were evidently fond of [his]113-fanny society ; and with such encouragement , [a man like [Crawford]133-mr. crawford]5849-a man like crawford , lively , and it may be , a little unthinking , might be led on to — there could be nothing very striking , because it is clear that [he]113-fanny had no pretensions : [his]113-fanny heart was reserved for [you]113-fanny . And [I]113-fanny must say , that its being for [you]113-fanny has raised [him]113-fanny inconceivably in [my]113-fanny opinion . It does [him]113-fanny the highest honour ; it shews [his]113-fanny proper estimation of the blessing of domestic happiness and pure attachment . It proves [him]113-fanny unspoilt by [[his]113-fanny uncle]526-his uncle . It proves [him]113-fanny , in short , everything that [I]113-fanny had been used to wish to believe [him]113-fanny , and feared [he]113-fanny was not . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]108-edmund am persuaded that [he]113-fanny does not think , as [he]113-fanny ought , on serious subjects . ”[108-edmund] “ Say , rather , that [he]113-fanny has not thought at all upon serious subjects , which [I]108-edmund believe to be a good deal the case . How could it be otherwise , with such an education and [adviser]5851-adviser ? Under the disadvantages , indeed , which [both]5359-both have had , is it not wonderful that they should be what [they]5359-both are ? [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s _ feelings _ , [I]108-edmund am ready to acknowledge , have hitherto been too much [[his]133-mr. crawford guides]5853-his guides . Happily , those feelings have generally been good . [You]5854-you will supply the rest ; and [a most fortunate man]5855-a most fortunate man [he]5855-a most fortunate man is to attach [himself]5855-a most fortunate man to [such a creature]5593-such a creature — to [a woman who , firm as a rock in [her]5857-a woman who , firm as a rock in her own principles own principles]5857-a woman who , firm as a rock in her own principles , has a gentleness of character so well adapted to recommend [them]5359-both . [He]5855-a most fortunate man has chosen [[his]5855-a most fortunate man partner]2249-his partner , indeed , with rare felicity . [He]5855-a most fortunate man will make [you]113-fanny happy , [Fanny]113-fanny ; [I]108-edmund know [he]5855-a most fortunate man will make [you]113-fanny happy ; but [you]113-fanny will make [him]5855-a most fortunate man everything . ”[108-edmund] “ [I]113-fanny would not engage in such a charge , ”[113-fanny] cried [Fanny]113-fanny , in a shrinking accent ; “ in such an office of high responsibility ! ”[113-fanny] “ As usual , believing [yourself]113-fanny unequal to anything ! fancying everything too much for [you]113-fanny ! Well , though [I]113-fanny may not be able to persuade [you]113-fanny into different feelings , [you]113-fanny will be persuaded into them , [I]113-fanny trust . [I]113-fanny confess [myself]113-fanny sincerely anxious that [you]113-fanny may . [I]113-fanny have no common interest in [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s well - doing . Next to [your]113-fanny happiness , [Fanny]113-fanny , [his]133-mr. crawford has the first claim on [me]113-fanny . [You]113-fanny are aware of [my]113-fanny having no common interest in [Crawford]133-mr. crawford . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny was too well aware of it to have anything to say ; and [they]2614-they walked on together some fifty yards in mutual silence and abstraction . [Edmund]108-edmund first began again — “ [I]108-edmund was very much pleased by [her]5859-she manner of speaking of it yesterday , particularly pleased , because [I]108-edmund had not depended upon [her]5859-she seeing everything in so just a light . [I]108-edmund knew [she]5859-she was very fond of [you]113-fanny ; but yet [I]108-edmund was afraid of [her]5859-she not estimating [your]113-fanny worth to [[her]5859-she brother]451-her brother quite as it deserved , and of [her]5859-she regretting that [he]451-her brother had not rather fixed on [some woman of distinction or fortune]5861-some woman of distinction or fortune . [I]108-edmund was afraid of the bias of those worldly maxims , which [she]5859-she has been too much used to hear . But it was very different . [She]5859-she spoke of [you]113-fanny , [Fanny]113-fanny , just as [she]5859-she ought . [She]5859-she desires the connexion as warmly as [[your]113-fanny uncle]3760-your uncle or [myself]108-edmund . [We]5863-we had a long talk about it . [I]108-edmund should not have mentioned the subject , though very anxious to know [her]5859-she sentiments ; but [I]108-edmund had not been in [the room]412-the room five minutes before [she]5859-she began introducing it with all that openness of heart , and sweet peculiarity of manner , that spirit and ingenuousness which are so much a part of [herself]5859-she . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant laughed at [her]5859-she for [her]5859-she rapidity . ”[108-edmund] “ Was [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant in [the room]412-the room , then ? ”[113-fanny] “ Yes , when [I]113-fanny reached [the house]427-the house [I]113-fanny found [the two sisters]1810-the two sisters together by [themselves]1810-the two sisters ; and when once [we]5863-we had begun , [we]5863-we had not done with [you]5868-you , [Fanny]113-fanny , till [Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant came in . ”[113-fanny] “ It is above a week since [I]108-edmund saw [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . ”[108-edmund] “ Yes , [she]5859-she laments it ; yet owns it may have been best . [You]5868-you will see [her]5859-she , however , before [she]5859-she goes . [She]5859-she is very angry with [you]5868-you , [Fanny]113-fanny ; [you]5868-you must be prepared for that . [She]5859-she calls [herself]5859-she very angry , but [you]5868-you can imagine [her]5859-she anger . It is the regret and disappointment of [a sister]3681-a sister , who thinks [[her]5859-she brother]451-her brother has a right to everything [he]451-her brother may wish for , at the first moment . [She]5859-she is hurt , as [you]5868-you would be for [William]228-william ; but [she]5859-she loves and esteems [you]5868-you with all [her]5859-she heart . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny knew [she]5859-she would be very angry with [me]113-fanny . ”[113-fanny] “ [[My]108-edmund dearest]5134-my dearest [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] cried [Edmund]108-edmund , pressing [her]2615-her arm closer to [him]2615-her , “ do not let the idea of [her]5859-she anger distress [you]5868-you . It is anger to be talked of rather than felt . [Her]5859-she heart is made for love and kindness , not for resentment . [I]108-edmund wish [you]5868-you could have overheard [her]5859-she tribute of praise ; [I]108-edmund wish [you]5868-you could have seen [her]5859-she countenance , when [she]5859-she said that [you]5868-you _ should _ be [[Henry]250-henry the eighth ’s wife]5872-henry ’s wife . And [I]108-edmund observed that [she]5859-she always spoke of [you]5868-you as ‘ [Fanny]113-fanny , ’ which [she]5859-she was never used to do ; and it had a sound of most sisterly cordiality . ”[108-edmund] “ And [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , did [she]5859-she say — did [she]5859-she speak ; was [she]5859-she there all the time ? ”[113-fanny] “ Yes , [she]5859-she was agreeing exactly with [[her]5859-she sister]331-her sister . The surprise of [your]5868-you refusal , [Fanny]113-fanny , seems to have been unbounded . That [you]5868-you could refuse [such a man as [Henry Crawford]131-henry]5874-such a man as henry crawford seems more than [they]5875-they can understand . [I]113-fanny said what [I]113-fanny could for [you]5868-you ; but in good truth , as [they]5875-they stated the case — [you]5868-you must prove [yourself]5868-you to be in [your]5868-you senses as soon as [you]5868-you can by a different conduct ; nothing else will satisfy [them]5875-they . But this is teasing [you]5868-you . [I]113-fanny have done . Do not turn away from [me]113-fanny . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny _ should _ have thought , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , after a pause of recollection and exertion , “ that [every woman]2334-every woman must have felt the possibility of [a man]4410-a man ’s not being approved , not being loved by [some one of [her]2334-every woman sex]5878-some one of her sex at least , let [him]4410-a man be ever so generally agreeable . Let [him]4410-a man have all the perfections in [the world]315-the world , [I]113-fanny think it ought not to be set down as certain that [a man]4410-a man must be acceptable to [every woman [he]4410-a man may happen to like [himself]4410-a man]5881-every woman he may happen to like himself . But , even supposing it is so , allowing [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford to have all the claims which [[his]133-mr. crawford sisters]4166-his sisters think [he]133-mr. crawford has , how was [I]113-fanny to be prepared to meet [him]133-mr. crawford with any feeling answerable to [his]133-mr. crawford own ? [He]133-mr. crawford took [me]113-fanny wholly by surprise . [I]113-fanny had not an idea that [his]133-mr. crawford behaviour to [me]113-fanny before had any meaning ; and surely [I]113-fanny was not to be teaching [myself]113-fanny to like [him]133-mr. crawford only because [he]133-mr. crawford was taking what seemed very idle notice of [me]113-fanny . In [my]113-fanny situation , it would have been the extreme of vanity to be forming expectations on [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . [I]113-fanny am sure [[his]133-mr. crawford sisters]4166-his sisters , rating [him]133-mr. crawford as [they]4166-his sisters do , must have thought it so , supposing [he]133-mr. crawford had meant nothing . How , then , was [I]113-fanny to be — to be in love with [him]133-mr. crawford the moment [he]133-mr. crawford said [he]133-mr. crawford was with [me]113-fanny ? How was [I]113-fanny to have an attachment at [his]133-mr. crawford service , as soon as it was asked for ? [[His]133-mr. crawford sisters]4166-his sisters should consider [me]113-fanny as well as [him]133-mr. crawford . The higher [his]133-mr. crawford deserts , the more improper for [me]113-fanny ever to have thought of [him]133-mr. crawford . And , and — [we]5885-we think very differently of the nature of [women]988-women , if [they]988-women can imagine [a woman]644-a woman so very soon capable of returning an affection as this seems to imply . ”[113-fanny] “ [[My]113-fanny dear]3657-my dear , dear [Fanny]113-fanny , now [I]113-fanny have the truth . [I]113-fanny know this to be the truth ; and most worthy of [you]113-fanny are such feelings . [I]113-fanny had attributed them to [you]113-fanny before . [I]113-fanny thought [I]113-fanny could understand [you]113-fanny . [You]113-fanny have now given exactly the explanation which [I]113-fanny ventured to make for [you]113-fanny to [[your]113-fanny friend]5889-your friend and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , and [they]5890-them were both better satisfied , though [[your]113-fanny warm - hearted friend]5891-your warm - hearted friend was still run away with a little by the enthusiasm of [her]5891-your warm - hearted friend fondness for [Henry]131-henry . [I]113-fanny told [them]5890-them that [you]113-fanny were of [all human creatures]5892-all human creatures [the one over whom habit had most power and novelty least]5893-the one over whom habit had most power and novelty least ; and that the very circumstance of the novelty of [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s addresses was against [him]133-mr. crawford . [Their]5890-them being so new and so recent was all in [their]5890-them disfavour ; that [you]113-fanny could tolerate nothing that [you]113-fanny were not used to ; and a great deal more to the same purpose , to give [them]5890-them a knowledge of [your]113-fanny character . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford made [us]5894-us laugh by [her]127-miss crawford plans of encouragement for [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother . [She]127-miss crawford meant to urge [him]451-her brother to persevere in the hope of being loved in time , and of having [his]451-her brother addresses most kindly received at the end of about ten years ’ happy marriage . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny could with difficulty give the smile that was here asked for . [Her]2616-her feelings were all in revolt . [She]2616-her feared [she]2616-her had been doing wrong : saying too much , overacting the caution which [she]2616-her had been fancying necessary ; in guarding against one evil , laying [herself]2616-her open to another ; and to have [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s liveliness repeated to [her]2616-her at such a moment , and on such a subject , was a bitter aggravation . [Edmund]108-edmund saw weariness and distress in [her]2616-her face , and immediately resolved to forbear all farther discussion ; and not even to mention the name of [Crawford]133-mr. crawford again , except as it might be connected with what _ must _ be agreeable to [her]2616-her . On this principle , [he]108-edmund soon afterwards observed—“They go on Monday . [You]5896-you are sure , therefore , of seeing [[your]5896-you friend]5889-your friend either to - morrow or Sunday . [They]5889-your friend really go on Monday ; and [I]108-edmund was within a trifle of being persuaded to stay at [Lessingby]80-lessingby till that very day ! [I]108-edmund had almost promised it . What a difference it might have made ! Those five or six days more at [Lessingby]80-lessingby might have been felt all [my]108-edmund life . ”[108-edmund] “ [You]108-edmund were near staying [there]3696-there ? ”[2617-he] “ Very . [I]2617-he was most kindly pressed , and had nearly consented . Had [I]2617-he received any letter from [Mansfield]130-mansfield , to tell [me]2617-he how [you]5896-you were all going on , [I]2617-he believe [I]2617-he should certainly have staid ; but [I]2617-he knew nothing that had happened [here]3798-here for a fortnight , and felt that [I]2617-he had been away long enough . ”[2617-he] “ [You]108-edmund spent [your]108-edmund time pleasantly [there]3696-there ? ”[108-edmund] “ Yes ; that is , it was the fault of [my]108-edmund own mind if [I]108-edmund did not . [They]5896-you were all very pleasant . [I]108-edmund doubt [their]5896-you finding [me]108-edmund so . [I]108-edmund took uneasiness with [me]108-edmund , and there was no getting rid of it till [I]108-edmund was in [Mansfield]3-mansfield again . ”[108-edmund] “ [The Miss Owens]244-the miss owens — [you]108-edmund liked [them]5896-you , did not [you]108-edmund ? ”[2617-he] “ Yes , very well . [Pleasant , good - humoured , unaffected girls]5901-pleasant , good - humoured , unaffected girls . But [I]108-edmund am spoilt , [Fanny]113-fanny , for common female society . [Good - humoured , unaffected girls]5902-good - humoured , unaffected girls will not do for [a man who has been used to [sensible women]5904-sensible women]5903-a man who has been used to sensible women . [They]5902-good - humoured , unaffected girls are two distinct orders of being . [You]113-fanny and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford have made [me]108-edmund too nice . ”[108-edmund] Still , however , [Fanny]113-fanny was oppressed and wearied ; [he]2617-he saw it in [her]2618-her looks , it could not be talked away ; and attempting it no more , [he]2617-he led [her]2618-her directly , with the kind authority of [a privileged guardian]2619-a privileged guardian , into [the house]427-the house . CHAPTER XXXVI [Edmund]108-edmund now believed [himself]2617-he perfectly acquainted with all that [Fanny]113-fanny could tell , or could leave to be conjectured of [her]2618-her sentiments , and [he]2617-he was satisfied . It had been , as [he]2617-he before presumed , too hasty a measure on [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s side , and time must be given to make the idea first familiar , and then agreeable to [her]2618-her . [She]2618-her must be used to the consideration of [his]2617-he being in love with [her]2618-her , and then a return of affection might not be very distant . [He]2617-he gave this opinion as the result of the conversation to [[his]2617-he father]534-his father ; and recommended there being nothing more said to [her]2618-her : no farther attempts to influence or persuade ; but that everything should be left to [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s assiduities , and the natural workings of [her]2618-her own mind . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas promised that it should be so . [Edmund]108-edmund ’s account of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s disposition [he]2617-he could believe to be just ; [he]2617-he supposed [she]2618-her had all those feelings , but [he]2617-he must consider it as very unfortunate that [she]2618-her _ had _ ; for , less willing than [[his]2617-he son]581-his son to trust to the future , [he]2617-he could not help fearing that if such very long allowances of time and habit were necessary for [her]2618-her , [she]2618-her might not have persuaded [herself]2618-her into receiving [his]2617-he addresses properly before [the young man]680-the young man ’s inclination for paying [them]2624-them were over . There was nothing to be done , however , but to submit quietly and hope the best . The promised visit from “ [[her]2618-her friend]1394-her friend , ”[108-edmund] as [Edmund]108-edmund called [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , was a formidable threat to [Fanny]113-fanny , and [she]2618-her lived in continual terror of it . As [a sister]3681-a sister , so partial and so angry , and so little scrupulous of what [she]2618-her said , and in another light so triumphant and secure , [she]2618-her was in every way an object of painful alarm . [Her]2618-her displeasure , [her]2618-her penetration , and [her]2618-her happiness were all fearful to encounter ; and the dependence of having [others present]2626-others present when [they]2627-they met was [Fanny]113-fanny ’s only support in looking forward to it . [She]2618-her absented [herself]2618-her as little as possible from [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , kept away from [the East room]1380-the east room , and took no solitary walk in the shrubbery , in [her]2618-her caution to avoid any sudden attack . [She]2618-her succeeded . [She]2618-her was safe in [the breakfast - room]3756-the breakfast - room , with [[her]2618-her aunt]463-her aunt , when [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford did come ; and the first misery over , and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford looking and speaking with much less particularity of expression than [she]2618-her had anticipated , [Fanny]113-fanny began to hope there would be nothing worse to be endured than a half - hour of moderate agitation . But here [she]2618-her hoped too much ; [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford was not [the slave of opportunity]2631-the slave of opportunity . [She]127-miss crawford was determined to see [Fanny]113-fanny alone , and therefore said to [her]2618-her tolerably soon , in a low voice , “ [I]127-miss crawford must speak to [you]2618-her for a few minutes somewhere ”[127-miss crawford] ; words that [Fanny]113-fanny felt all over [her]2618-her , in all [her]2618-her pulses and all [her]2618-her nerves . Denial was impossible . [Her]2618-her habits of ready submission , on the contrary , made [her]2618-her almost instantly rise and lead the way out of [the room]412-the room . [She]2618-her did it with wretched feelings , but it was inevitable . [They]2633-they were no sooner in [the hall]871-the hall than all restraint of countenance was over on [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s side . [She]127-miss crawford immediately shook [her]127-miss crawford head at [Fanny]113-fanny with arch , yet affectionate reproach , and taking [her]2618-her hand , seemed hardly able to help beginning directly . [She]127-miss crawford said nothing , however , but , “ Sad , [sad girl]5906-sad girl ! [I]127-miss crawford do not know when [I]127-miss crawford shall have done scolding [you]113-fanny , ”[127-miss crawford] and had discretion enough to reserve the rest till [they]2633-they might be secure of having four walls to [themselves]2633-they . [Fanny]113-fanny naturally turned [upstairs]4939-upstairs , and took [[her]2618-her guest]2636-her guest to [the apartment which was now always fit for comfortable use]2637-the apartment which was now always fit for comfortable use ; opening the door , however , with a most aching heart , and feeling that [she]2618-her had a more distressing scene before [her]2618-her than ever that spot had yet witnessed . But the evil ready to burst on [her]2618-her was at least delayed by the sudden change in [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s ideas ; by the strong effect on [her]2618-her mind which the finding [herself]2618-her in [the East room]1380-the east room again produced . “ Ha ! ”[2618-her] [she]2618-her cried , with instant animation , “ am [I]2618-her here again ? [The East room]1380-the east room ! Once only was [I]2618-her in [this room]4656-this room before ”[2618-her] ; and after stopping to look about [her]2618-her , and seemingly to retrace all that had then passed , [she]2618-her added , “ Once only before . Do [you]2618-her remember it ? [I]2618-her came to rehearse . [[Your]2618-her cousin]3780-your cousin came too ; and [we]5910-we had a rehearsal . [You]2618-her were [[our]5910-we audience]5911-our audience and [prompter]1479-prompter . A delightful rehearsal . [I]2618-her shall never forget it . Here [we]5910-we were , just in this part of [the room]412-the room : here was [[your]2618-her cousin]3780-your cousin , here was [I]2618-her , here were the chairs . Oh ! why will such things ever pass away ? ”[2618-her] Happily for [[her]2618-her companion]881-her companion , [she]2618-her wanted no answer . [Her]2618-her mind was entirely self - engrossed . [She]2618-her was in a reverie of sweet remembrances . “ The scene [we]5910-we were rehearsing was so very remarkable ! The subject of it so very — very — what shall [I]2618-her say ? [He]3780-your cousin was to be describing and recommending matrimony to [me]2618-her . [I]2618-her think [I]2618-her see [him]3780-your cousin now , trying to be as demure and composed as [Anhalt]178-anhalt ought , through the two long speeches . ‘ When two sympathetic hearts meet in the marriage state , matrimony may be called a happy life . ’ [I]2618-her suppose no time can ever wear out the impression [I]2618-her have of [his]3780-your cousin looks and voice as [he]3780-your cousin said those words . It was curious , very curious , that [we]5910-we should have such a scene to play ! If [I]2618-her had the power of recalling any one week of [my]2618-her existence , it should be that week — that acting week . Say what [you]2618-her would , [Fanny]113-fanny , it should be _ that _ ; for [I]2618-her never knew such exquisite happiness in any other . [His]3780-your cousin sturdy spirit to bend as it did ! Oh ! it was sweet beyond expression . But alas , that very evening destroyed it all . That very evening brought [[your]2618-her most unwelcome uncle]5915-your most unwelcome uncle . [Poor Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , who was glad to see [you]2618-her ? Yet , [Fanny]113-fanny , do not imagine [I]2618-her would now speak disrespectfully of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , though [I]2618-her certainly did hate [him]101-sir thomas for many a week . Nay , in sober sadness , [I]2618-her believe [I]2618-her now love [you]2618-her all . ”[2618-her] And having said so , with a degree of tenderness and consciousness which [Fanny]113-fanny had never seen in [her]2640-i before , and now thought only too becoming , [she]2640-i turned away for a moment to recover [herself]2640-i . “ [I]2640-i have had a little fit since [I]2640-i came into [this room]4656-this room , as [you]2640-i may perceive , ”[2640-i] said [she]2640-i presently , with a playful smile , “ but it is over now ; so let [us]5919-us sit down and be comfortable ; for as to scolding [you]2640-i , [Fanny]113-fanny , which [I]2640-i came fully intending to do , [I]2640-i have not the heart for it when it comes to the point . ”[2640-i] And embracing [her]2640-i very affectionately , “ Good , [gentle Fanny]113-fanny ! when [I]2640-i think of this being the last time of seeing [you]2640-i for [I]2640-i do not know how long , [I]2640-i feel it quite impossible to do anything but love [you]2640-i . ”[2640-i] [Fanny]113-fanny was affected . What [a happy creature]5990-a happy creature [William]228-william must be ! And [I]132-mary do take leave , longing for a happy reunion , and trusting that when [we]5991-we meet again , it will be under circumstances which may open [our]5991-we hearts to [each other without any remnant or shadow of reserve]5994-each other without any remnant or shadow of reserve . ”[132-mary] A very , very kind embrace , and some agitation of manner , accompanied these words . “ [I]132-mary shall see [[your]2645-you cousin]3780-your cousin in [town]3698-town soon : [he]3780-your cousin talks of being there tolerably soon ; and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [I]132-mary dare say , in the course of the spring ; and [[your]2645-you eldest cousin]5123-your eldest cousin , and [the Rushworths]217-the rushworths , and [Julia]112-julia , [I]132-mary am sure of meeting again and again , and all but [you]2645-you . And the other , that [you]2645-you will often call on [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , and make [her]123-mrs. grant amends for [my]132-mary being gone . ”[132-mary] The first , at least , of these favours [Fanny]113-fanny would rather not have been asked ; but it was impossible for [her]2646-her to refuse the correspondence ; it was impossible for [her]2646-her even not to accede to it more readily than [her]2646-her own judgment authorised . There was no resisting so much apparent affection . [Her]2646-her disposition was peculiarly calculated to value a fond treatment , and from having hitherto known so little of it , [she]2646-her was the more overcome by [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s . Besides , there was gratitude towards [her]2646-her , for having made [their]2647-their _ tête - à - tête _ so much less painful than [her]2646-her fears had predicted . It was over , and [she]2646-her had escaped without reproaches and without detection . [Her]2646-her secret was still [her]2646-her own ; and while that was the case , [she]2646-her thought [she]2646-her could resign [herself]2646-her to almost everything . In the evening there was another parting . [Henry Crawford]131-henry came and sat some time with [them]2647-their ; and [her]2646-her spirits not being previously in the strongest state , [her]2646-her heart was softened for a while towards [him]131-henry , because [he]131-henry really seemed to feel . Quite unlike [his]131-henry usual self , [he]131-henry scarcely said anything . [He]131-henry was evidently oppressed , and [Fanny]113-fanny must grieve for [him]131-henry , though hoping [she]2646-her might never see [him]131-henry again till [he]131-henry were [the husband of [some other woman]2649-some other woman]2648-the husband of some other woman . When it came to the moment of parting , [he]131-henry would take [her]2646-her hand , [he]131-henry would not be denied it ; [he]131-henry said nothing , however , or nothing that [she]2646-her heard , and when [he]131-henry had left [the room]412-the room , [she]2646-her was better pleased that such a token of friendship had passed . On the morrow [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords were gone . CHAPTER XXXVII [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford gone , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s next object was that [he]133-mr. crawford should be missed ; and [he]133-mr. crawford entertained great hope that [[his]133-mr. crawford niece]724-his niece would find a blank in the loss of those attentions which at the time [she]724-his niece had felt , or fancied , an evil . [She]724-his niece had tasted of consequence in its most flattering form ; and [he]133-mr. crawford did hope that the loss of it , the sinking again into nothing , would awaken very wholesome regrets in [her]724-his niece mind . [He]133-mr. crawford watched [her]724-his niece with this idea ; but [he]133-mr. crawford could hardly tell with what success . [He]133-mr. crawford hardly knew whether there were any difference in [her]724-his niece spirits or not . [She]724-his niece was always so gentle and retiring that [her]724-his niece emotions were beyond [his]133-mr. crawford discrimination . [He]133-mr. crawford did not understand [her]724-his niece : [he]133-mr. crawford felt that [he]133-mr. crawford did not ; and therefore applied to [Edmund]108-edmund to tell [him]108-edmund how [she]724-his niece stood affected on the present occasion , and whether [she]724-his niece were more or less happy than [she]724-his niece had been . [Edmund]108-edmund did not discern any symptoms of regret , and thought [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father a little unreasonable in supposing the first three or four days could produce any . What chiefly surprised [Edmund]108-edmund was , that [[Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s sister]2653-crawford ’s sister , [the friend]1156-the friend and companion who had been so much to [her]724-his niece , should not be more visibly regretted . [He]108-edmund wondered that [Fanny]113-fanny spoke so seldom of _ [her]2653-crawford ’s sister _ , and had so little voluntarily to say of [her]724-his niece concern at this separation . Alas ! it was [this sister]2655-this sister , [this friend]2656-this friend and companion , who was now the chief bane of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s comfort . If [she]724-his niece could have believed [Mary]132-mary ’s future fate as unconnected with [Mansfield]130-mansfield as [she]724-his niece was determined [the brother]695-the brother ’s should be , if [she]724-his niece could have hoped [her]724-his niece return thither to be as distant as [she]724-his niece was much inclined to think [his]108-edmund , [she]724-his niece would have been light of heart indeed ; but the more [she]724-his niece recollected and observed , the more deeply was [she]724-his niece convinced that everything was now in a fairer train for [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s marrying [Edmund]108-edmund than it had ever been before . On [his]108-edmund side the inclination was stronger , on [hers]724-his niece less equivocal . [His]108-edmund objections , the scruples of [his]108-edmund integrity , seemed all done away , [nobody]360-nobody could tell how ; and the doubts and hesitations of [her]724-his niece ambition were equally got over — and equally without apparent reason . It could only be imputed to increasing attachment . [His]108-edmund good and [her]724-his niece bad feelings yielded to love , and such love must unite [them]2659-them . [He]108-edmund was to go to [town]3698-town as soon as some business relative to [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey were completed — perhaps within a fortnight ; [he]108-edmund talked of going , [he]108-edmund loved to talk of it ; and when once with [her]724-his niece again , [Fanny]113-fanny could not doubt the rest . [Her]724-his niece acceptance must be as certain as [his]108-edmund offer ; and yet there were bad feelings still remaining which made the prospect of it most sorrowful to [her]724-his niece , independently , [she]724-his niece believed , independently of self . In [their]2661-their very last conversation , [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , in spite of some amiable sensations , and much personal kindness , had still been [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; still [shewn]127-miss crawford a mind led astray and bewildered , and without any suspicion of being so ; darkened , yet fancying itself light . [She]724-his niece might love , but [she]724-his niece did not deserve [Edmund]108-edmund by any other sentiment . [Fanny]113-fanny believed there was scarcely a second feeling in common between [them]2661-their ; and [she]724-his niece may be forgiven by [older sages]2662-older sages for looking on the chance of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s future improvement as nearly desperate , for thinking that if [Edmund]108-edmund ’s influence in this season of love had already done so little in clearing [her]724-his niece judgment , and regulating [her]724-his niece notions , [his]108-edmund worth would be finally wasted on [her]724-his niece even in years of matrimony . [Experience]262-experience might have hoped more for [any young people so circumstanced]2663-any young people so circumstanced , and impartiality would not have denied to [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s nature that participation of the general nature of [women]988-women which would lead [her]724-his niece to adopt the opinions of [the man [she]724-his niece loved and respected as [her]724-his niece own]2665-the man she loved and respected as her own . But as such were [Fanny]113-fanny ’s persuasions , [she]724-his niece suffered very much from [them]2666-them , and could never speak of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford without pain . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , meanwhile , went on with [his]101-sir thomas own hopes and [his]101-sir thomas own observations , still feeling a right , by all [his]101-sir thomas knowledge of human nature , to expect to see the effect of the loss of power and consequence on [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece ’s spirits , and the past attentions of [the lover]1832-the lover producing a craving for [their]2669-their return ; and [he]101-sir thomas was soon afterwards able to account for [his]101-sir thomas not yet completely and indubitably seeing all this , by the prospect of [another visitor]2670-another visitor , whose approach [he]101-sir thomas could allow to be quite enough to support the spirits [he]101-sir thomas was watching . [William]228-william had obtained a ten days ’ leave of absence , to be given to [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire , and was coming , the happiest of [lieutenants]2671-lieutenants , because the latest made , to shew [his]228-william happiness and describe [his]228-william uniform . [He]228-william came ; and [he]228-william would have been delighted to shew [his]228-william uniform [there]3696-there too , had not cruel custom prohibited its appearance except on duty . So the uniform remained at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , and [Edmund]108-edmund conjectured that before [Fanny]113-fanny had any chance of seeing it , all its own freshness and all the freshness of [its wearer]2673-its wearer ’s feelings must be worn away . It would be sunk into a badge of disgrace ; for what can be more unbecoming , or more worthless , than the uniform of [a lieutenant]5408-a lieutenant , who has been [a lieutenant a year or two]2675-a lieutenant a year or two , and sees [others made commanders]2676-others made commanders before [him]101-sir thomas ? So reasoned [Edmund]108-edmund , till [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father made [him]108-edmund the confidant of a scheme which placed [Fanny]113-fanny ’s chance of seeing [the second lieutenant of H.M.S. Thrush]2678-the second lieutenant of h.m.s. thrush in all [his]228-william glory in another light . This scheme was that [she]2679-her should accompany [[her]2679-her brother]451-her brother back to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , and spend a little time with [[her]2679-her own family]1438-her own family . It had occurred to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , in one of [his]101-sir thomas dignified musings , as a right and desirable measure ; but before [he]101-sir thomas absolutely made up [his]101-sir thomas mind , [he]101-sir thomas consulted [[his]101-sir thomas son]581-his son . [Edmund]108-edmund considered it every way , and saw nothing but what was right . The thing was good in itself , and could not be done at a better time ; and [he]108-edmund had no doubt of it being highly agreeable to [Fanny]113-fanny . This was enough to determine [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ; and a decisive “ then so it shall be ”[101-sir thomas] closed that stage of the business ; [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas retiring from it with some feelings of satisfaction , and views of good over and above what [he]101-sir thomas had communicated to [[his]101-sir thomas son]581-his son ; for [his]108-edmund prime motive in sending [her]2679-her away had very little to do with the propriety of [her]2679-her seeing [[her]2679-her parents]2443-her parents again , and nothing at all with any idea of making [her]2679-her happy . [He]108-edmund certainly wished [her]2679-her to go willingly , but [he]108-edmund as certainly wished [her]2679-her to be heartily sick of [home]367-home before [her]2679-her visit ended ; and that a little abstinence from the elegancies and luxuries of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield would bring [her]2679-her mind into a sober state , and incline [her]2679-her to a juster estimate of the value of that home of greater permanence , and equal comfort , of which [she]2679-her had the offer . It was a medicinal project upon [[his]108-edmund niece]724-his niece ’s understanding , which [he]108-edmund must consider as at present diseased . [A residence of eight or nine years in the abode of wealth and plenty]2687-a residence of eight or nine years in the abode of wealth and plenty had a little disordered [her]2679-her powers of comparing and judging . [[[Her]2679-her father]667-her father ’s house]2689-her father ’s house would , in all probability , teach [her]2679-her the value of a good income ; and [he]108-edmund trusted that [she]2679-her would be [the wiser and happier woman]2690-the wiser and happier woman , all [her]2679-her life , for the experiment [he]108-edmund had devised . Had [Fanny]113-fanny been at all addicted to raptures , [she]2679-her must have had a strong attack of [them]2691-them when [she]2679-her first understood what was intended , when [[her]2679-her uncle]312-her uncle first made [her]2679-her the offer of visiting [the parents]2693-the parents , and [brothers]3675-brothers , and [sisters]3676-sisters , from whom [she]2679-her had been divided almost half [her]2679-her life ; of returning for a couple of months to the scenes of [her]2679-her infancy , with [William]228-william for [the protector and companion of [her]2679-her journey]2696-the protector and companion of her journey , and the certainty of continuing to see [William]228-william to the last hour of [his]228-william remaining on [land]2697-land . Had [she]2679-her ever given way to bursts of delight , it must have been then , for [she]2679-her was delighted , but [her]2679-her happiness was of a quiet , deep , heart - swelling sort ; and though never [a great talker]820-a great talker , [she]2679-her was always more inclined to silence when feeling most strongly . At the moment [she]2679-her could only thank and accept . Afterwards , when familiarised with the visions of enjoyment so suddenly opened , [she]2679-her could speak more largely to [William]228-william and [Edmund]108-edmund of what [she]2679-her felt ; but still there were emotions of tenderness that could not be clothed in words . The remembrance of all [her]2679-her earliest pleasures , and of what [she]2679-her had suffered in being torn from them , came over [her]2679-her with renewed strength , and it seemed as if to be at [home]367-home again would heal every pain that had since grown out of the separation . To be in the centre of such a circle , loved by so many , and more loved by all than [she]2679-her had ever been before ; to feel affection without fear or restraint ; to feel [herself]2679-her the equal of [those who surrounded [her]2679-her]2700-those who surrounded her ; to be at peace from all mention of [the Crawfords]135-the crawfords , safe from every look which could be fancied a reproach on [their]135-the crawfords account . This was a prospect to be dwelt on with a fondness that could be but half acknowledged . [Edmund]108-edmund , too — to be two months from _ [him]108-edmund _ ( and perhaps [she]2679-her might be allowed to make [her]2679-her absence three ) must do [her]2679-her good . At a distance , unassailed by [his]108-edmund looks or [his]108-edmund kindness , and safe from the perpetual irritation of knowing [his]108-edmund heart , and striving to avoid [his]108-edmund confidence , [she]2679-her should be able to reason [herself]2679-her into a properer state ; [she]2679-her should be able to think of [him]108-edmund as in [London]6-london , and arranging everything there , without wretchedness . What might have been hard to bear at [Mansfield]3-mansfield was to become a slight evil at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth . The only drawback was the doubt of [[her]2679-her aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]108-edmund ’s being comfortable without [her]2679-her . [She]2679-her was of use to [no one else]2702-no one else ; but _ there _ [she]2679-her might be missed to a degree that [she]2679-her did not like to think of ; and that part of the arrangement was , indeed , the hardest for [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas to accomplish , and what only _ [he]101-sir thomas _ could have accomplished at all . But [he]101-sir thomas was master at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield . When [he]101-sir thomas had really resolved on any measure , [he]101-sir thomas could always carry it through ; and now by dint of long talking on the subject , explaining and dwelling on the duty of [Fanny]113-fanny ’s sometimes seeing [[her]2679-her family]322-her family , [he]101-sir thomas did induce [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife to let [her]2679-her go ; obtaining it rather from submission , however , than conviction , for [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was convinced of very little more than that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas thought [Fanny]113-fanny ought to go , and therefore that [she]2679-her must . In the calmness of [[her]106-lady bertram own dressing - room]2705-her own dressing - room , in the impartial flow of [her]106-lady bertram own meditations , unbiased by [his]101-sir thomas bewildering statements , [she]106-lady bertram could not acknowledge any necessity for [Fanny]113-fanny ’s ever going near [a father]5609-a father and mother who had done without [her]106-lady bertram so long , while [she]106-lady bertram was so useful to [herself]106-lady bertram . And as to the not missing [her]106-lady bertram , which under [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s discussion was the point attempted to be proved , [she]106-lady bertram set [herself]106-lady bertram very steadily against admitting any such thing . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had appealed to [her]106-lady bertram reason , conscience , and dignity . [He]101-sir thomas called it a sacrifice , and demanded it of [her]106-lady bertram goodness and self - command as such .
