[Her]264-susan temper was open . [She]264-susan acknowledged [her]264-susan fears , blamed [herself]264-susan for having contended so warmly ; and from that hour [Fanny]113-fanny , understanding the worth of [her]264-susan disposition and perceiving how fully [she]264-susan was inclined to seek [her]264-susan good opinion and refer to [her]264-susan judgment , began to feel again the blessing of affection , and to entertain the hope of being useful to [a mind so much in need of help , and so much deserving it]3025-a mind so much in need of help , and so much deserving it . [She]264-susan gave advice , advice too sound to be resisted by a good understanding , and given so mildly and considerately as not to irritate an imperfect temper , and [she]264-susan had the happiness of observing its good effects not unfrequently . More was not expected by [one who , while seeing all the obligation and expediency of submission and forbearance]3026-one who , while seeing all the obligation and expediency of submission and forbearance , saw also with sympathetic acuteness of feeling all that must be hourly grating to [a girl like [Susan]264-susan]3027-a girl like susan . [Her]264-susan greatest wonder on the subject soon became — not that [Susan]264-susan should have been provoked into disrespect and impatience against [her]264-susan better knowledge — but that so much better knowledge , so many good notions should have been [hers]264-susan at all ; and that , brought up in the midst of negligence and error , [she]264-susan should have formed such proper opinions of what ought to be ; [she]264-susan , who had had [no cousin]3028-no cousin [Edmund]108-edmund to direct [her]264-susan thoughts or fix [her]264-susan principles . The intimacy thus begun between [them]3029-they was a material advantage to each . By sitting together [upstairs]4939-upstairs , [they]3029-they avoided a great deal of the disturbance of [the house]427-the house ; [Fanny]113-fanny had peace , and [Susan]264-susan learned to think it no misfortune to be quietly employed . [They]3029-they sat without a fire ; but that was a privation familiar even to [Fanny]113-fanny , and [she]264-susan suffered the less because reminded by it of [the East room]1380-the east room . It was the only point of resemblance . In space , light , furniture , and prospect , there was nothing alike in [the two apartments]3033-the two apartments ; and [she]264-susan often heaved a sigh at the remembrance of all [her]264-susan books and boxes , and various comforts there . By degrees [the girls]3717-the girls came to spend the chief of the morning [upstairs]4939-upstairs , at first only in working and talking , but after a few days , the remembrance of the said books grew so potent and stimulative that [Fanny]113-fanny found it impossible not to try for books again . There were none in [[[her]264-susan father]667-her father ’s house]2689-her father ’s house ; but wealth is luxurious and daring , and some of [hers]264-susan found its way to [a circulating library]3038-a circulating library . [She]264-susan became [a subscriber]3039-a subscriber ; amazed at being anything _ in propria persona _ , amazed at [her]264-susan own doings in every way , to be [a renter]3040-a renter , [a chuser of books]3041-a chuser of books ! And to be having [any one]3817-any one ’s improvement in view in [her]264-susan choice ! But so it was . [Susan]264-susan had read nothing , and [Fanny]113-fanny longed to give [her]264-susan a share in [her]264-susan own first pleasures , and inspire a taste for the biography and poetry which [she]264-susan delighted in [herself]264-susan . In this occupation [she]264-susan hoped , moreover , to bury some of the recollections of [Mansfield]130-mansfield , which were too apt to seize [her]264-susan mind if [her]264-susan fingers only were busy ; and , especially at this time , hoped it might be useful in diverting [her]264-susan thoughts from pursuing [Edmund]108-edmund to [London]6-london , whither , on the authority of [[her]264-susan aunt]463-her aunt ’s last letter , [she]264-susan knew [he]108-edmund was gone . [She]264-susan had no doubt of what would ensue . The promised notification was hanging over [her]264-susan head . [The postman]3044-the postman ’s knock within [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood was beginning to bring its daily terrors , and if reading could banish the idea for even half an hour , it was something gained . CHAPTER XLI A week was gone since [Edmund]108-edmund might be supposed in [town]3698-town , and [Fanny]113-fanny had heard nothing of [him]108-edmund . There were three different conclusions to be drawn from [his]108-edmund silence , between which [her]264-susan mind was in fluctuation ; each of them at times being held the most probable . Either [his]108-edmund going had been again delayed , or [he]108-edmund had yet procured no opportunity of seeing [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford alone , or [he]108-edmund was too happy for letter - writing ! One morning , about this time , [Fanny]113-fanny having now been nearly four weeks from [Mansfield]3-mansfield , a point which [she]264-susan never failed to think over and calculate every day , as [she]264-susan and [Susan]264-susan were preparing to remove , as usual , [upstairs]4939-upstairs , [they]3048-they were stopped by the knock of [a visitor]5689-a visitor , whom [they]3048-they felt [they]3048-they could not avoid , from [Rebecca]268-rebecca ’s alertness in going to the door , a duty which always interested [her]264-susan beyond any other . It was [a gentleman]4549-a gentleman ’s voice ; it was a voice that [Fanny]113-fanny was just turning pale about , when [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford walked into [the room]412-the room . Good sense , like [hers]113-fanny , will always act when really called upon ; and [she]264-susan found that [she]264-susan had been able to name [him]108-edmund to [[her]264-susan mother]446-her mother , and recall [her]264-susan remembrance of the name , as that of “ [[William]228-william ’s friend]6103-william ’s friend , ”[264-susan] though [she]264-susan could not previously have believed [herself]264-susan capable of uttering a syllable at such a moment . The consciousness of [his]108-edmund being known there only as [[William]228-william ’s friend]6103-william ’s friend was some support . Having introduced [him]108-edmund , however , and being all reseated , the terrors that occurred of what this visit might lead to were overpowering , and [she]264-susan fancied [herself]264-susan on the point of fainting away . While trying to keep [herself]264-susan alive , [[their]3054-their visitor]2391-their visitor , who had at first approached [her]264-susan with as animated a countenance as ever , was wisely and kindly keeping [his]2391-their visitor eyes away , and giving [her]264-susan time to recover , while [he]2391-their visitor devoted [himself]2391-their visitor entirely to [[her]264-susan mother]446-her mother , addressing [her]446-her mother , and attending to [her]446-her mother with the utmost politeness and propriety , at the same time with a degree of friendliness , of interest at least , which was making [his]2391-their visitor manner perfect . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price ’s manners were also at their best . Warmed by the sight of [such a friend to [[her]107-mrs. price son]637-her son]3057-such a friend to her son , and regulated by the wish of appearing to advantage before [him]108-edmund , [she]264-susan was overflowing with gratitude — artless , maternal gratitude — which could not be unpleasing . [Mr. Price]228-william was out , which [she]264-susan regretted very much . [Fanny]113-fanny was just recovered enough to feel that _ [she]264-susan _ could not regret it ; for to [her]264-susan many other sources of uneasiness was added the severe one of shame for [the home in which [he]108-edmund found [her]264-susan]3059-the home in which he found her . [She]264-susan might scold [herself]264-susan for the weakness , but there was no scolding it away . [She]264-susan was ashamed , and [she]264-susan would have been yet more ashamed of [[her]264-susan father]667-her father than of all the rest . [They]3061-they talked of [William]228-william , a subject on which [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price could never tire ; and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was as warm in [his]133-mr. crawford commendation as even [her]264-susan heart could wish . [She]264-susan felt that [she]264-susan had never seen so agreeable a man in [her]264-susan life ; and was only astonished to find that , so great and so agreeable as [he]108-edmund was , [he]108-edmund should be come down to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth neither on a visit to [the port - admiral]3062-the port - admiral , nor [the commissioner]3063-the commissioner , nor yet with the intention of going over to [the island]3064-the island , nor of seeing [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard . Nothing of all that [she]264-susan had been used to think of as the proof of importance , or the employment of wealth , had brought [him]108-edmund to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth . [He]108-edmund had reached [it]7-portsmouth late the night before , was come for a day or two , was staying at [the Crown]3066-the crown , had accidentally met with [a navy officer]3067-a navy officer or two of [his]108-edmund acquaintance since [his]108-edmund arrival , but had no object of that kind in coming . By the time [he]108-edmund had given all this information , it was not unreasonable to suppose that [Fanny]113-fanny might be looked at and spoken to ; and [she]264-susan was tolerably able to bear [his]108-edmund eye , and hear that [he]108-edmund had spent half an hour with [[his]108-edmund sister]511-his sister the evening before [his]108-edmund leaving [London]6-london ; that [she]264-susan had sent [her]264-susan best and kindest love , but had had no time for writing ; that [he]108-edmund thought [himself]108-edmund lucky in seeing [Mary]276-mary for even half an hour , having spent scarcely twenty - four hours in [London]6-london , after [his]108-edmund return from [Norfolk]19-norfolk , before [he]108-edmund set off again ; that [[her]264-susan cousin]3692-her cousin [Edmund]108-edmund was in [town]3698-town , had been in [town]3698-town , [he]108-edmund understood , a few days ; that [he]108-edmund had not seen [him]108-edmund [himself]108-edmund , but that [he]108-edmund was well , had left [them]3072-them all well at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , and was to dine , as yesterday , with [the Frasers]258-the frasers . [Fanny]113-fanny listened collectedly , even to the last - mentioned circumstance ; nay , it seemed a relief to [her]264-susan worn mind to be at any certainty ; and the words , “ then by this time it is all settled , ”[113-fanny] passed internally , without more evidence of emotion than a faint blush . After talking a little more about [Mansfield]3-mansfield , a subject in which [her]264-susan interest was most apparent , [Crawford]133-mr. crawford began to hint at the expediency of an early walk . “ It was a lovely morning , and at that season of the year a fine morning so often turned off , that it was wisest for [everybody]408-everybody not to delay [their]408-everybody exercise ”[133-mr. crawford] ; and such hints producing nothing , [he]133-mr. crawford soon proceeded to a positive recommendation to [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price and [[her]107-mrs. price daughters]480-her daughters to take [their]3072-them walk without loss of time . Now [they]3072-them came to an understanding . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price , it appeared , scarcely ever stirred out of doors , except of a Sunday ; [she]107-mrs. price owned [she]107-mrs. price could seldom , with [[her]107-mrs. price large family]3074-her large family , find time for a walk . “ Would [she]107-mrs. price not , then , persuade [[her]107-mrs. price daughters]480-her daughters to take advantage of such weather , and allow [him]133-mr. crawford the pleasure of attending [them]480-her daughters ? ”[107-mrs. price] [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price was greatly obliged and very complying . “ [[Her]107-mrs. price daughters]480-her daughters were very much confined ; [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth was [a sad place]6107-a sad place ; [they]480-her daughters did not often get out ; and [she]107-mrs. price knew [they]480-her daughters had some errands in [the town]2773-the town , which [they]480-her daughters would be very glad to do . ”[107-mrs. price] And the consequence was , that [Fanny]113-fanny , strange as it was — strange , awkward , and distressing — found [herself]113-fanny and [Susan]264-susan , within ten minutes , walking towards [the High Street]89-the high street with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . It was soon pain upon pain , confusion upon confusion ; for [they]3075-they were hardly in [the High Street]2775-the high street before [they]3075-they met [[her]107-mrs. price father]667-her father , whose appearance was not the better from its being [Saturday]279-saturday . [He]667-her father stopt ; and , ungentlemanlike as [he]667-her father looked , [Fanny]113-fanny was obliged to introduce [him]667-her father to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . [She]107-mrs. price could not have a doubt of the manner in which [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford must be struck . [He]133-mr. crawford must be ashamed and disgusted altogether . [He]133-mr. crawford must soon give [her]107-mrs. price up , and cease to have the smallest inclination for the match ; and yet , though [she]107-mrs. price had been so much wanting [his]133-mr. crawford affection to be cured , this was a sort of cure that would be almost as bad as the complaint ; and [I]0-i believe there is scarcely [a young lady in [the United Kingdoms]3079-the united kingdoms who would not rather put up with the misfortune of being sought by [a clever , agreeable man]3080-a clever , agreeable man , than have [him]133-mr. crawford driven away by the vulgarity of [her]107-mrs. price nearest relations]3078-a young lady in the united kingdoms who would not rather put up with the misfortune of being sought by a clever , agreeable man , than have him driven away by the vulgarity of her nearest relations . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford probably could not regard [[his]133-mr. crawford future father - in - law]3081-his future father - in - law with any idea of taking [him]667-her father for a model in dress ; but ( as [Fanny]113-fanny instantly , and to [her]107-mrs. price great relief , discerned ) [[her]107-mrs. price father]667-her father was [a very different man]3083-a very different man , a very different [Mr. Price]228-william in [his]228-william behaviour to [this most highly respected stranger]3084-this most highly respected stranger , from what [he]228-william was in [[his]228-william own family]3085-his own family at [home]367-home . [His]228-william manners now , though not polished , were more than passable : [they]3087-they were grateful , animated , manly ; [his]228-william expressions were those of [an attached father]3088-an attached father , and [a sensible man]4563-a sensible man ; [his]228-william loud tones did very well in the open air , and there was not a single oath to be heard . Such was [his]228-william instinctive compliment to the good manners of [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ; and , be the consequence what it might , [Fanny]113-fanny ’s immediate feelings were infinitely soothed . The conclusion of [the two gentlemen]1140-the two gentlemen ’s civilities was an offer of [Mr. Price]228-william ’s to take [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford into [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard , which [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , desirous of accepting as a favour what was intended as such , though [he]133-mr. crawford had seen [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard again and again , and hoping to be so much the longer with [Fanny]113-fanny , was very gratefully disposed to avail [himself]133-mr. crawford of , if [the Miss Prices]283-the miss prices were not afraid of the fatigue ; and as it was somehow or other ascertained , or inferred , or at least acted upon , that [they]1140-the two gentlemen were not at all afraid , to [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard [they]1140-the two gentlemen were all to go ; and but for [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , [Mr. Price]228-william would have turned thither directly , without the smallest consideration for [[his]228-william daughters]498-his daughters ’ errands in [the High Street]2775-the high street . [He]133-mr. crawford took care , however , that [they]1140-the two gentlemen should be allowed to go to [the shops]3096-the shops [they]1140-the two gentlemen came out expressly to visit ; and it did not delay [them]1140-the two gentlemen long , for [Fanny]113-fanny could so little bear to excite impatience , or be waited for , that before [the gentlemen]4865-the gentlemen , as [they]4865-the gentlemen stood at the door , could do more than begin upon the last naval regulations , or settle the number of three - deckers now in commission , [[their]4865-the gentlemen companions]3098-their companions were ready to proceed . [They]1140-the two gentlemen were then to set forward for [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard at once , and the walk would have been conducted — according to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s opinion — in a singular manner , had [Mr. Price]228-william been allowed the entire regulation of it , as [the two girls]397-the two girls , [he]133-mr. crawford found , would have been left to follow , and keep up with [them]397-the two girls or not , as [they]1140-the two gentlemen could , while [they]1140-the two gentlemen walked on together at [their]1140-the two gentlemen own hasty pace . [He]133-mr. crawford was able to introduce some improvement occasionally , though by no means to the extent [he]133-mr. crawford wished ; [he]133-mr. crawford absolutely would not walk away from [them]397-the two girls ; and at any crossing or [any crowd]3101-any crowd , when [Mr. Price]228-william was only calling out , “ Come , [girls]3947-girls ; come , [Fan]6110-fan ; come , [Sue]264-susan , take care of [yourselves]3947-girls ; keep a sharp lookout ! ”[133-mr. crawford] [he]133-mr. crawford would give [them]397-the two girls [his]133-mr. crawford particular attendance . Once fairly in [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard , [he]133-mr. crawford began to reckon upon some happy intercourse with [Fanny]113-fanny , as [they]1140-the two gentlemen were very soon joined by [a brother lounger of [Mr. Price]228-william ’s , who was come to take [his]133-mr. crawford daily survey of how things went on , and who must prove a far more worthy companion than [himself]133-mr. crawford]3103-a brother lounger of mr. price ’s , who was come to take his daily survey of how things went on , and who must prove a far more worthy companion than himself ; and after a time [the two officers]3104-the two officers seemed very well satisfied going about together , and discussing matters of equal and never - failing interest , while [the young people]391-the young people sat down upon some timbers in [the yard]5289-the yard , or found a seat on board a vessel in the stocks which [they]391-the young people all went to look at . [Fanny]113-fanny was most conveniently in want of rest . [Crawford]133-mr. crawford could not have wished [her]3107-her more fatigued or more ready to sit down ; but [he]133-mr. crawford could have wished [[her]3107-her sister]331-her sister away . [A quick - looking girl of [Susan]264-susan ’s age]3109-a quick - looking girl of susan ’s age was the very worst third in [the world]315-the world : totally different from [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , all eyes and ears ; and there was no introducing the main point before [her]3109-a quick - looking girl of susan ’s age . [He]133-mr. crawford must content [himself]133-mr. crawford with being only generally agreeable , and letting [Susan]264-susan have [her]264-susan share of entertainment , with the indulgence , now and then , of a look or hint for [the better - informed and conscious Fanny]3111-the better - informed and conscious fanny . [Norfolk]19-norfolk was what [he]133-mr. crawford had mostly to talk of : there [he]133-mr. crawford had been some time , and everything there was rising in importance from [his]133-mr. crawford present schemes . [Such a man]3112-such a man could come from no place , no society , without importing something to amuse ; [his]133-mr. crawford journeys and [his]133-mr. crawford acquaintance were all of use , and [Susan]264-susan was entertained in a way quite new to [her]264-susan . For [Fanny]113-fanny , somewhat more was related than the accidental agreeableness of the parties [he]133-mr. crawford had been in . For [her]264-susan approbation , the particular reason of [his]133-mr. crawford going into [Norfolk]19-norfolk at all , at this unusual time of year , was given . It had been real business , relative to the renewal of a lease in which the welfare of a large and — [he]133-mr. crawford believed — [industrious family]3113-industrious family was at stake . [He]133-mr. crawford had suspected [[his]133-mr. crawford agent]3114-his agent of some underhand dealing ; of meaning to bias [him]133-mr. crawford against [the deserving]3115-the deserving ; and [he]133-mr. crawford had determined to go [himself]133-mr. crawford , and thoroughly investigate the merits of the case . [He]133-mr. crawford had gone , had done even more good than [he]133-mr. crawford had foreseen , had been useful to more than [his]133-mr. crawford first plan had comprehended , and was now able to congratulate [himself]133-mr. crawford upon it , and to feel that in performing a duty , [he]133-mr. crawford had secured agreeable recollections for [his]133-mr. crawford own mind . [He]133-mr. crawford had introduced [himself]133-mr. crawford to [some tenants whom [he]133-mr. crawford had never seen before]3116-some tenants whom he had never seen before ; [he]133-mr. crawford had begun making acquaintance with cottages whose very existence , though on [[his]133-mr. crawford own estate]3117-his own estate , had been hitherto unknown to [him]133-mr. crawford . This was aimed , and well aimed , at [Fanny]113-fanny . It was pleasing to hear [him]133-mr. crawford speak so properly ; here [he]133-mr. crawford had been acting as [he]133-mr. crawford ought to do . To be [the friend of [the poor]3119-the poor and [the oppressed]3120-the oppressed]3118-the friend of the poor and the oppressed ! Nothing could be more grateful to [her]3121-her ; and [she]3121-her was on the point of giving [him]133-mr. crawford an approving look , when it was all frightened off by [his]133-mr. crawford adding a something too pointed of [his]133-mr. crawford hoping soon to have [an assistant]3122-an assistant , [a friend]456-a friend , [a guide in every plan of utility or charity for [Everingham]31-everingham]3124-a guide in every plan of utility or charity for everingham : [a somebody that would make [Everingham]31-everingham and all about it a dearer object than it had ever been yet]3125-a somebody that would make everingham and all about it a dearer object than it had ever been yet . [She]3121-her turned away , and wished [he]133-mr. crawford would not say such things . [She]3121-her was willing to allow [he]133-mr. crawford might have more good qualities than [she]3121-her had been wo nt to suppose . [She]3121-her began to feel the possibility of [his]133-mr. crawford turning out well at last ; but [he]133-mr. crawford was and must ever be completely unsuited to [her]3121-her , and ought not to think of [her]3121-her . [He]133-mr. crawford perceived that enough had been said of [Everingham]31-everingham , and that it would be as well to talk of something else , and turned to [Mansfield]130-mansfield . [He]133-mr. crawford could not have chosen better ; that was a topic to bring back [her]3121-her attention and [her]3121-her looks almost instantly . It was a real indulgence to [her]3121-her to hear or to speak of [Mansfield]130-mansfield . Now so long divided from [everybody who knew [the place]459-the place]3126-everybody who knew the place , [she]3121-her felt it quite the voice of [a friend]456-a friend when [he]133-mr. crawford mentioned it , and led the way to [her]3121-her fond exclamations in praise of its beauties and comforts , and by [his]133-mr. crawford honourable tribute to [[its]459-the place inhabitants]3129-its inhabitants allowed [her]3121-her to gratify [her]3121-her own heart in the warmest eulogium , in speaking of [[her]3121-her uncle]312-her uncle as all that was clever and good , and [[her]3121-her aunt]463-her aunt as having the sweetest of all sweet tempers . [He]133-mr. crawford had a great attachment to [Mansfield]130-mansfield [himself]133-mr. crawford ; [he]133-mr. crawford said so ; [he]133-mr. crawford looked forward with the hope of spending much , very much , of [his]133-mr. crawford time [there]3696-there ; always there , or in [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood . [He]133-mr. crawford particularly built upon a very happy summer and autumn there this year ; [he]133-mr. crawford felt that it would be so : [he]133-mr. crawford depended upon it ; a summer and autumn infinitely superior to the last . As animated , as diversified , as social , but with circumstances of superiority undescribable . “ [Mansfield]130-mansfield , [Sotherton]27-sotherton , [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey , ”[133-mr. crawford] [he]133-mr. crawford continued ; “ what [a society]6111-a society will be comprised in [those houses]6112-those houses ! And at [Michaelmas]218-michaelmas , perhaps , a fourth may be added : some small hunting - box in the vicinity of everything so dear ; for as to any partnership in [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey , as [Edmund Bertram]108-edmund once good - humouredly proposed , [I]133-mr. crawford hope [I]133-mr. crawford foresee two objections : two fair , excellent , irresistible objections to that plan . ”[133-mr. crawford] [Fanny]113-fanny was doubly silenced here ; though when the moment was passed , could regret that [she]3134-she had not forced [herself]3134-she into the acknowledged comprehension of one half of [his]133-mr. crawford meaning , and encouraged [him]133-mr. crawford to say something more of [[his]133-mr. crawford sister]511-his sister and [Edmund]108-edmund . It was a subject which [she]3134-she must learn to speak of , and the weakness that shrunk from it would soon be quite unpardonable . When [Mr. Price]228-william and [[his]228-william friend]319-his friend had seen all that [they]3137-they wished , or had time for , [the others]347-the others were ready to return ; and in the course of [their]3137-they walk back , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford contrived a minute ’s privacy for telling [Fanny]113-fanny that [his]133-mr. crawford only business in [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth was to see [her]3134-she ; that [he]133-mr. crawford was come down for a couple of days on [her]3134-she account , and [hers]3134-she only , and because [he]133-mr. crawford could not endure a longer total separation . [She]3134-she was sorry , really sorry ; and yet in spite of this and the two or three other things which [she]3134-she wished [he]133-mr. crawford had not said , [she]3134-she thought [him]133-mr. crawford altogether improved since [she]3134-she had seen [him]133-mr. crawford ; [he]133-mr. crawford was much more gentle , obliging , and attentive to [other people]4182-other people ’s feelings than [he]133-mr. crawford had ever been at [Mansfield]3-mansfield ; [she]3134-she had never seen [him]133-mr. crawford so agreeable — so _ near _ being agreeable ; [his]133-mr. crawford behaviour to [[her]3134-she father]667-her father could not offend , and there was something particularly kind and proper in the notice [he]133-mr. crawford took of [Susan]264-susan . [He]133-mr. crawford was decidedly improved . [She]3134-she wished the next day over , [she]3134-she wished [he]133-mr. crawford had come only for one day ; but it was not so very bad as [she]3134-she would have expected : the pleasure of talking of [Mansfield]130-mansfield was so very great ! Before [they]3141-them parted , [she]3134-she had to thank [him]133-mr. crawford for another pleasure , and one of no trivial kind . [[Her]3134-she father]667-her father asked [him]133-mr. crawford to do [them]3141-them the honour of taking [his]133-mr. crawford mutton with [them]3141-them , and [Fanny]113-fanny had time for only one thrill of horror , before [he]133-mr. crawford declared [himself]133-mr. crawford prevented by a prior engagement . [He]133-mr. crawford was engaged to dinner already both for that day and the next ; [he]133-mr. crawford had met with [some acquaintance at the Crown who would not be denied]3143-some acquaintance at the crown who would not be denied ; [he]133-mr. crawford should have the honour , however , of waiting on [them]3141-them again on the morrow , etc . , and so [they]3141-them parted — [Fanny]113-fanny in a state of actual felicity from escaping so horrible an evil ! To have had [him]133-mr. crawford join [[their]3141-them family]568-their family dinner - party , and see all [their]3141-them deficiencies , would have been dreadful ! [Rebecca]268-rebecca ’s cookery and [Rebecca]268-rebecca ’s waiting , and [Betsey]148-betsey ’s eating at table without restraint , and pulling everything about as [she]268-rebecca chose , were what [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny was not yet enough inured to for [her]268-rebecca often to make a tolerable meal . _ [She]268-rebecca _ was nice only from natural delicacy , but _ [he]133-mr. crawford _ had been brought up in a school of luxury and epicurism . CHAPTER XLII The Prices were just setting off for [church]4565-church the next day when [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford appeared again . [He]133-mr. crawford came , not to stop , but to join [them]3141-them ; [he]133-mr. crawford was asked to go with [them]3141-them to [the Garrison chapel]3146-the garrison chapel , which was exactly what [he]133-mr. crawford had intended , and [they]3141-them all walked thither together . [The family]3724-the family were now seen to advantage . [Nature]284-nature had given [them]3141-them no inconsiderable share of beauty , and [every Sunday]3148-every sunday dressed [them]3141-them in [their]3141-them cleanest skins and best attire . [Sunday]242-sunday always brought this comfort to [Fanny]113-fanny , and on this Sunday [she]268-rebecca felt it more than ever . [[Her]268-rebecca poor mother]3654-her poor mother now did not look so very unworthy of being [[Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s sister]324-lady bertram ’s sister as [she]3654-her poor mother was but too apt to look . It often grieved [her]268-rebecca to the heart to think of the contrast between [them]3151-them ; to think that where nature had made so little difference , circumstances should have made so much , and that [[her]268-rebecca mother]446-her mother , as handsome as [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , and some years [her]268-rebecca junior , should have an appearance so much more worn and faded , so comfortless , so slatternly , so shabby . But Sunday made [her]268-rebecca [a very creditable and tolerably cheerful - looking [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price , coming abroad with [a fine family of]3154-a fine family of [children]339-children]3153-a very creditable and tolerably cheerful - looking mrs. price , coming abroad with a fine family of children , feeling a little respite of [her]107-mrs. price weekly cares , and only discomposed if [she]107-mrs. price saw [[her]107-mrs. price boys]3156-her boys run into danger , or [Rebecca]268-rebecca pass by with a flower in [her]268-rebecca hat . In [chapel]4323-chapel [they]3151-them were obliged to divide , but [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford took care not to be divided from [the female branch]3158-the female branch ; and after [chapel]4323-chapel [he]133-mr. crawford still continued with [them]3151-them , and made one in the family party on [the ramparts]2928-the ramparts . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price took [her]107-mrs. price weekly walk on [the ramparts]2928-the ramparts every fine Sunday throughout the year , always going directly after morning service and staying till dinner - time . It was [[her]107-mrs. price public place]3162-her public place : there [she]107-mrs. price met [[her]107-mrs. price acquaintance]3163-her acquaintance , heard a little news , talked over the badness of [the Portsmouth servants]3164-the portsmouth servants , and wound up [her]107-mrs. price spirits for the six days ensuing . [Thither]285-thither [they]3151-them now went ; [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford most happy to consider [the Miss Prices]283-the miss prices as [his]133-mr. crawford peculiar charge ; and before [they]3151-them had been there long , somehow or other , there was no saying how , [Fanny]113-fanny could not have believed it , but [he]133-mr. crawford was walking between [them]3151-them with an arm of each under [his]133-mr. crawford , and [she]107-mrs. price did not know how to prevent or put an end to it . It made [her]107-mrs. price uncomfortable for a time , but yet there were enjoyments in the day and in the view which would be felt . The day was uncommonly lovely . It was really March ; but it was April in [its]3165-its mild air , brisk soft wind , and bright sun , occasionally clouded for a minute ; and everything looked so beautiful under the influence of such a sky , the effects of the shadows pursuing each other on the ships at [Spithead]68-spithead and [the island]3064-the island beyond , with the ever - varying hues of [the sea]3167-the sea , now at high water , dancing in its glee and dashing against the ramparts with so fine a sound , produced altogether such a combination of charms for [Fanny]113-fanny , as made [her]107-mrs. price gradually almost careless of the circumstances under which [she]107-mrs. price felt them . Nay , had [she]107-mrs. price been without [his]133-mr. crawford arm , [she]107-mrs. price would soon have known that [she]107-mrs. price needed it , for [she]107-mrs. price wanted strength for a two hours ’ saunter of this kind , coming , as it generally did , upon a week ’s previous inactivity . [Fanny]113-fanny was beginning to feel the effect of being debarred from [her]107-mrs. price usual regular exercise ; [she]107-mrs. price had lost ground as to health since [her]107-mrs. price being in [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth ; and but for [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford and the beauty of the weather would soon have been knocked up now . The loveliness of the day , and of the view , [he]133-mr. crawford felt like [herself]113-fanny . [They]3168-they often stopt with the same sentiment and taste , leaning against the wall , some minutes , to look and admire ; and considering [he]133-mr. crawford was not [Edmund]108-edmund , [Fanny]113-fanny could not but allow that [he]133-mr. crawford was sufficiently open to the charms of nature , and very well able to express [his]133-mr. crawford admiration . [She]107-mrs. price had a few tender reveries now and then , which [he]133-mr. crawford could sometimes take advantage of to look in [her]107-mrs. price face without detection ; and the result of these looks was , that though as bewitching as ever , [her]107-mrs. price face was less blooming than it ought to be . [She]107-mrs. price _ said _ [she]107-mrs. price was very well , and did not like to be supposed otherwise ; but take it all in all , [he]133-mr. crawford was convinced that [her]107-mrs. price present residence could not be comfortable , and therefore could not be salutary for [her]107-mrs. price , and [he]133-mr. crawford was growing anxious for [her]107-mrs. price being again at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , where [her]107-mrs. price own happiness , and [his]133-mr. crawford in seeing [her]107-mrs. price , must be so much greater . “ [You]107-mrs. price have been here a month , [I]133-mr. crawford think ? ”[133-mr. crawford] said [he]133-mr. crawford . “ No ; not quite a month . It is only four weeks to - morrow since [I]133-mr. crawford left [Mansfield]3-mansfield . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [You]107-mrs. price are [a most accurate and honest reckoner]6113-a most accurate and honest reckoner . [I]133-mr. crawford should call that a month . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [I]133-mr. crawford did not arrive here till Tuesday evening . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ And it is to be a two months ’ visit , is not ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ Yes . [[My]133-mr. crawford uncle]3761-my uncle talked of two months . [I]133-mr. crawford suppose it will not be less . ”[133-mr. crawford] “ And how are [you]107-mrs. price to be conveyed back again ? Who comes for [you]107-mrs. price ? ”[133-mr. crawford] “ [I]133-mr. crawford do not know . [I]133-mr. crawford have heard nothing about it yet from [[my]133-mr. crawford aunt]3803-my aunt . Perhaps [I]133-mr. crawford may be to stay longer . It may not be convenient for [me]133-mr. crawford to be fetched exactly at the two months ’ end . ”[133-mr. crawford] After a moment ’s reflection , [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford replied , “ [I]3169-i know [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [I]3169-i know [its]3-mansfield way , [I]3169-i know its faults towards _ [you]107-mrs. price _ . [I]3169-i know the danger of [your]107-mrs. price being so far forgotten , as to have [your]107-mrs. price comforts give way to the imaginary convenience of [any single being in [the family]3724-the family]6116-any single being in the family . [I]3169-i am aware that [you]107-mrs. price may be left [here]3798-here week after week , if [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas can not settle everything for coming [himself]101-sir thomas , or sending [[[your]107-mrs. price aunt]3826-your aunt ’s maid]6120-your aunt ’s maid for [you]107-mrs. price , without involving the slightest alteration of the arrangements which [he]101-sir thomas may have laid down for the next quarter of a year . This will not do . Two months is an ample allowance ; [I]3169-i should think six weeks quite enough . [I]3169-i am considering [[your]107-mrs. price sister]4444-your sister ’s health , ”[3169-i] said [he]3169-i , addressing [himself]3169-i to [Susan]264-susan , “ which [I]3169-i think the confinement of [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth unfavourable to . [She]4444-your sister requires constant air and exercise . When [you]107-mrs. price know [her]4444-your sister as well as [I]3169-i do , [I]3169-i am sure [you]107-mrs. price will agree that [she]4444-your sister does , and that [she]4444-your sister ought never to be long banished from the free air and liberty of [the country]493-the country . If , therefore ”[3169-i] ( turning again to [Fanny]113-fanny ) , “ [you]107-mrs. price find [yourself]107-mrs. price growing unwell , and any difficulties arise about [your]107-mrs. price returning to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , without waiting for the two months to be ended , _ that _ must not be regarded as of any consequence , if [you]107-mrs. price feel [yourself]107-mrs. price at all less strong or comfortable than usual , and will only let [[my]3170-i sister]3790-my sister know it , give [her]4444-your sister only the slightest hint , [she]4444-your sister and [I]3170-i will immediately come down , and take [you]107-mrs. price back to [Mansfield]3-mansfield . [You]107-mrs. price know the ease and the pleasure with which this would be done . [You]107-mrs. price know all that would be felt on the occasion . ”[3170-i] [Fanny]113-fanny thanked [him]3170-i , but tried to laugh it off . “ [I]3170-i am perfectly serious , ”[3170-i] [he]3170-i replied , “ as [you]113-fanny perfectly know . And [I]3170-i hope [you]113-fanny will not be cruelly concealing any tendency to indisposition . Indeed , [you]113-fanny shall _ not _ ; it shall not be in [your]113-fanny power ; for so long only as [you]113-fanny positively say , in every letter to [Mary]276-mary , ‘ [I]3170-i am well , ’ and [I]3170-i know [you]113-fanny can not speak or write a falsehood , so long only shall [you]113-fanny be considered as well . ”[3170-i] [Fanny]113-fanny thanked [him]3170-i again , but was affected and distressed to a degree that made it impossible for [her]3171-her to say much , or even to be certain of what [she]3171-her ought to say . This was towards the close of [their]3172-them walk . [He]3170-i attended [them]3172-them to the last , and left [them]3172-them only at the door of [[their]3172-them own house]3173-their own house , when [he]3170-i knew [them]3172-them to be going to dinner , and therefore pretended to be waited for elsewhere . “ [I]3170-i wish [you]113-fanny were not so tired , ”[3170-i] said [he]3170-i , still detaining [Fanny]113-fanny after all the others were in the house—“I wish [I]3170-i left [you]113-fanny in stronger health . Is there anything [I]3170-i can do for [you]113-fanny in [town]3698-town ? [I]3170-i have half an idea of going into [Norfolk]19-norfolk again soon . [I]3170-i am not satisfied about [Maddison]286-maddison . [I]3170-i am sure [he]286-maddison still means to impose on [me]3170-i if possible , and get [a cousin of [his]286-maddison own]6125-a cousin of his own into [a certain mill]6126-a certain mill , which [I]3170-i design for [somebody else]5448-somebody else . [I]3170-i must come to an understanding with [him]286-maddison . [I]3170-i must make [him]286-maddison know that [I]3170-i will not be tricked on [the south side of [Everingham]31-everingham]6128-the south side of everingham , any more than on [the north]6129-the north : that [I]3170-i will be [master of [[my]3170-i own property]6131-my own property]6130-master of my own property . [I]3170-i was not explicit enough with [him]286-maddison before . The mischief [such a man]3112-such a man does on [an estate]6133-an estate , both as to the credit of [[his]3112-such a man employer]6134-his employer and the welfare of [the poor]3119-the poor , is inconceivable . [I]3170-i have a great mind to go back into [Norfolk]19-norfolk directly , and put everything at once on such a footing as can not be afterwards swerved from . [Maddison]286-maddison is [a clever fellow]6136-a clever fellow ; [I]3170-i do not wish to displace [him]286-maddison , provided [he]286-maddison does not try to displace _ [me]3170-i _ ; but it would be simple to be duped by [a man who has no right of [creditor]6138-creditor]6137-a man who has no right of creditor to dupe [me]3170-i , and worse than simple to let [him]286-maddison give [me]3170-i [a hard - hearted , griping fellow]6139-a hard - hearted , griping fellow for [a tenant]5379-a tenant , instead of [an honest man]6141-an honest man , to whom [I]3170-i have given half a promise already . Would it not be worse than simple ? Shall [I]3170-i go ? Do [you]3170-i advise it ? ”[3170-i] “ [I]3174-i advise ! [You]3170-i know very well what is right . ”[3174-i] “ Yes . When [you]3170-i give [me]3174-i [your]3170-i opinion , [I]3174-i always know what is right . [Your]3170-i judgment is [my]3174-i rule of right . ”[3174-i] “ Oh , no ! do not say so . [We]6142-we have all a better guide in [ourselves]6142-we , if [we]6142-we would attend to it , than [any other person]6143-any other person can be . Good - bye ; [I]3170-i wish [you]3170-i a pleasant journey to - morrow . ”[3170-i] “ Is there nothing [I]3174-i can do for [you]3170-i in [town]3698-town ? ”[3174-i] “ Nothing ; [I]3174-i am much obliged to [you]3170-i . ”[3174-i] “ Have [you]3170-i no message for [anybody]3668-anybody ? ”[3174-i] “ [My]3174-i love to [[your]3170-i sister]4444-your sister , if [you]3170-i please ; and when [you]3170-i see [[my]3174-i cousin]3764-my cousin , [[my]3174-i cousin]3764-my cousin [Edmund]108-edmund , [I]3174-i wish [you]3170-i would be so good as to say that [I]3174-i suppose [I]3174-i shall soon hear from [him]108-edmund . ”[3174-i] “ Certainly ; and if [he]108-edmund is lazy or negligent , [I]3174-i will write [his]108-edmund excuses [myself]3174-i . ”[3174-i] [He]3174-i could say no more , for [Fanny]113-fanny would be no longer detained . [He]3174-i pressed [her]3175-i hand , looked at [her]3175-i , and was gone . _ [He]3174-i _ went to while away the next three hours as [he]3174-i could , with [[his]3174-i other acquaintance]3176-his other acquaintance , till the best dinner that [a capital inn afforded]3177-a capital inn afforded was ready for [their]3178-their enjoyment , and _ [she]3175-i _ turned in to [her]3175-i more simple one immediately . [Their]3178-their general fare bore a very different character ; and could [he]3174-i have suspected how many privations , besides that of exercise , [she]3175-i endured in [[[her]3175-i father]667-her father ’s house]2689-her father ’s house , [he]3174-i would have wondered that [her]3175-i looks were not much more affected than [he]3174-i found them . [She]3175-i was so little equal to [Rebecca]268-rebecca ’s puddings and [Rebecca]268-rebecca ’s hashes , brought to table , as they all were , with such accompaniments of half - cleaned plates , and not half - cleaned knives and forks , that [she]3175-i was very often constrained to defer [her]3175-i heartiest meal till [she]3175-i could send [[her]3175-i brothers]3878-her brothers in the evening for biscuits and buns . After being nursed up at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , it was too late in the day to be hardened at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth ; and though [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , had [he]101-sir thomas known all , might have thought [[his]101-sir thomas niece]724-his niece in the most promising way of being starved , both mind and body , into a much juster value for [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s good company and good fortune , [he]101-sir thomas would probably have feared to push [his]101-sir thomas experiment farther , lest [she]3175-i might die under the cure . [Fanny]113-fanny was out of spirits all the rest of the day . Though tolerably secure of not seeing [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford again , [she]3175-i could not help being low . It was parting with somebody of the nature of [a friend]456-a friend ; and though , in one light , glad to have [him]133-mr. crawford gone , it seemed as if [she]3175-i was now deserted by [everybody]408-everybody ; it was a sort of renewed separation from [Mansfield]3-mansfield ; and [she]3175-i could not think of [his]133-mr. crawford returning to [town]3698-town , and being frequently with [Mary]276-mary and [Edmund]108-edmund , without feelings so near akin to envy as made [her]3175-i hate [herself]3175-i for having [them]3186-them . [Her]3175-i dejection had no abatement from anything passing around [her]3175-i ; [a friend or two of [[her]3175-i father]667-her father ’s]3187-a friend or two of her father ’s , as always happened if [he]133-mr. crawford was not with [them]3186-them , spent the long , long evening there ; and from six o’clock till half - past nine , there was little intermission of noise or grog . [She]3175-i was very low . The wonderful improvement which [she]3175-i still fancied in [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was the nearest to administering comfort of anything within the current of [her]3175-i thoughts . Not considering in how different a circle [she]3175-i had been just seeing [him]133-mr. crawford , nor how much might be owing to contrast , [she]3175-i was quite persuaded of [his]133-mr. crawford being astonishingly more gentle and regardful of [others than formerly]3189-others than formerly . And , if in little things , must it not be so in great ? So anxious for [her]3175-i health and comfort , so very feeling as [he]133-mr. crawford now expressed [himself]133-mr. crawford , and really seemed , might not it be fairly supposed that [he]133-mr. crawford would not much longer persevere in a suit so distressing to [her]3175-i ? CHAPTER XLIII It was presumed that [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford was travelling back , to [London]6-london , on the morrow , for nothing more was seen of [him]133-mr. crawford at [Mr. Price]228-william ’s ; and two days afterwards , it was a fact ascertained to [Fanny]113-fanny by the following letter from [[his]133-mr. crawford sister]511-his sister , opened and read by [her]3175-i , on another account , with the most anxious curiosity : — “ [I]3175-i have to inform [you]113-fanny , [[my]3175-i dearest]5134-my dearest [Fanny]113-fanny , that [Henry]131-henry has been down to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth to see [you]113-fanny ; that [he]131-henry had a delightful walk with [you]113-fanny to [the dockyard]2722-the dockyard last Saturday , and one still more to be dwelt on the next day , on [the ramparts]2928-the ramparts ; when the balmy air , [the sparkling sea]6152-the sparkling sea , and [your]113-fanny sweet looks and conversation were altogether in the most delicious harmony , and afforded sensations which are to raise ecstasy even in retrospect . This , as well as [I]3175-i understand , is to be the substance of [my]3175-i information . [He]131-henry makes [me]3175-i write , but [I]3175-i do not know what else is to be communicated , except this said visit to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , and these two said walks , and [his]131-henry introduction to [[your]113-fanny family]3869-your family , especially to [a fair sister of [yours]113-fanny]6154-a fair sister of yours , [a fine girl of fifteen]6155-a fine girl of fifteen , who was of the party on [the ramparts]2928-the ramparts , taking [her]6155-a fine girl of fifteen first lesson , [I]3175-i presume , in love . [I]3175-i have not time for writing much , but it would be out of place if [I]3175-i had , for this is to be a mere letter of business , penned for the purpose of conveying necessary information , which could not be delayed without risk of evil . [[My]3175-i dear]3657-my dear , [dear Fanny]113-fanny , if [I]3175-i had [you]113-fanny [here]3798-here , how [I]3175-i would talk to [you]113-fanny ! [You]113-fanny should listen to [me]3175-i till [you]113-fanny were tired , and advise [me]3175-i till [you]113-fanny were still tired more ; but it is impossible to put a hundredth part of [my]3175-i great mind on paper , so [I]3175-i will abstain altogether , and leave [you]113-fanny to guess what [you]113-fanny like . [I]3175-i have no news for [you]113-fanny . [You]113-fanny have politics , of course ; and it would be too bad to plague [you]113-fanny with the names of [people]3906-people and parties that fill up [my]3175-i time . [I]3175-i ought to have sent [you]113-fanny an account of [[your]113-fanny cousin]3780-your cousin ’s first party , but [I]3175-i was lazy , and now it is too long ago ; suffice it , that everything was just as it ought to be , in a style that any of [her]3780-your cousin connexions must have been gratified to witness , and that [her]3780-your cousin own dress and manners did [her]3780-your cousin the greatest credit . [[My]3175-i friend]3848-my friend , [Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser , is mad for [such a house]4907-such a house , and it would not make [_]117-_ [me]3175-i _ miserable . [I]3175-i go to [Lady Stornaway]255-lady stornaway after [Easter]153-easter ; [she]255-lady stornaway seems in high spirits , and very happy . [I]3175-i fancy [Lord S.]287-lord s. is very good - humoured and pleasant in [[his]287-lord s. own family]3085-his own family , and [I]3175-i do not think [him]287-lord s. so very ill - looking as [I]3175-i did — at least , [one]766-one sees many worse . [He]287-lord s. will not do by the side of [[your]6165-your cousin]3780-your cousin [Edmund]108-edmund . Of [the last - mentioned hero]6167-the last - mentioned hero , what shall [I]3175-i say ? If [I]3175-i avoided [his]6167-the last - mentioned hero name entirely , it would look suspicious . [I]3175-i will say , then , that [we]6168-we have seen [him]6167-the last - mentioned hero two or three times , and that [[my]3175-i friends]3937-my friends here are very much struck with [his]6167-the last - mentioned hero gentlemanlike appearance . [Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser ( [no bad judge]6170-no bad judge ) declares [she]254-mrs. fraser knows but [three men in [town]3698-town]6171-three men in town who have so good [a person , height , and air]6173-a person , height , and air ; and [I]3175-i must confess , when [he]6167-the last - mentioned hero dined [here]3798-here the other day , there were none to compare with [him]6167-the last - mentioned hero , and [we]6168-we were [a party of sixteen]6175-a party of sixteen . Luckily there is no distinction of dress nowadays to tell tales , but — but — but [Yours]6176-you affectionately . ”[3175-i] “ [I]3175-i had almost forgot ( it was [Edmund]108-edmund ’s fault : [he]108-edmund gets into [my]3175-i head more than does [me]3175-i good ) one very material thing [I]3175-i had to say from [Henry]131-henry and [myself]3175-i — [I]3175-i mean about [our]6168-we taking [you]6176-you back into [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire . [[My]3175-i dear]3657-my dear little creature , do not stay at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth to lose [your]6176-you pretty looks . Those vile sea - breezes are the ruin of beauty and health . [[My]3175-i poor aunt]3926-my poor aunt always felt affected if within ten miles of [the sea]3167-the sea , which [the Admiral]715-the admiral of course never believed , but [I]3175-i know it was so . [I]3175-i am at [your]6176-you service and [Henry]131-henry ’s , at an hour ’s notice . [I]3175-i should like the scheme , and [we]6168-we would make a little circuit , and shew [you]6176-you Everingham in [our]6168-we way , and perhaps [you]6176-you would not mind passing through [London]6-london , and seeing the inside of [St. George ’s]92-st. george ’s , [Hanover Square]93-hanover square . Only keep [[your]6176-you cousin]3780-your cousin [Edmund]108-edmund from [me]3175-i at such a time : [I]3175-i should not like to be tempted . What a long letter ! one word more . [Henry]131-henry , [I]3175-i find , has some idea of going into [Norfolk]19-norfolk again upon some business that _ [you]6176-you _ approve ; but this can not possibly be permitted before the middle of next week ; that is , [he]131-henry can not anyhow be spared till after the 14th , for _ [we]6168-we _ have a party that evening . The value of [a man like [Henry]131-henry]6182-a man like henry , on such an occasion , is what [you]6176-you can have no conception of ; so [you]6176-you must take it upon [my]3175-i word to be inestimable . [He]131-henry will see [the Rushworths]217-the rushworths , which [I]3175-i own [I]3175-i am not sorry for — having a little curiosity , and so [I]3175-i think has [he]131-henry — though [he]131-henry will not acknowledge it . ”[3175-i] This was a letter to be run through eagerly , to be read deliberately , to supply matter for much reflection , and to leave everything in greater suspense than ever . The only certainty to be drawn from it was , that nothing decisive had yet taken place . [Edmund]108-edmund had not yet spoken . How [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford really felt , how [she]127-miss crawford meant to act , or might act without or against [her]127-miss crawford meaning ; whether [his]108-edmund importance to [her]127-miss crawford were quite what it had been before the last separation ; whether , if lessened , it were likely to lessen more , or to recover itself , were subjects for endless conjecture , and to be thought of on that day and many days to come , without producing any conclusion . The idea that returned the oftenest was that [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , after proving [herself]127-miss crawford cooled and staggered by a return to [London]6-london habits , would yet prove [herself]127-miss crawford in the end too much attached to [him]108-edmund to give [him]108-edmund up . [She]127-miss crawford would try to be more ambitious than [her]127-miss crawford heart would allow . [She]127-miss crawford would hesitate , [she]127-miss crawford would tease , [she]127-miss crawford would condition , [she]127-miss crawford would require a great deal , but [she]127-miss crawford would finally accept . This was [Fanny]113-fanny ’s most frequent expectation . [A house in [town]3698-town]3191-a house in town — that , [she]127-miss crawford thought , must be impossible . Yet there was no saying what [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford might not ask . The prospect for [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin grew worse and worse . [The woman who could speak of [him]108-edmund , and speak only of [his]108-edmund appearance]3194-the woman who could speak of him , and speak only of his appearance ! What an unworthy attachment ! To be deriving support from the commendations of [Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser ! _ [She]127-miss crawford _ who had known [him]108-edmund intimately half a year ! [Fanny]113-fanny was ashamed of [her]127-miss crawford . Those parts of the letter which related only to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [herself]113-fanny , touched [her]127-miss crawford , in comparison , slightly . Whether [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford went into [Norfolk]19-norfolk before or after the 14th was certainly no concern of [hers]127-miss crawford , though , everything considered , [she]127-miss crawford thought [he]133-mr. crawford _ would _ go without delay . That [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford should endeavour to secure a meeting between [him]108-edmund and [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , was all in [her]127-miss crawford worst line of conduct , and grossly unkind and ill - judged ; but [she]127-miss crawford hoped _ [he]108-edmund _ would not be actuated by any such degrading curiosity . [He]108-edmund acknowledged no such inducement , and [[his]108-edmund sister]511-his sister ought to have given [him]108-edmund credit for better feelings than [her]127-miss crawford own . [She]127-miss crawford was yet more impatient for another letter from [town]3698-town after receiving this than [she]127-miss crawford had been before ; and for a few days was so unsettled by it altogether , by what had come , and what might come , that [her]127-miss crawford usual readings and conversation with [Susan]264-susan were much suspended . [She]127-miss crawford could not command [her]127-miss crawford attention as [she]127-miss crawford wished . If [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford remembered [her]127-miss crawford message to [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin , [she]127-miss crawford thought it very likely , most likely , that [he]108-edmund would write to [her]127-miss crawford at all events ; it would be most consistent with [his]108-edmund usual kindness ; and till [she]127-miss crawford got rid of this idea , till it gradually wore off , by no letters appearing in the course of three or four days more , [she]127-miss crawford was in a most restless , anxious state . At length , a something like composure succeeded . [Suspense]288-suspense must be submitted to , and must not be allowed to wear [her]127-miss crawford out , and make [her]127-miss crawford useless . Time did something , [her]127-miss crawford own exertions something more , and [she]127-miss crawford resumed [her]127-miss crawford attentions to [Susan]264-susan , and again awakened the same interest in them . [Susan]264-susan was growing very fond of [her]127-miss crawford , and though without any of the early delight in books which had been so strong in [Fanny]113-fanny , with a disposition much less inclined to sedentary pursuits , or to information for information ’s sake , [she]127-miss crawford had so strong a desire of not _ appearing _ ignorant , as , with a good clear understanding , made [her]127-miss crawford [a most attentive , profitable , thankful pupil]3198-a most attentive , profitable , thankful pupil . [Fanny]113-fanny was [[her]127-miss crawford oracle]3199-her oracle . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s explanations and remarks were a most important addition to every essay , or every chapter of history . What [Fanny]113-fanny told [her]127-miss crawford of former times dwelt more on [her]127-miss crawford mind than the pages of [Goldsmith]289-goldsmith ; and [she]127-miss crawford paid [[her]127-miss crawford sister]331-her sister the compliment of preferring [her]127-miss crawford style to that of [any printed author]3201-any printed author . The early habit of reading was wanting . [Their]3202-their conversations , however , were not always on subjects so high as history or morals . [Others]361-others had [their]361-others hour ; and of lesser matters , [none]3204-none returned so often , or remained so long between [them]3202-their , as [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , a description of [the people]460-the people , the manners , the amusements , the ways of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield . [Susan]264-susan , who had an innate taste for [the genteel and well - appointed]3206-the genteel and well - appointed , was eager to hear , and [Fanny]113-fanny could not but indulge [herself]113-fanny in dwelling on so beloved a theme . [She]127-miss crawford hoped it was not wrong ; though , after a time , [Susan]264-susan ’s very great admiration of everything said or done in [[[her]264-susan uncle]312-her uncle ’s house]721-her uncle ’s house , and earnest longing to go into [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire , seemed almost to blame [her]264-susan for exciting feelings which could not be gratified . [Poor Susan]264-susan was very little better fitted for [home]367-home than [[her]264-susan elder sister]3210-her elder sister ; and as [Fanny]113-fanny grew thoroughly to understand this , [she]127-miss crawford began to feel that when [her]127-miss crawford own release from [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth came , [her]127-miss crawford happiness would have a material drawback in leaving [Susan]264-susan behind . That [a girl so capable of being made everything good]3211-a girl so capable of being made everything good should be left in such hands , distressed [her]127-miss crawford more and more . Were _ [she]127-miss crawford _ likely to have [a [home]367-home to invite [her]127-miss crawford to]3212-a home to invite her to , what a blessing it would be ! And had it been possible for [her]127-miss crawford to return [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s regard , the probability of [his]133-mr. crawford being very far from objecting to such a measure would have been the greatest increase of all [her]127-miss crawford own comforts . [She]127-miss crawford thought [he]133-mr. crawford was really good - tempered , and could fancy [his]133-mr. crawford entering into a plan of that sort most pleasantly . CHAPTER XLIV Seven weeks of the two months were very nearly gone , when the one letter , the letter from [Edmund]108-edmund , so long expected , was put into [Fanny]113-fanny ’s hands . As [she]127-miss crawford opened , and saw its length , [she]127-miss crawford prepared [herself]127-miss crawford for a minute detail of happiness and a profusion of love and praise towards [the fortunate creature who was now mistress of [his]108-edmund fate]3214-the fortunate creature who was now mistress of his fate . These were the contents — “ [[My]113-fanny Dear]3657-my dear Fanny,—Excuse [me]113-fanny that [I]113-fanny have not written before . [Crawford]133-mr. crawford told [me]113-fanny that [you]113-fanny were wishing to hear from [me]113-fanny , but [I]113-fanny found it impossible to write from [London]6-london , and persuaded [myself]113-fanny that [you]113-fanny would understand [my]113-fanny silence . Could [I]113-fanny have sent a few happy lines , they should not have been wanting , but nothing of that nature was ever in [my]113-fanny power . [I]113-fanny am returned to [Mansfield]3-mansfield in a less assured state than when [I]113-fanny left it . [My]113-fanny hopes are much weaker . [You]113-fanny are probably aware of this already . So very fond of [you]113-fanny as [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford is , it is most natural that [she]127-miss crawford should tell [you]113-fanny enough of [her]127-miss crawford own feelings to furnish a tolerable guess at [mine]113-fanny . [I]113-fanny will not be prevented , however , from making [my]113-fanny own communication . [Our]6184-our confidences in [you]113-fanny need not clash . [I]113-fanny ask no questions . There is something soothing in the idea that [we]6184-our have [the same friend]6185-the same friend , and that whatever unhappy differences of opinion may exist between [us]6184-our , [we]6184-our are united in [our]6184-our love of [you]113-fanny . It will be a comfort to [me]113-fanny to tell [you]113-fanny how things now are , and what are [my]113-fanny present plans , if plans [I]113-fanny can be said to have . [I]113-fanny have been returned since Saturday . [I]113-fanny was three weeks in [London]6-london , and saw [her]127-miss crawford ( for [London]6-london ) very often . [I]113-fanny had every attention from [the Frasers]258-the frasers that could be reasonably expected . [I]113-fanny dare say [I]113-fanny was not reasonable in carrying with [me]113-fanny hopes of an intercourse at all like that of [Mansfield]130-mansfield . It was [her]127-miss crawford manner , however , rather than any unfrequency of meeting . Had [she]127-miss crawford been different when [I]113-fanny did see [her]127-miss crawford , [I]113-fanny should have made no complaint , but from the very first [she]127-miss crawford was altered : [my]113-fanny first reception was so unlike what [I]113-fanny had hoped , that [I]113-fanny had almost resolved on leaving [London]6-london again directly . [I]113-fanny need not particularise . [You]6186-you know the weak side of [her]127-miss crawford character , and may imagine the sentiments and expressions which were torturing [me]113-fanny . [She]127-miss crawford was in high spirits , and surrounded by [those who were giving all the support of [their]6187-those who were giving all the support of their own bad sense to her too lively mind own bad sense to [her]127-miss crawford too lively mind]6187-those who were giving all the support of their own bad sense to her too lively mind . [I]113-fanny do not like [Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser . [She]127-miss crawford is [a cold - hearted , vain woman , who has married entirely from convenience]6188-a cold - hearted , vain woman , who has married entirely from convenience , and though evidently unhappy in [her]127-miss crawford marriage , places [her]127-miss crawford disappointment not to faults of judgment , or temper , or disproportion of age , but to [her]127-miss crawford being , after all , less affluent than [many of [her]127-miss crawford acquaintance]6189-many of her acquaintance , especially than [[her]127-miss crawford sister]331-her sister , [Lady Stornaway]255-lady stornaway , and is [the determined supporter of everything mercenary and ambitious]6191-the determined supporter of everything mercenary and ambitious , provided it be only mercenary and ambitious enough . [I]113-fanny look upon [her]127-miss crawford intimacy with [those two sisters]6192-those two sisters as the greatest misfortune of [her]127-miss crawford life and [mine]113-fanny . [They]6192-those two sisters have been leading [her]127-miss crawford astray for years . Could [she]127-miss crawford be detached from [them!—and]6193-them!—and sometimes [I]113-fanny do not despair of it , for the affection appears to [me]113-fanny principally on [their]6192-those two sisters side . [They]6192-those two sisters are very fond of [her]127-miss crawford ; but [I]113-fanny am sure [she]127-miss crawford does not love [them]6192-those two sisters as [she]127-miss crawford loves [you]6194-you . When [I]113-fanny think of [her]127-miss crawford great attachment to [you]6194-you , indeed , and the whole of [her]127-miss crawford judicious , upright conduct as [a sister]3681-a sister , [she]127-miss crawford appears [a very different creature]6196-a very different creature , capable of everything noble , and [I]113-fanny am ready to blame [myself]113-fanny for a too harsh construction of a playful manner . [I]113-fanny can not give [her]127-miss crawford up , [Fanny]113-fanny . [She]127-miss crawford is [the only woman in [the world]315-the world whom [I]113-fanny could ever think of as [a wife]537-a wife]6197-the only woman in the world whom i could ever think of as a wife . If [I]113-fanny did not believe that [she]127-miss crawford had some regard for [me]113-fanny , of course [I]113-fanny should not say this , but [I]113-fanny do believe it . [I]113-fanny am convinced that [she]127-miss crawford is not without a decided preference . [I]113-fanny have no jealousy of [any individual]6200-any individual . It is the influence of the fashionable world altogether that [I]113-fanny am jealous of . It is the habits of wealth that [I]113-fanny fear . [Her]127-miss crawford ideas are not higher than [her]127-miss crawford own fortune may warrant , but they are beyond what [our]6201-our incomes united could authorise . There is comfort , however , even here . [I]113-fanny could better bear to lose [her]127-miss crawford because not rich enough , than because of [my]113-fanny profession . That would only prove [her]127-miss crawford affection not equal to sacrifices , which , in fact , [I]113-fanny am scarcely justified in asking ; and , if [I]113-fanny am refused , that , [I]113-fanny think , will be the honest motive . [Her]127-miss crawford prejudices , [I]113-fanny trust , are not so strong as they were . [You]6202-you have [my]113-fanny thoughts exactly as they arise , [[my]113-fanny dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny ; perhaps they are sometimes contradictory , but it will not be a less faithful picture of [my]113-fanny mind . Having once begun , it is a pleasure to [me]113-fanny to tell [you]6202-you all [I]113-fanny feel . [I]113-fanny can not give [her]127-miss crawford up . Connected as [we]6204-we already are , and , [I]113-fanny hope , are to be , to give up [Mary Crawford]132-mary would be to give up the society of [some of those most dear to [me]113-fanny]6205-some of those most dear to me ; to banish [myself]113-fanny from [the very houses and [friends whom , under any other distress]6207-friends whom , under any other distress , [I]113-fanny should turn to for consolation]6206-the very houses and friends whom , under any other distress , i should turn to for consolation . The loss of [Mary]132-mary [I]113-fanny must consider as comprehending the loss of [Crawford]133-mr. crawford and of [Fanny]113-fanny . Were it a decided thing , an actual refusal , [I]113-fanny hope [I]113-fanny should know how to bear it , and how to endeavour to weaken [her]127-miss crawford hold on [my]113-fanny heart , and in the course of a few years — but [I]113-fanny am writing nonsense . Were [I]113-fanny refused , [I]113-fanny must bear it ; and till [I]113-fanny am , [I]113-fanny can never cease to try for [her]127-miss crawford . This is the truth . The only question is _ how _ ? What may be the likeliest means ? [I]113-fanny have sometimes thought of going to [London]6-london again after Easter , and sometimes resolved on doing nothing till [she]127-miss crawford returns to [Mansfield]3-mansfield . Even now , [she]127-miss crawford speaks with pleasure of being in [Mansfield]3-mansfield in June ; but [June]290-june is at a great distance , and [I]113-fanny believe [I]113-fanny shall write to [her]127-miss crawford . [I]113-fanny have nearly determined on explaining [myself]113-fanny by letter . To be at an early certainty is a material object . [My]113-fanny present state is miserably irksome . Considering everything , [I]113-fanny think a letter will be decidedly the best method of explanation . [I]113-fanny shall be able to write much that [I]113-fanny could not say , and shall be giving [her]127-miss crawford time for reflection before [she]127-miss crawford resolves on [her]127-miss crawford answer , and [I]113-fanny am less afraid of the result of reflection than of an immediate hasty impulse ; [I]113-fanny think [I]113-fanny am . [My]113-fanny greatest danger would lie in [her]127-miss crawford consulting [Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser , and [I]113-fanny at a distance unable to help [my]113-fanny own cause . A letter exposes to all the evil of consultation , and where the mind is anything short of perfect decision , [an adviser]5488-an adviser may , in an unlucky moment , lead [it]6209-it to do what it may afterwards regret . [I]113-fanny must think this matter over a little . This long letter , full of [my]113-fanny own concerns alone , will be enough to tire even the friendship of [a Fanny]6210-a fanny . The last time [I]113-fanny saw [Crawford]133-mr. crawford was at [[Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser ’s party]6211-mrs. fraser ’s party . [I]113-fanny am more and more satisfied with all that [I]113-fanny see and hear of [him]133-mr. crawford . There is not a shadow of wavering . [He]133-mr. crawford thoroughly knows [his]133-mr. crawford own mind , and acts up to [his]133-mr. crawford resolutions : an inestimable quality . [I]113-fanny could not see [him]133-mr. crawford and [[my]113-fanny eldest sister]6212-my eldest sister in [the same room]2285-the same room without recollecting what [you]6214-you once told [me]113-fanny , and [I]113-fanny acknowledge that [they]6215-they did not meet as [friends]3751-friends . There was marked coolness on [her]254-mrs. fraser side . [They]6215-they scarcely spoke . [I]113-fanny saw [him]133-mr. crawford draw back surprised , and [I]113-fanny was sorry that [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria should resent any former supposed slight to [Miss Bertram]112-julia . [You]6214-you will wish to hear [my]113-fanny opinion of [Maria]126-maria ’s degree of comfort as [a wife]537-a wife . There is no appearance of unhappiness . [I]113-fanny hope [they]6215-they get on pretty well together . [I]113-fanny dined twice in [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street , and might have been [there]3696-there oftener , but it is mortifying to be with [Rushworth]126-maria as [a brother]4109-a brother . [Julia]112-julia seems to enjoy [London]6-london exceedingly . [I]113-fanny had little enjoyment [there]3696-there , but have less [here]3798-here . [We]6222-we are not a lively party . [You]6214-you are very much wanted . [I]113-fanny miss [you]6214-you more than [I]113-fanny can express . [[My]113-fanny mother]3827-my mother desires [her]3827-my mother best love , and hopes to hear from [you]6214-you soon . [She]3827-my mother talks of [you]6214-you almost every hour , and [I]113-fanny am sorry to find how many weeks more [she]3827-my mother is likely to be without [you]6214-you . [[My]113-fanny father]3762-my father means to fetch [you]6214-you [himself]3762-my father , but it will not be till after Easter , when [he]3762-my father has business in [town]3698-town . [You]6214-you are happy at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , [I]113-fanny hope , but this must not be a yearly visit . [I]113-fanny want [you]6214-you at [home]367-home , that [I]113-fanny may have [your]6214-you opinion about [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey . [I]113-fanny have little heart for extensive improvements till [I]113-fanny know that it will ever have [a mistress]6227-a mistress . [I]113-fanny think [I]113-fanny shall certainly write . It is quite settled that [the Grants]122-the grants go to [Bath]56-bath ; [they]122-the grants leave [Mansfield]3-mansfield on Monday . [I]113-fanny am glad of it . [I]113-fanny am not comfortable enough to be fit for [anybody]3668-anybody ; but [[your]6214-you aunt]3826-your aunt seems to feel out of luck that such an article of [Mansfield]3-mansfield news should fall to [my]113-fanny pen instead of hers.—Yours ever , [[my]113-fanny dearest]5134-my dearest [Fanny]113-fanny . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny never will , no , [I]113-fanny certainly never will wish for a letter again , ”[113-fanny] was [Fanny]113-fanny ’s secret declaration as [she]3215-she finished this . “ What do [they]6231-they bring but disappointment and sorrow ? Not till after Easter ! How shall [I]113-fanny bear it ? And [[my]113-fanny poor aunt]3926-my poor aunt talking of [me]113-fanny every hour ! ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny checked the tendency of these thoughts as well as [she]3215-she could , but [she]3215-she was within half a minute of starting the idea that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was quite unkind , both to [[her]3215-she aunt]463-her aunt and to [herself]113-fanny . As for the main subject of the letter , there was nothing in that to soothe irritation . [She]3215-she was almost vexed into displeasure and anger against [Edmund]108-edmund . “ There is no good in this delay , ”[3215-she] said [she]3215-she . “ Why is not it settled ? [He]108-edmund is blinded , and nothing will open [his]108-edmund eyes ; nothing can , after having had truths before [him]108-edmund so long in vain . [He]108-edmund will marry [her]463-her aunt , and be poor and miserable . [God]291-god grant that [her]463-her aunt influence do not make [him]108-edmund cease to be respectable ! ”[3215-she] [She]3215-she looked over the letter again . “ ‘ So very fond of [me]3215-she ! ’ ’ tis nonsense all . [She]463-her aunt loves [nobody]360-nobody but [herself]463-her aunt and [[her]463-her aunt brother]451-her brother . [[Her]463-her aunt friends]362-her friends leading [her]463-her aunt astray for years ! [She]463-her aunt is quite as likely to have led _ [them]362-her friends _ astray . [They]362-her friends have all , perhaps , been corrupting [one another]5612-one another ; but if [they]362-her friends are so much fonder of [her]463-her aunt than [she]463-her aunt is of [them]362-her friends , [she]463-her aunt is the less likely to have been hurt , except by [their]362-her friends flattery . ‘ [The only woman in [the world]315-the world]6237-the only woman in the world whom [he]451-her brother could ever think of as [a wife]537-a wife . ’ [I]3215-she firmly believe it . It is an attachment to govern [his]451-her brother whole life . Accepted or refused , [his]451-her brother heart is wedded to [her]463-her aunt for ever . ‘ The loss of [Mary]132-mary [I]3215-she must consider as comprehending the loss of [Crawford]133-mr. crawford and [Fanny]113-fanny . ’ [Edmund]108-edmund , [you]108-edmund do not know [me]3215-she . [The families]802-the families would never be connected if [you]108-edmund did not connect [them]802-the families ! Oh ! write , write . Finish it at once . Let there be an end of this suspense . Fix , commit , condemn [yourself]108-edmund . ”[3215-she] Such sensations , however , were too near akin to resentment to be long guiding [Fanny]113-fanny ’s soliloquies . [She]3217-she was soon more softened and sorrowful . [His]3218-his warm regard , [his]3218-his kind expressions , [his]3218-his confidential treatment , touched [her]3217-she strongly . [He]3218-his was only too good to [everybody]408-everybody . It was a letter , in short , which [she]3217-she would not but have had for [the world]315-the world , and which could never be valued enough . This was the end of it . [Everybody]408-everybody at all addicted to letter - writing , without having much to say , which will include a large proportion of [the female world]3222-the female world at least , must feel with [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram that [she]106-lady bertram was out of luck in having such a capital piece of Mansfield news as the certainty of [the Grants]122-the grants going to [Bath]56-bath , occur at a time when [she]106-lady bertram could make no advantage of it , and will admit that it must have been very mortifying to [her]106-lady bertram to see it fall to the share of [[her]106-lady bertram thankless son]3223-her thankless son , and treated as concisely as possible at the end of a long letter , instead of having it to spread over the largest part of a page of [her]106-lady bertram own .
