For though [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram rather shone in the epistolary line , having early in [her]106-lady bertram marriage , from the want of other employment , and the circumstance of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s being in Parliament , got into the way of making and keeping [correspondents]3224-correspondents , and formed for [herself]106-lady bertram a very creditable , common - place , amplifying style , so that a very little matter was enough for [her]106-lady bertram : [she]106-lady bertram could not do entirely without any ; [she]106-lady bertram must have something to write about , even to [[her]106-lady bertram niece]642-her niece ; and being so soon to lose all the benefit of [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant ’s gouty symptoms and [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant ’s morning calls , it was very hard upon [her]106-lady bertram to be deprived of one of the last epistolary uses [she]106-lady bertram could put them to . There was a rich amends , however , preparing for [her]106-lady bertram . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s hour of good luck came . Within a few days from the receipt of [Edmund]108-edmund ’s letter , [Fanny]113-fanny had one from [[her]106-lady bertram aunt]463-her aunt , beginning thus — “ [[My]463-her aunt Dear]3657-my dear [Fanny,—I]292-fanny,—i take up [my]463-her aunt pen to communicate some very alarming intelligence , which [I]463-her aunt make no doubt will give [you]292-fanny,—i much concern ”[463-her aunt] . This was a great deal better than to have to take up the pen to acquaint [her]463-her aunt with all the particulars of [the Grants]2009-the grants ’ intended journey , for the present intelligence was of a nature to promise occupation for the pen for many days to come , being no less than the dangerous illness of [[her]463-her aunt eldest son]3228-her eldest son , of which [they]3229-they had received notice by express a few hours before . [Tom]101-sir thomas had gone from [London]6-london with [a party of [young men]3231-young men]3230-a party of young men to [Newmarket]94-newmarket , where a neglected fall and a good deal of drinking had brought on a fever ; and when [the party]907-the party broke up , being unable to move , had been left by [himself]101-sir thomas at [the house of [one of [these young men]3235-these young men]3234-one of these young men]3233-the house of one of these young men to the comforts of sickness and solitude , and the attendance only of [servants]6060-servants . Instead of being soon well enough to follow [[his]101-sir thomas friends]533-his friends , as [he]101-sir thomas had then hoped , [his]101-sir thomas disorder increased considerably , and it was not long before [he]101-sir thomas thought so ill of [himself]101-sir thomas as to be as ready as [[his]101-sir thomas physician]3238-his physician to have a letter despatched to [Mansfield]3-mansfield . “ This distressing intelligence , as [you]6242-you may suppose , ”[921-her ladyship] observed [[her]3239-her ladyship]921-her ladyship , after giving the substance of it , “ has agitated [us]6243-us exceedingly , and [we]6243-us can not prevent [ourselves]6243-us from being greatly alarmed and apprehensive for [the poor invalid]6244-the poor invalid , whose state [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas fears may be very critical ; and [Edmund]108-edmund kindly proposes attending [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother immediately , but [I]921-her ladyship am happy to add that [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas will not leave [me]921-her ladyship on this distressing occasion , as it would be too trying for [me]921-her ladyship . [We]6243-us shall greatly miss [Edmund]108-edmund in [our]6243-us small circle , but [I]921-her ladyship trust and hope [he]108-edmund will find [the poor invalid]6244-the poor invalid in a less alarming state than might be apprehended , and that [he]108-edmund will be able to bring [him]108-edmund to [Mansfield]3-mansfield shortly , which [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas proposes should be done , and thinks best on every account , and [I]921-her ladyship flatter [myself]921-her ladyship [the poor sufferer]6247-the poor sufferer will soon be able to bear the removal without material inconvenience or injury . As [I]921-her ladyship have little doubt of [your]113-fanny feeling for [us]6243-us , [[my]921-her ladyship dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , under these distressing circumstances , [I]921-her ladyship will write again very soon . ”[921-her ladyship] [Fanny]113-fanny ’s feelings on the occasion were indeed considerably more warm and genuine than [[her]3241-she aunt]463-her aunt ’s style of writing . [She]3241-she felt truly for [them]3243-them all . [Tom]101-sir thomas dangerously ill , [Edmund]108-edmund gone to attend [him]101-sir thomas , and [the sadly small party remaining at [Mansfield]3-mansfield]3244-the sadly small party remaining at mansfield , were cares to shut out every other care , or almost every other . [She]3241-she could just find selfishness enough to wonder whether [Edmund]108-edmund _ had _ written to [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford before this summons came , but no sentiment dwelt long with [her]3241-she that was not purely affectionate and disinterestedly anxious . [[Her]3241-she aunt]463-her aunt did not neglect [her]3241-she : [she]3241-she wrote again and again ; [they]3246-they were receiving frequent accounts from [Edmund]108-edmund , and these accounts were as regularly transmitted to [Fanny]113-fanny , in the same diffuse style , and the same medley of trusts , hopes , and fears , all following and producing each other at haphazard . It was a sort of playing at being frightened . The sufferings which [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram did not see had little power over [her]106-lady bertram fancy ; and [she]3241-she wrote very comfortably about agitation , and anxiety , and [poor invalids]3247-poor invalids , till [Tom]101-sir thomas was actually conveyed to [Mansfield]130-mansfield , and [her]3241-she own eyes had beheld [his]101-sir thomas altered appearance . Then a letter which [she]3241-she had been previously preparing for [Fanny]113-fanny was finished in a different style , in the language of real feeling and alarm ; then [she]3241-she wrote as [she]3241-she might have spoken . “ [He]101-sir thomas is just come , [[my]3241-she dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , and is taken [upstairs]4939-upstairs ; and [I]3241-she am so shocked to see [him]101-sir thomas , that [I]3241-she do not know what to do . [I]3241-she am sure [he]101-sir thomas has been very ill . [Poor Tom]293-poor tom ! [I]3241-she am quite grieved for [him]101-sir thomas , and very much frightened , and so is [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ; and how glad [I]3241-she should be if [you]113-fanny were here to comfort [me]3241-she . But [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas hopes [he]101-sir thomas will be better to - morrow , and says [we]3251-we must consider [his]101-sir thomas journey . ”[3241-she] The real solicitude now awakened in [the maternal bosom]3248-the maternal bosom was not soon over . [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s extreme impatience to be removed to [Mansfield]130-mansfield , and experience those comforts of [home]367-home and [family]4300-family which had been little thought of in uninterrupted health , had probably induced [his]101-sir thomas being conveyed thither too early , as a return of fever came on , and for a week [he]101-sir thomas was in a more alarming state than ever . [They]3251-we were all very seriously frightened . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram wrote [her]106-lady bertram daily terrors to [[her]106-lady bertram niece]642-her niece , who [might now be said to live upon letters]3253-might now be said to live upon letters , and pass all [her]106-lady bertram time between suffering from that of to - day and looking forward to to - morrow ’s . Without any particular affection for [[her]106-lady bertram eldest cousin]3254-her eldest cousin , [her]106-lady bertram tenderness of heart made [her]106-lady bertram feel that [she]106-lady bertram could not spare [him]3254-her eldest cousin , and the purity of [her]106-lady bertram principles added yet a keener solicitude , when [she]106-lady bertram considered how little useful , how little self - denying [his]3254-her eldest cousin life had ( apparently ) been . [Susan]264-susan was [[her]106-lady bertram only companion]3816-her only companion and [listener]3256-listener on this , as on more common occasions . [Susan]264-susan was always ready to hear and to sympathise . [Nobody else]4733-nobody else could be interested in so remote an evil as illness in [a family above an hundred miles off]3258-a family above an hundred miles off ; not even [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price , beyond a brief question or two , if [she]107-mrs. price saw [[her]107-mrs. price daughter]382-her daughter with a letter in [her]382-her daughter hand , and now and then the quiet observation of , “ [[My]107-mrs. price poor sister]3690-my poor sister [Bertram]106-lady bertram must be in a great deal of trouble . ”[107-mrs. price] So long divided and so differently situated , the ties of blood were little more than nothing . An attachment , originally as tranquil as [their]3260-their tempers , was now become a mere name . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price did quite as much for [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram as [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram would have done for [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price . Three or four Prices might have been swept away , any or all except [Fanny]113-fanny and [William]228-william , and [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram would have thought little about it ; or perhaps might have caught from [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s lips the ca nt of its being a very happy thing and a great blessing to [[their]3260-their poor dear sister]3261-their poor dear sister [Price]107-mrs. price to have [them]3260-their so well provided for . CHAPTER XLV At about the week ’s end from [his]3262-his return to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s immediate danger was over , and [he]3262-his was so far pronounced safe as to make [[his]3262-his mother]629-his mother perfectly easy ; for being now used to the sight of [him]3262-his in [his]3262-his suffering , helpless state , and hearing only the best , and never thinking beyond what [she]629-his mother heard , with no disposition for alarm and no aptitude at a hint , [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram was the happiest subject in [the world]315-the world for a little medical imposition . The fever was subdued ; the fever had been [his]3262-his complaint ; of course [he]3262-his would soon be well again . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram could think nothing less , and [Fanny]113-fanny shared [[her]106-lady bertram aunt]463-her aunt ’s security , till [she]106-lady bertram received a few lines from [Edmund]108-edmund , written purposely to give [her]106-lady bertram a clearer idea of [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother ’s situation , and acquaint [her]106-lady bertram with the apprehensions which [he]108-edmund and [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father had imbibed from [the physician]3268-the physician with respect to some strong hectic symptoms , which seemed to seize the frame on the departure of the fever . [They]3269-they judged it best that [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram should not be harassed by alarms which , it was to be hoped , would prove unfounded ; but there was no reason why [Fanny]113-fanny should not know the truth . [They]3269-they were apprehensive for [his]108-edmund lungs . A very few lines from [Edmund]108-edmund shewed [her]106-lady bertram [the patient]3270-the patient and [the sickroom]3271-the sickroom in a juster and stronger light than all [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s sheets of paper could do . There was hardly [any one in [the house]427-the house who might not have described , from personal observation , better than [herself]106-lady bertram]3272-any one in the house who might not have described , from personal observation , better than herself ; [not one who was not more useful at times to [[her]106-lady bertram son]637-her son]3274-not one who was not more useful at times to her son . [She]106-lady bertram could do nothing but glide in quietly and look at [him]108-edmund ; but when able to talk or be talked to , or read to , [Edmund]108-edmund was the companion [he]108-edmund preferred . [[His]108-edmund aunt]630-his aunt worried [him]108-edmund by [her]630-his aunt cares , and [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas knew not how to bring down [his]108-edmund conversation or [his]108-edmund voice to the level of irritation and feebleness . [Edmund]108-edmund was all in all . [Fanny]113-fanny would certainly believe [him]108-edmund so at least , and must find that [her]106-lady bertram estimation of [him]108-edmund was higher than ever when [he]108-edmund appeared as [the attendant , supporter]3277-the attendant , supporter , cheerer of [a suffering brother]3278-a suffering brother . There was not only the debility of recent illness to assist : there was also , as [she]106-lady bertram now learnt , nerves much affected , spirits much depressed to calm and raise , and [her]106-lady bertram own imagination added that there must be a mind to be properly guided . [The family]3724-the family were not consumptive , and [she]106-lady bertram was more inclined to hope than fear for [[her]106-lady bertram cousin]3692-her cousin , except when [she]106-lady bertram thought of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; but [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford gave [her]106-lady bertram the idea of being [the child of good luck]3281-the child of good luck , and to [her]106-lady bertram selfishness and vanity it would be good luck to have [Edmund]108-edmund [the only son]3282-the only son . Even in [the sick chamber]3283-the sick chamber [the fortunate Mary]3284-the fortunate mary was not forgotten . [Edmund]108-edmund ’s letter had this postscript . “ On the subject of [my]108-edmund last , [I]108-edmund had actually begun a letter when called away by [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s illness , but [I]108-edmund have now changed [my]108-edmund mind , and fear to trust the influence of [friends]3751-friends . When [Tom]101-sir thomas is better , [I]108-edmund shall go . ”[108-edmund] Such was the state of [Mansfield]130-mansfield , and so it continued , with scarcely any change , till [Easter]153-easter . A line occasionally added by [Edmund]108-edmund to [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother ’s letter was enough for [Fanny]113-fanny ’s information . [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s amendment was alarmingly slow . [Easter]153-easter came particularly late this year , as [Fanny]113-fanny had most sorrowfully considered , on first learning that [she]3286-her had no chance of leaving [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth till after it . It came , and [she]3286-her had yet heard nothing of [her]3286-her return — nothing even of the going to [London]6-london , which was to precede [her]3286-her return . [[Her]3286-her aunt]463-her aunt often expressed a wish for [her]3286-her , but there was no notice , no message from [the uncle on whom all depended]3288-the uncle on whom all depended . [She]463-her aunt supposed [he]3288-the uncle on whom all depended could not yet leave [[his]3288-the uncle on whom all depended son]581-his son , but it was a cruel , a terrible delay to [her]463-her aunt . The end of [April]294-april was coming on ; it would soon be almost three months , instead of two , that [she]463-her aunt had been absent from [them]3290-them all , and that [her]463-her aunt days had been passing in a state of penance , which [she]463-her aunt loved [them]3290-them too well to hope [they]3290-them would thoroughly understand ; and who could yet say when there might be leisure to think of or fetch [her]463-her aunt ? [Her]463-her aunt eagerness , [her]463-her aunt impatience , [her]463-her aunt longings to be with [them]3290-them , were such as to bring a line or two of [Cowper]147-cowper ’s Tirocinium for ever before [her]463-her aunt . “ With what intense desire [she]463-her aunt wants [her]463-her aunt home , ”[463-her aunt] was continually on [her]463-her aunt tongue , as the truest description of a yearning which [she]463-her aunt could not suppose [any schoolboy]3291-any schoolboy ’s bosom to feel more keenly . When [she]463-her aunt had been coming to [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , [she]463-her aunt had loved to call it [[her]463-her aunt home]3744-her home , had been fond of saying that [she]463-her aunt was going [home]367-home ; the word had been very dear to [her]463-her aunt , and so it still was , but it must be applied to [Mansfield]3-mansfield . _ That _ was now [the home]3294-the home . [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth was [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth ; [Mansfield]3-mansfield was [home]367-home . [They]3296-they had been long so arranged in the indulgence of [her]463-her aunt secret meditations , and nothing was more consolatory to [her]463-her aunt than to find [[her]463-her aunt aunt]463-her aunt using the same language : “ [I]463-her aunt can not but say [I]463-her aunt much regret [your]3-mansfield being from [home]367-home at this distressing time , so very trying to [my]463-her aunt spirits . [I]463-her aunt trust and hope , and sincerely wish [you]3-mansfield may never be absent from [home]367-home so long again , ”[463-her aunt] were most delightful sentences to [her]463-her aunt . Still , however , it was [her]463-her aunt private regale . Delicacy to [[her]463-her aunt parents]2443-her parents made [her]463-her aunt careful not to betray such a preference of [[[her]463-her aunt uncle]312-her uncle ’s house]721-her uncle ’s house . It was always : “ When [I]463-her aunt go back into [Northamptonshire]15-northamptonshire , or when [I]463-her aunt return to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , [I]463-her aunt shall do so and so . ”[463-her aunt] For a great while it was so , but at last the longing grew stronger , it overthrew caution , and [she]463-her aunt found [herself]463-her aunt talking of what [she]463-her aunt should do when [she]463-her aunt went [home]367-home before [she]463-her aunt was aware . [She]463-her aunt reproached [herself]463-her aunt , coloured , and looked fearfully towards [[her]463-her aunt father]667-her father and [mother]3977-mother . [She]463-her aunt need not have been uneasy . There was no sign of displeasure , or even of hearing [her]463-her aunt . [They]3304-they were perfectly free from any jealousy of [Mansfield]3-mansfield . [She]463-her aunt was as welcome to wish [herself]463-her aunt there as to be [there]3696-there . It was sad to [Fanny]113-fanny to lose all the pleasures of spring . [She]463-her aunt had not known before what pleasures [she]463-her aunt _ had _ to lose in passing March and April in [a town]3306-a town . [She]463-her aunt had not known before how much the beginnings and progress of vegetation had delighted [her]463-her aunt . What animation , both of body and mind , [she]463-her aunt had derived from watching the advance of that season which can not , in spite of its capriciousness , be unlovely , and seeing its increasing beauties from the earliest flowers in the warmest divisions of [[[her]463-her aunt aunt]463-her aunt ’s garden]3308-her aunt ’s garden , to the opening of leaves of [[[her]463-her aunt uncle]312-her uncle ’s plantations]3310-her uncle ’s plantations , and the glory of [[his]312-her uncle woods]3311-his woods . To be losing such pleasures was no trifle ; to be losing them , because [she]463-her aunt was in the midst of closeness and noise , to have confinement , bad air , bad smells , substituted for liberty , freshness , fragrance , and verdure , was infinitely worse : but even these incitements to regret were feeble , compared with what arose from the conviction of being missed by [[her]463-her aunt best friends]3312-her best friends , and the longing to be useful to those who were wanting [her]463-her aunt ! Could [she]463-her aunt have been at [home]367-home , [she]463-her aunt might have been of service to [every creature in [the house]427-the house]3314-every creature in the house . [She]463-her aunt felt that [she]463-her aunt must have been of use to [all]874-all . To all [she]463-her aunt must have saved some trouble of head or hand ; and were it only in supporting the spirits of [[her]463-her aunt aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]106-lady bertram , keeping [her]463-her aunt from the evil of solitude , or the still greater evil of [a restless , officious companion]3318-a restless , officious companion , too apt to be heightening danger in order to enhance [her]463-her aunt own importance , [her]463-her aunt being there would have been a general good . [She]463-her aunt loved to fancy how [she]463-her aunt could have read to [[her]463-her aunt aunt]463-her aunt , how [she]463-her aunt could have talked to [her]463-her aunt , and tried at once to make [her]463-her aunt feel the blessing of what was , and prepare [her]463-her aunt mind for what might be ; and how many walks up and down [stairs]3320-stairs [she]463-her aunt might have saved [her]463-her aunt , and how many messages [she]463-her aunt might have carried . It astonished [her]463-her aunt that [[Tom]101-sir thomas ’s sisters]3321-tom ’s sisters could be satisfied with remaining in [London]6-london at such a time , through an illness which had now , under different degrees of danger , lasted several weeks . _ [They]3321-tom ’s sisters _ might return to [Mansfield]3-mansfield when [they]3321-tom ’s sisters chose ; travelling could be no difficulty to _ [them]3321-tom ’s sisters _ , and [she]463-her aunt could not comprehend how [both]5359-both could still keep away . If [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria could imagine any interfering obligations , [Julia]112-julia was certainly able to quit [London]6-london whenever [she]112-julia chose . It appeared from one of [[her]112-julia aunt]463-her aunt ’s letters that [Julia]112-julia had offered to return if wanted , but this was all . It was evident that [she]112-julia would rather remain where [she]112-julia was . [Fanny]113-fanny was disposed to think the influence of [London]6-london very much at war with all respectable attachments . [She]463-her aunt saw the proof of it in [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , as well as in [[her]463-her aunt cousins]3671-her cousins ; _ [her]463-her aunt _ attachment to [Edmund]108-edmund had been respectable , the most respectable part of [her]463-her aunt character ; [her]463-her aunt friendship for [herself]463-her aunt had at least been blameless . Where was either sentiment now ? It was so long since [Fanny]113-fanny had had any letter from [her]463-her aunt , that [she]463-her aunt had some reason to think lightly of the friendship which had been so dwelt on . It was weeks since [she]463-her aunt had heard anything of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford or of [her]127-miss crawford other connexions in [town]3698-town , except through [Mansfield]3-mansfield , and [she]463-her aunt was beginning to suppose that [she]463-her aunt might never know whether [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford had gone into [Norfolk]19-norfolk again or not till [they]3326-they met , and might never hear from [[his]133-mr. crawford sister]511-his sister any more this spring , when the following letter was received to revive old and create some new sensations — “ Forgive [me]113-fanny , [[my]113-fanny dear]3657-my dear [Fanny]113-fanny , as soon as [you]113-fanny can , for [my]113-fanny long silence , and behave as if [you]113-fanny could forgive [me]113-fanny directly . This is [my]113-fanny modest request and expectation , for [you]113-fanny are so good , that [I]113-fanny depend upon being treated better than [I]113-fanny deserve , and [I]113-fanny write now to beg an immediate answer . [I]113-fanny want to know the state of things at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and [you]113-fanny , no doubt , are perfectly able to give it . [One]766-one should be a brute not to feel for the distress [they]766-one are in ; and from what [I]113-fanny hear , [poor Mr. Bertram]108-edmund has a bad chance of ultimate recovery . [I]113-fanny thought little of [his]108-edmund illness at first . [I]113-fanny looked upon [him]108-edmund as [the sort of person to be made a fuss with , and to make a fuss]6257-the sort of person to be made a fuss with , and to make a fuss [himself]108-edmund in any trifling disorder , and was chiefly concerned for those who had to nurse [him]108-edmund ; but now it is confidently asserted that [he]108-edmund is really in a decline , that the symptoms are most alarming , and [that part of [the family]3724-the family]6258-that part of the family , at least , are aware of it . If it be so , [I]113-fanny am sure [you]113-fanny must be included in that part , that discerning part , and therefore entreat [you]113-fanny to let [me]113-fanny know how far [I]113-fanny have been rightly informed . [I]113-fanny need not say how rejoiced [I]113-fanny shall be to hear there has been any mistake , but the report is so prevalent that [I]113-fanny confess [I]113-fanny can not help trembling . To have [such a fine young man]6260-such a fine young man cut off in the flower of [his]108-edmund days is most melancholy . [Poor Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas will feel it dreadfully . [I]113-fanny really am quite agitated on the subject . [Fanny]113-fanny , [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]113-fanny see [you]113-fanny smile and look cunning , but , upon [my]113-fanny honour , [I]113-fanny never bribed [a physician]6261-a physician in [my]113-fanny life . [Poor young man]6262-poor young man ! If [he]6262-poor young man is to die , there will be [_ two _ poor young men less in [the world]315-the world]6263-_ two _ poor young men less in the world ; and with a fearless face and bold voice would [I]113-fanny say to [any one]3817-any one , that wealth and consequence could fall into no hands more deserving of [them]3817-any one . It was a foolish precipitation last Christmas , but the evil of a few days may be blotted out in part . Varnish and gilding hide many stains . It will be but the loss of [the Esquire]6266-the esquire after [his]6262-poor young man name . With real affection , [Fanny]113-fanny , like [mine]113-fanny , more might be overlooked . Write to [me]113-fanny by return of post , judge of [my]113-fanny anxiety , and do not trifle with it . Tell [me]113-fanny the real truth , as [you]113-fanny have it from the fountainhead . And now , do not trouble [yourself]113-fanny to be ashamed of either [my]113-fanny feelings or [your]113-fanny own . Believe [me]113-fanny , they are not only natural , [they]3817-any one are philanthropic and virtuous . [I]113-fanny put it to [your]113-fanny conscience , whether ‘ [Sir Edmund]108-edmund ’ would not do more good with all the Bertram property than any other possible ‘ Sir . ’ Had [the Grants]122-the grants been at [home]367-home [I]113-fanny would not have troubled [you]113-fanny , but [you]113-fanny are now [the only one [I]113-fanny can apply to for the truth , [[his]108-edmund sisters]4166-his sisters]6268-the only one i can apply to for the truth , his sisters not being within [my]113-fanny reach . [Mrs. R.]296-mrs. r. has been spending the Easter with [the Aylmers]297-the aylmers at [Twickenham]30-twickenham ( as to be sure [you]113-fanny know ) , and is not yet returned ; and [Julia]112-julia is with [the cousins who live near [Bedford Square]95-bedford square]6270-the cousins who live near bedford square , but [I]113-fanny forget [their]6270-the cousins who live near bedford square name and [street]6271-street . Could [I]113-fanny immediately apply to either , however , [I]113-fanny should still prefer [you]113-fanny , because it strikes [me]113-fanny that [they]6270-the cousins who live near bedford square have all along been so unwilling to have [their]6270-the cousins who live near bedford square own amusements cut up , as to shut [their]6270-the cousins who live near bedford square eyes to the truth . [I]113-fanny suppose [Mrs. R.]296-mrs. r. ’s Easter holidays will not last much longer ; no doubt they are thorough holidays to [her]296-mrs. r. . [The Aylmers]6272-the aylmers are [pleasant people]6273-pleasant people ; and [[her]296-mrs. r. husband]325-her husband away , [she]296-mrs. r. can have nothing but enjoyment . [I]113-fanny give [her]296-mrs. r. credit for promoting [his]325-her husband going dutifully down to [Bath]56-bath , to fetch [[his]325-her husband mother]629-his mother ; but how will [she]296-mrs. r. and [the dowager]6276-the dowager agree in [one house]3801-one house ? [Henry]131-henry is not at hand , so [I]113-fanny have nothing to say from [him]131-henry . Do not [you]6278-you think [Edmund]108-edmund would have been in [town]3698-town again long ago , but for this illness?—Yours ever , [Mary]132-mary . ”[113-fanny] “ [I]113-fanny had actually begun folding [my]113-fanny letter when [Henry]131-henry walked in , but [he]131-henry brings no intelligence to prevent [my]113-fanny sending it . [Mrs. R.]296-mrs. r. knows [a decline]6280-a decline is apprehended ; [he]131-henry saw [her]296-mrs. r. this morning : [she]296-mrs. r. returns to [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street to - day ; [the old lady]4745-the old lady is come . Now do not make [yourself]6278-you uneasy with any queer fancies because [he]131-henry has been spending a few days at [Richmond]96-richmond . [He]131-henry does it every spring . Be assured [he]131-henry cares for [nobody]360-nobody but [you]6278-you . At this very moment [he]131-henry is wild to see [you]6278-you , and occupied only in contriving the means for doing so , and for making [his]131-henry pleasure conduce to [yours]6278-you . In proof , [he]131-henry repeats , and more eagerly , what [he]131-henry said at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth about [our]6283-our conveying [you]6278-you [home]367-home , and [I]113-fanny join [him]131-henry in it with all [my]113-fanny soul . [Dear Fanny]113-fanny , write directly , and tell [us]6283-our to come . It will do [us]6283-our all good . [He]131-henry and [I]113-fanny can go to [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage , [you]6278-you know , and be no trouble to [[our]6283-our friends]6286-our friends at [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield . It would really be gratifying to see [them]6286-our friends all again , and a little addition of society might be of infinite use to [them]6286-our friends ; and as to [yourself]6278-you , [you]6278-you must feel [yourself]6278-you to be so wanted there , that [you]6278-you can not in conscience — conscientious as [you]6278-you are — keep away , when [you]6278-you have the means of returning . [I]113-fanny have not time or patience to give half [Henry]131-henry ’s messages ; be satisfied that the spirit of each and every one is unalterable affection . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny ’s disgust at the greater part of this letter , with [her]3328-her extreme reluctance to bring [the writer of it]3329-the writer of it and [[her]3328-her cousin]3692-her cousin [Edmund]108-edmund together , would have made [her]3328-her ( as [she]3328-her felt ) incapable of judging impartially whether the concluding offer might be accepted or not . To [herself]3328-her , individually , it was most tempting . To be finding [herself]3328-her , perhaps within three days , transported to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , was an image of the greatest felicity , but it would have been a material drawback to be owing such felicity to [persons in whose feelings and conduct , at the present moment]3331-persons in whose feelings and conduct , at the present moment , [she]3328-her saw so much to condemn : [the sister]1940-the sister ’s feelings , [the brother]695-the brother ’s conduct , _ [her]1940-the sister _ cold - hearted ambition , _ [his]695-the brother _ thoughtless vanity . To have [him]695-the brother still the acquaintance , [the flirt perhaps]3334-the flirt perhaps , of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ! [She]3328-her was mortified . [She]3328-her had thought better of [him]695-the brother . Happily , however , [she]3328-her was not left to weigh and decide between opposite inclinations and doubtful notions of right ; there was no occasion to determine whether [she]3328-her ought to keep [Edmund]108-edmund and [Mary]132-mary asunder or not . [She]3328-her had a rule to apply to , which settled everything . [Her]3328-her awe of [[her]3328-her uncle]312-her uncle , and [her]3328-her dread of taking a liberty with [him]695-the brother , made it instantly plain to [her]3328-her what [she]3328-her had to do . [She]3328-her must absolutely decline the proposal . If [he]695-the brother wanted , [he]695-the brother would send for [her]3328-her ; and even to offer an early return was a presumption which hardly anything would have seemed to justify . [She]3328-her thanked [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , but gave a decided negative . “ [[Her]3328-her uncle]312-her uncle , [she]3328-her understood , meant to fetch [her]3328-her ; and as [[her]3328-her cousin]3692-her cousin ’s illness had continued so many weeks without [her]3328-her being thought at all necessary , [she]3328-her must suppose [her]3328-her return would be unwelcome at present , and that [she]3328-her should be felt an encumbrance . ”[3328-her] [Her]3328-her representation of [[her]3328-her cousin]3692-her cousin ’s state at this time was exactly according to [her]3328-her own belief of it , and such as [she]3328-her supposed would convey to the sanguine mind of [her]3328-her correspondent the hope of everything [she]3328-her was wishing for . [Edmund]108-edmund would be forgiven for being [a clergyman]500-a clergyman , it seemed , under certain conditions of wealth ; and this , [she]3328-her suspected , was all the conquest of prejudice which [he]108-edmund was so ready to congratulate [himself]108-edmund upon . [She]3328-her had only learnt to think nothing of consequence but money . [[CHAPTER XLVI]298-chapter xlvi]3338-chapter xlvi As [Fanny]113-fanny could not doubt that [her]3328-her answer was conveying a real disappointment , [she]3328-her was rather in expectation , from [her]3328-her knowledge of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s temper , of being urged again ; and though no second letter arrived for the space of a week , [she]3328-her had still the same feeling when it did come . On receiving it , [she]3328-her could instantly decide on its containing little writing , and was persuaded of its having the air of a letter of haste and business . Its object was unquestionable ; and two moments were enough to start the probability of its being merely to give [her]3328-her notice that they should be in [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth that very day , and to throw [her]3328-her into all the agitation of doubting what [she]3328-her ought to do in such a case . If two moments , however , can surround with difficulties , a third can disperse them ; and before [she]3328-her had opened the letter , the possibility of [Mr.]3339-mr. and [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s having applied to [[her]3328-her uncle]312-her uncle and obtained [his]312-her uncle permission was giving [her]3328-her ease . This was the letter — “ A most scandalous , ill - natured rumour has just reached [me]113-fanny , and [I]113-fanny write , dear [Fanny]113-fanny , to warn [you]113-fanny against giving the least credit to it , should it spread into [the country]493-the country . Depend upon it , there is some mistake , and that a day or two will clear it up ; at any rate , that [Henry]131-henry is blameless , and in spite of a moment ’s _ etourderie _ , thinks of [nobody]360-nobody but [you]113-fanny . Say not a word of it ; hear nothing , surmise nothing , whisper nothing till [I]113-fanny write again . [I]113-fanny am sure it will be all hushed up , and nothing proved but [Rushworth]126-maria ’s folly . If [they]6291-they are gone , [I]113-fanny would lay [my]113-fanny life [they]6291-they are only gone to [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , and [Julia]112-julia with [them]6291-they . But why would not [you]113-fanny let [us]6292-us come for [you]113-fanny ? [I]113-fanny wish [you]113-fanny may not repent it.—Yours , etc . ”[113-fanny] [Fanny]113-fanny stood aghast . As no scandalous , ill - natured rumour had reached [her]3341-her , it was impossible for [her]3341-her to understand much of this strange letter . [She]3341-her could only perceive that it must relate to [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , and only conjecture that something very imprudent had just occurred in that quarter to draw the notice of [the world]315-the world , and to excite [her]3341-her jealousy , in [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s apprehension , if [she]3341-her heard it . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford need not be alarmed for [her]127-miss crawford . [She]127-miss crawford was only sorry for [the parties concerned]3343-the parties concerned and for [Mansfield]130-mansfield , if the report should spread so far ; but [she]127-miss crawford hoped it might not . If [the Rushworths]217-the rushworths were gone [themselves]217-the rushworths to [Mansfield]3-mansfield , as was to be inferred from what [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford said , it was not likely that anything unpleasant should have preceded [them]3344-them , or at least should make any impression . As to [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , [she]3341-her hoped it might give [him]133-mr. crawford a knowledge of [his]133-mr. crawford own disposition , convince [him]133-mr. crawford that [he]133-mr. crawford was not capable of being steadily attached to [any one woman in [the world]315-the world]3345-any one woman in the world , and shame [him]133-mr. crawford from persisting any longer in addressing [herself]3341-her . It was very strange ! [She]3341-her had begun to think [he]133-mr. crawford really loved [her]3341-her , and to fancy [his]133-mr. crawford affection for [her]3341-her something more than common ; and [[his]133-mr. crawford sister]511-his sister still said that [he]133-mr. crawford cared for [nobody else]4733-nobody else . Yet there must have been some marked display of attentions to [[her]3341-her cousin]3692-her cousin , there must have been some strong indiscretion , since [[her]3341-her correspondent]3350-her correspondent was not of a sort to regard [a slight one]3351-a slight one . Very uncomfortable [she]3341-her was , and must continue , till [she]3341-her heard from [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford again . It was impossible to banish the letter from [her]3341-her thoughts , and [she]3341-her could not relieve [herself]3341-her by speaking of it to [any human being]3352-any human being . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford need not have urged secrecy with so much warmth ; [she]3341-her might have trusted to [her]3341-her sense of what was due to [[her]127-miss crawford cousin]3692-her cousin . The next day came and brought no second letter . [Fanny]113-fanny was disappointed . [She]3341-her could still think of little else all the morning ; but , when [[her]3341-her father]667-her father came back in the afternoon with the daily newspaper as usual , [she]3341-her was so far from expecting any elucidation through such a channel that the subject was for a moment out of [her]3341-her head . [She]3341-her was deep in other musing . The remembrance of [her]3341-her first evening in [that room]1389-that room , of [[her]3341-her father]667-her father and [his]667-her father newspaper , came across [her]3341-her . No candle was now wanted . The sun was yet an hour and half above the horizon . [She]3341-her felt that [she]3341-her had , indeed , been three months [there]3696-there ; and the sun ’s rays falling strongly into [the parlour]6021-the parlour , instead of cheering , made [her]3341-her still more melancholy , for sunshine appeared to [her]3341-her a totally different thing in [a town]3306-a town and in [the country]493-the country . Here , its power was only a glare : a stifling , sickly glare , serving but to bring forward stains and dirt that might otherwise have slept . There was neither health nor gaiety in sunshine in [a town]3306-a town . [She]3341-her sat in a blaze of oppressive heat , in a cloud of moving dust , and [her]3341-her eyes could only wander from the walls , marked by [[her]3341-her father]667-her father ’s head , to the table cut and notched by [[her]3341-her brothers]3878-her brothers , where stood the tea - board never thoroughly cleaned , the cups and saucers wiped in streaks , the milk a mixture of motes floating in thin blue , and the bread and butter growing every minute more greasy than even [Rebecca]268-rebecca ’s hands had first produced it . [[Her]3341-her father]667-her father read [his]667-her father newspaper , and [[her]3341-her mother]446-her mother lamented over the ragged carpet as usual , while the tea was in preparation , and wished [Rebecca]268-rebecca would mend it ; and [Fanny]113-fanny was first roused by [his]667-her father calling out to [her]3341-her , after humphing and considering over a particular paragraph : “ What ’s the name of [[your]3341-her great cousins]6293-your great cousins in [town]3698-town , [Fan]113-fanny ? ”[667-her father] A moment ’s recollection enabled [her]3341-her to say , “ [Rushworth]126-maria , [sir]4023-sir . ”[667-her father] “ And do n’t [they]6293-your great cousins live in [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street ? ”[667-her father] “ Yes , [sir]4023-sir . ”[667-her father] “ Then , there ’s the devil to pay among [them]6293-your great cousins , that ’s all ! There ”[667-her father] ( holding out the paper to [her]3341-her ) ; “ much good may such fine relations do [you]3341-her . [I]3341-her do n’t know what [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas may think of such matters ; [he]101-sir thomas may be too much of [the courtier and fine gentleman]6297-the courtier and fine gentleman to like [[his]101-sir thomas daughter]1739-his daughter the less . But , by G — ! if [she]1739-his daughter belonged to _ [me]3341-her _ , [I]3341-her ’d give [her]1739-his daughter the rope ’s end as long as [I]3341-her could stand over [her]1739-his daughter . A little flogging for [man]2335-man and [woman]5979-woman too would be the best way of preventing such things . ”[3341-her] [Fanny]113-fanny read to [herself]113-fanny that “ it was with infinite concern the newspaper had to announce to [the world]315-the world a matrimonial _ fracas _ in [the family of [Mr. R. of [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street]6303-mr. r. of wimpole street]6302-the family of mr. r. of wimpole street ; [the beautiful Mrs. R. , whose name had not long been enrolled in the lists of [Hymen]300-hymen , and who had promised to become so brilliant a leader in the fashionable world , having quitted [[her]1739-his daughter husband]325-her husband ’s roof in company with [the well - known and captivating Mr. C.]6306-the well - known and captivating mr. c. , [the intimate friend and associate of [Mr. R.]301-mr. r.]6307-the intimate friend and associate of mr. r. , and it was not known even to [the editor of the newspaper whither [they]6309-they were gone]6308-the editor of the newspaper whither they were gone]6304-the beautiful mrs. r. , whose name had not long been enrolled in the lists of hymen , and who had promised to become so brilliant a leader in the fashionable world , having quitted her husband ’s roof in company with the well - known and captivating mr. c. , the intimate friend and associate of mr. r. , and it was not known even to the editor of the newspaper whither they were gone . ”[113-fanny] “ It is a mistake , [sir]4023-sir , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny instantly ; “ it must be a mistake , it can not be true ; it must mean [some other people]6311-some other people . ”[3366-she] [She]3366-she spoke from the instinctive wish of delaying shame ; [she]3366-she spoke with a resolution which sprung from despair , for [she]3366-she spoke what [she]3366-she did not , could not believe [herself]3366-she . It had been the shock of conviction as [she]3366-she read . The truth rushed on [her]3366-she ; and how [she]3366-she could have spoken at all , how [she]3366-she could even have breathed , was afterwards matter of wonder to [herself]3366-she . [Mr. Price]228-william cared too little about the report to make [her]3366-she much answer . “ It might be all a lie , ”[228-william] [he]228-william acknowledged ; “ but [so many fine ladies]6312-so many fine ladies were going to the devil nowadays that way , that there was no answering for [anybody]3668-anybody . ”[228-william] “ Indeed , [I]107-mrs. price hope it is not true , ”[107-mrs. price] said [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price plaintively ; “ it would be so very shocking ! If [I]107-mrs. price have spoken once to [Rebecca]268-rebecca about that carpet , [I]107-mrs. price am sure [I]107-mrs. price have spoke at least a dozen times ; have not [I]107-mrs. price , [Betsey]148-betsey ? And it would not be ten minutes ’ work . ”[107-mrs. price] The horror of a mind like [Fanny]113-fanny ’s , as it received the conviction of such guilt , and began to take in some part of the misery that must ensue , can hardly be described . At first , it was a sort of stupefaction ; but every moment was quickening [her]3366-she perception of the horrible evil . [She]3366-she could not doubt , [she]3366-she dared not indulge a hope , of the paragraph being false . [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s letter , which [she]3366-she had read so often as to make every line [her]3366-she own , was in frightful conformity with it . [Her]127-miss crawford eager defence of [[her]3366-she brother]451-her brother , [her]127-miss crawford hope of its being _ hushed _ _ up _ , [her]127-miss crawford evident agitation , were all of a piece with something very bad ; and if there was [a woman of character in existence , who could treat as a trifle this sin of the first magnitude , who would try to gloss it over , and desire to have it unpunished]3368-a woman of character in existence , who could treat as a trifle this sin of the first magnitude , who would try to gloss it over , and desire to have it unpunished , [she]3366-she could believe [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford to be [the woman]4587-the woman ! Now [she]3366-she could see [her]3366-she own mistake as to _ who _ were gone , or _ said _ to be gone . It was not [Mr.]3370-mr. and [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ; it was [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria and [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . [Fanny]113-fanny seemed to [herself]113-fanny never to have been shocked before . There was no possibility of rest . The evening passed without a pause of misery , the night was totally sleepless . [She]127-miss crawford passed only from feelings of sickness to shudderings of horror ; and from hot fits of fever to cold . The event was so shocking , that there were moments even when [her]3366-she heart revolted from it as impossible : when [she]3366-she thought it could not be . [A woman]644-a woman married only six months ago ; [a man professing [himself]3372-a man professing himself devoted , even _ engaged _ to another devoted , even _ engaged _ to [another]3373-another]3372-a man professing himself devoted , even _ engaged _ to another ; [that other [her]644-a woman near relation]3374-that other her near relation ; [the whole family]3375-the whole family , [both families]3376-both families connected as [they]3376-both families were by tie upon tie ; [all friends]3377-all friends , all intimate together ! It was too horrible a confusion of guilt , too gross a complication of evil , for human nature , not in a state of utter barbarism , to be capable of ! yet [her]3366-she judgment told [her]3366-she it was so . _ [His]133-mr. crawford _ unsettled affections , wavering with [his]133-mr. crawford vanity , _ [Maria]126-maria ’s _ decided attachment , and no sufficient principle on either side , gave it possibility : [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s letter stampt it a fact . What would be the consequence ? Whom would it not injure ? Whose views might it not affect ? Whose peace would it not cut up for ever ? [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , [herself]127-miss crawford , [Edmund]108-edmund ; but it was dangerous , perhaps , to tread such ground . [She]3366-she confined [herself]3366-she , or tried to confine [herself]3366-she , to the simple , indubitable family misery which must envelop all , if it were indeed a matter of certified guilt and public exposure . [The mother]3960-the mother ’s sufferings , [the father]1154-the father ’s ; there [she]3366-she paused . [Julia]112-julia ’s , [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s , [Edmund]108-edmund ’s ; there a yet longer pause . [They]3380-they were [the two on whom it would fall most horribly]3381-the two on whom it would fall most horribly . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s parental solicitude and high sense of honour and decorum , [Edmund]108-edmund ’s upright principles , unsuspicious temper , and genuine strength of feeling , made [her]3366-she think it scarcely possible for [them]3380-they to support life and reason under such disgrace ; and it appeared to [her]3366-she that , as far as [this world]3853-this world alone was concerned , the greatest blessing to every one of kindred with [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria would be instant annihilation . Nothing happened the next day , or the next , to weaken [her]3366-she terrors . Two posts came in , and brought no refutation , public or private . There was no second letter to explain away the first from [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ; there was no intelligence from [Mansfield]130-mansfield , though it was now full time for [her]3366-she to hear again from [[her]3366-she aunt]463-her aunt . This was an evil omen . [She]3366-she had , indeed , scarcely the shadow of a hope to soothe [her]3366-she mind , and was reduced to so low and wan and trembling a condition , as [no mother]3384-no mother , not unkind , except [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price could have overlooked , when the third day did bring the sickening knock , and a letter was again put into [her]3366-she hands . It bore the [London]6-london postmark , and came from [Edmund]108-edmund . “ [Dear Fanny,—You]302-dear fanny,—you know [our]6314-we present wretchedness . May [God]291-god support [you]302-dear fanny,—you under [your]302-dear fanny,—you share ! [We]6314-we have been [here]3798-here two days , but there is nothing to be done . [They]6316-they can not be traced . [You]302-dear fanny,—you may not have heard of the last blow — [Julia]112-julia ’s elopement ; [she]112-julia is gone to [Scotland]97-scotland with [Yates]174-mr. yates . [She]112-julia left [London]6-london a few hours before [we]6314-we entered [it]6-london . At any other time this would have been felt dreadfully . Now it seems nothing ; yet it is an heavy aggravation . [[My]108-edmund father]3762-my father is not overpowered . More can not be hoped . [He]3762-my father is still able to think and act ; and [I]108-edmund write , by [his]3762-my father desire , to propose [your]302-dear fanny,—you returning [home]367-home . [He]3762-my father is anxious to get [you]302-dear fanny,—you there for [[my]108-edmund mother]3827-my mother ’s sake . [I]108-edmund shall be at [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth the morning after [you]302-dear fanny,—you receive this , and hope to find [you]302-dear fanny,—you ready to set off for [Mansfield]3-mansfield . [[My]108-edmund father]3762-my father wishes [you]302-dear fanny,—you to invite [Susan]264-susan to go with [you]302-dear fanny,—you for a few months . Settle it as [you]302-dear fanny,—you like ; say what is proper ; [I]108-edmund am sure [you]302-dear fanny,—you will feel such an instance of [his]3762-my father kindness at such a moment ! Do justice to [his]3762-my father meaning , however [I]108-edmund may confuse it . [You]302-dear fanny,—you may imagine something of [my]108-edmund present state . There is no end of the evil let loose upon [us]6321-us . [You]302-dear fanny,—you will see [me]108-edmund early by the mail.—Yours , etc . ”[108-edmund] Never had [Fanny]113-fanny more wanted a cordial . Never had [she]3385-she felt such a one as this letter contained . To - morrow ! to leave [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth to - morrow ! [She]3385-she was , [she]3385-she felt [she]3385-she was , in the greatest danger of being exquisitely happy , while so many were miserable . The evil which brought such good to [her]3385-she ! [She]3385-she dreaded lest [she]3385-she should learn to be insensible of it . To be going so soon , sent for so kindly , sent for as a comfort , and with leave to take [Susan]264-susan , was altogether such a combination of blessings as set [her]3385-she heart in a glow , and for a time seemed to distance every pain , and make [her]3385-she incapable of suitably sharing the distress even of those whose distress [she]3385-she thought of most . [Julia]112-julia ’s elopement could affect [her]112-julia comparatively but little ; [she]112-julia was amazed and shocked ; but it could not occupy [her]112-julia , could not dwell on [her]112-julia mind . [She]112-julia was obliged to call [herself]112-julia to think of it , and acknowledge it to be terrible and grievous , or it was escaping [her]112-julia , in the midst of all the agitating pressing joyful cares attending this summons to [herself]112-julia . There is nothing like employment , active indispensable employment , for relieving sorrow . Employment , even melancholy , may dispel melancholy , and [her]112-julia occupations were hopeful . [She]112-julia had so much to do , that not even the horrible story of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ( now fixed to the last point of certainty ) , could affect [her]112-julia as it had done before . [She]112-julia had not time to be miserable . Within twenty - four hours [she]112-julia was hoping to be gone ; [[her]112-julia father]667-her father and [mother]3977-mother must be spoken to , [Susan]264-susan prepared , everything got ready . Business followed business ; the day was hardly long enough . The happiness [she]112-julia was imparting , too , happiness very little alloyed by the black communication which must briefly precede it — the joyful consent of [[her]112-julia father]667-her father and [mother]3977-mother to [Susan]264-susan ’s going with [her]112-julia — the general satisfaction with which the going of both seemed regarded , and the ecstasy of [Susan]264-susan [herself]264-susan , was all serving to support [her]264-susan spirits . The affliction of [the Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams was little felt in [the family]3724-the family . [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price talked of [[her]107-mrs. price poor sister]348-her poor sister for a few minutes , but how to find anything to hold [Susan]264-susan ’s clothes , because [Rebecca]268-rebecca took away all the boxes and spoilt them , was much more in [her]268-rebecca thoughts : and as for [Susan]264-susan , now unexpectedly gratified in the first wish of [her]268-rebecca heart , and knowing nothing personally of [those who had sinned]3392-those who had sinned , or of [those who were sorrowing]3393-those who were sorrowing — if [she]268-rebecca could help rejoicing from beginning to end , it was as much as ought to be expected from human virtue at fourteen . As nothing was really left for the decision of [Mrs. Price]107-mrs. price , or the good offices of [Rebecca]268-rebecca , everything was rationally and duly accomplished , and [the girls]3717-the girls were ready for the morrow . The advantage of much sleep to prepare [them]3717-the girls for [their]3717-the girls journey was impossible . [The cousin who was travelling towards [them]3717-the girls]3395-the cousin who was travelling towards them could hardly have less than visited [their]3717-the girls agitated spirits — one all happiness , the other all varying and indescribable perturbation . By eight in the morning [Edmund]108-edmund was in [the house]427-the house . [The girls]3717-the girls heard [his]108-edmund entrance from above , and [Fanny]113-fanny went down . The idea of immediately seeing [him]108-edmund , with the knowledge of what [he]108-edmund must be suffering , brought back all [her]268-rebecca own first feelings . [He]108-edmund so near [her]268-rebecca , and in misery . [She]268-rebecca was ready to sink as [she]268-rebecca entered [the parlour]6021-the parlour . [He]108-edmund was alone , and met [her]268-rebecca instantly ; and [she]268-rebecca found [herself]268-rebecca pressed to [his]108-edmund heart with only these words , just articulate , “ [[My]268-rebecca [Fanny]113-fanny]5625-my fanny , [[my]268-rebecca only sister]6323-my only sister ; [my]268-rebecca only comfort now ! ”[268-rebecca] [She]268-rebecca could say nothing ; nor for some minutes could [he]108-edmund say more . [He]108-edmund turned away to recover [himself]108-edmund , and when [he]108-edmund spoke again , though [his]108-edmund voice still faltered , [his]108-edmund manner shewed the wish of self - command , and the resolution of avoiding any farther allusion . “ Have [you]113-fanny breakfasted ? When shall [you]113-fanny be ready ? Does [Susan]264-susan go ? ”[108-edmund] were questions following [each other]681-each other rapidly . [His]108-edmund great object was to be off as soon as possible . When [Mansfield]130-mansfield was considered , time was precious ; and the state of [his]108-edmund own mind made [him]108-edmund find relief only in motion . It was settled that [he]108-edmund should order [the carriage]969-the carriage to the door in half an hour . [Fanny]113-fanny answered for [their]3401-their having breakfasted and being quite ready in half an hour . [He]108-edmund had already ate , and declined staying for [their]3401-their meal . [He]108-edmund would walk round [the ramparts]2928-the ramparts , and join [them]3401-their with [the carriage]969-the carriage . [He]108-edmund was gone again ; glad to get away even from [Fanny]113-fanny . [He]108-edmund looked very ill ; evidently suffering under violent emotions , which [he]108-edmund was determined to suppress . [She]3404-her knew it must be so , but it was terrible to [her]3404-her . [The carriage]969-the carriage came ; and [he]108-edmund entered [the house]427-the house again at the same moment , just in time to spend a few minutes with [the family]3724-the family , and be [a witness]3408-a witness — but that [he]108-edmund saw nothing — of the tranquil manner in which [the daughters]402-the daughters were parted with , and just in time to prevent [their]402-the daughters sitting down to the breakfast - table , which , by dint of much unusual activity , was quite and completely ready as [the carriage]969-the carriage drove from the door . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s last meal in [[[her]3404-her father]667-her father ’s house]2689-her father ’s house was in character with [her]3404-her first : [she]3404-her was dismissed from it as hospitably as [she]3404-her had been welcomed . How [her]3404-her heart swelled with joy and gratitude as [she]3404-her passed the barriers of [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , and how [Susan]264-susan ’s face wore its broadest smiles , may be easily conceived . Sitting forwards , however , and screened by [her]3404-her bonnet , those smiles were unseen . The journey was likely to be a silent one . [Edmund]108-edmund ’s deep sighs often reached [Fanny]113-fanny . Had [he]108-edmund been alone with [her]3404-her , [his]108-edmund heart must have opened in spite of every resolution ; but [Susan]264-susan ’s presence drove [him]108-edmund quite into [himself]108-edmund , and [his]108-edmund attempts to talk on indifferent subjects could never be long supported . [Fanny]113-fanny watched [him]108-edmund with never - failing solicitude , and sometimes catching [his]108-edmund eye , revived an affectionate smile , which comforted [her]3404-her ; but the first day ’s journey passed without [her]3404-her hearing a word from [him]108-edmund on the subjects that were weighing [him]108-edmund down . The next morning produced a little more . Just before [their]3413-they setting out from [Oxford]39-oxford , while [Susan]264-susan was stationed at a window , in eager observation of the departure of [a large family]3414-a large family from [the inn]3415-the inn , [the other two]1143-the other two were standing by the fire ; and [Edmund]108-edmund , particularly struck by the alteration in [Fanny]113-fanny ’s looks , and from [his]108-edmund ignorance of the daily evils of [[[her]3404-her father]667-her father ’s house]2689-her father ’s house , attributing an undue share of the change , attributing _ all _ to the recent event , took [her]3404-her hand , and said in a low , but very expressive tone , “ No wonder — [you]3404-her must feel it — [you]3404-her must suffer . How [a man who had once loved]6324-a man who had once loved , could desert [you]3404-her ! But _ yours_—your regard was new compared with —— [Fanny]113-fanny , think of _ [me]3404-her _ ! ”[3404-her] The first division of [their]3413-they journey occupied a long day , and brought [them]3413-they , almost knocked up , to [Oxford]39-oxford ; but the second was over at a much earlier hour . [They]3413-they were in [the environs of [Mansfield]3-mansfield]3419-the environs of mansfield long before the usual dinner - time , and as [they]3413-they approached [the beloved place]3420-the beloved place , the hearts of [both sisters]4894-both sisters sank a little . [Fanny]113-fanny began to dread the meeting with [[her]3404-her aunts]624-her aunts and [Tom]101-sir thomas , under so dreadful a humiliation ; and [Susan]264-susan to feel with some anxiety , that all [her]3404-her best manners , all [her]3404-her lately acquired knowledge of what was practised [here]3798-here , was on the point of being called into action . Visions of good and ill breeding , of old vulgarisms and new gentilities , were before [her]3404-her ; and [she]3404-her was meditating much upon silver forks , napkins , and finger - glasses . [Fanny]113-fanny had been everywhere awake to the difference of [the country]493-the country since February ; but when [they]3413-they entered [the Park]3753-the park [her]3404-her perceptions and [her]3404-her pleasures were of the keenest sort . It was three months , full three months , since [her]3404-her quitting it , and the change was from winter to summer . [Her]3404-her eye fell everywhere on lawns and [plantations of the freshest green]3426-plantations of the freshest green ; and the trees , though not fully clothed , were in that delightful state when farther beauty is known to be at hand , and when , while much is actually given to the sight , more yet remains for the imagination . [Her]3404-her enjoyment , however , was for [herself]3404-her alone . [Edmund]108-edmund could not share it . [She]3404-her looked at [him]108-edmund , but [he]108-edmund was leaning back , sunk in a deeper gloom than ever , and with eyes closed , as if the view of cheerfulness oppressed [him]108-edmund , and the lovely scenes of [home]367-home must be shut out . It made [her]3404-her melancholy again ; and the knowledge of what must be enduring [there]3696-there , invested even [the house]427-the house , modern , airy , and well situated as [it]427-the house was , with a melancholy aspect . By one of [the suffering party within]3430-the suffering party within [they]3413-they were expected with such impatience as [she]3404-her had never known before . [Fanny]113-fanny had scarcely passed [the solemn - looking servants]3431-the solemn - looking servants , when [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram came from [the drawing - room]420-the drawing - room to meet [her]3404-her ; came with no indolent step ; and falling on [her]3404-her neck , said , “ [Dear Fanny]113-fanny ! now [I]106-lady bertram shall be comfortable . ”[106-lady bertram] CHAPTER XLVII It had been a miserable party , each of the three believing [themselves]3413-they most miserable . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , however , as most attached to [Maria]126-maria , was really [the greatest sufferer]5532-the greatest sufferer . [Maria]126-maria was [her]105-mrs. norris first favourite , the dearest of all ; the match had been [her]126-maria own contriving , as [she]126-maria had been wo nt with such pride of heart to feel and say , and this conclusion of it almost overpowered [her]126-maria . [She]126-maria was [an altered creature]3434-an altered creature , quieted , stupefied , indifferent to everything that passed . The being left with [[her]126-maria sister]331-her sister and nephew , and [all [the house]427-the house under [her]126-maria care]3436-all the house under her care , had been an advantage entirely thrown away ; [she]126-maria had been unable to direct or dictate , or even fancy [herself]126-maria useful . When really touched by affliction , [her]126-maria active powers had been all benumbed ; and neither [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram nor [Tom]101-sir thomas had received from [her]126-maria the smallest support or attempt at support . [She]126-maria had done no more for [them]3438-they than [they]3438-they had done for [each other]681-each other . [They]3438-they had been all solitary , helpless , and forlorn alike ; and now the arrival of [the others]347-the others only established [her]126-maria superiority in wretchedness . [[Her]126-maria companions]3441-her companions were relieved , but there was no good for _ [her]126-maria _ . [Edmund]108-edmund was almost as welcome to [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother as [Fanny]113-fanny to [[her]126-maria aunt]463-her aunt ; but [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , instead of having comfort from either , was but the more irritated by the sight of [the person whom , in the blindness of [her]126-maria anger , [she]126-maria could have charged as [the daemon of the piece]3445-the daemon of the piece]3444-the person whom , in the blindness of her anger , she could have charged as the daemon of the piece . Had [Fanny]113-fanny accepted [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford this could not have happened . [Susan]264-susan too was a grievance . [She]264-susan had not spirits to notice [her]264-susan in more than a few repulsive looks , but [she]264-susan felt [her]264-susan as [a spy]3446-a spy , and [an intruder]3447-an intruder , and [an indigent niece]3448-an indigent niece , and everything most odious . By [[her]264-susan other aunt]3449-her other aunt , [Susan]264-susan was received with quiet kindness . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram could not give [her]264-susan much time , or many words , but [she]106-lady bertram felt [her]264-susan , as [[Fanny]113-fanny ’s sister]3450-fanny ’s sister , to have a claim at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , and was ready to kiss and like [her]264-susan ; and [Susan]264-susan was more than satisfied , for [she]264-susan came perfectly aware that nothing but ill - humour was to be expected from [aunt Norris]105-mrs. norris ; and was so provided with happiness , so strong in that best of blessings , an escape from many certain evils , that [she]264-susan could have stood against a great deal more indifference than [she]264-susan met with from [the others]347-the others . [She]264-susan was now left a good deal to [herself]264-susan , to get acquainted with [the house]427-the house and [grounds]3453-grounds as [she]264-susan could , and spent [her]264-susan days very happily in so doing , while [those who might otherwise have attended to [her]264-susan]3454-those who might otherwise have attended to her were shut up , or wholly occupied each with the person quite dependent on [them]3454-those who might otherwise have attended to her , at this time , for everything like comfort ; [Edmund]108-edmund trying to bury [his]108-edmund own feelings in exertions for the relief of [[his]108-edmund brother]805-his brother ’s , and [Fanny]113-fanny devoted to [[her]264-susan aunt]463-her aunt [Bertram]106-lady bertram , returning to [every former office]3457-every former office with more than former zeal , and thinking [she]264-susan could never do enough for one who seemed so much to want [her]264-susan . To talk over the dreadful business with [Fanny]113-fanny , talk and lament , was all [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s consolation . To be listened to and borne with , and hear the voice of kindness and sympathy in return , was everything that could be done for [her]264-susan . To be otherwise comforted was out of the question . The case admitted of no comfort . [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram did not think deeply , but , guided by [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [she]106-lady bertram thought justly on all important points ; and [she]106-lady bertram saw , therefore , in all its enormity , what had happened , and neither endeavoured [herself]106-lady bertram , nor required [Fanny]113-fanny to advise [her]106-lady bertram , to think little of guilt and infamy . [Her]106-lady bertram affections were not acute , nor was [her]106-lady bertram mind tenacious . After a time , [Fanny]113-fanny found it not impossible to direct [her]264-susan thoughts to other subjects , and revive some interest in the usual occupations ; but whenever [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram _ was _ fixed on the event , [she]264-susan could see it only in one light , as comprehending the loss of [a daughter]2535-a daughter , and a disgrace never to be wiped off . [Fanny]113-fanny learnt from [her]106-lady bertram all the particulars which had yet transpired . [[Her]264-susan aunt]463-her aunt was [no very methodical narrator]3460-no very methodical narrator , but with the help of some letters to and from [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , and what [she]264-susan already knew [herself]264-susan , and could reasonably combine , [she]264-susan was soon able to understand quite as much as [she]264-susan wished of the circumstances attending the story . [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria had gone , for the Easter holidays , to [Twickenham]30-twickenham , with [a family whom [she]126-maria had just grown intimate with]3461-a family whom she had just grown intimate with : [a family of lively , agreeable manners , and probably of morals and discretion to suit]3462-a family of lively , agreeable manners , and probably of morals and discretion to suit , for to _ [[their]3461-a family whom she had just grown intimate with _ house]3463-their _ house [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford had constant access at all times . [His]133-mr. crawford having been in [the same neighbourhood]3464-the same neighbourhood [Fanny]113-fanny already knew . [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had been gone at this time to [Bath]56-bath , to pass a few days with [[his]113-fanny mother]629-his mother , and bring [her]629-his mother back to [town]3698-town , and [Maria]126-maria was with [these friends]3467-these friends without any restraint , without even [Julia]112-julia ; for [Julia]112-julia had removed from [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street two or three weeks before , on a visit to [some relations of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas]3468-some relations of sir thomas ; a removal which [[her]112-julia father]667-her father and [mother]3977-mother were now disposed to attribute to some view of convenience on [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ’s account . Very soon after [the Rushworths]217-the rushworths ’ return to [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas had received a letter from [an old and most particular friend in [London]6-london]3471-an old and most particular friend in london , who hearing and witnessing a good deal to alarm [him]101-sir thomas in that quarter , wrote to recommend [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s coming to [London]6-london [himself]101-sir thomas , and using [his]101-sir thomas influence with [[his]101-sir thomas daughter]1739-his daughter to put an end to the intimacy which was already exposing [her]1739-his daughter to unpleasant remarks , and evidently making [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny uneasy . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was preparing to act upon this letter , without communicating its contents to [any creature at [Mansfield]3-mansfield]3473-any creature at mansfield , when it was followed by another , sent express from [the same friend]6185-the same friend , to break to [him]101-sir thomas the almost desperate situation in which affairs then stood with [the young people]391-the young people . [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria had left [[[her]126-maria husband]325-her husband ’s house]3477-her husband ’s house : [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had been in great anger and distress to _ [him]325-her husband _ ( [Mr. Harding]303-mr. harding ) for [his]303-mr. harding advice ; [Mr. Harding]303-mr. harding feared there had been _ at _ _ least _ very flagrant indiscretion . [The maidservant of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria]3478-the maidservant of mrs. rushworth , [senior]3479-senior , threatened alarmingly . [He]3478-the maidservant of mrs. rushworth was doing all in [his]3478-the maidservant of mrs. rushworth power to quiet everything , with the hope of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ’s return , but was so much counteracted in [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street by the influence of [[Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s mother]3480-mr. rushworth ’s mother , that the worst consequences might be apprehended . This dreadful communication could not be kept from [the rest of [the family]3724-the family]618-the rest of the family . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas set off , [Edmund]108-edmund would go with [him]101-sir thomas , and [the others]347-the others had been left in a state of wretchedness , inferior only to what followed the receipt of the next letters from [London]6-london . Everything was by that time public beyond a hope . [The servant of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria]3484-the servant of mrs. rushworth , [the mother]3960-the mother , had exposure in [her]3960-the mother power , and supported by [[her]3960-the mother mistress]3486-her mistress , was not to be silenced . [The two ladies]1504-the two ladies , even in the short time [they]1504-the two ladies had been together , had disagreed ; and the bitterness of [the elder]529-the elder against [[her]3960-the mother daughter - in - law]3489-her daughter - in - law might perhaps arise almost as much from the personal disrespect with which [she]3960-the mother had [herself]3960-the mother been treated as from sensibility for [[her]3960-the mother son]637-her son . However that might be , [she]3960-the mother was unmanageable . But had [she]3960-the mother been less obstinate , or of less weight with [[her]3960-the mother son]637-her son , who was always guided by [the last speaker]3492-the last speaker , by [the person who could get hold of and shut [him]637-her son up]3493-the person who could get hold of and shut him up , the case would still have been hopeless , for [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria did not appear again , and there was every reason to conclude [her]3960-the mother to be concealed somewhere with [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford , who had quitted [[[his]133-mr. crawford uncle]526-his uncle ’s house]3495-his uncle ’s house , as for a journey , on the very day of [her]3960-the mother absenting [herself]3960-the mother . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , however , remained yet a little longer in [town]3698-town , in the hope of discovering and snatching [her]3960-the mother from farther vice , though all was lost on the side of character . _ [His]101-sir thomas _ present state [Fanny]113-fanny could hardly bear to think of . There was but [one of [[his]101-sir thomas children]1549-his children who was not at this time a source of misery to [him]101-sir thomas]3497-one of his children who was not at this time a source of misery to him . [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s complaints had been greatly heightened by the shock of [[his]101-sir thomas sister]511-his sister ’s conduct , and [his]101-sir thomas recovery so much thrown back by it , that even [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram had been struck by the difference , and all [her]106-lady bertram alarms were regularly sent off to [[her]106-lady bertram husband]325-her husband ; and [Julia]112-julia ’s elopement , the additional blow which had met [him]101-sir thomas on [his]101-sir thomas arrival in [London]6-london , though its force had been deadened at the moment , must , [she]3960-the mother knew , be sorely felt . [She]3960-the mother saw that it was . [His]101-sir thomas letters expressed how much [he]101-sir thomas deplored it . Under any circumstances it would have been an unwelcome alliance ; but to have it so clandestinely formed , and such a period chosen for its completion , placed [Julia]112-julia ’s feelings in a most unfavourable light , and severely aggravated the folly of [her]112-julia choice . [He]101-sir thomas called it a bad thing , done in the worst manner , and at the worst time ; and though [Julia]112-julia was yet as more pardonable than [Maria]126-maria as folly than vice , [he]101-sir thomas could not but regard the step [she]112-julia had taken as opening the worst probabilities of a conclusion hereafter like [[her]112-julia sister]331-her sister ’s . Such was [his]101-sir thomas opinion of the set into which [she]112-julia had thrown [herself]112-julia . [Fanny]113-fanny felt for [him]101-sir thomas most acutely . [He]101-sir thomas could have no comfort but in [Edmund]108-edmund . [Every other child]3502-every other child must be racking [his]101-sir thomas heart . [His]101-sir thomas displeasure against [herself]113-fanny [she]112-julia trusted , reasoning differently from [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , would now be done away . _ [She]112-julia _ should be justified . [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford would have fully acquitted [her]112-julia conduct in refusing [him]101-sir thomas ; but this , though most material to [herself]112-julia , would be poor consolation to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas . [[Her]112-julia uncle]312-her uncle ’s displeasure was terrible to [her]112-julia ; but what could [her]112-julia justification or [her]112-julia gratitude and attachment do for [him]101-sir thomas ? [His]101-sir thomas stay must be on [Edmund]108-edmund alone . [She]112-julia was mistaken , however , in supposing that [Edmund]108-edmund gave [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father no present pain . It was of a much less poignant nature than what [the others]347-the others excited ; but [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas was considering [his]101-sir thomas happiness as very deeply involved in the offence of [[his]101-sir thomas sister]511-his sister and [friend]444-friend ; cut off by it , as [he]101-sir thomas must be , from [the woman whom [he]101-sir thomas [had been pursuing with undoubted attachment and strong probability of success]3509-had been pursuing with undoubted attachment and strong probability of success]3508-the woman whom he had been pursuing with undoubted attachment and strong probability of success ; and who , in everything but [this despicable brother]3510-this despicable brother , would have been so eligible a connexion . [He]101-sir thomas was aware of what [Edmund]108-edmund must be suffering on [his]108-edmund own behalf , in addition to all the rest , when [they]3511-they were in [town]3698-town : [he]101-sir thomas had seen or conjectured [his]101-sir thomas feelings ; and , having reason to think that one interview with [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford had taken place , from which [Edmund]108-edmund derived only increased distress , had been as anxious on that account as on [others]361-others to get [him]108-edmund out of [town]3698-town , and had engaged [him]108-edmund in taking [Fanny]113-fanny home to [[her]3515-her aunt]463-her aunt , with a view to [his]108-edmund relief and benefit , no less than [theirs]3511-they . [Fanny]113-fanny was not in the secret of [[her]3515-her uncle]312-her uncle ’s feelings , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas not in the secret of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s character .
