Had [he]108-edmund been privy to [her]127-miss crawford conversation with [[his]108-edmund son]581-his son , [he]108-edmund would not have wished [her]3515-her to belong to [him]108-edmund , though [her]3515-her twenty thousand pounds had been forty . That [Edmund]108-edmund must be for ever divided from [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford did not admit of a doubt with [Fanny]113-fanny ; and yet , till [she]127-miss crawford knew that [he]108-edmund felt the same , [her]127-miss crawford own conviction was insufficient . [She]127-miss crawford thought [he]108-edmund did , but [she]127-miss crawford wanted to be assured of it . If [he]108-edmund would now speak to [her]127-miss crawford with the unreserve which had sometimes been too much for [her]127-miss crawford before , it would be most consoling ; but _ that _ [she]127-miss crawford found was not to be . [She]127-miss crawford seldom saw [him]108-edmund : never alone . [He]108-edmund probably avoided being alone with [her]127-miss crawford . What was to be inferred ? That [his]108-edmund judgment submitted to all [his]108-edmund own peculiar and bitter share of this family affliction , but that it was too keenly felt to be a subject of the slightest communication . This must be [his]108-edmund state . [He]108-edmund yielded , but it was with agonies which did not admit of speech . Long , long would it be ere [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford ’s name passed [his]108-edmund lips again , or [she]127-miss crawford could hope for a renewal of such confidential intercourse as had been . It _ was _ long . [They]3519-they reached [Mansfield]130-mansfield on Thursday , and it was not till Sunday evening that [Edmund]108-edmund began to talk to [her]127-miss crawford on the subject . Sitting with [her]127-miss crawford on Sunday evening — a wet Sunday evening — the very time of all others when , if [a friend]456-a friend is at hand , the heart must be opened , and everything told ; [no one else]2702-no one else in [the room]412-the room , except [[his]108-edmund mother]629-his mother , who , after hearing an affecting sermon , had cried [herself]629-his mother to sleep , it was impossible not to speak ; and so , with the usual beginnings , hardly to be traced as to what came first , and the usual declaration that if [she]127-miss crawford would listen to [him]108-edmund for a few minutes , [he]108-edmund should be very brief , and certainly never tax [her]127-miss crawford kindness in the same way again ; [she]127-miss crawford need not fear a repetition ; it would be a subject prohibited entirely : [he]108-edmund entered upon the luxury of relating circumstances and sensations of the first interest to [himself]108-edmund , to one of whose affectionate sympathy [he]108-edmund was quite convinced . How [Fanny]113-fanny listened , with what curiosity and concern , what pain and what delight , how the agitation of [his]108-edmund voice was watched , and how carefully [her]127-miss crawford own eyes were fixed on any object but [himself]108-edmund , may be imagined . The opening was alarming . [He]108-edmund had seen [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford . [He]108-edmund had been invited to see [her]127-miss crawford . [He]108-edmund had received a note from [Lady Stornaway]255-lady stornaway to beg [him]108-edmund to call ; and regarding it as what was meant to be the last , last interview of friendship , and investing [her]127-miss crawford with all the feelings of shame and wretchedness which [[Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s sister]2653-crawford ’s sister ought to have known , [he]108-edmund had gone to [her]127-miss crawford in such a state of mind , so softened , so devoted , as made it for a few moments impossible to [Fanny]113-fanny ’s fears that it should be the last . But as [he]108-edmund proceeded in [his]108-edmund story , these fears were over . [She]127-miss crawford had met [him]108-edmund , [he]108-edmund said , with a serious — certainly a serious — even an agitated air ; but before [he]108-edmund had been able to speak one intelligible sentence , [she]127-miss crawford had introduced the subject in a manner which [he]108-edmund owned had shocked [him]108-edmund . “ ‘ [I]127-miss crawford heard [you]108-edmund were in [town]3698-town , ’ said [she]127-miss crawford ; ‘ [I]127-miss crawford wanted to see [you]108-edmund . Let [us]6326-us talk over this sad business . What can equal the folly of [our]6326-us two relations ? ’ [I]127-miss crawford could not answer , but [I]127-miss crawford believe [my]127-miss crawford looks spoke . [She]127-miss crawford felt reproved . Sometimes how quick to feel ! With a graver look and voice [she]127-miss crawford then added , ‘ [I]127-miss crawford do not mean to defend [Henry]131-henry at [[your]108-edmund sister]4444-your sister ’s expense . ’ So [she]127-miss crawford began , but how [she]127-miss crawford went on , [Fanny]113-fanny , is not fit , is hardly fit to be repeated to [you]113-fanny . [I]127-miss crawford can not recall all [her]127-miss crawford words . [I]127-miss crawford would not dwell upon them if [I]127-miss crawford could . [Their]6328-their substance was great anger at the _ folly _ of each . [She]127-miss crawford reprobated [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother ’s folly in being drawn on by [a woman whom [he]451-her brother had never cared for]6330-a woman whom he had never cared for , to do what must lose [him]451-her brother [the woman [he]451-her brother adored]6331-the woman he adored ; but still more the folly of poor [Maria]126-maria , in sacrificing such a situation , plunging into such difficulties , under the idea of being really loved by [a man who had long ago made [his]451-her brother indifference clear]6332-a man who had long ago made his indifference clear . Guess what [I]127-miss crawford must have felt . To hear the woman whom — no harsher name than folly given ! So voluntarily , so freely , so coolly to canvass it ! No reluctance , no horror , no feminine , shall [I]127-miss crawford say , no modest loathings ? This is what [the world]315-the world does . For where , [Fanny]113-fanny , shall [we]6334-we find [a woman whom nature had so richly endowed]6335-a woman whom nature had so richly endowed ? Spoilt , spoilt ! ”[127-miss crawford] After a little reflection , [he]3525-he went on with a sort of desperate calmness . “ [I]3525-he will tell [you]113-fanny everything , and then have done for ever . [She]127-miss crawford saw it only as folly , and that folly stamped only by exposure . The want of common discretion , of caution : [his]3525-he going down to [Richmond]96-richmond for the whole time of [her]127-miss crawford being at [Twickenham]30-twickenham ; [her]127-miss crawford putting [herself]127-miss crawford in the power of [a servant]4078-a servant ; it was the detection , in short — oh , [Fanny]113-fanny ! it was the detection , not the offence , which [she]127-miss crawford reprobated . It was the imprudence which had brought things to extremity , and obliged [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother to give up every dearer plan in order to fly with [her]127-miss crawford . ”[3525-he] [He]3525-he stopt . “ And what , ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny ( believing [herself]113-fanny required to speak ) , “ what could [you]3525-he say ? ”[113-fanny] “ Nothing , nothing to be understood . [I]3525-he was like [a man]4410-a man stunned . [She]127-miss crawford went on , began to talk of [you]3525-he ; yes , then [she]127-miss crawford began to talk of [you]3525-he , regretting , as well [she]127-miss crawford might , the loss of such a—. There [she]127-miss crawford spoke very rationally . But [she]127-miss crawford has always done justice to [you]3525-he . ‘ [He]3525-he has thrown away , ’ said [she]127-miss crawford , ‘ [such a woman as [he]3525-he]6339-such a woman as he will never see again . [She]127-miss crawford would have fixed [him]3525-he ; [she]127-miss crawford would have made [him]3525-he happy for ever . ’ [[My]3525-he dearest]5134-my dearest [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]3525-he am giving [you]113-fanny , [I]3525-he hope , more pleasure than pain by this retrospect of what might have been — but what never can be now . [You]113-fanny do not wish [me]3525-he to be silent ? If [you]113-fanny do , give [me]3525-he but a look , a word , and [I]3525-he have done . ”[3525-he] No look or word was given . “ Thank [God]291-god , ”[3526-i] said [he]3526-i . “ [We]6341-we were all disposed to wonder , but it seems to have been the merciful appointment of [Providence]304-providence that the heart which knew no guile should not suffer . [She]127-miss crawford spoke of [you]113-fanny with high praise and warm affection ; yet , even here , there was alloy , a dash of evil ; for in the midst of it [she]127-miss crawford could exclaim , ‘ Why would not [she]127-miss crawford have [him]3525-he ? It is all [her]127-miss crawford fault . [Simple girl]6342-simple girl ! [I]3526-i shall never forgive [her]127-miss crawford . Had [she]127-miss crawford accepted [him]3525-he as [she]127-miss crawford ought , [they]6343-they might now have been on the point of marriage , and [Henry]131-henry would have been too happy and too busy to want any other object . [He]3525-he would have taken no pains to be on terms with [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria again . It would have all ended in a regular standing flirtation , in yearly meetings at [Sotherton]27-sotherton and [Everingham]31-everingham . ’ Could [you]113-fanny have believed it possible ? But the charm is broken . [My]3526-i eyes are opened . ”[3526-i] “ Cruel ! ”[113-fanny] said [Fanny]113-fanny , “ quite cruel . At such a moment to give way to gaiety , to speak with lightness , and to [you]113-fanny ! Absolute cruelty . ”[113-fanny] “ Cruelty , do [you]113-fanny call it ? [We]6343-they differ there . No , [hers]127-miss crawford is not a cruel nature . [I]3526-i do not consider [her]127-miss crawford as meaning to wound [my]3526-i feelings . The evil lies yet deeper : in [her]127-miss crawford total ignorance , unsuspiciousness of there being such feelings ; in a perversion of mind which made it natural to [her]127-miss crawford to treat the subject as [she]127-miss crawford did . [She]127-miss crawford was speaking only as [she]127-miss crawford had been used to hear [others]361-others speak , as [she]127-miss crawford imagined [everybody else]458-everybody else would speak . [Hers]127-miss crawford are not faults of temper . [She]127-miss crawford would not voluntarily give unnecessary pain to [any one]3817-any one , and though [I]3526-i may deceive [myself]3526-i , [I]3526-i can not but think that for [me]3526-i , for [my]3526-i feelings , [she]127-miss crawford would—. [Hers]127-miss crawford are faults of principle , [Fanny]113-fanny ; of blunted delicacy and a corrupted , vitiated mind . Perhaps it is best for [me]3526-i , since it leaves [me]3526-i so little to regret . Not so , however . Gladly would [I]3526-i submit to all the increased pain of losing [her]127-miss crawford , rather than have to think of [her]127-miss crawford as [I]3526-i do . [I]3526-i told [her]127-miss crawford so . ”[3526-i] “ Did [you]3526-i ? ”[3526-i] “ Yes ; when [I]113-fanny left [her]127-miss crawford [I]113-fanny told [her]127-miss crawford so . ”[113-fanny] “ How long were [you]3526-i together ? ”[3526-i] “ Five - and - twenty minutes . Well , [she]127-miss crawford went on to say that what remained now to be done was to bring about a marriage between [them]3526-i . [She]127-miss crawford spoke of it , [Fanny]113-fanny , with a steadier voice than [I]3527-i can . ”[3527-i] [He]3527-i was obliged to pause more than once as [he]3527-i continued . “ ‘ [We]3526-i must persuade [Henry]131-henry to marry [her]127-miss crawford , ’ said [she]127-miss crawford ; ‘ and what with honour , and the certainty of having shut [himself]131-henry out for ever from [Fanny]113-fanny , [I]3527-i do not despair of it . [Fanny]113-fanny [he]131-henry must give up . [I]3527-i do not think that even _ [he]131-henry _ could now hope to succeed with one of [her]127-miss crawford stamp , and therefore [I]3527-i hope [we]3526-i may find no insuperable difficulty . [My]3527-i influence , which is not small shall all go that way ; and when once married , and properly supported by [[her]127-miss crawford own family]1438-her own family , [people of respectability]6348-people of respectability as [they]1438-her own family are , [she]127-miss crawford may recover [her]127-miss crawford footing in society to a certain degree . In some circles , [we]3526-i know , [she]127-miss crawford would never be admitted , but with good dinners , and large parties , there will always be those who will be glad of [her]127-miss crawford acquaintance ; and there is , undoubtedly , more liberality and candour on those points than formerly . What [I]3527-i advise is , that [[your]6349-your father]4493-your father be quiet . Do not let [him]4493-your father injure [his]4493-your father own cause by interference . Persuade [him]4493-your father to let things take their course . If by any officious exertions of [his]4493-your father , [she]127-miss crawford is induced to leave [Henry]131-henry ’s protection , there will be much less chance of [his]4493-your father marrying [her]127-miss crawford than if [she]127-miss crawford remain with [him]4493-your father . [I]3527-i know how [he]4493-your father is likely to be influenced . Let [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas trust to [his]4493-your father honour and compassion , and it may all end well ; but if [he]4493-your father get [[his]4493-your father daughter]1739-his daughter away , it will be destroying [the chief hold]6352-the chief hold . ’ ”[3527-i] After repeating this , [Edmund]108-edmund was so much affected that [Fanny]113-fanny , watching [him]108-edmund with silent , but most tender concern , was almost sorry that the subject had been entered on at all . It was long before [he]108-edmund could speak again . At last , “ Now , [Fanny]113-fanny , ”[108-edmund] said [he]108-edmund , “ [I]108-edmund shall soon have done . [I]108-edmund have told [you]113-fanny the substance of all that [she]127-miss crawford said . As soon as [I]108-edmund could speak , [I]108-edmund replied that [I]108-edmund had not supposed it possible , coming in such a state of mind into [that house]1793-that house as [I]108-edmund had done , that anything could occur to make [me]108-edmund suffer more , but that [she]127-miss crawford had been inflicting deeper wounds in almost every sentence . That though [I]108-edmund had , in the course of [our]6354-our acquaintance , been often sensible of some difference in [our]6354-our opinions , on points , too , of some moment , it had not entered [my]108-edmund imagination to conceive the difference could be such as [she]127-miss crawford had now proved it . That the manner in which [she]127-miss crawford treated the dreadful crime committed by [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother and [[my]108-edmund sister]3790-my sister ( with whom lay the greater seduction [I]108-edmund pretended not to say ) , but the manner in which [she]127-miss crawford spoke of the crime itself , giving it every reproach but the right ; considering its ill consequences only as they were to be braved or overborne by a defiance of decency and impudence in wrong ; and last of all , and above all , recommending to [us]6354-our a compliance , a compromise , an acquiescence in the continuance of the sin , on the chance of a marriage which , thinking as [I]108-edmund now thought of [[her]127-miss crawford brother]451-her brother , should rather be prevented than sought ; all this together most grievously convinced [me]108-edmund that [I]108-edmund had never understood [her]127-miss crawford before , and that , as far as related to mind , it had been the creature of [my]108-edmund own imagination , not [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , that [I]108-edmund had been too apt to dwell on for many months past . That , perhaps , it was best for [me]108-edmund ; [I]108-edmund had less to regret in sacrificing a friendship , feelings , hopes which must , at any rate , have been torn from [me]108-edmund now . And yet , that [I]108-edmund must and would confess that , could [I]108-edmund have restored [her]127-miss crawford to what [she]127-miss crawford had appeared to [me]108-edmund before , [I]108-edmund would infinitely prefer any increase of the pain of parting , for the sake of carrying with [me]108-edmund the right of tenderness and esteem . This is what [I]108-edmund said , the purport of it ; but , as [you]6358-you may imagine , not spoken so collectedly or methodically as [I]108-edmund have repeated it to [you]6358-you . [She]127-miss crawford was astonished , exceedingly astonished — more than astonished . [I]108-edmund saw [her]127-miss crawford change countenance . [She]127-miss crawford turned extremely red . [I]108-edmund imagined [I]108-edmund saw a mixture of many feelings : a great , though short struggle ; half a wish of yielding to truths , half a sense of shame , but habit , habit carried it . [She]127-miss crawford would have laughed if [she]127-miss crawford could . It was a sort of laugh , as [she]127-miss crawford answered , ‘ A pretty good lecture , upon [my]108-edmund word . Was it part of [your]108-edmund last sermon ? At this rate [you]108-edmund will soon reform [everybody]408-everybody at [Mansfield]3-mansfield and [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey ; and when [I]108-edmund hear of [you]108-edmund next , it may be as [a celebrated preacher in [some great society of Methodists]6361-some great society of methodists]6360-a celebrated preacher in some great society of methodists , or as [a missionary]6362-a missionary into foreign parts . ’ [She]127-miss crawford tried to speak carelessly , but [she]127-miss crawford was not so careless as [she]127-miss crawford wanted to appear . [I]108-edmund only said in reply , that from [my]108-edmund heart [I]108-edmund wished [her]127-miss crawford well , and earnestly hoped that [she]127-miss crawford might soon learn to think more justly , and not owe the most valuable knowledge [we]6363-we could any of [us]6363-we acquire , the knowledge of [ourselves]6363-we and of [our]6363-we duty , to the lessons of affliction , and immediately left [the room]412-the room . [I]108-edmund had gone a few steps , [Fanny]113-fanny , when [I]108-edmund heard the door open behind [me]108-edmund . ‘ [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , ’ said [she]127-miss crawford . [I]108-edmund looked back . ‘ [Mr. Bertram]108-edmund , ’ said [she]127-miss crawford , with a smile ; but it was a smile ill - suited to the conversation that had passed , a saucy playful smile , seeming to invite in order to subdue [me]108-edmund ; at least it appeared so to [me]108-edmund . [I]108-edmund resisted ; it was the impulse of the moment to resist , and still walked on . [I]108-edmund have since , sometimes , for a moment , regretted that [I]108-edmund did not go back , but [I]108-edmund know [I]108-edmund was right , and such has been the end of [our]6363-we acquaintance . And what [an acquaintance]3963-an acquaintance has it been ! How have [I]108-edmund been deceived ! Equally in [brother]6366-brother and [sister]3704-sister deceived ! [I]108-edmund thank [you]113-fanny for [your]113-fanny patience , [Fanny]113-fanny . This has been the greatest relief , and now [we]6363-we will have done . ”[108-edmund] And such was [Fanny]113-fanny ’s dependence on [his]3528-his words , that for five minutes [she]3529-she thought [they]3530-they _ had _ done . Then , however , it all came on again , or something very like it , and nothing less than [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram ’s rousing thoroughly up could really close such a conversation . Till that happened , [they]3530-they continued to talk of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford alone , and how [she]127-miss crawford had attached [him]3528-his , and how delightful nature had made [her]127-miss crawford , and how excellent [she]127-miss crawford would have been , had [she]127-miss crawford fallen into good hands earlier . [Fanny]113-fanny , now at liberty to speak openly , felt more than justified in adding to [his]3528-his knowledge of [her]127-miss crawford real character , by some hint of what share [[his]3528-his brother]805-his brother ’s state of health might be supposed to have in [her]127-miss crawford wish for a complete reconciliation . This was not an agreeable intimation . [Nature]284-nature resisted it for a while . It would have been a vast deal pleasanter to have had [her]127-miss crawford more disinterested in [her]127-miss crawford attachment ; but [his]3528-his vanity was not of a strength to fight long against reason . [He]3528-his submitted to believe that [Tom]101-sir thomas ’s illness had influenced [her]127-miss crawford , only reserving for [himself]3528-his this consoling thought , that considering the many counteractions of opposing habits , [she]127-miss crawford had certainly been _ more _ attached to [him]3528-his than could have been expected , and for [his]3528-his sake been more near doing right . [Fanny]113-fanny thought exactly the same ; and [they]3532-they were also quite agreed in [their]3532-they opinion of the lasting effect , the indelible impression , which such a disappointment must make on [his]3528-his mind . Time would undoubtedly abate somewhat of [his]3528-his sufferings , but still it was a sort of thing which [he]3528-his never could get entirely the better of ; and as to [his]3528-his ever meeting with [any other woman who could]3533-any other woman who could — it was too impossible to be named but with indignation . [Fanny]113-fanny ’s friendship was all that [he]3528-his had to cling to . CHAPTER XLVIII Let [other pens]3534-other pens dwell on guilt and misery . [I]0-i quit such odious subjects as soon as [I]0-i can , impatient to restore [everybody]408-everybody , not greatly in fault [themselves]408-everybody , to tolerable comfort , and to have done with all the rest . [[My]0-i [Fanny]113-fanny]5625-my fanny , indeed , at this very time , [I]0-i have the satisfaction of knowing , must have been happy in spite of everything . [She]5625-my fanny must have been [a happy creature]5990-a happy creature in spite of all that [she]5625-my fanny felt , or thought [she]5625-my fanny felt , for the distress of [those around [her]5625-my fanny]3538-those around her . [She]5625-my fanny had sources of delight that must force [their]3539-their way . [She]5625-my fanny was returned to [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield , [she]5625-my fanny was useful , [she]5625-my fanny was beloved ; [she]5625-my fanny was safe from [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford ; and when [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas came back [she]5625-my fanny had every proof that could be given in [his]101-sir thomas then melancholy state of spirits , of [his]101-sir thomas perfect approbation and increased regard ; and happy as all this must make [her]5625-my fanny , [she]5625-my fanny would still have been happy without any of it , for [Edmund]108-edmund was no longer [the dupe of [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford]3540-the dupe of miss crawford . It is true that [Edmund]108-edmund was very far from happy [himself]108-edmund . [He]108-edmund was suffering from disappointment and regret , grieving over what was , and wishing for what could never be . [She]5625-my fanny knew it was so , and was sorry ; but it was with a sorrow so founded on satisfaction , so tending to ease , and so much in harmony with every dearest sensation , that there are [few who might not have been glad to exchange their greatest gaiety for it]3541-few who might not have been glad to exchange their greatest gaiety for it . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [poor Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , [a parent]655-a parent , and conscious of errors in [his]101-sir thomas own conduct as [a parent]655-a parent , was the longest to suffer . [He]101-sir thomas felt that [he]101-sir thomas ought not to have allowed the marriage ; that [[his]101-sir thomas daughter]1739-his daughter ’s sentiments had been sufficiently known to [him]101-sir thomas to render [him]101-sir thomas culpable in authorising it ; that in so doing [he]101-sir thomas had sacrificed the right to the expedient , and been governed by motives of selfishness and worldly wisdom . These were reflections that required some time to soften ; but time will do almost everything ; and though little comfort arose on [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ’s side for the misery [she]126-maria had occasioned , comfort was to be found greater than [he]101-sir thomas had supposed in [[his]101-sir thomas other children]497-his other children . [Julia]112-julia ’s match became a less desperate business than [he]101-sir thomas had considered it at first . [She]112-julia was humble , and wishing to be forgiven ; and [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates , desirous of being really received into [the family]3724-the family , was disposed to look up to [him]101-sir thomas and be guided . [He]101-sir thomas was not very solid ; but there was a hope of [his]101-sir thomas becoming less trifling , of [his]101-sir thomas being at least tolerably domestic and quiet ; and at any rate , there was comfort in finding [his]101-sir thomas estate rather more , and [his]101-sir thomas debts much less , than [he]101-sir thomas had feared , and in being consulted and treated as [the friend best worth attending to]3547-the friend best worth attending to . There was comfort also in [Tom]101-sir thomas , who gradually regained [his]101-sir thomas health , without regaining the thoughtlessness and selfishness of [his]101-sir thomas previous habits . [He]101-sir thomas was the better for ever for [his]101-sir thomas illness . [He]101-sir thomas had suffered , and [he]101-sir thomas had learned to think : two advantages that [he]101-sir thomas had never known before ; and the self - reproach arising from the deplorable event in [Wimpole Street]88-wimpole street , to which [he]101-sir thomas felt [himself]101-sir thomas accessory by all the dangerous intimacy of [his]101-sir thomas unjustifiable theatre , made an impression on [his]101-sir thomas mind which , at the age of six - and - twenty , with no want of sense or [good companions]3548-good companions , was durable in its happy effects . [He]101-sir thomas became what [he]101-sir thomas ought to be : useful to [[his]101-sir thomas father]534-his father , steady and quiet , and not living merely for [himself]101-sir thomas . Here was comfort indeed ! and quite as soon as [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas could place dependence on such sources of good , [Edmund]108-edmund was contributing to [[his]108-edmund father]534-his father ’s ease by improvement in the only point in which [he]101-sir thomas had given [him]108-edmund pain before — improvement in [his]108-edmund spirits . After wandering about and sitting under trees with [Fanny]113-fanny all the summer evenings , [he]101-sir thomas had so well talked [his]101-sir thomas mind into submission as to be very tolerably cheerful again . These were the circumstances and the hopes which gradually brought [their]3551-their alleviation to [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas , deadening [his]101-sir thomas sense of what was lost , and in part reconciling [him]101-sir thomas to [himself]101-sir thomas ; though the anguish arising from the conviction of [his]101-sir thomas own errors in the education of [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters was never to be entirely done away . Too late [he]101-sir thomas became aware how unfavourable to the character of [any young people]3553-any young people must be the totally opposite treatment which [Maria]126-maria and [Julia]112-julia had been always experiencing at [home]367-home , where the excessive indulgence and flattery of [[their]3555-their aunt]468-their aunt had been continually contrasted with [his]101-sir thomas own severity . [He]101-sir thomas saw how ill [he]101-sir thomas had judged , in expecting to counteract what was wrong in [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris by its reverse in [himself]101-sir thomas ; clearly saw that [he]101-sir thomas had but increased the evil by teaching [them]3555-their to repress [their]3555-their spirits in [his]101-sir thomas presence so as to make [their]3555-their real disposition unknown to [him]101-sir thomas , and sending [them]3555-their for all [their]3555-their indulgences to [a person who had been able to attach [them]3555-their only by the blindness of [her]105-mrs. norris affection , and the excess of [her]105-mrs. norris praise]3557-a person who had been able to attach them only by the blindness of her affection , and the excess of her praise . Here had been grievous mismanagement ; but , bad as it was , [he]101-sir thomas gradually grew to feel that it had not been the most direful mistake in [his]101-sir thomas plan of education . Something must have been wanting _ within _ , or time would have worn away much of its ill effect . [He]101-sir thomas feared that principle , active principle , had been wanting ; that [they]3555-their had never been properly taught to govern [their]3555-their inclinations and tempers by that sense of duty which can alone suffice . [They]3555-their had been instructed theoretically in [their]3555-their religion , but never required to bring it into daily practice . To be distinguished for elegance and accomplishments , the authorised object of [their]3555-their youth , could have had no useful influence that way , no moral effect on the mind . [He]101-sir thomas had meant [them]3555-their to be good , but [his]101-sir thomas cares had been directed to the understanding and manners , not the disposition ; and of the necessity of self - denial and humility , [he]101-sir thomas feared [they]3555-their had never heard from any lips that could profit [them]3555-their . Bitterly did [he]101-sir thomas deplore a deficiency which now [he]101-sir thomas could scarcely comprehend to have been possible . Wretchedly did [he]101-sir thomas feel , that with all the cost and care of an anxious and expensive education , [he]101-sir thomas had brought up [[his]101-sir thomas daughters]498-his daughters without [their]498-his daughters understanding [their]498-his daughters first duties , or [his]101-sir thomas being acquainted with [their]498-his daughters character and temper . The high spirit and strong passions of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , especially , were made known to [him]101-sir thomas only in [their]3555-their sad result . [She]126-maria was not to be prevailed on to leave [Mr. Crawford]133-mr. crawford . [She]126-maria hoped to marry [him]101-sir thomas , and [they]3555-their continued together till [she]126-maria was obliged to be convinced that such hope was vain , and till the disappointment and wretchedness arising from the conviction rendered [her]126-maria temper so bad , and [her]126-maria feelings for [him]101-sir thomas so like hatred , as to make them for a while each other ’s punishment , and then induce a voluntary separation . [She]126-maria had lived with [him]101-sir thomas to be reproached as the ruin of all [his]101-sir thomas happiness in [Fanny]113-fanny , and carried away no better consolation in leaving [him]101-sir thomas than that [she]126-maria _ had _ divided [them]3555-their . What can exceed the misery of such a mind in such a situation ? [Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny had no difficulty in procuring a divorce ; and so ended a marriage contracted under such circumstances as to make any better end the effect of good luck not to be reckoned on . [She]126-maria had despised [him]101-sir thomas , and loved [another]3373-another ; and [he]101-sir thomas had been very much aware that it was so . The indignities of stupidity , and the disappointments of selfish passion , can excite little pity . [His]101-sir thomas punishment followed [his]101-sir thomas conduct , as did a deeper punishment the deeper guilt of [[his]101-sir thomas wife]546-his wife . _ [He]101-sir thomas _ was released from the engagement to be mortified and unhappy , till [some other pretty girl]3561-some other pretty girl could attract [him]101-sir thomas into matrimony again , and [he]101-sir thomas might set forward on a second , and , it is to be hoped , more prosperous trial of the state : if duped , to be duped at least with good humour and good luck ; while [she]126-maria must withdraw with infinitely stronger feelings to a retirement and reproach which could allow no second spring of hope or character . Where [she]126-maria could be placed became a subject of most melancholy and momentous consultation . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris , whose attachment seemed to augment with the demerits of [[her]105-mrs. norris niece]642-her niece , would have had [her]126-maria received at [home]367-home and countenanced by [them]3564-them all . [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas would not hear of it ; and [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s anger against [Fanny]113-fanny was so much the greater , from considering _ [her]126-maria _ residence [there]3696-there as the motive . [She]105-mrs. norris persisted in placing [his]101-sir thomas scruples to _ [her]126-maria _ account , though [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas very solemnly assured [her]105-mrs. norris that , had there been [no young woman in question]3566-no young woman in question , had there been [no young person of either sex]3567-no young person of either sex belonging to [him]101-sir thomas , to be endangered by [the society]3568-the society or hurt by the character of [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , [he]101-sir thomas would never have offered so great an insult to [the neighbourhood]540-the neighbourhood as to expect it to notice [her]126-maria . As [a daughter]2535-a daughter , [he]101-sir thomas hoped [a penitent one]3571-a penitent one , [she]2535-a daughter should be protected by [him]101-sir thomas , and secured in every comfort , and supported by every encouragement to do right , which [their]3572-their relative situations admitted ; but farther than _ that _ [he]101-sir thomas could not go . [Maria]126-maria had destroyed [her]126-maria own character , and [he]101-sir thomas would not , by a vain attempt to restore what never could be restored , by affording [his]101-sir thomas sanction to vice , or in seeking to lessen its disgrace , be anywise accessory to introducing such misery in [[another man]3573-another man ’s family]3574-another man ’s family as [he]101-sir thomas had known [himself]101-sir thomas . It ended in [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s resolving to quit [Mansfield]130-mansfield and devote [herself]105-mrs. norris to [her]105-mrs. norris unfortunate [Maria]126-maria , and in an establishment being formed for [them]3572-their in [another country , remote and private]3575-another country , remote and private , where , shut up together with [little society]3576-little society , on one side no affection , on the other no judgment , it may be reasonably supposed that [their]3572-their tempers became [their]3572-their mutual punishment . [Mrs. Norris]105-mrs. norris ’s removal from [Mansfield]3-mansfield was the great supplementary comfort of [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s life . [His]101-sir thomas opinion of [her]105-mrs. norris had been sinking from the day of [his]101-sir thomas return from [Antigua]18-antigua : in every transaction together from that period , in [their]3572-their daily intercourse , in business , or in chat , [she]105-mrs. norris had been regularly losing ground in [his]101-sir thomas esteem , and convincing [him]101-sir thomas that either time had done [her]105-mrs. norris much disservice , or that [he]101-sir thomas had considerably over - rated [her]105-mrs. norris sense , and wonderfully borne with [her]105-mrs. norris manners before . [He]101-sir thomas had felt [her]105-mrs. norris as an hourly evil , which was so much the worse , as there seemed no chance of its ceasing but with life ; [she]105-mrs. norris seemed a part of [himself]101-sir thomas that must be borne for ever . To be relieved from [her]105-mrs. norris , therefore , was so great a felicity that , had [she]105-mrs. norris not left bitter remembrances behind [her]105-mrs. norris , there might have been danger of [his]101-sir thomas learning almost to approve the evil which produced such a good . [She]105-mrs. norris was regretted by [no one at]3577-no one at [Mansfield]3-mansfield . [She]105-mrs. norris had never been able to attach even those [she]105-mrs. norris loved best ; and since [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ’s elopement , [her]105-mrs. norris temper had been in a state of such irritation as to make [her]105-mrs. norris everywhere tormenting . Not even [Fanny]113-fanny had tears for [aunt Norris]105-mrs. norris , not even when [she]105-mrs. norris was gone for ever . That [Julia]112-julia escaped better than [Maria]126-maria was owing , in some measure , to a favourable difference of disposition and circumstance , but in a greater to [her]112-julia having been [less the darling of [that very aunt]3579-that very aunt]3578-less the darling of that very aunt , less flattered and less spoilt . [Her]105-mrs. norris beauty and acquirements had held but a second place . [She]105-mrs. norris had been always used to think [herself]105-mrs. norris a little inferior to [Maria]126-maria . [Her]105-mrs. norris temper was naturally the easiest of the two ; [her]105-mrs. norris feelings , though quick , were more controllable , and education had not given [her]105-mrs. norris so very hurtful a degree of self - consequence . [She]105-mrs. norris had submitted the best to the disappointment in [Henry Crawford]131-henry . After the first bitterness of the conviction of being slighted was over , [she]105-mrs. norris had been tolerably soon in a fair way of not thinking of [him]131-henry again ; and when the acquaintance was renewed in [town]3698-town , and [[Mr. Rushworth]113-fanny ’s house]3581-mr. rushworth ’s house became [Crawford]133-mr. crawford ’s object , [she]105-mrs. norris had had the merit of withdrawing [herself]105-mrs. norris from it , and of chusing that time to pay a visit to [[her]105-mrs. norris other friends]3582-her other friends , in order to secure [herself]105-mrs. norris from being again too much attracted . This had been [her]105-mrs. norris motive in going to [[her]105-mrs. norris cousin]3692-her cousin ’s . [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates ’s convenience had had nothing to do with it . [She]105-mrs. norris had been allowing [his]131-henry attentions some time , but with very little idea of ever accepting [him]131-henry ; and had not [[her]105-mrs. norris sister]331-her sister ’s conduct burst forth as it did , and [her]105-mrs. norris increased dread of [[her]105-mrs. norris father]667-her father and of [home]367-home , on that event , imagining its certain consequence to [herself]105-mrs. norris would be greater severity and restraint , made [her]105-mrs. norris hastily resolve on avoiding such immediate horrors at all risks , it is probable that [Mr. Yates]174-mr. yates would never have succeeded . [She]105-mrs. norris had not eloped with any worse feelings than those of selfish alarm . It had appeared to [her]105-mrs. norris the only thing to be done . [Maria]126-maria ’s guilt had induced [Julia]112-julia ’s folly . [Henry Crawford]131-henry , ruined by early independence and bad domestic example , indulged in the freaks of a cold - blooded vanity a little too long . Once it had , by an opening undesigned and unmerited , led [him]131-henry into the way of happiness . Could [he]131-henry have been satisfied with the conquest of [one amiable woman]3587-one amiable woman ’s affections , could [he]131-henry have found sufficient exultation in overcoming the reluctance , in working [himself]131-henry into the esteem and tenderness of [Fanny Price]113-fanny , there would have been every probability of success and felicity for [him]131-henry . [His]131-henry affection had already done something . [Her]105-mrs. norris influence over [him]131-henry had already given [him]131-henry some influence over [her]105-mrs. norris . Would [he]131-henry have deserved more , there can be no doubt that more would have been obtained , especially when that marriage had taken place , which would have given [him]131-henry the assistance of [her]105-mrs. norris conscience in subduing [her]105-mrs. norris first inclination , and brought [them]3588-them very often together . Would [he]131-henry have persevered , and uprightly , [Fanny]113-fanny must have been [his]131-henry reward , and a reward very voluntarily bestowed , within a reasonable period from [Edmund]108-edmund ’s marrying [Mary]132-mary . Had [he]131-henry done as [he]131-henry intended , and as [he]131-henry knew [he]131-henry ought , by going down to [Everingham]31-everingham after [his]131-henry return from [Portsmouth]7-portsmouth , [he]131-henry might have been deciding [his]131-henry own happy destiny . But [he]131-henry was pressed to stay for [Mrs. Fraser]254-mrs. fraser ’s party ; [his]131-henry staying was made of flattering consequence , and [he]131-henry was to meet [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria [there]3696-there . Curiosity and vanity were both engaged , and the temptation of immediate pleasure was too strong for a mind unused to make any sacrifice to right : [he]131-henry resolved to defer [his]131-henry Norfolk journey , resolved that writing should answer the purpose of it , or that its purpose was unimportant , and staid . [He]131-henry saw [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria , was received by [her]126-maria with a coldness which ought to have been repulsive , and have established apparent indifference between [them]3590-them for ever ; but [he]131-henry was mortified , [he]131-henry could not bear to be thrown off by [the woman whose smiles had been so wholly at [his]131-henry command]3591-the woman whose smiles had been so wholly at his command : [he]131-henry must exert [himself]131-henry to subdue so proud a display of resentment ; it was anger on [Fanny]113-fanny ’s account ; [he]131-henry must get the better of it , and make [Mrs. Rushworth Maria Bertram]126-maria again in [her]126-maria treatment of [himself]131-henry . In this spirit [he]131-henry began the attack , and by animated perseverance had soon re - established the sort of familiar intercourse , of gallantry , of flirtation , which bounded [his]131-henry views ; but in triumphing over the discretion which , though beginning in anger , might have saved [them]3590-them both , [he]131-henry had put [himself]131-henry in the power of feelings on [her]126-maria side more strong than [he]131-henry had supposed . [She]126-maria loved [him]131-henry ; there was no withdrawing attentions avowedly dear to [her]126-maria . [He]131-henry was entangled by [his]131-henry own vanity , with as little excuse of love as possible , and without the smallest inconstancy of mind towards [[her]126-maria cousin]3692-her cousin . To keep [Fanny]113-fanny and [the Bertrams]114-the miss bertrams from a knowledge of what was passing became [his]131-henry first object . [Secrecy]305-secrecy could not have been more desirable for [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria ’s credit than [he]131-henry felt it for [his]131-henry own . When [he]131-henry returned from [Richmond]96-richmond , [he]131-henry would have been glad to see [Mrs. Rushworth]126-maria no more . All that followed was the result of [her]126-maria imprudence ; and [he]131-henry went off with [her]126-maria at last , because [he]131-henry could not help it , regretting [Fanny]113-fanny even at the moment , but regretting [her]126-maria infinitely more when all the bustle of the intrigue was over , and a very few months had taught [him]131-henry , by the force of contrast , to place a yet higher value on the sweetness of [her]126-maria temper , the purity of [her]126-maria mind , and the excellence of [her]126-maria principles . That punishment , the public punishment of disgrace , should in a just measure attend _ [his]131-henry _ share of the offence is , [we]3593-we know , not one of the barriers which society gives to virtue . In [this world]3853-this world the penalty is less equal than could be wished ; but without presuming to look forward to a juster appointment hereafter , [we]3593-we may fairly consider [a man of sense]5621-a man of sense , like [Henry Crawford]131-henry , to be providing for [himself]5621-a man of sense no small portion of vexation and regret : vexation that must rise sometimes to self - reproach , and regret to wretchedness , in having so requited hospitality , so injured family peace , so forfeited [his]131-henry best , most estimable , and endeared acquaintance , and so lost [the woman whom [he]131-henry had rationally as well as passionately loved]3596-the woman whom he had rationally as well as passionately loved . After what had passed to wound and alienate [the two families]3825-the two families , the continuance of [the Bertrams]2891-the bertrams and Grants in [such close neighbourhood]3599-such close neighbourhood would have been most distressing ; but the absence of the latter , for some months purposely lengthened , ended very fortunately in the necessity , or at least the practicability , of a permanent removal . [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , through an interest on which [he]121-dr. grant had almost ceased to form hopes , succeeded to [a stall in [Westminster]32-westminster]3600-a stall in westminster , which , as affording an occasion for leaving [Mansfield]3-mansfield , an excuse for residence in [London]6-london , and an increase of income to answer the expenses of the change , was highly acceptable to those who went and [those who staid]3601-those who staid . [Mrs. Grant]123-mrs. grant , with a temper to love and be loved , must have gone with some regret from the scenes and people [she]123-mrs. grant had been used to ; but the same happiness of disposition must in any place , and any society , secure [her]123-mrs. grant a great deal to enjoy , and [she]123-mrs. grant had again a home to offer [Mary]132-mary ; and [Mary]132-mary had had enough of [[her]132-mary own friends]3602-her own friends , enough of vanity , ambition , love , and disappointment in the course of the last half - year , to be in need of the true kindness of [[her]132-mary sister]331-her sister ’s heart , and the rational tranquillity of [her]132-mary ways . [They]3604-they lived together ; and when [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant had brought on apoplexy and death , by three great institutionary dinners in one week , [they]3604-they still lived together ; for [Mary]132-mary , though perfectly resolved against ever attaching [herself]132-mary to [a younger brother]5235-a younger brother again , was long in finding among [the dashing representatives]3606-the dashing representatives , or [idle heir - apparents]3607-idle heir - apparents , who were at the command of [her]132-mary beauty , and [her]132-mary £ 20,000 , [any one who could satisfy the better taste [she]132-mary had acquired at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , whose character and manners could authorise a hope of the domestic happiness [she]132-mary had there learned to estimate , or put [Edmund Bertram]108-edmund sufficiently out of [her]132-mary head]3608-any one who could satisfy the better taste she had acquired at mansfield , whose character and manners could authorise a hope of the domestic happiness she had there learned to estimate , or put edmund bertram sufficiently out of her head . [Edmund]108-edmund had greatly the advantage of [her]132-mary in this respect . [He]108-edmund had not to wait and wish with vacant affections for [an object worthy to succeed [her]132-mary in [them]3610-them]3609-an object worthy to succeed her in them . Scarcely had [he]108-edmund done regretting [Mary Crawford]132-mary , and observing to [Fanny]113-fanny how impossible it was that [he]108-edmund should ever meet with [such another woman]3611-such another woman , before it began to strike [him]108-edmund whether [a very different kind of woman]3612-a very different kind of woman might not do just as well , or a great deal better : whether [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny were not growing as dear , as important to [him]108-edmund in all [her]132-mary smiles and all [her]132-mary ways , as [Mary Crawford]132-mary had ever been ; and whether it might not be a possible , a hopeful undertaking to persuade [her]132-mary that [her]132-mary warm and sisterly regard for [him]108-edmund would be foundation enough for wedded love . [I]0-i purposely abstain from dates on this occasion , that [every one]1239-every one may be at liberty to fix [their]1239-every one own , aware that the cure of unconquerable passions , and the transfer of unchanging attachments , must vary much as to time in [different people]3614-different people . [I]0-i only entreat [everybody]408-everybody to believe that exactly at the time when it was quite natural that it should be so , and not a week earlier , [Edmund]108-edmund did cease to care about [Miss Crawford]127-miss crawford , and became as anxious to marry [Fanny]113-fanny as [Fanny]113-fanny [herself]113-fanny could desire . With such a regard for [her]132-mary , indeed , as [his]108-edmund had long been , [a regard founded on the most endearing claims of innocence and helplessness , and completed by every recommendation of growing worth]3616-a regard founded on the most endearing claims of innocence and helplessness , and completed by every recommendation of growing worth , what could be more natural than the change ? Loving , guiding , protecting [her]132-mary , as [he]108-edmund had been doing ever since [her]132-mary being ten years old , [her]132-mary mind in so great a degree formed by [his]108-edmund care , and [her]132-mary comfort depending on [his]108-edmund kindness , an object to [him]108-edmund of such close and peculiar interest , dearer by all [his]108-edmund own importance with [her]132-mary than [any one else at Mansfield]3617-any one else at mansfield , what was there now to add , but that [he]108-edmund should learn to prefer soft light eyes to sparkling dark ones . And being always with [her]132-mary , and always talking confidentially , and [his]108-edmund feelings exactly in that favourable state which a recent disappointment gives , those soft light eyes could not be very long in obtaining the pre - eminence . Having once set out , and felt that [he]108-edmund had done so on this road to happiness , there was nothing on the side of prudence to stop [him]108-edmund or make [his]108-edmund progress slow ; no doubts of [her]132-mary deserving , no fears of opposition of taste , no need of drawing new hopes of happiness from dissimilarity of temper . [Her]132-mary mind , disposition , opinions , and habits wanted no half - concealment , no self - deception on the present , no reliance on future improvement . Even in the midst of [his]108-edmund late infatuation , [he]108-edmund had acknowledged [Fanny]113-fanny ’s mental superiority . What must be [his]108-edmund sense of it now , therefore ? [She]132-mary was of course only too good for [him]108-edmund ; but as [nobody]360-nobody minds having what is too good for [them]3619-them , [he]108-edmund was very steadily earnest in the pursuit of the blessing , and it was not possible that encouragement from [her]132-mary should be long wanting . Timid , anxious , doubting as [she]132-mary was , it was still impossible that such tenderness as [hers]132-mary should not , at times , hold out the strongest hope of success , though it remained for a later period to tell [him]108-edmund the whole delightful and astonishing truth . [His]108-edmund happiness in knowing [himself]108-edmund to have been so long the beloved of such a heart , must have been great enough to warrant any strength of language in which [he]108-edmund could clothe it to [her]132-mary or to [himself]108-edmund ; it must have been a delightful happiness . But there was happiness elsewhere which no description can reach . Let [no one]404-no one presume to give the feelings of [a young woman]843-a young woman on receiving the assurance of that affection of which [she]843-a young woman has scarcely allowed [herself]843-a young woman to entertain a hope . [Their]3619-them own inclinations ascertained , there were no difficulties behind , no drawback of poverty or [parent]3622-parent . It was a match which [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas ’s wishes had even forestalled . Sick of ambitious and mercenary connexions , prizing more and more the sterling good of principle and temper , and chiefly anxious to bind by the strongest securities all that remained to [him]108-edmund of domestic felicity , [he]108-edmund had pondered with genuine satisfaction on the more than possibility of [the two young friends]3623-the two young friends finding [their]3623-the two young friends natural consolation in [each other]681-each other for all that had occurred of disappointment to either ; and the joyful consent which met [Edmund]108-edmund ’s application , the high sense of having realised a great acquisition in the promise of [Fanny]113-fanny for [a daughter]2535-a daughter , formed just such a contrast with [his]108-edmund early opinion on the subject when [the poor little girl]3626-the poor little girl ’s coming had been first agitated , as time is for ever producing between the plans and decisions of [mortals]3627-mortals , for [their]3627-mortals own instruction , and [[their]3627-mortals neighbours]3628-their neighbours ’ entertainment . [Fanny]113-fanny was indeed [the daughter that [he]108-edmund wanted]3629-the daughter that he wanted . [His]108-edmund charitable kindness had been rearing a prime comfort for [himself]108-edmund . [His]108-edmund liberality had a rich repayment , and the general goodness of [his]108-edmund intentions by [her]3626-the poor little girl deserved it . [He]108-edmund might have made [her]3626-the poor little girl childhood happier ; but it had been an error of judgment only which had given [him]108-edmund the appearance of harshness , and deprived [him]108-edmund of [her]3626-the poor little girl early love ; and now , on really knowing [each other]681-each other , [their]3631-their mutual attachment became very strong . After settling [her]3626-the poor little girl at [Thornton Lacey]231-thornton lacey with every kind attention to [her]3626-the poor little girl comfort , the object of almost every day was to see [her]3626-the poor little girl [there]3696-there , or to get [her]3626-the poor little girl away from it . Selfishly dear as [she]3626-the poor little girl had long been to [Lady Bertram]106-lady bertram , [she]3626-the poor little girl could not be parted with willingly by _ [her]106-lady bertram _ . No happiness of [son]3633-son or [niece]3634-niece could make [her]3626-the poor little girl wish the marriage . But it was possible to part with [her]3626-the poor little girl , because [Susan]264-susan remained to supply [her]3626-the poor little girl place . [Susan]264-susan became [the stationary niece , delighted to be so]3635-the stationary niece , delighted to be so ; and equally well adapted for it by a readiness of mind , and an inclination for usefulness , as [Fanny]113-fanny had been by sweetness of temper , and strong feelings of gratitude . [Susan]264-susan could never be spared . First as a comfort to [Fanny]113-fanny , then as [an auxiliary]3636-an auxiliary , and last as [her]3626-the poor little girl substitute , [she]3626-the poor little girl was established at [Mansfield]3-mansfield , with every appearance of equal permanency . [Her]3626-the poor little girl more fearless disposition and happier nerves made everything easy to [her]3626-the poor little girl there . With quickness in understanding the tempers of those [she]3626-the poor little girl had to deal with , and no natural timidity to restrain any consequent wishes , [she]3626-the poor little girl was soon welcome and useful to [all]874-all ; and after [Fanny]113-fanny ’s removal succeeded so naturally to [her]3626-the poor little girl influence over the hourly comfort of [[her]3626-the poor little girl aunt]463-her aunt , as gradually to become , perhaps , [the most beloved of [the two]390-the two]3639-the most beloved of the two . In _ [her]3626-the poor little girl _ usefulness , in [Fanny]113-fanny ’s excellence , in [William]228-william ’s continued good conduct and rising fame , and in the general well - doing and success of [the other members of [the family]3724-the family]3641-the other members of the family , all assisting to advance [each other]681-each other , and doing credit to [his]228-william countenance and aid , [Sir Thomas]101-sir thomas saw repeated , and for ever repeated , reason to rejoice in what [he]228-william had done for [them]874-all all , and acknowledge the advantages of early hardship and discipline , and the consciousness of being born to struggle and endure . With so much true merit and true love , and no want of fortune and [friends]3751-friends , the happiness of [the married cousins]3645-the married cousins must appear as secure as earthly happiness can be . Equally formed for domestic life , and attached to country pleasures , [[their]3645-the married cousins home]855-their home was the home of affection and comfort ; and to complete the picture of good , the acquisition of [Mansfield]3-mansfield living , by the death of [Dr. Grant]121-dr. grant , occurred just after [they]3645-the married cousins had been married long enough to begin to want an increase of income , and feel [their]3645-the married cousins distance from [the paternal abode]3647-the paternal abode an inconvenience . On that event [they]3645-the married cousins removed to [Mansfield]3-mansfield ; and [the Parsonage]368-the parsonage [there]3696-there , which , under each of [[its]368-the parsonage two former owners]3650-its two former owners , [Fanny]113-fanny had never been able to approach but with some painful sensation of restraint or alarm , soon grew as dear to [her]3651-her heart , and as thoroughly perfect in [her]3651-her eyes , as everything else within the view and patronage of [Mansfield Park]130-mansfield had long been .
